Form support: "Hi , Thank you for choosing Promise Technology for your storage solutions. Unfortunately Mavericks is not compatible with the Pegasus J4 unit for now . Our engineering team is working on this issue and soon will there be an update on the same. We are sorry for the inconvenience ."* The unit has been discontinued. As it is not still being made, Promise has reduced incentive to provide support and update software for the existing unit.* Most 2.5" drives are not supported by the unit. Promise maintains a compatibility list that only has 22 drives on it, with no large SSDs among them. The largest supported SSD is 300GB. Searching other forums and reviews finds many users complaining that attempts to use other drives fails.Again, it's a shame. The unit is a wonderful concept. I would kill to have four SSDs in this form factor. But modern cheap 750GB and 1TB SSD drives are unsupported, and six months and counting on official Mavericks support utterly destroys trust in the Promise brand. That's downright disturbing for hardware that was released only two years ago.

This stuff smells extremely strong. When the cat uses it in the next room, I can tell the moment she starts digging. It's unpleasantly strong even 30 feet away. After a week of my cat digging less and less, eventually she wouldn't even try burying her mess anymore. She let it sit up atop the litter, presumably so she wouldn't have to smell the strong odor of the litter anymore.I switched away from this litter a month ago, and she's still afraid to bury litter anymore. Before using Fresh Step Multi Cat, she was extremely fastidious.If you've already ordered this, and if my box was representative of a normal batch, I recommend cutting it with regular litter to reduce the overpowering scent.

This is a fun toy. The iPhone app that controls it is a breeze to set up, and has a large number of options for playing with the color and intensity of the bulb. You can do more than choose the color and brightness - you can also tie it to music, and set up gradual hue changes.The bulb options can only be changed when the phone is near the bulb. There doesn't seem to be an internal long-term timer for any kind of automatic on/off at preset times when the phone user is away. Range is limited by Bluetooth, not wi-fi, so you can't use it from the far side of your home either. This is only a toy for playing with room lighting while you are present.The bulb simply isn't very bright, either. It's great for a small and intimate space. Don't expect to light a medium sized room with this. You'll want to put it in a separate bedside lamp or the like.I like it, and it feels like a taste of the kind of mechanisms that will be built into all home lighting decades from now. For now, it's a brilliant little experimental toy. If you're an iPhone nut and you're curious about the upcoming "Internet of Things," this may even be a must-have.

The look of this is absolutely great. In addition to being attractive, it has a satisfyingly hefty weight, and it's cool the way it folds flat for packing and storage. Unfortunately, it doesn't work as well as some of the more basic napkin holders.Rather than a weight that focuses on one small place in the center, as with most napkin holders, the holder has a bar that lays flat against much of the napkin when full. If one pulls upward and out, as one would with most napkin holders, the arm flips up and off the napkin. It needs to be moved back in place manually.If the napkin holder isn't full, the arm tends to move backward on its own, causing the stack of napkins to skew backward. It's unattractive. It also doesn't work as well once the arm moves back, as it grips only the back edge of the napkin. This often results in a second napkin to come out part-way when removing the topmost napkin.

Aesthetically okay, but these are not leather. They are faux letter, as indicated in the description. For some reason, this is allowed to be listed with a name that makes a false claim.It's a very thin faux leather veneer over what seems to be fragile cardboard. These will not take much handling, and will probably be even more sensitive to changing humidity than leather, and will be particularly susceptible to mold or other forms of rot if not kept in perfect storage conditions.

This popcorn pops up to a nice size, and the flavors are very evenly distributed. The taste of this isn't much different than the regular butter-and-salt versions. The "classic butter" and "sea salt" may be feel-good labeling more than anything else. But it's still a very tasty popcorn. It could perhaps use just a touch more butter.The cool thing about these is that the bags have a built in "bowl." By pulling the red cellophane-like plastic off, the bag unfolds into a self-standing serving bowl that's comfortable to hold, or to stand on a table. We enjoyed it for movie time. Getting the plastic off takes quite a bit more of a pull than you might guess. Be forceful, but be sure you're pulling in the right direction so you don't tear the bag.The only real down side is that the bag contains slightly less popcorn than some of the other bags. If you're using a microwave with an automatic popcorn setting, you may need to pull it out a few seconds early. The setting will probably assume a standard portion size. The first bag came away slightly burnt when this ran through a full automatic cycle. By taking the bags out when the microwave's automatic popcorn setting had 10 seconds left, these were just fine.

The speakers are surprisingly nice, given the small display. There isn't room-shaking bass by any means, but the low end isn't absent the way it normally is on small monitors.The video quality is nothing to write home about. It's a bit muddy, as if the video is pinned to something less than 24-bit color. The effect is most noticeable on flesh, which looks pasty. It has a wide color range regardless, and it has temperature customization as well as the familiar contrast and brightness settings. There are also some mpeg and digital noise reduction options that don't work as well as the counterparts on Sony TVs. There's some kind of edge enhancement filter that creates a sort of embossing effect even when it's disabled - the effect is more pronounced when it's set to "on." It's pronounced enough that you wouldn't want to use this as a PC display.My big problem is that the TV sometimes powers on with a problem where it plays TV static then silence, even when on an HDMI input. Powering off and back on again is the only thing that seems to bring audio back. The static is quite loud and sends my cat fleeing the room every time.

These are decent clamps at a good price. My only complaint is that they come with no lubrication whatsoever. It's necessary to oil or grease them up before use or you'll find you're shedding metal slivers as you use them.

Be sure to read the full details. The title says leather, then the description basically says "the title is a lie, it's faux leather."These are cardboard trays covered with some kind of very thin faux veneer. They will be damaged by humidity, stressing or bending much more rapidly than a product with real leather.

This is a great find for large dogs. But for cats, even the half gallon size is far too large.Half a gallon is 64 fluid ounces. Cats need 2-4 ounces a day. That means the half gallon size holds 16-32 days' worth of water for one cat. However, any cat water dish starts to look a bit funky and unpleasant after just a few days. Unless you have a huge number of cats sharing the waterer, or unless you absolutely need to leave the cats untended for a week, consider a smaller waterer.The construction of the thing feels sturdy. The built-in water filter is a nice touch as well. Unfortunately, the instructions don't tell one to remove the plastic from the filter brick (it's not obvious), and don't tell how to flush the filter before the first use. There also isn't any information on where to get replacement filters. You may find that you have to run without a filter after the first few months, and it wouldn't surprise me if many people were unknowingly running with the filter still covered.

The cats both like this brush, and so I occasionally brush their cheeks with it. It seems to evoke the familiar memories of mom's raspy tongue. But it's far too tiny to be effective as a general use cat brush.

This contains the famous graph of 80 successive pulses of PSR B1919+21, which was used as the cover of Joy Division's "Unknown Pleasures," as an illustration for the "The Nature of Pulsars" article. It is the first known print of this image. That makes this a pretty sound collectible.

This works well with 2012 iMacs. It operates with USB 3.0 devices, and it splits the higher current offered by USB 3.0 across ports, so you can operate multiple bus powered USB 1.x and USB 2.0 devices off of a single unpowered hub.The cord is long enough that you can comfortably mount this on the back stand of an iMac, avoiding any new front-visible desk clutter. The back side is flat and takes well to double-sided sticky tape, as does the aluminum on the iMac stand.

This was the perfect solution to high property taxesEver since I started wearing this around the neighborhood, property values have gone down. This has resulted in lower annual assessments, resulting in lower property taxes, resulting in my finally saving enough money for a matching horse head mask.Also popular at church.

These ship well, no problems at all. They aren't any different than what you get when you pick them up in the grocery store.These are geared toward kids, as you can imagine. The tomato sauce is almost more of a tomato syrup, and the pasta is very insubstantial. There's a surprisingly decent amount of meat.Unlike the Chef Boy-ar-dee variants, these don't have a pull ring on the top. If you don't have one where you plan to have these, your next Amazon purchase may be a nice can opener!

These are tasty and fun, very flavorful. They taste more like fruit than most regular gummy candies.Keep in mind that these are very small. Each little fruit piece is like a small gumdrop, smaller than a typical popped popcorn kernel. There are 10 of each flavor, for 50 total. That makes these fairly pricey, even as imports go!

It's a small container, but it lasts a long time. It's water based and safe with silicone toys. It doesn't dry out or get tacky after a few minutes like most others, so you don't need to replenish it or drown things. It also wipes up really easily without leaving detectible residue. It pretty much just feels like pre.This has a click-flip cap similar to some salad dressings, which makes it tough to mete out a consistent amount. Save the pump cap if you have one from another 8oz Spunk bottle. The caps are interchangeable.

This is by far the worst thing I've ever put in my mouth. That includes some bi-curious experimentation that ended poorly.Edit: Seriously, compare the other reviews on this to the other Sodastream flavors. This is uniquely horrible.

The cheesecake itself is absolutely delicious - spot on! The packaging is very convenient and these are shipped in a thick styrofoam cooler that should ensure that they arrive at a good temperature.The crust is a bit lifeless; hard and more sugary than flavorful. It could really stand a little extra butter or shortening. It's like they forgot the rest of it would be cheesecake and tried to make it a little healthy. That cost it one star, but the rest - yum!

Check the sizes if you're buying for price. These are smaller than the bottles you normally see in this form factor at the local grocery.These are the same great Heinz products you find in the local grocery. They ship well, as none of these are especially sensitive to temperature or rough handling. The smaller bottles are more convenient for keeping the whole set together in the refrigerator door or packing along for an outing or office use. They do all have a squeeze cap, with the relish opening being a bit wider than the other two. They make rude noises, but no mess!

Terra Exotic Veggie Chips are delicious, more interesting than standard potato chips and there's a variety to the crispiness. In the other reviews, some users don't like this, but it's inherent in there being different types of food.As a word of caution: These are a major heartburn trigger for some people. Personally, I have no problems with potato chips, fatty foods, chocolate, caffeine, pasta sauces or any of the other common trigger foods. But one serving of these and an hour later I'm miserable without some Pepto or Tums. Looking to internet forums, I found that these cause problems for others too. Like me, it took others a while to connect these with the problem, as they have a healthy image. At the end of the day though, they are still fried chips.Try a single bag before committing to a bulk purchase.

The dog tag concept is nice, but the execution isn't professional. The text is sealed inside a sticker, but has the look of regular inkjet printer output. The sticker comes unpeeled easily when warmed from body heat. The back scratches very easily, and the hole is too small for a regular keyring. This would not make a good keychain as advertised, but it's probably okay as a pendant.

All six pins arrived via US Post. They're decent quality and individually wrapped. One could carry a pocketful of these around and give them away - I'm tempted to get a few more orders and distribute them at political events.The paint is a little imprecise, but I only notice this on very close examination. From more than a few inches away, they look great. Impressively, the blue portion is painted all around the 50 unpainted stars, which stand out as gold. This is preferable to white on a small piece of jewelry like this, as the reflective metal catches the light. It's a lightweight metal, and the weight is hardly noticed when worn. Although they are light, they are still sturdy. I tried to bend one with enough force to hurt my thumb, and it didn't give at all.The pin on the back is similar to other pin backs: Two leafs that catch a notch around the pin, and the leafs release when both are squeezed. This is easy to put on, and isn't likely to come loose accidentally.

This works as described. Once configured, one can launch an iPhone app to turn lights and appliances on and off, and one can set scheduled on and off times.PRO* Works, and there are few alternatives* Option to set one-way transition times, ex. always off at 10pm, but never automatically on* Can apply schedules to one or more specific days of the week* Firmware is updatable, so Belkin can add/fix features* Works seamlessly with multiple iPhone/iPod Touch/iPads, though this is not advertised* Supports WEP and WPA2 encrypted networksCON* Setup was unreliable, took multiple attempts at the identical procedure* WiFi range is poor (may rely on appliance cord as antenna? Setup never completed without errors until I plugged in my lamp)* App is flaky during setup - will pop up a dialog saying an error occurred, then proceed to a "success" screen despite not working* No documentation included. Should have a sheet with troubleshooting, wattage limits, explanation of buttons, etc at the least.* App is slow to start up - can take several seconds to find switches each time it's launched* Uses one plug, encroaches on remaining plug space. It doesn't cover the outlet, but there's not enough room for most other appliance cords* Wide. In addition to encroaching on remaining plug space, it's too wide for side-by-side outlets as with 4-plug panels or plug multipliers* No security beyond network participation. Anyone on the local network can control all appliances and edit schedules.

The good: This is as precise as you would expect from a Wacom input device. Having a mouse that's designed for the tablet surface is convenient; there's no worry of scratching your Wacom when using a device designed for that surface. It also works with later version mice. Wacom removed the "Intuos4" portion of the product name for this same model when they released the Intuos5 tablet.The bad: The scroll wheel is slippery. There's no ribbing or coarse surface as with other scroll wheels, but there's enough resistance that it doesn't move easily. It's made of a very slick and only slightly rubbery plastic. I frequently have to lick my finger in order to prevent my finger from merely sliding over the mouse wheel, or I have to constantly bear down a bit and risk misclicks. I've given serious thought to trying to score the surface with a razor blade in order to give it more of a grip, but I may still return the thing so I can't do that yet.The scroll wheel jumps in coarse clicks. I would guess that there are only 16 or so clicks for a full rotation. This means the wheel has to be set to be very slow with lots and lots of spinning to move, or one has to live with scrolling pages 1/4 of a screen at a jump.The ergonomics are bad for any but the tiniest hands. The mouse is not as long as a typical mouse - if you've used a notebook "travel mouse," you know how that feels. This one is also taller than typical mice, giving it an almost ball-like shape in your hand. It has an unusual downward slope toward the buttons. I've got hands that are only slightly larger than average, yet I have to contort my hand like I'm posing for some kind of kung fu "eagle talon" move in order to rest my fingers on the buttons and scroll wheel. This thing makes my hand ache. I'd love to see one with a profile more like Apple's wireless mice.The verdict: I'll probably send it back and get felt feet for an existing mouse, or try to get used to the Intuos5 touch input.

These are standard dill pickles with no frilly seasonings or unusual character added. They're a good size, each one a satisfying hand size. They're decent for a pickle purist.Unfortunately, they simply aren't made to ship. These have little protection, and even a slight squeeze causes the packages to leak. Temperature and air pressure changes mean that you're likely to receive a wet box, an unhappy driver and, if you use slow shipping, several spoiled pickles. I love Amazon and buy most everything here, but these are better purchased locally.

If you only need to read Blu-Ray media, this is a cheap, workable solution. It works well with Windows, Mac and Linux with appropriate software. It does require two USB ports in order to provide power, unless you purchase a separate power adapter. This is common for external optical media drives.The unit has an exceptionally cheap feel to it. The plastic case is a flimsy, yielding plastic that you would more expect from a Happy Meal toy than a computer peripheral, but it does its job. Just don't stack anything on it. The tiniest bit of pressure on the top is enough to flex the case and grind against the spinning media.The trouble comes in with older CDs and DVDs. The overhead space for media in the drive is ridiculously low. If you have media that's even a fraction of a milimeter thicker than normal, as happens with adhesive labels or some older multi-color screen printed CDs and DVDs, they'll actually scrape against the internal surface of the unit, either refusing to play or producing too many errors for playback. Even the adhesive hubs that you'll find on Netflix rental DVDs can add too much to the height of the DVD for playback. You actually have to peel these off before some titles play.I give the unit three stars because it offers a fully working Blu-Ray drive at a very low price. However, this would be a poor choice of general purpose drive.

The quality of the printed study content varies significantly. Much of it is spot on; it's up to date and relevant. However, the author often drops into explaining basics that shouldn't be necessary for any computer professional. At other times, the author seems to state opinions and speculation as fact. The book desperately needs review from a technical editor. Much of the content could be excised in order to make a much, much smaller and more focussed book.The practice exam content is good. Many would do well to purchase that and decide whether they need the remaining content, or whether this set is the best source of that material.Some of the advertised study content is completely missing from the CD. What's present is difficult to use if you aren't using Windows, as the primary navigation tools are Windows executables. (Really? For platform-neutral content? In 2011?)All in all, the set seems to have been assembled rather ad hoc, and bulked up with unnecessary material that doesn't justify the list price.

This beautiful blue barrel has finally got me back in the game. I'm pumpin' like I've never pumped before. But where's the "Amazon Subscribe and Save" option? I'm SICK of having to remember to re-up my supply each month.

With a person on the scale, this unit can take far too long to settle. The number jumps up and down a pound or three at length before it finally announces a number. Unless you're very light or have exceptional stability, this can take as much as a minute of trying to stand still.The packaging claims that this is accurate to within a tenth of a pound, but that doesn't match my experience. Setting a fixed weight on it will return different values with each subsequent weighing. I put two 60lb dumbbells on the scale, and the reported weight was sometimes as low as 118.5, and as high as 121.3. In half a dozen weighings, that's 2.8lbs variance on a fixed weight! At least with the non-moving dumbbells, it was able to announce a number in five seconds instead of a minute.The announcement voice is also incredibly loud, really more shouting weights in a grainy voice than announcing them. After the tests above, I tried taping a paper napkin over the speaker. That helped quite a bit, making the voice sound clearer and more natural, though still quite loud.

With liquid diet shakes like Atkins or Medifast, one may have trouble maintaining proper bowel movements. This can mean many extra visits to the toilet, or plenty of extra wiping and developing the itchiness that accompanies that much skin abrasion. A few of these with every diet shake makes all the difference in the world.Except at very low doses, there will be a small increase in flatulence. This will be true of any soluble fiber product. This is less of a concern when one isn't producing liquid stools anymore, however.

The Track ListThis review is for the COMPLETE score, which is currently not available ANYWHERE to my knowledge, but is the ideal way to hear this score (naturally). For reference, after seeing the film in the theater twice, I believe the correct chronological order of the music to be:OvertureThe GridFather and SonThe Son of FlynnEncom Part IEncom Part IIRecognizerArmoryArenaRound OneRinzlerThe Game Has ChangedOutlandsFather and SonAdagio For TronNocturneOutlands, Part IIReflectionsEnd Of LineCastorDerezzedFallSea of SimulationRectifierDisc WarsC.L.U.ArrivalFlynn LivesSunrise PreludeTron Legacy (End Titles)Solar SailerFinaleThe PiecesOverture is a mix of electronic and orchestra, and is not used in the film. It is the main theme of the film which is used many times and is a perfect overture.The Grid is very similar to Overture, but features a build-up and voice-over by Jeff Bridges. Normally I don't care for voice-overs...but this one is awesome.Father and Son is a slower version of the main main theme. Beautiful.The Son of Flynn is an electronic piece that sounds more like a Daft Punk song, building upon its own electronic themes. Great.Encom Part I and II are atmospheric film music which are uniformly excellent and a nice break after the faster paced The Son of Flynn.Recognizer is the awesome music you remember from the Tron Legacy Trailer, a sinister foreboding piece that gradually builds upon itself to become an epic awesome musical masterpiece evoking appropriate awe and wonder of the first glimpse of a world only previously imagined.Armory is a slow down-beat piece played while Sam is being suited up to fight in the games, it's one of my favorite tracks. Slow, methodical, and beautiful.Arena, Round One, and Rinzler are all battle music from the games and to me are similar in feel. They are more brash, harsh, loud, and lively than more of the other tracks, featuring a lot of digital distortion. Still good though.The Game Has Changed is another one of the best tracks, featured during the light-cycle battle. Show-down music. Great stuff.Outlands Part I and II is atmospheric music to evoke the landscape of the digital world, and is similar to something John Williams or James Newton Howard would use in Hook or Peter Pan. Another of my favorites, though both pieces are very similar, almost to the point of being one piece.Adagio For Tron is slow piece that builds in in sad gravity like Chopin piece, as it describes Flynn's creation of the new Grid, and how it was then corrupted and filled with tragedy by his creation C.L.U.Nocturne is another of my favorites, mostly because it reminds me of Nightvision from Discovery. It's slow, sad, and sweet. I love it.Reflections is basically the start of the theme from C.L.U., and thus is part of the theme of that character. Dark and sinister starting with strings and then moving into electronic sounds.End of Line, Castor, and Derezzed are all club music from the End of Line club. The first is industrial sounding, the second is more rave-type club music (more upbeat, with a cut-out seconds after it starts). Derezzed is arguably the best "Daft-Punk style" track on the score, with infectious beats and addictive electronic stylings that will make you want to listen to it over and over. A perfect piece of music for a stylized fight. Fantastic.Fall is an appropriate piece of music played during a quick crisis in the film, a piece that gets the heart rate up quick. I don't care for the electronic distortion on this track as it distracts from the main musical theme played.Sea of Simulation is another slower paced piece that sounds very Daft-Punkish in tone. Soothing and slow, it's the music from the journey on the solar sailor. Another favorite.Rectifier. Sinister villain music of threatening imminent demise. CodeMaster Talon told me it reminds her of Captain Hook's Theme from Hook. Appropriate music. A good track if you like Zaibach from the Vision of Escaflowne soundtrack or One Winged Angel from Final Fantasy VII.Disc Wars is a piece full of determination which builds on itself. Less brash than the arena battle music, it is nonetheless appropriate battle music. Excellent.C.L.U. is naturally the villains' main theme and an excellent sweeping sinister piece which builds upon itself going from sinister to contemplative to urgent, blending the best of Reflections and Fall. Outstanding.Arrival is your brief breather before the epic finale. It's the music played when our heroes finally arrive at their destination and there is a spiritual tint to the piece as it goes from light and angelic to heavy and mortal. Gates of Valhalla music. Brilliant.Flynn Lives is by far the best piece of music in the entire score. It is the epic climax music which uses Wagnerian string and horn motifs for brilliant dramatic effect. This piece literally makes the final showdown of the movie what it is. There are no words to describe how brilliant and awesome this piece is. Academy Award material if I ever heard it. The main Tron Legacy theme is used to its maximum potential.Sunrise Prelude is....gorgeous. It combines the slow beautiful beats of the style of Encom, Armory, or Nocturne with the slow orchestral beauty that comes later from the finale. It's the last track in the movie and being at once sad, dramatic, romantic, and achingly beautiful... is absolutely perfect.Tron Legacy (End Titles) is perfect ending credits music. It's an electronic, upbeat, catchy, fantastic remix of the main Tron Legacy Theme from Overture, The Grid, ect.Solar Sailer is another slower paced electronic piece similar to Sea of Simulation (and goes quite well together with it). Not my favorite track as it's just not progressive enough in its melody for my taste, but it's a favorite track for many people (including my girlfriend).Finale is the Sunrise Prelude (only orchestra with no electronic sounds) which morphs into the main Tron Legacy theme with carefully chosen electronic instrumentation. After a somewhat rousing main theme is quietly takes its leave like the last star of night under the light of day. An wonderful finale to a fantastic score.The ScoreTron Legacy has one of the greatest musical scores in film history, easily on par with the best of John Williams, James Horner, and perhaps even the revered Ennio Morricone. It's THAT good. And this coming from me, a person who pretty much only listens to video game music, J-pop, and most of all, TONS of orchestral scores for TV shows and films (you would think Silva Screen Records is on speed-dial and City of Prague Philharmonic Orchestra as my homepage for all the music I have from everything from El Cid to The Last Starfighter).The first Tron had a very unique musical score that was largely made-up of electronic sounds, resulting a very appropriate computerized feel. When I heard that Daft Punk would be creating the score for Tron Legacy, I didn't know WHAT to think. On the one hand, I was a huge fan of Daft Punk's album discovery (check out my spotlight review on Amazon if you don't believe me). And on the other hand...there was just so much potential to get everything wrong and ruin the score by producing something that didn't fit with the vibe of the new film and the original. Hence, I tried to keep an open mind and not set my expectations too high so as not to be disappointed. I needn't have worried.Some have said that the score needs to stand on its own, and is best heard separate from the film. I couldn't disagree more. A ballet is meant to be watched, an opera is meant to be watched, and a film score is meant to be watched. When you see the film Tron Legacy the music fuels everything on-screen. The film was actually cut to the music, resulting the movie feeling very much like an awesome long music video. From the opening notes and title of the film to the epic climax at its finish, I highly recommend seeing the film to fully enjoy the music. That said...This score manages to perfectly capture the feel of the world of Tron, simultaneously paying tribute to the past while being completely fresh and new (I have heard the score to the original Tron and could not find any copied musical cues whatsoever). Rest assured, the themes in this score are brand new, yet totally appropriate. Sometimes the music is completely electronic, sometimes it is completely orchestral, many times it is a mixture of both, but it is always excellent.Too Many Adagios?It appears that most of the negative reviews of this score are from people who were expecting another Daft Punk album. In case you haven't guessed it yet, this is not an album like Discovery. Not even close. There are no words to any of the songs, and they were designed for a film, not a dance club. While some of the tracks certainly are brilliant in a very similar way to Daft Punk's past work (Derezzed and other tracks like End of Line and Castor), primarily this score succeeds as what it was designed to be. A film score.Some have commented that the score to Tron Legacy is similar to other scores, and this is true. It may at times remind you of Mass Effect (with its heavy synthesizer use) or Inception (with its heavy two-tone use) but that is very unfair. This score blows Inception's score out of the water in every way. I had thought Inception had the best score of the year until I saw Tron Legacy, but it feel incredibly repetitive and unimaginative in comparison. And Mass Effects themes are not nearly as dynamic, full, or original in comparison (the tracks on Mass Effect are also very short).Flynn Lives, And So Does Daft Punk's Greatest AchievementWhen I heard the track Flynn lives I thought of the finale to an Ennio Morricone score like The Good The Bad And The Ugly where a soaring vocal would not be inappropriate. The main theme is simply that strong, that beautiful, that good. Honestly, this score belongs with the best of the best, and deserves to be listened to along with the best of great film composers of the last 30 years (Williams, Silvestri, Powell, Horner, Goldsmith).It would be absolutely criminal if this score does not win an Academy Award. If you are a fan of film music you owe it to yourself to purchase the score immediately. Just be sure you get the complete score and listen to it in the proper order, and see the film at least once to experience the music the way it was meant to be.Special note on the LP edition of the score:This is the most complete version of the score available to my knowledge. While the tracks are not in chronological order, there is only one track missing. Ironically it is one of my favorite tracks and the one I listen to the most, Father and Son. This is especially irritating as this is a Disney album and Disney and Apple are very close partners, yet this is an iTunes exclusive track. Its absence is absolutely idiotic in this otherwise complete album.Also, the beautiful album notes on a sheet of paper inside of the album rather than on the record sleeves, and there is no digital download or other extras included with this LP.Musically, the LP version of this album is practically identical to the MP3/CD release versions, however the digital and orchestral parts of the soundtrack blend together slightly better (the digital sounds are less sharp), and the bass is greatly reduced. The bass from the MP3 shakes the foundations when I play the Overture, but is nearly unnoticeable on the LP. I own both and consider both an essential purchase.

I saw this show listed on Netflix for a while, and had meant to give it a try. My wife watched a bit of the first episode and told me it wasn't very good, so I avoided watching it for a while. Then a good friend came over and told us that we HAD to watch this show, because it was so good. I was intrigued, and willing to give the show a chance.I saw the first few minutes and thought it was a poorly animated, low-budget, generic show not really worth my time. But I'm open minded and patient, so I continued to watch the show. And as the show went on, I was shocked.Everything a Teen-Aged Super-Powered Show Should BeI've seen a lot of anime and cartoons in my time, and watched a lot of teen-aged super-hero stuff. Heck I'm even trying to write a superhero academy story myself (but that's another story). So when I tell you that this is the best story of this type I have ever seen, try to comprehend how many shows were inferior. Why is this show so good, and why does it rise to the top of the crowd of shows in this genre?Welcome to Beacon AcademyThe world of this show is one filled with evil monsters and defended by super-powered "Hunters". They get their powers from "dust", and naturally they all go to superhero school to learn how to do this.Shows of this type tend to have lousy voice acting, superficial stories, flat characters, and be incredibly generic (generally failing to tell a story that feels compelling or involving) and certainly at this point we have all seen so many similar superheroes that every new superhero starts to feel incredibly generic (or even worse, yet ANOTHER interpretation of an old character without any of the charm or awesome backstory that made it a good character in the first place). That's what makes this show so refreshing. It isn't afraid to pile on the homages, the archetypes, the action and the drama, but at the same time there's an absolutely delicious blend of charm, wit, and innocence that's reminiscent of the very very stories ever told. You don't like these characters because they remind of something you used to like. You like these characters because although they are borrowed from classic fairy tale, anime, and comic book tropes, they make them all their own.Homages or Rip-Offs, Stereotypes or Archetypes? A show or a movie?Unlike seemingly EVERY other person writing reviews for this show (and liking it) I have NEVER watched anything by Rooster Teeth, nor had I ever even heard of them before now. I have never heard of the show's creator (I am sorry he died though). So all I can go off of is what I find as I watch the show. There are homages galore on this show. There is a main character who looks like Little Red Riding Hood, a girl whose bow looks like cat ears, a battle maiden robot, and a dog whose name is a number in German. These are no rip-offs. They are shout outs.Every one of the main characters has a personality and backstory that you can see coming from a mile away. That does not, however change the fact that the characters are very well done and extremely likable. Their personality is thoroughly developed and very charming. Honestly, I think a lot of the people who complain about the characters simply don't understand the subtleties of this show. If character development is told through expression, though the food the character eats, and through the music that plays during scenes, this is not a sign of a poorly made show. It is simply the sign of one that has an introverted undertone that rewards persistence and determination, rather than exposition-bubble spelling-out of everything that many Americans are used to.I didn't watch this show in the manner it was originally produced (a series of short episodes), but rather as two movies. While everyone seems to be complaining that the "series" isn't non-stop fight sequences, for a MOVIE, the pacing is just about perfect. There's action, romance, character development, and lots, and lots, and LOTS of character interaction that builds the world of the show and is incredibly enjoyable.The styleGetting to the style of the show, while it certainly is low-budget (lack of detail on background characters in the first season), it is also very stylized, reminding my of some of the better cell-shaded polygons of some video games famous for their art style. It certainly won't wow for accuracy of physics when you look at the characters' walking movements (they kind of "float"), but the emotion expressed in the main characters is fantastic, and the fights certainly do wow.The SincerityMy friend observed quickly while watching the show that while a monster was clearly decapitated, instead of a fountain of blood there were "flutters" or red rose petals. In the course of two seasons, I can't recall hearing a single swear word. My immediate reaction was one of confusion. Is this supposed to be a show for kids? The main protagonist is a young teen, so...maybe? But wait, everyone else is an older teen. The jokes and plot and structure of the show seem geared toward an older audience. But then...why no swearing and gore?This is no flaw, in fact it's incredibly charming. All of the characters, and especially Ruby, are so incredibly sincere in everything they say and do, that it's impossible not to quickly fall in love with them. I quickly realized there was not a single main character I didn't like, and that's something I don't think has ever happened for me in any show I've ever seen. This is the real reason why this show is so good. You want to believe in the characters and are rooting for them all the way.Why things will changeForget about the great action, the low-budget beautifully-styled animation, and the fairy-tale monster-hunter trappings. What you have left is a the best thing since Sailor Moon and My Little Pony:Friendship is Magic. It's a show about young girls with a distinct personality, a strong mission in life, a quest of personal discovery, and wonderful interaction with each other. It isn't stereotypical. It's downright revolutionary in today's culture.If anyone says these characters are flat and one-dimensional, I'm sorry, but they just don't get it. These characters are portrayed from the heart, and they constantly surprise you with things they say and do, and new dimensions of their personality. They learn, and grow. The ice queen realizes she needs to re-examine her view of life. The dragon protagonist intuitively comes to realize she needs to take charge. The goofball clueless idiot comes through in the aid of others. And the catgirl learns to trust and rely on her friends and deal with her past while the older sister digs into her own.This show is a reconstruction of American animation and the magical-girl/high school girls/teen super-hero genres, and I KNOW that it is going to influence the future animation, particularly in the United States. The world needs more shows like this, and it's a massive breath of fresh air. I cannot wait for the third season. As it is...it's difficult not to get even more drawn in than I already am.This show is not to be missed by anyone who appreciates anime, or any kind of animation in general. Just watch more than the first episode, as the first episode is NOT a good representation of the overall quality of the show.P.S. The floaty cartoon physics remind me of Reboot!

I bought this cable to output from a switchbox for an Xbox 360 and a Desktop PC. I purchased this cable because I've used AmazonBasics cables before and the quality has always been solid, and I didn't want to take chances on a generic cable.This cable is high quality, braided and shielded, with crystal clear picture. It's quality-built in every way. If you need a cable that requires better quality (like connecting a swtichbox to a home theater like I'm doing), this is an excellent choice.

I've had bad experiences in the past with VGA switches, as I'm sure many others have. Ghosting, fuzzy image, various kinds of EMI (electromagnetic interference). So I was willing to pay a few dollars more for quality this time around.I'm using this box to switch a Desktop PC and Xbox 360 into a 720p projector, and the picture quality is perfect. No ghosting. No fuzziness. Just crystal clear perfect quality. Usually a passive switch (unpowered) has problems detecting image sources and resolutions, but this is not the case here. I'm able to run my 360 and my PC at completely different resolutions, and so far the resolution has not reset and there have been no problems detecting image sources.The switch may eventually wear out but for this price it's perfect considering the image quality. I cant comment on the sound switching as I am using a stereo receiver for that function.

I bought this game a while back but only got to play it yesterday for the first time, because it requires three players and we always only had two, and the rules are pretty complicated (perhaps overly so). Just the same, when we finally got to play it...If you are familiar with say, Libertalia or Jamaica, you will understand the main gameplay mechanic of a day and night action, and if you ever played Monopoly (who hasn't?) you shouldn't have TOO much trouble with the buying and selling pieces.The game board is beautiful, but not really big enough to accommodate the cards for the wrecks. Likewise, there is detailed art for the divers, but I'm not of most of them because they're so mean looking. All the monsters look the same. The pieces are very high quality. The personal deck cards for players have cards that looks almost identical for the market where you sell and the equipment shop where you buy, resulting in my accidentally using the wrong card for an action. Similarly, people kept getting goods, gold, and artifacts confused because the cards look too similar. The rule book is at once over-complicated and lacking in detail on important topics. Some parts of gameplay are explained over and over, and you are STILL confused about where or not you can send multiple divers to the same wreck, or how it gets decided who goes to a wreck first (since you all move your ship at the same time). At the end of the game when there were only two wrecks left, the last player of three could do nothing because the other two players had already claimed wrecks (frustrating).People have said in other reviews that there is no backstabbing in this game, but I did not find this to be the case. Often other players KNOW where the good treasure with no monsters are, and when someone jumps in with two divers and drops a weight each, they clean the deck out before another player gets their turn. Likewise, it is REALLY irritating when you need ONE piece of equipment but can't buy it because another player is at the equipment shop and the price is now ten dollars more than you have. Playing this game, it was obvious to me that I was going to lose, because I had no idea that shallow wrecks had no monsters and contained far less valuable loot than deep wrecks until very late in the game. This could have been made clear in the instructions.All in all, this IS a fun game, and it has wonderful artwork and theme. I do think the game could be improved by a bigger board with dedicated spaces for wrecks, re-written rules. and better artwork for the player cards and monster cards (with different effects than just LOSE YOUR DIVER). I would love it if there were say, minor monsters, mid-level monsters, and big monsters that required bigger weapons to defeat and had bigger effects on the player. If this game ever gets a new edition with changes like this I would buy it for sure. In the meantime, it was a good fun game, but it's certainly more complicated than Jamaica (my father kept calculating the math for his sales wrong), but a lot more fun than Monopoly.

I've tried a lot of protein powders in recent memory, but I've come to the conclusion that there's really only one brand that you need. I gave this one a shot, and it's not terrible (mixes well, decent taste), but it has a slight chemical taste (probably from the artificial flavor). It has a good ratio of protein to sugar, but not the best I've seen.All in all, it's a decent product, but not recommended. I stand by my old recommendation for the King of Protein Powders, Jarrow. Jarrow has NO artificial flavors or sweeteners, mixes and tastes better than anything I've ever tried, and make you feel great after you consume it.On the plus side for this protein, it comes in a nice container with the scoop on the top, not buried at the bottom.

Judging by the description of this novel, it sounds like a lot of fun. But once you actually start reading, you find that a lack of writing skill makes a story that should be exciting drag instead. For starters, for being set in SPACE the description is not very interesting. You never feel like you are THERE. Space lends itself to stark writing with bite, or beautiful poetry, but you'll find neither here. Likewise sci-fi is often the realm of kooky teams of heroes or extreme isolation and introspection, but instead there's just...nothing. I feel nothing for these characters. They have no personality. I don't know them, I don't care about them. The space location is boring. The computer tech doesn't sound particularly brilliant, or even particularly bright, more just weird and delusional (but she lacks enough description or internal monolog to even be annoying).Don't get me wrong, I enjoy a variety of sci-fi. I'll read the fantasy epics of Brandon Sanderson, the dry hard sci-fi of Isaac Asimov (where plot is king), and the adventures of Anne McCaffrey with their heavy characterization. This book isn't awful. It just really isn't very good. It needed to be rewritten with some character and description, and then re-written again.

Up until now my favorite Daft Punk album has been the amazing Discovery, but this album is so good it gives it a run for its money. While most convert albums suffer a bit from the "noise" of the crowd's cheers, in this case they actually add to the experience rather than distracting.Discovery was a sweet box of evolving melodies, but this is a driving, thrumming, buzzing beat box of awesome! I always loved how the melodies of Discovery melded into each other, making you want to listen to the entire album. This is a series of Daft Punk's best songs mixed together perfectly with enough wonderous glorious bass to benchmark any speaker system.If I have a single complaint, it's the that the Close Encounters of the Third Kind opening is missing from the audio recording, and should be included. Other than that, listen to this and enjoy. It's awesome music for just listening, but it's REALLY great for exercise, doing chores, or (obviously) having a dance party. Highly, HIGHLY recommended.Final note: If you have a record player the complete Alive Boxed Set is totally worth it as it includes a backstage pass, stickers, bonus tracks, a turntable pad, and a gorgeous art book.

I'm a big fan of giant robot anime and a love Saturn games that combine 2D and 3D. This game is a perfect blend. While your ship/robot is 2D sprites the enemies and level are in 3D. There's horrible draw-in but I don't mind a bit because there's a super helpful radar, perfectly designed levels, and absolutely gorgeous high-speed graphics.The game has it's main menu in English but the controls and mission briefings are in Japanese. This isn't a problem because the objectives are straightforward and the controls can be figured out in a minute or three.I've played a lot of games like this over the years (robot war-machines fighting in cities) but this is the most anime-like of any of them, with the best controls, the best graphics, and the most fun gameplay by far.If you love Saturn action games and especially if you love giant robot anime you are going to love this game. It is worth the high price.

I've played a lot of board games in the past few years, and as part of my research I've watched a lot of online top lists and board game reviews. This game kept showing up at the very top of the game lists, so I've been wanting to play it for years. The only thing that has held me back is the relatively high price that just wouldn't come down. Then I got a chance to get a copy for around 35 bucks and knew I had to grab it.If you've played Libertalia, you'll understand the concept of morning and evening actions, and if you've played Formula D, you'll understand planning your dice rolls and playing the odds to get further ahead, else crashing and burning. But even if you haven't, this game is NOT as complicated as it may look at first, despite game mechanics seemingly copied from everywhere.Every player has a deck of cards, and each "round" a "captain" is appointed who rolls the dice and sets the dice in the order of his choosing (a bit like the Godfather of Cash N' Guns). Each player resolves their morning and evening action after flipping over their selected card (Libertalia), placing resources into their ship's hold. You move your ship and pay the cost of spaces (Monopoly). When ships occupy the same space space they fight (Formula D Danger Dice). First one to pass the finish line ends the game, and everyone else finishes the round (Splendor) adding up their victory points which are a combination of treasure chests, gold coins, and board position.Great, great, but is it any fun?I have played this game ONCE, using five players. I immediately fell in love. The instructions, board, and pieces are absolutely fantastic. The theme is glorious as is the artwork and build quality. Gameplay moves quickly, and there is plenty of room for rivalry. More than that, this game is incredibly fun to play. I enjoyed it from turn one, and it only grew on me more from there.People who complain that this game is boring, or that the winner was determined too early, are actually complaining about the skill inequality of the people playing. Just like Formula D or Splendor, a very good player is going to absolutely destroy everyone else. While playing the game, I quickly started calculating the cheapest way to move forward, and the best time to use my movement cards. Everyone else was accumulating gunpowder, or food, or money, but I knew that the easiest way to win was to win the race, so I focused all my strategy on that. Focusing on WINNING by staying at the front of the pack, and perhaps pulling ahead in point at the last minute by increasing your treasure or gold, is where the REAL fun would come from, as a tense rivalry is always fun.The last time I played Formula D, it was an insane all-out tire-melting rivalry between my father and me to see who passed the finish line first, and who blew up their engine. Likewise, two skilled players could have quite a fight for the lead at the end of this game, but families with kids could also have a great time playing this game. I played this game with the best of Korngold (The Seahawk, Captain Blood) playing on my record player and have a rollicking good time.Good times, and highly recommended!

The last time I tried out a Vega product (Vega Sport Performance Protein, Chocolate, Tub 29oz), it made me sick. My sister suggested one of it's ingredients may have been an allergen, and thus caused my discomfort. My wife was surprised when I gave this product a go, fearing I would have the same reaction. Fortunately, I do not seem to be allergic to this product or have any stomach discomfort, so that's a plus. On the other hand...I've used a lot of different shakes mixes over the years, and so far the best by far has been Jarrows. In theory a vegan solution should be superior as long as it uses quality ingredients, but I am not impressed with this product either.First of all the product doesn't taste very good and very chalky. Others have said it tastes disgusting, which I did not find. It's far from good though. And for a product packed with nutrition I expected a huge energy boost and overall good feeling like I get when I mix up a shake with some fruits and veggies and some of the Jarrows protein powder. No such good feelings after mixing with a small bit of fruit and few suppliments. No energy boost. Apparently all of the healthy-feeling effects of the all the veggies crammed into this product were lost somewhere in the manufacturing/processing.Finally, this product is expensive.My two cents? Skip this stuff, buy some Jarrows protein powder, and blend with some liquid vitamin/minerals and a generous helping of fruits and veggies. You'll feel amazing after drinking it and it will taste much better than this stuff. On the other hand if you're a vegan...I can't help you. I have yet to find a vegan nutritional shake that 1. tasted good enough to want to consume and 2. actually appeared to have health benefits.

Some people have called me an Apple "fanboy", which is pretty darn ridiculous when you consider that I haven't been a fan of Apple computers since the 90's when they came in any color you wanted as long as it was beige. At any rate, my experience with "modern" Apple products has been kind of hit and miss. I wasn't a fan of the white MacBook my sister got back when OS X was young, and I've had varying degrees of success using ipods, pod touches, and more recently my wife's MacBook Pro, an iPad Mini, and two iPhones.My experiences with a hand-me-down iPhone 4 were disastrous from the beginning. For starters, it CONSTANTLY dropped calls. People couldn't hear me if I was sitting down, and when phone calls DID work they were filled with static and extremely low in volume. Text messages took forever to send, the cell signal was abysmally slow and constantly dropping, and the battery life was terrible as well. To top it all off the thing's microphone didn't work so I couldn't record YouTube videos. Overall impression? Yuck! All that said, despite the horrific time I had getting it to play Infinity Blade and sending texts etc, and the fact that it would refuse to play songs from my iTunes (it removed songs as soon as it played them sometimes for no apparent reason and the phone backups constantly corrupted), it was the only smartphone I had and my wife insisted I keep using it so that she could send me pictures in texts (otherwise I would have gladly gone back to a dumb phone).A few years passed, and my wife got two phone upgrades. Her first one was to a Samsung Galaxy S4, and the second was to an LG G3. She tried to give me the S4 but I didn't want it. When I announced I was going to get a G3 she said if I got it she was taking it. So I let her have it. In the meantime it was getting harder and harder to justify paying my enormous phone bill to Verizon when I had a phone that couldn't really make phone calls or do anything else. So in the end, despite my better judgement, I slapped down almost three hundred dollars to get a White iPhone 5c and after jumping through some hoops (had to order a Sim Card from Verizon and Activate the Phone) I finally got it working. My thoughts?If you are using a sad iPhone 4 throw that piece of junk away and get one of these!First of all, despite all the benchmarks saying that the 5S and 6 are a gajillion times faster than this little phone, it's still WORLDS faster than an iPhone 4! Infinity Blade III takes seconds to open instead of minutes. The color and contrast are much better. It's built much sturdier and has a slick, smooth, extremely comfortable feel. Sending texts is instant. Navigation is smooth, liquid, and incredibly responsive. The first time I turned it on it transferred everything off of my old phone using iCloud in mere minutes. And the 4G LTE results in persistent, fast, responsive Internet that is much less of a drain on the battery. I took the phone to work today and when I got home it still had 75% left on it's battery!What else can I say? It includes Siri, the camera is greatly improved, it supports IOS 8 and runs great with it (not choppy as iPhone 4 was with IOS7). It's beautiful, sturdy, and relatively cheap. As I said, around three hundred bucks for a refurbished one that looked new, and with 32 GB of space.I haven't transferred my MP3s over from iTunes yet because I'm currently cleaning up my music collection, but it after cleanup and loading it up with MP3s they all play without disappearing like on my iPhone 4, I'd say this phone is perfect. As it is, it's by FAR the best phone I've ever used. Very, very nice!

I was kind of half-dreading the release of this film for quite a while, while my wife was eagerly anticipating it (completely with a elbowing and whispered "You're taking me to see that" upon first viewing of the trailer). I must say, for once the trailers were honest. This film appears from it's trailer to be overblown, and it is. It appears to be overlong, and it is. It also appears to be a heavy drama, an existential, confusing conundrum, and a visual-effects candy explosion, and...surprise, surprise! It is, it is, it is!Don't get me wrong, it's kinda sorta awesome in a way. It's either the best awful movie you've seen in a while or the worst awesome movie you've seen in a while (an "honor" it perhaps shares with Jupiter Ascending [ya know, cuz everything else is "Rising" these days]). It starts with a bleak, dusty future where humanity is doomed due to a crop "blight" of all things, and space exploration is largely forgotten as humanity sits and waits out it's end on the ball of dust-blown dirt called Earth. A series of strange events draws our has-been protagonist to what's left of the Space program, and sets him on his inevitable journey to save the human race in some form or other.The space sequences in this film are incredibly breath-taking, but it takes what feels like an hour and half to get around to them. This film seriously feels 3 hours long and suffers from a terrible need of some judicious editing. At any rate, once the space part of this space movie starts things finally get moving both dramatically and physically.Through the course of this film there's confusion aplenty, and lots of aching, angsty emoting from everyone onscreen as they argue the merits of betrayal, hopelessness, ridiculous gambits, lies, and finally, groan-inducingly impossible Deus Ex Machina plot twists that jump the space shark through a wormhole and back.On the whole, you CAN enjoy this film, if you take it as a modern 2001:A Space Odyssey, and realize that it is more religous/fantasy than hard sci-fi, and is attempting through slick visuals and wild leaps of logic to take you to a place where "love" can conquer all and accomplish the impossible, even filling in plot holes the size of a planet.And yeah, the scene with the music "No Time for Caution" is completely amazing. It's too bad the rest of the film wasn't as riveting.*Update May 22 2014*My wife really likes this film so she insisted we buy it. I wanted to wait for it to be cheaper, but wait she could not. Therefore we bought the Digital HD version on Amazon and watched it that night on our projector in the living room. Thoughts?On another viewing this film has improved dramatically. When you know what you are getting it's easier to sit back and enjoy the wonderful music, incredible special effects, and great acting. The plot is still a bit bonkers in some ways (a certain scene at the end near/in a black hole still makes me laugh because it's so darn ridiculous), and there are some serious issues with editing, but ya know...This film grows on you. The music is quite mesmerizing. The characters are more likable in subsequent viewings. The relationship between the astronaut and his daughter seems less weird than it did in the theater somehow. And the cinematography in some places is really really great.After a second viewing I was left with the feeling that this is a very good film that could have been a great one if it just had had better editing. It's something my sister pointed out to me a few years back. A film is more editing than anything else, and great editing is woefully unappreciated. Very often what people think is good direction is really just good editing. Where the editing on this film is good (docking sequence) it shines. Where the editing is not so good (on Earth) it drags in places. Overall though, it's STILL a film worth seeing, and now I think it's a film worth seeing over and over, and especially if you enjoyed it in the theater. It's not perfect. But it's quite fun for a nearly 3 hour film. It's also a great showcase for your home theater setup (just crank up the bass and enjoy the music's roar in key scenes).

As an economics fan, I've read a lot of books on the subject over the years. I've read books on how the economy works, comic books that explain economic history, and plenty of books on personal economics and behavioral economics. I have to say, if you combine this book with "Crossing the Energy Divide" you pretty much know everything you need to build the future, stop global climate change, and eliminate unemployment and poverty once and for all. It's the doing of it that proves problematic.A lot of the people writing reviews seem either have very poor math skills (sub-fifth grade level), no knowledge of economics, or to be against this book because it isn't a) A Brief History of time or b) Appealing to every political agenda while addressing a very divisive subject. Look at the world around you. People have sorted themselves geographically, ideologically, and politically into clans that work themselves into a frenzy before going to war against everyone and anyone who doesn't agree with their views. Views reinforced, strengthened, and worsened by constant positive and negative reinforcement. There was a time when good facts had a chance to educate. Now if facts don't agree with a religious dogma (and that which cannot be disproved is a religion despite what anyone may think) then they are slammed as a worthless opinion no matter how truthful, valid, or useful. But enough with the other reviewers. On to the book!In the course of all the economics books that I have read I was struck again and again by the strange fact that despite the supreme confidence that economists had in their theories, they did not explain actual events. This book fills in the gaps, and explains easily and logically what the flaw is in previous theories. This is not a hard to understand book loaded with difficult math. I have seen those books before. While the writing isn't superb, it is entertaining and more than readable for a person of average intelligence. In fact, I would recommend this book as a textbook for a 6th grade economics class. It would help young readers get a firm grasp on how economics actually effects them in the real world.Explaining the problem alone would make this book fifty pages, so the author explains lots of methods he suggests to fix the problem in aggregate by compensating for a lack of Free Market Economics in the real world. Are his ideas pie-in-the-sky, idealistic, unrealistic, fantasy? In some ways yes. It's highly unlikely that the Powers That Be will sit still for ANYTHING that helps the poor at their expense, and we all know that. But it's not the job of an economist to fix the problems of the real world. It's the job of a good economist to find the answer, tell you what it is, and give you some suggestions for how to implement said answer! And this the author does wonderfully and beautifully. Does he naively believe that he will be taken seriously by politicians he thinks are on his side? Sure. Does it matter? Nope. Because now that he has PROVEN what the source of the problem is and what solutions in the real world would look like in theory, it's up to future generations to apply this knowledge. Or not, depending on if they like their world filled with unemployed starving people.To me, this book is definitely one to keep on my shelf for future reference. If you love economics books, read this book immediately. It won't cure cancer or reverse climate change, but it DOES explain the real cause of unemployment clearly, logically, and irrefutably.My only read criticism is, the title should be "Raise Wages Now (and end unemployment and poverty while you're at it)".

My hat's off to everyone involved in this film. After the insanely, atrociously, hilarious bad first film I didn't think it was possible to create a more hilarious, cheesier movie. But apparently the sequel's creators kicked common sense to the curb to make the impossible possible.First of all, obviously I loved the first Sharknado. If you enjoy cheesy movies it is by far a classic in every way. But this...sweet mother of shark! I refrained from seeing this film for a long, long time after it was released because I was frightened, genuinely scared, that is would be a horrible film now that the creators and actors were self-aware of what a phenomenon the first movie was. But...no. It can't be. This film is literally BETTER in every way!!!!The Only Thing Missing is Bruce Campbell...and maybe a shower scene for Kari WuhrerApparently a LOT of people loved the first Sharknado, to the point where they begged and pleaded to be in the sequel. And apparently someone in production read my review (not seriously, but...maybe?) and said "Hey! He's right! We need some Return of the Killer Tomatoes product placement jokes and Kari Wuhrer from Beastermaster 2:Through the Portal of Time and Eight Legged Freaks!" Because...yes! She is in this film! And looking DANG good for being 47 years old! The product placement jokes are absolutely hilarious. The cameos likewise are ridiculously awesome. I'm talking Kelly Osborne, Will Wheaton, Reality TV stars, B-movie stars, morning television stars, commercial stars, and just about every B-list actor you've ever heard of. The only real downside here is that the gorgeous Kari Wuhrer is absolutely wasted in her role, with no double-shotgun wielding/kung fu kicking action that I'm been hoping for (and continue to be disappointed by the absence of) since Eight-Legged Freaks. She's a gorgeous woman with a lot of presence and needs to do more Shark Butt Kicking! But hey, at least she's in the movie...Wink, winkJust about everyone in this film plays things incredibly straight faced yet incredibly good-natured. From the weather girl talking about a shark storm to a certain famous taxi driver, just about everyone who isn't a main character makes you smile. The film itself is incredibly self-aware, but it doesn't' come across as groan-worthy from anyone. that's probably helped by the fact that...Strike a PoseAll the main characters play their parts so incredibly over-actingly seriously that it's absolutely priceless! The protagonist Fin's anguished face and endless camera posing are sure to be the stuff of legend in years to come. His once famous, now down-and-out actress love interest Tara Reid likewise plays the role EXACTLY like in the first film. If anything they are even MORE into their roles than before!"There's something on the wing!"You know you are in for a treat from the INTRO to the movie, which an absolutely insanely awesome combination of Snakes on a Plan (Sharks on a plane? Sharks on a plane!) and the classic Twilight Zone episode Terror at 30,000 feet. It's absolutely quite possibly the most hilarious intro to a movie ever made, and worth seeing the entire film for alone. The rest of the film alternates between goofy, forced, and awesome, but seems to lose a bit of steam, until the sharks attack, and then again, until the finale which I simply was not prepared for. I THOUGHT nothing could top the ending of the first Sharknado, but was I ever wrong! It's the most over-the-top ending to any monster movie ever by a long shot.Forget Lake Placid. Forget Gator and Gator 2. Forget Eight Legged Freaks and Bats. THIS is the greatest monster movie franchise of modern times, and one of the best comedy series of all time to boot! I simply cannot wait for the sequel!

I've literally played every version of Virtua Racing that exists. I played it in the arcade as a kid. I played it on the Genesis. I played the Playstation 2 version. And yes, I bought and played the Saturn version. And I am here to tell you that this is indeed the very best version in existence.The original arcade version was fondly remembered for it's crisp beautiful graphics, and the crazy seat that moved around to try to simulate G-forces. The genesis version lacked a lot of the excitement of the arcade, but it was still very fun to play. And the PS2 version was very pretty, but had horrible sound effects every time your turned sharp etc (really annoying tire screech sound). This version...is awesome.I love racing games on the Saturn, and have actually found very few that I didn't like (not fond of Daytona USA on Saturn, but that's about it). This version of Virtua Racing features gorgeous simple graphics and a decent draw distance. It moves at a fast pace, and the controls feel perfect. The sound effects, music, and overall feel is excellent. The races run a bit long, but it has a lot more depth than any of the other versions of this game and the tracks are all beautifully designed.I played this game on my projector just to see if it was worth keeping. I expected to play it for just a few minutes and then decide it was another lousy game to be traded in. I ended up playing it for hours. The races can get a bit boring and repetitive if you are looking for AI that does more than drive in circles and and don't like your races long, but the fact that it's a bit more of a simulation than an arcade game is actually a bit of welcome break from all of the other excellent arcade-style racing games I own for Saturn.In the end, if you are a serious fan of SEGA racing games, and Virtua Racing in particular, you are going to want to own this game because it takes a one-trick pony and turns it into a fully-fleshed-out championship of racing and lets you drive a variety of cars on large selection of tracks compared to every other version of Virtua Racing. Highly recommended to Saturn Racing game collectors.

I've read quite a few similar books to this over the years, and I think maybe people have the wrong idea about how the scientific mind works. A good scientist asumes nothing, and doesn't care about how obvious what they are testing may appear to others. A good scientist cares about reproducible, provable results. And a good scientist who is a decent writer tries to share their proven knowledge with others to better their lives.I find it kind of silly that people criticize this book for telling them what they already know, because honestly some of the greatest books of the past century do the exact same thing. How To Win Friend and Influence people tells us WHY it's important to take interest in others. Dave Ramsey tell us WHY budgeting, getting rid of debt, and saving for the future is a good idea. And this book tell you WHY you need to think of money and save it in different ways than you have been. Not because you don't know necessarily what you should do, but maybe because you need a nudge to make you motivated to DO what is in your own best self interest.The beauty of behaviorI find behavioral psychology very compelling, and the way it applies to economics is particularly compelling to me. So often people waste years of their lives pursuing a machine-like way of thinking that they think will lead to a better life, but in actuality makes them miserable. I grinned as I read this book repeatedly because I came to realize that things I had been criticizing myself for (buying things far in advance, eating very small portions of treats, buying things and then letting them sit on the shelf for years before using them) were all actually things I had unconsciously done to INCREASE my enjoyment of life.But the real compelling point of this book isn't about behavior, it's about THINKING. If you focus on acquiring material possessions, and how long you have to wait for them, if you are always worried about wasting time because it costs you money, and if you buy ever greater quantities and become selfish, you will be very unhappy indeed. If on the other hand you turn using your possessions into an experience, you buy things in advance, you savor your treats, and think unselfishly, you are going to be happier. Your focus determines your reality, young Jedi.The book is not perfectly written, but it is short and breezy and entertaining, enjoyably well-written. I recommend reading this book to increase your happiness per dollar. And if you are forgetful or need reminders you may want to put it on your shelf to help you remember the importance of adjusting your thinking now and then.I know that personally this book has already made me happier because I realized I can stop beating myself up for doing things that make me enjoy life more.

I heard about this book through a news story online that briefly mentioned the coming demographic crash. At the time I had never heard of such a thing, except perhaps in a speech by Al Gore long ago where he asked people by a show of hands what percentage of the crowd came from a large family, and what percentage had a large family themselves. Back then, I was quite shocked to learn what I had been told as a child (overpopulation would destroy the world) was completely untrue. Fast forward to now, and after reading the article I realized I had to read the book and get the whole story.Great WritingPeople can argue about the accuracy or world view of the author all they want, but I cannot deny the author writes with great style. I was again and again reminded of one of my recent favorite books talking about the future of the modern world "Crossing the Energy Divide". Both books are clearly written by authors that have a genius of writing a difficult and complex subject in a light and entertaining manner, while at the same time a thoughtful and convincing one.This book is not long at all, and you could arguably read it in a day. But giving how powerful, compelling, and important the message is, you may want to buy it put it on your shelf for reference. While the author does have slants in his view, it's obvious that he is trying very very hard not to be biased or push his views on others, but rather to simply give the facts and broad strokes of the problem and possible solutions as he sees them.You might not agree with all of the language, or the solutions proposed, but you'd be a fool to think the message isn't an important one that needs to be addressed before it's too late.

It's been a long time coming, but the ultimate release of a classic film is finally here! I've owned the old Manga release, and the horrific "Special Edition" that butchered the opening credits. When I saw that the a new release was out I immediately purchased it, hoping that AT LAST I would have the release that this film has always deserved. I was not disappointed.First of all, you are probably wondering if the picture quality has finally been cleaned up to make this film look the way it always should have, and the answer is a resounding yes! It appears that like so many American DVD releases of anime coming out, this one was pulled off of an HD Japanese master probably used for the Japanese blu ray. No more yellowed, speckled, cruddy, dirty picture. Everything is bright and colorful and crisp. Simply gorgeous! But the REAL surprise for me was in the audio options.I know that voice!I was a fairly big fan of the old Manga release (but not the additional swearing), and the Japanese dub is a classic despite it's mono sound. So when I saw there was yet another English dub I was thinking it would probably be yet another sub-standard dub like the mediocre Disney dub from Castle in the Sky. I was shocked and amazed when what I found was more akin to the classic English dub of Giant Robo!Like Giant Robo, the original English dub is VERY loose with the translation and is nowhere near the subtitles. And like that classic dub, it is incredibly over-the-top. And yes, like that dub, I absolutely love it to pieces! I did detect a voice or two from Giant Robo, and I'm pretty sure Trigun is in there as well as some other classic 90's voices (Solid Snake from Metal Gear Solid is Lupin!!!!). Everyone does an absolutely fantastic job in their role. In particular I loved the ridiculous fake European accent from the guard who now sounds like Arnold Schwarzenegger! It's silly, over-the-top and at time laugh-out-loud cheesy, and all the more awesome for it. In addition...The Effect of SoundAnime in general is not known for having fantastic sound effects, and the sound in the original Japanese dub of this anime is quite subdued. But the new dub features surround sound effects that are incredibly immersive and superbly balanced. You hear birds chirping, thunderous waterways, and suitably punchy sound effects in fights and chases. All of this makes the movie immensely more theatrical than it was before. Likewise, while the original Japanese dialog is classic, the new Americanized dub is on-par with the very very best of dubs that rewrote the dialog to create something new. I'm reminded again of Giant Robo, but also of Martian Successor Nadesico and Bubble Gum Crisis Tokyo 2040.There's more!There's also a commentary, a reversible case, and other extras. Purists will buy this release for the improved picture alone. But if anyone wants my two cents, I'll say you absolutely MUST hear the new dub if you haven't before. Yes, the original Japanese is a classic, and so is the old dub. But this dub, amazing as it may sound, is ANOTHER classic. It's nothing like the old dubs with their quieter, less immersive effects, but it IS absolutely fantastic and recommended both to fans with an open mind, and people who don't normally like anime and have never seen this film before.If you love great films, buy this release. It's definitive.
