The writer who obviously has a passion about werewolves let his imagination run wild.  This werewolf is not a lycanthrope hence it is not bound to the lunar cycle.  This is ok because; it is well established that not all werewolves are lycanthropes.  Yet all Lycanthropes are werewolves.Without giving too much of the story away this werewolf feasts itself on people from the southwest in States that border Mexico.  This werewolf is pretty much a glutton in that he generally eats what he kills, not always but most of the time.  This werewolf feasts himself on homeless, aliens and others who are not usually missed.  This werewolf has a somewhat narcesistic sense of itself.  This werewolf seems to think eating people is one of its absolute rights as a beast.The Border Patrol \ Homeland security rule book was very well researched which gave the book a real sense.  The entire sign \ tracking is explained in almost too much detail since it often slowed the process of the story.  I can forgive the authors dwelling on the sigh \ tracking too much because; it is obvious the author liked sign \ tracking.  Werewolf the book has only a few issues.  Sometimes the words are not well crafted as if english is the authors second language.  There are some spelling issues but, I don't mark hard on spelling errors.  There are a few places where the message being convayed is so muddled and confused by bad English that, I had to make up my own story to bridge back into the main narrative.  These issues are great but NOT unforgivable.  This is NOT the best werewolf themed book I read on Amazon.com but it is far from the worst werewolf book I read here.The cover art sort of symbolizes the quality of the book.  This werewolf is a true werewolf he is not politically correct.  This werewolf has no redeeming characteristics to recommend mercy for him in polite society.  This werewolf is a monster tried and true  through and through.  However like the cover picture this werewolf story is not fully formed it is NOT half baked but its sentence structure is not tight and realistic as it could be.  The lapses in English threaten to overtake the story but never really do.  Werewolf is a fun book to read for the most part because; this werewolf is just so sadistic and bad.  The characters are just well developed enough to make you care about them.  If this Werewolf book is a first effort it is a darn good one.  Yes the story lacks polish but, this is raw, sadistic gritty werewolf tale that makes your brain go ewwwwe as your mind draws the images the words convey.  If you made this book into a movie you'd be holding the arms of your chair not quite totally frightened but very tense ito the point of being totally on edge.If I could I'd give this book 3.5 stars because; I am NOT sad I purchased this book.  It is not polished, it does move slow from time to time and it has its flaws but everything considered this werewolf book contains an old skool werewolf.  This werewolf is killing, eating people, murdering people sadistically and most of all this werewolf is just totally lovin it.  Don't let the art work on the cover fool you this is no childrens book, unless you have children that are werewolves.  Oh and the page count is wrong.  There are many more pages and they are filled with a good story even if it needs a little work.

Best New Werewolf Tales (Vol. 1) was just pure awesome no two ways about it.  Reading these short stories was some kind of painful because; they were so good it hurt.  So quickly the characters developed and almost instantly I wanted to know more.  I wanted the drama the excitement to go on and on.  I was like a fiend.  I wanted more of each story.  The stories are written in a way that is barely abeit painfully satisfying.  The story basically takes you to the point where in each case the werewolf is fully revealed in all it's glory.  The narrative then trails off and allows you to fonish the story using your own imagination.  However each story is unique and intoxicating in its clever detail.  Each character is lovingly crafted in ways so awesome the readiung experience defies words.These are werewolves that have an air of accessibility about them.  I like this because it suggests what life would be like is regular Mr \ Ms  Smith every man \ woman had to deal with knowing or becoming a werewolf in real life.  The werewolf tales are fun and interesting.  I love how Best New Werewolf Tales (Vol. 1) trails off leaving the reader to complete the story in their own minds.  This is another dark horse werewolf book I did not expect to like and ended up flipping head over heels in love with.  These werewolf stories all pose fun what if's and ask what would you do in this situation.  For those who really love werewolf lore these stories are a thrill a minute.It is exactly because; these are story stories that the characters develop quickly and the pacing is both fast and intense.  For those who love a real intense werewolf themed yarn this is as intense a jolt of werewolf action as I have seen.  I found each story in its own unique way satisfying to the extreme.  Did this werewolf story earn its five stars heck yeah! I'd have given Best New Werewolf Tales (Vol. 1) ten stars were it possible because; they were earned.  Again if I had a limited budget for werewolf themed books this would be a must have.  Like I said in my lead in title I am looking forward to the Best New Werewolf Tales (Vol. 2) like a like a CRACK fiend HURTING FOR THAT NEXT FIX!  I'm being as real as it gets on this book.  I'm truly and totally loving it!

Update and warning:  This screen protector added so much static to my Fire HD 10, the Kindle was going crazy.  As soon as I removed the screen protector, the problems stopped.  I think eventually the static would have destroyed the Kindle.

Not sure how I missed the announcements for this Kindle.  I came across it by accident looking for a different cover for my 8.9 Fire HD.This new 5th generation Kindle is working great.  Very thin.  Not particularly heavy.I didn't like how the home page was cluttered with a bunch of icons, but Amazon Help explained how to drag and drop one on top of the other, so they form a folder.  Keep on dropping, and all the little-used stuff turns into one icon.  Always hated the carousel.The settings are better organized.There are lots of reviews, so I won't go into much detail.  Just wanted to add the stars.

First, I think the newswrap look is hilarious.  I'm easy to entertain.Love this case.  It's a perfect fit, but sleek and thin.  Its most valuable feature is the wide base on which it stands.  I use my Kindle lying down, so it needs to be stable.I have the Kindle 10.1  It fits this case perfectly and feels snug.  The band is easy to open and close and seems like it holds well.  If the band wears out before I upgrade to the next generation Kindle, it's cheap enough to replace.It's so easy to set up.  The built-in swivel is sturdy.I guess if there were a downside, it would be that I don't like the woven texture of the cover.  But after a short while, I don't even notice it.

Who wrote this?  Guys don't use some of the wording and phrasing in this book, such as "lovely."  Cole's and Jon's attention to dumpy little old Amy is straight out of romance novels.  The writing is so amateurish, that it's impossible to understand their fierce dedication to Amy.I've read all the Crais books, so I'm disappointed.  This will by me last.Where's Pike?A lot of the story is copied from the previous book about Maggie and Scott.

Toshiba makes a really nice, lightweight, attractive laptop.Best PC I've ever had, so far.  It's worked well. out of the box.  Wanted to get Win 8.1 before they all come out with Win 10.My first ssd.  It would be fun to watch it work, if there was anything to see.  Pretty much instant everything.The backlit keyboard has excellent touch and huge letters.  Very easy to use.The HDMI port works fine with my Sony Bravia 32" TV.  Picture is crisp.  Fonts are also crisp.There's a neat little charging feature through a USB3 port that lets it charge off the power cord or the battery even if the PC is hibernating, sleeping, or even shut down, I think.  Not sure if it works on all 4 USB 3 ports, but conceivable a person could get rid of a nest of charging cords.  It adjusts to the power needed for each attachment.The video card is such high resolution, the native resolution doesn't work for my TV-PC monitor.  However, it adjusted to the TV's resolution perfectly after a reboot.  And the card's ultra high resolution is a bit tiny for me to see on the laptop's native monitor.  I should have gotten progressive lenses in this last pair of eyeglasses.  Hasn't mattered to me.  I didn't buy it to manage photos.The included software is nice.  I never used that stuff off my HP PCs.  The movie manager was fun to set up with my video collection.  It even manages multiple-episode TV series collections.  I think one of the included programs will convert DVD videos to the hard drive.  DVDs are often much cheaper than the downloads, so I've bought quite a few.  I've been using WinDVD to rip and code.Can't find a YouTube downloader, but the free one online works fine.The almost terabyte ssd will be adequate for my needs.Update:  Has a couple fun power gimmicks.  SO much more cleverly designed than any HP I've had in years.  The power features have a "Panel Open - Power On" setting to avoid continually charging the battery if it's plugged in all the time, like mine is.  "Panel Open - Power On" is in the Control Panel power options.  Turn the setting on, unplug and use battery down to 50%.  Then plug back in.  It charges up to 80% and then runs straight through from the power cord instead of the battery.  Runs cooler, too.  I notice that over a few nights, the battery has drained down to 79%.  I'm assuming that the bit of battery drain eventually gets recharged.There's another setting where the speakers can be used with a line in, such as from a phone, even if it's powered off or sleeping or hibernating.  Maybe not more practical than earbuds, but fun.  Also the USB ports can be lowered to USB 2 to save battery.  Another thing it can do is charge phone, Kindle, etc., even if powered off or sleeping or hibernating.  These options can be run off battery or plugged in.  Neat ideas to play with.  What a great sense of humor those designers have.This PC has worked flawlessly for the couple weeks I've had it going at least 16 hours a day.
I have all their albums.  Better than most of the other tenor albums.  Their rendition of "Forever Young" is the breathtaking.
I think it's first person.  Forgot.  This fellow is hilarious.  Most of the fun is his way of talking.  Super neat characterizations.

Same as their Act Two album, this group does beautiful work.  Rich harmony, perfect voices, gorgeous accompaniment.  And lots of beautiful, familiar songs.  A wonderful new find.  As I noted in a review of the other album, Collabro know how to do justice to "Let it go."  Actually, they perfect all the beautiful pieces they have on these albums.

Beautiful harmony, voices, accompaniment.  Great song selection.  Some of their familiar pieces have slightly different chords in certain familiar spots in the songs, but they pull it off with superb accompaniment.Don't remember if it was this album or their Stars album, but these guys know how to do justice to "Let it go."

Super slow for something with "Turbo" in its name.  Also, the little sliding cover is difficult to close and probably won't last long.  It doesn't actually cover the opening.  Bad design.A USB3 Passport external drive about the size of a cigarrette pack with twice the capacity, for around the same price, is many times faster than this thing.  The same folder copied to this drive and to my USB 3 Passport hooked up to the same port on the computer took 45 seconds on the Passport and (I need my calculator) 325 seconds on this flash drive.This has only one plus - It's tiny.

This is one purchase I'm so happy I got.  I needed it to swivel to point an L shaped nozzle in different directions, without having to twist and hold the heavy hose in place.  This swivels exactly as needed.  And the easy turnoff is SO much better than those stiff brass ones.I have the 2-way and 4-way as well, and they are holding up perfectly.  They also work well in winter.

Most people might say these are "somewhat large."  These run very roomy.  In fact, Appleseed's tends to undersize their clothing.  For me, these comfortable, roomy pants are perfection.  I could sit in them all day.The waistband is roomy, so the tie might be necessary for some people.  My waist is large.  The waistband is also soft enough to be unnoticeable.  Many denim pants waistbands feel like being wrapped in barbed wire.The denim is fashionable, but comfortable.Summary:  These pants are great for lounging and being comfortable, but they look fine out in public.  The two shades are about to become my winter wardrobe.  Appleseed's wide whale corduroys are equally comfortable.

One extra star for the tissue idea, which is just about impossible to find.  There are problems with this bag, but I understand a new model is coming soon.I am using this to hang off a side table by my couch.  Main thing I wanted was a small trash bag for general use and for sewing.  The tissue compartment solves a long-standing problem with what to do with a big tissue box.  I am using the more economical 120-count family size of Puffs.  The box doesn't cram into this organizer without distorting the organizer, crushing the box, and trapping the tissues, but the 120 count pile of tissues without the box fit fine and dispense easily.  If they start to fall out, all I'd really have to do is cut a couple slits and slide a strip of self sealing velcro or something.  I always get annoyed when things are designed for the small, expensive product sizes.  This organizer is obviously intended to be practical.  You can always make the tissue compartment smaller with a liner, but it's not getting any bigger.By the way, Puffs aren't the pop-up style, so they work great when removed from their box.The trash section is perfect for my needs.Trash part stays open, so it's easy to drop stuff in it.Extra pocket is a nice touchBottle holder is another good idea; although, I think it might make the bag hang crooked.The quality of the extra pocket and bottle holder could be better.

Everything's good about these jars.-Square shape makes them easy to arrange and neat looking-Size of each bottle is generous.  No need to refill frequently.-Removable sprinkle plastic caps under the lids are great for sprinkling or not.-Plain glass and black styling looks unobtrusive and consistent-Labels stick well to the bottles-Six worked out perfectly for me.-Packaging was the best I've seen, but no wasted space-They look so much neater than the original spice jars.-Frequently used spices can be bought in bulk.-Lids are easier to uncover than those pop-up flaps on many spice jars.I tried a funnel for filling them and realized that it gets dirty after the first spice.  I switched to small pieces of tablet notepaper twisted into disposable funnels.  The papers held in the jars easily for filling.  Takes a couple seconds of practice.

Don't let the "Gregorian Chants" fool you, these are lovely popular songs.  Their harmony is beautiful, as is the accompaniment.  They sing together quite precisely, but not barbershop style.  One of my new favorites.

I use my Echo mostly as a timer.  I'd pay the same if that's all it could do.  Someday it would be nice if it could keep track of multiple times, such as if I'm cooking different things.  Then if it could repeat a word when a particular time is up, such as "cake timer."  "Alexa, cake timer, 30 minutes."  I'd like to start multiple timers at the same time, or even in the middle of the cake baking, start another timer for boiling eggs.  So 10 minutes into the cake baking, "Alexa egg timer, 5 minutes."  Etc.It's useful even for things such as holding a yoga pose for 30 seconds.  Might make a handy counter, such as "Alexa, count off seconds up to 30" for doing exercise reps.By the way, I knocked it off a shelf, and it was fine.

Rewriting my original review.  I love this pan.  Perfect size, great quality, nonskid ring in the middle.At first it left my bottom crust raw, but I moved it up on the proper baking rack that my microwave-convection oven came with.  Now it works fine.The item in the picture looks round, but there are small handle areas that make it very easy to maneuver.  Love that nothing slides on the middle ring. The ring comes off and back on easily for cleaning.

Best I can describe this singer's voice is "pure and clear." Even though the album shows maybe Chinese? on the cover, her English lyrics are clearer than most singers'.  Internet says she's Taiwanese.She sings the songs without annoying embellishment.  She can carry a tune, in other words.  Not true of everyone.  The accompaniment is full orchestra and just as beautiful as her singing, and it's well balanced with her voice.  Her choice of songs is lovely as well.Only complaint is that she has only one album available that I can find.This is the second artist I've purchase who seems to be producing music from one or more of the Asean countries.  Both have been lovely.  MORE.

First of all, I'm a long-time Safco fan.  Their stuff is so well made and so sturdy.  Even on this cart, the plastic braces are twice as sturdy as many other brands.  Welds are excellent and blend in smoothly. I use it as a microwave cart, with a dozen or more simplehuman canisters on the other two shelves.  Everything fits just right, because the shelves are adjustable.Pros-The black finish looks chic and hides in shadows.-Adjustable shelf heights made everything fit like custom made.-Rim on each shelf faces downward, so things slide on/off shelves easily.-Very strong.  Holds my 60lb microwave-convection oven on top and probably 50 pounds of canisters on each shelf.-Solid top surface holds microwave sturdily.  The oven's feet would have slipped through a wire top.-Impeccable quality of every component - always my experience with Safco.-Very easy to assemble.-It's just the right height.-Condition of every piece was flawless.  I got lucky.  Others have reported problems (see packaging con).-No wasted space.Cons-Casters don't roll very easily on 1/2" thick rug.  I won't be rolling it, so that's not an issue here.-Packaging could be SO much better.  Even a little styrofoam would help.  The paint work held up well, despite everything wrapped in thin plastic and left to bang around together.  Mint condition.-Outer box was inadequately taped.-This is more likely a carrier comment, but the packaging was flimsy enough that one corner was crushed.  Fortunately nothing was damaged inside.

Everything rocks in it.  Round pieces slide forward or backward over that middle lump.  The three stars are because it's adjustable.  I really needed that.The little posts tend to go in crooked or loosen.  I used Loctite with them.

What I like about RC is that he plays the notes - always the original melodies, and not all the cheezy riffing up and down. (I don't know how to describe it.)  I just hate playing where they have to riffle through three notes above or below on the off chance they might hit the right note.  Clayderman always just plays the melody.  And his accompaniment is excellent.  The pieces in this album are so relaxing.
Just discovered her.  I downloaded three songs I like best.  Back for more soon.Excellent accompaniment, lyrics, singing, harmony.

It's addictive.  I do the easy puzzles and cheat throughout by using the layer buttons.  Sure works smoothly on my Kindle Fire, as do Sherlock and Honeycomb Hotel.  Zillions of puzzles.  Different tile sets and layouts.  Incredible value.  Nothing every goes wrong with them.
Missy's favorite kitty litter.  Been using it for years.  Clumps well, and, most importantly, very low dust.  Hard to find in stores.

I'm loving this thing.  Big enough, but easy to store.  Easy to clean, too.Easier to get out of the oven.  They collect steam underneath, and it can be a mess trying to get a large, hard plastic one out of a smaller microwave.Sure beats the two that I threw away.  They didn't collapse.

With a bad back, knees, hips, the one-sided handle is useless.  And too high.  Like everybody else says, the table top is tiny.  Already gave it away.It was nice looking.  Too heavy.  I put furniture glides under the feet.  And it's very cumbersome in a small space.

Very short and amateurish.  Author's phrasing isn't good enough to bring off much of the intended humor.  Story was not even a tiny bit developed.  It's like the author got bored and typed and period, and the book ended.  I can't remember if I paid for this or if it was Kindle Unlimited.  Either way, it was a waste of money.

Pros-SO easy to operate. One of my least favorite chores is struggling with hose attachments.-The nozzles are widely spaced to accommodate different hose connectors.-Connectors are metal-The valve handles require little finger strength but stay in place.-The on/off is clean and drip free.-Everything is parallel, so it's obvious which direction is on or off.-The cap that attaches to the water faucet is easy to operate by hand.  Don't need my water hose pliers anymore.-And it's pretty.Cons:-None yet, well, except it'll encourage my neighbor across the street to "share" my water for his auxiliary garden in the empty lot behind me.I've stripped and broken stiff brass splitters that I had to use pliers to operate.  Would have been nice to have this years ago.

Much smaller than the description.  I have the Bucket Boss 69000 Cable Bag.  When reading the specs, this one described itself as larger, but it doesn't have a 3" side piece. The top and bottom are attached with very little storage room inside.  Quite a disappointment.  I'll get another Bucket Boss.  Additionally, this isn't nearly the quality of the BB.

These little guys are such a waste of $.  One barely holds and the other just flops back and forth.  They're flimsy, cheap plastic.  Must have cost less to make than the packaging.  I'm glad I didn't waste the money on two pairs.

It's even better than described.  Heavy and sturdy fabric well stitched and well braced.  Good water protection on the roof.  Some reviews mention that the fiberglass poles hurt their hands, but I had no problem.  I did get a splinter from my plywood underlayment...I set mine up on a 3' x 7' piece of 3/8" plywood.  The plywood is on an outdoor mat that happened to be available.  Ground cover below that is gravel.  Then I got four 2x3 sheets of Brock/Sakrete Interlocking Paver Base Panel.  Found them at Lowe's and HD.  $12 a panel.  Not cheap, but both stores sell them one sheet at a time, rather than that they be purchased in bulk.  I put two panels end-to-end under the tent floor and two on top of the tent floor.  Like a sandwich.  These panels have grooves for any water flow and holes for drainage.  They weigh about the same as styrofoam, but they are much stronger and coated with something.  Anyway, I like them.  On the plywood, I put D-rings at the corners and zip tied the convenient eyelets at the corners of the tent to the D-rings.  I used a strip of velcro to tie to that little tieback attached to middle back wall and hold it to an awning clamp on the side of my RV.  Very stable.My bike is a 20" Schwinn Loop, but I've added a largish basket to the back rack and a longish mirror to the end of one handlebar.  It fits fine.  I stand the bike in the tent using the single bike version of Amazon's http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00849P2M0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1I have room for a narrow little table in the back that holds my bag of equipment and lube and supplies.  The two hooks on the inside back wall of the tent are handy for helmet and tire pump.One thing I noticed is that when the YardStash was in the sun for maybe an hour, it got quite warm and stuffy inside. Those little air vents will be important.It's so handy not to have to make room to store the bike in the shed or in the car or outside.

Thank you.  The older books have wrong publ dates where they have been re-released.  If Amz would allow sort by original publ date, we'd all be happy.  This has been especially cumbersome with the Reacher books.

The game doesn't allow you past one level unless you write a review.  I had no idea how I'd like the game until after I played it longer.  I am now revising my premature review.  I'd take all reviews here with a lot of skepticism, because I'm guessing that most people won't take the time of find their original review and revise it, regardless of how offensive it was to be forced to write a review based on so little gameplay.After some playtime, I found the game getting repetitious and boring.  The puzzle solutions never change.  You build the same animal pictures with the 5x5, 10x10, 15x15, and 20x20 puzzle sizes.  They are placed on the same background.  Over and over. The difficulty level isn't much of a challenge, even on the 20x20 puzzles.  I've played other games, like the KPix puzzles that are far more interesting and challenging.I tossed it a second star, because it's relaxing, in case you can't fall asleep.

Here is a link from Amazon showing the type of clamp (not necessarily the correct size) I got in the Ace Hardware plumbing dept to hold this mirror.http://www.amazon.com/Ancor-403752-Electrical-Stainless-Cushion/dp/B000NHZZ82/ref=sr_1_68?ie=UTF8&qid=1422999084&sr=8-68&keywords=hose+clampThe clamp I got was a little too large, so I put a strip of rubber spacer.  I can add a washer or two, if the screw starts to slip.  The clamp I bought has a nice rubber coating that grips well and protects the handlebar grip.  HOWEVER, the one I got had to have the holes drilled a teensy bit larger to accommodate the bolt end of the mirror.I've used this style of mirror biking in downtown Chicago for years and really love it.  It twists and adjusts to most any position.  Perfect size, excellent view.  None of that convex stuff to distort the image.  You're busy staying alive along the edge of the street.  There's no time to process a tiny, disproportionate image.I was concerned that the mirror would get in the way when I'm trying to hold the handlebar grip, but I twisted the clamp so the stem is mostly vertical.  The very flexible articulating function of the mirror positions it perfectly.

Bigger and stronger than I expected.The dividers aren't attached at the bottom.  Sorted clothing can intermingle.Also, those sticks that have to be inserted to stiffen the shape are a pain.  And they keep sliding out.  I got by with just the top ones.  Can't fold the baskets without removing the sticks.

Not a lot of space saving, maybe an inch and a half, but they are nice pedals.  Good grip, great spin.  A teensy bit heavier than the old pedals, but I'm not a weight weenie.  They still stick out a bit, which is kind of a good thing.  They can help protect the side of the bike in the back of the car.  Mine's a folding Schwinn Loop.  Not sure what that 9/16 thing is.  These fit my cranks fine.

My bike shop guy and several customers who saw it think it's a really nice bike.Upgrades, replacements and removals, before first ride:--Upgraded the brakes.  The plastic parts on it would never work right.--One brake cable arrived kinked and had to be replaced.--Changed out the saddle to a Cloud 9 based on the large number of complaints in these reviews.--Folding pedals are on the way from an Amz merchant (who is a SLOW shipper).--Saddle bag for on the back rack.  Just a little one to hold spare tube, tiny pump, gloves, pants leg straps, Y wrench, maybe a multitool someday.--Removed the fenders.--Changed seatpost to a Thudbuster LT (LT is long travel.  ST is short travel.  Can't imagine paying that much money for a short travel post.)--Added a lock and computer.--Got it tuned up at Cycle Mania, the local bike shop.  The guy has it running like a Rolls Royce.--Named it "Winona Rider."  Get it?  "Rider" instead of "Ryder?"  And it matches her gothic look, which I've always found amusing.Shifting is the best I've ever had.  All 7 speeds work well.  For me the lower gears are a plus.  I do have hills, and I always use lower gears anyway.  My average speed is about 5 mph - downhill.  I've met bikers out in the desert who stop to offer to help, thinking I'm going so slowly, I must be in trouble.  In the city, I've met people who are amazed I can stay upright at my low ground cruising speed.  But I digress.A plastic bin will hold the bike folded in the car.  I'll cut one end to flap open on the box to make the bike easy to move in and out of the bin and to protect it from other stuff banging into it.  Hope not to fold it much to avoid damaging the cables.Speaking of which, that center fold is a little confusing.  I'm getting the hang of it.
Lovely orchestration, flawless singing, beautiful arrangements.  I even liked the Caruso song, which I never like.Hope they have more albums planned.

Given some of this reconstituted and served in a blind taste test, I'd have pronounced it regular heavy cream.  It didn't seem sour.  It did seem to have a strong cream taste.  I just LOVED it.The night before, I mixed and refrigerated per directions.  I think I used a tiny bit less water.  It still ended up liquid the next day.  No matter.  I have plenty of things that are great with liquid cream.First I tried it in biscuit dough, and it didn't seem to have any effect.  Then I tried it on partially thawed mixed fruit.  To me it seemed decadently creamy and good.
I like these guys.  Good harmony and accompaniment.  Every song is a pleasure.
Beautiful voice, great melodies, wonderful harmony.  Perfect album.  Only complaint is that there aren't enough of them.

Huge disappointment after I read the directions.  Basically this is an overpriced can of powdered skim milk with a little chocolate tossed in.  Starbucks cocoa is so much better.  Something I need to be careful of in the future.  Lesson learned.The drink leaves some saccharine aftertaste.Dirt cheap added filler is very expensive "convenience."
For my taste, this rice is all-around perfect.  Cooks beautifully every time.  Tastes great.

Cheap, but they are already starting to shred at the zipper after only two uses.  In the long run these will be a waste of money.The good part is that they're all large.  I hate those sets with the worthless small and medium bags.

Got the cheap crunch-it-yourself tool pieces with the snaps.  Worthless, so I switched to this.  This tool is SO easy to snap shut, BUT it's very difficult to keep lined up over the rounded button head long enough to compress the snap piece.

Would have preferred all large ones, but this is what I could find.  The zipper strings come off.  Combine this with the tendency of the elastic to trap the zippers.  Frustrating and slow to work with.Decent quality.  I bought a different brand, cheap pile of 10, which are already shredding.
This woman's accompaniment, harmonies, singing voice, lyrics, melodies, and all-around style are wonderful.  Only downside is that there are only two albums available.

Very sturdy mat.  It's smooth on one side and woven texture on the other side for a non-skid grip.  Fits my small, round Whirlpool microwave perfectly.  It's easy to grab out to use as a counter mat if needed.  There are no bumps or raised areas, though, to allow air to circulate under a hot pan or dish, so I doubt it's a whole lot of counter protection.I'd recommend this to anybody and will likely see if there's another pattern I could use.  I have a Hamilton Beach sandwich maker I use daily, and this is a perfect size for under it.The design is on both sides, by the way.

She has a nice voice.  I was buying various versions of the song, but didn't like many.  This one made the cut.  Would have liked more accompaniment.  The Canadian Tenors' version of "Forever Young" is fantastic.
The singer's voice is creaky, but the accompaniment has so much harmony, I bought this anyway.  Lovely song.  The Canadian Tenors' version of the song is fantastic.

It's sturdy and neat looking, but it's capacity is only the size of your sink perimeter.  Dishes have to be able to drip down.It doesn't hold anything standing up, so its capacity is very much less than a dish drainer.The thing I don't like about dish drainers is their tendency to accumulate dust and dirt very quickly.  Their tiny nooks and crannies are difficult to clean.  Too high maintenance.  This rack is almost zero maintenance.My sinks are tiny, so the fact that this can be rolled up to fit is quite useful.I will continue to use this.
Arrived with wrong adapter and had to be returned.  If it had the right parts, it would still be flimsy.It was cheaper at Lowe's, but there I found something that worked a lot better for my purpose.

I use this almost daily.The removable egg attachment is too floppy, which drops a star.  The whole unit gets very hot and takes quite a while to cool down.  A floppy middle section can be dangerous.  It has to sit open to cool off.  Update to this paragraph:  I got the hang of this and don't have a problem with any of the parts.  I keep it on its own silicone trivet.  Close the lid and lift by the back foot and hinge where it's not hot.  Easy to move.  Very easy to remove the middle section and toss in soapy water to soak.  Wipe out the top and bottom plates and any gunk I slopped on it.I'm experimenting with different kinds of bread.  I like is the Thomas English muffins.  They're so tiny and flimsy, though, they don't hold the egg, cheese, ham well.  I can't find the Thomas sandwich size.  The Thos bagel thins are pretty bad tasting.  I found some wonderful sourdough bread loaves she cuts about 3/4" thick.  Perfection.Bought the dual sandwich maker, too, for baking biscuits to use as the bread.  I haven't experimented in other sandwich recipes, except grilled cheese.  That turned out quite good.  I think I made a sandwich on the bottom and one on the top section.Months later:  Still enjoying this daily.  It's holding up well, considering the egg, cooking oil, cheese, crumbs, and other stuff I've dripped all over it.  Still never used the double one.  Just no need to fire up the extra watts.

Cat vomit.  Need I say more?  I found a small bottle of this at a local pet store.  Highly recommended, so I stocked up on these larger bottles.It's odorless, which is a huge plus with a cat.  And it cleans the mess and takes away the odor that is being cleaned up.  I can tell, because after I've cleaned, Missy doesn't spend all day trying to bury it.I don't like the pop top, so I moved a sprayer from another bottle to this.
Wish I had these sturdy clips years ago.  They are strong and so much easier to use than pins.  And they're less likely to kill the cat if she eats one.

I have bought half a dozen of these over the years.  I currently have this XL and a smaller one.  They are waterproof.  They look nice.  They have a ton of capacity.  I drag them back and forth a bit to get behind them for one thing or another, and they hold up very well.  Assembly is easy.I've tried a couple Rubbermaid storage boxes, and water just flows right into the non-locking seams.One thing I would like is a cover that fits each size.  It would be so much handier to keep them clean.

I get a lot of use out of the two of these.  I always transfer food to freezer bags.One of the best features of these holders is that they fold flat for easy storage.  Another big plus is their adjustable height.  Setting the handles the correct height so the bag rests on the bottom, and starting the fill gently will work every time.The loss of a star is for the slight flimsiness of the construction.  I always have to be careful not to break it.I need a couple more.
I've bought several of this tub over the years.  It's such a nice multi-use tub and stores sturdy and flat.  The tapered bottom fits into my tiny sink top, if needed.
I have these on birdseed cans.  They sure are handy.  It takes a bit of pressure to get the ring on.  Feels like it's sturdy.

I've used this a couple months now.  I had to buy a dolly with a handle to roll it around.  Glad I did.This machine does its job, but it has lots of shortcomings.  It leaks under the top cover down the sides.  I've felt it leaking while it's working.  It also sprays and leaks water from wash to spin and spin to wash.The manual is just awful.  The drain knob does not need to be on "drain" to run water out of the spin side.  So you can wash while spinning.  I load stuff in the spin side.  Shut it up.  Set on 5 minutes.  Spin out the wash water.  While it's still spinning, I turn on the fresh water into the spin intake.  After a few seconds, it usually drains out of the drain hose.  I turn the water off and drain till no more water comes out.  Turn the water back on.  I keep doing this cycle 4 to 6 times during a 5-minute spin until the water seems to come out clean.Lint gets under the agitator.  The manual doesn't tell how to pop the screw cap off.  I figured that out.  However, I can't get the screw loose.  Even under the cap there was lint, so I'm sure a ton more has collected under the agitator.The wash and the spin sides spray on each other.  The lids have to be shut to keep from splashing around the outside of the machine.  I have it on a large tray to catch any drips.  I also have it on a couple pieces of neoprene to prevent it from sliding.  It moves quite violently when it's working.  This is more noticeable when only one side is working, because it throws the machine out of balance.The wash side is nice and spacious, but the spin side doesn't really handle as much as the wash side.  A better balance of capacities would help.The washing agitation is quite vigorous.  Feels like the clothes are getting clean.The drain pump doesn't get the bottom couple inches of water out of the machine.  I roll it on its handy dolly to the back door and drop the drain hose under the back steps and let it gravity drain.  It still has some kind of lower level that holds water.  I can hear it when I move the machine to its storage spot.I bought a garden hose adapter for my kitchen faucet and then cut a 5/8"ID (inside diameter) hose to the length I need to run water to the wash and spin intakes.  A splitter would allow for two little hose pieces, so there's no need to move the hose back and forth.  My sink's too small to hook up so much stuff.I clipped a finch feeder sock over the end of the drain hose, which catches all the lint the useless built-in lint collector doesn't get.I'm having way too much fun doing laundry.

Every once in a while, a book comes along that will stick with you long after you've finished the story. A story that will touch your heart and soul like no other. This is one of those stories--- the kind that'll make your heart bleed for these two wonderful characters while trying to find their way back into the world of living again. That they manage to do it while a slow burning love affair between them burns brightly, makes this story both just that much more heart-breaking, and heart-warming at the same time.The "Vixen and the Vet" is a very touching story about a forgotten war hero who has been living in complete solitude for the last eight years because of the massive injuries he had recieved while serving time over in Afghanistan as a medic, and a woman who has fallen from grace because of a man who played her for a fool.Savannah lost face in the world as a serious investigative reporter, but that's not all she lost. She also lost her home, her job, and her fiance' over false information that had been fed to her by none-other than her ex-fiance' and his father. Two men that she could trust to tell her the truth, when in fact, they were the guilty parties and not the colleagues they so thoroughly convinced her of doing the dirty deeds. Savannah Carmichael has returned to Danvers, Virginia to lick her wounds after being sacked from a prominent position at a high-ranking New York newspaper. The life and career she worked so hard to aquire was now in complete shambles. When shes suddenly given an opportunity to redeem her professional career by writing about the slighted town veteran, Savannah jumps at the chance to capitalize on Asher Lees story.Asher has all but given up on living a normal life, little lone finding a woman who can except him for what he's become. After being seriously injured in war, he comes home a year and a half after the incident took place, but not with the hero's welcome like he so deserved, that's for sure. He has no family left that he can turn to, he was an only child and his parents were killed when he was still in high school. Mrs. Potts, a former grade school teacher came to live with him to see to his needs, and when he came home all disfigured...it was Mrs. Potts who acted as his protector. His face is badly disfigued from the burns and broken bones in his face, his left eye droops, and he has also lost his hand and an ear when that IED blew up right next to him when he went to help rescue a downed fellow soldier. Everytime he went into town his looks made small children cry out in fear, and the people in town started to refer to him as a freak. Rather than being continually chastized about his looks, Asher had decided to hold himself up in the mansion on the hill with a life of solitude for eight long lonely years.I am not going to tell the story, instead I am going to say that this is such a beautiful and moving story, one that is full of love, laughter and heartache. It is a story you need to read for yourself to realize just how fantastic this story really is. I have no doubt what-so-ever... that this story will touch your heart, just like it did mine.

I loveed every single book in this anthology. They are all very different and unique, and most of all.....very heart-warming. If these 8 wonderful stories don't put you into the Christmas spirit, then nothing will.These are all very fantastic books that are worth at least a 5 star rating, if not more- at least IMO anyway.....Christmas at Copper Mountain by Jane PorterCome Home for Christmas, Cowboy by Megan CraneA Cowgirl's Christmas by CJ CarmichaelA Cowboy for Christmas by Katherine GarberaMistletoe Wedding by Melissa McCloneA Sweet Montana Christmas by Roxanne SnopekBlame the Mistletoe by Dani CollinsHer Mistletoe Cowboy by Alissa CallenAnd even if there is one or two in this collection that you're not real crazy about, it's still worth the small amount of money you've paid for this wonderful collection. It's a win-win in my book!

Just okay. I had a really hard time trying to get into this story. The writing itself was well done, but the story left me totally confused. It didn't end the way I thought it would, not even close. I thought this was going to be about a romance between Cameron and Cassie, but that's not what happened at all. Not even close.

It was okay, but I sort of got lost in all the Indonenesian travel details. Plus...I just didn't like the way the story was written, it just felt a little choppy and the dialogue just didn't seem like what you'd hear people say in real life, either. I did like the fact that this was based on a true story, and I do believe in not only fate, but also love at first site.

I don't know why, but this story was so emotional for me. More so than any of Catherine Gayle's other books. The details were so painful to read about, but I DID get through it.... and I'm so happy I did. Razor was so brass in all the other books, but he sure redeemed himself in my eyes, that's for darn sure!!!Tori was sent to the U.S by her father to go to study ballet and also so she could escape a fate no one should have to bear.  Her father knew that that was the only way to keep her safe from the Russian Mob. They were after her and her mother so they could use them in a human trafficing ring they were running. She did escape, but in the process both of her parents were brutely killed. After her father was killed, her funds had had been depleteed, so she had to turn to doing things to survive that no one should ever have to resort to doing. After her dreams of becoming a ballerina came to a halt, so did her other means of survival. She heads off to Las Vegas to become a prostitue, but only because it was the only other way she knew of in order to make enough money to survive on. But the first person she runs into that night just happened to be, Razor, a man who took one look at her and instantly knew that there was more behind this woman's actions than really meets the eye.Razor was so sweet and understanding through this whole thing; he just made me want to melt. And Tallie, I could really kiss that woman for not only not judging her, but also for standing up for her when Tori needed it the most. I also loved Razor's mom, what a woman!!! I loved how Razor kept describing his mother's all business kind of stances....just too funny. But the woman had real back bone to her, probably because she could relate to Tori and what she had been through just to survive. Her and Razor's personal talks on the phone about protection was totally hilarious, too. I also loved Dimas and the way her befriended Tori when so many others turn their back on her. I can't wait to read his story now, because I have a feeling there's really something very deep & dark going on with him, too.As an added bonus, the early scenes in the book take place at the wedding of Babs and Katie, beloved characters from the Portland Storm series, and if you loved that series...then you'll definitley love this spin-off series!

This book hooked me right from the start, and the suspense was one of the best I've read in a while. But there were so many loose ends left unresolved by the end of the story. Things like: Did the Connor's mother really kill her ex-lover? Or did Donavon kill his father because he found out what his son was up to? Will busting this ring help find Connor's sisters baby? Who is behind all this illegal adoptions? Did Jessa lawyer really not know anything? Or was he just playing dumb? Did the real kidnapper really act all on his own? Or was there other accomplises they we still don't know about yet? All these loose ends just sort of left me a little disappointed.Now in all fairness, I do realize that this is just the first book in this romance series, and I have no doubt that we will be visiting some of these same characters again in the future books to come. So.... it is very possible that we'll get to see all these loose ends get tied up over time.I did like the tension aspect between the siblings; it's something that I have personally witnessed in real life, so at least for me, that part felt very real. My question is now that they know Liam is really Connor's long lost son, will they keep the little boys name the same? Or will they change it back to his real given name?Overall; I thought this was a really, really good book!

I liked it, but I really didn't love it like I thought I would. The whole story is basically told in the first person, which I rarely like anyway. The story itself sort of drove me crazy with all of Carrie's thoughts being very repetitive. I couldn't wait to finish reading it - I think I spent more time skimming than really reading. In the beginning, I thought Adam was a jerk for ignoring his poor children the way he did, and I was happy that Carrie finally took him to task for the way he was treating both his children and his family.I did like little David and Oliva, as well as all of the other Fletcher family members.

Wow! This story was short, but oh so sweet! I spent most of the time either drying my eyes or laughing my butt off, and sometimes I found myself doing both of those things at the same time. Cameron and Will are so, so perfect for one another. The precious few moments spent between Cameron and her father sure made me a blubbering mess. I knew Fred the moose would show up so I anxiously awaited his arrival although I did not know where or when, but I knew the story just wouldn't be complete without him showing up. Poor, poor Fred, I felt so bad for him and just wanted to reach out and give him a big warm hug.The big Abbott family is filled with so much love and support for one another; they are all so warm and big hearted that it makes you want to become part of the family, too.I am so loving this whole series, so far! The whole Abbott family is just as heart-warming as the McCarthy's family in the Gansett series, which I've read many times over.Can't wait to see what Marie Force has in store for us next......

O...M...G!!!!!! This book was so FREAKING FANTASTIC! There were so many twists and turns in this story that it almost made your head spin. And truthfully; most of these I didn't even see coming. The suspense alone had me sitting on the edge of my seat, biting my nails right down to the nub. In fact; I think this book---as far as the suspense goes, anyway---is the best that I've read since Dani and McKenna first blew into town, after finally blowing the roof off of a major scandel that involved all those high profile and very powerful government officials. Not that there hasn't been some really fantastic suspense scenes in all the other books--- because there has been some real nail biting scenes in the past books, too--- but this one just sort of set my nerves completely on end, just like it did in the first book of the Bluegrass series involving McKenna and Dani.Of course it was fun to go back and get reaquainted with the town and all of it's residence again. I see the Rose sisters are still a force to behold, God Bless their sweet little meddling hearts... And of course.... just like in all the other books, there were lots of laugh out loud moments, too like: all the usual betting that was taking place at Blossom Cafe, and Hooch who made me smile throughout the whole story, the story line that involved Sienna meeting her mother, Kenna at the court house, and I especially loved the meeting that took place at the Rooney law offices. Kathleen Brooks always seems to outshine most other author's when it comes to having the ability to seemlessly weave a little bit of laughter into an otherwise, very tense moment.I knew there was going to be something very explosive happening between Sienna Ashton and Ryan Parker, after watching the way they acted around each other growing up, but never in my wild imaginations would I have thought it would be this explosive. Wow! These two were so hot together you almost needed to wearing firefighter gear to keep from being scorched from the heat they generated!It was great getting to know more about this whole new generation growing up in the wake of their parents footsteps. I can't wait to read more! And a big 'Thank you' to Kathleen Brooks for always keeping your books so freshing and exciting! You've done a very outstanding job, so far, and I can't wait to see what you have up your sleeve next!!!If anyone hasn't had the pleasure of reading this series, yet, I suggest you try it out now. I promise... you won't be sorry!

WARNING......For all of you that are used to reading Christie Ridgeway's other more timid books, let's just say this series might not be for you. I loved all of her other books I've read over the years, but....this series seems to border more on the erotic side, especially this one..I wanted to love this book but I think the writer was trying so hard to make us see Bing as a bad boy that she sort of went overboard. Seriously though, all of his internal dialogues are of the sexual nature. So much so that I actually felt like "dick" was another character in the story. I also didn't feel the connection between these two at all. Alexa was this good girl, and I couldn't see what the heck she saw in him at all.It was okay if you like all the explict sex scenes, but it's not my cup of tea, for sure. I think I'll be skipping the rest of the series.

I wasn't sure that I liked Samara all that well in the beginning. She just seemed so ungrateful for all the things people tried to do for her, while whinning that she had to do everything on her own because she had no one to turn to. What? Maybe if she wasn't such a whiny, selfish person; she would have made more friends. BUT......I have to admit that she did start to grow on me after a while.As for Jade......it was never mentioned why this child acted the way she did, but having a grandson and two great-grandsons who suffer from completely different stages of Autism---Jade's behavoir reminded me of the boys when they were her age.Logan is a saint in my books and one of the most likable heroes, I loved him right from the very start. He had the patience of a Saint, while dealing with the teenagers, Jade, and especially Samara.Over all I thought this was a pretty good read, although the ending seemed a bit rushed.

Not having read anything by this author before, this book really took me by surprise.... but in a very good way. Meri and Trey together made me both laugh and swoon. I love a good cowboy story anyday, but this one was better than I expected. With Meri being a virtual city girl all of her life, I didn't give her much hope when she decided to head to wards her newly inherited mountain ranch in Wyoming, but I would have been completely wrong!!! And while she could be a real fumbling klutz at times, I have to give her kudo's for being strong-willed enough to want to learn how to do things all on her own, rather than letting these big strapping cowboys doing it all for her.Trey....who wouldn't swoon around a big hunky cowboy like him hanging around? There were many times throughout the story, when most men would have given up on Meri and just walked away, but not Trey. But then again; I guess Meri gave him enough laughs to keep him coming back to see what other precarious situations she could possibly get herself into next. Of course those heated kisses they shared probably had something to do with him wanting to hang around, too. lol!I also fell in love with a few of the secondary characters too like: Bandy,Trey's right hand man and ranch foreman, and then there was Meri's close friend, Samantha, and of course last but not least was Trey's sweet housekeeper, Consuelo.

I really love this series, and Nicky & Sam's story was a great addition. They have a long rocky road to get through before they can finally find their HEA, but IMO--nothing good or anything worth having....has ever came easy. I loved the ending of the story, but I did think it was a little rushed. Other than that; this was a very, very good story.

I loved this book! The suspense aspect of the story was a real nail biter, and because of all the twists and turns this story took, the suspense last almost throughout the whole story. It wasn't all intense though, there were a lot of laugh out loud moments, too, especially when Sally was with her over protective, macho brothers. Of course there's the great friendships between both the women and the men, too, and we get to watch Sally continue bamboozle more people into taking on rescue animals from the shelter. Heck, I think this woman is capable of selling ice cream to the Eskimo's! lol!Sally Gray has been surrounded by tall, dark, handsome men her entire life, after all....she grew up with three hulking brothers and a very protective father. So it's going to take a lot more than big muscles and a fondness for Irish Wolfhounds to make her fall for the man from Copper Creek. When she first meets Todd, she's not sure about leaving Max with him. The man is very good looking, but he's also seems to very disturbed by something. She has no clue to why he is the way he is, nor is she sure that she wants to know. But her first priority is Max, and to ensure his safety, she'll have to visit his ranch on a regular basis to make she Max is doing okay.Todd Randall had the perfect life; he had a very successful career as a commercial pilot which often took him around the world. He had a beautiful caring wife and son that he loved beyond words. Then in one terrifying night he was a witness to a horrible crime and suddenly everything changed. That was the night that Todd's whole life was turned upside down; the night that he lost the only two things that matter to him the most, his wife and his son. Todd has never been the same since. Then one day this woman shows up on his doorstep with the dog he has agreed to adopt from the local shelter, and suddenly his quiet, laid back life style is spinning out of control.This book was so emotional for me in many ways, but all of the hilarious antic's pulled by Sally and her friends help to balance this story out perfectly, for me. I really love this series, and all the stories so far have been so different and unique.If you haven't tried this series yet, I suggest you do so now. I promise, you won't be sorry you did.

This book was so, so powerful! Two very lost souls who end up in the same town, still trying to heal their wounded hearts. Will they be able to help each other become a whole person again? Or is it way too late for them to ever find peace and harmony in their lives again?After being rescued 3 yrs ago, Dylan Bayliss is still suffering severely from effects of being a torchered POW from the Taliban in Afghanistan. And because of his severe case of PTSD, he can't even stand to have anyone standing close to him, little less touching him.  He feels like a totally broken man and doesn't think he'll ever be able to become a normal man again. And then he meets a woman named, Annie O'Leary.......Annie got pregnant at the age of 16 and married a 31 yr. old man that comes from a family of wealth. But the family cuts him off for marrying her. They aren't married very long, when her husband quits his job and refuses to work again. Right after baby Ruby is born, they divorce and he moves back home with his parents. A few months later, Annie's whole world comes to a stop when a major tragedy takes place. She has never had a normal life, and her parents are basically usless when it comes to supporting her. Five yrs later she has found a new place to live and has found herself 3 really good friends to lean on. And then one day she's introduced to Logan's good friend, Dylan Bayliss.Annie's not sure what's going on with Logan's friend, Dylan Bayliss when she meets him for the first time, but she can plainly see that this man is as broken as she is. What caused him to be this way, she's not sure, but maybe there is a way she can help him, and in turn, maybe help herself. It's worth a try, but is she really ready to open herself up to the possiblity of pain due to failing once again?This story had me laughing so hard at everyone's wild antic's one minute, then bawling my eyes out during all those sweet tender moments the next. I love the camraderie of all the friends involved in this series; every one should have a few supporting friends like these in their lives.If you loved the 'Montana Bride's Series', you will love this series, too! Leeanna Morgan writes stories that contain all of the things that are important to her; good friends, family, a strong sense of community and a happy ending.I highly recommend this series to everyone, even if you haven't read her other series.

I loved this book! I have read all of  her 'Montana Bride's Books' series before this, and I loved them all. If all of the books in this series turns out to be half as good as her other series, then I'm going to be a very happy reader. I really, really loved the slow growing romance between Logan and Tess. I thought it was more realistic than the usual instant love some author's write about these days. By having these two meet and then grow from a trust worthy friendship first, and then slowly into a more romantic situation, just made it seem so much sweeter and so, so much more touching, at least for me.Now I can't wait to read about Annie & Dylan; this ought to be very interesting, for sure!

I thought that the story started out really good, a little different than I expected anyway with Chloe's house burning down and all. And while she's still at a loss of what to do about her living arrangements, she ends up meeting a really great guy, Derek, who just happens to be one of the firemen on the scene. He goes above and beyond and helps her find a place to stay.She moves in with his adopted family and they are all great, but then Derek starts to flip out over something that has to do with his house? I know the author tried to explain his reasons for acting that way, but ...IMO- his behavior just seemed way to extreme. And the way that he treated Chloe everytime she tried to ask about his childhood or his house was so unforgivable, if you ask me.Other than that one point, I thought this was a very good book. I loved the whole adoptive family. Emily and Rob were so, so sweet and understanding. I love how all their kids treated Derek like one of their own family members, and Rob & Emily did, too. And truthfully, I loved Derek & Chloe when they were together having a great time, at times the love between them even became so hot it was almost explosive!

Wow! I was thoroughly surprised by just how good this book was. I was drawn in from the first paragraph and hated it when I reached the end.  There were so many emotional moments, and I felt every one of them right along with the characters.I loved the closeness and protectiveness of the sisters, but I have to say Willa was my favorite of Thea's sisters. Lord have Mercy, she was such a hoot! I hated the turmoil between Calder and his brother, Peter, but then it's not surprising when you're dealing with a family member who is an alcoholic, but it came as no surprise to me when the source of the conflict in that story was revealed towards the end of the story. Those few very heart-felt, emotional moments between the brothers had me bawling like a baby. And also I loved the relationship between Marie and Peter, too.It wasn't perfect, but given the situation .....it was real.I really liked Calder and Thea together; and the fact that they had become good friends way before starting a romantic relationship, was a plus in my book.. This story has it all; laughter, sassy characters, and a sweet long over due romance.

I'm sitting here in Florida and it's in the 90's, but the descriptions in these stories actually had me shivering. I loved all three of these stories. I think everyone should have the chance to live in a small town just like this one, where people cared about one another as if they were all one big happy family. I, myself, lived in a very, very small town growing up and it was wonderful.I totally loved the three romances from all three of these wonderful authors, they were so sweet and very emotional. But the thing I loved the most was how well the stories connected and wove themselves together. Wonderful job ladies!I would highly recommend this collection to everyone!

I liked this story. It was so believable, and the characters were, too. There were times this story made me laugh, made me cry, and warmed my heart. The only thing that bothered me was the ending. I felt after all that build up, the ending felt a little abrupt. Other than that, it was a pretty good read.

I really enjoyed this box set. I had read about some of the San Francisco Carringtons, but I knew nothibng about the Island branch of the family. I thought that all four books in this box set were equally good. The situations and the characters all seemed very real to me, and the author made me feel as though I had been right there with them all. I could see the vibrant flowers, smell their wonderful fragrances. I could also feel the breeze on my face, hear the waterfalls plunging down from out of the mountain top, and see the crysatl clear waters and the bright blue skies. Yep, she took me there, for sure.

From some of the recent reviews, I didn't know whether or not to take a chance on this book, but I am soooo glad I did. I have to admit that  I thought Alexis was such a cold hearted woman, but as the story goes on we learn that Alexis has had some horrible losses and is just protecting her heart. Tyler however; was a total gem right from the beginning. He was tolerant and patient with Alexis, when most men would have just walked away. I wasn't sure I liked Alexis' family, either, but then after a while I realized that they were also hurt by the way their daughter and sister up and left for 17 years, without so much as a phone call or a letter.The only thing that disappointed me, was that I wished the author would have written a short epilogue at the end. I would have loved to know how things worked out down the road for these two.

I loved everything about this book from beginning to end. Lots of humor and heart-warming moments. I love the sassiness of the female characters, and the last minute suspense was really good, too. I had never read anything by this author before, but you can rest assured that this won't be the last book I read of hers. Totally impressed!

I don't like stories that continue to jump from the past to the present. I understand laying out the history, but to go back and forth with each chapter is just way too much for me. Why not just start the story off with a prologue and be done with it? I liked the main characters just fine, but I felt there was just too much on again, off again drama going on.

I started off reading this all out of order. I got Matt's story free from BookBub, and I liked it so much I went back and found out that there was a christmas book that was also free. So natually I had to get that one, too. By that time I was completely hooked, so rather than by the first few books seperately, I opted to buy this box set, and boy am I glad I did!Every single person in the Alexander Family are so warm, giving, and very lovable, as are those lost souls that they have taken in over the years as one of their own. After having read Matt's story and the Christmas story, I was a little bit disappointed in this set though. Not the love matches persay, but with all the over the top sex scenes. I'm not a prude, I love the Hot sex scenes as much as anyone else, but there were times in the first two stories where I finally started to skip through those scenes. At least we were warned about the story with Trent & Mara, and yes, I skimmed through that story, also.Other than that, though, I love this series!

The whole Alexanders family is so dynamic, you can't help but feel like you're apart of the love too! I love Christmas time and all the festivities that go along with it, but most especially, getting to spend quality time with family & friends. Eli has me a bit confused at times. He can help but think & worry about Kaylee 24/7, yet whenever she gets near.... he runs.As for Kaylee? I feel so bad for her because her life has not always been a bowl full of cherries. And that in itself will help you grow up very quickly. So, as far as I'm concerned? The differences in their ages should never have been a point of contention for these two.

This book had me hooked right from the first page, and it didn't let up until the very last word. This book has angst, humor, sexy times, and love. What more could you ask for? I really like Penny, her character was strong enough not to put up with anyones crap. She knew what she wanted in life, and she went for it. My heart went out to Matt and all he'd been put through, but I loved that he still had the ability to make jokes, or at least keep his emotions hidden from his friends and family. Not that thats a good thing, but when you're somewhere trying to support your friends, it's not a good thing to bring them all down with you, either.Thankfully, Penny was able to see right through him, just as he did her. These two were a match from heaven. I liked this book so much, that I just went back and ordered this whole series.I would highly recommend this book, and this series to everyone!

I loved this book! It's was a clean romance story. This story  also had a little humor added in, along with a touch of mystery and suspense. There were a few very sad moments in this story, but it's not the kind that would leave you feeling depressed for days. I think it was because there were much more happier moments to balance the story out.I loved Louisa and Justin, but I also liked all of the secondary characters, which for me is a big deal. But the thing that really caught my attention was the ending. I would have never ever expected anything like that. It really caught me by surprise, and I totally loved every minute of it.

Do not bother with this box set, unless you love porno. It's a set of five books about nothing more than sex, sex, and sex. The whole set is only 195 pages altogether, so that should tell you something, and not a story line among the whole bunch. It's advertised as Romance. Well where I come from romance is about much more than just sex.

WARNING!!!!!!!This is only part of a book, you have to buy the next few installments to get the whole story. I really, really, despise that tacit, and won't be buying anything else by this author.In fact; I don't have any idea why there are so many 4 & 5 star ratings. This book was all about sex, thinking about sex, or talking about sex. Aren't these people suppose to be from a rich shipping conglomerate or some such thing? Funny, I never once heard them talk about their business. As far as I'm concerned, this whole dysfunctional family has got a lot of mental issues they need to seek professional help for.The book just seems to jump all over the place, and nothing makes much sense, except these guys love sex....all kinds of kinky sex with any female they can find. It read more like a porno flick, but even those sometimes have a story line, which was lacking here.I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone, period!

I loved this book! Stack is this big macho MMA fighting machine, who is easily taken down by a little bitty woman like Vanity. I liked the fact they even though she had lost her whole family, she didn't turn into a whiner. And even though she was loaded, money wise, she never flaunted it. I loved Stack's mad dysfunctional family and the network of MMA fighters he surrounds himself with. One of the things I especially liked was the close male friendships that Vanity has developed with some of the fighters. That's probably because I grew up in a neighborhood where there were only a few females around to relate to. Mostly our neighborhood was filled with these kinds of guys, only they didn't belong to the MMA, but they were big ole sports jocks. Being one of the biggest tom boys around, they included me in most of their sporting activities. So even after I had grown into my adulthood years, it was a lot easier for me to relate more to them than with the female demographic.I can't wait to see how the situation between Armie & Rissy works out. The way they were acting in this story, it ought to be very explosive! As an extra added bonus, Tough Love features a novella from Ms. Foster's Buckhorn series. This was also another amazing series by Lori Foster.I would highly recommend this book to everyone!

All I can say is WOW! WOW! WOW! This book is a little more serious than all of Ms. Graykowski's other books, but IMO- it's the best one yet. And that's saying something because I thought all of her other books were fantastic! This one though, for some reason just seemed to touch my heart much, much more than all the others did.In this book Ms. Graykowski tackles a few very delicate issues, and she does it with all of the dignity and respect they deserve. One of those issues deals with what it feels like for a woman who gives birth to a child, only to end up losing that child within minutes after their birth. Another is issues of both abandonment & self-destruction. And last but not least, is the issue of abuse. Lord knows there are millions of people in the world that has had to deal with at least one or more of these issues during their lifetime.But this story isn't all dark and depressing, far from it in fact. There are plenty of humous things going on, even though some of them happened to be laughing through while they are still shedding tears. The scenes with little 3 yr. old Julia were otut and out hysterical, and she also brought a lot of joy throughout this whole story. And of course there's Sweet Louise, and really....who can get too serious with her around? I love this woman to pieces and want to be just like her one day. She sure has a way of making those big Alpha males cringe like they're just little school girls. We also got to re-visit with some of our other favorite characters in the past books, as well as meeting a few new ones along the way.I can almost guarantee you that this book we have you laughing one minute, and crying the next.Debra Covington was raised in a rich, but loveless household. But one day after defying her hard-core father's wishes, she is sent out on the streets with nothing more than the clothes on her back. And she was pregnant to boot! Who does that to their own child? Nine months later after having lost her baby, the man she loves, the respect of her father, and her favorite Aunt.....she sets out on a life of self- destruction. Over the next 10 years Debra continues to blame herself for everything. I was so engrossed with this character that I felt like just wanted to reach through the pages and give Debra a huge bear hug, as she was going through all of this.I couldn't really blame Warren for his part in all of this. He was young and had the whole world on his shoulders at the time. Besides; Debra's father completely lied to the guy, and more than once! In the end, Warren turned out to be perfect for Debra. Okay maybe he was just a little bit flawed in his way of thinking, but after finding out the whole truth......he really started working very hard to make their relationship work.It's no surprise that Katie Graykowski has become one of my favorite author's. Her stories will warm your heart, and having you rolling with laughter. Her characters are always funny, lovable, and can even become downright awkward at times, but always such a joy to read about.I would HIGHLY recommend not only this book, but this whole series, to everyone!

I liked this book, but I didn't quite love it.First let me list the things I did like:*I thought that Rebecca and Patrick were very likable characters, and I also fell in love with those little kiddo's, too.*I like the fact that Rebecca wasn't some weak whiny heroine. She was a strong, smart, beautiful young woman raising her daughter on her own, and needed no one to fend for her.*Patrick had a very dangerous job as a Navy Seal, but he was also a very dedicated father, who was also left on his own to raise his young son. In some cases with a death of a parent or even when a divorce takes place, the surviving parent usually cuts ties with the other grandparents. But that didn't happen in this case, which was a very nice change.*I loved the undeniable chemistry between Rebecca and Patrick. They were both acted very mature, and didn't make any moves without taking in the consideration of how their actions would affect their childrens lives.Now having said that, this is the things that bothered me:*This book was listed as a Romantic/ Suspense, but as far as I'm concerned the suspense part of the story was very, very weak. It was like it was almost over and done with, before it really even really got started.* And while I loved the story line, the ending left a little bit to be desired. It just felt so rushed. I couldn't believe when I turned the page and it was over. I went back thinking I must have missed a few pages, but nope...it just ended. There was somewhat of an HEA, I guess. It just wasn't what I thought it should be.Over all, though, I think this was still a pretty good read.

I have been waiting for this book for what seems forever. Ty and Hailey have generated so much spark and innuendos in all of the other books. So much so that you just knew there was something going on between the two of them. But I never expected this book to be so HOT!!!! It was also funny, and at times, very heart-breaking.Ty always seemed so playful and mischievous; the complete opposite of the up tight Hailey, for sure. Therefore, I couldn't figure out how these two characters could ever meld together, but now I do.At first I wasn't too crazy about Hailey, but she sort of grew on me as times passed. After reading this book, she's one of my favorite characters, so far in this series....other than Kathy that is. ;)Kathy, Ty's mother, just cracks me up! She's the kind of mother that never pulls any punches when telling her kids just how it is, but she's the kind of mother everyone dreams of having. The scene on the back doorstep on that first early Sunday morning, had me rolling on the floor with laughter. I guess this woman really had her work cut out for her, after raising those 4 HOT Bennett boys. Whew!!!Loved this book, but moreover; I love this whole series. Each book just keeps getting better and better. Keep them coming.

Robyn Carr books are like no other. She has a way of pulling you in, and making you feel like you are part of the story. She seems to really excel when it comes to small town settings, and this series is no exception. She writes about such unique characters, all of facing real-life problems while dealing with all their own emotions and fears. I love all these characters because they all seem to have the same hopes and dreams that each of us can relate to. And in just like her 'Virgin River Series', this series she has once again created another beautiful, emotionally compelling snapshot of life in the close-knit community, only this time the setting takes place in Thunder Point, Oregon.At first I sort of felt so sorry for Lin Su, but when she started playing the "mommy" card with Charlie I lost all respect for her. She's just lucky Charlie didn't run away, or worse. So she didn't have the greatest childhood, she's far being alone in that aspect. And I'm sure getting pregnant and having no family support must have been hard on her, but there are thousands of other women in the world that have had it just as bad, or even worse, and they don't act that way.I did however; love the character of Blake. IMO- He had it so much worse than Lin Su ever did. But rather than acting like a crazed person, he not only pulls himself up by his boot strings and makes something of himself, he also starts a program that reaches out to help kids that are living in simular situations.It is always fun visiting Thunder Point again. We get revisited some of our favorite characters from the other eight books in the series, and we were able to catch up on their lives.Now I can't wait for the next book!

This story might have been short, but it lacked for nothing. It was a quick moving story and it kept my attention all the way through. Annamae is a great character, she had an inner strength about her. I can't say I blamed her from running away the way she did. The lack of privacy would have drove me crazy within a week's time, and she had put up with it most of her life.I thought that Wynn was very interesting in his own kind of way.  Being a cop and hiding out in a small town, the last thing he needs is cameras pointed his way. After all; he's in hiding until he has to testify against a mob kingpin.
