When Annamae had shown up unexpectedly like she did, he realizes the best way to keep everything contained is by keeping her close.The hot chemistry between the two of them was so undeniable right from the very start, so of course it really doesn't take long after that before things heat up very quickly between the two them.I have to say; I fell in love her feisty grandmother. She wasn't afraid to speak the truth no matter what, or who it involved. She was also a very hip when it came to the younger generation.  Go Grandma!

I really, really enjoyed this box set. I also found a few really, really good author's that I hadn't heard of before, and will be checking out their other works in the near future. I know some of you have reviewed a few of the books in this set, but I thought I would break them all down for those of you who may be on the fence about buying this box set. So here's my reviews for all the books in this set.Having My Baby---By Theresa Ragan  I gave this story 5 stars, it was just that good!This was such a cute story with a few good laughs along the way. While in college a struggling Derrick Baylor opted to donate his blood to the local blood bank and his seman to the CryoCorp company for extra money to hold him over. Almost immediate afterwards he had huge change of heart and had immediately wrote a letter telling them to remove him from their donor list and had also included the money they had given him. He thought all was well; until he recieved another letter years later stating that the sperm he had donated had been sold.Jill Garrison never expected the annoynous sperm donor to show up wanteing to lay claim to her unborn child, but that's exactly what happened when she was only a few weeks away from her due date. The shock of having a strange man show up at a park where her and her friends were gathered, threw Jill into a tizzy. She passes out and then if that wasn't bad enough, her water broke sending her into an early labor.This story ends up in a battle of wills, but who will win? Will it be Derrick? Jill? Or will they all win in the end?Getting Lucky--by Katie Graykowski  I would give this story a 10 plus star rating if I could, it's just that good!This story is so heart-breaking, but also very funny at the same time. Sounds weird, I know, but you'll just have to read it to see what I mean. Lucky's two long time friends Betts and Charlie, and the woman known as Mama, is so dang hysterical! The three little girls will also surely melt your heart, and if that doesn't peak your interest, I'm sure the sparks that fly between Will and Lucky will do the trick.Lucky Strickland was married to a music star for seventeen years. All she ever really wanted though was for him to love her and raise a big family together. But that didn't happen because she found out that she had Cervicle Cancer and had to have an emergency Hysterectomy. So imagine her shock when she learns on live T.V no less, that her now deased husband had been living a double life since the day they were first married. Not only did he cheat on her with his long time mistress, but they had three daughters together. Then the biggest shock of all came, when the will was read and she found out that she was left viturally broke and all alone. Her cheating husband had left everything they had left---well  except the contents of her personal closet---to the three children he left behind.THE MEMORY OF YOU--  BY Laurie Kellogg--- I give this a 5 star rating, also.For me this was a very powerful story that really hit home. I grew up in the era of the Veitnam War, and several of my friends lives were either lost in that battle, or they came back as totally different people. The soldiers of today don't get the best support from the government or the people, but back then those soldiers were hated by most of the public, and left hanging out to dry so to speak, by our own Goverment officials who sent them there in the first place. Sad I know, but oh so true.For those of us who remember Operation Homecoming, it's a reminder of what our brave veterans endured without hitting us over the head with it. This story was very funny in some places, and very, very heart-rending in others. But the heart-warming tales of Abby, Matt, little Matthew, as well as Little Roury, just goes to prove that  the idea that love can, indeed, conquer all.JOCKEYS AND JEWELS---BY BEV PETERSEN  I give this story a 4.5 star rating.Kurt MacKinnon was a great cop but he has moved on to be a very successful horse trainer. When his ex-partner Connor dies while investigating something dodgy in the horse industry, Kurt tries to find out what went wrong. His knowledge of horse racing ought to give him an inside edge.Julie might have been an adult but she was written as if she were a naive teenager. She is trying to make a name for herself as a rider and so is willing to ride mistreated animals and tolerate abuse from trainers. She clearly has talent but has to fight against gender discrimination to get decent mounts.Pettersen dealt with the serious issue of animal abuse but I found it upsetting that none of the characters reported the abuser to authorities or really tried to stop it. Hence the 4.5 star rating.OPERATION: DATE ESCAPE---BY LINDSEY BROOKES  I give this a 5 star rating, also.After her divorce from a lying, cheating scum bucket, Kelsie Collins has a problem being set up on to many blind dates by both her mother, and her best friend. Each time she went on a blind date, things became worse than they were the last time. Hence the reasn for writing her book of ways to escape a bad date. Then she meets Cole Maxwell, a real hot looking fireman that she wants nothing to do with.  After all; her ex was a good looking man, and look where that got her....she was left with nothing but a big ole heart-ache.Cole Maxwell isnt sure what to think when the sexy redhead hes just rescued from a bad date informs him that hes too perfect to date. Thats a first. Hes had relationships end because the women couldnt handle the risks that go along with his chosen profession, but never because hes too perfect.  But he's too infatuated by this little "china Doll", as he  likes to call her,  to  ever give up on her.This is one of the most comical stories I've read lately. The things Kelsie gets herself into is hysterical. Her friend Nanci with an "i" is a real character, too. I love the camraderie wth the  men at the firehouse. Her mother sort of got on my nerves here and there, but I think that happens with most mothers. Cole was the perfect hero in this story. He was so understanding, patient, and very caring with Kelsie. He was also very funny at times, too. And the chemistry between these two was explosive!THE GOOD DAUGHTER---BY DIANE LAYNE  I give this a 4 star rating, but only because I felt it drug on a bit too long.The best part about The Good Daughter is that you actually get two romances for the price of one! I really felt for the heroine, who wants so badly to do good but she's stuck in a world of evil with only one way out--to bring down her father. But I was also drawn to the famous (and super hot) soccer player whose wife was being held hostage by the mafia.The story has a number twists and turns, along with surprises, both good and bad. Like I said before, it was a very good action packed story, but it just drug on a bit too long, at least it did for me.SEIZED BY DARKNESS---BY AUTUMN JORDEN  I give this story a 4 star rating also.I would have love to see even a short epilouge at the end, to let us know more about their HEA. To me; the ending just felt too rushed.This is a story that touches on one of the most horrible practices still going strong today. Human trafficking has been a problem since the beginning of time and unfortunately it is still making immoral people a lot of money. It was really hard to read some of it, because it just broke my heart. At the same time I was awed by the bravery of Nicole in getting them all of harms way, and into safety.MEET YOUR MATE---BY JACIE FLOYD  I give this story a 5 star rating.This story was so much fun to read.Annabel Morgan and Max Williams have already met. They have even worked together in the past. Now, when her step-daughter wants to set her up with a hunk of a man before leaving for college, she chose of all people - Mad Max.These two couldn't have more different if they tried. While she was an uptight,  straight-laced woman with practically no social life or sex life, what so ever. Max on the other hand likes to live more on the wild side, and he has the reputation for being a love 'em & leave 'em kind of man.The things that these two get into, and the things they put each other through on their dates, will have you laughing your butts off. This story just seemed to flow so effortlessly. I have never read anything by this author until now, but I love her style and her humor. I will tell you this though, she just earned herself a new fan.LOVE & OREO'S----BY ELIZABETH BEMIS  I give this story a 4.5 star rating.This story was so sweet and heart-warming. It's a story about accepting  people for who they are, not what they look like....but what's inside that person.Quinn grew up as a chubby little guy, but in his junior year of college he became sick of being picked on, so he decided to change his image. He lose a whopping 85lbs and turned himself into a fitness guru. Now he own 6 very successful gyms around town.Katherine had always been over-weight, and had been made the butt of every joke in school. The more she was teased, the more she ate. Then one day at a job fair she met a greek god and couldn't believe he actually gave her a second look. Although...he wasn't quite as honest with her about who he was. He gave her a false name for one, and secondly, the next day she was completely blind-sided when she found out that the man who own Mitchell's gyms was the same man she'd met the day before, and was also her new client.To say that she was upset, would be an huge understatement.  But if they can't put their differences aside, their working relationship would be a total loss. These two were hilarious, and there were more than just romantic fireworks going on between these two. Katherine was nobody's pushover. She gave as good as she got, and then some!MARRYING MR. PERFECT---BY LIZZIE SHANE  I give this story a 4 star rating.This story was sort of cute but also very heart-wrenching, at the same time. I felt so bad for Lou, and who wouldn't? She had been so in love with Jack for what seemed like forever. Yet she couldn't bring herself to say a word or act upon her feelings for him because for one, her fear of being rejected...and two, for fear of losing her best friend.Jack on the other hand, feels guilty about letting his friend sacrifice her own life in order to take care of him and his children after his wife had died. So needless to say; that when another friend comes to visit and tells him about a show she's producing, he agrees to accept a spot on that dating show. But only does so because he feels like he needed to find himself a wife---so he could set Lou free so she could finally find her own happiness in life. Little did he know that the only  love and happiness Lou really wanted to find, was with him and his children.I highly recommend this box set to everyone!

I really, really loved this book. The pain and anguish Paul has to go through with his mother, just broke my heart. And then if that wasn't enough, Hope walks into his life and just when he thinks he can have it all....she starts to pull away. It was hard to hate Hope for her actions, because I could see where she's coming from, too. It would be so hard to try to trust someone again, especially after what she was put through.Throughout all the books Marie Force has written to date, her characters have always been about strong, committed people who have strong morals and values. They don't tear each other down, but rather they lift them up when things get tough, support each other and cheer each other on in whatever their next endevour my be. The women aren't catty or the jealous types. The men and women alike; will gladly jump in and help with any project when they're needed.And Marie Force isn't afraid to tackle a few delicate issues, either. This time it happens to be about a mother of two grown men, who is suffering from the effects of Dementia. Not an easy subject, for sure, because this disease not only affects the person going through this horrible disease, but it also takes a major toll on their family and their friends lives, too. I thought that Marie did a good job walking us thru the disease of Dementia. Marie also has the cany ability to seamlessly weave multiple story lines throughout the book while tackling these tough subjects. When you read her books, you can't help being sucked into the story so deeply, that you feel like you personally know these people. Every time I pick up a new book in the series, it feels like going back home to catch up with all my family and friends, once again.Her books are always filled with laughter, tears, joy, hope, and most of all.... happiness. I have read every single book that Marie has written so far, but I think the "Gansett Island" series will always be my favorite. Just like Maddie & Mac will always be my favorite couple. Although....The "Green Mountain" series is also a very fantastic series, too. I am getting hooked more and more on this series, with every new addition added to the series.I hope and pray that Marie will never stop writing the Gansett series though, because that would surely break my heart! I can't even imagine not being able to go back to visit the McCarthy family and friends ever again..

IMO- "The Keeneston Roses" far exceeds all of the others in this series. If you haven't read all of the books in this series yet, you may find yourselves feeling a bit lost. But for those of us who have followed this series religiously right from the very beginning, this was an amazing treat. The Rose sister's have been abig part of every book in this series and yet, we never had the opportunity before now to find out why they never married, or how they lived their lives were while growing up in the town.This book finally gives us all those answers, and more. We not only get to know what happened to them to make them become the wonderful women they are now, but we also got to see part of their future, and their long over due HEA's, too.And as happy as I am to finally get to see the things that happened to them many years ago, it also made me sort of sad to know that with their advanced aging, we probably won't be seeing much of Rose sisters in the future books. And I, for one; will miss them immensely. I know it won't feel the same without them, but then again I have complete faith in the ability of Kathleen Brooks to pull us through into the next generation. I know that she will somehow find a way to make this series continue to come alive, and keep it just as interesting as she has done in the past. I know that the townspeople will keep the spirits of Rose sisters alive for a long time to come, if only in their hearts and fond memories of times past. I don't think there's one single person in that town, that the Rose sisters haven't reached out touch deeply somewhere along the way.I know that I'll stick around just to watch the fun unfold. It will be very interesting to watch the reactions of these wonderful, but very powerful parents as they deal with the love lives of their children. ::Smirk:: And God help all those children and their love interests along the way, 'cos Lord knows they'll need all the need all the help they can get in they are ever to survive their interfearing parents! LOL!

If you're looking for a good, well written romance series with added humor, this series is perfect for you. After reading the previous two books in this series; it was clear that Mac "Maverick" Maven, whose plan to restore the old mountain hotel to its former glory, including hosting top-level poker tournaments with his buddy's several times a year, and Dare's Deputy Sheriff, Peggy McBride have definite sparks flaring between them.When these two get together, it's explosive! They are just as heated with their disagreements, as they are between the sheets. I am really, really enjoying this series. There are lots of laughs, steamy romances, and many interesting and wonderful secondary characters you'll instantly fall in love with, too.

What I love most about Ms. Chastain's writing is that no matter what she writes, she crafts strong unwavering Southern characters. While Southern Man was contemporary Southern fiction, Love in Smallfoot Alley is a contemporary novel with a dash of sci-fi or paranormal, and it delighted me that I was able to enjoy the same bold and true characterization that was feature in Southern mind. Ms. Chastain writes with the realization that "it takes all kinds to make a world", and you'll find within her books all kinds of relatable people from your everyday life. There was a hard-to-win romantic angle as a subplot that kept me turning pages until the end because I simply had to know if a certain heart would be thawed, and I was also captivated by the paranormal subplot. If you enjoy Southern contemporary fiction and Michael Crichton as I do, I don't see how this story could possibly let you down.

The texture was terrible--waxy, like a cheap crayon. The color wouldn't stay on for five minutes. The odor was nauseating. Maybe it had spoiled. I don't know why the lip color had so many issues when so many other vegan lip colors are great. Just choose a different brand, and you should be happier than if you purchased this one!

I purchased this after my children and I had a delightful experience with the Insect Lore Butterfly Garden. I really wish that I had heeded the reviews on this product and saved myself some cash and my children disappointment. I ordered the ladybugs standard delivery and they all arrived alive and well. We put them in the habitat with their food and placed precisely the amount of water required on the sponge in the top of the habitat. Within 2 days, half had stopped moving--and they weren't pupating either. Within one day, a third more had met the same grisly fate. At present we have two ladybugs that appear to be trying to pupate, but we aren't holding our breath that this experiment is going to pan out. The habitat is poorly and cheaply designed. The plastic top doesn't sit all the way down on the base, and the ladybugs get trapped under the rim of the lid. The sponge for their water dries out way too fast. You are only supposed to add water every day and a half, but that wasn't enough for my bugs. In 24 hours, the sponge was completely dry. The food included wasn't enough to get them to pupate. They ate it all up, and the instruction manual said you could give them raisins after they emerged as ladybugs, but there wasn't enough nourishment to get them to that state. It was like a poorly done terrarium, the Shady Pines of the bug world-- the final home for little critters who won't get proper care.

This iron is okay for the money. We mostly iron khakis, jeans, blouses, and button up shirts at our house. This iron heats up quickly, and I like the steam function. It also holds more water than some of my previous irons so I get the pleasure of filling it up less. It also seems to do a great job on utilizing all the different fabric settings. However, it started leaking water on the second use. To be fair, I've never owned an iron that didn't leak, but by now, you'd think I'd finally find an iron that doesn't leak everywhere. It does it's job, but I don't think I'll be purchasing this again.

I am a novice when it comes to survival skills and disaster readiness. I bought this book after several word of mouth recommendations and couldn't be happier with it. It covers a little bit of everything from preparing shelters and fires to surviving a lightening storm or recognizing venomous creatures. I disagree with some of the negative reviews that state the information is too shallow. This is a big book, designed to give you in a running start in any situation. An entire book could conceivably be written about any survival skill in the book, and no one needs a set of survival encyclopedias for their bug out bag. This is a thick book, possibly too heavy for your bag, as it is. If you want an excellent place to begin honing your knowledge, this book is it. It's the best guide I've seen.

Wolf Dawson is a masterfully told Southern Gothic that will have you turning pages and telling yourself "just one more chapter" until you reach the end. I finished this book in about an hour and a half because I was that invested in the characters and couldn't bear not to find out what happened to them. The conclusion left me breathless and it was a real surprise--I'd pegged the crimes on a completely different character.Wolf Dawson is the story of the Dawson and Seaton families, two local families with plenty of reasons for a deep-seated grudge. Wolf Dawson supposedly died during the Civil War, but now he's home and owner of the enviable Seaton home. Juliet Seaton meets Dawson at the river when a marauding wolf is on the loose and sets into motion a ghostly whodunit that offends the sensibilities of the whole town.If you want a suspenseful, dark, romantic story that will keep you up until the witching hour, this is it. The genre of Southern Gothic fiction is incomparable in the hands of Charlsie Russell. She can't write them fast enough for me.

I found this book to be engaging, interest, and well-written. Sometimes nonfictional accounts can be too dry and fail to capture the personalities of the people involved, but Into Thin Air doesn't suffer from that in the slightest. The prose is rich and highly readable while the characterization is riveting. The book teaches the reader in great detail about the history of mountaineering Everest without getting too heavy or textbookish. I found myself unable to stop reading until I had reached the end. The only true disappointment to me was the epilogue or appendix during which Mr. Krakauer defends the validity of his book. I didn't realize when I bought the book, that it is highly controversial. It seems that most of the climbers dispute each other's memories of what exactly happened on that disastrous climb. I think they should leave the argument behind and realize that in the midst of a storm of that magnitude at that altitude with that lack of supplies and oxygen that the truth will never be known, they will always be at the mercy of whatever their oxygen-deprived brains concocted at the time. Nevertheless, I intend to read some of the rival accounts. This book was a fascinating study of an intense survivalist situation.

I discovered how serious my allergies are after a visit to the allergist this summer, and I began researching all the ways to make myself more comfortable. I was a real skeptic when it came to air purifiers. I bought this one primarily because it releases zero ozone. We have a suspected asthmatic in the house, and ozone can aggravate breathing. I set it up with the suspicion that I had flushed close to two hundred dollars down the toilet. Then after a few hours, I noticed the air was markedly different in the living room and kitchen. It felt easier to breathe. I felt like I was taking deeper breaths, the kind you're supposed to take. That night, my husband who hadn't wanted me to buy it, said his chest felt better. My kids didn't cough as they fell asleep that night. And by the next day, I saw less dust and particles in the air. Before I knew it, I no longer needed Benadryl to supplement my prescription antihistamines. My husband turned it off for a day while he did some work in the living room, and in two hours we were all coughing. I'm a believer. Is it noisy? A little. It reminds me of a box unit air conditioner, but I like the white noise. The front latch is clumsily done as a lot of reviewers have stated. I haven't had to tape it on yet, but I suspect I will. This purifier may not improve the quality of your life the way it has mine. Research shows that air purifiers are tremendously helpful for some and not at all for others. But I plan on buying another Honeywell for my bedroom.

This monitor is one of the poorest calibrated I have ever used. I am well aware of the frequent fluctuations in blood pressure we all naturally have, but if this monitor is correct, I should have been dead last week. I suffer from low blood pressure, and in the course of an hour, I received the following readings: 90/80, 216/127, 87/63, 127/98, and 103/78. I followed the instructions on how to position the cuff meticulously so that wasn't the issue. This monitor wasn't even within 20 points of what the physician got in the office. Don't risk your money on this inaccurate device.

Summer in the South was a good read. A Northern girl spends the summer on the Southern estate of her wealthy friend and uses the time to get to know his quirky, eccentric family. While there, the details of family history she picks up inspire her to write a different novel and solve an ages old mystery that has haunted the family.The writing was good, and most of the character development was competent, especially in the older generation. I felt like some of the younger generation was neglected slightly in development because they were so busy trying to ferret out the secrets of their predecessors. All in all, I recommend the book to those who enjoy cozy mysteries or a good Southern tale. The flow was slightly rough in places and some loose ends could have been tied up better, but this is a very interesting novel.

I recently purchased an older edition Bible that I've had trouble finding at a reasonable price, and when I located one, you can be sure that I wanted to protect it! This is the case it will go in. I feel that the case is only so-so in quality. I think the exterior material looks inexpensive and not durable. I expect it to flake after a while. I do like the handle quite a bit. It seems sturdy. Unlike several reviewers, I am not having any issues with the zipper skipping or being too stiff. There is a little mesh pocket on the interior that I can't imagine being useful for much other than a few hard candies or very short highlighting pencils, but I like the outer pocket on the case. It will easily accommodate church bulletins. The pen/pencil holder is also fine. I think this case is best for someone with a lighter weight Bible or someone who doesn't want to lug the extras of a notepad and other study items. I seem to prefer the convenience of a trifold Bible cover with organizer now that I own two Bible covers, and I probably wouldn't purchase this one again.

I recently purchased two study Bibles and wanted to protect them in a case that would allow me to "grab and go" when Sunday morning came, and I have to say with one tiny flaw this one really fit the bill. I use the Thomas Nelson NKJV Study Bible, 2nd edition. My measurements came in at 6.75 X 9.5 X 2.1 inches. My Bible fit into this case with a little wiggle room to spare. I followed another reviewers suggestion to go ahead and buy the XL if you had a Bible that would fit a size L but intended to carry lots of extras. I am blown away by the trifold design. I can accommodate a good sized notepad, business cards, church programs, a pen, and even accommodate my spare set of glasses. My case didn't have a noticeably strong nylon odor as some reviewers had noted, and it looks like the kind of case that will stand up to minor spills and messes (I have two small kids). I do take issue with the Velcro closure. I think it is the only aspect of this case that was not done well. I can see it slipping open if you have loaded the case with a heavy Bible and extra stuff. If Zondervan had put a snap on this case, I would have given it a 5 star review. That being said, I would purchase the case again and may purchase a size L for a smaller Bible.

Nom Nom Paleo is officially my go to Paleo cookbook. My husband and I embarked on the Paleo journey two weeks ago. We ordered this book and three others. This book scores major points with us for actually being a hardcover with sewn binding and thick durable pages. While I do enjoy my other Paleo books, the quality was the worst of cheap and they all had tattered binding within one week. Short of cramming Nom Nom Paleo down a garbage disposal, this book is meant for the actual, heavy kitchen use.The book is divided into the following sections: introduction (very basic paleo intro); building blocks (like mayo, sriracha, and other meal builders); nibbles; salads and soups; eggs; plants; seafood; poultry; meat; and treats. Amusing and insightful blurbs precede each recipe, and the photography is top level quality. Little cartoons and asides educate and delight throughout the book.I have made mayo, a real keeper and super simple as well as the Peruvian roast chicken with aji verde sauce. I think my husband thought twice about peeling all the crispy skin off the bird and devouring it all in one meal. We are also big, big fans of her Liar bars, a snack/energy bar knock off. Every recipe is clearly explained and well written. I see several reviews bemoaning the lack of protein, but there are twenty something protein recipes and that excludes the eggs and seafood chapters. Paleo isn't a free pass to scarf down all of your calories through meat. A wide variety of vegetables and some fruits and nuts should round you out.If I owned only one Paleo book, this would be it. If you are a newbie like me looking for the cookbook to get you started, I think this should be the book. Most of the ingredients were easily attainable for me in my small town grocery store with the exception of coconut aminos...and Amazon can help you out with obtaining those if you can't procure them. I adore this book, and I have my fingers crossed for another one. I read on the author's blog that she was quitting her job as a pharmacist so here is hoping she'll produce another book soon.

This book rocked, and if you enjoy a trilogy that builds on the merits on character development and suspense rather than weepy melodrama and awkward necking, then this is the series for you. Seriously, if you're picking this up as a "kissing book", you'll be disappointed...buy something else. This novel is about suspenseful plot building.Blue Sargent, a charming and self-possessed girl, in a house full of psychics, has always been told that if she kisses her true love, he'll die. She lacks the fortune telling abilities of her relatives but possesses the remarkable ability to sharpen any other psychics' gifts. She is independent and likes herself. She's no shrinking violet, hoping that next year she'll be school beauty.Her world changes when a Raven boy from Aglionby crosses her path. She has seen him on St. Mark's Eve which means he's her true love or she'll kill him. Blue wants neither...especially regarding an Aglionby guy.The Raven boys are headed by Gansey, a strange mixture of modern day wealth and old world charm. He's obsessed with finding and awaking the ley line that he believes King Glendower is buried on. Legend has it that Glendower will grant a favor to the person who awakens him. Gansey's pals: foerce, brooding Ronan; poor, abused Adam; and quiet, mysterious Noah round out the group on his quest to find the king. When Gansey leaves behind his scholarly journal of notes and Blue finds it, their paths converge on an adventure that will adjust everyone's relationships and self-perceptions.This novel is the first in a trilogy. The emphasis is on character and plot building. There is action and fantasy elements but they are sprinkled in as seasoning instead of constantly engaging the reader. It makes the story more believable. As soon as I finished the novel, I reread it, and it was even more fun. The author does an amazing job with foreshadowing and dropping little breadcrumbs for the reader to pick up before a major plot reveal--and she still managed to surprise me several times.Now go buy this book if you enjoy quality more than making out and a novel that builds into a second book that doesn't slump with the dreaded "sequel slump". These books are worth the journey, people.

I am a newbie to the Paleo lifestyle. Well Fed is one of two books that I purchased to guide me in this new way of taking care of myself after developing health problems that I think, in part, are to be blamed by my previous carbohydrate-reliant way of eating.Well Fed is a paper back book that looks very small and thin. Don't be deceived! This little book is jam-packed with recipes. You could probably get by fairly well on cooking supper for a very long time if this was the only Paleo book you owned. It is divided into the following sections: very basic intro to Paleo; the weekly cookup; sauces and seasonings; protein; veggies and salads; fruits; and resources.Many of Joulwan's recipes are "hot plates", meaning a  precooked protein, several cups of  steam-sauteed veggies, and an accompaniment such as cauliflower rice or zucchini noodles that are seasoned with one of several delightful spice combinations and perhaps an accompanying sauce. The spice and the sauce gives a cultural spin to the dish depending on what you pick so you get to eat French one night and Moroccan the next. These recipe suggestions are grouped together on a couple of pages with the techniques for cooking your desired protein, sauce, spice, and veggies on separate pages located throughout the book. If you are someone who does not like flipping through cookbooks to make a meal (and I know you're on here), this book is not for you. I don't mind it at all. Joulwan does lots of prep work one day per week and cooks her veggies and proteins and stores them in the fridge for quick assembly and heating throughout the workweek. This technique may not be for those who are very busy. There are tons of recipes in addition to her hot plates technique, and they will delight.The first thing I made was the Deconstructed Hamburger salad. You better believe it was tasty. I topped it with Joulwan's homemade mayo, and I nearly swooned with delight. I've been afraid of making mayo for years, but it took 5 minutes of my life and was extraordinary. My husband ate seconds of the salad and asked that I prepare it again. I also made the Moroccan grilled chicken plate over cauliflower rice and made the Moroccan dipping sauce. Talk about a trip to foreign country from your dinner table! It takes me a bit longer now to prepare meals, but it is worth it to feel better. One thing the author could do in future editions to improve the book would be to include how long all the condiments/sauces will last in the refrigerator.This book is very poor quality. I have used it heavily for three days, and it is falling apart. I've been nice to it, too. I don't crack the spines on my books. I see a lot of reviewers are having theirs spiral-bound at office supply stores for a few bucks. I will do the same. My recommendation is to buy the book, but take it and have it bound before you use it. In addition to the binding being awful, the pages seem to not hold up well to handling. So spiral bound the thing, use a cookbook stand for sure, and maybe place a clear laminate sheet  across the pages while cooking. It is nuisance for sure, but the recipes are so good that I have ordered Well Fed 2.

Amazon kept recommending this book to me based on my other purchases. After a while, I read some glowing reviews, and with a sense of caution, I ordered the book. After all, it was only $15, no real tragedy either way.Oh wow! This book is worth every dime! Over 95% of the recipes appealed to me. I immediately made the Marshmallow Swirl S'mores Fudge. It was so simple to make, and everyone from my husband to my children was constantly in the fridge, cutting "one more piece". Then I made the Nutella Frosted Banana Cupcakes. The Nutella Frosting has been adopted by our household as the frosting of choice. We were all like cats licking cream from a bowl while groaning pathetically as we ate. Those babana cupcakes would make a fine substitute for a breakfast muffin basket if you leave off the frosting, too! Two whopping successes in a row definitely gets my vote of recommendation.While I recommend the book, I do wish to caution that it isn't perfect. It needs another pass of proofreading/editing. I found a typo or two in the blurbs about the recipes which is technically not a huge deal. However, the recipe for the Pretzel Peanut Butter Cups does not include the use of pretzels in either the recipe or the ingredient list. Any reader should be able to utilize common sense to figure out from the photo that a pretzel goes on the top and bottom of the Peanut Butter Cup, but I've been reviewing cookbooks for years so I can tell you that this kind of omission matters to people.Sally is a gifted food photographer. It amazes me that the photos she takes match the quality of the recipes she writes. The book is well made, and it stays open to cook with without the use of a cookbook stand, if you so wish. The font for recipes is a bit on the small side, but it shouldn't be too much of a problem. You will find a broad range of delicious treats to cook. This book is what you pull out for any occasion: birthday parties, girls' night in, bakes sales, and showers. It is a fun treat for baking from , and I can't imagine many home cooks not being able to glean something delicious from this awesome book. Sally, I hope there's a sequel in the works!

I love paranormal romance, and after reading the positive reviews on here as well as the product description, I thought this novel was going to be a thrilling romance of epic proportions. Let me put it this way: my mom and dad are closer to a great couple than this tired group of characters. The chapters are slowly paced, and when something of interest or note occurs, it's over with in the flash of an eye and you're back to slogging through superfluous details. Maggie and Eran are boring, dull, and lack development. The novel takes too long to explain Maggie's gift. Maggie's housemates (Rufus, Felix, Ezra) are over-the-top domestic and boring; Falter takes their opposing meal (tofu versus burgers) planning too far. It isn't comic-relief--it's bad writing and it detracts from the limping plot. I also don't get the point of setting the novel in New Orleans if the novel isn't going to have a mildly Southern tone. Beyond affecting some ridiculous accents, I didn't understand why she choose that setting. Also, this is the poorest formatted/proofread/edited book that I have come across all year. This is the first and absolute last Falter novel that I will read.

Consuming Passion: A Food-Obsessed Life, by Michael Lee West, is the consummate food writing of the South. West effortlessly blends autobiographical sketches with her thoughts and experiences regarding food, and she rewards your reading effort by tossing in at least a recipe per chapter. To get better Southern food lore, youd have to turn to Craig Claibornebut give up a few chuckles along the way.From making cornbread to crafting sugared violets to seasoning a cast iron pan, you will find an endless assortment of clever ruminations on the Southern kitchen. Wests recipes are basic, delicious, and fool-proof, but her confidences regarding failures, successes, and draws in the kitchen that hook the reader and lure her in. Her anecdotes regarding family and friends will alternate between leaving you howling with laughter and shuddering. The uncles in the family all die young, but the aunts know its really death by butter. When Aunt Dell invites West over for an impromptu roast, the family finds the seasoning has been tainted by none other than weevils. They watch fascinated and horrified as Dell strains the sauce and serves it anyhow. West goes on hot pursuit of a bed supposedly from the childhood home of Margaret Mitchell and walks away with not only the bed but a delicious gingersnap recipe that might have originated from a childhood friend of Ms. Mitchell.Consuming Passions straddles a fine line between witty and informative, leaving the reader to soak up every word and then reread the book. Wests work has since broadened to encompass mainstream fiction such as her popular Teeny series. Yet when I find myself with a craving that I cant identify, be it literary or culinary, Consuming Passions: A Food-Obsessed Life is a regular cure all.

It is no secret that I am a raving fan of Jeni Britton Bauer. When people ask me where to go for ice cream, I send them to her shop. When people ask me what ice cream cookbook to purchase, I recommend Jeni's first book. And now she has a second book! I'm telling you that I'm beside myself. Jeni's cookbooks don't make me feel like a rock star in my kitchen...that's just stupid. Jeni's cookbooks make me feel like a professional chef in my kitchen, and that's worth everything.Jeni's Splendid Ice Cream Desserts is the book that you have to buy if you have a comfortable mastery of homemade ice cream preparation and are looking to advance your skills by turning that ice cream into restaurant worthy desserts. The book is divided into three main parts: ice cream parlor, bakeshop, and sundae bar.Ice cream parlor gives you all new ice cream recipes that aren't found in the original Jeni's book. Think black forest cake ice cream, bellini sorbet, and salty caramel Crme sans Lait. Caution: this is not the book you want to buy if you are looking for run of the mill basics! You will not be getting plain vanilla, chocolate, or strawberry. These are inspired recipes with big twists in the flavors, and while they're awesome, this isn't the book for you if you want basic flavors. The French Toast Frozen Custard is incredible.Bakeshop provides lots of recipes so that you can serve cakes, cobblers, and cookies alongside your awesome homemade ice creams. You will find wiseman's chocolate cake, Bauer House biscuits, sauted fruit, and all manner of delicious ice cream accompaniments. Wiseman's chocolate cake is one of the moistest chocolate cakes you can make.Sundae bar will help you put it all together with gorgeous photos of assembled parfaits and sundaes. Somehow Jeni has elevated these humble drugstore desserts into works of art meant to eaten. I haven't made this one yet but the Salty Grahama (whipped cream, salty vanilla custard, sliced bananas, whiskey caramel sauce, and salty graham gravel) is next on my list. Jeni gives you the recipes for every component you need from sauces to gravels in this section.It's a well made book with beautiful photography, but I have come to expect nothing less from this ice cream expert who only uses the best ingredients and tries to locally source them. I have worn out her previous book, and I can tell this book is going to get the same workout this summer. The only problem with Jeni's books is that I have trouble not taking credit for her work when I serve up the end product.

It is a rare occasion when I can't finish a novel. This novel doesn't boast bold characters; it boasts a cast of clich characters. It changes narratives far too often, and normally I don't mind split narrative novels in the least. Never one to shy away from a piece of Southern family drama, this jumbled mess of a novel is best described as an episode of Jerry Springer whose script is being sold as Southern fiction.

I'm new to the Beekman cookbooks. I missed their initial heirloom recipes book a few years ago, but I saw this new dessert edition at the local B&N, thumbed through it for about a minute, and decided that I had to order it. This book has become my quintessential winter baking book in a short time.It is a beautifully bound hardcover with a definite heirloom keepsake vibe. I love the plate in the front of the book that reads "the first generation to own this book is" with a blank series of lines for you to fill in. There are blank lines at the bottom of most recipes and after each chapter so that you can pen in your own precious seasonal family recipes. This is excellent if you want to give the book as a gift to a loved one and share your own family heritage.The book is arranged seasonally, winter through fall, to highlight the best that each season has to offer. You will find both classic recipes (do it all yellow cake, banana pudding with vanilla wafers, vanilla pastry cream) and amazing twists (chocolate rocky road potstickers, oatmeal cream pie with ginger cream, cinnamon bun bundt cake). I find that the majority of ingredients are readily available with no special searching or ordering. The recipes are clearly written and many can be made by a novice baker who is detail-oriented. I love the one bowl chocolate almond cake.I only have one small gripe with the book, and it isn't enough for my to downgrade my five star rating. The nostalgic pictures of these desserts are breathtaking. I wish there were more pictures. This book is lush with beautiful photography that captivates the reader and hearkens back to another time, but I would rather have pictures of the finished pumpkin jelly roll or banana cake with cream cheese frosting than full page pictures of copper pots, delicate china, and lovely outdoor scenes. There was also one teensy mistake in the well referenced index: all the "g" entries were lumped in with the "f" entries with no delineation. This really shouldn't affect how you use the book.I think this is one of the best baking books to be released this season. Even someone who doesn't cook well would derive a lot of joy from this just by leafing through the pages. I don't think anyone should hesitate to purchase this gorgeous and tasty book.

I have a confession to make. I consider myself an accomplished cook, but my Achilles heel in the culinary department is pie making. There's something about making a crust that makes me as nervous as can be. I bought a pie book this year, but it seemed a little past the skill level of this novice pie baker. So I decided to buy this book as an early Christmas gift to myself. I am beyond happy that I bought it!The book is a softcover with a durable cover that looks to wipe clean. My only complaint is that you need a cookbook stand to actively cook from it. It is laid out well with a wonderful cross-referenced index, and the pictures, oh the pictures! The pictures are full page for each and every pie, and they make you declare that you will master the art of pies.The book is divided as follows: pie and tart crusts; cream, meringue, and ice cream pies; tarts and galettes; slab pies; pie toppings; classic southern pies; fruit pies; cobblers and crisps; hand pies and fried pies; equipment; ingredients; and crust index. My favorite sections are the pie and tart crusts chapter as well as the crust index. The crust index is a genius two page spread that lets you choose one of the crust recipes and pair it with a suggested filling. This way, you can make a pie anytime by utilizing a crust you re comfortable making and handling. You don't have to be a pastry pro to pull off these recipes--there are a number of press in the pan crusts. I find this very reassuring. If you're a pastry pro, they show you how to make a lattice crust or do a decorative crust edge.You will find a wide array of pies, something to please everyone. There are lots of old expected classics such as vinegar pie, chess pie, and banana cream pie, but you will also find lots of awesome and welcome twists on classics such as red velvet pie, maple chess pie with brown sugar bacon, and mini bananas foster pies. The salted caramel pecan tassies are amazing and a showstopper for company. Be sure to check out the toppings chapter which will show you how to make everything from apple cider drizzle to homemade crme fraiche.I am pleased with my purchase and hope Southern Living produces more books in a similar vein. I will enjoy this book for many years to come and think it would make a nice stocking stuffer for the family member with a sweet tooth who enjoys baking.

Callie's Biscuits and Southern Traditions is a collection of southern recipes that are easy to pull off, require basic ingredients that you won't have to order, and won't break the bank. It is a well-bound hardcover that stays open on the countertop if you want to cook from it and don't have a stand. The print is mostly easy to read. On a few pages, the backdrop is a white woven dishcloth and the weave of the cloth competes with the small black type. It isn't true for every page but be aware. The book is moderately generous with photographs, but you have to wonder why someone would include a family photograph but not a picture of the sage butter-roasted turkey. There are also fun asides throughout the book to tell you all about everything from grits to bereavement food.The introduction tells how the author came to make biscuits.She also lists tools she finds helpful in the kitchen. Each chapter is given a 2-3 page introduction, and most recipes are introduced with a paragraph or two divulging their history or what makes them special. The recipes are well-written and easy to follow.The chapters are as follows: biscuits; skillet and stove top; roasting and slow cooking; salads and sandwiches; baking; and entertaining. Entertaining is subdivided into sit-down holiday dinner; cocktail celebration; throw-together oyster roast; game day; southern picnic; playdate; and party drinks.Truth be told, I found the organization and content of the author's chapters to be a little odd. Take for example, chapter 1 (biscuits). There are 14 recipes in the chapter, but only 3 biscuit recipes (buttermilk, black pepper, and cast-iron yeast). However, the biscuit chapter includes southern shortcakes (yeah, I know it's a biscuit) along with recipes for macerated fruit, whipped cream, and shortcake trifle (basically, put the aforementioned ingredients together!). Then there are recipes for cinnamon stickies and buttermilk blueberry cobbler in the biscuit chapter despite there being a scant baking chapter later on. While I confess the food is good, this book suffers from poor editing or organization.The salads and sandwiches chapter includes southern favorites from ham salad to egg salad along with coleslaw, potato salad, fruit kabobs, and corn salad. There are a couple salad dressing and four vinaigrettes. The tuna salad is presented three ways: classic, Tuscan, and Soho. Now I know that Southern cooking encompasses all kinds of cuisine, but really? Soho tuna? There is also a recipe for fiery pimento cheese-laced "naughty" eggs. The feeling of the recipes being a hodgepodge that don't necessarily fit anywhere continues.You'll find sweet and savory recipes in the baking chapter. The author tells you right off the bat that she finds the art of cake baking to be elusive so don't expect to find a hummingbird cake, red velvet cake or some other beautiful southern cake here. You'll find basics like haystacks, pecan pie, and chocolate chip cookies here.My favorite recipes are the pimento cheese shrimp and grits and the black pepper biscuits. You'll wish you thought of both dishes.My bottom line? This is a nice cookbook with some standout recipes. It won't make or break your cookbook collection to own it. I will probably regift this book. I simply already have enough of these type recipes. I think this would be a basic starter book for the aspiring southern cook.Update 11/22/13 You may also want to try the Callie's Meeting Street Crab Dip as well as the cast-iron pimento cheese dip. However, upon further use of the book I have an additional criticism. The index is poorly done. You'd think the aforementioned crab dip would be located under "crab" or "dips". It was actually listed under "Callie's". Just in case anyone is confused, this is not a negative review. I gave the book 4 stars for great food, but there are aspects of the book that can be improved.

Journey along with Sam and a host of unforgettable characters as they trek along the Continental Divide after the mysterious suicide of a mutual school friend and discover their own marvelous, wounded spirits along the way. Pate does a magnificent job of balancing chuckle-inducing humor against poignant soul-searching as her memorably-crafted characters face the disappointments and joys of everyday life and seek to uncover their spiritual selves. Pate also admirably captures the female friendship on paper, portraying its supportiveness, rivalry, love, and vagaries. This debut novel juxtaposes the physical journey of a lifetime against the mental journey of a lifetime and leaves the reader with the sense that she has made new friends along the way. Journey along with Sam and prepare to learn something new about yourself.

I purchased this basket to go with my daughter's Halloween custom because a traditional pumpkin wouldn't do.This basket is fine for that purpose. The handle is sturdily attached and the basket is secure enough to handle being stuffed to the brim with light weight candy.As far as home dcor purposes go, this is not the basket for you if you desire a pure white basket. The wash on this basket is very thin and a lot of the natural color of the willow shows through so it would be good as a shabby chic basket. The handle can't be positioned up and left that way. It flops over easily due to the design of the hinges on the handles. This is also not a basket for you to carry heavy objects in. It isn't made of sturdy enough materials.This basket would best excel as a prop such as for a costume or a small gift basket. This would be useful to fashion a get well basket out of. It would be terrific to hold a mug and tea or cocoa packets and a packet of cookies.I think the basket is fine for any lightweight purpose and some decorating. I think overall the quality could be better but it is sweet and cute.

For the price and beauty of this product, it simply can't be beaten. I shopped for weeks for an appropriate rocking horse for my youngest. I wanted something that I could hang onto for a while even after she outgrows it, and I truly found it with this rocking horse.The info states that it is for an 18 month to 3 year old child and will accommodate up to 50 pounds. It arrived unassembled, in great condition with all wooden pieces and all hardware. It took my spouse approximately 20 minutes to assemble this horse. The pieces are quality and should stand up to years of abuse from my children. The kit also came with customer service info in case we needed help. Both of my children enjoy playing with the horse and they squabble over it.The horse is terrific. I only have minor criticisms.The horse's mane could have been attached a little better. A few more pieces than I expected have pulled out due to play. Also, the faux leather bridle over the nose slips around quite a bit and has to be put back into place. I also notice that the runners are a little short for good rocking action. The horse rocks but it is not as smooth and fluid as I expected.I think this is a fine addition to any child's playroom. I look forward to seeing my children enjoy it for the next few years.

I have been waiting months for Rachael Ray's Week in a Day to come out. The idea is that one spends a day cooking (a Cook Day) to be rewarded with 5 delicious meals for the week ahead. It sounds terrific to this working mom of two tiny children but in actuality, the book doesn't deliver as well as I hoped.The book is divided into 43 weeks of 5 dish menus. Each week has its own theme: five fiesta favorites; meatlover's lane; a chicken in every pot; hearty classics, Thanksgiving anytime, etc. After that comes 4 foundation recipes (poached chicken, parmigiano-herb stock, roasted tomatoes, and pulled pork) that you use frequently. Then the final section is 1 Grocery Bag, 3 Meals in which you are given 8 grocery lists that promise three hearty meals utilizing only one sack of groceries.Don't get me wrong. I think the food is delicious and hearty. I cook everything from Food Network classics to Thomas Keller. I think Ray's food has improved steadily over the years and does deliver. The problem? I can't imagine utilizing many of these menus on a Cook Day to deliver meals later in the week. The recipes all have a common theme but most of the time that theme means cooking lots of different proteins and utilizing new ingredients with each dish. It isn't cost-effective and goodness knows, I don't own enough pots, pans, and kitchen implements to make all five recipes in a day. Ray says she frequently spends a good 5-6 hours cooking up a week's worth of meals. I can't see myself making 5 of most recipes in these menus in under 5-6 hours. The interruption of cleanup between recipes would make it an all day ordeal.I fully realize you have to spend some time in the kitchen to make good food, and her recipes are good. I just don't like the premise that anyone can go in the kitchen and make these menus in a day. It seems to me that you sacrifice too much time with your family to pull these off. I'd rather spend an hour on any given day cooking a great meal than sequestering myself in the kitchen for a whole day to save some time through the week. I choose to think of this as just another Rachael Ray cookbook and ignore the Week in a Day concept.You won't find any grocery lists for each week on the 43 week menus, but there are lists that head all 8 of the One Bag, Three Meals section which I think is a lot more practical for the parenting, working cook of today. There is two page spread of Microsoft tags at the beginning of the book that you can scan with your phone to get bonus side dish recipes and cooking videos. There are some nice full color photographs of the finished dishes in this book.Most dishes taste great. The short rib ragu with drunken papperdelle is a winner as is the Thai ribs and drumsticks and ancho-chipotle turkey chili. I reiterate: you won't hurt for good food in this book. I just don't think the menus were well done to optimize your time at home. More repetition of the same protein or transforming more leftovers into new dishes would have earned this book a solid 5 stars from me. I'm happiest when I ignore the notion that these menus should be cooked in a day.

In Allegiant, the third book in a promising and much anticipated trilogy, Veronica Roth delivers a novel that wouldn't have ordinarily made it out of the slush pile of any reputable publisher. Her prose barely rises above the complexity of "See spot run", and her endless repetition of the same weary adjectives makes me fervently hope someone buys her a thesaurus for Christmas. I am similarly underwhelmed by her ham-handed use of point of view. The previous two books were written solely from the point of view of Tris while this book's point of view alternates between Tris and Tobias. Roth's plain Jane, junior high style prose never achieves a difference in voice between her own narration, Tris, or Tobias. This is especially disappointing because Tobias is such a complex, mysterious character and should have delivered riveting chapters. The finale is the most monotone book I have ever had the misfortune of reading, and if you're perceptive, you realize early on why she has to write from the perspective of two characters. Many people are howling about the ending, and while I maintain it was not the ending I hoped for, my opinion is that Roth is too poor and weak of a writer to achieve the shocking, hard-hitting ending she desired. Never mind all the intricate plots, subplots, and endless revolutions. She couldn't achieve resolution. You could argue that not all dystopian futures will be  or have to be resolved and that her book is actually realistic, but given the scores of weaknesses throughout the book, I'm going to guess that Roth couldn't tie up her loose ends.I'm not sure what happened to the most anticipated young adult novel of the year, but my primary theory is that having released three novels in three years and a slew of forthcoming Divergent-related short stories, Roth was really just looking to cash in big while she could. This trilogy could have been great, and I am sorry a better author didn't come up with it.

The America's Test Kitchen Cooking School Cookbook is my favorite cookbook of the fall so far. It is chock full of culinary know how and is an absolute pleasure to leaf through on these autumn evenings. It has something to offer everyone whether they are a beginning cook or an advanced cook.This is one heavy, well-made book. They didn't skimp on binding it either. This 822 page beauty should stand up to years of heavy use in the kitchen. Toss it on the counter and use it as a reference as you cook--it will stay open on its own.The chapters are as follows: cooking basics; how to cook: eggs; vegetables; pasta; rice, grains, and beans; meat; poultry; seafood; grill; stocks and soups; salads; quick breads; yeast breads and pizza; cookies; cakes; fruit desserts; pies and tarts; custards, puddings, and frozen desserts; appendix; and index.I'm going to answer a question that many of you have. Those of you familiar with America's Test Kitchen are wondering about the recycling of recipes from book to book. The answer is yes, they did recycle recipes. I own the America's Test Kitchen TV Show Cookbook 2001-2010 as well as ATK Family Cookbook. The first item I compared in the index is "eggs". I came up with repetitions from one book or the other for eggs benedict, some deviled egg recipes, several frittata recipes, huevos rancheros, omelets, quiches, a salad, and scrambled. Next I cross referenced "sauces" between the three books as came up with as generous an amount of overlap and then got modest overlap once more when I searched "potatoes, mashed" in the index. So why am I giving this book 5 stars?I'm giving this book 5 stars because I feel that it offers something not many other books do. I'm a self taught cook, cooking everything from Rachael Ray to Thomas Keller in a week. No one at my house could teach me to cook growing up, and I will never be able to afford culinary school. There are huge gaps in my cooking knowledge and this book will fill them! When I hold this book and get picture by picture tutorials on recipes, I know that I'm going to learn how to do them accurately from beginning to end. There are 35 pictures to show you how to make sticky buns with pecans. It's hard to get that kind of in depth tutorial just anywhere.The book is set up so that a core technique is photographed thoroughly so that you can master it step by step such as pan roasted chicken breasts and then they present you with a recipe library so that you can practice the master technique in other ways such as in chicken saltimbocca or chicken marsala. Despite 2,500 beautiful photographs to teach you, you aren't going to get step by step photography or even a finished picture of every dish.I appreciate the "what can go wrong" charts on all the master technique recipes. They give you a wide range of problems ( fillets overcooked, fillets take longer to cook than indicated, etc) and then give you suggestions on how to cope with the problem in your home kitchen. Most of us have had similar problems regarding a dish that didn't quite want to follow the recipe's directions.Each master recipe has stats to tell you how long to prep, how long to cook, the portion yield, whether you can make it ahead, and the difficulty level. Each master recipe also gives you a comprehensive list of all the kitchen tools and gadgets you will need to make each recipe a reality.There are nice encyclopedic primers for a variety of ingredients that educate the reader all about cuts of beef and cuts of pork as well as the basics of prepping vegetables and what basic kitchen tools do. I could go on and on, but each time I turn the page, there is a new surprise. Tables for conversions and equivalencies, high altitude baking, and meat doneness temperatures reside in the appendix.I love their sticky buns with pecans--talk about a breakfast treat. The chicken piccata is also a dependable recipe that is savory and well-balanced. Their French apple cake can't be beat. ATK consistently produces dependable recipes.My summary after a lengthy review? Buy it. Sure, you aren't getting hundreds of new recipes. You are getting dependable, trust worthy culinary know how. This is the one cookbook I am choosing to stuff in my bag when I go on vacation with plans to cook.

Come Home to Supper: Over 200 Casseroles, Skillets, and Sides (Desserts, Too!)--to Feed Your Family with Love is Christy Jordan's much awaited book after her surprise runaway hit Southern Plate. She states in her introduction that this is a book about feeding your family on busy nights. She says sometimes we all sit around watching a tv chef prepare filet mignon when what we're really wanting is a new recipe to prepare a pound of ground beef to feed our family. I think that's practical insightful thinking for modern families relying on the drive through.Her book is a paperback and it doesn't stay open on its own. You will need a cookbook stand to use this book at the stove. I don't need a photograph for each recipe but many of you will be disappointed to learn that there isn't a photograph for each one. Most of the food photography is full page and looks appetizing.The recipes are divided into the following chapters: beef; pork; chicken; seafood; sandwiches; casseroles; sides; breads; desserts; and pantry. As you can see, the author tries to deliver on her promise to deliver practical, no frills, everyday cooking to you. These recipes are clearly written and will involve no online shopping to buy obscure ingredients. Most ingredients are probably in your pantry this very second. You also won't have to buy a half shopping cart of ingredients to prepare a meal from this book.Jordan inflects a lot of the same soul from Southern Plate into this book. She talks about reliance on family and spending meaningful time with your children in asides throughout the book that are sprinkled with family photographs. You will also find cooking tips scattered at the tops of the pages that teach the reader about cooking a tender roast, simple weeknight menus, saving bacon grease, and finding a perfect casserole dish. There is an outstanding chart on mixing and matching your own casseroles.While I think Jordan stays true to the theme of easy family meals, some of the recipes seem a little uninspired. Take for example Catalina chicken. It involves onion soup mix, catalina dressing, and chicken. My guess is that most of you have cooked a variation of this already. Ice cream rolls involve self-rising flour and just melted ice cream. Again, recipes like these have been making the circuit for a while. Yet there are also major hits in this book. The chicken fettucine is a tasty treat, and if you love cinnamon, you must get to the kitchen now and make her cinnamon pudding cobbler. It's wonderful. I think Jordan consistently shines brightest in the desserts department.If you are opposed to cooking with canned cream of mushroom, Coca-Cola, soup packets or other prepackaged convenience items, this book is not for you. This is all about getting supper on the table with a minimum of fuss. Some of you will be interested to know that Jordan mixes up her Southern style recipes with a few surprises such as a West Indies Salad and Big Fat Greek Taters.I think this is an overall nice addition to your weeknight cooking shelf. As always, I am touched by Jordan's commitment to families. This is the kind of cooking you share with your neighbor over the fence, at church, or in line at the supermarket. Her Southern Plate is my favorite book of the two. This book will make a nice gift for newlyweds, new cooks, and Southern plate fans with its mix of easily prepared recipes.

Don't waste your money.  First I read through all the great reviews of this camera and was in ahhh of all the features so I pulled the trigger and ordered on.  Prime Next day a Bonus.So to start I am very tech savy.  I opened the box, followed the directions, (by the way there pretty poorly written) to a 'T'Plug power into Camera,  Connect ethernet cable to your router, install SD card.  So far so good.  Then you have to go to there web site and create a user account.  Ok, here is where my Security Concern Meter pegged into the red.  For this camera to function you have to create a user account on a foreign server, and then provide them with your WIFI passcode in order for there software to program the camera.  After careful consideration, and knowing I can change my pass on the fly I opted to go for it because I was curious about this camera based on its price point.After going through the four or five windows to set up an account I was able to access the camera, remember its still plugged into the ethernet port.  The minute I connected for live feed I got nothing but massive mic feedback on my pc, so I had to turn my volumn off.  I was able to do all the functions through the online web browser controls.Well now for the real test, what I bought the thing for Wifi connection.  I unplug the Ethernet and no wifi.  The thing will not connect.  I take the unit and literally plug it in within five feet of my Wifi Router and it will still not connect.  I did the install procedure at least a dozen times and reset the unit several times.  After an hour of wasted time I packed the thing back and off to Amazon it goes.  I am tech savy enough to know there is a huge problem with this unit.Normally I rarely ever go through the bad reviews but on this product curiosity got the better of me. I clicked the one star review and lo and behold countless complaints about the same problem I had, and these were not scattered over years.  I counted close to 50 of them within a few months of August 2015.  A lot of them from individuals who based on how they described the problem were as Tech Savy as myself.  Do your self a favor and steer clear from this product.  And if the Tech complaints don't get you just think about this:You buy this unit, install it, and it works as advertised.  You set it up in your infants room thinking you now have peace of mind.  One problem, everything this camera is seeing, and hearing is being transmitted back to the Foreign servers of Fujikam 24/7.  That means someone can be monitoring your child from a third world country and over time they will know your daily patterns, and of course your Router during setup broadcasted to them your  I.P. address which with the right software on the net will lead directly to your home address. I am not much of a conspiracy theorist but if I was this is the greatest gimmick out there to engage in black market child selling.

Love this stuff and have been looking for it for years.  My first job was a cook in a restaurant and part of the closing procedure was to use this product on all the stainless in the kitchen.After installing stainless steel appliances in my home I probably went through half a dozen spray cleaners trying to find a product that would match Sheila Shine.  No go. I was ecstatic when I found this product on Amazon.  A little pricier than you would pay at a Wholesale Restaurant supplier but then I am not buying a case of them at at time.A lot of people complain about the smell.  Yes it has a smell, but if you ever worked in the restaurant industry this smell will be familiar to you.  It's actually not as bad as some people have remarked and it dissipates quickly.Also you have to remember that a little goes a long way.

What can I say, snaps those little suckers dead every time.We have a hoarder that lives a few doors down and the rats that live in this house travel the fence line to find food.  My yard just happens to be the fence highway they travel to get to other neighbors homes that live pet food etc.. out.  I started a few years back using the conventional wood snapper traps.  There good, but man watch your fingers and hands when you set them. Looking at an alternative I stumbled across these bad boys at my local farm supply.http://www.amazon.com/Trapper-T-Rex-Rat-Trap-Traps/dp/B0084X5ONI/ref=sr_1_16?ie=UTF8&qid=1438880570&sr=8-16&keywords=rat+trapsThe T-Rex at our farm supply were pricey at $10.00 a pop, but they looked great, seemed easy to load etc..so I bought six of them.  Big mistake.  They lasted about two to three months and would break, in the same place every time.  The latch lip that holds it down when you set it.  Also, my traps are screwed down to the upper fence cross member, so on these units you have to hold the trap open to load the bait.  Fed up with these T-rexes I found these Snap-E's.  Bought a couple of them and could not be happier.  These units are like the Rat Terminator.  They consistently catch em, whereas the T-Rex on occasion they would get out.  I have found rats hanging by their paw, even a couple where the trap nailed them on the snot/mouth. I am certainly going to order more of these just to have them on hand.Biggest pro on these traps is the fact that you can load the bait uncocked and then cock it when your done.

First, the product we just received looks nothing like the product advertised, and I am providing the pictures to back that claim up.I bought this product based on solely on all the great reviews in hopes that it would provide us an easy way to wash my 85 year old bed ridden mothers hair.  The neck opening does not even exist.  The two ends on the top inflated unit squeeze the persons face and neck.  Oh, and notice where the drain hole is on this unit, in the back so water does not drain out of it also the drain is to narrow so water can't escape down the tub.On this unit buyer beware and little my pictures paint a thousand no's as to why you don't want to pull the trigger on this item.

I recently became the caregiver for my 85 year old mother who is bed/wheelchair bound.  Unfortunately our house cannot support a transfer bench to move her into the shower so I opted to try this unit with an inflatable bed/hair wash basin.The material this unit is made off is thick and the seams are sealed very well.  I don't ever foresee any leaks developing at the seams.  There is a support tube that inserts at the top of the bag that prevents if from collapsing while you hang it, also makes it easier to carry it from the bathroom to the bedroom.I would give this a five star mark if it had the following.1. A larger opening to fill the unit. For example something in the size of a CamelBack,  backpack hydration unit.  The opening on this bag is small, so if you fill it in the tub like I do you waste water and with the opening so small the surge of water does not allow for the air to escape easily.  The bab is pretty big so you're not going to get it full using a bathroom sink.  The only other option would be to use a kitchen sink.  Is this a deal breaker no, but something to deal with.2. The water release.  Sorry this is a no go.  They incorporate a hospital I.V. drip stop as the on/off for the shower head.  I would have much rather seen a trigger valve.  Truthfully I would have paid extra for something like this.  Is the I.V. drip stop usable yes but not convenient.

I have owned Food Saver units for around 20 years.  Buying and cooking in bulk and then using my FoodSaver to portion on meals and freeze them has been a life saver.  The only downfall has been the cost of replacement bags.  Ouch, even at Costco they're expensive.I spent countless hours reading reviews on Amazon of various products and finally decided to pull the trigger on these Sure Luxury even though they did not have a lot of reviews.  However the ones they did have were all favorable. I got an 8" and an 11" roll.  This review is for the 8", however I see no difference in product between the two.The shipper got high marks for the product showing up in two days using Prime.  I spent a few hours yesterday bagging a variety of foods.  Sausage links, Kings Hawaiian Rolls, (Secret to bagging bread - Freeze it for a few hours so its hard and then vacuum bag it) Fish and some other items.  All in all around 40 bags.  Considering over the last twenty years I have probably vacuumed over 5,000 items in FoodSaver's I can honestly say these bags perform better than the originals.  There approximately the same mil size but for some reason the indented pattern that allows the air to be vacuumed seems to work much better.Two thumbs up for this product,  all probably order a few more rolls in case this vendor in the future does not supply them.

My original Stant locking cap had a broken o-ring so I needed a new one.  Happily I found this on Amazon, cheaper than my local automotive stores.  In fact they don't even carry the green cap that says Diesel, they have to order it, and for more money.Arrive just in time for my bi-annual smog check.My old stant cap you use to have to make sure that it was locked with the key once you installed the cap.  This one locks automatically a great feature.  With people stealing fuel all the time it's a simple feature to put you at peace of mind.

Love these scrubbers.  I used to buy these years ago through commercial restaurant suppliers.  Unfortunately the supplier I used went out of business and I have not been able to find them locally, or they were too much online direct from various web sites.A few weeks back I decided to look on Amazon  and low and behold I found my little scrub buddies.  No hesitation in ordering and I love them.  First you can't beat the price.  These are the real deal used in restaurants everywhere.I use them in our cast iron pans, pots etc...  I even use them to scrub off burned on items that get on the stove top on occasion, no scratching of the stainless steel.  Could not be happier with this product.

Just moved my mom out of a group elderly care home and back to my house.  I noted that the group home used a strap belt to help my mom move up and down from her wheelchair and bed.  I was not sure whether they were going to allow us to take the strap assists when we moved her so I decided to buy a new one on Amazon.  This product popped up in the search so read through the review and decided to pull the trigger and order one.Wow, what a great product.  Professionally made and with multiple assist handles as the picture depicts.  We now have used it for the last three days and it is much easier than a strap assist.  I highly recommend this product over strap assists.
Nice replacement for my old faulty garage door.  Definitely made a huge improvement in the overall operation.

So far so good. Have not had to use both charge ports.  Did check the voltage coming out when charging my S3 and it was putting out around 3.7a.  No complaints there.  Overall good product.  All certainly buy some more of these units.

Battery charges with no problem on a 2a charger. Battery arrived quickly.  No issue with packaging. Battery had a 60% charge when I got it.  Ran it down to about 10% which took about a day or so.  Recharged up to 100% in about five hours.  Each subsequent full charge usage to 10% has taken anywhere from 24 hours to 36 hours and that is under heavy usage.  Recharging from 10% to full, using a 2a charger takes about four hours.

Great product.  Bought this a few years ago and never got around to reviewing it.  I can't say anything bad about this.  I use it a couple times a month and throw it in the dishwasher and have had not issues.
