Comes with a protective plastic cover protects not only the blades but you when your rooting around in the drawer.

This book was recommended to me by a financial attorney.  If your thinking of or planning on a new start up company with a group of business partners this is the book for you.  Start ups are generally always of the blood and sweat of the original partners.  Slicing Pie helps you understand how to fairly share in the equity of the company from start up development to operation.  I bought several copies of this book for a group of friends that were in the talking stages of a new start up.  It helped everyone understand what there piece of the pie would be based on what they were going to contribute during the start up.

Bought these about a year ago and love them.  The tee handle locking screw makes it easy to lock these down on the spit.  Also if you have to adjust your meat once you have it on the BBQ.  The only thing I did not like is the fact that they will not fit on my larger diameter spit.  I am thinking of buying another pair so I can Rotisserie more meat.  Prongs are the perfect length.  Very happy with this purchase

Great product for men.  Works best right out of the shower when your hair is still wet.  I use a couple drops in my palm and then rub them together before running it through my hair.  Nice because I have really thin hair on the top of my head and it provide the volume I am looking for.  Even found my daughter using it on occasion to style her hair and she loves it.

A great alternative way to refill your cartridges.  Instructions are great and simple to follow, plus they include the parts necessary to convert the starter cartridge to a full use cartridge.  I have bought this product now twice and will happily buy again with no reservations.

The jury is still out on this product.  I use it on a my Marble counter top.  Cleans efficiently however I don't really see a shine coming from the marble which is what I was hoping for.  I could probably accomplish the same thing with diluted Simple Green.  Not sure whether I will buy again when I run out.
Bought my daughter a box of these for LaCrosse.  Same balls they use in practice and tournaments and substantially cheaper than buying at big box sporting goods stores.

Great cable as far as I can tell.  I had some concerns when I first plugged this into a 2a. supply source.  Phone would not charge, however tried the next day and the cables seem to work find.  Only time will tell.  My biggest issue with all these USB to MicroUSB has been the Micro USB locking tabs not securing the cable to phone port.  All come back in a few months to update this review.  So far I could not be happier and will probably buy a couple more to have around.

Fed up with paying premium for replacement filters and not able to source them through my own vendors I happily came to Amazon and found these.  What can I say a cheap perfect alternative knock off.  Installed one about three weeks ago and have had no issues with pressure or water flow.  I added some pics so you can see the quality build on these.  When I replace the first one in six months or so all cut it open and add pics of the Samsung for interior comparison.  Hope this helps all of you that are on the fence whether to purchase these or not.  Cheers.

We had a similar model to this unit which dated at least thirty years that finally fell apart from weather exposure.I figured I would just buy one of the more popular units on Amazon that had a good price point.  For a fruit picker it comes down to being only as good as the operator.  However there are some points that I think may be helpful to others.Pros:1. Deep basket, on smaller fruit you can usually harvest several before having to empty basket.  Avocados we can usually pull two to three at a time.2. Foam insert is a nice touch for soft skin fruits like peaches.3. comes with a hose clamp to attach the unit to your pole.  Nice addition so you don't have to run to Home Depot, however be warned the pole we used the clamp was too small.  Luckily we had larger clamps.Cons:1. If you have extremely large fruit you will have a problem as some will not fit in the basket.  My grapefruit tend to be around 1 1/2 larger than a softball and some will not fit in this basket.2. The bent prongs at the end of the picker that are designed to catch the fruit as you pull them off have a tendency to bend.  This occurs with our Oranges as the the are pretty well attached to the tree.  Our Avocados, Grapefruit, Tangerines, Mandarins etc... no problems.3. The pole we used is a Mr. LongPole.  Most common fiberglass extension pole out there.  You find them at almost all brick and mortar hardware stores.  There are issues using these poles and properly attaching the basket to the pole.  (note we did not want a permanent attachment as we use the poles for other things.: These poles use a plastic coupler that attaches the male thread used at the end of the pole to the actual pole.  The coupler is actually a larger diameter than the inside diameter of the basket neck.  The only way to properly attach the basket to these types of poles, using the Hose Clamp is to slide the basket down so the middle of the neck is roughly at the center point of this coupling and then clamp.  Remember the clamp that comes with the unit will not work here.  Fully expanded it will not fit.  If you pull the neck of the basket below the coupler, you could use the hose clamp that came with the unit, however about four inches of your pole would be sticking into the basket.  See the pic I attached which explains all this.Overall for the money its a decent product.  I give it a couple of years of use before it needs replacement.  I think next time all opt in and buy the Phoenix model with the bag and stem cutter.

Bought this battery to replace my almost three year old Samsung that came with my S3.  First the packaging was a cheap little cardboard box with a bubble wrap envelope to hold the battery.  Packaging was obviously previously opened, and there were no Charging/Break in instructions.The Battery had about 63% charge when I installed it. It drained down to 5% within a few hours after installation so I gave it a complete charge to 100%.  That charge drained down in about six hours.  Again repeated the charging......Move forward two weeks of using this battery.  I get about 30% more usage time with this battery compared to the Samsung.  Frankly I see this as pretty poor considering its suppose to be a 3800mah.  It compares to the Samsung when the phone was brand new. I have not gotten a full 24 hours of usage out of this battery.  I was hoping that with the 3800mah I would have at least seen 36 hours before needing a charge. I am still in the window of returning this battery and try another brand.In my humble opinion this is just another knock off battery made in a factory where 30-40 percent of the faulty batteries make it through QC. Personally I would not buy this again.Edit:  Well a few days have gone by since my first review.  This battery is junk, plain and simple.  Had it on a 2a. charge for almost six hours and it did not get past 15%.  Replaced it with the Samsung and no issues charging so I know its not the charger.  Sending it back for a refund.  As I said in my original post this a cheap knock off from a factory that has no QC in place.  I drew three x's on the original box that I am going to ship it back in.  I am curious if someone gets it down the road and if they do they read this post.  Final Comment:  Don't waste your money on this junk battery.  Run, run far and fast.  Cheers.

In 2011 we switched to Smart Phones.  Anticipating the need to be able to charge at multiple locations I bought several of these in both the 3ft and 6ft range.  I assumed with the Amazon Branding there would be some additional quality control involved, WRONG.Every one of these cables failed within 18 to 24 months.As others have noted, and someone posted a pic of it, the Micro Side of the cable is cheaply made where it goes into the body.  We had several of them pull out, some bent with very little effort and the majority of them failed due to the little friction tabs that are suppose to help keep them in place lost their ability to stand up.At the time we bought them I do not recall if they were designated for 2a power.  I can say that none of the cables at that time were able to support 2a charging, and data was extremely slow.

I am an industrial contractor so our phones can get pretty beat up at times.  When we Dropped Nextel years ago and switched to Smart Phones I did a lot of research into cases.  I know one of the big issues would be phones being dropped, bumped into while in a belt clip etc...  Our first Smart Phones were the HTC Evo and I outfitted everyone with Otter Box Defender cases.  After two and half years of in field use we never had one broken screen or failed phone due to being dropped.  After the useful life of the HTCEvo we moved on to the Samsung Galaxy III.  Again I outfitted all the phones with OB-Defender cases.  Two and half years later no broken screens or phones caused by drops etc...Some things to note:  When we had HTC Evo phones I ordered the black cases.  The rubber on the case seemed to be pretty soft and over time the flap for the earphone and power cord began to tear off.  We did not warranty this as it was over one year.  When we switched to Samsungs I opted for colored cases per everyones preference.  The colored cases seem to have a much heavier rubber, however my daughter has the light gray for her Samsung V and it is falling apart.  The rubber on the back of the case seems to be delaminating and where the earpiece and power cord go in the flaps are tearing away.The other nice feature of this phone is the fact that third party companies make Dash and Rear view mirror adapters which when mounted the Otter Box encased phone snaps right into.  A nice feature when you live in a hands free state.I give these covers a four star for only one reason.  The belt clip holster has an issue with the tab that holds the phone in place.  They constantly break off.  To the best of my knowledge OtterBox actually does not make these as we have found the same identical design on AliBaba for other phones.  The plastic used needs to be more of Noryl and not composite injected plastic.  I believe that would help with the tab always breaking.  The good part is OtterBox warranty.  They cover every issue we have had with these holsters no questions asked and even have replaced broken replacements.  Also, we had one or two issues over the years with the front clear screen coming unglued from the rubber case.  We contacted them, sent them pictures as required on the warranty and they covered the flaw with no questions.

Bought this just prior to Xmas 2013 for the specific use of monitoring Fry OIl. (I can't judge it's merits on Candy making).From day one the unit made a very slight buzzing sound. (I was too lazy to warranty because of this)  Within the last few weeks the LCD screen started flashing.  Half not visible and finally it went blank, although the unit seems to be working even though the LCD cannot be seen. I have replaced the batteries and still no change.  I emailed Maverick to find out what the warranty on this unit is and if I am still within it how they handle it.  (I will follow up when I here from them)July 2015:  Just wanted to follow up.  I am changing my rating from two stars to one star.  I attempted to contact the seller of this unit multiple times and never received a response.  Poor customer service and very disappointed in the performance of this unit.Pros:: The unit has a long probe and adjustable pot clip, which for my use seemed to grip with no problem, (frying in a dutch oven): Preset temperature for both Candy and Frying nice feature and the "Reach Temperature" audio signal for the most part was loud enough.  (I read some complaints where people said they could not hear it in another room. My response: Why would you leave hot oil or hot sugar on a stove and leave the kitchen, just my two cents): Easy clean up of the probe and the flip down cover over the LCD screen provides protection if you store it in a drawer.: LCD head rotates up and down for easy viewing.  Nice feature.Cons:: If you need dead on +/- 1 or 2 degree temperature monitoring this is not the unit you want.  From Maverick's website FAQ page:------I tested my thermometer in boiling water and it reads 208F instead of the expected 212F. Is there anyway to calibrate my digital thermometer?There is no way to calibrate our units. All of our digital thermometers have a tolerance of +/- (3-4) degrees F so it is normally for the temperature readings to be off by a few degrees.--------: A few people complained about the size of the digital LCD display being to small. I agree its hard to read, I measure it to be almost like a 4 or 5 font, so if your eyesight is not that of a Steely-eyed Rocket Scientist you're going to be squinting a little bit to read the display.All in all it is an ok digital thermometer.  Would I buy it again, probably because it is so cheap.  However I may try a Poland if Maverick does not warranty my current unit.

Bought this shredder two and half years ago.  I have always owned Fellowes shredders and for the most part have never had any real issues with them and when we did, Fellowes was spot on regarding warranty service.The primary reason I bought this unit is the micro shred which meets all the legal shredding requirements mandated for the type of work I do.  I would give this five stars accept for the crappy bag holder design, and this really goes for every Fellows Shredder I have owned.  The bad holder should have some way of attaching the bag around the rim and then holding it in place.  Also who ever designs these things need to put a full bag in one and then consistently pull the bag out to see where all the sharp edges are.  We use the fellows bags and they tend to rip or get caught on the upper portion of the holder.Overall a great shredder and we have had no issues in the 2.5 years we have had it.
What can you say, its a butter dish.  Nice snap tight lid.  Hard Plastic, dishwasher safe.  The price is great, and frankly you can't find these in any big box retailer.

Love these things.  We make home made Tacos all the time and go to our local market for daily fresh made Corn Tortillas.  I have owned one of these taco shell makers now for some thirty years.  In my divorce a few years back the ex got my Shell Maker.  I was really excited to find them on Amazon as none of the local stores had them anymore.  Great price, great product.  Just wish they made a vs. that allowed you take make multiple shells using a large pot, or dutch oven.
Again great price on these little weber tin foil trays.  Fraction of the cost of the Big Box and BBQ speciality stores.

This is just a quick warning about the Twin Cuisine design for all those that are interested.Four star for the cutting ability of the knife, One star for the handles,(Because you can't click no stars)I have been involved with the restaurant industry for some thirty years now as a Chef, management, designer, contractor etc... So I know good from bad when it comes to restaurant products.About four years ago I decided to purchase a new set of knives.  Henckel being one of my top choices, based on previous experience and ownership.I settled on the Twin Cuisine because I liked the larger handle and overall weight of the knives and the look. Full length tang, no rivets and a more robust design of the handle.  I purchased from various vendors on Amazon a compliment of around nine knives of various lengths and cutting styles.  I also got two sets of the Twin Cuisine Steak Knives.Speaking for the knife, (cutting portion) they are a great set of knives.  They keep there edge, (as long as you hone them) and I think I have only had to sharpen them a few times over the years.Now for the handles.  Every one of these knives the handles are cracked, not cracking.... cracked.  From my 10" chef knife to the steak knives.  There is definitely a flaw in the plastic used to mold these handles.  I have found references on other forums about this problem with the twin cuisine so buyer-be-ware.Although they are warrantied for life the hassle is you have to send them in one at a time to Henckel, which frankly I have not taken the time to do, and it can take them up to eight weeks to deal with the warranty.

I rarely ever write reviews on products unless they truly stand out as superior.  The Zojirushi rice cooker is one of those products and I speak with experience as an owner of one for over five years now.Five years ago, fed up with cheap rice cookers from the local Big Box stores I went on a quest to find the perfect Rice Cooker.  I started by going to Asian markets in my area to see what appliances they were selling.  Every store had a variety of Zojirushi rice cookers.  So back to the Internet to learn more about Zojirushi.  Site after site praised these units, so I pulled the trigger and got the 10 cup, induction heating unit. (I recommend the bigger unit as opposed to the 5 cup unit)Since owning this unit we have cooked several hundred batches of rice and every time the batch comes out perfect.  The multiple settings for different types of rice could not be more dead on.  Don't know how they do it, don't care...it's just nice to have a kitchen appliance that does what it is suppose to do over and over without one flaw.I have used the timer and again, product came out perfect.We have even cooked Gaba Rice in this unit.  The setting it has for it takes a couple of hours but the overall product is superb.We buy a variety of bulk wild rices from our local grocery store,creating our own wild rice mixture.  Instead of water we substitute homemade chicken stock as the cooking liquid. The finished product is to die for.Oh, and yes you can cook any grain in these units including hot cereals like oatmeal.If your looking for a rice cooker and can look past the price then don't think twice.  The Zojirushi Induction Rice cooker will not let you down.

I'm not going to go into detail on how great this product is.  I think the majority of reviewers have hit it dead on.However, for those posts that complain about the unit not charging all give you a heads up explination.The USB connector that is installed in these units is a joke. It becomes loose from its interior mount and pushes back into the headset to the point that the USB cord when pushed into the headset will no longer make contact with its male counter part.  It still has a snug fit, but it won't charge.We switched all our corporate phones at the first of the year to Evo's and bought Voyager Pro+ headsets for each one.  We have returned so many to our local Sprint Store where we purchased them that they will no longer counter-warranty them.  We are now having to go through Plantronics online warranty.Besides the way they mount the USB port in the headset, I think what happens is the natural human instinct to hold the headset straight forward with one hand when you go to plug in the USB cord.  The problem with this is the USB port ends up being at close to a 45 degree angle, (headset design) so you have tendancy to offset the USB cord when you push it into the unit.  That offset angle causes pressure in the wrong place and eventually allows it to break away inside.  Its the only theory that I can come up with for the number of headsets we are returning for warranty.  If it was just one person I would say abuse, but several, that points to a design flaw.For the most part the units are great, if you use it daily, buy a second one and leave it in the drawer.  Believe me your going want it when that USB breaks.

I bought my first food saver unit over 15 years ago.  This is my fourth unit and my last from Food Saver.  Seriously we got better use out of our very first unit in 1997 then we get out of this latest version.  The last unit prior to this one lasted about two years and I doubt that this latest model will last that long.  This latest unit has been in service for around 16 months.Pros:-Looks cool on the counter and takes up less room with its new vertical design.-Stores a full bag roll nicely, and the bi-directional cutter is a nice feature.-spring loaded vacuum hose, again a nice feature so you don't have to root around trying to find the hose attachment when you need it.-Touch buttons give you a lot of control.-Cleaning is fairly simple for the tray and lower gasket-you have unlimited length, so if you want to vac. a full salmon filet you can do it.Cons:- forget vacuuming anything with any moisture content. For example Shrimp, Fish, even some chicken.  The unit sucks the liquid into a holding tray, which has two metal sensors that shut the unit down.  You have to open the unit, (all go into that next) and then wash out the tray, oh and dry it completely because it won't operate unless its dry.- When you go to open this thing it actually folds open so your going to need counter space to do it. Cannot be done one handed, you need two hands to release push the release buttons.-As others have posted its almost impossible to re-use bags.  The used bags don't seem to trigger the sensor inside the unit properly so it will go through the motion of clamping down on the bag and just when you think its going to start vacuuming it releases the bag.-Again as others have noted when this unit seals you loose about one inch of the bag. So forget trying to get maximum use out of a bag.  Just add an inch to what ever you used to use when bagging.-soups-liquids: First get your video camera out because your going to want someone to tape you doing this for laughs later.  I figured out the perfect way to bag liquids years ago.  I open up our dishwasher and pull out the top tray and place my liquid filled bag on top of that and then place the bag in the old style food saver, and got a clean perfect vacuum every time.  This new style its almost impossible to achieve.  Reason.  You have to shove so much of the bag into unit and when it vacuums, you have to be quick to force a seal, because the tray will instantly fill up with fluid and shut the unit down.  In reality for liquids you have to almost double the size of your bag from the amount of liquid you put in it to make it seal properly using this method.-Finicky operation: Lately the unit will have fits of not wanting to seal.  It will go through the motions and then release the bag.  We shut it off, turn it back on and it will work one time.-Cleaning of the upper portion is difficult, none of the parts come out so you have to really make sure you clean everything otherwise your going to wake up the next morning with a nice funk of a smell, oh and its easy to forget to clean out the tray.  My wife forgot a few weeks ago after vacuuming a bunch of Shrimp.-Pop out bag cutter.  Seriously what were they smoking when they came up with this idea.  A bag cutter located at the bottom of the unit.  The only way you could use this thing is to bring the entire unit to the edge of your counter and then run bag through it, and if your lucky you might get a clean cut.Conclusion:If you do occasional vacuum bagging then these units are for you.  If you bag weekly, like we do in our house, these are not the units to buy.  The cost of the bags/rolls alone, even buying them from Cost co, or online defeats the purpose of having these units.  The best option is to buy one of these units. VacMaster Pro 112 Chamber Machine found here[...]Yea they are a lot more money, but when you research how they operate, vacuum and seal you will understand why you want to go with one of these style units.  The bags in bulk are less money then the FoodSaver Units and will offset the price difference in about a year in our household.

A note of warning to all those that have bought the Twin Cuisine.I purchased multiple knives from various vendors three years ago to make a complete Chefs Set.First Henckel makes a great product, as long as you buy there upper end line that is made in Germany.When I purchased the Twin Cuisine line I went to various restuarant suppliers I work with and tried out varies knives for feel.  I have to say that the Twin Cuisine had the overall best fit for my larger hands.  The weight was there and over course the Henckel name.Last winter I was taking some time to stone sharpen all the knives and I noticed cracking on the plastic molded handles.  Not just one knife but every single knife.  From Steak to Carving.  Every single handle had cracks in them.  After researching this on the net, it looks as if the Twin Cuisines all have this problem after a couple of years.I have yet to send them back to Henckel because they informed me it can take up to 12 weeks for them to warranty them.  (I guess they send them back to Germany vie a boat and then mule express, so I have not taken the time to do it as I need the knives professionally)

I bought a complete set of Twins three years ago.  Pieces from different vendors to make the set.Last winter I was examining the knives and low and behold, every single one of them has cracks in the plastic handles.  It apparently is a noted issue as others have described.JA Henckels are life time warranty, but the only way you can get the warranty is to send the knives in.  I was told by them it can take up to twelve weeks to warranty. so I have not taken the time to send them in.  (although I plan on doing it shortly because it pisses me off, as a Chef, to spend good money and get a half ass product in return for it.)

I have been a Sorel user since the early 70's when they were first introduced in the States in the Lake Tahoe area.  Introduced my wife to them in the mid 90's and she instantly fell in love with them.  I bought my daughter her first pair two years ago. Youth Yoot series.  These were great boots, although when I got them I was dissapointed that the upper was all vinyl and not leather.  Before I bought her next pair I vefified that the upper was all leather, just like the adult series.My daughter loves her new Sorels.  (Just Like Mom and Dads) They were great, get the job done in the harshist and coldest conditions.  Easily dried out at the end of the day, (Sweat from her feet getting so hot in them)If your a fan of Sorels you cannot go wrong with this boot for kids.One recommendation that was taught to me back in the 70's by Sorel personel.  Even though the boots have a water proof upper and stitching, I make it a habit of every pre-season applying "Snow-Coat" to all our Sorels.  I use an old sock, and and an old hair dryer to melt it into the leather and the stitching.  Keeps the leather soft and the seams water proof.I have tromped through ice rivers for miles and never once had a leak in a Sorel.Just to show you the longevity of Sorels.  My first pair, from around 1975 lasted until around 2003.  The only reason I replaced them was there was no more tread left on them.  My wife has been using hers now for around 15 years and they have little to no wear on them..

Bought two of these recently for my wife.  She has an Evo phone with an OtterBox Commuter case on it.  (Figured the second one would be needed as a back up in case they were cheapely made) Little snug for the first week or so, but the case stretched out enough that it holds the phone in its Case perfectly.  Really good construction for such a cheap case.  Leather, belt loops and belt clip, a complete case.  Magnetic flap stays snug over the phone, (once the case has stretched out)All in all a good product for the price

What can I say that others have not already said before.  Great overall keyboard.However be warned.  The lettering on the keys will last around two years and then you will see them gradually fade and be gone.  We have gone through at least ten of these keyboards, all for the same reason,-Faded Keys.

If your going to buy one of these units make sure it's the newer version three blade.  At some point in the last year or so the design changed slightly and they added a third blade.  Home Depot carries these in both the new three blade version and two blade version.  Same model number and SKU#.  The older vs has a tool box located on the left side of unit, looking at it from the entry side.  The newer version the tool box is located under the exit tray.  (Heads up)We have had one of these for about four years.  Only used on a couple of projects. The unit works great as long as you use dry wood.  We bought some Premium 2x6's at Home Depot and on the third to fourth pass the motor on this unit fried.  The so called Premium wood was still to wet for the two blade version Turns out that Ridgid won't honor the lifetime warranty.Also the dust collection on the older version clogs too easily, even when your using a commercial shop vac system.

Been a fan of Pelican products for over twenty years.  From lights to cases.I started using the 2400 Series Stealth Lite years ago because of its rugged design, approvals, (we are a military contractor), and of course the legendary Pelican Warranty.  Although the 2400 is a great flash light, it sometimes is a little to Bulky to carry around.  (Works great as a Hard Hat Lite, though)I started researching lights several months ago and decided on the 2390.Pros: The first thing out of the box is you notice the rugged construction.  It's weight.  It's compact size. This truly feels like a military grade compact flashlight.The touchy feely ends when you throw in the batteries and turn it on.  Wow!!! This is one bright, long throwing flashlight.  Like an idiot I actually turned the light and looked at the illumination.  Instant blindness for a few seconds.  I could see this being a major assist for a Cop or Military person wanted to stop a bad guy in his tracks.In fact my neighbor and good friend who is a cop and officer in the military came over and checked out the light at night.  As he said, "Hands down the best flashlight he had every used."  I had a hard time prying it from his hands when he went home.The ballistic belt holster with extra battery compartment is a big plus.  Easy access to the light and you always have a spare set of batteries on hand when you need them. May not seem like much but when your crawling around in complete darkness and your light starts to go dead those spare batteries can be complete life saver.Finally the truly great feature of this light is how bright it is.  I have been forced in the last few days to use my StealthLight 2400, (see cons below) and to compare the difference, well its like illuminating a room with the sun vs. using a candle.Cons:The Lithium batteries that come with the light,.... A joke.  They lost the Lumens Ummph... at around twenty minutes of operation.  (That's not continuous.  That's my estimate of actually usage time)I did a lot of battery research when the lumen value dropped.  Turns out that others have done the research for us on batteries.  Surfire seems to be the hands down winner on Lithium CR123 battery design and manufacturing.  Cheapest place to buy them... Direct from Surefire.Bought a box of twelve for $21.00 from Surefire.  On the net the same box runs from $28.00 to $34.00.  The Surfire batteries work great in these flashlights.  What ever you do, order extra batteries on the net.  Lithium CR123 batteries at the store will run you around $5.00 to $6.00 apiece, Ouch!!!  Trust me you don't want to be in a jam and need batteries at the last minute.This light has no approvals, for example; CSA- Class I, Div. 2; Gp ABCD, T3C; Class ll; Div. 2; Gp G,; FM- Class I, Div. 2; Gp. ABCD, T3A.; MSHA 10C-633-0; ETL - Class I, Div. 1, GP.D, CL.I, Zone 1, GP. IIA OPERATING TEMP. CLASS T3 CONFORMS TO STD.This probably stems from the Lithium batteries and the heat generated from the bulb more then anything.  It can be a problem for certain industries when these approvals are required for use.  For example Fire Fighting.  Combustable confined areas, etc....The Big Con.I dropped my flashlight from around three to four feet in height directly onto a concrete floor at a job sight the other day.  The light hit at a perfect angle on the corner of the lens hood.  The hood split from its machine threads that screw into the battery compartment base.  Looking at it the threaded portion of the hood is very thinly machined aluminum.  Big bummer because I have gotten used to the flashlight, and now I am forced to use a 2400 Stealth light while I warranty the unit.  Like I said earlier its like using a candle vs. the sun.  Thank god for Pelicans Warranty!!!Conclusion:After getting this light and using it for at least four months, on an almost daily basis I would not trade it for anything.  In fact as I have done with Leatherman products in the past all buy an extra one or two as backups when something breaks.All get some of the tactical Accessories for example the gun mount.  I see this light as a great tool while hunting at night.I will also be buying these for my service guys.  Frankly if the thing did not come with a belt holster I could bet one of my guys would have conveniently borrowed it by now. ;)

I got a good chuckle out of reading some of the negative reviews on this unit. I own an industrial water treatment contracting company and it always strikes me as funny how uneducated people are with water, something they use every day.  I figured I would take a minute and clarify a couple of things for people that use or are planning on purchasing one of these humidifiers, (Oh and yes I actually own one)Humidifiers have been a part of our family for around fifteen years after I read a study on how they can reduce the usual winter ailments, colds and flu's.First how these units work.If you take the humidifying unit apart, you will find two probes.  I believe they make them out of Carbon and other materials.  They are round and about " thick, and approximately four inches long.  These probes are then connected the electrical cord.  When you plug it in and the probes are immersed in water, they create an electrical current between the two probes.  This creates water that boils, and thus creates steam.Some key facts about water.  Pure water will not conduct an electrical current.  This is why the instructions recommend adding a pinch of salt if your unit does not produce steam.  The salt when disolved increases the TDS, (more on that in a minute) thus creating a conductive in the water.Water is considered the Universal Solvent.  In other word's water pretty much will absorb and dissolve anything that we submerge or add to it.  Sometimes instantly. Sometimes over time.  Two key things are in water that effect these humidifiers.  One is the hardness of the water.  Hardness is measured by checking how much Calcium and Magnesium is in the water.  The other effect is Totally Dissolved Solids, or TDS. (all the other minerals that actually dissolve into water)When you boil water, (essentially what these units do), the vapor that they produce is considered pure water or close too pure.  So in essence as the water vapor escapes the unit what is left behind are the residual minerals, (tds) and the hardness, (magnesium and Calcium).  Generally the Hardness cakes on the probes and creates a cement like residual. TDS usually fall out of suspension as clumps.  Gray/black sand/rock formations.So when you read comments in these reviews about residual inside the tank, or that the unit stopped producing steam, what these people are referring to is the residual left over after the water is boiled off.  Depending on the water quality of their tap, the residual can be a lot or very little.Ok, before you purchase one of these units, just remember.  It's $15.00. (Wal Mart has them for a few bucks less) Your not buying an ultra fancy $200.00 BrookStone humidifier/vaporizier.  These are generally one season, low maintenance, throw them away when you're done. (depending how many days out of the year you fire them up)  So keep that in mind.If you want to make one last, you can get some plain white vinegar.  Find a jar or container that the Humidifying unit will fit into.  That means something that the bottom portion that sets in the water not the top part where the cord goes in. (Edited this to better explain it) and fill it with 3/4 vinegar and the rest water, creating a mild acid solution. Set the probe portion in it and let it soak for a day.  Repeat as necessary until the unit operates to your liking.  Note the probes inside the unit do wear out, and hard water deposits do cake up pretty thick on the probes which increase that Wear and Tear effect. (I've taken enough of them apart to know)Bottom line - If you want a cheap way of creating warm humidified air these are the unit for you.  Don't expect anything more then what they price them at, and if you don't plan on maintaining them, ie using vinegar to keep the probes semi-clean of hardness deposits, then expect no more then one to two years of use.

Now THAT'S a tricycle!One of the latest incarnations of the Power Wheels family, the Harley differs in its cool quotient!  ... As in, it's *very* cool.  (Though I have to admit the Jeep Wrangler is pretty cool, too.)It's not apparent from the picture, but the Power Wheels Harley IS three-wheeled.  Like any tricycle, it's possible to tip, but it's pretty stable, in my opinion.This is going to be a HUGE hit with any child lucky enough to get one.  I also think a sit-on vehicle like this is likely to have longer use than a sit-IN toy as a child grows.  The slower speed is fast enough to be fun while being easy for a parent to keep up at walking speed.  When the child is older, you can allow greater speed.This is the best Power Wheels to-date, I think.  It looks good, works well, and is a blast!A few wishes: That the wheels were a LITTLE bit softer and quieter.  The Power Wheels continue the legacy of Hot Wheels trikes in that the hard plastic wheels can be noisy.  And while the HD Cruiser arrived intact, the box took a pretty good beating in delivery.  A beefier box would be nice.

Eh - just another rolling pin ... right?WRONG!  I was *amazed* at the quality of the Epicurean rolling pin when I opened the box.  The finish is exceptional, and the shaping is dead perfect.  I almost passed this item over because I assumed, despite owning other Epicurean items, that this was just an overpriced, prosaic item.  I also thought that because of the solid construction (i.e., the body and handles are one piece) that it would be hard to use.  Absolutely NONE of this turned out to be the case.  This rolling pin is a joy to use.  It positively glides under your hands.  You don't grip the handles, the pin simply rolls under them.  The shape of the handles is such that you have perfect control.  I also like the pin's heft.  The composite construction makes it heavier than most wood pins, which is a very good thing while rolling.  That it is dishwasher safe is just icing on the cake.  Though to be honest, I would prefer hand-washing it anyway.The Epicurean Rolling Pin is a great example of good design and updated materials improving the most common of items.  A functional, tactile, and visual pleasure.Highly Recommended.

Right up front, I should say that I LIKE Lenox. We have a Lenox holiday China set that we just love as well as other Lenox pieces here and there.This trivet, however is not worthy of the brand. It is indifferently made and indifferently finished. We willlikely use it this season, but it will not remain as part of our  permanent holiday decor.Please see the attached pictures. This is a simple cast piece. It obviously comes from a rough mold and requires both surface grinding (plus polishing for the top) and some handwork to remove the flash in the cutouts. Problem is, the polishing and grinding doesn't remove all the pits, a lot of flash remains, and the cast-in feet are so rough that they don't properly fit and are actually splitting their rubber caps.

The Philips Fidelios are quite refined - in construction as well as sound.  Surfaces are textured just so.  Controls move and click with exactly the right pressure and with excellent positive feedback.  They are comfortable (well, as comfortable as possible, given that they are on-ear) and the cushioning is a nice medium soft with no hard or soft spots.  The band initially felt too tight, but lightly springing it outward took care of that.  No cheap wire or metal band extensions here - the band extenders are engineered tubular sliders with a fit and finish that matches the rest of the set.  Even the carrying bag is a step up from the usual.  I'm not sure if it's laminated or a single piece of material, but it's a smooth microfiber on the outside and has a satin interior.The sound is superb (hence the review title).  The Fidelios have an extended range - down to 7 hz and up to 23k hz, and I can't detect any any undue bumps in the spectrum.  Maybe a slight bump in the upper mids, but that's it.  Nothing tinny in the top end (which would drive me around the bend) and I was impressed by the clarity of the low end.  These nicely separate simultaneous low tones and sound/instrument artifacts.  Nothing lost, no mud.  The clarity also adds to their dimensionality.  They are exceptionally quite.  The ambient noise suppression works very well.  I can't detect outside sounds until I have the volume almost off.  It's a pleasant listening experience.I'm not a big fan of on-hear headphones.  I have owned a lot of over the ear headphones over the last 30 years and only a few on-ears.  These are the first on-ears that I would consider the equal of some of my over-ear sets. That they are Bluetooth and fold flat for travel just adds to the attraction.Well Done, Philips!  Recommended.

When I received the roll of Block-It, I instantly cut a piece and held it under running water.  No penetration at all, regardless of force or time (up to several minutes).  Then I immersed it, crushed it under water, and took it out.  First, I snapped it dry.  It left a barely perceptible dampness on the film side which dried quickly, and a slight dampness that lingered for perhaps 15 minutes on the fabric side.I tried ripping it.  Very tough.  I cut it with a knife.  Point penetration takes a litte effort, but then it slices fairly easily.  Even leaving a ragged cut edge, though, it was still VERY hard to tear.  Cuts can be torn - made to run - with a little less effort than the factory edge, but it will not freely run or tear out on its own.  It will deform quite a bit before the edge finally starts to give.  It does not leave a lot of stray fibers sticking out the edge like some wraps.As mentioned above, there is a film side and a fabric side.  The fabric side is pressure-imprinted with a dense dot pattern, in turn making the "channels" on the film side.  "Fabric" (as Kimberly Clark calls it) it isn't really.  It's a dense, thin mat of very fine, non-woven fibers.  It presumably provides the surface area to enhance the breathability and self-drying performance of the barrier, the film side being vapor permeable only.Block-It is softer and nicer to work with than other wraps.  I liked it immediately.Among other things, I use house wrap as pattern material for outdoor products-related sewing.  Need to mock up a tent ... house wrap is just the thing.  It has enough strength for the purpose, comes in large sizes, can simulate weather performance, and comes in sizes for things like tent panels.  Block-It happens to stitch really nicely on a sewing machine.  I think it performs for this purpose better than typical wraps and it appears to be FAR less likely to tear on a stitched seam.I'm not quite sure how it would perform as a ground cloth for camping.  It's tough enough, no doubt there.  It's waterproof enough on the film side.  I just don't know how the fabric side might perform, or whether it might hold too much dampness for too long if it were subjected to an extended rainstorm.All-in-all, a superb product.  A distinct step-up for construction purposes over its most common competitor, and a better alternative for some of its non-traditional uses.Recommended.

Very cute!  Baby soft fur and lovely, squishy body begging to be hugged by a toddler.  No small parts, no loose bits.  Adorable expression.  And while it's billed as a "jumbo," the size is perfect for that toddler to carry anywhere, take to bed, or bring in the car.  A little bigger than the average teddy bear, but not huge at all.Snuffleupagus is one of Sesame Street's gentlest, most lovable characters. The Playschool plush version is a really excellent depiction of him.  Very well done!

Oh.  My.  God.This is REALLY good chocolate.  Rich, smooth, creamy.  just enough body not to melt all over you (but don't hold it TOO long).  And the flavor just keeps on getting better as you eat it.In case you didn't see the full description (for which you have to click the "more" box), this includes *eight* bars.  My first read, as always, was the incredients list.  It's short and sweet (pun intended).  One additive (Soy Lecithin), and that's it.Get it.  You won't regret it.  Unless you eat all of it.  Yourself.  In one sitting.Did I say it was good?

This is the second Lucien Piccard Watch I've received for review and I have to say that this brand continues to delight me with its quality.  AMAZING quality for the street price, in fact.  Very finely-finished and best quality stainless, and finely-fitted face.  Contrary to the description (black dial), the watch matches the picture.  The pearl face is quite pretty and the lines radiating from the center are understated and add - you actually can't see them from all angles.  Similarly, the effect of the crystals is understated.  They give just a little more pop on the pearl face, but this is a great watch for anytime wear.Unlike many brands, you can expect to receive a Lucien Piccard in perfect condition.  I've never seen a watch so completely covered in tight (and thick) wrap.  It covers every bit of the watch, with some parts having more than one layer.  It a bit fussy to get off, but the reward is flawless, polished surfaces.One reviewer commented that you need to get a finger between the band and your wrist to open the latch.  No need ... just lift at the connection point to pop it open.The face is 36mm - very common, mainline size for a woman's watch these days, especially for day wear.Please do note that this is a timepiece only.  No day/date.  No rotating bezel.  No complications, etc.Great materials, excellent (Japanese) movement, perfect fit and finish.  Adaptable to multiple uses and circumstances, short of formalwear.

I like small humidifiers and have had others of this type and size.  Although they are targeted at small spaces - typically bedrooms, or even bedside - I find they work quite nicely for wintertime use in larger spaces.  I've used them for full winter seasons in quite large spaces, including a great room space that included the kitchen and eat-in area in addition to the family room, plus an office.  It's enough (run on full) to take the edge off the dryness when it's really cold outside, and without saturating the air to the point where it's condensing on windows and sills.  (This was in NH.)  Small humidifiers also don't take up much space.The compromises?  Well, size for one.  It works for you in taking up less space - but it means you have to fill it more often.  It can mean that you run it on high more than you would a larger unit.  Plus these small humidifiers aren't really meant to be run 24x7.  I've worn them out ... typically by not descaling often enough.  But offsetting THAT is low replacement cost.The Vicks unit is an improved version of a bubble style humidifier sold by a number of companies.  Vicks adds the projecter functionality, which is terrific for kids, and the capability of adding vapor pads.  They include a sample of their own Vicks brand pads (menthol).  This is a distinct improvement on adding something directly to the water.  The unit is quiet, starts quickly, and is VERY easy to fill without spilling a drop.  The entire bubble top simply lifts off, you open the fill cap on the bottom, fill, replace the cap, then plop the bubble back on the base.  That's it.  No latches, no fittings, no twist locking, no fuss.  An occasional descaling with plain white vinegar is all that's needed for maintenance.Recommended.

This is one of the nicer jewelry items I've received from Amazon to-date. Very elegant and well-sized for dress or club wear - not too big, not too small, though I would say for an adult or perhaps an older teen only (prom wear maybe).  They look and feel like a far more expensive set of earrings.

There are a lot of things to like about this shaker, several of which improve on basic shaker design.First is the integrated juicer.  Obviously irrelevant to a bar setting, it's PERFECT for at-home use where you don't typically have fresh lemon or lime juice.  Not only that, it's stout.  I didn't expect the plastic to be as strong as it is.  The juicer lifts right off without fuss, exposing the strainer top into which it fits!  Very nice integrated design.  The strainer top - the black part in the picture - isn't the usual shaker friction fit that's a pain in the neck, nor is it a fussy screw top.  Plunk it down in the right spot - it's marked, and a quick twist of an inch locks it down.  Leakproof, too, as it's sealed with an O-ring.  The top is plastic, also tough, marked at the 1 and 2-ounce levels, and pops easily onto the shaker top.  It's *also* leakproof as it has its own gasket in the strainer top.  Finally, the tapered main body is really nice to hold while shaking.  Pours nicely, too.A very nice shaker, and one that keeps the mess to a minimum.  Recommended.

Looks good.  Feels great.  It pretty much stops there ...Belkin puts out some nice products.  This isn't one of them.  I liked it when I opened the box.  Attractive design, and it's made of a combination of hard and soft-touch materials that look and feel great.  While not completely non-slip, the soft-touch plastic on the bottom will prevent outright skidding.  It's also pleasantly weighted.  It promises stability and support.It delivers neither.  The phone is perched awkwardly on an oval pedestal from which the Lightning connecter projects.  You would expect the phone to rest against the raised back - but it does not unless you press the pedestal (and phone) back to do so.  The phone is easily rocked in any direction.  A little push to the side and it will fall off the dock entirely.As MANY reviewers have noted, this "case compatible" product is not, in fact, compatible with a great many cases on the market.  I suspect it's not compatible with the *majority* of cases on the market.  I have a very common non-Apple silicone case available at your local big box electronics store and I cannot use the Belkin Mixit without removing the case.  That's a complete deal klller.Disappointing really.  All Belkin needs to do to fix this is to dump the pedestal and provide some adjustabiity for the connecter in the base itself.  Zero to hero.  1 star to 5.

Light weight, and the polished bowl sets off nicely against the dark handle.  The stiffness is just right.  You can tweak it a bit, but it won't bend easily on its own.  The stuff bag fits my fork and (regular-sized) spoon, too.  Superb for camping/hiking, as it keeps your hand a bit further from the heat.

I bought Ultimate Navigation at the same time as Burns' Wilderness Navigation.  The coverage on compass navigation BASICS is similar in both, with a touch extra depth in Ultimate Navigation.  Beyond that, Ultimate Navigation takes things as far as most will care to go.  More coverage in "special environments" (desert, mountains, etc.), more technical detail, more (and sometimes more esoteric) advice.My concern at the time I bought the two books was that Ultimate Navigation would be too much, perhaps confusing.  The slight European cast to the contents didn't help that impression.  I should not have been concerned.  Reading through both at the same time (not literally, of course), I quickly found I preferred Brotherton to Burns.Both Brotherton and Burns have the experience to be regarded at authorities on the topic.  Burns come at it from a hiking/camping point of view, while Brotherton's is rooted in search and rescue.  Even though my interest is the former rather than the latter, I found Brotherton easier to read.Finally, Ultimate Navigation covers topics not included at all in Wilderness Navigation, celestial navigation being the biggie.Highly Recommended.

Soft, non-kink, and a good length, the Iwata hoses run a bit pricier than most other brands, but as one-time, or non-consumables purchases, I don't mind spending a little extra for the quality.  I've never had a connector fail or a leak.  Easy to coil, doesn't take a set.  I use mine with Iwata quick connects as well.  Nice stuff.Recommended.

I bought two Rollypolys, one for my pack, one for my wife's.  These things are little gems.  When rolled up, they are a fraction of the size of most competing dump pouches.  The construction is very stout, too, and the bag stays open on its own beautifully.  The included clip for vertical webbing mounting is a nice touch.  While the Rollypolys have a belt loop, it doesn't seem to add any floppiness when Molle-mounted, as the thing is so compact when rolled up.Ours are mounted on the sides of our packs, low, so that when open you can reach directly into the pouch without fussing with the pack.This is a Swiss Army sort of pouch.  Useful for all kinds of things you wouldn't think of until you have the need.  Anyone who hikes or camps will find uses for it constantly.One reminder applicable to the dump pouch concept, no matter what the brand:  With any MOLLE-mounted dump pouch, you will have to remove the pouch to carry it full or conveniently dump it.  Leave it mounted on your pack and you have 3 options: empty it an item or handful at a time, turn the pouch inside out to empty it, or turn your pack upside down.  Yikes!  Obviously not an issue if you're using it to carry a water bottle or something.I used Blackhawk! 3" Speed Clips to mount mine.Highly recommended.

I recently bought a couple of Maxpedition Rolypoly dump pouches.  I really don't care for their Tac Ties and I'm not too fond of some of the other strap alternatives on the market either.  So I grimaced and bought the Blackhawk! Speed Clips.Wow, these things really hold!  I had my doubts.  Would the clips at each end slip off the PALS webbing?  Would the pouch feel secure?  Could it be knocked off ...The clips not only hold, but are somewhat difficult to get over the webbing until you get the hang of it.  There is no shaking or bumping off of the pouch.  These are as secure as conventional snap straps.  While those may be permanently attached to the pouch at the top, snaps do pop open, and it is somewhat easier for a soft strap to work loose if it does than for the Speed Clips to come off on their own.  But that's cutting a fine line, I think.  The point is that the Speed Clips hold very well indeed."Speed," however, may be overstating things a bit.  I'll grant that you can get them off pretty quickly, but getting them on still takes a bit of time.  If you really need rapid off AND on, perhaps you're better off with something like Vanquest's molle sticks.  The Blackhawk! Speed Clips are best viewed as an excellent alternative to the several other semi-permanent strap options out there.Recommended and available in several sizes and a couple of colors.  As my pack is khaki and my wife's black, I just bought black for both.  You don't really see them anyway.

An excellent compass overall.  Very rapid needle settling.  Easy turning bezel with just the right amount of friction.  It's very forgiving of level.  I prefer the centered direction of travel arrow to other models' two arrows (one on each side).  Accurate.My only complaint is that the declination adjustment, while it holds firmly, is hard to adjust because it's SO hard to see the scale.  TINY and RED.  Both of which make it a real eye buster.  Bright daylight with a white background works best.

Pretty, well-made and finished.  I'm not a big fan of the semi-hollow back design, but the rope-twist is really well done.  Nice as an accent piece, perhaps a little finger or thumb ring (depending on size and taste).  The Amazon collection keeps on keeping on!  Good buys all.

This is a humongous watch.  Some automatic chronographs are this large to incorporate a lot of complications ... but this is a quartz watch with only the most basic chrono functions.  Reviewers seem to have received different watches.  Mine DOES have the 21446 Pro Diver tag on it, does have the typical 3 embedded chrono dials as well as the dedicated start, stop/reset buttons, and does have a rotating bezel (counterclockwise only, as is often the case).  Note that the bezel is VERY stiff when new.  (That's OK.)Stylish?  Opinions differ.  Gold isn't my cup of tea, but the styling itself is classic diver watch, with big number markers, easily read bezel marks, and nice, big crown and buttons.  Mine came with a stainless steel bracelet, not the band pictured.  As a fashion accessory, big is in!  So it actually works for the ladies for certain kinds of outfits.  Otherwise, think big guy.  6'4"+?  This is your watch.  I can almost guarantee the band or bracelet will be big enough, too.So, whether as a user or a fashion accessory, it works.  As long as you like gold.  As long as you like BIG.  Purely from a ratings perspective, I gave it three stars because I think the overall quality is OK, but it's just a bit much.  As a user (diver watch), I would no particular concerns for its water resistance, but would prefer a bezel with deeper cuts for better grabability.

This is a very nicely-made and finished watch at this (street) price point.  It is competing with everything from aluminum, plastic, and pot metal cases with cheaper straps, to a lot of lesser stainless steel models.  The back of the LP, if not the rest, is 316 stainless.  The entire watch, both case and strap, is just beautifully finished and polished.  The quartz movement is Japanese (usually a pick-up over the more common Chinese movements on watches in this price range.There is exactly nothing rose or rosy on this watch, despite the model name.  And despite it being described as a woman's watch, it leans a lot more toward being a genderless sports watch design than feminine.  The only nod to the latter is really the outsized Roman numerals on the dial.Please note that the dive-type bezel is stationary and there is no sweep second hand.  I.e., the bezel is a decorative element.  There are no secondary functions on this watch - including day/date.  It is time only.  The watch is water RESISTANT only.  It is NOT waterproof.  All of this is informational.  Lucian Piccard is not posturing this watch as something it is not.  It is a timepiece and a dress accessory.  I include these comments for anyone unfamiliar with watches who is looking for a functional sports watch (dive, chronometer, etc.), perhaps as a gift.Minor criticisms are that the case is bit thicker than I would like, given that it's a timepiece only, and the crown, attractive though it is, is small and shaped in a way that makes it a bit hard to turn.In it's price class and for it's intended purposes, I think this is quite a bit better made than many.  It is a good buy.

I prefer Iwata's QDs at the airbrush end for the simple reasons articulated in the title.  They are dead-reliable, small, and light.  If you use some other (unmentioned) brands, you might be taken aback at first by how small they are.  No worries, though, I've never had one fail yet.  Typical Iwata quality.

I really like this pack a lot.  It has compromises in size, organization, weight, construction, and so on, but every pack does.  For my uses - bug-out, survival, daypack, compact weekender, etc., it excels.  The organization of the admin compartment is superb.  The external PALS coverage is exactly what I wanted.  I wanted a strong handle.  It's tough.  And it's comfortable for both me and my wife (I bought two), i.e., no anatomy issues.Leaving aside the "normal" compromises, there are only a few things I'd like to see in addition.  The biggest of those is some PALS webbing on the back panel of the main compartment.  I understand why they are not there, of course, given the panel material, and that I could use a standalone panel, but still ...  Second, It would really nice if the admin compartment were a detachable bag.  I can add such a bag, naturally, but I don't want to transfer the contents, and much of what's in the admin section is useful for those side trips away from the pack and also casual use around town besides, were I able to clip it to a shoulder strap.No impact on this review, but 5.11 - WHEN ARE YOU GOING TO COME OUT WITH A STANDALONE SLICK STICK SYSTEM!!!!???  I'd replace my Blackhawk speed clips in a heartbeat!

Absolutely 5 stars ... but you really, really, really need to know its best use, and why THAT'S what drives the rating.The "nots" first (as applied to best use):It's not for learning knots.It's not for knowing their applicability.It's not for knowing alternatives or limitations ... even, in some case, their dangers.It's not for comprehensive tying instructions.It's not for perspective on cordage, as applied to knots or otherwise.What it IS is a compact, limited, reminder reference.  Like many other reviewers, I could pick over which knots to include or exclude.  I have decided opinions on being cautious with some of those included.  I don't NEED the reminder for all of them ... which represents unwanted weight and bulk in an emergency pack.But still - as a reasonably chosen set, in a very compact form, waterproof, and crystal clear (I obviously disagree with a few reviewers on this), it nails its best use for me.  I.e., in that aforementioned pack.If you need a good knot learning reference, I highly recommend the Grog Knot app and website.  This is one instance in which apps are better than books for learning.  Animations are enormously helpful.

Review preface - I'm the enterprise data architect in one of the largest financial services firms in the US.  My comments pertain to such environments.I found this book ... conventional.  Perversely, I suppose, I found it too data-centric!  Data does NOT drive the organization.  Data - or better, information - informs it, and the difference goes a lot further than subtleties.  The author takes things a bit far, IMHO, when it comes to suggesting C-level roles for data and analytics.Data management issues are legion and getting more complex all the time.  You cannot fix, solve, correct, or compensate them for them in the ways suggested by the author.  Mind you, that does not obviate the need to take many of the steps covered in the book.  After all, if you have a need for mastered data in a particular context, you have the need.  Addressing data quality, especially narrowly focused on an issue, will always be necessary.But none of the data management topics in the book, and that's what they are, will really address the information needs of a large, complex, modern corporate environment except at the margins.  The goals, beyond simple monitoring mechanisms like dashboards and KPIs (the bane of my existence) are sometimes put in an analytics framework.  They might be articulated as descriptive, prescriptive, and predictive, for example.  Reporting strategies.  Models.  Etc.  All of these are a house of cards built on assumptions of ownership, control, quality, security, and enforcement that are increasingly irrelevant.  Want hardening of the company data arteries?  Put modern "data management" in place.  If it doesn't consume your company's entire budget or drive you to the bin, it will leave you holding, in a few years, a figuratively unoccupied leash wondering where the dog went as everyone, every business process, every vendor system, every legacy situation, every new technology, and every bit data freely available everywhere and anywhere undermines and obviates your strategy.Here's the heart of it.  State.  We increasingly need ALL of our data in every conceivable state, in motion or at rest, even temporary and error-ridden, in infinitely possible combinations.  Oh, and the rest of the world's data too, in the same way.  No matter what your data management activity perspective, the problems just became insurmountable.  The fact that most data forms don't carry sufficient state or sematic information complicates things further.Doubless, I'm preaching to the choir here.  But wait, you say, how about the more limited usages mentioned earlier?  Doesn't that validate the need for data management structure?  Well, yes and no.  I'll stipulate the value of (data) control and definition within the context of a business operational process.  But recognize that NON-operational data use, process-bound or not, is made more difficult by those controls and definitions.  I'll note in passing that non-documented and unofficial processes exist (sometimes properly) WITHIN the boundaries of a larger business process ... and it is often the data in THIS context that is wanted by someone over yonder!  (Just ask your nearest auditor.)Finally, consider how any particular data is becoming increasingly irrelevant.  (Again, all of this in the context of a very large organization or corporation.)  An insufficiently appreciated phenomenon of truly vast data availability is that data compensates for data.  What if you had, as a vendor who recently presented at my firm has, 30,000+ data points per person, tracked within thousands and thousands of tiny geographic boundaries?  Don't have this or that data?  This bit is old or of suspicious quality?  Don't have access to yet something else?  Guess what ... you can impute that data with astounding (and known) statistical accuracy.  Um, your PII data policies aren't gone - you're going to be held to them, possibly to criminal violation levels, but it's now security theater and better viewed as a cost burden rather than a control.By all means, have at the activities in "Creating a Data Driven Organization."  It is well-written and clear (hence the 4 stars).  You really have to to be able to operate.  Just don't expect it to actually rise to the title's promise in the modern world.Parting shot - expect "the organization" to fragment, too.

I cannot tell you how many sets of drills, bits, ratchets, and so on that I've purchased over the years.  It seems like half the time I go out to purchase a drillbit, I wind up with a set because the pricing is so heavily biased toward sets. I.e., I can buy a single bit Or an entire set for a couple of bucks more.So in several respects, this Bosch 91 piece set is no different.  It has the usual assortment If larger than most.  Screwdriver bits, flathead, Phillips, star, and Torx.  A ratchet handle. A small assortment of nutdrivers.  And several types of drills, including masonry, general purpose, and brad bit.  The last is a nice addition. They can be hard to find in the big box stores, and are much, much better to use in wood then the general purpose bits most people use.At the proposed sell price (this set is pre-release as I write this), this is a LOT of set for the money.  I have a few minor complaints, but the set is so well priced that I cannot in good faith give it less than five stars.The complaints are these: I don't like the cheap, blowmolded case.  Cases of this type of  ALWAYS wind up unable to hold some of the tools firmly.  The way Bosch has implemented it, I'm not sure if they have addressed the problem or made it worse. Rather than mounting the bits and drills directly to the blowmolded surface, they are placed into soft plastic holders first.  These feel almost like the soft, white plastic erasers you used in school.  A couple of them had already slipped out of place in shipping.  Second, the ratchet handle is serviceable but not terribly high quality, either.  Good enough for homeowner use, but I look on it as an eventual throwaway.  The quality of the various bits remains to be seen.  I like Bosch tools quite a lot but I don't expect best quality bits in these sets anyway.So the rating leans heavily toward value for the money. Sure, a "better" alternative is a nice selection of, say, Excelite or Wiha nut drivers and screwdrivers, and some top quality drills,  but a) that's going to cost some serious coin, and B) that's not what most people really need anyway.  I guess this is another way of saying that if you keep finding yourself buying set after set like me, perhaps a better alternative is to go for broke and buy top-of-the-line tools ... hopefully once.  But if you are in the typical homeowner category, this is a well appointed set for the money.

These are clearly better alternatives to the gloves found in the big box stores, supermarkets, etc.  They are a bit more durable. They seem to fit better. And the very light texture helps without being too much at all.  Interestingly, after receiving these, I noticed this brand of gloves being used in a local salon and spa.Unless you go through these things like water through a sieve and use them lightly besides, the few extra dollars you will pay for these  and it is only a few  is worth it.

When my wife first started using airbrush makeup, we did not have a cleaning station.  We thought that since everything she was using was water-based and that the cleaner was water thinnable besides, that simply spraying out into some paper towels or perhaps the wastebasket would be fine.Oh my God, no!  Trust me, the last thing you want is to get a good lung full of airbrush cleaner mist!  So we quickly and I mean quickly acquired an Iwata cleaning station.Like all Iwata equipment, the cleaning station is very nicely made indeed.  It has a well shaped, weighty, frosted glass jar, heavy duty lid with replaceable filters for the exhaust port, a heavy-duty chrome airbrush support, and a matching chrome loop handle.  The port for the airbrush tip is rubber grommeted.  The whole thing may be taken apart and stored in its own jar!Functionally, it is perfect. It's dead simple to use and filters beautifully, besides catching excess cleaner and paint (or makeup) in the jar, of course.  It is also aesthetically nice, which was something of a surprise given it's utilitarian nature.We have since acquired another, as we have added airbrushes. There was no question as to which cleaning station to buy after the experience with the first.Highly recommended!

We recently re-did our bedroom closet,  in the process adding a third tier of shirt hanging rods  near the (10') ceiling.  At first, we thought we would use a stepstool that we keep in the closet. That got old fast!  Looking into hanger hooks, we found a variety of rigid and telescoping types.  We decided to go with the commercial quality, rigid, one piece hook. I'm glad we did!  The quality is really, really good. One piece, chrome steel.  Nicely finished wood handle.  And the book is generously sized. Surprisingly, it is lighter than we expected.  It works beautifully and easily.  When done, it hangs  dead straight  on the end of the middle tier hanging rod.  So no fussing to find it in a dark corner or having it get tangled up in things.This was an inexpensive, easy win for us.  Highly recommended over the gimmicky, multi-piece and consumer grade alternatives.

I bought this knife for my wife after she saw the ladybug version. She wanted something slightly larger than that knife and thought the dragonfly knife a bit nicer besides. When the knife was delivered and she opened it, it exceeded both our expectations! This is a beautifully made knife.  The fit and finish on her example is about as close to perfect as I have seen in this price range.  Every bit of it is well finished. The knife arrived shaving sharp.  The lockup is really strong.  (lockback-type)  She even commented on the quality of the clip and its attachment.  Unlike other knives she owns, this one stays in an organizer next to her living room chair, where she keep it at hand for constant use.  As a fine craft object, despite being machine made, I see her pick it up from time to time to simply look at it and enjoy it, too. The Dragonfly is Japanese made.  As with many Japanese Spyderco knives, it uses VG10 steel.  It seems to be a good choice for this knife.  It holds an edge well for the household uses to which it is put, is easy to sharpen, and is a nice step up from the run-of-the-mill stainless types used in cheaper knives.The knife was a bit stiff when new, but is breaking in quite nicely. I'm happy to report that the thumbhole is usable for one-handed opening of this knife, though I had my doubts before it arrived due to the knife's small size.  As a lockback, of course, it requires both hands to safely close it.Recommended!  And though I have never been a huge fan of Spyderco knives, this one has notably piqued my interest in them.

These are as well made as the other jewelry in the Amazon curated collection.  Good detail. Good construction.  The materials, of course, have been either downgraded from fine jewelry or upgraded from costume jewelry, depending on your point of view.In this case, you get sterling silver, man-made white sapphires, and processed (though genuine) amethyst.  That combination at this price is a very good value.I'm giving these earrings only four stars, however, as I thought they came off a bit flashier than elegant.  They are of a (larger) size that lends them best to dress wear.  I believe they would be too much, too large for every day wear, unless perhaps you work in a rather formal environment, simply like to wear a lot of jewelry, or like larger pieces.  Don't take my size comments too literally though!  They are not huge or anything - simply bigger than most people wear as everyday stud earrings.

I can't speak to professional needs, but for the layman and for typical residential use, this is a SUPERB reference.  Printed on heavy-duty, water-resistant paper, ring-bound to lay flat, and sensibly organized, the DeWalt Electrical Code Reference is instantly usable.  Every page covers a single topic.  Every page is *clearly* illustrated with a photograph.  Supplementary graphics are used sparingly and well.  Every element in each photograph is numbered and corresponds to notes and instructions below the photo with corresponding numbers.  The overall organization of the reference is electrical basics (wiring types, terminals, outlets, etc.), then room types (bath, kitchen, basements, etc.), then lesser-used topics (outbuildings, mounted equipment, service entrances, underground cabling, etc.).  Tables are provided - inline with the content where you need them - to size conductors, boxes, compute loads, etc.This is usable as a desk reference, but its small size, clarity, durability, and instant access to information makes it perfect for homeowner use where the work is being done.  This is easily the best reference I've seen for this use.  Highly recommended.

The Cuisinart CSG-900 setup is quite nice.  Range is SUPERB, with monitoring up to 300' away.  I REALLY like that it takes two probes. One monitors the grill's temp itself, and the package includes a grill/grate standoff, and one probe for the food.This setup is about as good as it gets for my Big Green Egg smoker setup. Smoking/barbecueing things like pork shoulder, brisket, etc. can be a bit of a pain from the standpoint of maintaining smoker temp within a few degrees over as long as 15-20 hours.  I'm accustomed to going outside frequently to check and adjust.  A remote monitoring solution is going to save a lot of trips.I don't have to worry about internal meat temps when smoking meat all day.  But I do for barbecuing and grilling larger items with shorter cooking times.  Enter the Cuisinart's food probe.  Not terribly useful to have a remote for a quick grill item, of course - but something like a 2" filet or a whole chicken?  Absolutely.Although the CSG-900 seems well enough made, I'm unsure of the longevity of the plastic.  I would have preferred something tougher and perhaps even rubberized, particularly for the outdoor unit.  The latter, by the way, is weather-sealed, with a gasket on the battery compartment door.  You have to use a screwdriver to open the compartment, unfortunately, but the machine screws thread into brass inserts, not the plastic, so no problem there.

I like these quite a bit. They are frankly better constructed then I expected. The steel is a decently thick gauge without being too heavy. Nothing flimsy here at all. The tips are thicker than the body, as they should be, and are well shaped and perfectly aligned.  I like the soft touch coating. It appears to be well adhered, where I was concerned that it might come off as a cheap dip. The benefit to the extra width is that you can adjust your grip easily. It doesn't do anything for you except the final third near the tip, however, the rest is really styling and only adds weight. At a slightly lower price point, I might give these five stars. As they are at a price where they are competing with really high-quality professional tools, I will knock them back one star as they don't quite rise to that level. As nice as the soft touch feature is, for example, I'm not sure you would want to autoclave these if you have that sort of usage.

As with my prior review of these labels in another format, these are truly stellar quality.  I particularly like their matte surface,  as it readily takes most pens and markers, besides being printable.  Glue adhesion works just as you would like it too. The labels stay put when you want them to and come off when you need them to.  They ARE waterproof.  Well, I wouldn't soak them in a bucket of water permanently, or anything like that, but they are going to resist getting wet quite nicely.  Do not get the glue wet before you stick the label down, however!  It won't stick! Once it's there, no problem.  The larger format of these labels is really convenient if you have a lot of text or graphics. Just be aware that the cost per label is quite a bit higher, too.  There are several hundred more labels per pack in the smaller format. Use what you need, of course, but I actually find the smaller format the most useful size.

The DLL apron has an interesting mix of qualities.  Mostly good.(Preface - I'm a 5'8.5" male.)The apron body itself is larger than usual.  It extends WELL over my sides into the back a bit.  Full side coverage!  The top of the apron (chest, blouse, or upper) is similarly generous, bordering on too large.  Why too large?  Because I have to tighten the neck strap to keep it from sagging to the point where it's hard to slip over my head.  It likely would work better on a woman as many aprons are defiicient in this regard.The straps are asymmetic.  Longer on one side than the other.  As I like to tie an apron in the front, they are barely long enough, but do work.  Because they are asymmetric, the tie ends up on the side (which is fine).The fabric is THIN.  Hold it up to the light and you can see through it. Washing will shrink it a little.  (I'll return to this review after more use.)  That includes both the body of the apron as well as the straps.
