Besides concerns over bleed-through, it is hard to get the apron to lie completely flat - not quite enough body for that.  The rings holding the neck strap are smallish and light-gauge steel.  That turns out to be a Good Thing, however, as they hold the strap tightly and do not slip, unlike many others on the market.Well constructed.  Well sewn.  Inexpensive.

I have had Acme Thunderer whistles for over 50 years.  The 60.5 is my favorite, hands-down.  Small, beautifully made, loud, and great tone.  I will say parenthetically that I'm pretty impressed by their plastic 660 too, though.The chrome will wear off the edges eventually, giving it nice patina without changing anything else.  In fact, you can BUY this whistle in un-chromed brass if you want.  (or gold-plated, for presentation, or engraved, or ...)The Thunderer line isn't a world reference standard for nothing!

(This review duplicates one I posted for another Wrangler pair in the same line, though different sizing and slightly different design.  Same quality.  Same fit.)Frankly, much better than expected! I mostly gave up on Wrangler years ago. This pair of pants, though still a lower-priced, minimally-designed, mass-market item, is nonetheless excellent in several ways. The fit is spot on, waist to ease in hips and butt, crotch, and thighs to hems. Detailing, such as it is, is good, from zipper and studs to stitching. A substantial, jeans-like button/stud closure. The material is lightweight, but tough. I appreciate that as an alternative to jeans, as I currently live in the South. These are stretch pants, but that has been done *minimally* and just right (5% spandex). Just enough to ease movement. These are not the stretch poly pants of decades ago.

This is my first plastic ACME whistle - I bought a yellow 660 also. (I'm a huge fan of their metal whistles, having owned them for 50 years.) I kept a couple of other plastic whistles, having tried and tossed them over the years. One is a Fox 40. Until now, I thought that was about as good as you could get with plastic. The ACME 660 blows it away - pun intended. It is incredibly easy blowing, light, tough, and LOUD. Loud and high-pitched ... higher than an ACME 60.5. In fact, it is just short of shrill. It WILL get attention. Any reasonable blow on the 660 will give a classic pea whistle sound, which differentiates it from pea-less warbling-type whistles with multiple holes, which have different sound qualities at different pressures.

Heavy-gauge steel.  Good fit, good finish, easy mounting.  What more could you need?  Well, perhaps a slightly lower price - these cost half as much as the rack to which they're mounted!  But they do the trick nicely supporting a cover.  While you can get away without cover supports, you'll eventually catch the cover in a hanger and rip it, so bite the bullet and get the supports.

I was quite dismayed on receiving the mount box.  It was tiny!  OMG, I thought, this is going to be some ungodly conglomeration of small parts engineered to fit in small, flat package, ala IKEA.Nope, this mount is a robust chunk of heavy-gauge steel.  It's *beautifully* made (as well as designed), smooth in operation, though stiff when new, and dead simple to put together and mount.  I particularly appreciate that you have some leveling capability after the mount is up.  I also didn't appreciate, until the TV was up, that there is a good amount of side-to-side positioning available, as well as tilt and swing, due to the way the support arms work.The finish on the mount is as flawless as the design.  It has a really good coat of paint (may be powder coat - not sure about that), and not a burr, bit of flash, or sharp edge ANYWHERE.  Everything is smooth, radiused, surface finished, and painted perfectly.All fasteners are included, including lag bolts for the wall.  They are packaged - wait for it - in a compartmented strip of heavy plastic bag ... each type of fastener in its own compartment and labeled!  I've never seen anyone else do that.  The quality of the hardware appears good and it, like the mount, is painted and matches.  Machine screws and spacers are provided to match a wide variety of TV fastener needs.The only thing that extended my installation was the discovery that my walls are steel framed (this is an apartment).  So I needed to use anchors and not the provided lag bolts.  No problem, just took a run to the store.  I had a brief scare after opening everything up thinking my TV wasn't compatible, but quickly figured out there were hidden mount points under a piece of the table-top mount that I hadn't removed yet.  When I called EchoGear support, I had someone on the line within a couple of minutes.  Terrific service.I couldn't be happier with this mount.  Stellar quality at a world-beating price.  I almost bought a full-motion mount at Best Buy for nearly $200.  And the EchoGear mount is a far better product for a MUCH lower price.  It simply cannot be beat.

I like these.  They are well-made and fit my Z-Racks (with cover supports) well.  These are a good alternative to vinyl if you need to block light.  My only complaint, hence the 4 stars, is that I find them over-priced for what they are - a fairly simple, lightweight nylon cover with 2 zippers.  It seems like it should be possible to sell these for a fraction of the current price.  They are almost as much as a decent, basic rack!The Garment Store was terrific, by the way.  They went right out and I had them in just a couple of days.

This is my first plastic ACME whistle.  (I'm a huge fan of their metal whistles, having owned them for 50 years.)  I kept a couple of other plastic whistles, having tried and tossed them over the years.  One is a Fox 40.  Until now, I thought that was about as good as you could get with plastic.  The ACME 660 blows it away - pun intended.  It is incredibly easy blowing, light, tough, and LOUD.  Loud and high-pitched ... higher than an ACME 60.5.  In fact, it is just short of shrill.  It WILL get attention.  Any reasonable blow on the 660 will give a classic pea whistle sound, which differentiates it from pea-less warbling-type whistles with multiple holes, which have different sound qualities at different pressures.A great whistle in modern materials - and still in the Thunderer family of tones.  The 660 is an excellent choice for a keychain whistle.  Light and in a bright color, you won't mind carrying it, and it's easy to find instantly.

Frankly, much better than expected!  I mostly gave up on Wrangler years ago.  This pair of pants, though still a lower-priced, minimally-designed, mass-market item, is nonetheless excellent in several ways.  The fit is spot on, waist to ease in hips and butt, crotch, and thighs to hems.  Detailing, such as it is, is good, from zipper and studs to stitching. A substantial, jeans-like button/stud closure.  The material is lightweight, but tough.  I appreciate that as an alternative to jeans, as I currently live in the South.  These are stretch pants, but that has been done *minimally* and just right (5% spandex).  Just enough to ease movement.  These are not the stretch poly pants of decades ago.I'm wearing them to work tomorrow.Nicely done, Wrangler!  And at a good price point!

Most of the details in the build of the CM57 are quite nice.  The body material provides a nice grip - well-shaped, too.  The LCD is excellent.  Big, bright symbols and numerals.  No pixellated nonsense here, and the backlight is just right.  The battery door is solid and sealed with what appears to be a neoprene gasket.  It screws closed with a very small philips screw.  I'm not fond of compartments like that, but the CM57 at least has a threaded brass insert, and the screw itself is captive.  It is NOT screwed directly into the plastic body of the meter.  The flexible loop itself is covered with a very tough material and should last a long time.  The points where the cable plugs into the body seem a little flimsier, and I find the twist-lock mechanism to be a little fussy, but it works.  It just doesn't give the same confidence as the rest of the meter.  The built-in (LED) flashlight function seems gimmicky at first, but is well-integrated (when the meter is on, the on/off switch is used to control the flashlight) and is handy.Meter operation is dead simple.  Loop goes around the conductor of interest.  Turn the meter on - it defaults to auto-ranging.  Change the range with a push of the range button if you want.  Inrush has a dedicated button.  Bluetooth is built-in and works with the FLIR app.  I didn't test this, as I have no need for it.  I did verify that Bluetooth works, however, and it's easy to turn on.  Hold and record functions are accessed with a long push of the relevant button and turn on an indicator in the LCD when you do.The "instruction manual" is 1 page.  1 page for every language on the planet, that is. (OK, to be fair, it's a "getting started" doc.)  It comes with a CD containing 15 PDFs, however.  Each is a separate language version of a full manual.  19 pages, but that's all you need.  One bit of detail of importance to many:  Inrush detection is 100 MS after pressing the Inrush button.  Thresholds are by range and non-adjustable.  They are: A) 30A range - minimum triggering threshold is 0.5A, B) 300A range - minimum triggering threshold is 5.0A; and C) 3000A range -  minimum triggering threshold is 50A.Boxed, and no case, unfortunately.  All-in-all, a robust, stand-alone flexible "clamp" AC-only current meter.Nice meter and should be on your short list if you are looking for one of this type.Note to FLIR - the included Eveready batteries were DOA ...

As with my review of the corresponding 2-tier Z Rack I ordered from the Garment Rack Store, these are excellent quality.  These are heavy-duty, all steel, and sturdy.  The chrome plating and paint (base) is excellent.  Casters are almost ridiculously smooth.  I'm very pleased with the quality, price, and service from the seller.

Terrific quality.  These are heavy-duty, all steel, and sturdy.  The chrome plating and paint (base) is excellent.  Casters are almost ridiculously smooth.  I'm very pleased with the quality, price, and service from the seller.

I am using these to label plastic storage bins (45 gallon size).  We have about 80 of them in our storage unit and have been writing contents on the original factory labels, as we haven't found any until now that were really suitable.  Our requirement is that it be readily writable with pen, sharpie, pencil, etc., that it be tough, and that it can be peeled off.These labels are PERFECT.  Matte surface that's easily writable and non-smear.  Sharpie dries instantly.  They are really, really tough.  Although they feel like simple paper, you can't tear them.  They don't abrade, and they are waterproof.  They peel off the plastic bins easily, but don't peel off too easily either (e.g., from a rub).  Really, they are perfect for this.They are, unfortunately, quite expensive.  But in this case, you get what you pay for.  Amazon's price at least gives a decent discount.

I love this book.  Clear instructions, with multiple recipes with and without starters.  Great comments on ingredients and how each is appropriate to different styles. Good pictures throughout.  I was disappointed by the Greek style of the Northeast US being left out, as that's what I grew up with, but there's PLENTY of other styles to keep me busy for a long, long time.Tony likes the two baking steel approach, which is reflected in his instructions.  I like to use one in conjunction with the broiler.  No problem adapting either way, though.Probably the best single volume on pizza making out there.

I love my Mora knives.  On most counts, the Light My Fire knife is typical Mora.  The blade grind is a little unusual at the tip, but otherwise the usual Scandi grind.  Quality is 100% Mora and you get the usual Mora sheath.I'm of mixed opinion on the fire steel feature.  It *works* really well.  Good bright, hot strike easily and every time.  The handle storage is convenient, but doesn't really feel as though it locks securely in place, feeling more like a friction "lock."  So Im not so thrilled by that, hence the 4 stars.  Lose the fire steel and you're missing part of your knife handle.  I got the knife on an Amazon lightning deal at a good price.  It is otherwise a bit high for a Mora.  This one will live in a bug-out bag as an emergency knife.  All-in-all, I think I prefer a separately-stored fire steel on a sheath.

Absolutely 5 stars.  This stapler is *beautifully* designed and made.  It functions flawlessly and effortlessly.  It is literally the smoothest, easiest stapler I have ever used, bar none.  My first test was through the box it came in, folded several times.  Click.  Click Click.  Wow.  Through cardboard layers with no effort and perfect function?  No misses, no munged staples, no jams.  Perfect.  It is now my work stapler, replacing the typical office-supplied junk.Buy it.  And put your name on it.

We have owned several Foodsavers over the years.  The oldest - bought perhaps 25 years ago - lasted the longest.  It finally gave up the ghost a couple of years ago.  We bought several others (also Foodsaver), but none lasted very long.So I did some research and bought a Weston commercial sealer AND two hand impulse sealers.  Perfect!  You can seal bags of liquid without bubbles with a little care with an impulse sealer.  (Ours are AIE with 5mm wide seals.)  And the Weston vacuum sealer is incredible.  Fast and powerful, economical with bag rolls, and it has a clear sealing cover so you can see what's going on ... important when packing moist and juicy items (like meat ...).  This current setup, which works very well indeed, is the standard for testing Foodsaver's Gamersaver sealer.As others have pointed out, the Gamesaver is BIG.  Really big.  Too big, and frankly, I don't see a reason for it.  The Weston can seal bags as wide, and that unit is quite a bit smaller.  The motor is powerful enough to pull a decent vacuum.  It isn't as fast as the Weston, nor the vacuum *quite* as good, but it's close, and it's more than good enough.  The Gamesaver has a progress indicator consisting of a series of LED lights.  Nice, but not necessary.  Sealing is somewhat slow, but is VERY good.  The double seal is nice - worthwhile when sealing for longer-term storage ... and a reason we bought our wide-seal impulse sealers for bag-making (among other things).  It is one of the Gamesaver's best features.  I dislike the solid seal cover.  You can't always count on pre-freezing items, nor is it always desirable, and that means you're sealing wet items blind.  The Gamesaver has a decent setup for handling this, using a removable/cleanable liquid catch tray and suctioning UP (through the cover), rather than down, which has a better chance of getting into the motor.  It's an improvement, but a clear cover works better in that you can not only avoid pulling liquid into the pump (which is what the Gamesaver setup addresses), but can hit the manual seal at the precise moment that the bubbles are gone and BEFORE there is a lot of liquid across the seal area.  Liquid in the seal can compromise the seal!  Finally, I really don't like the excess bagging required to seal.  While we usually DO use extra-long bags when sealing large quantities, that's so we have enough bag to cut and re-seal after using a portion.  The Gamesaver requires excess *beyond* the seal, which not only negates that approach, but would use extra bag inches on re-sealing.Bottom line is that the Gamesaver improves on the standard Foodsaver machine in several ways: bag size capability, seal quality, double seal, vacuum power, decent cutter, stainless steel exterior, cord storage, etc.  But it competes at this price point with machines that are its equal or better.  All-in-all, the Gamesaver is a good machine ... as long as you can get it at a good discount.  Perhaps it will come down over time to a more competitive price.

I'm of two minds on this product.  It does work - quite well, in fact.  It closes slowly, gently, and quietly.  It is very lightweight, though.  Molded plastic instead of the solid construction of (typically) higher-end products.  I'm not sure how well it will last.  On the other hand, it's not terribly expensive, either.  I wouldn't use it in a bathroom that would get heavy use (kids), or for unusual applications, like bariatric use.  For average adult use, it should be fine.  It came well-packaged and with installation hardware.

I found the fit and finishon these cutters better than expected.  They are well-aligned and adjusted.  The handles are comfortable.  Surfaces are well-enough finished for their purpose.  ... which is WIRE cutting.  These are NOT bolt cutters. They cut hard wire effortlessly, however, and that is their best use, in my opinion.  They are rated for up to 3.8mm music wire.One such use is hobby pliers.  You'll chew up your jewelry wire cutters pretty quickly if you start cutting hard wire with them.  I also wouldn't use these for production-like uses (e.g., cutting jump rings for maille) - even on a small scale, but they are perfect for the occasional hard wire snip, in addition to small (thin) nails and brads, pre-made chain, and the like.

Would I buy the Nvidia Shield?  (I received a demo unit to evaluate.) - maybe.Would I be satisfied with it as a single gaming solution? - no.Would I replace my Apple TV with it? - No.Is it expensive?  No maybe about it. - yes.Include a remote? - no.Game controller? - yes, one ...Are there a lot of apps available? - um, no.Will there be?  - who knows ... And welcome to the Android compatibility game ...This is a well-made, polished product in many respects.  Good game play. Great potential.  It's kind of an odd compromise between a game console and other kinds of devices. Buying one is something of a gamble on its potential.  That would be a no-brainier at a (much) lesser price point, but at THIS price, that's money that could go to a proven system.In the end, while I find myself pulled, I would hesitate buying one.  Yet it's quite good, too.  5 star quality.  3 for current app availability.  4 overall for now.(Updated, given software update that provides Netflix access.  The rest of the review stands as-is, however.  The basis of the review is that it's a quality system with potential.  The potential is yet to be realized.)

I like this connection system.  As long as you are careful and consistent with your cable cuts (in particular) and keep things square on assembly, they work very well and seem stable.  I haven't had a failure yet - but it's not like I'm dragging them around stages, either. Nor would I. Over the years, almost every cable failure I've had has been shorts or breaks at or near the connector.  And while I'm happy enough with this system's setscrew, I wouldn't trust it to serve as sufficient strain relief for use requiring any non-trivial amount of cable movement.  It's well-suited to pedalboard use, or short run TO a pedalboard from an amp.  From the pedalboard to guitar?  Maybe not.  It would be OK in a studio or home, but not on the road.Heavy wire.  Nice connectors.  Quality all around.  This is an excellent system when used in the proper circumstances.Recommended.

I've really taken my time with this book before submitting a review because it's so unusual.  You will see it variously described as for experts (or "not for beginners"), difficult to wonderful, not a pattern or project book (completely true), focused on menswear (well, sort of), etc.  The author himself finally characterized it in a blog response in a way that made sense to me:  He called it "a catalog."Bingo!  Not a catalog in the sales sense, of course, but a catalog of variations applicable to shirtmaking.  I.e., after presenting basic shirt blocks, the book covers HOW various details (collars, cuffs, plackets, etc.) work and what they require from the pattern or block itself.  So it will show how a collar type is cut, assembled, folded, stabilized, and attached to get the desired effect or look.  WHY does such and such a collar curve or stand in the way it does?  WHY does a certain detail require modifying the base pattern in such-and-such a way?  Etc.  ... All without dimensions or patterns per se in the book itself, as again, it is NOT a pattern book.  Someone *really* skilled, of course, could draft their own from the descriptive information and pictures.In essence, the book give the reader a really fast and easy way to reference the look - and work involved - in adding the details they would like in a given shirt or blouse.  This is an excellent resource for people who work from base patterns (or slopers), which describes many advanced sewers.  I think most home sewers would find the material interesting, but frustrating to use.  An advanced sewer who is used to adjusting, re-drafting, and creating series of patterns and even test garments isn't going to be troubled in the least.Like some other reviewers, I find access to the online materials really frustrating.  I'm not really a fan of supplemental online information anyway.  You KNOW it's going to move or disappear at some point in the future ... maybe 2 years, maybe 20, but eventually.  I also agree with common review complaints about some of the details in the book being a bit spotty (references to drawings, and so on).  The book could be organized better, too.All-in-all, I would characterize this as a must-have reference for serious sewers, despite the minor flaws in content and any online content issues.  It's use as a catalog, as the author called it, along with the descriptions of WHY the detail construction works as it does, isn't unique, exactly.  But having it in such compact form, fairly comprehensively for a single garment type, is terrific.
I like Belkin's cords and consider them almost as good as Apple's - at a better price. The shorter the cord, the less difference it makes, most things equal, but I've had zero problems with Belkin.

Although not the biggest Belkin fan, I find their Apple-compatible cords well-made and a better-priced alternative to Apple's own.This shorty is a convenient travel cord. It's perfect for use with your Mac or PC, and won't tangle in your bag.

These are well-made utensils from a materials and construction standpoint.  From a design point of view, not so much.  My immediate reaction was that they are chunky, i.e., thick and, unfortunately, somewhat clumsy to use as a result.  Spatulas and spoons need more of an edge than these to work effectively.  A pasta fork needs finer tines.  Second, these utensils are somewhat small.  While I have room in my kitchen for a few shorter items, I would not buy these as a primary, or everyday use set.  Finally, they are just too flexible.  That won't get in the way of stirring a thin sauce, but you'll definitely notice when dealing with heavier dishes.  We make homemade hash, for example, which we make to put up in large batches.  Ours requires browning in a cast iron pan and the DII spoons and spatulas won't do the job lifting and turning, and won't do the job scraping.  Back to the wood utensils!Comfortable in the hands, well finished.  Just not up to my expectations.

These are not sunglasses!That might seem obvious, given the description, but a lot of reviews talk about the V50s as if they were sunglasses.  They are bright environment (usually outdoors, but not always) *safety glasses*.  Do they share some things in common with sunglasses?  Sure, but their primary role is physical protection of the eyes, not fashion wear.  Safety glasses have to meet various specifications, confirmed by testing, have to function in harsh and dirty environments, and have to be usable by a lot of people whose physical characteristics differ.The Jackson V50s are excellent safety glasses.  I don't know about you, but I've had to use my share of crappy generic-looking, mega-oversized, square-lens, wing-on-the-temple-pieces safety glasses that never fit, barely work, and scratch if you sneeze.  The Jacksons are reasonably styled, robust as all get out, come with a headband to replace the temple pieces when needed, have ventilated foam eyecup liners, and are optically decent for a safety glass.  These are really well-made with a lot of attention to detail.  They also come with a drawstring storage bag - keep the scratches away during storage won't be a problem.Criticisms and other comments.  The temple pieces aren't adjustable for either length or fit.  They have a decent spring to them which will keep them in place comfortably for most, but if you have a very thin or very wide face, they may not work well for you.  They do not hook over the ear (that's my preference, actually).  They cannot be used over regular glasses.  Because the V50s are pretty dark for a safety glass, I suspect some people are going to try using them for light welding.  That would be a serious mistake for anything involving an arc, and not a great idea for gas either.Recommended over many, many alternatives in the market ... the safety glasses market, that is, not the sunglasses market.

I'm giving this knife 5 stars despite having a few reservations.  Those are (and I'll detail them further): the Axis mechanism, the blade when unlocked, the blade's finish, and the blade's recurve.  Why, if I have reservations?  In short, because I chose this knife knowing them - and would do so again. It's a terrific combination of utility and carryability in a folder under 3", feels great in the hand, is tough, and is light besides.  It is my 3rd Benchmade, and my first Benchmade folder.  It replaces a much lesser EDC knife (Buck).On to my issues with the knife:Axis - I'm not a fan of this mechanism.  It requires openings between the scales and liner in order to accommodate the springs.  That's GUARANTEED to accumulate lint and grunge over time - and requires taking the scales off to clean it out if it's stubborn.  Second, I find it's easiest and smoothest when you grip the studs on both sides of the knife.  Yes, it's ambidextrous, but it's not quite as sure using just my thumb.  I expect this will get somewhat better as the pivot wears in.  It's nearly as fast to just use the thumb studs on the blade itself.  Finally, even a slight bit of pressure on the blade makes it very difficult to actuate the mechanism.  So ... both Axis studs and a free blade - instant release.  Anything else, not so much.  And keep it clean.The Blade Unlocked - Ah yes, that same lack of continuous tension that you get in something like a lockback, the free-swinging blade that allows you, once unlocked, to flick it open instantly and effortlessly, can become rather dangerous when you go to folding it again.  I like that I can do it one-handed.  I caution against flicking it closed, though, and have a wonderful cut to prove it.  (I don't have any doubt as to how sharp the blade is from the factory, either.)  The knife flicks open to its lock position, without fail, every time, with the barest flick of the wrist.  Closing it this way is more of dance and not as reliable.I love S30v steel and have several knives made with it.  I also like the tumbled satin finish on this knife.  I don't like the machining marks left before tumbling, however.  You can both feel and see them on every surface of the blade.  At this price point I expect better, even in a production knife.The Recurve?  For me, that's a sharpening issue.  It's hard enough to sharpen this steel.  The recurve just adds to the problem.  Looks good, though, and it's understated.Other comments and quibbles:  Apart from the lack of pre-polish before tumbling, this knife is very well-made.  No gaps, nothing mis-cut, nothing out of alignment.  It is delivered to design, sharp, and ready-to-go out of the box.  Part of its lightness comes from the partial skeletonization of the liner.  A bonus is that the knife balance just at the point of the index finger cutout.  There are some jimping-like cuts in the liner at the back half of the knife.  Pointless, really, as they are *below* the level of the scales.Summary - great knife.  There are compromises, but all knives have them, and I bought the North Fork knowing exactly what they are.  Your mileage may vary, but I would buy it again.

Although not *exactly* what I was looking for (which was a multiclamp), I got a REALLY good price - $14.00 - on one of these at Guitar Center (sorry, Amazon), as it was the last one in stock, so I made it work.I just love DW hardware!  My rack is a mix of brands: Gibraltar, DW, Pearl, etc.  All of it is very functional, but the DW stuff is by far the best built. Better machined, better finished.  Little things like the springs on the connectors make life easier.  Hinges are smoother and tighter.  And DW appears to use better materials.  It's satisfyingly solid.If only DW produced the range of connectors that Gibraltar does!  Nonethless, that's irrelevant here.  This is a basic 1.5" rack tube to vee clamp.  If that's what you need, you will be very happy with this one.Now, if I could just get DW to get their rack casters pricing out of the stratosphere ...

I grew up in a large family.  Middle child with older sisters and younger brothers.  Born in the mid-50s and really coming of age in the mid to late 70s, the events at the center of Days of Rage were at once familiar, yet somehow more a part of my sisters' lives than mine.  They were involved in the causes of the time - protests to SDS to Woodstock, no less - but were far from radical.  Perhaps because of that, I always had the impression that the radical and so-called revolutionary groups of that period were never truly a major threat, that their views were simply too extreme for most people, however they might sympathize with some of the causes nominally rooting their philosophies.Another reviewer notes something similar when citing thousands of bombings during this period, and people weren't unduly alarmed.  Call it cultural warfare or criminality, a lot of people ultimately rolled their eyes, dismissed these groups, and, in the end, condemned them to the distant margins they wound up inhabiting, in turn to be progressively eliminated by the political and law enforcement machinery.  Few of us with these impressions have been surprised when some long-lost radical resurfaces after having spent the better part of life in a middle-class existence.  People like Bill Ayers notwithstanding, most of the so-called radicals faded into ordinary life.  I had a Sunday School teacher who was a former Weatherman.Burrough's book only strengthens my original impressions.  The stories, interesting though lacking some energy somehow, never persuade me that the influence of any of these people extended much beyond the weeks most of the events hit the news (noting in passing that this is the author's premise).  They carry me back, but don't describe or project their impacts into the present in any compelling way.  It's like reading about the labor riots of decades earlier.  You know they were real, they had their time and context, but they have become footnotes.  And so it is with the extremists of the 60's and 70's.  The cultural impacts of the period itself are undeniable.  That of the most hardened radicals?  Not so much.  The subtitle reads, in part: "America's ... forgotten age of revolutionary violence."  Forgotten indeed - and well-titled.It was a terrible waste then and still is.A well-written book, but nonetheless mostly simply descriptive.  Worthwhile for the added details of the people and events, but no real insights.  Perhaps best for those who did not live through the period.

I like D'Addario strings and use them currently.  They're well-made, consistent, and sound good.  To be perfectly honest, I can't hear a lot of difference between these and the lights I usually use.  The action is somewhat stiffer, of course, but the sound is quite similar.  Sound depends on picks, technique, and the banjo itself, but nonetheless I would recommend choosing between the D'Addario Lights vs. the Mediums on the basis of playing style more than sound.Excellent life, lively, and playable.

Not quite as stiff as the picture suggests, the InterDesign Bin nonetheless has sufficient body to stand on its own and support a reasonable load.  It's best used for stuffing with objects that aren't so heavy as to collapse it.  So filling it with socks, for example, would be perfect, while marbles would not be.  The knit is loose enough to be able to see through the holes in the fabric here and there, so tiny objects or those with poky parts might not be a great idea either.The material is polypropylene, so should hold up and be easily washed, if necessary.Best as a closet or bureau stuffer, I think, and good for the price.  It's one of those things that always finds a home.

Popped right in and recognized instantly without issue.  Running several weeks now without issue.  These replace OWC memory which did not hold up.  While I could have sent for OWC replacement, I decided to switch makes instead.

Accurately cut for length and cross-sectional dimension, these bars go together easily and hold well without racking, once the canvas is secured.  While the outside surfaces of the bars are well-finished, the cuts where the bars interlock are left somewhat rough.  That's fine, as far as their inner surfaces go, but splinters and whiskers of wood are left sticking out, which can snag you, if you are not careful or do not remove them.  The wood is quite soft, presumably pine.

I pushed this chisel for two full days chipping hard ice.  It's small for that purpose, but worked like a charm and held up beautifully.  Barely perceptible wear.  The bottom edge bevel lets you get right down to an underlying surface with control and without damage with just a little care.  Great tool, though I could wish for little more length.

I bought this rotohammer to chip ice!  After the horrendous 2014/2015 New England winter, having had my house closed down for months while away, I had ice sheets ranging from an inch thick to as much as two feet thick in places around the house - walks, decks, steps, in front of the garage, etc.  I always have some thin ice.  No problem.  I get out there with a long-handled steel ice chipper and away it goes.  Hit a tough spot, scatter some ice melt and come back the next day.  Not this year!  The ice was hard as a rock, very cold, and tightly adhered, having built up and been protected by an overblanket of several feet of compacted snow.  I was having trouble even with the blade of a mattock (pickaxe) and couldn't find anyone to take the job on for me.So I checked out rentals at the two big box home stores.  $180 for two days for an SDS Max hammer with a long scraper.  Not a whole lot less for an SDS plus with a tile scraper.  So I looked at purchase instead.  I found the older model of this hammer on sale as well as this one at the regular price.  Made an offer to the manager for the same $$ off as the old model, which he took.  And went home to chip ice.My God, what a difference.  I chipped ice for 2 solid days.  All.  Day.  Long.  The thinner ice, up to 2" or so, mostly came up fairly easily.  The thick stuff I had to work more like a jackhammer.  I worked the tool HARD and got the job done.  And still have the roto hammer to show for it.  I was concerned about damage to bricks and deck surfaces from the tile scraper I used.  It was not a problem in practice.  A slower speed with just enough pressure skimmed the bottom bevel of the scraper JUST off the surface.  The little bits of ice left behind mostly disappeared in a day.I would have appreciated a trigger lock or speed limiter, but the trigger is at least easily actuated and controlled.  The front handle is easily and quickly rotated, greatly appreciated as I had to work at all kinds of weird angles in some places.  Working down on a ground-level, horizontal surfaces, I had it vertical most of the time.  The straight line of force from the D-handle through to the bit is perfect.  No tendency to leverage away or wander at all.  I didn't have any use for the hanger, so can't comment on that.  I have NO complaints about vibration with this tool, even after day-long use.  No fatigue or buzzing feeling in the hands like I would get from a reciprocating saw after a while.This is a really well-designed and well-made tool.  I agree with other reviewers that the case is somewhat flimsy.  It's a hard plastic and not very thick.  Spacious, though.Highly Recommended

This book is awesome!Summary:Modern, cool pictures.  Includes many girls and people from all cultures.  Fun information for young people to learn, presented an engaging way.  I highly recommend this book for anyone probably around 2-5 years old.Longer version:I bought this book for my daughter because it is very different from all of her other books.  She is almost 3 years old and has been interested in tools a little bit, curious about screwdrivers and hammers, and she is starting to understand the idea that different people have different jobs, so I thought this would be a fun way to teach her a bit more about that.  It is.  It has just the right amount of new information, and it is presented in this fun way where it shows you the tools (cute drawings of them) and then you can guess what person uses the tools.  When you see the answer it shows a picture of a couple people using the tools to do their job.For example, the first pages say:"To build a HOUSE, start down low.[on a sign] WHOSE TOOLS ARE THOSE? Do you know?"[and on the opposite spread there is a cute picture of a chalk line, chisel, jointer, float]Then you open the right page from the middle open to the left and it shows a spread that says:[on a sign] "the MASON'S!"and the mason is saying "I smooth the cement until it's flat!"So the tools and occupations included in this book are:1. chalk line, chisel, jointer, float --> mason2. hammer, level, square, saw --> carpenter3. utility knife, snips, nail gun, ladder --> roofer4. screwdriver, drill, linesman pliers, wire stripper --> electrician5. adjustable wrench, pipe wrench, pipe cutter, pipe tape --> plumber6. brush, roller, roller tray, masking tape --> painter7. (and it ends with the completed house that has more building going on: kids building with blocks).The pictures are very modern and fun.  The tools all have little faces and legs drawn on them, so they are very engaging, instead of boring.  The text is well-chosen.  The borders of the pages also give a clue about what the answer will be.  The pages that reveal the answer have a lot going on in them, so there is plenty to talk about.  We like to find each of the tools in the picture.One of the things that I really like about this book is that it includes a lot of girls. It is also about as diverse as a book about this stuff could possibly be: half of the main characters are female; all ethnicities are represented; there are chubby people and slim people; people appear to be varying ages.Princess books are cool too, but I really enjoy sharing books like this with my daughter, that show girls are DOING something instead of being silly and sitting around waiting to fall in love with a stranger.

This book was okay, and I felt confident going into potty training as a result of reading this book.  It seemed like a good method.Except that it didn't really work for us.I really thought my daughter was ready for potty training--she is two and a half and she talks really well, and she was sometimes asking to use the bathroom...but...we have been doing this method for almost two months, and she is still not potty-trained.  She is dry at night, and poop always goes in the toilet (which makes the whole thing worthwhile anyway, maybe?)...but she went from having about one wet accident a day after a few days of this method to now, she stays dry if we are not home but otherwise it is just one wet accident after another. And she has stopped helping me clean them up, so a few days ago I finally just bought some Pull Ups and she is wearing those half the time. Not the result I was expecting.  I started out very patient, but after so many weeks of cleaning up pee several times every day, I am out of patience and enthusiasm.I think maybe the candy lost its appeal; at first I let her have princess chocolate coins but it seemed like she was having a LOT of candy each day. So we switched to gummy worms, and then pez and jelly beans...but now my daughter is still not potty trained and went from eating almost no sweets to eating tons of candy every day for several weeks. I was kind of expecting it to be a week of m&ms or something, but she doesn't like those, so...?I may reread this and see if I am forgetting a next step or something...if things turn around, I will update.

My 2 year-old daughter loves this book.  After we first got it it was her favorite, and she wanted to hear it many times every day.  Now, we just read it occasionally.  A few minutes ago she was feeling really mad, so I pulled it out and started reading, and she instantly calmed down.  Other times without reading it I sometimes ask her, "what feelings are in your heart right now?" and that helps her sort it out better.  Feelings can be a little hard for kids to identify and understand, but this expresses them in a new way.  The pictures are modern, interesting, and engaging.  The heart cut outs kind of add to it.  Prior to this we used to read Walter Was Worried fairly often, and that is also a good one (very different from this).  I will probably start including this with second or third birthday gifts for my friends' kids.  It is really lovely, and it has enhanced our talks about feelings, and my daughter's ability to cope with strong feelings.

My daughter is almost 2 years old and she has been enjoying this puzzle for a few months.  The pieces are big enough that is is relatively easy, but there is variation in how difficult the different pieces are.  For example, the barnyard is large and very easy to fit into its spot, so my daughter didn't have any trouble with it even from the beginning.  The dog is also pretty easy because it is basically a rectangle.  The sheep has been the hardest piece because it is scalloped around the edges so there are a lot of little parts that you have to get right for it to work.  She can do it now.This puzzle seems like it will last a long time.  It all looks very nice and professionally done.This makes a great early puzzle.

My daughter (22 months) brings this book to me and asks me to read it to her often.  This book is very simple, so it talks at her level and she understands it.  It is a very easy way to share scripture with my daughter, and it has a nice message.  She likes to notice and talk about the kids standing or sitting, or doing whatever they are doing.  This book also has a dog that appears throughout the book, and she loves that dog. The pictures are beautiful, and they are detailed enough that they are interesting to look at. This is a very sweet book.

I ordered these because the last time I ordered organic vanilla beans I got the starwest ones, and they ended up not being from Madagascar.  Although the other ones were good, I wondered if I was missing out on something by having ones that were not from Madagascar.  This time I ordered these, thinking that they were organic and from Madagascar, and therefore the best of both worlds.Well...these are sticky, and they are long.  They're fine.  These are kind of bland in flavor compared to the other ones, though.  These come in a sealed plastic package with an address-label type sticker that says they are Madagascar vanilla beans.  The other brand came much better packaged, in a foil type pouch instead of just a little plastic thing.  I don't know if that is part of why the flavor was better?So, I don't know if the difference in flavor is due to where it was grown, the packaging, or the organic (or not) nature of the product, but I don't like these as well as I liked the other ones, and I'm planning to go back to the other ones next time.These beans are fine, so if the difference in price really matters to you a lot and you just want something that will work, these are okay.  If I couldn't buy the other ones I would substitute with these, definitely, because they're not hard like the ones in stores sometimes...I'm sure they would be fine for making vanilla extract.  The other beans are definitely superior, though, so if you're looking for a premium product, I would go with the other one.Another thing about these ones.  I brought them with me to Uruguay, and I've been using them very quickly, but after a few weeks of being wrapped in their own package they started to mold.  Mold is an issue here, so I should have thought that something so moist could have a problem, but if you're not planning to make vanilla and use all of the beans right away, especially if you live somewhere where mold is an issue, keep them in the fridge after you open the package!

Ever since I learned about artisan chocolate, I have been kind of a chocolate snob.  I have tried several of Amano's chocolate bars (Dos Rios used to be a favorite) and chocolates from many other artisans.  Last year my husband and I even toured an organic cacao farm in Panama to learn about how chocolate is grown and processed.  This was not my first bar of good chocolate.I discovered Amano Chuao about a month ago, and of all of the chocolates I have tried, this is definitely my favorite.  It has such a symphony of flavors!  Unlike many other fine chocolates, this does not have a strong leather or raisin taste to it...and Amano has such a smooth texture to it that it just melts in your mouth and leaves such a heavenly aftertaste.Highly recommended!

I bought this to leave with Grandma when she was going to be watching my daughter while my husband and I were away for a day and a night.  They did the red one, and I did the other two with her later.  I thought it would be a fun activity that they could do together without my mother-in-law needing to come up with something really creative that was at her (toddler) level of development.  My mother-in-law didn't mention how it went for them, but it was fine for us.  I did feel like it was a GREAT option for something to leave with a babysitter so that they have something new and interesting to do, without relying on the babysitter to be creative.  The pieces are all there, and there isn't a big mess, so it is great for that.This isn't the most exciting activity of your kid's life, and it isn't a reusable game, or anything like that.  It will take a little while, either all in one sitting or we did it in three sittings because my daughter was 18 months old when she did these, and her attention span is not very long.I had been thinking it would be fun to do color collages because my daughter is obsessed with what colors things are, and this was nice because it made it so that I didn't have to go find or buy a bunch of stuff.  There were some fun textures, and there is a mix of stuff like papers, stickers, buttons, and just a variety of little things of different colors.Could you do the same thing cheaper on your own?  Eh...maybe?  If you were buying in bulk and getting a bunch of stuff for a bunch of kids, you might be able to.  But you would end up with a lot of extra "stuff" and it takes time to find items that will work well, and the sticky back is so much cleaner than trying to work with glue.I would recommend this, especially as an activity for with babysitters, since on my own I don't mind taking the time to be creative and come up with crafts for us, but this is nice and simple without requiring much from the adult who is helping.

For us these definitely don't work 36 hours.I started using them on my daughter (1.5 years old) and myself because we are doing some extended travel and where we are now if we do nothing my daughter wakes up with 6-8 new bites each morning.  Poor girl!  I don't feel great about her/us breathing chemicals all night long, and the bracelets that we have right now are not working, and they are so huge that she won't leave them on.So, a friend recommended these patches and we picked a few boxes up when we were back in the US for the holidays.At first they were great!  No new bites!  Then, I left one on two nights instead of one and it was more than 36 hours and she got eaten up, but I assumed it was my fault for exceeding the time limit.  Then we started putting a patch on right before bed, and leaving it on for the next night also.  That is less than 36 hours but for us it doesn't work.  When we do that (if she is uncovered at all) she gets bitten just as much as she would without the patch.  For the first night with a fresh patch, it still seems to help, but she often does get a bite or two even with a new patch.  We've been using these most nights for a little over a month now, so maybe the mosquitos who don't like people with patches, or they're desperately hungry by now or something, I don't know.The other thing is, they leave a big sticky residue along the border of the patch.  It takes some scrubbing to get it off, which is not terrible if you're an adult removing it from yourself, but it is much harder to get cooperation from a young toddler...so my daughter has little outlines of patches usually for 3-5 locations at any given time, until I gradually scrape them off during showers.  Which reminds me of something else...if you leave a patch in the same spot too long, it causes a rash.  I think it mentions that on the page that comes with it, and it kind of makes sense anyway, but it is a downside, because it sometimes happens in less than 24-36 hours.  It usually goes away within a day or so, though.So, I'm still glad we bought them.  A net would be tough because I'm in and out of her bed all night, so we need to do SOMETHING and this does seem to make an improvement.  They are not a perfect solution, though.If you're going somewhere for a short amount of time, these are a great option; just definitely plan to change them more often than every 36 hours, and you will probably be happy.

If you have read about fluoridation much before, this movie is a treat to watch because it includes video footage of people you've already read about, and lots of interesting pictures and video clips.  If you have not studied the topic, then you really, really need to watch this right away so that you can be made aware of this important information and what to do about it before you are affected any more than you already have been.I worried because of the introduction and some of the reviews that this movie might not have scientific sources for information.  Not true!  This film is full of interview with experts on the related subjects, plus clips from news and other media, excerpts from journals, letters, and articles, and even an experiment where they measure fluoride levels in different items.  The sources are not listed or highlighted in an easy to access format--in some cases they are pictures of letters from regulatory agencies, or things like that, but they are legitimate sources.  It isn't just a bunch of extreme opinions, it is good scientific information.The experts included were: Dr. Doris Rapp (whose book on Amazon has overwhelmingly "excellent" reviews), a guy from Natural News Mike Adams, Dr. David Kennedy DDS, Dr. Paul Connett (chemistry professor at SLU), James E. Rota (eco-dentist?), Dr. Charlie Goetschel (eco-chemist), Gary O. Pittman (supervisor at chemical plant), Dr. Laura Pressley (chemist), a couple activists (Mary E. Moore and Gianlucca Zanna) and video of Dr. Phyllis Mullenix.Some of the topics that stood out to me:- Two main reasons why a lot of countries do not fluoridate: not right to force it on people who didn't want it, and not all of the health issues were sufficiently resolved. @ about 20 mins into the film.- Fluoride stays in our bones! (Could be contributing to problems of arthritis and all of the hip and knee replacements.) @ about 44 mins; and the amount of fluoride in water has no difference in the amount of cavities. @ about 49 mins- Blacks and Mexicans are even more susceptible to effects because of a gene that they have that causes them to absorb more; other susceptible people include lactose intolerant people (calcium deficiency leads to increased absorption); babies (they drink a TON compared to their body weight); low-income people who can't afford to buy other water.- Problems because Fluoride is actually a drug. @ about 1:01- Fluoride causes neuron damage and has been proven to reduce IQ. @ 1:04-1:06- Cool testing experiment is @ 1:11- In other country labels show how much fluoride is in bottled water @ 1:15.- After about 1:16 there is a wrap up with several suggestions for ways to protect yourself from fluoride.The only thing I really didn't like about this film was the introduction.  It starts out by saying there is some recommendation to kill off a bunch of the population, and asking how will it happen, and this movie is the first of a three part series (the other parts are about food and air) to explain how it is happening.  Even though I was already convinced before watching this that fluoride is not safe to consume, I don't think it is all part of some big elaborate sinister plot, nor is any evidence given in this film to show that it is part of such a conspiracy.  But, the truth is, fluoride is still a poison, and after those first kind of off-putting few minutes of the movie, the rest of the film is quite good, and well worth watching.  If the filmmakers are motivated by something that seems kind of dumb to me and might make many viewers more skeptical, well, that is just fine if it leads them to interview key people and assemble good data for the public to digest in an interesting format.Also, even though this film is not rated, I did not notice anything offensive in the film, aside from the fluoridation scheme itself!  But what I mean is, if a family wanted to watch this, I didn't notice any swearing, there definitely isn't any nudity or violence; a fertilizer plant supervisor talks about some of the injuries that occurred at the plant for about a minute, but there are no pictures.  I think it would be totally appropriate for about ages 10 and up, and younger would be fine except that it just might be boring for them.I really enjoyed this film.  We had already been using a Berkey filter with the extra fluoride filters, but we are currently traveling, and this gave me the idea that it would be really interesting to get a fluoride tester so that we could test tap water in different countries and regions that we visit.  They don't try to sell us on fluoride testers in the film, but it looks like Amazon has them for about $300-350, and I didn't realize it was something that could be easily done outside of a lab with microscopes or very expensive specialized equipment.I look forward to the following films in this series.I highly recommend this film, and if the first few minutes seem kind of extreme and over-the-top, keep watching because it gets a lot better.

This is a cute little color wonder coloring set.  It is kind of hard to find color wonder stuff that doesn't feature characters from Disney movies and tv shows, but this is a nice "generic" set.  Pretty.  Of course, since it only includes 5 markers we also use markers from other sets.  But my daughter doesn't care what colors things are anyway, so five are plenty for her.Some of the pages at the beginning seemed to take a few seconds longer to show the color, but now that we are well into the coloring book the color shows very quickly.  I don't know if it has anything to do with the paper, or how the markers are stored, or what.I'm glad we got this set.

I've bought a few other brands of almond flour, including Bob's and a couple others, and of the ones I have tried, this has been my favorite.The flavor is great.It takes up a bit of space in the fridge, but it is well worth it.  I'm trying to change my diet to paleo, and this makes it a lot more practical.

I bought these to be a toddler snack on a recent flight, but we didn't get to them until now.  They are wonderful!  Very tasty, crisp, but not hard, and obviously from real fruit, instead of tasting super-processed like most other toddler food.  My daughter (18 months) loved them.  We also got the banana strawberry mix, and they were good too, but I think these had more flavor.  We will definitely be buying more of these when we return to the US!

I bought some of these to try as a snack on our flight recently, and we didn't get to them during the flight, but they would have been perfect for that.  The strawberries were not super flavorful, but they tasted real, and my daughter (18 months) liked both the strawberries and bananas.  We also tried the pineapple ones, and I thought they were better, although maybe they were really just sweeter.  We like that the ingredient list is as clean as can be, and they are just so convenient that we will surely pick some more of these up the next time we're back in the US.

Our bag is now broken. We are using it as a cover.July 2013 - flight to Panama from US (1 connection).  Arrived ok.Sept 12, 2013 - direct flight from Panama to Uruguay.  Arrived ok.Sept 13, 2013 - while transporting bag to our hotel, first strap broke off.  One strap is inadequate for the amount of weight, but we're doing it anyway.Oct 7, 2013 - in airport, seam tears open.  Bag now has a gash that is several inches long.So, now we're primarily using it only as a cover.  It is better than nothing, I think...but...it is about as durable as a product that would cost $8-10, at most. Not sure how to replace it since we're still in South America.  Our broken bag makes car seat transport even worse than it already was.Padding on the straps is almost non-existent, and not comfortable. Bag seams are weak. Zipper sticks sometimes.  The metal on our strap broke.  Did they not test some sample bags before they started selling these?I sure hope they don't use the same manufacturer for the car seat itself!!

I have had enough bad experiences with fally-aparty luggage that I knew I needed something more reliable before my husband and I set out on our world travels.  I was right.His luggage is falling apart, and mine is just awesome.  When I first got this Eagle Creek 25 piece I wished I would have just gone with two of the larger size because this couldn't be carried on but yet it has less space than the 30...and I was feeling kind of sore about it since they cost about the same amount...but now I am quite happy to have both the 25 and the 30.  Having both is a lot easier to manage with than having two large pieces.  When we take smaller trips, I can choose between one slightly larger piece or one slightly smaller piece.I maybe wish I would have chosen the smaller size so that I could have the flexibility of using it as a carry-on sometimes if I wanted to.Overall, though, this is wonderful.  The fabric is good, the zippers are good, the way the pockets are is good.  The handles everywhere make it so easy to lift and move.  The telescoping handle works well and isn't flimsy.  The wheels are good.  This is easy to travel with.My only recommendation is that you make sure you know what size you want, but that isn't a problem with the luggage.

I was really excited to buy Meet the Colors because my 16 month old daughter is obsessed with colors right now.  I saw a preview of it and I could understand why it has won so many awards: it mimics what we do all the time, by pointing out stuff that is each color, and saying only the color name (which avoids confusion).  It is slow paced, so there are probably not the same TV issues that some other programs have.  Sure, it may be annoying to listen to, and I was prepared for that, but as parents we can handle minor annoyances for the sake of enriching our kids' learning experiences.  So many reviewers talk about their kids loving these programs, so I was excited to let my daughter watch it.Yeahhhhh, so much for that.  My daughter is totally bored by it.  She rarely watches any media, so it's not that she's used to more stimulation from TV, either. The first time she watched this she got about halfway through.  We've tried to get her to watch it a few more times since then, and she won't sit for it for more than a couple minutes.  It is kind of pathetic watching her try to watch it, even.  She yawns a lot, and then starts looking around for something else, and then she starts to close my computer.  I'm done trying to get her to watch it.  If she is so uninterested in this program, I don't think I should push it.Instead, we're doing basically the same thing in real life: pointing stuff out that is different colors, and talking about it. So far she LOVES yellow, she knows blue, green, red, and purple, and sometimes she knows pink and orange.  That's good enough for a 16 month old baby, anyway, and I'm sure as we continue talking about colors she will continue to get better and better with them.  She talks about colors ALL DAY every day right now, as she is constantly pointing them out everywhere, and also pointing out plaid, stripes, and dots, so we'll get there.I don't know why I kind of hoped she could just watch a little TV program and learn them all instantly.  It's not so bad to be personally involved in her learning.  It's kind of fun to help her figure things out.So, the best thing about this movie for us is that it helped me decide not to spend any money on the other similar shows (I was thinking about doing lowercase letters and phonics, plus Spanish ones).  It's not terrible, but it is very boring, and I can't in good conscious pressure my baby to watch more tv than she is interested in.

We bought this book yesterday and now we've read it a few times.  It's really cool!  Each spread has a type of animal, what the male is called, what the female is called, and what the babies are called.  So, for example, the cow page shows a bull, a cow, and a calf.  All in Spanish, though, of course.  Then there are little voice bubbles from the animals making the sounds that they make.  The sounds they make are in cursive writing instead of printing.  As someone who is still learning Spanish the sounds are kind of hard to read for some of them, but to someone who actually knows Spanish I'm sure it would be very obvious what they say.One neat thing about this book is that it is the size of a board book--it is a board book--but it has a TON of pages.  The pages are thinner cardboard than the cover.  I think there are maybe 40 types of animals included.  The pages are colorful and the pictures are in the same style as the cover...I think they are pretty engaging, although there are so many that my 15 month old daughter does not have the patience for all of them at once, and definitely not all of them in Spanish and English, so we read parts of the book instead of reading the whole thing every time.I hadn't ever seen anything like this before, so I thought it was really cool!  I think it would be interesting to a wide variety of ages, from very young babies (the pictures are often fairly high-contrast) to adults (especially those who are studying Spanish).

We got a copy of this book in a Cheerio box while we were living in Panama, and although my daughter is just over a year old, she LOVES it.The words have a nice sound as you read them; on pages where the balloon is going farther away, the sound of the words sounds like a balloon floating far away, and on kind of the climax page where the balloon is coming down and someone is about to get it the text says "Sand box. Shoes and socks. Sun hat. Orange cat."  It's very short, very short, and it just adds to the excitement about the balloon being about to be found.There is little enough text that it is not boring to my daughter.  Our Cheerios version is in English and Spanish and if I read both sets of text on each page then that is too much, but if I read only English it is just right.  Sometimes I will read mostly English and substitute a line here and there in Spanish so that she gets more exposure to that.The pictures are really well done.  There is a lot to talk about as we read this book; "Do you see the truck, where is the truck?  The truck is BLUE!"  "Blue bird sings---TWEEEEET tweet-tweet-tweet-tweeeeet!---Tower bell rings--DIIIIINGGG DOOOONG!"  "How many bees do you see on this page?" etc).  It has a lot of things that she loves--cat, dog, flowers, bees, balloon, sun, birds, trees, Molly, etc.  It has been her favorite book for the past couple weeks, so lately we read it about 3 times each day.I just wish it were available as a board book, because she is fascinated by tearing paper right now and the Cheerios version is not very durable.  We've had to tape ours back together a few times now, so that was why I was checking this out on Amazon.It is a fun book, though, and great for little kids, not just ages 4-8 as the description states.Highly recommended.

There is a lot to talk about as we read this book; "Do you see the truck, where is the truck?  The truck is BLUE!" It has a lot of things that she loves--cat, dog, flowers, bees, balloon, sun, birds, trees, Molly, etc.  It has been her favorite book for the past couple weeks, so lately we read it about 3 times each day.I just wish it were available as a board book, because she is fascinated by tearing paper right now and the Cheerios version is not very durable.  We've had to tape ours back together a few times now, so that was why I was checking this out on Amazon.It is a fun book, though, and great for little kids, not just ages 4-8 as the description states.Highly recommended.

This book is really cool!  We bought it a little while ago, but my daughter has recently taken more of an interest in it.  She is now 14 months old. Also, she has recently started identifying colors, and I think maybe this book is partially responsible for that.So, there are a few things we especially like about this book:- The Spanish is a little repetitive (nice in books for kids), but not at all obnoxious, and different enough (because of the colors and the little plot) that it maintains my daughter's attention and I don't mind reading it whenever she wants to hear it.- The Spanish and English are well integrated, so you don't feel like you have to choose between reading one language or the other or awkwardly repeating the same text in both languages and trying to keep a child's attention while you do so.- The illustrations are very carefully designed, so, for example, on the yellow page where they want the yellow book the pages have mostly yellow items, but of the books the only book that they need is the one that is yellow.  This is visually appealing, and it creates a "sense" and a feeling of the color discussed on the page without being obvious about it in a boring way.- The pages also have different themes--so, when they're looking for the red jacket you can talk about the colors of the other jackets, or discuss winter clothing items, or when they're looking for the green flute you can talk about different musical instruments, or different green things.  There is a lot going on and a lot to talk about on each page.- The brother and sister are playing together in a natural, friendly, respectful way, and it is unclear who the main character is so whether the book is being read to a boy or a girl and whether that child is an older sibling or a younger sibling (or an only like my baby, they can relate to the perspective of whichever kid (like them) is being the leader.- Normal household things are going on in the background, which you can watch and talk about...for example, on the title page the mom is doing laundry on the clothesline and you can see that the kids get the idea of having a tent from that laundry.  There is a cat that is hanging around the mom, the way that cats hang around their people, and you can notice the cat behind things, or "find" the cat's tail, etc.- The mom does not participate in the plot, but she is seen as present or available (if they DID need her) and paying attention to them while she is doing her own tasks (for example she checks in on them while they're having their siesta).- There is good continuity between the pages, if that makes sense.  For example, with an older child when you're talking about the specific items that they're looking for your child could "find" the item with the kids (the kids are never touching the things on the page where they're going after the item) and on the next page their guess would be confirmed because one of the kids is holding the thing from the last page.  There are also subplots in the background, such as the mom watering plants, and you see her take various steps towards that (filling water and so on) in the background, and there are previous activities that you see the kids are doing or have done.- The teddy is a "magical" character (he is anthropomorphic) and that adds creativity to the story, but his role is just a play on the imagination--he does things that inspire creativity, kind of, without being the leading character.  The teddy is kind of cool because he makes it so it isn't the kids being forced to take a nap, or needing to take a nap...they're just "helping" their tired teddy take a nap.  I think this is really good, because kids I think sometimes know they are tired but want to resist naps, and if a child is "helping" their toy take a nap and just happens to take a nap with the toy, that gives the child a healthy amount of power (kids feel powerless a lot and want to feel empowered) because they're guiding the activity, but it also meets the child's need for sleep.  So, for this reason, I sometimes will encourage this book before my daughter needs to take a nap; it gently and indirectly encourages sleep as a "fun" activity.- Also, kind of neat, I was just looking at the other books available by these authors and I see that there are items from the other books in this book, so if you were already familiar with those books you could notice some carry-over from the other ones.Sorry if this review is oddly theoretical, of if my ideas about children are uninformed--I only have my one daughter--but these are some of the things I think about as I am reading this to my daughter.It is a simple but complex story that is fun and beautiful to read.  And, I think beginning readers could learn to "read" it aloud also since there is not just a ton of text.We really like this story and I want to get the other ones by these authors as soon as we are able to!

I love having a luggage scale with me, because it is nice to be able to redistribute items ahead (if necessary), and to have the peace of mind knowing ahead that luggage weight will not be an issue at the airport.  This luggage scale is a fantastic option because it is small, easy to use, and provides accurate and consistent results.
The battery that came with the computer quit holding a charge, so we ordered this.  It has been working perfectly for a while now.

This is my daughter's second pair of Robeez, and we love them.  She just turned 14 months old, so they are a little on the big side for her.  The way that Robeez are sized it seems like there is a little time where the kid's feet are either kind of tight in the smaller size, or they have too much space in the bigger size.  That's kind of where we're at with these.I ordered these because I thought they would stay kind of clean--previously we had the dog shoes and the suede picked up dirt SO fast, so I wanted ones without suede and not too light of a color.  They DO stay pretty clean.Also, she has a lot of "girly" outfits that are pinks and purples, and these shoes always seem to match.  Either the pinks are main colors in things that she is wearing or they highlight accents of things she is wearing.  But, it's the kind of shoe where even if they don't really match, they don't seem like they don't match, kind of like her baby-carrier thing doesn't match things we're wearing.  I don't know if I am explaining that well, but she has two other pairs of shoes and it seems like they often do not match (one pair seems like it often does not match because the style is a little too dressy, whereas these shoes work with dressier or very casual outfits, and the other pair seems like it often does not match because the colors are too light and pastel-ish whereas these shoes match with light clothes or bold colored clothes).The fit is fine, even though they are a little big still.  She has been learning to walk, and she is more steady when barefoot (as to be expected with any shoes) but she doesn't really stumble while wearing these either.Great shoes.  Well made.  I'm glad we bought them.

I ordered this a week after another reviewer wrote not to purchase the $58 kit because it is incomplete, and I worried that some of the items would be missing, but I wanted Prime shipping so that it would arrive before our trip, and I figured that worst case scenario I could just replace whatever was missing with items from the grocery store.My kit (the $58 one) was totally complete.  The zippers had a zip-tie closure that had to be cut open, and there was a list of all of the contents, which I verified to be correct.  I wonder if maybe the other reviewer had some confusion about how items are listed?  For example, on the list it says that it has a certain number of something, but sometimes there are two per pack (one dose).  I don't know.  Mine was totally fine, though.Also, we have been away for almost a month now, and I have had a few opportunities to use the kit.  It is great, because it turns out when you're traveling sometimes you have different problems than you do when you're home, so I have appreciated having things that I may not have thought to pack in a homemade kit if I had tried to do that.  We are about 35 minutes from a town down bad roads that are sometimes impossible to drive during monsoons, with bad cell reception, in a place where we don't speak the language, so I feel safer knowing that if we had some kind of more serious emergency we would not be completely on our own with whatever we happen to have.It is large enough that it is not something I want to carry around in my purse, but it was space well used in my luggage.I think I will try to add some more Tylenol and some kid band-aids, but otherwise, so far so good.If you're considering this, I definitely recommend it.

I bought four of these locks, and used them.It took a few seconds for me to figure out how to set your own combination, but once I looked at the instructions it was easy.  Practiced locking and unlocking.  Memorized my code.  Left on our trip.We arrived, and none of the little red tabs were showing, so I thought the bags must not have been opened.  NOPE!  I unlocked one of my bags to find a TSA page inside informing me that my bag had been checked.I highly doubt they sat around trying to guess my combination, there is only one way to access the main section of my luggage, and supposedly the zipper on my luggage is a secure one, so it would appear that they unlocked my bag as usual and the "instant alert" feature did not work.None of the other bags had notices inside or red tabs, so I guess my one bag was the only one they opened.Kind of disappointing.  I will keep using them because now our travel is international so they are the same as any other locks anyway, but I bought these because of the alert feature, so I would have chosen a different product if I knew that the feature didn't work.  But maybe it is just the one lock?

I bought this for $15 at Deseret Book for my daughter (13 months) to expose her to Book of Mormon things in a fun way, because she loves books with flaps.Well, this book does have a lot of flaps--most pages have 2-3 flaps.A bunch of the items that they used for letters are kind of stupid, though, in my opinion.  C is for Curelom (with a drawing like an elephant and a little rhyme about them being extinct).  H is for Hagoth (who "was curious and liked to roam.  He built many ships and sailed for from home") and I is for Islands ("where Hagoth's people might be").  Most of the rest of them I like better.  My best guess is that the authors wanted this book to appeal to a wide range of kids and they thought that the trivia would make it more interesting.  Or maybe they thought they had everything else covered well enough?  I don't know.The other thing is, some of the flaps are cool--the ones on the Jesus page, for example, where one flap folds out so that a kid is jumping out of mom's arms to run to Jesus and the Jesus flap folds down and Jesus kneels down for the kid.  Or, there are flaps where people are burying their swords.  Those are great.  Some of the other flaps are silly, like ones where people's facial expressions change, or on the F for family page, a flap opens a banner that says "I [heart] FAMILY NIGHT!".  Those are fun.  But a bunch of them are of the animals from the front cover (a goat, a lizard, and a bird)...you can open the flaps to find silly animals in the Book of Mormon scenes.  I don't really like those.The back of the book says it "will have young children learning their ABCs--and Book of Mormon names, places, and things."  Well, there are not really places in it except for "islands".  There are a bunch of names, though.  And several Book of Mormon things.Overall, it's a fun book.  I don't love the extremely cartoony style of drawings, and I don't love all of the letter choices, but there are not a ton of choices for LDS board books about the Book of Mormon, and even fewer have flaps to lift, so eh, this will work.  My daughter likes it.  My guess is that it would especially appeal to primary age kids.

4.5 stars - I mostly love this bag.  I tend to kind of use my purse as a diaper bag, but I am also very picky about purses and I've been needing a new one.  I saw a PPB Touring Tote at a local store and loved the size and shape but I didn't care for the pattern that they had, so I came on Amazon and found this.I do love this color and pattern in person.  It just kind of matches everything.  I was worried about all the white--I thought maybe it would be more likely to get really dirty.  It hasn't gotten dirty at all, though, and I have used it a lot and set it in plenty of places that could have caused problems.  I think it just has to do with the glazed texture of the fabric; I think that keeps it really clean.I leave the short strap on the purse, and it typically works well for me.  Sometimes when I have too much stuff in the bag the short strap is awkward to use.  At those moments it seems like the longer strap would be a better choice, but I don't carry all of the straps with me (because that would be heavy and take up space) so I just end up out of luck and awkwardly trying to carry it too full with the short strap anyway.  Not a huge problem.The pockets on the exterior sides are less useful than I thought they would be, because the fabric is so stiff that stuff inside the pockets is somewhat hard to retrieve--not terribly, but it doesn't seem natural, if that makes any sense.  The pocket with the snap (by the PPB logo and the green embellishment) is the one I rely on most often for keys and other small things.
