I recently tucked the wipe container into the changing pad zippered pocket on the other side of the exterior.There is a really small pocket inside another pocket on the inside and it seems like it is supposed to be for something, but I don't know what.  Keys, maybe?  My keys are too big to fit well.  A pacifier?  I don't know.  I don't usually put anything in that pocket.  It would be nice if one of the interior sides had a zippered pocket for my stuff so that my stuff and my daughter's stuff didn't all float around together in the bag, but I just put what I can in the four interior side pockets and whatever gets mixed together gets mixed together.  Maybe I need to start using zippered luggage organization pouches or something.The handle looks like seatbelt material.  People comment on that, and I think it's kind of embarrassing.  The metal latch on the short handle is sometimes squeaky.  I think I should apply WD40 or some metal lubricant, but I worry that if I tried to do that I would end up with stray drips of WD40 coming off on my things inside, or on the diaper bag itself, and I don't want that.  So, I just haven't bothered to figure that out yet, but I probably will eventually since the sound is really obnoxious.  It doesn't do it all the time.It may sound like I have a lot of complaints, but that's just because I'm listing them all.  The truth is, I use this bag all day every day, everywhere, and it is a great size, and I love how it looks, and although there are a few things about it that I would change if it were up to me, I am still glad I bought it, and if I were to go back again, I would definitely buy the same thing again.  If you use your purse as a diaper bag, this is a good choice.  If I had two kids, I would probably have gone with the boxy backpack style, but with just my daughter this is working out very well for me.

I had planned to buy one of these, but then we received a battery operated aspirator at my baby shower. It was fancy, but it didn't work, and my daughter hated it.  The bulb syringe worked better than the battery operated one, but I've seen pictures of how moldy and nasty they get, so I didn't like using that.  So, for the past little while, I kind of try to use a tissue, and end up sort of picking her nose to try and get her boogers out.  Not ideal!She's been sick lately, though, so I wanted to be able to just help her out so she could breathe better.  We finally went and bought one of these locally so we would have it right away.Oh, gosh.  It's so easy!  My daughter didn't really like it the first time, but then she realized it's much better than the other ones, because it works.  So the battery one I kept pushing in her nose, and it wouldn't grab the snot, so I would try to help it, and it just always took way longer than it needed to.  This is quick.  You clear it, and maybe repeat, and you're done.  That's it.  No rooting around, listening to a tune, while a machine tries to do it.  It just works.  We didn't even have to change the filter, either, because it just sat in the bottom of the bottom compartment, and it rinsed right out.Super easy.  I'm glad we have this now.  Kind of a weird product, but also a totally awesome one.

My husband and I are preparing to do some long-term international travel.  I bought this book to help us prepare for the trip.A lot of the information is very practical.  I'm glad we got the book because it has started some good discussions there are some useful lists of things to bring or not bring, and see, and be careful about, and so on.If you're on a tight budget and you're planning to pinch pennies everywhere you can, you'll like this book a little better than I did.  My husband and I are not rich or anything, but we are planning to rent houses and cars in each of the cities that we visit...so the ongoing focus on saving money is sometimes interesting, but not as useful for us as it would be for some other people.  Also, things that would be more interesting to us, such as topics related to everyday living--how to choose houses or cars or doctors, etc, are totally absent.  When I read the part about not bringing jeans because they're too heavy, my husband actually laughed.  We're not going to be living out of backpacks, and he wouldn't even consider leaving jeans behind.I can't honestly say we're really doing anything different because of this book, at least so far.  The information about places is general enough to be interesting, but not specific enough to eliminate the need for other research.So, overall, a fun book for getting excited about travel, with a whole lot of information that may or may not be very useful to you, depending on what you're looking for.  Even though we didn't feel like this was written for us, we have enjoyed reading it together, and I will continue to look back to it for ideas as we continue to prepare.  I haven't decided whether it will come along with us.UPDATE 3/13/2015: We did end up bringing this book along with us, and we used it occasionally as we were planning where to go next.  During our travels, the sections about places were more useful than the beginning parts.  I finally quit carrying it with us when we stopped off in the US for a visit after a year or so of traveling.

I like this a lot.My dad was in town and I let him use some for his baths, and he liked it too.  (That surprised me, because he is often a complainer.)This has a very relaxing scent, and it feels great in the bath--not overly oily.  The foam lasts a little while and then it clears, but the scent lasts.Overall, it is great stuff. And, each jar lasts for quite a few baths.

I was wanting some of these for my daughter because I remember when my sisters and I used to wear them back when we were growing up.These are basically the same as I remember--rabbits, dots, bows...I remember us having other shapes too (like, a violin or fiddle or something? and different flowers?) but I thought these were great.  The bow shaped ones don't stay in my baby's hair well, but the others do.  It's nice because even though they do appear to be assorted designs and colors, they are in matching pairs, so there's no problem matching if you want one on each side.I love these.  My sisters noticed them when we were visiting, too, and they were excited to see this little blast from the past.  It's also fun, because they're something different than the flowers and bows that I usually put in my daughter's hair.  A lot of the baby hair accessories are kind of similar styles--ruffley bows, or boutique bows, flowers, etc, but this is just totally different--plastic? with a picture?  Feels good to mix things up a little.This is a six-star product, definitely.

Mine actually came in retail packaging, not the boxes pictured.  That's fine, though.I love these batteries because they are so reliable.  I recently ran out of them and tried to use regular batteries since they are so much cheaper at my grocery store.  What a frustration!  Every time I took pictures, or sometimes every other time, I needed new batteries.  A little ridiculous, really.  The whole package lasted less time than a pair of these lithium batteries would last.  So silly, too, because that box boasted that the batteries would last almost a decade without losing their charge...for what?  Five minutes of taking pictures in 2023?  Not really worth saving those batteries, if you ask me!Anyway, these lithium batteries are awesome.  I am not a photographer with a fancy camera, just a regular person with a regular point and shoot type camera and for me these last quite a while, even though I like to take a lot of pictures every day.  It's nice to have 24 on hand, because as I go through them two at a time I don't have to worry about running out and choosing whether to pay so much for these at the grocery store or not.  Right now, they are $1.46 each on Amazon, and my grocery store sells them for about $3-4 each.  At $1.46 these are a no-brainer.If you're really reading reviews deciding whether to buy these or not, oh gosh, you have no idea, your life is about to get so, SO much better.  Quit reading, and just buy them!

My daughter really likes this.It's kind of nice because it is a similar weight and has similar dimensions to my smartphone.  When my daughter goes after my phone, I offer her this!  I don't know if she realizes that it looks the same as a phone or not--she is 9 months old and I don't think she understands how phones work...she just knows that mine has the screen that lights up, and obviously this one doesn't.  So, if she were to have the choice between my phone and this, she would of course choose my phone.However, the weight and shape of this are a nice change from her other teethers which tend to be similar to one another.  I think that makes it an attractive option for her.  It isn't one of those toys that she just can't put down.  She isn't crazy about it.  But she does like it all right.  And, it gets a good reaction from adults who notice it and get a kick out of it.  I think it is clever.  I love buying girly colored things for my daughter, but I think maybe she would have been more convinced that it is her phone if we had ordered the black one.  If I were to order this again I would probably order the black.Anyhow, this is a fun novelty, and a so-so substitute for real phones that you don't want chewed up.  Very cute idea.  We're enjoying it.

I always gravitate toward bath salts that are lavender scented.  For me, lavender is a relaxing scent, and I really don't like flowery, perfume type scents, not to mention artificial fragrances, which I would never even consider for bath salts.Anyway, I wanted to mix it up a little, so I bought this and hoped that I would like it.Actually, I just finished the little shaker of it and I loved it. It is a little oily, but not bad. Just enough so that you actually notice that it makes your skin softer, and not so much that you feel really oily. The smell is wonderful.  It is still as relaxing as lavender always is, but the mint makes it refreshing, too.  It's a perfect combination.The biggest problem that I had is that it seems like this is a generic shaker, not really intended for these bath salts, since they are not really dry and totally free flowing.  It works okay with the pour hole on the top, but the little shaker holes really don't work well at all.  That isn't a really big deal, though.  It's not like you have to break the top out and scoop the salts out...so, whatever, it's fine.If the idea of this scent seems interesting to you, I recommend trying it!  I was pleasantly surprised by how much I liked this.EDIT: Oh, I see that there is only one picture of this product.  On the other sides it has the info currently posted on the Amazon page, plus it says it is good for "approximately 8-10 euphoric baths".  The ingredients are: natural sea salt crystals, dendritic salt, pure essential oils, shea butter and meadowfoam seed oil extract, and rosemary extract.  I'll post pictures of the other sides of the canister later.

We got these because of the good reviews on here, and they arrived today.  I went around and stuffed them into all of the outlets that my daughter can reach.  She has become interested in outlets now that she is mobile.  Tonight I went to charge my phone, and I can't get the plug out!  I guess that's what the little spaces at the top and bottom are for--I think maybe I'll need a flat screwdriver to pull them out.That's fine by me, though, because for the minor inconvenience of needing to find some tool to remove these, I feel totally convinced that my daughter will not be able to accidentally hurt herself with an outlet for her entire toddlerhood, and that was the point of getting these plugs to begin with.  I think even a kid that is coordinated and big enough to pick at a plug would struggle to get these out.We're happy.  Our daughter is too, because she hasn't realized they're preventing her from accessing the outlets and instead she is amused by all of the dots that popped up around the house today.

My sister bought this for my daughter and sent it up to us a few months ago.  We've been doing swim classes, so she wears it every week.First of all, we have gotten a ton of compliments on this suit!  It is very cute in person, because of the ruffles and the colors.In ours the size is "small" and it says that it is supposed to be for 12.5-18 lbs. I think that would probably be correct for most babies...but my daughter is tall and skinny.  She's 9 months old now and she only weighs just over 15 lbs, but she is tall for her age.  I've noticed over the past couple weeks that this suit is getting to be a little tight.  It's time for us to go up a size. So, we didn't reach that 18 lb upper limit, but she's worn it for several months anyway, and we have really enjoyed it.  I also see that a couple stitches have popped where one of the front straps connect.  It isn't noticeable at all unless you're really looking at it, but I guess that's just further evidence that it's a little too tight now and it's time to move on.If you're looking for a girly swimsuit, this is a great pick!

EDIT 7/8/2013: Just a final note that my daughter has thoroughly worn these shoes out.  For the past month or so she LOVES to talk to me about the dog on her shoes---all day long!  It was kind of funny when she finally realized it was a dog, because she loves dogs so much and she had already been wearing them for a while...Anyway, these were fun shoes.  The dog washes up moderately well with a bit of dish soap and a toothbrush.  The middle piece of the dog's bow came off.  The soles are still fine, but fairly dirty.  The dog is filthy.  We didn't have any more problems with stitches coming out.  My daughter is almost 13 months and these shoes (size 6-12 months) are just now starting to look like we're ready to move up to the next size.EDIT 5/24/2013 (Also reducing from 5 stars to 4):  Okay, now are you ready for a real review from someone who actually knows about these exact shoes?  I originally reviewed these about 6 weeks ago, and now I have more that I would like to add.  My daughter has been wearing these as her only shoes.  She goes barefoot around our house (most of the day) and when we go outside she wears these shoes.  She is still only crawling and cruising--she doesn't walk on her own yet.  So, she probably wears these on average maybe 30 minutes a day or less, but occasionally we'll go out for several hours and she'll wear them all or most of the time.  When it seems safe for her to be barefoot she is, and a lot of times she is in our Boba 3G carrier (I'm wear her) or in her car seat as we drive places.  So, what I'm saying here is that she wears these shoes regularly, but not anywhere near all day every day.  The actual amount of time that these shoes are walked in or crawled in is usually outside (or in places that I wouldn't want her to wear socks out of concern that whey would be dirty), but that is probably an average of 5 minutes a day.  Usually a few seconds here or there, and occasionally half an hour here or there.  So, that gives you a very clear idea of the use these have seen.Structurally, these shoes have held up fine.  They are still cute.  BUT, they're quite dirty.  I don't know what the washing instructions are (if there are any) so maybe I need to look into that.  Here are the issues with these shoes:- The dog is made of light suede.  It seriously started getting dirty like, the day after I wrote my original review.  I've rubbed it with a wet washcloth a couple times, but that didn't make a much of a difference.  For kids that are not crawling (ie new babies or little kids that are past crawling and on to only walking) that material is probably fine, and even cute.  For crawling kids, I would not pick something with light suede again.  I wish I could post pictures on this product, because you would see what it actually looks like.  It just looks dirty.  And, if you're only using the shoes once in a while (like, to go with one outfit that is worn only occasionally) that would be more likely to be fine, too.- The bottoms of the shoes are also pretty dirty. I would kind of expect that, though, and that's not a big deal.  It's size 6-12 months, and she's a month away from 12 months.- We had another problem with stitching that started to come out.  On the bottom of one of the shoes the stitching started to come out by the inner edge.  There ended up being a thread hanging from the shoe that was about an inch or maybe a little longer.  It was really only a few stitches.  I trimmed it, and it isn't super obvious, but it looked a little bad before I trimmed it.  The dog's eye has not lost much more of the stitching, so I'd say it is still 80% there?The sizing has still been about right.  My daughter will be one in almost a month and these shoes fit her just right.  Which means that if we go up in size for her next pair, they will probably be a little big...or if her next pair is the same size they will last for a little while, but I don't really know how long.  I think I'll probably get the next size up for her next pair...but these will definitely be fine at least for the next month.Anyway, I think I will try to wash these, and hopefully they will clean up well.  If you're buying for a tiny immobile baby or a walking baby these may still be a good pick.  If you're buying for a crawling baby that has many pairs of shoes, these may still be a good pick.  If your crawling baby received these as a gift, don't worry, you'll still really like them...but if you're choosing a main (or only) pair of shoes for a crawling and cruising baby, I would pick a different style of Robeez without the light suede.Hopefully that is helpful to someone!  I noticed when I was comparing the different kinds it seemed like most of the reviews are either non-specific to the style you're looking at(eg. "WE LOVE ALL ROBEEZ!!!") or they are from people who haven't used them, usually because they ordered a size too big (eg. We got these and they are the best!  Can't wait for my baby to be born so she can wear them!) So, this gives you something more objective to consider.The shoes are super cute though.  We have gotten tons of compliments.--- ORIGINAL REVIEW from April ---I ordered the 6-12 month size because my daughter is 9 months old.  I had considered ordering the next size up so that they would last a little longer (I expected to get 3 months of use), but I'm glad I didn't!  If anything, these shoes are just a little too big.  My daughter is just starting to cruise around rooms holding onto furniture, and when she wears these she trips more.  But, I think she's getting used to them, and I'm sure she'll grow into them better.The shoes are great!  The sole is just a piece of leather (with the dog picture stitched on the bottom), so it's relatively thin, and I think she can still feel the ground better than if she had a rubber sole.  I had heard that Robeez stay on well, and that is true.The stitching on the dog's eye started to come out.  I worried a little that we would end up with a blind dog, but I pulled it a bit more and was able to get it to a point where it stopped coming out, and despite losing 8 stitches or so, I think it is just not as thick, because the eye is not messed up.These shoes are a nice color of brown, and they match a lot of my daughter's outfits.I highly recommend these, with the condition that if you're buying for a 9 month old, 6-12 months is probably still the right size!  If you go up, you'll most likely have shoes that are too large.  But that's a feature, not a problem with the product.  (Correct sizing!)

At our last house we had a shower filter to reduce the chlorine, so when we moved to a rental just a couple minutes away that didn't have chlorine filtration, I immediately noticed a difference.  I knew I wanted to filter bath water for me and for my baby, but since we're only at this rental for a few months I thought it would be great to use this bath ball because it's easier than trying to remove a shower head that has been attached for 20+ years, and I don't actually know if we're allowed modifying that anyway.So, I was expecting a little bit of a hassle, because I knew I was going to have to swirl this around in the tub before I got in the water, and I felt okay about that commitment.When it arrived, my husband laughed at me.  There's no way that is going to make much of a difference, he said.  I told him there had been good reviews online, and I pointed to the package insert that claimed that it could change "up to 100%" of the chlorine.  But when I read that, my husband laughed, and I knew why.  It would have been one thing if it said 96% or even 99.9998% of the chlorine, but really? 100%...that doesn't sound like a very scientific figure for such a rudimentary filtration method.  And, "up to" is such a suspicious term--of course, it is going to vary depending on whether you swirl and swoosh it around enough...but, if you've ever stopped into a store that's having a sale UP TO 80% OFF and found that most items are full price or 5% off and only a couple ultra-clearance items are actually very discounted...you understand that "up to" doesn't mean much of anything.Still, the reviews were good, right, so I was expecting to have positive results.  I write lots of reviews and I trust other reviewers, so I had a lot of faith in that.  So what if I didn't have a 100% experience, or even a 85% improvement.  If the water was noticeably better, say, 25% improved, I would have to consider that a success, since any reduction in the amount of chlorine that we're breathing and soaking in is a good thing.  I expected at least that.So, I faithfully followed the instructions.  I swooshed and swirled, for longer than the package even said to, and let it toss around in the bath too, for the enhanced results that it promised in the information that came with it.I did this for 4 or 5 baths.Nothing.I did not notice any difference in our baths at all, except that I felt kind of awkward hanging out by the tub nakedly wanting to climb in my bath and doing the boring exercise of swishing.  So I tried filtering while clothed instead and found that small splashes got my sleeves wet, which was even less comfortable.The vapor still smelled like chlorine.  The water still felt bad and left my skin extra dry.So, I tried some other things.  I tried a couple baths where I dangled it under the faucet (not recommended!) while the water was running, because some reviewers had mentioned success with that.  Nope.  I tried removing the ball cage so that the mesh bag could come into more contact with more water and maybe potentially filter more.  Nope.I have to conclude that there is really no difference.I told my husband that it turned out that it didn't work.  He wasn't surprised.  I was disappointed that my experience didn't prove him wrong, and even more disappointed that our water is still totally chlorinated.I'm not bothering to use this anymore.  It isn't worth the hassle and it doesn't do anything.  I'm embarrassed that I thought it would work, because it seems like kind of a dumb idea if you think about it.  How many tiny tiny particles must be in the water, and what is the mathematical probability that they will come into contact with the metal scrubby pad inside the mesh?  Pretty unlikely, I would guess.It seems like it would be nice to have a non-shower solution that works, and I know chlorine is bad for us...but don't waste your money on this!  Sloshing it around the tub for as long as you are supposed to is not as convenient as it sounds, and I cannot report even the slightest improvement.  I think the best option may be to fill the bath with a shower that filters, unless you can get a reverse osmosis system.(I almost never return items or give items 1 star, but I wish I could return this, because otherwise I'm just going to throw it away.  Do places accept used returns?  I've never done that before.  Maybe I'll check.)

I heard about these on one of Alejandra Costello's organizing videos (which are awesome, if you're getting organized), and then when I saw them at a local store I picked up a package of them thinking they might help me organize my accounting stuff as I am getting business documents organized for taxes.This is one of those products where as soon as you start using it, you realize you really needed it all along.I have used them to divide big statements into quarters of the year, and to combine things that belong together but are not the same thing (like my Broker's ledger, statements from my Broker, and my own communications with him about our account transfers).  It's kind of like having paperclips that don't get caught on things or accidentally fall off, and little tabs on the side that make it obvious what it is while it is still stacked up with other things.I'm so glad I started using these!

This is a cute little board book with pictures of a mama polar bear and a baby polar bear.  Basically, they both start out together, and then the baby gets just a little bit away from the mom to be on its own and do the things that it is able to, but then soon returns back to the mama bear again.This is basically a model of "secure attachment" as described by John Bowlby in his book "A Secure Base"--babies (humans and in some other species) initially need to be close to mom a lot, then gradually go slightly farther away and stay gone for slightly longer between times when they check in.  That's basically what is happening here; the baby bear is being "independent" in a safe way, near mom.Anyhow, my daughter didn't think about that as we were reading it.  She is 9 months old, and she just kept saying "Oh! Oh! Oh!" on each page because she gets excited when she sees animals.  The text is good because the bear does things that babies are learning (eg, rolls, climbs).  And the pictures are nice.I noticed that the other reviewer recommend this for younger elementary school kids.  I haven't had kids that age, so I don't know about that, but I do know that this book is even appropriate for babies.  My daughter loves it.

I got this book to read to my daughter (she is 9 months old), and we like it a lot.The pictures are not extraordinary, but they are happy, in the style of the cover picture.  Each page has two words, an adjective and a noun (such as "warm sun" and "soft sand") and the book goes through a bunch of different beach and summer-type things.My daughter was born in June, so it is nearly April now and most of her life that she can remember has been winter, so I thought it would be fun to help her get ready for summer by including this in our rotation.  I like reading books about seasons with her.  It is nice because it doesn't have too many words.  She never loses interest before the book is over.We really like this book.

We love this outfit--my daughter has worn it to bed as a sleeper though the colder months, and also sometimes during the day.It is made of microfleece? I think.  It's very soft.Something that we liked about it is that since it has no feet, she hasn't outgrown it early because she is tall.  It still just fits her fine.Anyway, it is very cute and we're glad we bought it.

I really liked this sleeper.  My daughter looked adorable in it, and although I don't usually care for pink and orange together, in this case it looks great.It's nice because it snaps down both of the legs instead of just one.  That's nice because I don't have try to get my daughter to put one leg in one side that is closed up.  Snapping both sides is just easier.The only thing about this sleeper is that my daughter is tall and skinny, and although other Carters 9 month outfits still fit her, this seems too short (it is a little tight down at the feet and around her neck).  So, sadly, she only wore this a few times.I'm still glad we had it, though.  It's really cute in person.

I love how the only two five star reviews are from people who ordered it to give as a gift and have never even seen the toy in use!  Uh...does it help anyone to know that it looks like the picture?  We received this as a gift, from someone who thought it looked fun.  It does look fun.This toy doesn't work, and it never has worked for us.The idea is cute: fill up the cup on top, and it will trickle down causing the top section to whirl, the middle section the move little balls around, and the final section to spin.  On ours, only the penguin part works.  Our penguin stays up pretty well, so it can collapse if you want it to, but you can also watch the interior twirl.  It does twirl a little, kind of slowly.If you fill the middle section, it has trouble filling, and then it has trouble draining.  The balls do nothing.  It does rattle when empty, but...this is a bath toy that doesn't do anything special in the water.If you fill the bottom section, it drains out the bottom.  The thing in the middle does not spin.If you keep the pieces connected, on ours, the top twirls minimally.  Nothing else happens at all.  If you separate the pieces, the starfish part in the middle drains with a pattern.  Sometimes.  If the water doesn't get stuck.  The fish on bottom still does nothing.I think we're probably just going to throw this away.  If you're considering buying this (for your kiddo or as a gift) save your money or buy something else.  Anything else.  Worst Bath Toy Ever!

I ordered this because my daughter (8 months old) was having a tough time getting to sleep, waking frequently, and having trouble going back to sleep.  We wanted to develop a better bedtime routine.I asked my Facebook friends if anyone had tried the Tranquil Turtle Sleep Machine and nobody had but someone recommended putting this oil on the soles of my daughter's feet at bedtime.I decided to try both.  So, now we 1. go potty; 2. change into jammies; 2. rub a drop of Serenity oil on each foot (or if she is wearing jammies with feet I put it on her wrists); 3. read stories, always ending with Goodnight Moon; 4. say goodnight to Dada and Chalcy (the dog); 5. turn on the Tranquil Turtle; 6. lay her down on her floor bed and nurse until she is almost or completely asleep.When we first started using the oil the smell seemed too busy to me...I felt like I kept trying to figure out what the scent was (which, it's a blend, so it's a lot of things), and it had kind of an overly sweet smell, I thought.  I didn't really care for it.  We've been doing this for almost a month now, I think, and now I like the scent.  It just smells like "bedtime" to us.  I think my daughter likes it too.  Bed time is not a LOT better...this didn't magically help her go to sleep and stay asleep all night, unfortunately.  But it is better than before.  She wakes less.Overall, I don't know whether it calms us or not, but it is pleasant, and a nice addition to our routine.

I almost, almost bought this from Amazon several times, but the price was usually about $10 with shipping, and that seemed like too much to pay for this.  I'm just used to buying almost everything from Amazon, though, so it seemed like a real hassle to have to go to a store for this toy.We were at a local store the other day and they had these for about $4.  So we bought one.  And we got to choose the color, too. But, I let my 9 month old baby choose what color she wanted and she picked orange.  Hm.  Oh well.I noticed that some reviewers mention sloppy construction with glue left on the toy (making it a bad idea to chew on).  Ours does not have any glue that is visible.My daughter loves this!  It is currently one of her toys that we keep in the car to entertain her while she is in her car seat.  She likes it because if you shake it or hit it against things it rattles.  Also, the spacing of the holes make it very easy to grasp and it is just perfect for chewing on; she already has 8 teeth, and when she puts this in her mouth she can teethe on the sides of her mouth very effectively.  So, she likes that.Ball was her first word, so it's always fun when she plays with this one, because she sometimes chatters about it "Ba. Ba. BaaahhL." etc.Great toy.  I'm glad we bought one.  Also, I'm glad I didn't buy it on here.  Just look for this one at your local grocery store or superstore.Highly recommended.

We're trying to expose our daughter to Spanish from a young age, so I've been reading a bunch of books to her in Spanish.  We borrowed "Buenas noches, Estados Unidos" from the library and LOVED it, so I decided to buy this one for us, especially since I am also from California.Eh, it was okay.Although my daughter used to like the Estados Unidos one all the way through, this one is not as engaging to her, for some reason.  I think older kids would probably enjoy it more.I felt like the things they picked were a lot of times kind of similar...for example, there are several pages about the beach, which, okay, I get that that's a big thing in California (and it is), but it seemed a little repetitive.  There are a few pages about other things like computer scientists, farmers, and vineyards.My Spanish is not the best, and I understood more of the United States one.  This one it seems like more of the pages have a lot of words.  I think that's part of why my daughter loses interest.  The illustrations are also not as nice as in the United States one.Overall, though, it's fine.  If I hadn't loved and enjoyed the Estados Unidos one so much, I probably would have given this 5 stars.  So, if you're choosing between those two, I would go with the United States one and not the California one.  But, we're not going to send it back.  We don't hate it.  I'll buck up and go learn the words that I don't understand, and my daughter will grow (and so will her attention span), and it will be fine.The series is nice.  Maybe we just need more places, and that will just increase our vocabulary more and invite a broader variety of places on the pages.

We're interested in exposing our daughter to Spanish from a very young age, so I've been reading Spanish board books to her.  She is almost 9 months old.This book is fantastic!!It's really different from the other Spanish/bilingual little kid books out there, which are often pretty similar to one another, and tend to have the same problems.  Spanish books for kids are either in Spanish only or Spanish and English.  I know enough Spanish to be able to read books for kids just fine, so I don't mind when they are in Spanish only, but this is nice because it is also in English, so in case you couldn't tell what was happening in the picture (or maybe your original language is Spanish), it is also in English.The things I like the best about this book are:- Modern pictures!  This style of pictures is totally different than the other Spanish kid books we've bought and borrowed from the library.  That's fun!- Engaging content.  My daughter doesn't care a whole lot about this yet, but I can imagine a 2 year old boy thinking this book is AWESOME.  It has kids do things like sit down and stand up, and pick their nose (we just pretend).  I can imagine that being hilarious to a little boy, though.- Original.  Often when I like a book in English we read the Spanish version, and I am almost always disappointed with the way they chose to do it.  In this case, I'm not comparing this to something else, so it's just great on its own.- Nice binding.There isn't anything that I don't like about this book.  Maybe it would have been nice if it were more colorful?  I don't know.  It's really fine the way it is.  Check out the "Click to look inside" option here on Amazon to see an example of the book.Highly recommended, especially for little kids (although babies find the activities interesting too).

I ordered these in size 12-18 mos for my daughter who is skinny and almost 9 months.  They're a little loose, but not bad.  I'm definitely glad we got this size instead of getting 6-12 months.These seem to be pretty well-made; the stitching looks good.  The fabric is thick enough that I don't think my daughter gets cold while wearing them, and thin enough that she doesn't sweat too much either.  Just right for any time of year, I think.We'll be ordering more.

I wanted to start taking B-6, and I was considering magnesium as well, so I was excited to find this sublingual liquid.  I have had a good experience with sublingual vitamins in the past.  I feel like they absorb better than when I take capsules.Anyhow, as if it wasn't good enough that this has magnesium and zinc along with it, it also tastes delicious.I highly recommend this supplement, and in the future when I buy supplements I'll check for this brand first.

My daughter is 8 months old and she has 8 teeth...so you might guess that she has been teething a lot.  And you would be right.She also wants to be held constantly, so I love to wear her in my Boba 3G.  Unfortunately, she's been teething on the carrier.  I decided to search for teething pads because I saw another brand of carrier that had them, and I discovered these!So we got them, right away.They are quite nice.  Easy to put on and take off.  The fabric is soft.The only thing I don't really like is that they are white.  I have the montenegro Boba 3G...so...my whole carrier is black, and then there are these white pads.  It looks a little weird.I think I get why they do it, though, because we once had to wash our carrier (not just spot clean) and the dye just poured out of the carrier.  If they used the came dye process for these pads the babies would get color EVERYWHERE.  Still, in my opinion, that just means that maybe for the teething pads you could dye them with more colorfast process, and/or use safe dye, and then they would match a little better.  White is basically the last color I would have chosen to go with this carrier.But, anyway, my daughter is no longer chomping on the actual straps, so that's a win.If you have a Boba 3G and a kid that's teething, these are essential.

Well, I'm really disappointed.I bought this for hanging my purse (which weighs 1.5-2 lbs).  I read other reviews mentioning things falling, and when I saw that following the instructions is kind of a pain (you have to clean surfaces with rubbing alcohol and press for a little while), I figured maybe the other people didn't follow the instructions closely.  I thought that by purchasing a hook that is supposed to hold 5 lbs (more than double the weight that I was using it for) and following the instructions very closely we would be fine.I carefully followed all of the instructions--I wiped with alcohol, pressed the hook on for at least 10 seconds, removed the hook and pressed the base for at least 30 seconds, then put the hook on and waited overnight before I put my purse on this hook.  (I even saved the instructions because it said to.) My purse doesn't hang there all the time, even, maybe every other night...and yesterday when I went to look for my purse it was on the floor.  The hook fell!Not only that, it took a big chunk of paint off (almost 1" square).Seriously??  I bought this because we are renting.  I didn't want to damage the paint.  That was the whole point.  So, it bothers me that this didn't work.We are using the Command picture strips for our pictures, too, so I hope those don't fall.I don't recommend this product.

I can see why some people would like this, but I don't really care for it.We're doing kind of natural things as far as parenting goes--I'm breastfeeding, so we don't carry bottles or formula.  I wear my baby when we go places, so we don't have a stroller to attach this to, and consequently nowhere to put this while we're out and about; I would just have to carry it in addition to my daughter and anything I have bought while we are out, etc.  It's just way too big to bother with.We have left my daughter with her grandparents while my husband and I have gone on trips, oh, 2 or 3 times, and this bag is what we use for several days worth of her clothes, milk, bottles, the bottle warmer, and a blanket.So, I noticed that one of the other reviewers mentioned being able to carry her laptop in this bag (and she considered that to be another feature!).  If you want space for your laptop, yeah, that would definitely fit.  You may be able to fit a desktop computer in here.  Well.  Maybe not.  I don't know.Anyway, it is a very large bag, so if you're carrying stuff for multiple kiddos, maybe you'll be into that.I also felt like the interior organization of the bag didn't really work for me.  The interior pockets kind of flop this way and that for me, and get squished.  The times that I have used this, I'm always digging around to try to find whatever I am looking for.  God forbid I toss my keys into this bag, I would probably never get into the house!So, yeah.  This is a large, very open bag.What I usually do is make my regular purse into a diaper bag.  I put like 4 diapers in my purse, a baggie with a few wipes in it, depending on how long we're going to be gone, I sometimes have a onesie or something simple to change her into in case we have some kind of diaper blowout or throwup disaster...a small toy to keep her busy if she needs a distraction...sometimes I've had a pacifier in my bag, but she's not very interested in those, so I don't think I do anymore.  And that's it.Another thing I don't really like about this bag is that to me it looks cheap.  Well, okay, it is cheap, so what else was I expecting??  I don't know.  The exterior, well, and the interior, are plastic-y.  I thought the style would be modern with a hint of baby (because of the light pink), and when it arrived, it seemed more baby with a hint of modern.  If that makes sense.  Maybe I'm a diaper bag snob.Really, though, in the times that we have used this it hasn't been a bad bag.  Nothing has broken or seemed like it would break.  It does seem to be pretty well made.  So, if you're looking for a large diaper bag, this may be exactly what you need.

I just wrote a really long review and my page refreshed and I lost the whole thing.  Too bad.  In short:We're doing a trial of 9 different kinds of cloth diapers (mostly all-in-ones and all-in-twos) and these are our favorites.Some features: the elastic is adjustable in the legs so it fits all babies well (which is awesome since my daughter has super skinny legs).  The velcro is better than the velcro on most other diapers, and it seems like it will last longer.  These diapers dry very quickly.  They are super trim, so they look nice on my daughter instead of making her look like an insect (with a huge bum) like other cloth diapers do.I just ordered a bunch of these yesterday and I found an article online about the company.  Softbums was started by a lady and her husband helps run the company.  They invented the diaper based on their experience cloth diapering their own kiddos.  I kinda liked that.Also, about this particular color: Softbums does a "calendar" thing where they make limited edition diaper prints every month.  Berry Owls was one of the 2012 limited edition prints.  It is very cute.  I know all computers display things differently, but on my computer the coloring looks like little girl pink.  It isn't.  Berry is a better description.  The color is pink, but it's kind of a blend between girl pink and raspberry color.  It looks really great.

These socks are a little thinner than the other Luvable Friends socks 8-Pack Newborn Baby Socks that we have used before.  These also go higher up on the baby's leg than the other ones.  My daughter is really skinny, so they don't cut into her leg at all; they fit really well.  They're stretchy, too, so average-build babies will probably also find that they fit very nicely.My favorite thing about these socks is that they stay on really well.  I don't think they have ever fallen off at all.I'm sure I will be ordering more of these.

I was kind of curious to see what I would actually receive, since some other reviewers mention expecting four castanets and receiving two.  Also, I could find no mention of what these castanets are made of.  I hoped they would be wooden, but decided it would be fine either way.I received one yellow plastic castanet.  It makes a very castanet-y sound, and seems to be easy to use, which is great since it is for my infant daughter to play with.  At her Kindermusik class they have a box of various instruments (including castanets) and I had the idea that it would be fun to have some more instruments at home for her.It does seem pretty durable.  It is made by Hohner Kids, actually, and my yellow one has a bright purple elastic piece connecting the pieces.Aw, now I feel kind of ripped off.  I just searched and found the same product available at nearly half the cost.  Heyyyy.  Don't buy this.  Buy THIS instead: Plastic Finger-Size Castanet(color may vary)For $4.95 (which is what the other link charges for the same thing) this is a 5 star product.  For $7.33, I was originally going to give it 3-4 stars, but there is nothing about this castanet that makes it worth $2.38 more than the other link.

This album has two songs that are a whole bunch of sounds, and we like those the best.  The farm song has a whole bunch of farm songs (and it is actually in the context of a song), and there is another track that is sounds from the zoo, and that has adult and baby animal sounds for monkeys, elephants, and just a whole bunch of animals.  It catches my daughter's attention every time we listen to it.

We just moved into an apartment.  We're not planning to stay for a very long time, so we didn't want to make bigger changes (like an accent wall), but we're still trying to feel like we're home.I found these decals at Walmart and decided I would see if this worked in our living room.It's something.These are not made out of the nice kind of vinyl that is popular for walls (and cars) now.  Instead, it's basically clear stickers.  I didn't put them on a wall that gets direct light, so mine don't look shiny.  They're kind of matte stickers anyway, so I don't know that shine is going to be a problem for most people.The stickers are fairly large.  I think the tall "L"s are about a foot tall, the "ive", "augh", and "ove" are maybe about 5" tall, and "WELL", "OFTEN", and "MUCH" are maybe about 2" tall.I had trouble spatially understanding how large the entire thing would be, and knowing how I should put them on my wall.  I just copied the picture, and added a few extra diamonds.  There is also nothing to help you get the words straight.  This was a bit of a problem for me, and I still don't think I have them perfectly straight, but it says on the package that they are repositionable, and that is true--I removed "Love" probably half a dozen times before I decided it was straight enough.  I think the only limitation with repositioning them would be if your fingers were dirty, or you somehow got stuff stuck to the sticky part.  That would wear it out pretty quickly.It is also sometimes a little tricky to remove the decals from the backing. You have to hunt for a spot that will peel just the part you want.Overall, I was happy enough with the experience.  I think when we buy a house I will probably go with custom vinyl...but this is all right for now.  I think it makes our apartment look a little more lived in.

My mother-in-law gave this book to my daughter for Valentine's day this year.  (I think she gave it to each family of grandkids, maybe?)So, my daughter is only 7 months old, but I read this to her today.  She was actually kind of into it, I think because the pictures are kind of busy--a lot is going on on every page.I LOVE this book!First of all, the story is really sweet.  This man's life completely changes because of something simple and sweet.  It shows that small things that we do can really affect other people.Also, I have been reading a lot of books about gentle parenting and good communication lately and they all emphasize the importance of empathy and relating to people (including kids) empathically.  This book shows people who are acting empathically--Mr. Hatch notices how people around him are doing, he asks them about it, and then he responds to help them.  Then, at the end of the book, the people in his neighborhood respond to him with empathy as well.  So, I think kids (and adults) of all ages can benefit from this dialogue and also the examples of characters behaving well.The illustrations are excellent!  The tone of the story is really evident from the illustrations.  For example, before Mr. Hatch receives the valentine, the illustrations are brown and gray, that kind of projects how sad and boring his life is.  Then, after Mr. Hatch receives the valentine, the illustrations are colorful and bright.  The actions of the picture also match the mood--before the valentine everything is really still and plain (I'm thinking of a picture of Mr. Hatch eating lunch at work and there's a prune sitting on the table...).  After the valentine, the pictures are really busy, with people and motion.  There are also a couple transitional pages where there is a moderate amount of action and color.  Goodnight Moon is kind of this way, with the color--the pages dim as you go through the book.  I think kids pick up on that type of subtle change.This book claims that it is for ages 5-8, and maybe the difficulty of the words matches that, but it's really very pleasant for all ages, I think.  And it's nice and appropriate for any time of year, not just Valentine's Day.Fantastic book.  I highly recommend this!

I just got through my package of French Lavender bath salts.  I plan to buy this again.The lavender scent was enough to be relaxing but not overwhelming.  It does smell like essential oil and not like "fragrance."  That was important to me because fragrances and perfumes often bother me; I buy unscented laundry soap and deodorant, etc.  This was just right, though.It fizzes up a little and puts kind of a foam on the surface of the bath, then that gradually dissolves.  I found that a couple handfuls is all I really need to have a nice bath.  I have't timed how long the foam lasts, but I love a good bath so I've tried many different brands of bath salt before and this is very comparable (in foaminess and amount of time the foam lasts) to other kinds I've used before.These salts are not too oily.If you're considering these bath salts, I highly recommend them.  Actually, even if you're not considering them, I highly recommend them.  I would think life was pretty awesome if someone gifted these to me.  ;)

Like many other parents, I am trying to expose my daughter to music (and several other things) from an early age, to help her develop into the best little person she can be.  So, we got her this little piano for Christmas, and she has been using it since then.Sometimes she gets really into it.  She is now 7 months old, and she's little, so this is just the right size for her to sit down in front of it.  I set her down at the piano toy and she will play with it for a little while.  She thinks it is interesting to try to pull the keys up instead of pushing them down.  That feels funnier, I guess.  Sometimes she presses the keys, and I tell her how great it is that she is "making music."  Of course she does not use the song book at all.  She has not noticed that the cardboard strip of notes is a separate piece.  If she had, it would be destroyed by now, but I don't think that really matters.I am glad that this is not an electronic toy...but...the description says it is hand tuned.  By who??  Monkeys??  This toy is so out of tune it is comical.  It also sounds more like one of those xylophones than a piano.But, whatever, she's 7 months old.  She's understanding that a piano has white keys and black keys and that you can push them down (or try to pull them up) and when you push them down they make different sounds.  That's kind of what I was hoping she would learn.  The recommended age range for this is 3 and up.  By the time she is 3, we plan to start Dogs and Birds with her and she will need something that plays the real notes...but...in anticipation of that...this is acceptable, and kind of a cute toy.If you're hoping to purchase a musical instrument, this is not very good.  If you're buying it for a baby or small child and you don't care too much about whether it is in tune, go right ahead.  We're happy that we bought this, although I got it as part of a Black Friday sale.  I don't think it is really worth the list price.

This underwear is super comfortable.  My pack had hot pink, black, and white, each with black and white striped elastic.  The fabric is cut just right, so I don't have to readjust during the day--that's something that I appreciate in a good pair of underwear.  Covers the right parts.  I would buy these again.

I was happy to get this sample pack for my daughter so that she could try many different foods.I like Happy Baby baby food because it has very, very clean ingredient lists.  No extra stuff added!This sampler comes with a great variety of different baby foods.The only thing that is a little weird is that the packages are quite large for stage 1.  My daughter doesn't eat this much solid food before it has been a few days and we're supposed to discard the rest.  Seems like it would make more sense to do a bit smaller portions.  Bigger kids will like the generous portions, though, and I suppose kids that are eating stage 2 or 3 may still like single foods from time to time anyway.If you're interested in trying a variety of flavors--or if your baby is!--this is a great way to do it.My daughter likes these.

I worked at a grocery store for a year or so, about 10 years ago.  At the grocery store we always had box cutters around to use for so many different tasks, and I got into the habit of using one often.Simple box cutters are hard to find, though!Since my time at the grocery store I've tried buying cheap razor blade scrapers (which work well but not for cutting) and razor blade cutters (which cut well but don't scrape, AND they are usually bulky enough that I end up not using them because they're too big to be comfortable to use).  I haven't ever found simple box cutters like this in a store before.More often than not I just try to use scissors to cut things.  Scissors are a poor substitute for a good box cutter, though!So, I was happy to find these, and even happier to have them around.Some people seem to care a lot about the colors, and their reviews reflect that.  The colors are assorted; mine came 1/3 white, 1/3 yellow, and 1/3 orange.  Orange and yellow are not my favorite colors but...it's a box cutter!  What difference does the color make??  Would the people concerned with that be as particular about the color of their scissors or bottle of toothpaste?  I doubt it!  If you don't like the colors that you get, here are a few ideas for you:- Use a Sharpie to write names on them (in case you wanted a wider variety of colors for identification among different cutters);- Wrap the sheath in duct tape.  If you want to be extra-fancy, buy several different colors of duct tape and you can have a rainbow of different colored box-cutters;- Spray paint your box cutters in whatever color you prefer.Be assertive, people!  You are only limited by your imagination.  If you want hot pink box cutters, make it happen!Anyhow, these box cutters are extremely useful.  We just purchased new couches a few days ago and they came in large cardboard boxes that we needed to break down.  I happened to have one of these in my purse and MY, OH, MY, what a difference!  It was so quick and easy to cut the boxes down.  It reminded me of the time that I lived with my sister and we bought a Christmas tree and I used the "saw" on my pocket knife to trim a bit off the bottom of the trunk.  My pocket knife worked so well compared to our steak knives!  Annnd, then a couple years ago when my husband and I bought a real tree (which needed to be trimmed) and I used a real saw.  It was a difference of night and day.  If you are cutting boxes with scissors, it's as if you're trying to use a pocket knife to trim the bottom of the Christmas tree!  Live large!  Get box cutters!  But don't use them to trim the bottom of your Christmas trees.  I don't think these box cutters would work well for that.Highly recommended for anyone!  (Except children and people who are at risk of harming themselves.)  Great product!

What Babies Want is a documentary that explores the truth that babies are conscious beings, and the implications of that fact.  The film is divided into many chapters: the first several are about birth and bonding (or not bonding), and the later chapters are about how the birth experience affects people and society.  There are a variety of experts that participate in the film, including doctors, a midwife, psychologists, a "ritual keeper" from an African tribe, parents, and others, and they each share their knowledge and/or experiences related to the topic.I really enjoyed the first half of the film and the end.  At the beginning of the film they talk about how the goal is to help our children grow into their authentic selves and "keep the spark alive."  I liked that.  They showed how science has found a lot of evidence that babies are molded by early experiences, and that even if they are not totally aware of those experiences, they play them out later.  A lady named Sobonfu Some (a "ritual keeper" from an African tribe) was featured a lot, and I liked what she had to say.  Sobonfu Some told about different traditions that her people in Africa have, including telling the babies "We thank you for the gift that you are going to bring."  In Africa the people prepare a lot for a baby to be born.  At the end of the film Sobonfu Some said that they have young children in another room when a baby is born so that when the new baby cries out the children can respond--the new baby is basically crying, "I'm here, is anyone out there," and the kids are saying "You're in the right place and you're wanted!"  I don't know if babies would think of that, but it seemed very nice to me.  I think our culture misses out for not having rituals the way that tribes and older societies did; I think rituals give us something that I don't really understand.There were a couple quotes that I especially liked.  One was by Wendy Anne McCarty, and she said "When we come from the belief that babies are conscious, every way we are with our babies changes.  We include them, we know that they're taking everything in, it is imprinting, it is the course of what is life here as human being like?"  In the film they talked about all of the routine hospital procedures that are not very welcoming to new babies, and that those things partially came about because people thought that babies were not really aware anyway.  The thought occurs to me often that my daughter is a real person, and she is feeling her feelings as strongly as I feel mine.  I also have the strong feeling that everything I do for her now, and the way that I treat her now as a young baby is forming the foundation of her life, and I feel like it is critically important that I do things the best that I can.  I take that very seriously, and I felt like Wendy Anne McCarty's quote matched up with how I feel.After the first half of the film there was a portion that I didn't really connect with, in which various people discussed how non-ideal birthing affects people.  They discussed people acting things out--an example was of a girl who had a cord around her neck when she was born so she put a string around a doll's neck even though she didn't know why.  To me, that seems a little unbelievable and weird.  Although I do believe that all of the hospital routines that do not encourage bonding have an impact, I doubt that single specific moments "replay" like an elderly man mentioned; he said that because his head was pushed back in he felt rejected and the same thing played out over and over again in his life.  In my opinion, there was a lot more going on than just that one moment.  If he felt rejected over and over again, his family had more serious problems than just an untimely birth experience.  I think my thoughts on this are somewhat influenced by my reading of Ina May's Guide to Childbirth.  In Ina May's book she mentions times when labor may stop because of some reason or another because we don't feel safe or ready or we lack privacy, or for whatever reason.  So, I think that the birth experience is a fluid experience that may set the tone for a particular way of living, but when this film said that mothers should apologize to babies for things that didn't go right with a birth...I don't know how that could make much of a difference except maybe subconsciously.  A segment of the movie about a lady who was dealing with her birth seemed really weird to me.  They were lighting candles, and I didn't connect with that part of the film at all.1The film ended with a great, uplifting message about children seeking a place of belonging.  I liked that.Overall, I enoyed the film quite a bit.  It made me want to go wake my daughter so that I could hold her!  I think it is important to make birth as gentle as possible and to encourage bonding.  I liked the ideas about helping children feel like they belong and welcoming them.  There was a quote about how in the early years you need to connect with children to learn who they are and what their purpose is, and I really liked that.I think this would be an especially fun movie for parents to watch while they are expecting.  It shows several birth scenes that are very sweet, without being preachy, and I think most moms would enjoy that, and they would enjoy feeling the importance of the baby they are carrying and the importance of having the best birth experience that they can.

First of all, the colors are a little different than they look on my screen, which could be just my computer's display, but it's worth mentioning: this set is not neon pink, it is hot pink, kind of like a darker Barbie pink color.  On my screen it looks like more of an electric pink, which it isn't.The top is a tunic.  In some ways, it is great because it fits my tall, skinny daughter well, and it would also fit chubby babies well.  The sleeves are kind of funky, though.  I can't decide whether it is a fashionable thing that I like, and it's nice to have variety, or whether it just looks strange.It isn't as cute as I thought it would be, but we tend to like classic styles.  If you wear peasant tops yourself, and tunics, and those sorts of things, maybe this top is awesome?  I don't know.I probably wouldn't buy it for us again, but maybe other people love it.It is well made.  The stitches are strong, and all of that.

I bought this set for the kitty print sleeper.  It is SO cute!  It kind of reminds me of the Japanese print fabrics that you can get for sewing.  My daughter loves our cat so "we" talk about kitties when she wears this stuff.One thing worth mentioning: although Carters clothes usually have pretty thick fabric, this set is fairly thin.  It would be great for summertime.  It isn't super thin, where you have to worry about snaps tearing off when you unsnap, but it isn't toasty warm, either, if that makes sense.  My daughter is wearing this during winter and she needs blankets, etc, to keep warm enough.Although I bought this for the sleeper, the other outfit is also GREAT!  My husband said "she looks ridiculous...but in a cute, baby way." Adults don't go around with a kitty on their head or feet, so to him some baby clothes seem silly.  And they kind of are.  It was a compliment, though.We love these outfits!Highly recommended for any little ones.

This is such a wonderful book!I love it.My daughter is 7 months old now and she loves it too.  She tries to pick the little boy off of the pages, and she loves a shirt that the boy is wearing in one of the pages.Anyhow, the illustrations are very sweet.  It's kind of cute to see what the teddy bear is doing in each of the pictures; sometimes he is doing what the boy is doing, and other times he is reacting to what the boy is doing.I want to explain how I feel about this book, but I don't really know quite how to say it...before our daughter was born, I thought crying babies were obnoxious.  Now, when my daughter cries, I feel sorry that she is sad, and I want to help her feel better.  Even though my daughter is a baby with very strong emotions, I seldom lose my patience with her, because I'm just crazy about her.  I feel like she is the best baby in the world.  This book, to me, puts that feeling into words--as I read the book I'm expressing to my daughter that I just love everything about her, because she's a great little person.  I doubt that my daughter understands much of it now, but I plan to keep it in our book rotation for a very long time.  I think it would be great to hear this kind of book as a little kid!  So reassuring and comforting.Something else that is really nice about this book is that it is a little poetic.  It rhymes, but not awkwardly...it's just right.  As I read it aloud, this book has a beautiful cadence.The only thing I would change about this book is that the pages are kind of thin for a board book.  Usually board books have thick cardboard for the cover and each of the pages.  This book has a slightly puffy cover and pages that are more like a thicker cardstock.  I would have preferred all thick pages.This is definitely, definitely worth buying!  I'm so glad we got it now.  Every little kid should have this book (and someone to read it to them)!

I accidentally ordered the 5 pack, which I realize is not the best deal for price.I'm still very happy.These Post-It notes are very pretty, and I like having the bright colors.  The green doesn't really look like the mint green in the picture (at least on my monitor screen); it is more of a neon green.  Also, the yellow is not as golden.  I actually already had Post-Its in the standard Post-It yellow color AND a golden color and this is kind of in between--more golden, but not orangey.  If you've bought "ultra" specifically, you may already have these precise colors, but it you have a different set, you may get a slightly slightly different color.  I love getting as many different colors as I can, so this was a pleasant surprise.These notes work best with markers, I think.  I used them with regular pen and only some of the colors show up well; yellow and green do.  Purple is dark enough that the pen writing is nearly lost.  That kind of defeats the purpose of having a bold color note somewhere...if the writing is not immediately obvious.I see that some reviews complain about 1/2 size pads.  They didn't order this product.  These pads are the normal thickness.  Also, these are not "super-sticky" pads, they are the regular adhesive, and they work great.

Well it's that time again to restock the old sock drawer and this time I decided to plop down a few extra bucks and get something nice. I chose these.Pros1. These are really nice socks. They fit my feet like a glove and actually kind of hold them. Never had socks feel like that before so I like these.2. These breathe really well, the tops appear a bit thinner to help moisture escape and fresh air to penetrate.3. The bottoms are cushioned a tiny bit which feels nice.4. They look nice. Neutral colors means I can wear these with anything.5. I can't speak for everyone, but these rest right on my ankle which is about the perfect height for me. I wear a size 9.5 shoe and my feet are of average width.6. They feel well made. These don't give the impression that they're going to get holes or stop being good anytime soon.Cons1. None so far although I am a tad weary of how thin the tops are. I'll update my review if anything goes wrong.Overall, these are some really nice socks. A tad on the expensive side but I feel like I got my money's worth for right now. Of course we'll see how long these last but for now, I'm happy with them and I think they'll last a while.

I bought these so I'd have a nice, reliable, and comfortable pair of slippers to wear around the house and occasionally out to get food (like drive thru where I don't plan on leaving the car)Pros1. They look nice. I bought the coffee brown pair and they just look good.2. These are comfortable. There is some cushioning although I don't expect it to last for years and years of use. They fit my feet very well and don't fall off.3. The bottoms are rubber soles which adds a non stick element. I also feel comfortable wearing these outside because they do have a "sort of feel like shoes" feel to them.4. The inside is fuzzy which makes these comfortable to wear with socks or with shoes.5. Good for squashing bugs on the wall =P6. They seem well made. I didn't have any loose threads and the stitching feels secure and we'll done.Cons1. None yet but I'll likely update my review if things go wrong.Like other reviewers have noted, these do squeeze your feet a little bit so they're probably not for people who need wide slippers. They also provide little arch support but I knew this buying them. They're slippers, not running shoes =)Overall, I love these things and I finally feel like I have a comfortable pair of slippers that's going to last me a while. I've been wearing them since they got here and I've not problems with them whatsoever. Good price too!

I bought this because I'm a big fan of fairy tail.Pros1. Large wallet.2. Inexpensive.3. Decals look cool.Cons1. The pockets are different sizes. The one closest to the front is too short while the one in the back shallows your cards whole.2. There seems to be like tissue paper or something in there that keeps making a crinkle sound. AnnoyingIt's not a bad wallet but not a great one either. Little things yknow?

I bought this for my 05 Equinox because it didn't come with a USB, Bluetooth, or aux cable set up. I use my HTC One M9 as an MP3 player.Pros1. Crystal clear audio.2. Bright, useful display.3. Easy controls.4. Decent length cable.Cons1. None yet.Like other reviewers say, this delivers  crystal clear audio with subtle distortions because that's what radio does sometimes. Usually distortions lastly only a few moments and don't happen overly frequently.The challenging part is finding a station that's open enough for this to sound good. I used radio-locator.com, it's a site that's literally designed to show you which stations should work best for equipment like this.I would recommend. It's a good little thing that will work for cheap until I can buy something more permanent.

I bought this for my pair of Sennheiser HD 558 headphones. I opened them up and removed the locking mechanism so I can use any old 2.5mm cable and decided instead to go with a 2.5mm to 3.5mm adapter (this one) and then your standard 3.5mm male to male cable to connect my phones to stuff.Pros1. Works at least for audio. I don't use a microphone so if you do, I would defer to other people's reviwes...although some say it does and some say it doesn't so I wish they'd put like the product name of the equipment that does and doesn't work so we'd know.2. The adapter is fairly long which is good for me because the headphone jack is tucked up in my headphones a pretty good ways.3. It's cheap.Cons1. I guess it doesn't work for microphones on some devices.I got this solely for listening to audio and for that purpose, it works great. No troubles, ticks, static, or other audio anomalies (at least so far). I'll update the review if I notice something but otherwise this works fine for me.

I bought this for a pair of headphones that has a removable cable. The stock cable was too long and this one is a better length.Pros1. Cheap2. No reduction in sound quality from the stock cable on my headphones.3. Looks of good construction. I've had it for a bit and it hasn't broken and doesn't feel like it's going to.Cons1. None really.This is a solid cable at a good price. I would recommend.

I bought this because a pack of 4 is cheaper here than pretty much anywhere near me. It is, in fact, 4 rolls of decent quality packing tape.Pros1. 4 rolls2. Good quality3. Cheap.4. Fits my tape gun thing.Cons1. NoneIt is what it is. Good purchase, will likely purchase again when I eventually run out.

Warning: Before you buy these, you REALLY need to Google "open vs closed headphones" if you don't already know about them. Don't worry, you're not dumb for not knowing, but you should know the difference before even considering buying these. Open headphones leak sound and don't cancel out noise. They are designed that way for a reason. These are open headphones and a lot of reviewers don't seem to have realized that when they bought them. Please, please Google it before buying.The short version: Closed back headphones are, well closed on the backs. These are made for noise cancellation and noise reduction for those around you. They also add a bit of "edge" to the sound of the music you're listening to and are generally found in headphones that laud bass (such as the Audio Technica ATH-M50s or the Beats by Dre brand).Open backed headphones are open in the back. This adds a little more softness and to your sound and gives it a wider sound stage (as though you're listening to speakers in the room, not headphones. The effect is subtle). The Sennheiser 558s are open backed headphones, thus should NOT be purchased for noise cancellation or noise reduction.Okay now on to my review! =)Wow these are incredible. I've long been wanting to upgrade my audio experience and after reading tons of reviews, commentary, and forums threads, I decided that these were the perfect fit in my price range.A few things to note:1. I'm not a "bass head". I like a nice, even sound. I want to hear the bass but I don't necessarily need it to punch me in the ear holes.2. My equipment includes a Xonar DG soundcard on my computer which provides way more than sufficient power to drive these headphones. Smartphones/tablets/etc will work very well, but I tested these on my computer.3. I am NOT an audiophile. I'm a normal guy who listens to a lot of audiophiles talk.Pros1. The soundstage is incredible. I've been a life long purveyor of the "less than $40 headphones" market and this is unlike anything I've ever heard out of that range of headphones. It's very clean (of course, source pending, if the recording is bad, the sound will be bad) and very even. The instruments have a good "separation". It's very easy to pick out every individual instrument and listen to it. This is not something I could do with my Sennheiser 419s or my Koss PortaPros. The highs are high, the lows are low, and the mids are mid. It's very clean cut and crisp.2. The headphones are very comfortable. The cloth ear-cups and headband pad are soft and feel great. I could wear these forever and be happy with it. The earcup pieces also pivot to help fit on your head more evenly. It's all very nice.3. These can get very loud before any distortion sets in. In fact, I've yet to hear any distortion out of these. I'm sure it can happen if you push it hard enough, but at that point, you're risking an ear injury.4. I like that I can take the cable out and replace it if need be. Good call Sennheiser.5. I like the design. They're not like ridiculously high-end-looking, but they're definitely not eye sores.6. I'm going to dedicate another pro to the sound here. They really do sound incredible. I do want to address the "open ear", "lack of noise reduction", and "sound leakage" everyone's complaining about. These are open ear headphones. You don't buy these for noise reduction and sound containment. That's not what they were built to do. You don't buy a Corvette to pull a trailer. You do not buy these for airplanes, subways, or noise cancellation.Cons1. The 558s are made entirely out of plastic. They feel of high quality and such, but we all know what happens to plastic when accidents happen. I don't worry about them breaking on their own (through normal wear and tear) but I'll definitely be extra cautious if I'm over a hard floor or concrete.2. The mesh that covers the outside holes on the headphones are cloth. I feel like they're gonna rip someday. Not someday soon, but someday.3. These squeeze your head quite a bit when you first open them up. They require a couple of weeks of wear before they loosen up a bit for optimal comfort. They're great out of the box but if your head is sensitive, these may give you a headache on day one. Don't freak out, put them on something that's roughly head-sized and let them sit a day or two to loosen up a bit :)4. The treble is a bit high on these with a flat EQ and the mids are a bit heavy. I used the EQ that comes with the Xonar DG sound card (some cute little Asus app) to turn the treble and mids down a bit and I boosted the bass a little bit. I don't believe these are the fault of the cans but rather my music and set up. Just be warned, you may have to make minor adjustments to hit that sweet spot for you!5. The cable is removable but it isn't a generic cable. It's a 2.5mm with a special twist latch that is specific to Sennheiser cans. That means replacements are a bit harder to find and cost a bit more money. That is particularly troubling considering that this thing comes with a quarter inch jack with a 3.5mm converter. The two together are larger than some brands of cigars. Not great for mobile use.I do want it noted that my cons are nitpicks, not major concerns (hence, no stars off). When you start spending into the 3-4 digits in price for headphones, the little things start to matter more.Look, here's the thing folks. These are far and away the best headphones I've ever owned without question, period.. Obviously if you already have a pair of $120+ headphones, you are taking a side step or maybe even a step down. However, if you're reading this and you have a $5, $25, $50, etc pair of headphones, be aware that you're stepping up to a wholly different music experience and it's one that is intensely subject to personal taste.For instance, if you love heavy, hard-hitting bass, these aren't for you. I didn't list that as a con because it's not a bad thing. These things aren't designed to sound like a pair of Beats by Dre.If you need something with more noise reduction (to shut out the world around you), these are not for you. These were not designed for that purpose.When you start getting up in to the "low end of the high end" headphones and higher, you gotta start doing a little soul searching and figure out what kind of sound you want because up here, it varies a lot between headphones. Once you figure out what you really want, you can find headphones that match that profile.Do your research and enjoy yourself. If you like a nice, even sound where the bass is present, but not thumping and an open, airy sound-stage, these are utterly fantastic at this price point.**Update**I've now had this for roughly 4 months. The sound is still amazing, the fit is still tight enough to be comfy but not so tight as to cause headaches or issues.I have performend the "foam mod" on these, which entails taking the rubber foam from the backs. The soundstage does get a bit wider and the bass gets less edgy, but I prefer the sound like this overall.I have also performed the mod that removes Sennheiser's proprietary lock ring for the headphones. I can now use any 2.5mm cable (I use a 2.5mm-3.5mm adapter with a dual sided 3.5mm headphone cable).
