I was using them along with a Hubsan receiver to power my carbon fiber micro H until my AlienWii and Micro Motor Warehouse motors showed up. They worked great, and I have not put them on yet another frame where they continue to do well.

I've recently gotten into flying quadcopters and found myself very disappointed with the neck strap that came with my $$$ transmitter. I found this here, and I'm very glad I did. It's exactly what I'm looking for. I adjusted the straps to the right length, and then used one of those little "Nite-ize" S-hook carabiners to attach it to the transmitter's mount point. The strap's padding is very soft and non-abrasive, unlike the nylon webbing one that came from the factory. It nicely distributes the weight and is extremely comfortable.

I'm glad I found these here on Amazon. I went to a local hobby shop for these and they wanted $10 for 15 of these along with 5 3-pin connectors, I bought it because I needed it, but when I got home and found these I felt a little ripped off. Oh well, live and learn I guess!

I bought this case as a storage/transport solution for my growing fleet of micro quadcopters. There is enough space in here for my hobby-grade transmitter, a tool kit, my FPV goggles & antenna, 3 quads (a 4" diagonal Hubsan, a 5" diagonal micro H, and a 9.5" diagonal Dromida Ominus), and a ton of spare props, parts, accessories and other junk. The radio I'm using is a Devo 8S and has a folding antenna. If your antenna does not fold you might have some trouble making it fit. The foam inserts work well, but I'm looking for a good supply of gray non-pluckable foam so I can make some real cutouts for all my stuff. The pluck foam works okay but does not hold up well over time (this is true of any of that kind of stuff I think) - the neighbors of the cubes you've already plucked get loosened up from use and will eventually fall out. All that aside, this thing is doing a great job of protecting my little gadgets. I'd say this is every bit as tough as a Pelican case, but at a much better price. I'll probably pick up another one for my new 250-class quad, but since it's so much larger there's no way I'll be able to keep both it and the transmitter in there. That's fine, I'll just carry two cases.

Love this "cover"...  I heard this song several months ago and was hooked. Then I heard the original in the gym recently and exclaimed "oh, I love this song!". I listened a bit more, heard the actual lyrics and said "No, wait, nevermind". Glad I found the better version here :)

A local hobby shop wanted almost $10 for a total of 5 of these connectors along with the associated pins. I spent $13 here on Amazon and got 100 pins, 100 3-pin connectors, and 100 2-pin connectors. They are every bit as good as the ones I got locally, but at a fraction of a fraction of the price. No complaints at all.

A local hobby shop wanted almost $10 for a total of 5 of these connectors along with the associated pins. I spent $13 here on Amazon and got 100 pins, 100 3-pin connectors, and 100 2-pin connectors. They are every bit as good as the ones I got locally, but at a fraction of a fraction of the price. No complaints at all.

These seem to be the real deal. I have ordered from another seller here on Amazon and received what turned out to be some decent looking knockoffs. The knockoffs had an unfortunate tendency to randomly shoot off the motor shafts while in flight, leaving the quad to plummet to the ground. I haven't had that problem yet with these. I have lost two of these, but only during some pretty intense crashes. They did not break, but just came off and I could never relocate them again. These things seem to take a beating and keep going.These give more lift than the standard Hubsan prop, but will cause the motors to heat up noticeably after flight.

These seem to be the real deal. I have ordered from another seller here on Amazon and received what turned out to be some decent looking knockoffs. The knockoffs had an unfortunate tendency to randomly shoot off the motor shafts while in flight, leaving the quad to plummet to the ground. I haven't had that problem yet with these. I have lost two of these, but only during some pretty intense crashes. They did not break, but just came off and I could never relocate them again. These things seem to take a beating and keep going.These give more lift than the standard Hubsan prop, but will cause the motors to heat up noticeably after flight.

These were definitely not genuine Parrot Rolling Spider props. I bought a set of red and a set of white from another seller, and they were genuine. They took a while to arrive and were considerably more expensive, but I think it was worth it. These are imitations and while they look good, have one big drawback. I lost one of the original ones and replaced it with one of these. I was flying my micro H via FPV and suddenly the quad just fell out of the sky. I wandered over to where it crashed and noticed that this replacement prop had come off. I located it and reattached it, and launched back into the sky. I hadn't made it 10 feet before a heard a faint "fzzzp!" noise and saw that exact same prop come flying off yet again. I repeated this several times, and it was the same each time. The prop just would not stay on the motor shaft. So while these look great and are much cheaper than the others, they are pretty much guaranteed to come flying off your motors and leave your quad to fall from whatever height it happens to be at. Not worth saving 3 bucks to have that happen and potentially lose the whole quad.They came in bags very similar to the originals, yet side by side you can see slight molding differences, and differences in color. I guess everything of value these days gets its own knock-off.

I bought these to replace the very dim 3047 reverse bulbs on my wife's 2012 Chevy Silverado. Only one filament is lit for some reason, even though two are available, and the light it produced was very anemic and hard to see by. I did a bit of research and found that these were supposed to be a pretty close replacement.  Turns out, they are a perfect replacement. The reverse sockets on her truck have 3 wires going to them, 1 goes to the 2 ground pins, and another is 12V switched by a sensor on the transmission, and the 3rd wire is... I have no idea what. It seems that it doesn't really matter, and these bulbs light up at full intensity. It's now almost painful to look at them, and the light they provide is very plentiful and makes backing up much, much easier. I'd highly recommend these to any other Silverado owners.

Ahh, my first quadcopter. I've got to say, I'm really darn impressed with this thing. I'll probably write a more extended review later, but figured I should write a short blurb here today.I was introduced to the Ominus by searching for quadcopters on another website (hobby town usa). They didn't have the copters themselves, but they had tons of replacement parts. That caught my attention because most other quads I had seen previously were definitely more "toy grade" than this - if you break it, you might as well toss it, because there are no spare parts available. I went looking for this elsewhere and of course found it here on Amazon for the cheapest price available. I have since bought a Hubsan H107D, but I still enjoy flying this one as well. It's much larger, measuring about 10" diagonally between prop centers, where the Hubsan is about 4".The Ominus has much greater lift, and about 15 minutes of flight time per charge vs 5 minutes on for the Hubsan. I think the Ominus is a bit more stable and forgiving than the Hubsan, at least in Beginner Mode. I like that it has 4 different control modes, all the way up to Expert. I started getting pretty good recently, and switched into Expert Mode. Turns out I'm not that good after all, and I immediately crashed :)  Apparently in Expert Mode, all the onboard gyros and stabilization are turned off, and all of that is left to the pilot. I'm SO not ready for that yet. However, it's nice to know that it's there! I'll get there one day, and it's going to be awesome. This has some really great potential.The flip mode works great, and is a lot of fun to toy around with. Pairing the quad with the Tx is very easy, but setting the control response and calibrating the sensors is a bit trickier (much easier on the Hubsan). Be sure to download and print the manual, and keep it stashed in the box when you take it somewhere. Incidentally, the box it comes in doubles as a decent carry case. When it inevitably starts to wear out, I'll start looking for a more durable case.I started flying in my living room, and then in my backyard. I was "okay" but kept crashing, of course. There are no prop guards for the Ominus, and it's fairly large and those blades pack a wallop. For beginners, I'd definitely recommend going out and finding a large open field to learn in. An unused baseball field is pretty good. My city park has a very large circular field that is bordered by tall trees, and it's pretty much perfect. The trees block the wind, and there are almost no obstacles. This was when I really started learning how to fly, since in the house and even my backyard I was so worked up about avoiding obstacles that I couldn't really concentrate on actually flying and seeing how to control it. After one day flying in a field, I was much better prepared to fly in more close confines. A new pilot will find that panic and overcorrection are their two worst enemies, and flying in an open field mostly removes these. Just make sure to practice when there is no one around that you could crash into.My one concern with the design of this quad is the design of the motor housings. The motors double as landing gear, and have little rubber feet in the bottoms of their housings. The housing is held in by a tiny screw opposite a larger plastic snap-in tab. That's all well and good, but if you hit the ground with a lot of lateral speed, especially moving in a diagonal direction, that tab isn't going to hold. The housing is then held in at an angle by that tiny screw, and the motor's gear won't interface properly with the prop gear. I bent it up pretty good once or twice, and once even had to undo that screw to get everything bent back into shape. Now that I'm flying better, this isn't as much of a concern, but I still wish the motor housings had some sort of brace that ran back to the center of the quad.Now I'm tinkering with the idea of mounting a camera to the Ominus for a bit of aerial photography. I bought the 808 #16 keychain camera, which is the lightest and cheapest of the cameras I've seen so far. It only weighs 19g, but is still apparently enough to throw the flight controller off. I'm sure the Ominus can handle the weight, but I think the balance might be off. The extra weight slung beneath it throws off the reponse quite a bit. When you move the stick back from forward flight, the Ominus overcorrects on its own and actually starts to fly slightly backwards for a second or two. Then the flight controller must decide that something's wrong, and responsiveness goes way down and it's hard to keep in the air. The camera runs off a 3.7v lipo cell just like the Ominus's cell but smaller, so I'm considering stripping it out of the case, removing the battery, and mounting it under the Ominus's canopy. There seems to be enough room in there. I can also probably find somewhere to connect it to power. I'm just not sure yet that I want to carve up the canopy so I can manipulate the controls. The good news is, if I mess it up , there are plenty of replacement parts available.I'm not sure why this never showed up in my initial searches here on Amazon, but I'm so glad I stumbled on it. Get one! You'll love it.  (Oh, look at that, I meant to write a short review, and absolutely failed. D'oh!)

Perfect! I picked these up for my H107D, and they seem to match the originals in almost every way. I have only used about 1 set, and keep the rest in the original baggie, folded up and stored in the carry case right on top of the Tx screen. They fit right in!I like these better than the original because I prefer black/red over white/red. So far they've served me quite well.

I needed a prop protector for my new Hubsan quad, and from other reviews found out that the ones for the H107L wouldn't fit the larger motors on the H107D. The H107C uses the same motors, so this prop guard fits perfectly. It arrived in 2 days via Amazon Prime, while most other prop guards arrive in several weeks from China. I paid $7 instead of $2, but figure it's worth it to protect my favorite new gadget. I'm ordering several replacements but from other sources, since I don't need them immediately.I've been using this for about a week and it's worked great, protecting my props from most crashes. It helped save my quad from a ~75ft fall, but I somehow managed to break slightly it in a much more minor crash in my back yard last night. I'm guessing the first crash weakened it, and I probably mashed it just right to finish the break. It's still mostly functional, as the break is in one of the support arms coming off a motor. I think it will continue to protect the props until my replacements show up from... wherever.

I bought this to allow me to connect the batteries from my Hubsan H107D to the charger that came with my Dromida Ominus. The Hubsan factory charger only pulls about .7 amps on the 5 volt side, while the Dromida charger pulls about 2 amps, so in theory it will charge a single battery in roughly 1/3 the time. The Dromida uses the JST connector while the Hubsan uses a Walkera connector, and this certainly does the trick of adapting one to the other.I'm a little leery of using this cable for its intended purpose, since connecting multiple cells to a charger in parallel isn't necessarily the best way to go about it. It's very easy for the different cells to charge to different voltage levels, and this can lead to damaged cells and outright dangerous conditions like swollen batteries and even fires. You can read other reviews here for other customers' experiences with that. Due to these concerns, I'm only attaching one battery at a time to the Dromida charger. All I can say is that, for my purposes, this cable works perfectly. It was delivered to me here in Georgia within just a few days, which is also nice.

NOTE: Be sure to read the updates I've added at the bottom, there's some pretty important info added.I recently picked up a Hubsan H107D, and found that I only got about 5 minutes per charge. I quickly ordered a 5 pack of extra batteries, which keep me in the air much more often, but were a pain to charge. So, buying this charger seemed like a natural course of action. It seems to charge very well, but the battery connections to the charger aren't very snug. The little lugs that prevent unwanted disconnection on the Hubsan just aren't present here, so the connectors slide in and out a little too easily. Not a big deal, unless you intend to try using this in your car.I used my USB inline voltage/current meter on this and was surprised (and pleased) to see how much current it draws. The factory Hubsan charger initially pulls .7 amps at 5.05V or so, which is about 3.5 watts. This charger initially pulls as much as 2.6 amps, which is about 12.9 watts. I say "initially" in those readings because the charger pulls more current at the start of charging and slowly tapers off until the battery is fully charged. Anyways, 12.9 watts comes out to 3.2 watts per battery, which is almost as much as the factory charger. Of course, all these figures are on the 5 volt side of the charger, so the batteries themselves are seeing lower voltage and higher current. After converting to 3.7 volts and allowing for 85% efficiency (both of which are rough guesstimates), the battery probably sees about .8 amps on the factory charger and .74 amps on this one. Not bad, not bad at all.So that's the nitty gritty for the electronics geeks, the short version is: if you provide this charger with a high power USB adapter (like the Sabrent 50 watt 5-port USB charger I used here), you can charge four batteries in almost the same time it takes to charge a single battery on the factory charger. Gone are the hours spent monitoring the factory charger and swapping out the batteries when they're done.My one reservation about this charger is that it should have used a USB micro B port for power input. The cord it comes with is very thin, and while the barrel connector on the end isn't "proprietary", if this cable gets damaged or lost you'll probably just have to get a whole new charger.All in all, I'm very glad I got this as it makes the process of getting the Hubsan back in the air much, much less tedious.UPDATE: I read a few other reviews, and saw that people were actually able to fully insert the batteries by pushing them in very, very forcefully. I tried it and sure enough it worked, but the grip was so tight I had to use needle nose pliers to get the battery back out. If you do this, do NOT just pull on the wires - you will ruin your battery and/or charger. I ended up prying the case open and trimming the retention bumps on each charger port with a hobby knife. Reassembly was a little tricky because the "ports" are really just a connector on the end of a 1" set of wires that's all twisted up until they fit, and each connector fits in its own little slot in the top half of the case. You have to make sure the wires don't get pinched during reassembly because you really, REALLY don't want a short circuit. There is no glue, the case halves stay together fairly well on their own due to the post/hole design. Now the batteries snap in nicely, stay there the whole time, and can be removed with a reasonable amount of force. I can now use this in the car while driving without having to worry about the connectors sliding apart. I still wish this used a micro USB port rather than the barrel connector, but oh well!UPDATE 2: I started noticing that my flight times were substantially reduced from what I originally was getting from my batteries. Some of the flights were down to as low as 2 minutes. It turns out that this charger was cutting off charging a little too early and the cells weren't getting full. I'm still using it because it does boost overall charging speed of my 6 batteries, but I'm having to switch up the routine a little. I'm now charging 4 at a time on this charger but now when it cuts off I'm swapping the batteries one at a time back to the factory Hubsan charger to top them off. Overall, it's still a lot quicker than charging all 6 batteries one at a time on the factory charger, but it's a bit more of a hassle than it would otherwise be. For safety reasons it's better to under charge LiPo's than over charge them, but there is still such a thing as too little. Knocking the rating down to 4 stars :(

Seems very well constructed. This "hybrid" jack feels like it weighs a TON, I'd hate to see what the full steel construction ones feel like at twice the weight. The shipping box it came in was damaged during trasit, but the jack and all its accessories were unharmed and I just had to clean the styrofoam shrapnel off everything. I toyed around with lifting my old 1983 Supra, and it moved it around like it was hardly there. A vast improvement over my 15+ year old floor jack.

My wife uses this to plug her iPod 4 into the USB port on her 2012 Chevy Silverado's dash. She puts the iPod in a small cubby nearby, and the original 3 foot cord was getting in the way. With this cable, she can put the iPod in the cubby without a dangling cord, and still be able to pull it away when necessary to skip tracks. Perfect!
A nice addition to the Greenfield kickstand I just installed. I wish it had come with the stand, but it was only a few bucks more and arrived within a few days.
They stick great so far and haven't given me any problems. I used these to mount 2 cellphone cradles in the dash cubby below my car's radio. They haven't budged!

Got it for $20 in 2015. The locks are made with good rivets. It's all stainless steel and holds its form. It is thin and lightweight. It is not water tight. It is however tight enough for any kind of solid. A considerable amount of food can be packed into this. If you go with nutrient dense things like nuts, beans, grains etc, it is more than enough for me, a 200lb man. Being stainless steel it doesn't tarnish, and it can be cleaned with a copper scouring pad easily. One downside is cleaning involves 3 separate containers as opposed to one single container, but that is the price to pay to have separate compartments!

Good stainless steel. Mirror finish. But it is huge at 13" definitely not a dinner plate unless you are truly preparing a dining "experience" with sauce drizzles and garnish artfully arranged around the rim of the plate!  It is a great plate though. The one thing I would change is the steel not be rolled at the edge but rather a solid lip so food does not get caught there, but that would certainly place this at a substantially higher price point. It's a pretty solid plate though, you could probably cook an 8" pizza on it (seriously).

These are good quality and fresh. They are able to "sprout." They have a creamy texture and are good in many recipes, particularly vegan/vegetarian dips, sauces, cheeses, and spreads make use of raw cashews. They are 99% whole just as pictured. For freshness it is best to put them in a large glass or steel jar.Hope that helps

They are only a small percentage of wool, but they are thick. In -20 degree weather my feet got a tad nippy in waterproof boots, but they are far superior to standard socks, the equivalent of a double layer at least I would say. They are well put together and have a small amount of padding. They are much too warm during hotter 40degree days leaving feet quite sweaty. Overall they are a fantastic addition to my wardrobe and I would recommend them for the price, quality of build, and materials. They are not itchy, but rather soft. Made in China.Hope that helps.

Solid rubber is good because it has a high tackiness and flexibility. It also holds up to harsh cleaners well as you will periodically want to scrub this for any mold despite overall resistance to mold, anywhere there is a lot of moisture trapped for extended periods carries the risk. This makes me feel a lot safe with my 5yr old daughter taking showers as soap scum can get quite slippery and potentially deadly as if you hit your head hard on the bathtub, cast iron is not forgiving. It is also soft and comfortable on the feet.

These work like they are supposed to, very easily pulling plastic off a cut wire. The one complaint is there no auto-adjust for the initial cut, which most wire strippers have. It is good for pulling once the plastic is cut, but there is just a bulk wire shop, and a sheath puller, so you can't actually strip a wire with just this tool, which is stupid considering how bulky and expensive it is, this feature could have easily been included to some degree. In my opinion, a tiny $5 channel lock does just as well of a job. It's just like those auto-octagonal wrenches, they are okay in specific situations. This tool is great for pulling a big hunk of sheathing off or pulling sheathing that would otherwise risk pulling the wire out such as thin gauges.
Wore these today in minus-20F weather. They helped considerably under thin neoprene (scuba-style) gloves I was good for an hour or so before my fingers felt discomfort.

Mirror polish, what is not to love. It was either this one or the red one to be like the movie "Office Space." But I'm happy with the chrome, it looks very retro. It is heavy. I can tell the plating is solid, and that after many years of use a light polish will get it looking like new. I expect this to last many decades. The spring loader is quite strong. It is made just as solid as the ones I have from the 70s. The staple assist models of other brands that can go through 70 sheets in my experience misfire significantly more than this, and I do dozens of staples daily in my paper pushing county gov. job. When in doubt go with ol' trusty! There is a 747 in every office for a reason!

These are not below freezing all day gloves, but I have to measure houses in snow and rain as an appraiser, and these keep my hands dry and warm until I get back in the car. They are also good commuter gloves as you can easily reach your hand in your pocket for keys. If only they were also touch-screen capable!

I grew my own peppermint for a long time. I had a huge patch of it that grew like a weed. I would dry it out and make tea and mint juleps. This pouch is great quality and looked and tasted exactly like my own dried just a day ago mint. Couldn't be happier. It is likely organic as mint has very few pests due to the volatile oils. Not even grasshoppers would touch my mint. My pregnant wife says it soothes her stomach during morning sickness.

Great tasting coffee. Mine was definitely as fresh as I would get in any grocery. It has a great flavor. I prefer somewhat mellower coffees as super dark acidic coffees upset my stomach. This coffee is an easy drink for me, making my necessary caffeine intake pleasurable instead of a difficult chore with a post-consumption regret as queasiness sets in. Maybe it's also because this coffee is not tainted by pesticides? Coffee is one of the more pesticide products, and non-organic coffee is directly responsible for the destruction of the rain forest and countless species and habitat. I will likely purchase this brand again.

I got these for my wife to use instead of paper towels to save money, and be easier on the environment. They are as absorbent as a paper towel, but they can go through the wash many times before becoming unusable. So you can use them once, like a paper towel, with all of its convenience and sanitations, then put them in the wash where they consume almost no space. They are also better at scrubbing since they do not fall apart. Great purchase.

Thick, warm, can be pulled over mouth & nose if desired. Versatile. This is better than a baklava or scarf in outdoor professional and work situations as it is discrete and will blend in with most dark jackets. Lots of body heat is lost through the neck, nearly as much as through the head. I always wear this if I have to work outside below 20.

Pretty decent, easily pulls over the whole head. The knitting is good with no imperfections and is nice and stretchy. However it is thin for my taste as the main reason for this type of headgear is extreme cold. It is substantially thinner than most entry-level stocking caps. It is essential to wear an additional cap over this if you are at 20 or below for an extended period in my opinion. But it does a very good job of covering areas most caps don't, and it is thin enough to wear additional gear over it. So just keep all that in mind. It is good quality, and if combined with a couple other pieces of gear you're set. It is easy to pull down below your nose if desired and glasses will not fog up when driving etc. A huge plus, as most thick neck warmers if pulled up will force vapor up and cloud glasses. I use it for commuting in sub zero temps, then take it off before going into the building so I don't shock my colleagues.

Excellent door sweep. Solid rubber. PVD coated aluminum. Aluminum does not rust. Rubber is highly resistant to sun, weather, grit etc. This effectively stops drafts. Even if your floor is not level it will drastically reduce drafts. It looks good in residential application, not out of place at all facing inside the house. It is easy to cut with a hand-hacksaw.. Stanley has a decent 12" one on amazon for $5, which you will likely need to size it for your door.Other tools helpful to have during installation: tape measure, black sharpie to mark cut, drill for pilot holes, and screwdriver.Brush-sweeps are preferred by some when the floor is very unlevel as it will accommodate a bow in the floor better. My floors are quite uneven but this works excellently and will last many years, and has nice clean lines and does not trap grit. Although if you are not careful the rubber can scrape a pebble against a wood floor. The reason I got this is I know because of the materials, rubber and aluminum it will stay looking like new.

Great price at about $6 in 2014. The frame is all steel. The handle is a plastic mold around the metal frame. The tension screw is plastic which appears to be the only possible weak point but seems solid when used and gets the blade nice and tight with minimal effort, I think it is also molded around a metal core from the feel of it. I got this to cut a handful of aluminum thresholds and door sweeps to size and it made the job go fast and cut cleanly through thick aluminum. I didn't want my super sawzall bouncing all over marring the aluminum =)

This belt is thick, rugged heavy duty nylon. It is definitely not for standard "civilian" pants as 2.25" will not fit most belt loops (it would be too bulky anyway). I bought this initially to potentially use with my kilt since kilts have wide belt loops, but it is also a very thick belt with thick padding, and is quite stiff and inflexible making casual wear of this unpleasant. However I have repurposed it in house remodeling as I can easily hang pouches of nails, hammers, and drill holsters from this belt, not weaving it through belt loops but just clicking it around my waist.

I live at 8,000ft in the mountains where it can get to -40. So I have a lot of thermal base-layers. This is clearly a step above your standard low-end thermals. They are thicker, softer, with a more substantial elastic waistband that is soft, and fit better with nice leg room on my 6'2" frame (I bought large). 60% cotton 40% polyester. All the sewing is double stitched. When it comes time for me to buy more thermals, this is going to be my go-to for sure.

They are truly double walled stainless steel. The outside is a mirror finish while the inside is finely brushed. They are light weight standard sized cups. They are great to give to the kids as they can be dropped on concrete. For that reason it is also a great camping or travel mug. The double wall does no do a whole lot to retain heat as the top surface area lets off quite a bit regardless, but it keeps the outside of the mug a normal temp if there are boiling liquids inside.

These have a nice heft to them and are solid. There is no hollowed out area like some handle pulls have. They have a nice finish, and are easy to clean. They look exactly as pictured. They measure three inches from screw-center to screw-center, which is a standard pull-size comfortable to most hands in standard-sized cabinetry.

This is quite large, unless cooking for a large family with a mortar as your only tool I can't see needing anything much larger. It fits over 4 large avocados. The stone is nice and rough for things like flowers and small seeds, which this can grind to a fine dust. So it is versatile and large. It handles small quantities as easily as large. Seasoning mortars is a simple process that does not require and great skill, you basically just rinse it, let it dry, grind up some brown rice, and dump it out, and done. You can grind in peppercorns, chili pods or other spices if desired to "season" the stone itself.One possible issue with some is the bottom is rough. On a fine surface this could scratch. Same with the sides. Typically it is good traction. However if you don't like it rough you can paint the bottom with epoxy paint/resin and lightly sand it for an easy glossy finish. The ones with polished sides are more aesthetically appealing in my opinion, so if you are really into the aesthetics of your kitchen, you may opt for a glossy outside as polished granite is quite beautiful. Those tended to be smaller and more expensive.The natural stone of this mortar is also appealing and unobtrusive and would likely work for many rustic themed kitchens. It is a nice piece to display next to dark woods, and green plants =)  It is granite, so unless you drop it from a great height onto concrete it should last for hundreds or thousands of years, it is what the Rocky mountains are made of after all =)  Gets you more in touch with your food, the texture, the smells releasing. It is a slower and more gentler method to grind food than a blender or food processer. High speed commercial blenders warm foods which can oxidize your super-foods. It is fun to experiment with various foods and preparation. It may not seem like much of a difference in mindstate, but just not hearing a whirring blender that you have to shout over, or the annoying rattle of a coffee grinder, the stone is much earthier.It's just a mortar!

I saw the album on youtube, and wanted to listen to a higher quality version without worrying about having a connection to listen in the place of the journey. If you like Shpongle, FSOL, Yggdrasil, Ott, this wont disappoint space travelers. My favorite album of theirs so far, very chill too.

Aluminum is light weight and it is the next best conductor next to copper, so it heats up fast and stays hot easy. Aluminum is however much cheaper than copper, and much lighter, which makes it great for over camp fires. The aluminum is thick and I have zero worries of this pan getting dinged. It is really more of a stovetop pan that will heat up really fast. Good for saut veggies or searing. Aluminum does not oxidize in a true sense but it can develop a whitish patina that some consider unattractive because it looks like calcium deposit. It is easily cleaned by scrubbing with an abrasive.

I was hesitant on these because I read reviews of other products like this not working. These work flawlessly on my Samsung galaxy s3. It is great because first thing in the morning on my commute listening to audio books, I don't have to fumble with gloves outside. They really do work. The material appears like it will hold up for many years of daily commuter use in this way. When it is in the negatives I put on wool cut-off finger gloves as an outer layer so I can still use the digital touch screen fingers. I wish I could find out where to get some of these material so I could sew it onto all of my gloves lol.For their thinness they are tightly knit, well made gloves.

Best belt I have ever owned. The nylon is soft, and extremely pliable, almost silken. This is not a stiff, military paracord-type nylon, or one of those coarse cotton/hemp weaves. This belt is the most comfortable belt I've ever worn. The buckle is awesome, never comes undone, and can be attached to other web belts. Extremely happy with this purchase. I am a 36" waist, ordered a 36" belt, and there is about 2 inches extended through my first belt loop, so the fit is also very good, although they say you can custom-adjust it.

Being so high in vitamin C I was thinking this would be somewhat tart, like a citrusy or berry flavor. The flavor is much closer to unsweetened tamarind, somewhat bitter with a bit of a tart & only slightly fruity kick in a powerful flavor that is not unpleasant, but not as versatile as say, orange juice. It's good to add to smoothies in measured amounts as an additive for a broad spectrum of vitamin, as opposed to using as a base-flavor.The reason this is better than vitamin C is it contains a more complete spectrum of antioxidants and bioflavonoids not present in processed vitamin C, like the difference between white flower and wild rice, which is more complete of a food? Some research has been done showing citrus with complete spectrums are superior to straight ascorbic acid, and ascorbic acid can actually have a leeching effect as it scavenges from other antioxidants to complete a spectrum. Lots of research out there on vitamin C, so I will just add to the chorus of "whole food is better."When in doubt on the effectiveness of a vitamin, but you feel like your body needs it, going to the whole food seems to be the wisest long-term choice to me.Hope that helps.

Got a pair of these awhile ago and they held up as good as $90 pairs, and with audio books there is no loss of enjoyment while in a noisy commute, why beat up a $90 pair of buds when sound quality isn't realized anyway? So when I saw these on sale for $6.50 during cyber Monday I didn't hesitate to pick up a second pair for my wife. The sound quality is fine with voice and high tones. With music you obviously loose a lot of bass. The noise reduction works via the silicon molding to the ear canal, and it aids in keeping the buds in place during drives.

This is pretty decent matcha. You can use is straight out of the box just mixing it into water as it already has the "ideal" amount of sweetener for a "sweet matcha" taste. The downside is if you want a richer, fuller matcha flavor it is not really attainable as there is quite a bit of sweetener in this. I prefer a stronger matcha as I drink it primarily for the health benefits, so I tend to go for the straight powdered tea without anything mixed in. However with straight matcha it is also easy to make it too strong and possibly bitter. So this is a nice easy way to enjoy matcha with less room for error. I would highly recommend this if this is your first time trying to make your own matcha.Hope that helps.

Works awesome for hair dye. I dye my wife's hair who I would call a light brown-blonde. It turns her hair a nice natural reddish hue with very good color saturation. She was asked by her professional hair stylist who colors her hair, with compliments following. My dad, not knowing I had done the coloring, and is particular with women's hair color, also spontaneously commented on the coloring, asking what/how she did it. The reason Henna is so spectacular is because it is a natural product, surprise it gives effortless natural color with natural gradations and a deep natural resonance. Artificial colors are flat, artificial, lifeless. To a sensitive eye, the difference between a natural color and a fake color is readily apparent. This is also completely non-toxic. It smells quite good in my opinion, like wheat grass juice with strong grassy notes.I am not an expert hair dyer. I undertook this with my wife because I am cheap, and doing it for her myself turned out to be enjoyable with easy and excellent results. My formula is basically to mix some vinegar into the powder until it is a very thick mush. Then I pour boiling water into it until it flows similar to the consistency of somewhere between pudding and heavy creamer.I also have added indigo (for black shade), crushed hibiscus (bright red), and clove (deep red/maroon).Price-wise, I get many more uses out of this on my wife's hair than a standard kit.The one con is there can be little bits of clumps/granules, and/or plant matter, especially when adding hibiscus or clove, but it washes out and does not effect the end-color or texture of the hair negatively.One great plus, it is a natural conditioner that leaves hair SILKY smooth for days. I believe it is due to the high levels of anti-oxidants in greens. In contrast artificial color tends to weaken hair, making it more brittle.Hope that helps.

These worked with organic vapor staining and varnishing in an enclosed 10x10 room for 30 minutes with no noticeable odor. They also worked in a house over a 30minute period, varnishing the entire house in an enclosed state, with no noticeable odor, while insects around me were dying (literally) from the fumes. I also wear eye protection as fumes can irritate any mucous membranes. I try to minimize exposure, even with these. If fumes/chemicals are greater than oxygen levels in certain situations these may not be sufficient. For a typical floor refinishing of a residence these are perfect, and an absolute safety necessity as organic vapors cause almost immediate brain damage even in low levels.The value pack was a great value when I got them and after using them I consider them comparable in quality to the 3M disposable masks, from what I can tell with my own senses (smell/taste = clean while in use). These also work great for insulating as the cartridges block fiberglass insulation particulates easily.Hope that helps.

I have used dozens of tarps, some the standard blue ones from hardware stores, others cheap ones, from canvas to vinyl.I live in an area at 8,000ft elevation near a ski-hill where it can snow multiple feet in a short time. This resists all snow loads in my application (which is basically just a cover for outdoor furniture)Pros:Much thicker than your standard tarp (obvious increase in durability)WaterproofHeavy - does not blow away as easily in high wind!This tarp has more brass (no rust) grommets than usual, so you can tie it down more completely.Cons:If you are moving large amounts of soil/gravel with this over concrete or another abrasive surface, vinyl does not hold up over time under those conditions, but this will still be superior to other tarps in that regard so it is not really a con for this tarp, but just all tarps in general.Neutral:Because it is so heavy duty (a plus) it also is difficult to fold or bend. This can be good or bad depending on your situation. Canvas is much more flexible while retaining durability but is not waterproof and is more porous and therefore more difficult to clean!Overview:This actually is a quite noticeably thicker material, heavier duty, and overall just heavier. I have no doubt this will hold up for many years if not decades to come. I do not regret the added expense one bit, it was worth every penny. If you are going to be leaving it out in the weather for years, it is worth the investment.Hope that helps.

Call me forgetful, but I left the lid on accidentally for a few minutes and it melted into the pot ruining the unit. Should have had a metal or glass lid with plastic handle for an extra dollar. My next fryer I get will not have melting components. Poorly thought out fryer materials.That said, it was easy to clean the residue out and I'll get a different lid and keep using it. It brings oils to heat great. I use coconut oil and sometimes mix it with canola. Works great. Canola foams though.I wish the interior was not teflon, but it makes it easy to clean as oil does not stick to it. Cleaning vinegar with a paper towl works well.One great feature is the safety cord which should be a legal requirement for appliances like these. In addition to being forgetful, leaving the lid on during use, I am also rushed in the kitchen often, and I have yanked it out multiple times and instead of spilling boiling oil on myself the cord just flips off.Overall, it is a great fyer, if you don't mind teflon, and can remember the plastic lid, it would be a 5-star fryer for you!

Bulova makes auto watches with swiss and japan movements. Their swiss ones are superior, and that is what this one is. It is equal in quality to other solely swiss makers in the mid-luxury range. The movement is a 25 jewel 26,800 vph high beat watch. The rotor spins on ball-bearings. The movement is very dependable. It would be nice if the crown was screw down. The dial is nice with multiple textures and roman numerals. Solid stainless steel case and band. Butterfly clasp. Fixed bezel. Sweeping second hand. Non-hacking. Pretty standard good quality, good price. Very happy.

Stuhrling watches have a few lines. They have a quartz line swiss made, then a quartz line japan made. They have a mechanical line swiss made, and a mechanical line china made, and a mechanical line japan made.Their swiss lines are the best, with the best movements, that are the most durable and reliable. The cases, and dials are all similar quality in my opinion. Their leather bands are always laminated leather (good quality). Their metal is always shiney, and pure with zero imperfections. Their mechanical watches made in China are notoriously unreliable, and thankfully this is not one.This watch is almost exactly as pictured. Their cases are similar in quality to invicta, seiko, and android. This case/dial/crown has a bit more ornamentation and bling than most watches in this price-range.Hope that helps.

Sage is a volatile oil. If you have ever used peppermint essence, bergamot, oregano, or tea tree oil, it is similar to that family of smells. It is earthy and minty if I had to pick two words. Now is a quality maker of essential oils, and they are predictable and uniform every time I buy them.. having bought basically a shelf-full to make my own natural colognes and aroma therapies.Modern medicine shows sage is a potent antioxidant, both the oil, and whole herb. It can be used to treat a variety of disorders such as candida overgrowth, colds, sore throats, but dilute it properly with other oils or you can give your sensitive mucus membranes a chemical burn (although not an artificial chemical). This is food grade essential oil that can be used for consumption.If you have belief in traditional herbology lore, sage is purifying of evil spirits etc, and sage rubs are made to smoke out negative energies.Sage goes good with Bergamot in cologne, also Frankincense.Hope that helps!

I have a few different brands of derma rollers, including the one from derma logi that is over twice as expensive. The main difference is in the width of the needles. Personally, I'd prefer to spend an extra $2 to get one with finer needles, not length of the needle but the needles "sharpness."I decided to go for it despite questionable reviews and bought all three lengths because the price at $7.99 was well below any other brand.They all came in a plastic box sealed in cellophane. I cleaned it with alcohol before use anyway.Compared to derma logi ($15-$20), and SGF limited ($10-$16), for the price, I got what I expected. This derma roller is actually quite decent. I can't honestly say that I can tell a huge difference (although there is a difference). The tips, on use are less honed and take quite a bit more pressure, and is slightly more painful to use. On side-by-side visual inspection, the needles of this brand are around twice as thick (maybe a bit less), which is what makes it slightly more painful, and cheaper to produce.You do feel discomfort/pain using any derma roller. I'm a guy with high pain tolerance, and if you are using it on sensitive areas such as neck, cheek, around eyes, etc, you will definitely feel some degree pain without question both during and after use. They can also make your face quite red, and sensitive to direct full-sun.That said, this derma roller, and all others will stimulate collagen production, and decrease lines visible, age spots, scars, large pores, reduce acne etc. One of my favorite uses is if I notice a pimple, if you roll a derma roller over it a few times it will break it up and release it without causing a scab.I am happy with this purchase. It is more painful to use that my more expensive derma rollers, but for 1/2 the cost you are getting what you pay for.The 0.5mm size is good for around eyes and smile lines. The 1mm is a good general length to get if you are getting only one size as it can still be used in sensitive areas, just a bit more gently. The 1.5mm is quite long and would be good for occasional deep tissue stimulation where there is thicker skin, such as the back.Hope that helps.

Spice Island, McCormick, Morton, etc all make good spices in my opinion. This is just as good as any other brand. Your main concern will be keeping this amount of spice fresh if you don't use it fast enough. A good way to do this is small snap-shut Tupperware containers or used empty glass jars.Curry, if you didn't know, is a spice used in Indian cooking. You likely know that if you are buying this quantity. But it is earthy and spicy, and can be overpowering if you use too much, like any spice. Some of my favorite uses of curry are with bean recipes and vegetable recipes. Such as kidney and garbanzo beans. And broccoli, cauliflower, and spinach.Plain yogurt adds a nice creaminess to many curry recipes. It's not hard to invent your own recipes.Hope that helps.

This is vinyl lined so salt wont corrode the copper. The copper is solid and I don't see this being dented easily. The crank is fastened with a nice sized bolt that wont strip. The coarseness of the grain is adjusted with a nice sized screw that wont strip. This is one of the best salt ginders I've seen, although I wish they would have used glass instead of vinyl as a barrier between the salt and copper. The actual grinding mechanism is tool steel against vinyl.All in all a great grinder, although I think their pepper grinders are more "perfect." I would give this 4.5 stars if I could. I suppose vinyl doesn't really react with salt so it's not like you're going to be affected by plastic, it's just not my preference.Hope that helps.

This grinder is solid brass with solid tool steel innards (high quality steel that holds up well under wear & tear). There is no plastic, no glass, no ceramic. The brass is thick, over 2mm and I do not see it ever getting dented or crushed. It is a hefty grinder to hold.The crank is great and is attached by a nice bolt that will never strip.The coarseness of the grind is adjusted by a large screw which will also never strip.I cannot think of a single thing I would change about this grinder.Don't use salt with this as salt will corrode brass. This same company makes vinyl lined grinders for salt.Hope that helps.

I've made quite a few watch boxes, and owned various jewelry armoires, including antique solid wood ones, so that will be my point of reference.This is very thick, heavy, and durably material. When you knock on it, it feels as harder and heftier than solid oak. The box is literally made of super strong woven carbon fiber material, which is also used in watches themselves as dials and bracelet links, so it's a great material. It doesn't expand, contract, rot, or scuff very easily. I think it's a great material that should hold up for decades. All the components of the box fit together nicely and feel durable. It's almost exactly as pictured. The carbon fiber gives the box a pleasing texture that is beyond just painted or enameled wood. In my opinion this is superior in nearly every way to a wood box.Hope that helps.

I was worried at first because the tops are silicone. The silicone tops work great though. They stay in place, the ball rolls easily, and the top screws on tightly so there is not much loss of oil wish is your main concern with these. The fancy swirl is nice. I buy my own essential oils then make natural fragrances with them in these bottles and it's already saved money (when compared to buying pre-made natural essential oil fragrances).Hope that helps.

I have lots of different aromatic essential oils including peppermint, oregano, lemon, frankincense, myrrh, patchouli, sage, cedar, etc, and I would rank this with some of the stronger smelling oils that has the potential to overpower others. 25 drops of this to 50 drops of frankincense and 25 drops of peppermint and the cinnamon will overpower it. It's best to follow a recipe. Cassia cinnamon is Chinese cinnamon, not the pricier Sigon variety, which are actually different plants, and while sigon has a superior flavor, taste, and health benefits, as a smell I can't tell the difference. So as an essential oil it is great!Hope that helps.

Ebel is up there is quality with any other luxury brand. Rotor that spins like a top. Crown that winds like a toothpick in hot butter. Pushers that have a definite click. Stainless steel case. Sapphire crystal. Screwdown back. 3D textured dial including indices. 3-tone hands. 3-tone dial. Swiss movement obviously. Valjoux 7750 base-plate modified to Ebel specs, I'm not sure if they modify a valjoux 7750 in-house or make the whole thing to spec but Ebel has most of their own calibers. Ebel was sold to movado in 2004. If you go to ebel's site they no longer have any automatic chronographs and this was one of their last ones made to date. Possibly a collectors item.Hope that helps.

You could probably fit 4 of these on a small burner top. So this is not the most efficient way to heat water, but it is one of the most efficient ways to make a small portion of expresso. It is built like a tank. It will never need to be replaced, ever. Everything is metal except the handle and a single silicone gasket. It is 3 pieces.Hope that helps

For smaller gauge wire it is okay, like 22-16, but much beyond that wont work. And with most metals of that gauge pliers are just as easy and inexpensive. This is also not hardened metal like stainless steel or even steel. I think it is aluminum, a softer metal. It's inexpensive, but in my opinion, $5 is steep for something this size and material. I see this as great for someone who has arthritis. Maybe for that person it would get 5 stars or at least be worth a try.Hope that helps.

Carbide is a hard but brittle metal. It stays sharp longer than high speed stainless steel, and is typically used for the highest quality router bits for that reason. This works great as what its advertised for. The larger teeth remove material rather quickly, yet it is a very honed tip. It holds up quite a long time if you don't use it for the right job such as shaving off a touch rather than carving with it.Hope that helps.

Great uniformity of thickness. Great deepness of colors. Great strength. Everything that you'd expect. Getting 3 colors in one box lets you do color-patterns from the get-go, which also makes it easier for beginners to do more complex weaves successfully, although errors will show up more too. Hope that helps.

Swiss movement. Mineral glass. Stainless steel case and crown. Solid leather band without padding (nice). Nice solid stainless clasp. Textured dial. Second hand w/ date function.The only thing I wish they would have done differently is the roman numerals are just printed on the dial, I wish they were 3D/textured like the dial center, I mean as long as the dial is being stamped, but the dial is still nice! Many at this price point don't even bother with a textured dial.Great for the price point.Hope that helps.

This are soft aluminum so they are easy to work with, easy to shape, easy to open, easy to close. The only downside of that is #1 they will slightly tarnish over time and #2 will pull apart easier than say pure stainless steel, brass, or copper.I like them and they are fun to work with, happy with the purchase.You want to start off with a 5-6" bent nose pliers and a snap ring pliers for these I would say. And check out some weave patterns on the internet or buy a book on the subject so you aren't just slapping rings together =)Hope that helps, easy cheap hobby to start!

I was hoping for a uniform thread that I could possibly braid without too much trouble, and that's what I got. It is basically like a cord, very strong, very durable, soft enough to wear around the neck or wrist, and it was cheap. I'm going to start making a necklace right now!Hope that helps.

The print quality is pretty bad on this. The image is blurry. The red is not natural looking. It is basically like a large poster you would find at walmart for a pop star, only the quality is significantly worse. Mine did not appear to be vinyl coated. I was expecting it to have some kind of laminate coating. It was just semi-gloss poster paper, and since I bought mine open box via amazon warehouse deals it was also very crinkled, not that I counted that it my rating. The photo in the item description is accurate, you can notice how it is blurry even in a tiny picture, well life-size it is very blurry. So if you are expecting a blurry picture on standard poster paper, and really like marylin, they you might be happy =)Hope that helps...

This is a great item. It's a lot easier than rolling. When tortillas are rolled, if you are doing a lot they tend to wrap around the roller which is a pain. With this that isn't an issue. Neither is a tortilla being too thick in the middle. You need almost no skill to use this, that is why it is awesome. And if you lightly grease this the tortilla wont stick. The curing of the cast iron, since you won't be cooking with this, is simply to keep it from rusting.Cast iron is a great material. It is heavy and solid. It wont break. I found some antique cast iron skillets buried in one of my back yards. They had some surface rust, but after re-seasoning them, they are like new. So someone even with the intention of destroying them, could not lol! So it's a really durable material!

I got the 220V version, wtf amazon. Worked great once I got the transformer. This is a great jewler's tool because you can make finer movements with your finger-tips not having to hold the weight of a motor. There are tons of attachments you can get and most of the parts are compatible with Foredom. 4A in 220V is equivalent to 8A in USA 110V, so my model was 4A, being that I got the wrong one for some reason, which is more of amazons fault. The foot pedal is solid cheap plastic, and is also the most likely part to break. Luckily pedal switches are easy to find and universalized.Hope that helps.

Made in the USA.Heats up fast due to aluminum core. There are two types of electrical wire, copper which is the best and aluminum which is second best. Aluminum is right behind copper in terms of conductivity. We all know how expensive solid copper and copper core pots are. Aluminum, for cooking food, is really just as good in my opinion.The pan itself is very thick, including the edges. When you are cooking, you can easily give yourself a burn if you hit the edge with your hand. I was used to less expensive value-brand pots, and thin lips of just stainless steel don't conduct heat well. I wasn't used to the top lip being able to burn me. Also if you use metal cooking tools, and rest them against the lip, it will conduct heat into them. And if you rest plastic against the lip, it can melt it. To me, this is the mark of a truly good pot.The lid is the same level of quality. It fits tightly, creating a good seal that traps steam for dishes such as sunny-side-up eggs where the tops turn white via steam. The lid will also get hot and conduct heat. But the handle will not get hot.There are zero rivets or bent over metal to collect dirt or old food grime. The lip is a solid piece of metal.The bottom of the pan is perfectly flat, so it rests perfectly on my glass-top oven. Cheaper pans will have a slight curve and do not heat up well at all.Storing the pan, you can flip the lid upside-down and place a pot on top of it!This pan has a lot of great features and it's very high quality. Going from a value-brand to this has been great and I can't believe I didn't spend a bit of money sooner. Cooking with this has been a joy! Food cooks faster and more evenly too. And I don't have to turn the dial up as high to cook food. I used to have to cook food on high. Now that will burn food that it used to just barely get. Even med-low can burn foods I used to have to have on high. It took a bit of getting used to actually being able to cook foods. So I figure I must be saving some money on energy too.Hope that helps!

This is solid metal and is very stable. Note however that the main pillar is two sheets of parallel metal, it is not a boxed-in pillar, which you cannot easily see from the picture. This is a great lamp regardless though. The hammered look makes the lamp appear unique, and if it is truly hand forged, then to a degree it actually is.The shade seems somewhat on the large side, and a square share would better fit the overall geometry of the lamp, but shades are easy to replace.Hope that helps.

I've owned about 6 different neck-sleeping products including cervical pillows by other brands in the $20-$80 range. The curved memory foam pillows from walmart suck for cervical traction because the indent/curve is not nearly deep enough. An $80 one I had didn't last long because it was not densely packed enough so it became to compressed to be much use. Dog-bone pillows are pretty useful, but having nothing on the back of the head is too much of an indent, so it can be used for short periods of time but not all night long.This is hands down the best pillow I've ever used for my neck problem. I am a side sleeper but I like to start out on my back and wake up on my back. When I bought this I didn't realize it was designed for side-sleepers. I just thought dang, it's like this is designed to also be good for my side! If you have neck problems, with a standard cervical pillow if you lay in the middle of the pillow, it is not good for your neck, and the edges are too poofy with no contour.This pillow is perfect for those with neck problems who sleep on both their back and side. Surely I'm not the only one.When I use this pillow I have zero neck problems. If I go without it my chronic condition returns (pulled a disk out of my neck doing a deep arm stretch too early in the morning, which permanently loosened my ligaments).Hope that helps!

These do not filter everything. They filter only things that cause diarrhea and disease. They don't filter out heavy metals, radiation, salt (ocean water), fluoride etc. In a life-threatening situation where you have little access to water save dirty pools, this could save your life. Dirty pools in warm areas are rich in microbe life. If you drink from them the effects of diarrhea and vomiting are worse off than simply going without water. They are very light weight. They have no expiration date. They take up little space, less than the space required for a water bottle. If you are hiking/backpacking in an area where there is a possibility of getting lost, carrying one of these is a good idea.Hope that helps!

I have a few AKG audio products. They are all phenomenal. This is a top of the line, light weight, microphone you wear around your ear. The audio pickup is fantastic with no distortion. When giving a presentation you want something that blends in while not sacrificing audio quality. The thin skin-tone accomplishes this along side AKG's superior audio engineering. If you want the best and get paid the big bucks for speeches where you circulate the audience, don't hesitate spending something extra that can make or break a performance.Hope that helps.

This is a great kit because everything you need is included. It's a great space saver. If your kitchen is anything like mine space is at a premium. This also puts frequently used pots and pans at your finger tips. Ever try tugging a pan out that is stacked on the bottom of some pots and it's just a terrible experience? Well, no more situations like that with this, all your favorite pans are right in front of you. I should have gotten one a lot time ago. People will spend $400 on a kitchen cabinet, and they aren't exactly the most convenient way of storing pots and pans.I just screwed it into 2x4's with a stud finder. Honestly if your studs aren't 16 inches on center it doesn't matter, you just add a couple cross members and screw those into where you do have studs and screw the rack into that. A minor extra step that adds about $2 to the cost, and you need a drill anyway. Make sure to put pilot holes in the rack itself so you don't split the wood.Hope that helps.

Melamine, practically speaking is a type of plastic used in the commercial food industry. It is very durable, reusable, and easy to clean. However it will not stun your guests the way a glazed earthenware plate will. It is good for picnics, barbeques, and other outdoor events. Or for the kids plates in help-yourself holiday meals.Hope that helps.

This is resin (solid plastic) with a metallized paint coating and black patina rubbed in crevices as a finishing touch. I sit it next to a salt lamp and the orange glow reflects off the statue beautifully in my otherwise dark room, creating a subtle and relaxing atmosphere to meditate in.I doubt it would hold up well outdoors.Hope that helps.

I have had hundreds of watches pass through my hands as a watch hobby collector, including oris, tag heuer, eterna, omega, tissot, victorinox.The rubber links between steel on the band is an interesting mix I haven't seen before.The movement is a high quality swiss chronograph. The case, pushers, crown, and strap are all much better than in pictures, similar to other high-end swiss brands. If you're expecting a luxury watch in the $500-$1000 range you won't be disappointed. The pushers are smooth and solid, not chintzy and sloppy. In a chronograph that is important. The second hand doesn't have any play, it stays where it's supposed to. The movement is jeweled. That's what separates a $200 chronograph from a $500+ chronograph.This is not a luxury watch that has higher end details though such as a fully jeweled movement, or precision grinding on the links.Hope that helps.

Made in the USA. Sides are woven plastic hollow cord on a particle board frame. The hamper is quite heavy. The lid is solid and very heavy. It is on a loose hinge. You can easily sit on it, although I would not sit on it regularly due to the woven plastic upholstery. I use it to store clean clothes in that I don't use frequently. For dirty clothes it is not the greatest in my opinion because of the lid's inability to be propped open when directly against a wall.Hope that helps.

These are quite small paper-board boxes (not corrugated). The orange coloring is paper that has been glued down with a spray adhesive (well done). The boxes are very small in that they would not fit a watch. They would fit a fine necklace/pendant, ring, brooch, ear buds, coins/money, candies, needles, buttons, thread, stamps, etc. Great for little hand-made gifts or storing small nick-nacks.Hope that helps.
The steel is thick and will not bend or flex. It screws down into a CMT jig. Differently branded jigs typically will require a template for their brand.Hope that helps.
These are standard kraft mailers that you'd expect to find at Staples or Office Depot. They hold up well in the mail. they measure true to size. Everything is identical quality.Hope that helps.

The tool and all the accessories work just fine. A lot of what you're paying for here are the disks, edge grinder, and pad. Those things alone contribute to around $100 of the cost here. Additionally the head of the angle grinder has been modified to allow water to flow through it, and a GFCI to protect yourself from working with electricity and water, if electricity arcs it will shut off. When you are using this, it will produce a lot of water. If you are making the counter indoors with a wood floor, you will likely want to create some kind of catch basin or water channel. The tool itself has a good amount of power, although this is not super high end, I've had no problems with overheating.Hope that helps.

The main competitors are DeWalt and Milwaukee. Is there much difference? Not really. The main difference are the unique tools in the various lines of batteries because once you buy into a batter kit it doesn't make much sense to buy into another.As for the tool itself, you can take off lugnuts on a truck with this. You can also get attachments for hex shanks to drill massive holes through telephone poles or log homes.An impact wrench transfers a blow to a hammer and anvil inside of the tool instead of your wrist. A normal high power drill, if you are drilling into something serious and the bit binds, but the tool keeps rotating, you can break your wrist. So drilling with one of these can be the safer way to go.The motor brushings can be replaced. The thing likely to finally wear down electric impact hammers in the end is the hammer striking the anvil enough time mushrooms the steel pieces so they are further apart, which reduces the torque. But that requires many years of hard daily usage. The batteries have quite a long life-span. Lithium batteries can typically be charged between 300 and 1000 times. On this makita box it says 1000 charge cycles. I would factor in cost with convenience. If you have a large air compressor, an air-powered impact wrench is going to be cheaper over the long run if you use it a lot.Hope that helps.

My mom had a hand held battery powered vacuum. It didn't have the power to do much, it would run out of juice fast and when the battery got old you were out of luck, basically having to throw the thing out. This little thing has power to spare. I turned it on without holding onto it on accident and the power of the motor revving up flipped the vacuum to its other side! It can suck up strands of hair imbedded into carpet, that always seems to be the true test of a vacuum. It has no bag, you have to snap off the front and split the unit in two to empty it. This filter is a flimsy cotton filter with a soft plastic membrane for the seal. I do no see it holding up as well as the vacuum. I looked to see what the price is for the filer and currently they are $7.50 for two of them, which isn't so bad. The filter can be cleaned multiple times before wearing down. I just pick off hairs and lint with my hands, no biggie.Hope that helps!

I work at a job that requires you wear pants for "safety reasons." But during 100 degree days, getting close to heat stroke, when all I have to do is walk around peoples yards, it doesn't exactly feel safe. So I wear these. They are nice and thin, like swimming suit material, and extremely breathable. If you get water on them they dry in a few minutes. They also offer no protection for "safety reasons." I've ran into barb wire and thorny plants and pointy stuff will stick right through them. But I love them. If you are fair skinned, but like to get outside, these will offer great sun protection while not overheating you. They are worth the price, you will not find anything better.As far as fit goes some reviewers commented on that. I am 6'2" and weight 185lbs. They fit my thighs perfectly. I do not wear baggy pants but I do deep squats in my daily activities and they never restrain my movement at all. I have ripped many relaxed fit dockers of the same size doing deep squats, but not these pants. I think they're great!Hope that helps!

The Maxx Elite "Gentle Warm" Bottle Warmer & Sterilize is very easy to use. 4 buttons for operation one being power- the others are Gentle Warm, Express Warm, Sterilize with the temperature in big bold letters. There is an auto shutdown feature if the device runs out of water to prevent hazards. The Gentle warm can actually be left on through your next feeding cycle keeping a bottle ready for you. Overall it is a very nice quality item!* "I received free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review."I was not compensated for my review and all my opinions are my own.

3:55 MinsThe Terra Friendly Self-Inflating Travel Pillow is a really nice option for Travel/Camping/Home use.  It comes with a 100% cotton Pillow Case, an elastic band to keep it nice and tidy, and a carry.storage/bag.I the pillow case is very soft, and the pillow is light-weight and easy to inflate/deflate to your comfort or needs!* "I received free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review."I was not compensated for my review and all my opinions are my own.

This is a USB-C to USB-C cable  with a nylon braiding.  The USB 3.1 Type C is rated at up to 10Gbps data transfer rate..that is blazing fast. The nylon braiding makes it more durable, protects the center wiring much more, and allows for maximum flexibility while keeping the insides safe. IF you are going to invest in a cord, you should shoot for the ones with nylon braiding.  Many of the new devices coming to market are coming out with USB-C ports even power-banks--check out Anker if you don't believe me. IF you are looking into this type of wire with USB-C then you should already not the connectors are universal and you don't even have to think when plugging it in.. nice!  This is a good option!* "I received free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review."I was not compensated for my review and all my opinions are my own.

Its a nice quality Bamboo wood charging dock. Wires are not included, but I like the natural feel to it, and you can keep you watch on it it as-well.  Nice option if you want less metal in your life...feng shui .. Good option for a work/study desk* "I received free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review."I was not compensated for my review and all my opinions are my own.

The Devotional Bible is a great resource for a man looking for his way, and in need of understanding Christ.  I am for the most part attracted to the Chronological Bibles, but I love to see the differences in the way things are explained and compare and contrast.This Men's Devotional Bible is very well thought out. Ink is Black/ Gold, contains a Dictionary in the back which really I think many bibles are in need of and would help people tremendously. The unit is tiny and portable!  I did have to research the technology a bit I found out that the ionizer creates negative ions which seek out positively charged particles, such as dust, dander, bacteria, pollen, mold, smoke, chemical vapors, and other allergens and then, once the positive and negative ions are bonded together, they become too heavy to float, and no longer affect the air quality of the surroundingsWhat is the ideal space for this size? I messaged the company and they recommended about 30cm surroundings space.This model is a little different the the product picture. The larger holes at the end that are releasing the negative ions have bristles. When I first received the unit- I turned it on, a green light lit up. For the most part it is silent but makes little sounds here and there. I couldn't feel anything on the skin on my so I put it to my cheek. When both bristle touched my skin, I would feel a little shock!You can actually fill a small container with smoke, put the device in there, and watch the smoke disappear. I also Found meter readings of it on youtube.Way cool technology. I wish this was bigger so it could work for my entire room!* "I received free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review.

The Tree New Bee 15.6- 17 inch laptop cooling fan is a good option, but I do have some concerns.First thing to note is that there are 4 fans, 2 USB ports (1 for power, 1 for data), 2 controls for the fans and lights. 2 stoppers in the front that stop your laptop from comping forward.2 legs that come out the back for height.Everything works, which is great.My thoughts and concerns.There are 4 total fans, you can control the speed of the fan and turn on a light with the same switch. My conern is you can not turn off the lights, unless you turn off the fans. You can use any 2 fans at a time, or all 4 adjusting the speeds according to your needs, but there is not an option to turn the light off.You have 2 legs in the back to come up, but I think the unit would be even better if there was an option for 2 heights.The front stoppers were a great idea I have 4 different cool fans for my laptops and this is the first I have with this option to keep the laptop from slipping. my issue is that the stoppers are not rounded off and are kinda sharp and hit my wrists. I am using small laptop and that could be the issue, but if they were rounded off w/ rubber to prevent the sharpness. To zoom all you need to do is pull outward on the lens area where the grip is.  IT was kinda hard in the beginning, but pull it in and out about 30 times and you will make it a lot smoother. The Lens mount can also rotate 90 degrees.The charging port is also located on the battery pack. you get a home charging cord, and a cig-lighter charger for the car.For the most part is a a very well made light.3 things I would liked to see different:- The charger type- I would like to see it as a micro-usb- I would like a travel case, even if it means the price goes up-  add a little more foam to the front of the forehead mount, because I feel over time it won't keep its formOverall it is the best head lamp that I own!  I usually try to give points for improvements together with any praise I may give, but that does not take away from the product. I give it 5 stars!"I received free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review.

In front of the laptop sleeve locations you have 2 divider type sleeves for tablets. my laptop also fits int he back one snugly. I feel you can actually carry (2) laptops in this sections  securely.On the back you have a zippered pocket that has 2 buckles that come out and turns the bag into a backpack. The Actual straps have a fair amount of cushion that keeps the bag from sinking into your shoulders even when packed to max weight capacity.To turn it into a messenger bag you click the buckles that are on the straps together and hook onto the metal clips on the outside of the bag.The Habik Bag was very well thought out down to the last detail! It will secure your laptop, keep you organized, and efficient since the netting will allow you to pull out what you are looking for at a glance.I love this bag! This is now my main laptop bag :). This is the second iPad Air 2 case that I have tested.  Bought it on a deal when the price hit $8.99.Decent case.  You basically get what you pay for -- and by that, I mean that it looks nice but it's not as well made as the Apple brand cases.Also bought the KHOMO case on Amazon (link below), and though it's a few dollars more expensive, I think it has a better rubber finish that looks and feels nicer than this brand.  I would definitely look at this case instead...http://www.amazon.com/iPad-Air-Case-Rubberized-Built/dp/B00OKSMA6A/ref=cm_cr_pr_product_top?ie=UTF8

I am the perfect candidate for these kind of insoles.You see, I am a postal worker.  I work in a sorting center, walking constantly on my feet upon a cement floor, for 8 hours a day.I go through new shoes every 6 months.I had high hopes for these gel insoles.  Had hoped that it would give me better support and less feet aches than standard insoles.The verdict?  No dramatic differences.  I can't say the insoles make my feet feel any better.  I still get a great deal of foot aches and discomfort after several hours of walking.  I don't even know why the word "massaging" is even in the product description because that feeling doesn't even exist.Yes, my shoes are sized properly.  Yes, I did cut these insoles correctly as many of Amazon reviewers have suggested.  I just don't think these insoles offer any relief or additional comfort benefits that one would expect from the product description.

I have a cat that I picked up from the ASPCA when it was a young adult.I think the reason why it ended up at the ASPCA was because it was a "dirty" animal.  By that, I mean that it didn't use the litter box on a regular basis.This was a problem we had pretty much from the beginning of her adoption and now 5 years later.We had her taken to the vet and there were no problems found.Sometimes she uses the litterbox.  More often she does not.  Changing litter to a premium brand did not help long-term, either.So, placing these puppy pads in her favorite area to urinate has become a daily necessity.Fortunately, they effectively soak up the urine and we simply throw out a pad every single morning and replace it with another.Cheaper than other brands, and has the trusted Amazon quality.

There was no hesitation to buy this Plugable Technologies 3.0 hub.
