You see, I bought their similar 2.0 hub a few years back and it still works incredibly well for connections that don't necessarily rely on 3.0 speeds.As a iMac power user, I rely on an incredible amount of accessories that require USB connections.  So, having 10 ports at my disposal is something I greatly appreciate.  There are two pop-up connectors that I use for flash stick drives that I transfer files to and from.  They are perfect for quick access.This is a powered hub, so it won't rely on the resources of your computer.Judging how long my 2.0 hub has lasted, I don't have any fear that this unit won't last me for years to come.

This is the second KabelDirekt product I have bought in the past few weeks.  I was so happy with the first set of cables that I immediately put my faith into this brand.You can see how extremely well built these cables.  They are thick, with gold plated ends and an excellent finish.  Have no problem delivering 1080p 3D signals to my display and they are already 4k ready.As someone who is deeply invested in Home Theater products, and has experience with various cables, I have found the KabelDirekt brand to be among the very best I have tested.

I was quite amazed at what $15 bought me.When I upgraded to the iPad Air 2, I never bothered to get a case.  I use the device around the house for the most part, and for that reason, I felt reasonably assured that it would not drop.Had to go on a business trip at the last minute.  I scrambled to find something cheap to cover my iPad while traveling.  Just happened to come upon this product from KHOMO based on the number of positive reviews.  For $15 it seemed like a safe gamble.I was quite amazed by the quality of this case.  Compared to what Apple charges for theirs, this case doesn't scream "cheap."  It seems well made and it even has a magnetic closure that automatically awakes and puts your iPad to sleep.Really, it would be hard to tell that Apple didn't make this cover themselves.But here is the problem...It doesn't function well as a prop-up stand.  In another words, using it on may flight, I had it titled up on my seat tray by folding in the cover and using it as a stand.  The cover collapsed several times during my flight.  It just seemed as if the cover was not durable enough to act as a stand.So, the "You can watch movies on an airplane with this cover" functionality fails miserably  It will work, but chances are you are going to be fidgeting with the cover over and over to keep it propped up.Other than that, this is an exceptional case.

Bought two of these 30lb. containers based upon positive Amazon reviews.They do a great job of holding dry dog food.  Since I combine two different brands of dry food, I use two of these side-by-side.  Also purchased a small scoop on Amazon.I don't understand the reviews saying this is not "air tight."  It has a seal around the edges of the cover, and it indeed does keep air out.I do agree that it is not the most well constructed food container you can purchase.  As other Amazon reviewers have pointed out, parts tend to come apart with repeated use.  In my case, the front locking latch came off at one point.  I was easily able to snap it back on -- but really, this kind of thing should not be happening.  For that reason, I deducted one star from my review.In all, I would still recommend this storage case for keeping your dog/cat food fresh.

I own a really nice Seido surface case that I have been using with the iPhone 6 Plus.When the iPhone 6S Plus was released, I considered a new case.  The Spigen was on sale for a single day, dirt cheap, so I picked up their Gun Metal Air Cushioned case.It's a fairly nice case.  I really like the way the side buttons function from within the case.  In all, I would agree with most all Amazon reviews that this is a terrific case for the price.The problem is that it is a smidgen too thick on the bottom to fit in my iPhone charger stand.  Now, this isn't the Apple's new lightning dock.  The dock I am using is made by Henge Docks (Gravitas).  It is supposed to support most cases that fit the iPhone 6S plus, but the Spigen case bottom rubber is just too thick to fit compared to the Seidio.I would make certain that if the dock you are using is grooved and meant to support a certain size case, that you check to make certain the Spigen is not too large for your needs.

I have gone through many brands of iPhone protection screen covers over the years.Upon purchasing my iPhone 6S plus, I purchased the Aduro Shatterguardz Premium Tempered Glass protector based on the mostly satisfactory reviews on Amazon.The product was packaged quite well.  There were a few extra stickers in the packaging that I didn't quite understand their use for -- and the instructions on the back of the box didn't explain why they were included.  However, applying the cover itself was a relatively painless process.  Simply clean your phone's screen with the supplied wet wipe and cloth, than peel the backing from the protector, aligning it correctly with the cutouts on the front of your phone.I was delighted to see that the protector was easily applied and any small amount of bubbles beneath it were effortlessly evened out with the included cardboard tool.The biggest gripe I have with this protector is the same gripe that most Amazon reviewers have.  It does not fully cover the entire screen of the iPhone 6S Plus.  It leaves a very small margin of unprotected area around the edges.  Now, this could be due to the fact that Aduro felt that cases with side overlap might not fit correctly over the protector.  However, I have a case with an overlap and there still is a smidgen of unprotected glass around the sides of the iPhone.Is this a deal breaker?  I would guess, no.  However, this is the first glass protector I have used that doesn't fully cover the iPhone screen and I am really wondering what is going on with this product that it has not been corrected.As far as reports from reviewers that the cover "shatters"...I don't quite understand those remarks.  If you apply this cover carefully without being abusive to it, I can't see anything going wrong with the install process.As far as how well it protects your phone when it drops?  Well, fortunately, I have not had to even test that feature.  I rarely drop my phone. However, something tells me that if you don't have a case protecting your phone with a front lip, nothing is going to protect your glass should it fall face down on pavement from considerable height.

Let me start off with a complaint.  For some reason, this cable took weeks to arrive at my door.  I am a PRIME member and I believe this was not eligible for prime shipping.  That's a shame because it took about 5 weeks to reach my door after ordering.  I hope that issue has been resolved.Like the concept of this cable.  It's really one of the coolest cables of its kind I have found.  For one, it has a dual tip for charging either an iPhone (lighting cable) or Android device (Micro USB cable).It also has a streaming flow of light across the cable to indicate charging speed and level.Of course, when using this in your vehicle -- as most of you will -- nighttime use will yield maximum results.  During the day, you won't notice anything other than your phone or tablet being charged.However, at night, it's sooooo cool to turn on your vehicle and be greeted by a stream of blue lights running across this cable.  It's sure to elicit some "oohs" and "aaahs" from those in your vehicle.  Most certainly, nobody has seen anything like this before.My worries are overall durability.  Some reviews have already expressed that this cable stops working after a short period of time.  I have found that the lights don't stay on once the device is fully charged.  Should they?  If not, something is already wrong.  I know if I move my phone, all of a sudden the cable comes to life.  It's not clear whether this is normal working practice or not.Truth be, I haven't used this cable long enough to establish long-term usage reliability.  I will certainly update this review should these cables stop working.On the surface, outside of the extremely long time it took to receive, I am very happy with this purchase.  It really adds a bit of flair to your vehicle at night.  It's just a really "cool" cable.  Just wish it was made from a company that had a little more reliable history behind them.  Something tells me that these are cheaply made cables and that the lifespan will not be what one expects from major cable manufacturers.  Time will tell.

Wire hangers.  Hate them.  They ruin shirts.Best thing I did for my clothes, years ago, as get rid of all my wire hangers.  I switched to more durable and thicker plastic hangers that I found at my local Price Club store.However, the Price Club store stopped selling the hangers for some reason.  So, I turned to Amazon.  Bought the 12-pack and was pleased to find that these were the same type of hangers I already owned.  Nice thick plastic.  Durable.  No bowing.  No banding.  Heavy enough for pants.  Gentle enough for shirts.

I recently purchased a Waring Dual Waffle Maker.I wanted to obtain the same spatula/fork took that hotel chains offer with their waffle makers that one sees at the complimentary morning breakfast.For under $10, this fit the bill perfectly.I don't understand the negative reviews.  I just made my first batch of waffles this morning.  Using this tong, I simply slipped the spatula beneath the waffle and removed it with the fork grip.  The waffle lifted out of the grill perfectly.  If I had just used a fork instead, I risked tearing the waffle apart.The size is perfect.  I don't need another huge gripping device in my utensil drawer.  It works wonderfully, and it's the same design that you see at hotel breakfast counters.  If it works for them, it certainly should work in the home.Listen, I am not putting down other reviewers.  Everyone has their particular likes and dislikes about how a product should perform.  However, what could be more simpler than sliding a spatula under a waffle and using a grip to gently pull it out from the grill?  This gripper works as advertised.

To begin with, I have owned a Braun electric toothbrush for many years.  I have one of their older rotating head models that still works well.  In other words, I have experience with these toothbrushes.  I also feel that, by far, you get a better clean using a rotating brush over a standard one.  I am a little over 50 years of age. In my lifetime, I have only had one cavity. I take great pride in maintaining proper dental hygiene.  I believe anyone can be cavity-free if they floss regularly and brush their teeth and gums twice a day for at least two minutes.What I liked about the older Braun electric toothbrush was that I could actually time my brushings to the recommended 2 minutes.  Start the holder, and at the two minute mark, the brush heads would make a funny motion to indicate that your two-minute mark has occurred.This new 7000 SmartSeries toothbrush takes that experience to a whole new level.The best thing about this expensive toothbrush is that it comes with a portable gauge with adhesive holder that you tack on to your bathroom wall near your sink.  It actually pairs with the toothbrush via bluetooth.  When you turn the toothbrush on, the indicator starts counting towards your 2-minute goal.  I like this, because without the indicator on the older brush, I never knew how far into my routine I was.  An indicator on the gauge not only counts your brush time, but also tells you if you are brushing too hard.  If you are brushing too hard, a sad face will appear on the indicator.  I was surprised how often this happened -- and it showed me, for the first time, that I was not brushing properly.The only thing I wasn't too crazy about was that every 30 seconds, the toothbrush heads would slow down for a split second, to indicate another 30 second cycle had just passed.  I don't think it was necessary for Braun to implement this feature.  It's not a deal breaker, certainly -- but I do agree with other Amazon reviewers that it can be annoying.At first, the thought of having a phone app for brushing your teeth seemed ludicrous.  However, after using the included gauge --- and becoming dependent on it --- I can see how an app would be perfect when traveling.  Think about it.....you can leave the gauge at home and use the mobile app instead to show you your progress and indicate when you are not brushing correctly.Now to debunk some prior review myths....Yes, it is true, it takes a full 24 hours to initially charge this toothbrush.  That's kind of crazy.  However, I suppose no big deal.  Some have said that the charging light is overly bright to the fact that it's almost like having a night light in their bathroom.  This is not true.  Yes, it has a blinking blue charging light, but in total darkness, it did not become bright enough to be distracting.Yes, it's a little noisy when being used.  However, not the point where you are going to wake up everyone in the house.  If you are like me and keep the bathroom door closed, nobody is going to be awakened by this toothbrush.The 7000 series is a bit larger and heavier than the older Braun toothbrushes.  However, it does seem to be more powerful.  I also feel a better clean, overall, using this series over the older model.It comes with, I believe, 3 brush heads.  A registration coupon inside offers a $3 savings on replacement heads plus an additional $7 off coupon when you register online.There is a beautiful travel case included.  I agree with one reviewer that the travel case might be better if it had air vents.  However, if you thoroughly dry your toothbrush prior to putting it in the case, I don't see any problems.Braun has moved from the fully upright charging stand to a flat dock.  I like this design.  It includes a covered area to store toothbrush heads for members of your family.With the included Amazon clip coupon, I ended up paying about $120 for this toothbrush.  It's pricey...yes...but once you start using it with the included gauge, you will look forward to using it every morning.

Just bought a new Lincoln crossover and I wanted some sort of organizer to hold all my car cleaning products.  I usually keep a collection of sprays and wipes on hand to handle bird droppings and such.Looking at the picture, this seemed like it would suit my needs perfectly.  However, upon receiving the item, I was a bit dismayed that this organizer was HUGE.I don't think I need something this big in my cargo area.  It takes up more room than I would have hoped.  If I have to go shopping or take friends on a long weekend excursion that includes luggage, it seems like this would be the first thing I would need to remove from the vehicle.It arrives folded.  All you need to do is insert the two cardboard base plates to form the box.  It's certainly ample enough to hold just about anything.  As I already noted, perhaps too large.If you have a lot of items you need to lug in the back of your vehicle, I would guess this will perfectly suit your needs.  However, if you are like me and just want an organizer to hold a few sprays and cloths, perhaps you should look for something a little smaller.

Up until today, I haven't been a huge waffle eater.  Not to say I don't like waffles -- I just don't have the means of making them.In fact, the only time I eat waffles is when I am traveling.  And, you can't imagine the excitement I get from staying at one of those hotels that has the complimentary breakfast that includes the waffle maker that you pour the mix into, flip, and then wait for the beeps to finish.  I mean, sometimes I would race to be at breakfast early enough that I wouldn't have to wait on line to use one of these things.So, the prospect of having one of these waffle makers in my home is something I have been pondering over for quite some time.  One of the big reasons I abstained from an initial purchase is because it's just another device that takes up room on a crowded countertop.  However, as time went on, my inner needs took over, and I ordered one of these devices.This morning, I went from unpacking box to my first batch of waffles in under 15 minutes.For those of you getting to ready to buy one of these babies, I will be more than happy to give you an overview of use -- plus a tip on what kind of mix to buy.To explain how easy it is to go from box to your first set of waffles, here is the quick setup guide...1. Unpack. Plug unit in wall.  Remove the filler shipping inserts from both waffle grills.  Wipe any possible shipping dust (I had none) from each grill using a moist cloth.2. Turn on Waffle Maker unit to preheat.  Set dial to 3.5 (mid-point) as an initial start.  Allow unit to preheat for about 5-7 minutes.  It will beep 6 times to tell you it is ready.3. For first use, prime both waffle grills by spraying or brushing cooking oil on the grills.  Manufacturer claims that you don't need to use any non-stick spray afterwards.4. Once unit beeps 6 times to tell you it is preheated, pour batter into one of the two grills.  Use spatula to even it out.  Close and flip.  Indicator light on grill will go out.  If making another waffle, repeat process for second waffle grill.When waffles are done, the unit will beep three times.I suggest purchasing very cheap plastic waffle tongs.  They will work perfectly in removing your waffles.  This is the one I purchased from Amazon..http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006OVZRT8?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01On my very first try, the waffles came out PERFECT!  I mean, PERFECT!  I couldn't have messed this up if I wanted to.  Put the hot waffles on my plate, doused it with maple syrup....and mmmmmm......perfection.  The 3.5 setting seems to give the perfect balance between delicately crisp on the outside and fluffy on the inside.As for what mix to use....I did a lot of research on Amazon.  I poured over reviews of several mixes.  I ended up going with Hungry Jack Belgium Waffle Mix.  The reason was because all one has to do is add water to the mix.  The others require you add eggs and oil or melted butter.  I just didn't want that hassle.And, let me tell you, I don't believe you can get better tasting waffles from a mix that requires all those extras to be added.  When you make waffles, you want it to be a simple process.  Trust me when I say that the Hungry Jack Belgium Waffle Mix makes outstanding waffles.  Certainly the best waffles I have ever tasted.I am completely happy with my new waffle maker.  It's effortless to make outstanding restaurant quality waffles in a short period of time.  Clean up seems non-existent.  The waffles left no residue behind.  Once the unit cools, you simply wipe it down with a cloth.Construction seems very solid.  It certainly doesn't feel cheaply made.  I can't speak for long-term use as today was the first day I have actually used it.  However, I anticipate that it will serve me well for many years to come.

Just purchased the Waring Dual Waffle Maker from Amazon.Before receiving the unit, I poured over several Amazon reviews regarding different brands of Belgium Waffle Mix.  I really wanted the best tasting mix that could be had.The thing that turned me off about most of the mixes was the fact I had to add eggs with oil or melted butter.  I had hoped that there would be something a little more simpler to put together in a hurry without worrying about whether I had extra food items in my refrigerator.The Amazon reviews for Hungry Jack Belgium Waffle Mix were very good.  Some said it was the best tasting waffles they have ever had after trying several other mixes.  You can confirm these claims by reading reviews on the single box product.So, I took a chance and ordered the 2-box combo of Hungry Jack.  It arrived at my home in perfect condition.  No problems with the expiration date -- I did not receive old product.Yes, it's as simple as measuring the mix and adding water.  I used the 2-3 Waffles measurement.  It barely made 2 waffles.  Granted, I did fill the first Waffle grill to capacity, so I came up a wee bit short on the second.  However, it's safe to say, you'll get two nicely sized waffles out of this measurement.The taste?  Wow!  I can't see how using the other mixes that require the addition of eggs and butter to be any better than this.  The waffle was perfectly cooked -- crisp on the outside and fluffy inside.  It had a nice, sweet, vanilla-ish taste.  I would go as far as saying it's on par with the best waffles I have eaten.So, yes, you can get outstanding waffles from a mix that just requires water.  I am still sitting here, an hour after digesting, reflecting upon how great my first batch of waffles tasted.Now, I should warn that a box goes very fast.  Just making two waffles, I went through 1/4 of the box, if not more.  If you have a large family or plan to make waffles often, one box will not last you long.  I am glad I went with two boxes.

Okay, let's get to the meat of this review...This is the printer that most of you are going to want to get your hands on. Whether for personal or business use, the WF-R4640 handles all your printing, scanning, faxing and copying needs quickly and flawlessly.I am so happy that Epson gave me the opportunity to test this printer alongside its smaller (and less expensive) sibling, the ET-4500.  I will make references to both printers throughout this review so you have a comparison of why one might suit your needs more than the other.  You can also click on my profile and see my recent review of the ET-4500.So, let's begin, shall we?First of all, this printer is an absolute BEAST.  When it arrives on your doorstep, you will be rather amazed at how large the shipping box is.  Epson recommends that two people take part in lifting this computer.  I am relatively strong and fit, so I was able to do it on my own, though I will admit, it was quite a struggle single-handedly lifting the printer from the ground floor to the upstairs office, hoisting it on a stand.Epson has done an excellent job packing this printer for transport.  It is loaded with tape and inserts that protect all the parts inside.  You will spend the first 5 minutes peeling off dozens of protective tape strips and removing styrofoam inserts.  Quite frankly, I was very pleased that Epson took such care in making certain my printer arrived undamaged.Enclosed with your software disc is a Quick Start Guide.  This is all you need to quickly reference and set up this printer.The first thing I was relieved to find was that the installation of ink is quick and painless.  Now let me use this opportunity to compare the process to the ET-4500, which comes with 4 bottles of ink that you need to manually pour into reservoirs.  It's a somewhat messy process where one needs to wear protective gloves.  Not so with the WF-R4640.  The ink comes in 4 large bags.  You simply shake each bag vigorously for 20 seconds and then insert them into the printer.  What I really liked about this process was the printer's pop-out cartridge in which the bag of ink easily rests upon before being snapped to closure.Oh, and please heed the warnings on the ink bags....don't drink the ink.  :)Turn on the printer and it takes about 12 minutes for the ink to be primed throughout.  That's 8 minutes faster than the ET-4500.A big upgrade on the WF-R4640 is its 4.3" Color Touch Screen.  It's such a pleasure to use compared to the ET-4500 which is mono and not touch responsive.  I love the fact that I can use the screen as I would my smartphone.  From start to finish, the setup process is executed by simply touching your finger on each selection.  In some cases, there is a small QWERTY keyboard where you can type in your Fax header and phone number.  The color menu is very attractive and makes it so very easy to pick the function you want the WF-R4640 to do.Connecting to the WiFi network was effortless as well.  The hard way of setting up your WiFi network would be to install the enclosed software and connect your Mac/PC to the printer via USB.  However, why go through all that?  Just use the touch screen to select SETUP and then choose the WIFI WIZARD option, which scans for your home network and then prompts you to enter a password.  I had my WF-R4640 connected to my home network in no time.  By the way, I should mention at this point that I use Mac computers in my home and business.  No compatibility issues at all, except for document scanning, which I will talk about shortly.The big reason why you are reading this review is that you want to know about print quality.  I think I am in the perfect position to give you an idea of how well the WF-R4640 compares to most laser printers (as I own a recent, popular Brother laser) as well as an ink-jet printer such as the ET-4500.Epson doesn't describe this model as a "laser" printer.  They tout their "Precision Core" technology whose performance they claim goes beyond laser.  Quite frankly, that's a claim that is difficult for me to confirm.  I can tell you without hesitation that the WF-R4640 is leaps and bounds ahead of its smaller sibling, the ET-4500 in speed and print quality.  I mean, printed Internet pages with lots of background information came out wet on the inkjet computer.  Not so on the WF-R4640.  At 20 ppm, this printer is 4 times faster than its sibling...and it really shows.  Print jobs were very quick, with results churned through this machine in no time.The Brother 4570 (which is their most popular laser model) boasts 30 ppm, and though that means that its printing is faster, it's not night and day when comparing it to the Epson.I mention the Brother model because that is the laser printer I have been using over the past two years.  Comparing the two, I found the print results to be almost indistinguishable.  Both featured razor-sharp text.  Both produced equally pleasing images, though I would not use either for printing photos.  You really need a specialized printer for that.  The Brother laser provided slightly more vivid/pronounced text and images but the differences were rather subtle.So if already owned a very good laser printer, why did I even consider the Epson WF-R4640?Well, that's a question that's easy to answer on several levels....First, this is an all-in-one machine that meets the needs of a home business like mine.  For the longest time, our office had separate scanner and faxing machines.  We can now get rid of those individual machines and rely upon the Epson to do all of that...and more.  There were no problems sending out a test fax to my old machine.  It was great that the fax contained the header information I had programmed into the Epson.  Copies of documents looked identical to the original, so I am very pleased with the overall copying functionality.  Document scanning worked in principle.  I was able to easily scan a document through the printer's top feeder.  It wirelessly initiated the document capture software on my iMac.  The problem was, the document software on the iMac could not process the document.  Several attempts put the Epson printer into "interrupt" mode, which essentially is an error mode.  Now, mind you, I am using a pre-release version of El Capitan OS X.  I have no doubts in my mind that the problems I am experiencing are due to Epson not providing a final software update compatible with the upcoming operating system.  At least I know that the WF-R4640 is communicating wirelessly with my Mac and Epson only needs to provide a software update to fix the document issue.It's kind of funny that I am this far down in the review and I am just starting to talk about this printer's ink capacity...Okay, so you are paying somewhat more for an all-in-one like this.  Well, your investment is in the ink itself.  This printer comes with enough ink to print 20,000 black/20,000 color documents.  Now think about that kind of capacity for a moment.  Even in a busy work environment, that's a lot of ink.  In a home environment, with normal years, it would take years to deplete that supply.  Additionally, it is my understanding that replacing the ink is much cheaper than dealing with cartridge replacements.  So, this is an investment that will pay off in the long run.Epson did provide me both the WF-R4640 and ET-4500 printers to test side-by-side.  Epson made it very clear to me that I could say whatever I want about these two models, be it good or bad.My review of the ET-4500 was not totally favorable because I felt that it wasn't suited for home business use, but rather for families that need a basic printer with all the bells-and-whistles.  I also did not totally approve of print quality and speed.The WF-R4640 is built for business.  It's fast enough to tackle big jobs and the print quality is comparable to expensive laser printers.  With two letter trays, its paper capacity is ample enough that you won't have to keep refilling.  I would not be surprised if this printer becomes the new standard for what other printer companies must now strive for.Please Note: I received the following printer from the manufacturer in exchange for my impartial review.

I can't fully take credit for the title of this review.  Upon browsing through other reviews (prior to receiving my own unit), I saw another customer describe the Epson ET-4500 as a "$400 machine with $100 features."  I took the liberty of putting my own spin into that opinion.Truth be, this really is a low-end ink-jet printer with expensive features tacked on.  Don't look at that opinion as a total slam against the ET-4500.  You really are getting a rather excellent all-in-one printer that offers copy print, scan, copy and fax functionality.  While many other printer companies offer similar products for hundreds less, the ET-4500 offers enough ink in the box to outlast the competition.  Epson claims there is 20 cartridges worth of ink included.  I would estimate that Epson is on the money here.I really had to take a step backwards when I tested this printer over the course of a weekend.  I am a small business owner who has used laser printers for my needs.  So, it was very odd for me to see this printer where, instead of installing cartridges, I was filling reservoirs with different colored bottles of ink.So, the first thing I need to point out is that there is a more elaborate setup process to this printer than one would normally expect.  However, using the enclosed quick-start guide, it pretty much becomes a no-brainer from start to finish.  However, I wasn't prepared to don a pair of rubber gloves as I unscrewed bottles of ink and poured them into individual tanks.  Now I warn you -- and please heed this advice --- you MUST wear gloves when handling the ink.  It *looks* as if you can easily pour the bottles into the tank without a single drip.  However, it's more involved than that.  You have to first unscrew the cap, remove the protective foil, screw the cap back on, remove the cap tip, and then "squirt" ink into the tanks.  In doing that, it is guaranteed that you will get ink on your hands.  Also, be certain to put a newspaper underneath the printer to catch any protective foil or dripping ink.  After the ink reservoirs are filled, you will be walked through a setup that includes a 20-minute wait as the ink does an initial circulation through the machine.Though the Epson ET-4500 comes with a software disc to walk you through internet connectivity, I was easily able to set most everything up using the 2.2" mono screen which resides on printer's front panel.  I simply went into setup -> network settings -> WiFi Setup and had the printer scan for my wireless network.  I entered my password and...voila!...the printer connected easily.  There is even a little WiFi icon that remains ever present on the home screen letting you know its connected.  At that point, any person using a device connected to your home network has access to that printer.  That's good for me, as I set this up as a centralized household printer where anyone in my family, including guests, can print from their phone/tablet/computer.All of Epson's features worked flawlessly.  I was able to perform a document scan, make a copy of a newspaper article, and fax an article to my fax machine.  Of course, I tested all sorts of basic printing options from Internet websites as well as documents I had stored on my computer.So, here is the rub...Although the Epson flawlessly executes all of its functions, it does it exceedingly slow.  I am used to a laser printer spitting out a printed copy within seconds of firing up.This Epson reminds me of my very first ink-jet printer well over a decade ago.  It prints as if it's actually drawing each character as the paper goes from feeder to output tray.  You sit and watch for what seems like a good half minute as your document gets printed.  It's not the kind of speed someone doing business work would want to see.  The same kind of "chug-along" speed is experienced when scanning and copying.  It's just not speedy enough for my preferences.Additionally, I was somewhat disappointed with its print quality.  For basic document prints, the results were pretty damn good.  Though not quite laser quality, I was pretty happy with how professional printed documents looked.  Where I really was disappointed was when I printed a webpage or photo filled with lots of colors and background images.  The paper actually came out wet.  As I picked up the document, ink smeared on my fingers.  Yeah, this is ink-jet alright.  I suppose if I had just let the paper dry before handling, it would have been okay.  Lesson learned.However, the reality of the situation is this...To get into a business all-in-one that gives you the professional quality speed and printing quality someone like me desires, I would have to pay at least twice this price.  Epson has introduced the WF-R4640 alongside this model.  I am being sent one to review.  It supposedly offers faster speeds and print quality that rivals (or exceeds) laser printers.  I will be putting that model through its paces over the next few weeks and I invite you to reference that model on Amazon to read my review when it posts.  I will attempt to revisit this review and post a direct link here.All that being said...I have to put myself in the mindset that the Epson ET-4500 is a budget printer with lots of bells and whistles intended for family use.  Put in that perspective, this printer performs admirably.  I mean, you get all the functions that an office printer would offer.  It performs all these functions beautifully.  For general family or personal use, most people won't mind that it performs all these functions more slowly than professional models.The Epson ET-4500 is well built.  It looks rather handsome sitting in our living room where it can be accessed by everyone.  Best of all, it contains enough ink that I don't have to worry about having to replace anything despite the heavy usage that it will receive.  Remember, you are making an investment in a printer that comes with an abundance of ink -- much more than any other printer being offered -- and the option of cheaper refills once it runs out. This is the reason why it costs more than competing all-in-one printers.My final recommendation is that the Epson ET-4500 should not be a consideration for business owners or anyone looking for professional laser quality speed or printing results.  Please wait for my review of the WF-R4640 in the next few weeks.  For those who want a cheaper all-in-one that is well-built and sacrifices speed for great bells-and-whistles, should consider the ET-4500.  It's perfect for home use, by everyone in the family, who can take advantage of being able to print wirelessly from their favorite device.Please Note: I received the following printer from the manufacturer in exchange for my impartial review.

Recently adopted a small dog and wanted to take her with me on trips.I own a luxury vehicle and the last thing I wanted was for my pet to destroy the front bucket seat.The Alfheim dog cover is perfect for my needs, although I was also considering the KIRGO cover which is much more expensive.  Glad I stuck with this brand.It comes with absolutely no instructions but it's quite elementary to figure out how to install.  There are two straps on the cover.  The first (at top) goes over the headrest and fastens with one loop going in the bottom slit and then through the top.  Pull to lock.  The second (in the middle) fastens in exactly the same manner.The bottom skirt fits perfectly across my rather wide-bottom 2016 Lincoln MKX seat.The seat cover seems to be made of durable material.  It isn't bulky, and really, doesn't look that out of place that it cheapens the look of my interior.  If I have anyone riding with me in my vehicle, it seems a "snap" to remove the seat cover.If there were anything different I would prefer about this seat cover would be plastic buckle fasteners (for easy connect and disconnects) rather than having to manually loop the strap through two slits -- which I can see being a real pain-in-the-neck if having to continually remove and install this seat cover.Oh....and if you have taken the time to read this review and make it to this point, a little extra surprise for you (and apparently ME): There is an included pouch to store your seat cover when not in use.  Niiiiiice!

After reading dozens upon dozens of Amazon reviews, I knew what I was possibly getting into when buying this scale.  I almost didn't do it, but there was the temptation to try it with the knowledge that I could return it....and return it I did.First of all, if you purchase this very expensive scale, know right out of the gate that Withings offers no customer support.  Oh, you can go to their website or use their app and see their encouragement for you to write an Amazon review.  However, the company has absolutely no presence on Amazon, addressing disgruntled customers when their product fails to work as promised.  Go to their online support, send them an email, and get nothing in return.  They don't answer support questions/complaints.So, basically, when you buy this product hope that anything that goes wrong with it does so within the Amazon return period.  Anything beyond that and you may be royally screwed.Next...To even set this scale up, you must have a smartphone capable of running the Withings app.  You cannot simply set it up with your PC.  You must also have a wireless WiFi connection in your home.  Don't rely on bluetooth because that connection will not be stable and you will not be able to use increased functions such as weather reports.Initially, I did not have a smooth setup process with this scale.  I almost sent the product back.  My issue was that, using the Withings app, I paired the Smart Body Analyzer scale to my iPhone 6 Plus via bluetooth.  When the option to pair it WiFi appeared on my screen, it would not advance the app any further.  In other words, the screen became stuck.  The only option I could select was "I have no Wifi connection" (despite the fact I did).  So, I had to solely rely on Bluetooth.  Big mistake.  Every time I left the house and came back home, the bluetooth connection would not automatically re-establish itself.  This is a common problematic theme for most reviews on Amazon.Of course, I wrote customer support an email.  However, as indicated throughout dozens of Amazon reviews, customer support does not exist.  Some have claimed to have gotten email responses from Withings, but those instances seem to be far and few.As I noted, I was about to send this product back until, very quietly, Withings issued an update to their iOS app.  It was if Withings had read my email support complaint and addressed the issue without bothering to respond to me directly.  The update solved the WiFi connection issue and allowed me to pair my phone with my home's wireless network.Once the scale was paired over WiFi, then I saw the benefits.  I was able to use more of the scale's features including daily weather report.  All my daily weigh-in's were automatically sent to my iPhone and computer, maintaining its connection from day to day.That's not to say that in the past week that I have owned this scale that things haven't been perfect.  Today, the scale decided not to give me my heart rate reading but reported everything else.  Not sure if that problem will continue or not.At first, I decided to keep the scale because I actually liked what it did when it actually worked.  In conjunction with the iPhone app, it keeps a daily progress of my weight and actually tells me how I am doing towards reaching my goals.  The Withings app is quite good, integrates with the Apple iOS health app, and since I also own their wireless Blood Pressure Monitor, it keeps all my readings in one place.I just worry about the longevity of this piece of hardware.  When you have a good handful of reviews that complain about deficiencies in the product, combined with a total lack of support from the manufacturer, one worries about whether they are buying a sound product for the exorbitant price.UPDATE: This morning my "stable" WiFi connection stopped working.  The scale appeared to work as normal, but was not transmitting weight data to my WiFi network and the Withings app as it had done initially.  I went through multiple attempts to re-establish an Internet connection by pushing the PAIR button on the scale.  Each time it failed to connect to my wireless network.One of the biggest things missing from this Smart Body Analyzer is a simple BLUETOOTH or WIFI indication on the display screen, actually alerting the user that there is a connection taking place....because, really, one has no idea if information is even transmitted/recorded until one opens the app or goes to the Withings website and logs in.  Today, I waited hours for this morning's weigh-in information that never came.  Once again, the WiFi and scale stopped communicating with each other.  And, no, it's not my router.  I am a computer guru.  I have multiple hi-tech gadgets in my home accessing my wireless network and none of them act as erratically as this poorly designed device.Frankly, I am tired of of having to play with connections on an almost daily basis.  I should have listened to the reviews.  I should have abstained from purchasing a product like this when there were so many inconsistent Amazon reviews.If the company can't stand behind this product -- if they can't make a presence on Amazon -- then they surely must be aware that these problems exist and are doing whatever they can to hide themselves from public response.And be careful of positive reviews from reviewers who don't have a VERIFIED purchase beneath their name.  A lot of positive reviews being printed on Amazon from folks that don't have that moniker.  There is a good chance that Withings is posting a wealth of good reviews in hopes of countermanding the bad ones from those who have VERIFIED PURCHASE beneath their name.

I am in my early 50s and recently been diagnosed with mildly high blood pressure levels by my physician.  This is after a lifetime of having perfect blood pressure (and I am in the best physical shape of my life).I had been planning for quite some time to purchase one of these wireless blood pressure monitors and was keeping an eye on the reviews for the Qardio brand that is also sold on Amazon.  However, after all the negative reviews over hardware and sync failures with that brand, I knew I had to look at something else.  Actually, what finally drove me to Withings was the 5-star reviews of its app on the iTunes store.  There's nothing worse than a strong product that comes with a lousy iOS/Android app.  Fortunately, Withings comes through with flying colors in both departments.Out of box, setup was easy.  With batteries already loaded, I simply hit the bluetooth button on the cuff and paired it with my Apple phone.  I would recommend that purchasers install the app first, launch it, and have it walk you through the process.I would also recommend that before you hit the START button on the app and take your first reading, to click on the settings icon on the upper corner of the app and have it automatically take three readings to average out your readings.I was pleasantly surprised, using the enclosed instruction booklet, how easy it is to place this cuff above the elbow, wrap, and take a reading.  It's really effortless.  The results are not only sent to my iOS device, but readings are logged within the app and can easily be shared or emailed to my physician.Have not had to change the batteries yet, so I don't know how difficult that process will be.  There is a screw at the bottom of the cuff tube to access the batteries, though I am concerned about it becoming stripped over time.  I would be very, very gentle with any coin used to open it.I also, at the time of purchase of this Blood Pressure monitor, put the Withings Body Scale in my cart.  At the last minute, I removed it due to a few negative reviews and the mention that there is no customer support from this company.  That is concerning.  However, now that I have seen the Withings app in action and the fact that it supports all their fitness products, I have gone ahead and ordered the body scale.  It's kind of cool that I can track my weight gain/loss and blood pressure numbers all in one app, sent wirelessly, without me having to do anything than just use the products.So far, I am very happy with this Blood Pressure Monitor.  If I have any problems I will come back and update the review.

I turned my basement into a Home Theater room.  I wasn't initially motivated to do it, because the basement space is shared with a separate cellar where all kinds of varmints seem to find their way inside.I wasn't aware of how bad the situation was until I installed these inexpensive pest catcher trays.Within a few days, I found the trays littered with crickets and spiders.  Additionally, the tray has trapped a multitude of mice that get caught and cannot escape.So, this tray is hugely effective at catching all sorts of pests.  I would highly recommend its purchase.

Amazon features many of these type of new LED Desk lamps and it's hard to distinguish which is better than the other.  About two months ago I bought a cheaper LED lamp from another company, and thought I like it, it's not as advanced as this one.In fact, I may have never bought this Coocheer product if not for the price it dropped $20 in sale price after I had been watching it for a few days.Just received the lamp this morning and within mere minutes from taking it out of the box, I had it assembled and plugged in.Assembly is pretty straight-forward.  No need to read instructions.  Take all the plastic protection off the product.  Put the light and swivel arm into the desk base and use the large hand screw to lock it into place.The great thing about this lamp is that it saves a great deal of space on your desktop when not in use.  All you simply do is collapse the light upon itself.  It sits, almost unnoticed, until you are ready to use it.  At that point, you unfold and extend and swivel it to your needed use.The light has several different power levels including: reading, relaxing, study and sleep.  As a desk lamp I really didn't need all these settings but it's nice to have.  As a bedside lamp, I can see how these settings would come into use.The great thing about LED lighting is that one, it's very relaxing on the eyes compared to bulb lighting.  Secondly, there is much more life longevity to be had with this kind of technology.If there are any real negative points to be observed they would be firstly, that the lamp could be a bit brighter.  For large desks, I think the light barely illuminates an entire area.  Fortunately, the lamp can be easily moved for the coverage you need.  Secondly, the piano black model does collect quite a bit of fingerprints.  This is a lamp that will need to be wiped down often.  Also not happy with its overly large plug that takes up more than one space on my extension strip.Still, I give it five stars.  It's a quality-made product.  I like it.  Think it's a bit overpriced so I would definitely watch it for when it goes on sale.Haven't tested it it with my iPhone 6.  All the reviews say it works well with that, so I am going to go on a leap of faith that I will have no problems.  Nice to have a built-in USB charger at my disposal.You can buy this product and be assured you are getting a nice quality desk or bedside lamp.

It's rather amazing to see how inexpensive flash drives have become.For just under $30 I picked up this SanDisk 128GB USB 3.0 drive for my Macbook Pro.  I mean, just a few years ago, one would pay a small fortune for a drive of this capacity.The thing I really like about this drive is that it's so small, once inserted into your portable computer, it will become part of the laptop itself.Mind you, it's not exactly flush to the laptop.  There is 1/8" of hardware sticking out from the side once fully inserted.  Is it an eyesore?  No.  Does it prevent proper insertion into a laptop bag?  Does it make using your laptop more difficult or less portable?  No, no and NO!I suppose those who want perfection will nitpick that the drive slightly sticks out.  Everyone else will be quite content.Why do you need one of these drives?  Imagine being able to add 128GB of storage to your laptop or desktop computer.  Not only that, but 128GB of super-fast SSD storage.  If your computer already has an SSD drive in it, you will be amazed by how quickly files transfer from drive to drive.  I will be up front that I don't know much about transfer speeds, but having a Macbook Pro with a built-in SSD, I see my files back up several times faster to the SanDisk than they did to a physical hard drive.This flash drive is so unobtrusive, it remains virtually hidden from sight.  You'll forget its plugged into your desktop computer.  You will almost forget its plugged into your laptop.  Those with a Macbook will appreciate it's silver and black colors that go perfectly with the keyboard.Just a reminder for Mac users:  Go into Applications -> Utilities -> Disk Utility.  Click on the SanDisk SSD drive in the left column.  Click on the ERASE button in Disk Utility.  Give your drive a name and select OS X EXTENDED (Journaled) to format the drive in something your Mac will recognize.

I know a little about quality spoons.  My mother owned a really nice set of spoons -- a heirloom from a bygone area -- when kitchen dishes and utensils were made with care.  I mean, the spoon to the handle had rivets in it.After decades of owning these spoons, one of them finally broke.  Of course, when a utensil that has served your family so well for past decades finally breaks, it's tough to find something to replace it.I spent time pouring over Amazon reviews of several spoons.  The OXO steel spoon seemed to get the most favorable feedback.  Of course, one is still gambling when they don't have the opportunity to actually see the product in person.  As I usually do, I ordered this product blindly hoping for the best.Just unpackaged the two spoons I ordered this morning.  My Mom and I were very impressed.  In fact, so much so, we just stood there holding the spoons for quite a few minutes admiring its build quality and weight.This is a nice, hefty spoon with a great handle that looks as if it will last forever.  There is no question that this is quality built through and through.  I mean, for $10 a spoon, you can't go wrong.Do what I did when I read other positive Amazon reviews.  Take my word for it that this will be an outstanding serving spoon that will last for many years to come.

I recently rearranged my workspace, and as thus, had to move from a convenient under desk drawer to having to place my keyboard on the desk itself.Not a big deal, but certainly not as ergonomically friendly.So, I searched Amazon for a nice wrist pad.  Didn't mind paying more for something that was comfortably padded and built to last.I believe I found that with the Glorious Gaming Wrist Pad.  It seems well built, it's very comfortable, and it has non-slip backing that prevents the pad from moving anywhere while in use.It's essentially PERFECT except for one glaring problem...The logo on the front.  It's rather large and ugly.  It features a bearded man character next to the company name.  There's no need to put that kind of obtrusive advertising across the front of a really nice product.  Why not put it underneath?  What kind of ego played into the logo placement?  Really, it takes a perfect product and makes it seem....well....silly.Still, I suppose the one downside is outweighed by the upsides of having a really great wrist rest against your wrist.

On and off, over the past year, I have been looking for a suitable replacement to my current wallet which always is left "somewhere" other than my pants pocket because it's too large and heavy.  Filled with about nearly two dozen different cards, it has become enormously thick and unattractive.A simple Google search for "best thinnest mens wallet" brought me to an article that compared many of the best rated wallets.  The Allet Classic Leather Wallet was among those in that group.  First thing I did was come to Amazon and read the many, many positive reviews.  Of course, you can sit here and read dozens of praises and still come away not believing you are going to get a wallet that truly satisfies you.So, I took a chance and ordered this wallet.  What the heck.  It costs under $40 and I figured if I didn't like it, I could return it.The wallet arrived last evening.  Taking it out of the package it seemed quite nice.  It's made of pliable leather and rip-stop nylon.  This morning, I began loading my credit, bank and reward cards into the 4 compartments that align both sides of the wallet.  I put a wad of bills into the cash compartment and then folded everything up.Amazing!  Absolutely Amazing!  You really have to see it for yourself to believe it.That bulky mess of a wallet I used to own was streamlined into something neat and compact.  I was actually easily able to slide it into the front of my pants with no resulting bulge.  I mean, for the first time in memory, I actually want to put my wallet in my pants pocket.This wallet totally redefines everything we used to know about our wallet.  We don't need long, horizontal wallets with center flaps that encourage us to stuff as much crap as we can inside of it.  Allet has created a more vertical design, keeping it simple, keeping it thin.You really need to experience this wallet for yourself.  I think you will be as amazed as I was.

I am probably the toughest critic against Spigen's original Apple watch case.  If you look at their thin exact fit model (42mm) you will clearly find my Amazon review labeled "DO NOT BUY."That was a very stern warning, which apparently hundreds of Amazon buyers chose to ignore, and thus quickly discovered that they made a huge mistake.  The original Apple watch case from Spigen was a horrible product.  It fit so loosely around the watch that it easily popped off.  I went through three of those cases and each one was lost.  There were hundreds of complaints from Amazon purchasers who had similar problems.I must say that Spigen Customer Support was pretty damn good to me.  They sent me replacements, and finally recommended I look at their Tough Armor case.  I decided to order it and I can clearly say at this point that I am very, very happy.The biggest con to this case is that it's an inconvenience to install and remove it.  To do so, you must remove one of the two sides of the watch band and pull the rubber casing over the entire watch until it fits into place.  You must do the same thing to remove it.  It's not a simple pop on and pop off product.That being said, the upside is that no matter what, the case will not come off.  And you know what?  After going through multiple cases and having them all pop off, I am kind of relieved by having something like this and don't quite mind the extra effort of putting it on and off when I want to look more formal vs. having protection for my watch while at work.This "Tough Armor" case doesn't add as much bulk as I had anticipated, although it does turn a very handsome wrist wear into something that looks like an old Casio watch.  Still, for those of us who are blue collar workers and are prone to scratching our watches, this level of protection is a godsend.This case also comes with a face guard, which I am kind of scratching my head about its inclusion.  Does one really need a guard over the face of their watch?  Well, that's your decision.  Me?  I threw the face guards out.

Have always loved the concept of Listerine strips.  Imagine not having to lug around a bottle of mouthwash liquid when you get that "icky" feeling in your mouth.These little strips simply slide out of the dispenser, onto your tongue, and dissolve instantly to give you that "clean mouth" freshness.I have used the ordinary flavor in the past and decided to try Arctic Berry.  Wow.  Really like the flavor blast it initially gives you.  Was a really neat idea for Listerine to make other flavors available.  I can't find these flavors in my Costco store, so it was nice that I could order it on Amazon.The only problem I ran into is that the one-at-a-time dispense method doesn't always work.  I have a whole group of strips fall out of the dispenser at once onto the floor.  Chances of this happening are rare, but it does happen.Overall, really like this flavor.

I used to carry around a huge, soft lunch bag around my shoulder.  It was always much bigger than what I had actually needed it for, so when it finally fell apart, I decided to downsize and go with the Coleman 9 can cooler in gray.Unfortunately, the size of the cooler is much smaller than what is depicted.  I like to bring sport size bottles of Poland Spring water to work. They don't fit snuggly in the cooler.  You can actually fit two of them in there, but they slant upwards and rest up against the zipping portion of the bag.  Not ideal, but it's the only way I can fit them in there.If you are the kind of person that brings a sandwich and perhaps a can or two of beverage to work, then this cooler's size will work perfectly for you.The bag itself is well made and seems quite durable.  However, as others have suggested, the strap is not long enough to wear around your shoulder.  You can do it, but the bag itself will hang closer to your neck than it will your waist.Just be aware that this bag is quite small and is only meant for a few cans, a piece of fruit, a sandwich and perhaps a cold pack.  If you want to place larger "sport" size bottles of soda or water in it, you will be disappointed it does not fit snuggly.

I have a home theater room filled with posters inside frames.  I was looking for a slightly smaller frame to fit a 24x36 movie poster that I had purchased.  Didn't want anything expensive, but wanted a frame that wouldn't look cheap.Went to many different stores to look at frames in the $20-$30 price range.  They all looked either cheaply made or had a plexiglass covering that was cracked.  Site reviews also reported that some of the frames were so cheaply made that they would not hang straight, but rather bowed towards the bottom.So, after reading positive reviews about this frame, I went ahead and blindly bought it from Amazon.I was pleasantly pleased to find that the frame fit my needs PERFECTLY.  First, I need to talk about the manner in which it was shipped.  It came double boxed, with a secure cardboard wrap around the frame itself.  This meant no matter how badly the package is handled in delivery, the frame is highly protected against damage.  That was very nice to see.The frame itself looks great!  It isn't overly expensive (under $40), but looks expensive.  It has a wood frame with plexiglass covering.  The plexiglass has peel-off protective wrapping on BOTH sides so that it arrives unscratched.  In addition, you get all the necessary hooks, screws and wiring to mount the frame to the wall.  A complete package where you need not buy any additional hardware.As far as the poster fit?  Perfect!  My 24x36 movie poster fit perfectly inside with no information lost along the sides.I cannot recommend a better frame in this price category.  You should be quite pleased with it.

There are clouds everywhere you look.  Tech-Savvy people are uploading and keeping their valuable information on a multitude of online services like Dropbox, Box, OneDrive and Google Drive.  All these services offer free limited storage with options of expanded storage for a monthly fee.  For the most part, these services are generally secure, though there are always chances that your data could be lost or compromised.What if you had the opportunity to have your own secured server right in your very home that could be accessed from just about anywhere?  That is the promise of Seagate's newest product, Personal Cloud Home Media Storage.  Once connected to your home router, you simply connect with your home PC (Mac or Windows), upload your valuable photos, videos, documents and music to your personal cloud, and have it instantly accessible on every computer, tablet and smartphone you own, wherever you may be. Additionally, Seagate advertises that you can view all this content via streaming to your SmartTV.Out of the box, Seagate provides everything you need for immediate hook-up including ethernet cable that gets connected to your wiring.Seagate makes installation an absolute breeze.  In fact, out of box, I had it set up in under 8 minutes.  I simply plugged the media storage unit into the wall, and then using the supplied ethernet cable, made a connection to my home router, a few feet away.  Seagate provides excellent instructions for connection your Mac or Windows PC.  Essentially, for my Mac, once the unit was connected to my router, I could see a personal server icon in my finder window.  Once clicking on that icon, I was able to begin the initial setup by further clicking on the URL icon file.This would be a good time to talk about the different personal cloud storage models that Seagate makes available. There are three single bay units in 3TB, 4TB and 5TB sizes.  These are for budget-minded individuals that just want maximum storage space.  The more expensive 2-Bay models come in 4TB, 6TB and 8TB sizes.  These allow you to split the maximum storage size in half so that anything you upload is automatically copied to another bay.  This gives you the most protection for your data as if one hard drive ever fails, your secondary has a copy.  The photo above illustrates my 2-bay 8TB model.  I have the option of having 8TB of data available to me.  However, I chose to use a RAID setup where all my data would be dispersed across two 4TB drives for maximum protection.Uploading your files to your personal server couldn't be more simple.  Seagate creates a PUBLIC and PRIVATE folder for my data.  Anything placed in the public folder can be accessed remotely by yourself or anyone you give permission to access it.  The PRIVATE folder is securely kept on your computer and cannot be accessed from your remote devices.  You can set this personal cloud storage device to perform automatic Time Machine (Mac) or Windows backups, if you choose to do so.  I have not tried to restore from Time Machine, but I am concerned about some reviews on Amazon that cite the Time Machine backup does not work as it should through this device.I should also note that the Seagate Personal Cloud unit has two USB ports (USB 2.0 and 3.0) for attaching and backing up an existing external drive you may already own.Through the Device Manager you can also configure your personal server to automatically back up its data to popular online cloud services such as Dropbox and Google Drive.Download the free SeagateMedia app for your mobile device and you have complete access to all the files in your PUBLIC folder (but not your PRIVATE folder).  This means you can access photos and documents as well as stream your music and videos directly from your server no matter where you are.  While access speed to various media was faster on a WiFi network (whether my own or another), I was able to successfully stream video while on my AT&T LTE cellular network.A great feature of the SeagateMedia app (at least as tested on iOS devices) is that you can automatically set it up to immediately upload any photo or video that you take with your iPhone or iPad.  This means that the moment you capture your precious event, it's available on your personal server.  Photos and videos that were previously uploaded to my iOS devices prior to installing the Seagate Personal Cloud were instantly uploaded to the server and available for viewing.The SeagateMedia app is available for iOS, Android and Windows phone.Note that for computer to computer access to your personal cloud, you need to be on the same WiFi network.  I could not access my Seagate device on my laptop once I left my home WiFi network.  It would be nice to see Seagate provide an access app for the desktop at some future point.While the SeagateMedia app does an admirable job of allowing you to access your files, it seems ill-conceived and unusually bloated, for which I question what Seagate was thinking of in the first place.  The app comes preloaded with thumbnails filled with videos of sharks, kittens, architecture and more.  It has absolutely nothing to do with your personal files and it serves, at least for me, to make it more difficult to find your content.  When you do finally get to the meat of the application, you'll find that your videos, pictures and music are somewhat neatly organized.Both Chromecast and Roku offer the SeagateMedia app so that you can essentially stream your content to your display.  I tested out the app on Roku and was very disappointed with the results.  While I was able to access and view photos and videos that resided on my iOS device, I was not able to access any content uploaded to my Seagate Personal Cloud.  At the time of posting this review, Seagate tech support was unable to figure out the problem.  As with the iOS version, the Roku SeagateMedia app seemed half-baked, and browsing through folders and having to deal with the bloated content seems like a rather unimaginative experience.Final ThoughtsThough not as all-around refined as I had hoped, at its core, the Seagate Personal Cloud ideally serves its purpose as a storage device that can be accessed most anywhere.  You can use it with software (such as Time Machine on the Mac) to regularly backup and restore your computer.  You can access all your files while on the road through the SeagateMedia application.  Owning one of these devices eliminates the need to pay high monthly costs for online storage systems.PROS* Simple and quick installation to your PC. Plug it in and configure in mere minutes* Access to all your documents, files, music and videos from any computer on your home WiFi Network* Access to all your documents, files, music and videos on your iOS, Android and Windows mobile devices as well as Roku and Chromecast.  Works over WiFI or Cellular connection via SeagateMedia app.* Very effective for computer backups such as Time Machine on Mac or similar software on Windows operating system.  Be aware, however, some reviews on Amazon cite the Time Machine backup not to work as it should through this device.* 2-Bay models have mirrored raid connection for extra protection of your most valuable data* Set up Seagate Personal Cloud to automatically sync data with Dropbox, Google Drive and other popular online cloud servicesCONS* Mobile app is bloated with preinstalled videos.  Finding your content can be cumbersome.  Seems like not much thought was put into providing a simpler, more enriched mobile experience* Could not access personal content through SeagateMedia application on Roku device despite several attempts to work out bugs with Seagate supportOverall, I'm not overly blown away by this cloud server and its remote access, but I am somewhat satisfied with the limited things I have been able to do with my Seagate Personal Cloud.  This is definitely a product that could use further refinement, and one hopes that Seagate will put that effort forward.  Until then, it simply serves its most basic purpose.

Like everyone else, one of the biggest fears I have is a failed water heating system that causes a flood in my basement.  Happened about 13 years ago and it's an issue I never want to revisit again.Always wanted to get an auto-shutoff valve.  Did a lot of research, but in the end, the biggest mistake I made was to try and save some money and buy the cheapest solution.You get what you pay for.This product is total garbage that did nothing but give us hours of heartache trying to figure out why it wasn't working.My brother is a plumber.  He fitted this valve to our water heater.  First of all, the valve ends did not match properly.  He was able to somehow alleviate that problem.  However, as soon as it was installed and plugged in, the device went into flood mode whereas it started beeping loudly and closed the hot water heating valve.We spent a good hour trying to figure out how to reset the device, which we could not.  We had to dismantle this product to manually open the hot water valve.There is absolutely no customer support information in the instructions to be found anywhere, so we couldn't even call the company for support.Looking at the gear inside the valve motor, you could see it was cheap plastic.  The gear only moved once when inserting the batteries.  Other than that, there was no gear movement (which opens and closes the valve) whether you pushed the OPEN or CLOSE button.Yes, I am aware there are positive Amazon reviews for this product.  However, do yourself a huge favor.  GOOGLE this product and read the multitude of complaints from buyers that could not get the valve to open once this product was installed.  One review is from a plumber that pleads people not to waste their money on this brand.This is absolutely going back to Amazon this week.  I opted to spend another $130 for another brand (FloodMaster) from another company.  Figure if I wanted a quality device I should just pay more money for one.EDIT:  My brother just installed a Floodmaster unit.  As noted above, it costs $130 more, but my brother was so pleased by the simplicity of the installation and the quality of the product.  As a plumber, he asked me to warn as many people as I could not to buy cheap junk like the Floodstop and go for the Floodmaster instead.

Needed a disposable brush for touch-up painting.This fit the bill wonderfully.  In fact, it has outlasted its need for touch-ups as I have been using it over and over again with many washes in-between.  Have not seen any loose hairs this far after all its usage.Nice quality brush at a low price.

What can you say about cable ties?Well, I know Monoprice.  I buy many of their home audio/video cables and they are a company known for selling quality products at low prices.Their cable ties live up to the Monoprice name.  Nice large pack of ties.  Using it to tie home theater cable together.  So far, not one defective tie cable in the batch.

I needed a good entrance mat for my basement where I just installed new carpeting.  My goal was to have visitors wipe their feet before walking across my beautiful rug.Well, it does the job -- beautifully.  The ribbed matt really collects shoe dirt.  It seems very durable, and it's heavy enough that it doesn't slide all over the floor when someone steps on it.Would highly recommend

Listen...Didn't need to spend a lot of money for a power strip.  I feel very lucky to have found a quality-built power strip with lit on/off switch and 6 power plugs for less than $13.I built a home theater in my basement and bought one of these.  Loved it so much, I bought an additional one for all the equipment in the room.  I am about to add two power recliner chairs next week -- so guess what -- I am going for the 12' cord model which is only a few dollars more.Yeah, guess you can say I am sold on this brand.  You can buy better, but trust me, this is a quality power strip that won't break your wallet.
Black?!  It was supposed to be black.  Came in white color.Otherwise, it does the simple task it needs to connect two plugs to a single outlet.

I consider myself to be a coffee snob.  Like most people, I enjoy good coffee.  I go to the expensive coffee shops, buy my coffee whole bean, then grind and brew.I owned a very expensive Technivorm Coffee Brewer for several years.  When it recently died, a lot of online research brought me to the Bonita BV1800SS.  It was a tough choice to buy this brewer, as Amazon reviews were very mixed.  However, I took a gamble and had one recently delivered to my home.I'll get right to the point -- it makes perhaps the best coffee I have ever tasted.  Certainly better than the more expensive Technivorm.  That being said, I am brewing a little differently than I had.  The big change is the filter.  With the Technovorm, I was using a gold filter.  Most coffee snobs don't like these gold filters as the water passes through them too quickly.  The Bonavita comes with samples of brown filter paper which I indeed did find to be far better than the gold filter I had been using.  The coffee itself may not be as piping hot as I would have liked, but this machine does indeed make a smooth, delicious cup of java.That being said, this is one of the most ill-designed coffee brewers I have used.First of all, the brewing process is absolutely inane. There is no separate filter basket drawer on the machine.  You actually have to unscrew the carafe lid and place the filter basket on top of the carafe, insert it into the brewer, and brew the coffee.  Then, once the coffee is brewed, you remove the bulky filter basket from the carafe, screw on the lid, and pour your coffee.Now, most people won't want to screw on the carafe lid -- especially if making a single cup of coffee.  It's impossible to pour the coffee without that carafe lid attached without spilling some of it on the counter.Another problem, as I briefly stated above, is that it doesn't quite make piping hot coffee.  It's hot, but once you add a smidgen of creamer or milk, it substantially cools itself down.Finally, there isn't a hot plate to maintain the temperature of the coffee.  My model has the stainless steel carafe, but I don't trust it's going to keep the coffee hot for long periods of time.I should also mention that this coffee maker is a steam machine.  See those vents atop the brewing area?  They eject clouds of steam.  So, if the coffee maker is stored under a cabinet you risk ruining that cabinet with the hot escaping steam.  I simply pull the coffee maker forward, away from the cabinets, when doing my morning brew.For the most part, I'm happy with this coffee maker because, damn, it makes a great cup of coffee.  However, one really gets the feeling that after plunking down some serious change for this coffee maker, that some corners have been cut to sacrifice quality for price.

I knew I was going to buy these lights and be somewhat disappointed.I needed LED lighting to add some ambiance to my basement home theater.  The lighting would reside atop and below the edges of my 118" diagonal front screen and along the front speakers.The first obstacle to buying these lights are the price.  They are at least 3x expensive than ordinary LED strip lights.  Yes, they are a cut above what you can get cheaper because of the hub and mobile app control, but not that much better that they should cost $90 a strip -- especially when some of that may very well get cut and wasted.Secondly, these lights are not too bright.  In a totally darkened home theater room they really didn't do a good job of adding punch to the objects they were supposed to highlight.  You really need to double up on these lights to get the output you would want -- but who wishes to do that when they are so darn expensive.I did send a personal email to Philips telling them that they should reconsider their pricing for these lights.  Heard no response back.Installation is fairly easy.  You simply plug in hue bridge (and you need the starter kit to even use these lights) and then each strip of light.  A webpage tutorial takes you through setting up an account and then giving instructions on how to connect everything together.  The hue bridge needs to be plugged into a router.  I wish it was simply WiFi accessible so I can place it anywhere I want, but just another minor annoyance that adds up to disappointment.I use the iPhone and iPad mobile app to control the lights.  It's kind of cool that you can change the colors right on the mobile apps as well as turn on/off/dim each individual strand.It's a tough call whether to recommend these lights.  I spent $600 on a starter kit and 4 additional single kits in order to accomplish what I needed.  In the end, I can't say it was worth the money.  The light output is miserable.However....The ease of use, hue bridge connection and mobile apps make this one of the very few "sure thing" choices when you want the most control over your lighting.

Needed a black tie, at the last minute, for a New Years party.Ordered this through Amazon knowing I needed it within days.I knew it was cheaply priced compared to other ties, but I just needed something basic.Was very surprised to find a great-looking tie that didn't feel as cheap as it was priced.I think this is perfect for anyone looking for a basic necktie.

Amazing how people will take Windex to their expensive television display.  What a way to completely ruin it.Wanted a screen cleaning kit that was safe for screens and effective at cleaning them.This fits the bill perfectly.  With its included large cloth, this cleaning kit perfectly cleans screens with no streaking.  I use it on my plasma display, iMac, Macbook, iPhone, etc.  So many uses.

The best streaming device out there.  Puts Apple TV to shame.Unfortunately, I don't use it as much as I would like.  I stopped my Netflix subscription a year ago.  However, I always like to pick this baby up and browse through the immense amount of streaming options.  The remote, and its ability to attach a headset to it is a real plus.If you are looking at streaming device options, don't hesitate to purchase the Roku 3.

Love the Despicable Me minions.I am not one for stuffed animals, but I thought that Stuart would look really cool in my Home Theater room.Upon receiving this plush toy, I was quite taken back by its build quality and stitching.  Was so impressed, I bought the Dave minion as a compliment to the Stuart.  Now I have both minions staring at me from my Home Theater display stand.Happy to see these are about $20 apiece.  At that price, they are a MUST BUY.  I think I paid almost twice for each almost a year ago when the movies were still popular.

Have two cats and one dog.  Enough said?The product seems to work quite well with my handheld steam cleaner.Removes the stain.  I don't mind the odor of the product.  It's only temporary.I continue to purchase this brand whenever I run out of steamer cleaning detergent.I would recommend it highly.
Love the fact these come in different colors to accent (or blend in) with the cord I need to fix.Not very wide, but it certainly suits its purpose.  Very strong adhesive.Would recommend
