Bought a Macbook Pro about two years ago.Was shocked to find that the MagSafe adapter cord starting fraying right at the point where it joined the power brick.I was even more shocked -- and became very angry -- when I went to the Apple store to read review after review of the same problem happening to other Apple owners.  It is very apparent to me that the fraying of the cord is a very common problem.I wrote a very angry letter to Tim Cook.  That letter got forwarded on to Apple Support.  I got a phone call from them explaining how to take better care of the cord (how to properly wrap it), but no offer to compensate me for the $80 I had to spend on a replacement that has effected hundreds of other Apple users.So, the point I am making here is that there is a problem with these cords.  They are not made strong enough to withstand normal usage.  Apple is doing nothing to improve its manufacturing.Yes, these work perfectly.  However, I would recommend wrapping some electrical tape at the point where the cord meets the brick just to prevent fraying issues.

Needed a holder for my EZ PASS unit while in a rental vehicle.I have one of the newer EZ PASS units and this clip-on suction cup device works perfectly.Perfect fit.  Easy mounting and removal.It's also cheaply priced.Don't look anywhere else for something as basic and effective as this EZ PASS holder.

Bought this for my 2 year-old nephew.He seemed interested in it at first.  Downloaded one of the free apps that come with this game.  It held his interest for awhile.Didn't buy any additional apps for this because they are so darn expensive.Instead, my nephew seems to gravitate towards the iPad mini which offers a wider selection of games with better graphics which immerses and involves him in the environment far better than this piece of junk.I realize that iPads are far more expensive than LeapPad units.  However, you get what you pay for.  Just consider that.

Based on overwhelmingly positive Amazon reviews, I purchased this iPad holder blindly.Used it with my older iPad 3.  The fit was not perfect.  With the iPad out of the case, I really had to stretch the arms beyond its capacity.  I almost thought I would break them.  Did finally get the iPad to fit into the holders.  I would guess the thinner iPad Airs will fit much better.Had rented a Cadillac SRX.  Put this in its cupholder.  I felt as if I was forever screwing the base into the cupholder in order to tighten it.  It would not tighten itself perfectly.  As the car moved, there was a bit of sway from the mount.  Not too bad, and not certainly to the point where I felt that it would tip over completely.I do realize that different vehicles have different cup size holders so everyone's mileage with this mount will vary.In all, I felt it was effective for what it did.  It allowed me to place my iPad at eye-level view so I could look at its navigation while driving my vehicle to Canada.I would estimate that this is probably the best of all the other mounting tools out there for the price.  Of course, chances are that you are not going to get a perfect fit for your vehicle.

Did a lot of research on car chargers like this.It's essential that you have the proper wattage to charge your larger electronics (such as the iPad)This 12 Watt charger fits the bill.Scosche has been rated very high in quality.  You may pay a bit more than other chargers, but I can tell you that this is probably the best charging unit available on the market.  Its quality construction and ability to provide constant, efficient power is the reason why you want to consider this above all others.

Sometimes I wonder if I am really saving money with my expensive razor.Yeah, straight razor replacements are very expensive.However, to purchase a $300 Panasonic premium shaver and to have to buy these replacement blades and foil every year seems to almost be a "wash" when you consider the price.Still, I consider the Panasonic electric shavers to be excellent, and one really needs to replace its blades at least once per year.  When replacing the foil and blades with this kit, it feels as if you you just purchased a new razor.

Had the older Panasonic 5.8 DECT phones.  They had limited range.  Could not get across my property, let alone even talk on the phone while on my deck which is located on the other side of the house.So, recently I purchased the Panasonic Dect 6.0 phones (TG7875s).  By themselves, the range of these phones is greatly increased.  I can now talk on my deck.  However, when walking the dog, I still can't talk across my large property.I took a chance and ordered one of these range extenders.  I was a little apprehensive about spending the money because of the mixed Amazon reviews.It's a very tiny device.  Getting it to pair was effortless, though Panasonic's documentation is very poor.  The best thing I would recommend anyone do is to go to Panasonic's Support site and look at the video tutorial. Hopefully this direct link will work for all of you...http://shop.panasonic.com/shop/model/KX-TGA405B?support=y(Click on HELP & TUTORIALS and then the video link)The pairing can be done in less than two minutes as you watch the video.Placed the Range Extender somewhere in the middle of the house.  Was not getting a secondary green signal.  Only Amber.  Yet, when I tested the phone range across my large property, I was very surprised to find that I had excellent signal strength throughout.  Phone calls actually sounded as if I was right next to the base unit.I think, because I did not put the extender closer to the base unit (which is why I get the amber light instead of green), there is an occasional "quick" signal loss, but it's not even worth worrying about.The main thing to be considered is that this range extender works as advertised.  I believe you could double the coverage of your Dect 6.0 phone using this device.  It's amazing the coverage it gives you.  If you need to be out in your yard, working or just walking your dog, this extender will give you the complete signal coverage that you need.

Having bought the Panasonic TG7875S system, I wanted to buy this detector as an accessory to help locate the keys I always seem to lose.It's small enough not to be obtrusive on the keychain.It works perfectly with the phone system.  You go to its menu, select Key Detector, and a homing device appears on the phone handset with a signal that increases as you approach the keys.  Really neat!The problem is, the key alarm is not as loud as I had hoped.  Also, I have had the key detector alarm go off for no apparent reason while I was at work a few times.  I suppose, perhaps, it's picking up random signals from the alarm system or otherwise.  No way to stop it from chiming, either, without opening the battery draw to quiet it.So, it's useful, but not perfected.  Still, I would recommend a purchase.

My dog chewed up the power cord for my USB charging unit.This replacement worked perfectly at a great price.Being an audio and videophile, I am well aware of Monoprice and their reputation for having quality products at low prices.  For that reason, I did not hesitate to order this cord replacement through them.You can buy with confidence.

Have had various 3D displays for the past few years.Recently purchased the Samsung F8500 series 3D plasma.  Best plasma display out on the market right now, though Samsung has recently stopped manufacturing it.The 3D glasses that come with the Samsung displays are abysmal.I took a chance and ordered two pairs of these glasses.  Yes, they are very expensive, but well worth it.  As others have pointed out, they are extremely durable and comfortable.  The sides block out ambient light.  The 3D quality you get with these glasses is fantastic.  Having a case and cleaning cloth included is an added bonus.The only problem I had was that one of the glasses stopped working after a month.  I simply ordered another pair through Amazon (which worked perfectly) and returned the defective ones.If you are looking for premium eyewear that is a cut above the flimsy, plastic glasses that are included with your TV, this is the way to go.

Recently bought the PS4 gaming system and figured I would pick up a second controller.Ordered it through Amazon.  Was available through PRIME and it arrived quickly and as promised.Of course, I need not have to say that this controller is fantastic.  It is ergonomically perfect and works as expected.Happy to now have two of these so that I can invite a friend to play multiplayer games.You won't go wrong ordering this controller.  Order the dual charging unit with this as well.

Bought these here on Amazon via AVA PRODUCTSDelivery was slower than normal, though it was not available through PRIME.The batteries worked perfectly.  Needed power for a clock.Would repurchase these again if needed.

This turned out to work perfectly.No longer wish to rely on spinning hard drives and am very happy to see that prices on SSD counterparts have dropped substantially.Originally bought the M500 drive, but returned it once I found out that the MX100 is a newer and faster version.  It only cost a few dollars more.I bought an enclosure that works perfectly with this drive, though its build is somewhat subpar...http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FCLG65U/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1In all, this is a terrific SSD drive at a very affordable price.  I trust Crucial's reputation so I am certain that I am not going to have any problems down the road.

Bought this for my 2-year old nephew for Christmas.He immediately took to it, grabbing chalk and doing his artwork on the chalkboard.This is the perfect gift for a pre-school child.  Will keep him/her busy for hours.The only thing to keep in mind is that chalk and dry markers are not included.  There was a very simple eraser shipped with the easel, but you will probably want to opt for something of better quality.Construction is quite good, and the tray fit comfortably beneath it without having to use extra tools.

I really enjoyed the first story. The acting is excellent and the post-war period settings are superb. However, in the second story there is just a touch too much incredulity in some of the plot, which did rather spoil the well-worn, "look out he's got a bomb" disaster scenario. It did remind me more of a "Five go mad in Dorset" type story, crossed with a game of Cluedo (Clue) using secret passages and unbelievably naive supporting characters.Having said that, it was definitely worth watching for a few hours to relax.

Fun item. When you add hot water the constellations replace the stars due to the heat sensitive sticker on the outside of the mug. If, like me, you leave your drink for too long you can also see it's gone cold :-)Do NOT put in dishwasher or scrub the outside, obviously!

Cheap sprayer that does a reasonable job. The only thing you have to do is attach the hose to the reservoir and you're good to go. The only small problem is the connector is plastic and a bit fiddly. If only they had used a brass connector and thread it would be better. Having said that, once it's connected you're probably never going to have to undo it again anyway. For the price this is a good sprayer. Spray can be crudely adjusted from cone to stream. There is no pressure relief valve so if you have liquid left over when you finish I suggest you invert it so the pipe cannot draw liquid and spray until the pressure is gone.
Not as cute as I hoped. Looks cheaply made.

Nice soap that can be used with a brush to whip up a decent lather for shaving. It's not as creamy as Taylor of Bond Street, but I have been using it for a few months and it doesn't leave my skin dry like I thought it would.

Don't waste your time with these. The two I used in an over mirror light fitting lasted a couple of months before the main light in the first one went, leaving only the background lamp. The second one went the same way a month or so later. Now we have 2 lamps which put out about as much light as a candle. Fine if you want to pretend you live in the 19th Century I guess, but not a lot of use really.
I would give this a really in depth review but then I'd be talking through my hat... ;-)

This is a nice kit. Its not a GoPro so cannot be compared to something that costs 5x as much. As an intro to this type of camera it is great. the video is good quality, although the microphone is pretty poor. Otherwise it works well in lower light situations too. The stills camera is not so good. It may be 12MP but for some reason the quality is just not there. Images are OK up to about 12x8" but then become pixelated.I intend to use mine as a dash cam to start with and for beach videos as the housing seems pretty good.So far I haven't been able to get the wifi to work and, as would be expected, the instruction "manual" is of fairly limited use and can be seen here: www.sjcam.com/download/sj4000wifi-English-manual.pdf Whether this is the app or the camera I do not know but it is frustrating.Overall, a good buy for the money

We are using this on our Jack Russell Terrier who has a mite infection. It stops him scratching and is helping to heal up the patches. This is money well spent, in my opinion. Plus, any left over can be used on insect bites etc., for the rest of us!

Nice looking and usable fun croquet kit when finished. We bought ours for a party so it served its purpose. However, there are a few points to note:1. The wooden handles have to be screwed into the heads. There are no metal fittings involved, just a wooded screw fitting. This is not very accurate so one of the six heads was really difficult to get on. I managed in the end, but there is no way I am unscrewing it, which leads me to ...2. The bag is not big enough to hold the full kit once the heads are on the mallets3. The mallets themselves are very short as this is really only a fun kit4. The hoops are thin wire and the balls are sturdy plastic/composite material5. The wood finish is acceptable, but not great. I definitely would not leave this outside for extended periods in the sun, or overnight
Though the narrator has a rather dull tone, and the visuals are wacky,the information provided is useful. It was good for my 11th grade daughter who was doing a research project.

I am a real fan to the m43 (MFT) camera format, championed by Panasonic and Olympus. I love the fact that the cameras and lenses are smaller and lighter than DSLRs and yet can produce stunningly high quality work that is comparable to that achieved by these these behemoths in most circumstances. The fact that panny have somehow managed to pack 20.3 MP into this sensor size is astounding.Unlike many modern photographers I do not usually jump into a new piece of kit quickly, preferring to make the most of my current kit for as long as I can and concentrating on technique. However, this is a special year for me so I took the opportunity to "move up" from my trusty GX1 to the new GX8, bypassing the GX7 model altogether.Wow, what a difference! The GX8 is quite a hefty body for a m43, at least compared to the GX1, and feels much more solid. The handgrip is larger and more comfortable and the arrangement of buttons and dials although a little bewildering at first, is brilliant in operation. The two rotary dials, around the shutter release and the on/off button, make manual selection of aperture and speed so easy when compared to the old "thumbwheel" of the GX1 (and my trusty LX5). The fact that almost every button can be programmed to the photographer's preference is also a boon.I use the EVF almost exclusively for composing so I am glad to have an integrated tiltable one (I use the LVF1 on my LX5 and the LVF2 on my GX1). The swing out, fully tiltable touchscreen has finally made it to the GX range and is a good feature for protecting the screen when not in use and for using the camera in those situations such as really high (or low) POV shots.So far I have found focus with my existing m43 lenses to be fast (*see update 4 below) and the image quality to be extremely good. There are a host of new features that I would not normally use, but one that stands out is the 4K Photo burst setting where 8MP images are shot at 30fps to allow selection from a fast moving target. This is a new one for me, and I am not sure how this differs from using a normal burst mode (which is able to achieve 40 fps using the electronic shutter a SH speed) but I will experiment.* Update 1 on battery life: I only managed to get 95 shots (shooting RAW+JPEG) on the initial full charge of he DMW-BLC12E 7.2V battery. That was using unpowered lenses and without too much chimping. I am hoping this improves as the battery conditions, but let's see.My spare battery gave me 115 shots (RAW+JPEG) on a shoot with no used of LCD whatsoever, so it's fair to say this camera CHEWS through batteries, unfortunately. I would definitely recommend carrying a couple of spares or more for a day's shooting!* Update 2 on battery life: Today, I managed 230 shots on a fresh battery, including several pano shots so maybe it's something to do with battery conditioning? Go figure! However, I do wonder if it could be a software/firmware issue (see below)* Update 3 on functions: I had a little extra time to play around with some of the functions I wouldn't normally use, namely the scene modes and the panorama mode. The scene modes are great for getting some different black and white compositions, HDR effects, toy effects etc. The great thing for those of us that shoot JPEG and RAW is that even in scene mode a RAW (RW2) file is also saved too, so if you want to change the image in post then you can. Having the instant feedback on the LVF and the ability for a quick JPG is great (Yes, I know this has been available on the previous GX models, but I never used it).The panorama mode is a bit tricky to get used to as you have to practice getting the speed correct. I did this handheld and the camera complained about me panning too slowly, then too fast and finally not panning level enough. In the end though it worked pretty well. You end up with a 8176 x 1920 px (15.7 MP) JPG  and no RAW file though, which is a little disappointing. For serious work I shall continue using vertical orientation and stitching but it is a fun thing to have.* Update 4: I have now taken 530 shots and I am not happy with the pinpoint focus, which seems a bit spotty. When used on my 45-200mm lens to get some background defocus the lens is incredibly difficult to focus on the foreground, even when the foreground object is 8-10 feet away. I did not have this issue with this lens on my GX1. I wonder if this is related to the firmware issue (see below, Update 5)* Update 5: IMPORTANT firmware glitch. I have now had two separate occasions when the camera has locked up totally just leaving the EVF functioning (I don't use the LCD for composing). No buttons worked, even the on/off rotary switch. The only thing I could do was to remove the battery. This is extremely disappointing on a $1000+ camera and, despite the fact that I am a panasonic "fanboy," I am going to try to return the camera and get a replacement. Accordingly, I have removed 2 stars form my review, which is a crying shame as otherwise I love the camera!Handy References:A couple of resources I have found useful so far are linked below (replace [dot] with a dot, obviously):1. GX8 full user manual - http://www.naturalexposures[dot]com/private/gallery/GX8manual[dot]pdf2. Panasonic site for updating lens firmware to see if your lens firmware is OK for IBIS - http://av[dot]jpn[dot]support[dot]panasonic[dot]com/support/global/cs/dsc/download/fts/index2[dot]html

This is a review of the KIT as described. I will review the camera once I have run a few hundred shots through it.I wanted to get the GX8 body as cheaply as possible and at over $100 under list price PLUS a 64GB card AND two additional batteries this was a bargain. It arrived withing 4 days of ordering too.
Stylish rain jacket that fits well. The blue is very pretty.

What a lovely dustpan and brush set. Made from sustainable bamboo and recycle plastic, who could ask for more!This didn't come with instructions so, for the benefit of those new to college life, I will supply mine, learned through much trial and error:(1) Remove brush by pulling out from convenient holder in handle.(2) Place dustpan (the flat bit) in front of the dust/dirt/small objects you want to pick up (Note: items should be dry for best results)(3) Hold handle of pan and tilt slightly(4) Now, holding the brush in your other hand by the handle place it on the far side of the dirt to be collected, bristle side down (this is important)(5) The arrangement should be pan - dirt - brush (bristles DOWN)(6) Apply just sufficient pressure to press the bristles slightly against the floor but still to allow you to draw the brush towards the dirt and the pan in one "sweeping" motion(7) Dirt should be "swept" into the pan(8) Carefully lift pan with dirt. Important tip: keep it horizontal (if you forget this simply go back to step 2, above)(9) Go to trash can and tilt the pan so that (most of) the dirt falls into can(10) Place brush back into handy holder.Congratulations, you've swept up something.

Some people like to carry a pocket handkerchief. Personally, I like to be ready for a meal should one present itself. This full 5-piece setting can be carried in my large coat pocket and allows me to maintain my decorum should someone offer me a morsel to eat "out of the blue," so to speak.The knife is sharp enough to remove those stubborn crusts from sandwiches and also peel and slice an apple with relative ease. There is always a compromise when carrying a knife in one's pocket. It needs to be able to cut, yet safe enough so that one does not stab oneself when stumbling around the subway after imbibing a beverage, or three.  Pocket knives can be misinterpreted by the increasingly wary security forces and a serrated blade seems a good compromise.But I digress.Admittedly this is hardly a complete set: there's no soup spoon, fish knife, etc. but one has to get by these days and this set has served me well (if you pardon the pun) and has not yet become bent or broken.

Neat lantern and flashlight that packs small and is great for camping or use in an emergency. Takes 3 x AA batteries.Three setting for light: high, low and flashing.Wow - when folded and used as a flashlight, due to the lens over the LED, this seems as bright as my 500K candle power B&D flashlight! The settings as a flashlight seem to equate to "Summon Batman", "Stun", and "Full Lighthouse Beacon" settings.

What a shame, this could have been good. To state this is "based on Philip K Dick's novel" is misleading. Aside from the loose concept of "precogs" there is little similarity with the classic sci-fi short story. The story line of this series is extremely weak, and cannot be made up with illogical CGI and overly loud  and dramatic background music. The acting is poor to say the least, ranging from the comical overacting to wooden performances all round. The best part of the whole experience was the ad breaks...

Clearly building on the early experimental work of such greats as Ibn al-Haythan and Anthemius of Tralles, Cooper takes to the field with his astounding contraption snugly fitted to his collar. His work is a sublime fusion of the work of Martin Parr and Henri Cartier-Bresson, to which he adds his own surreal viewpoint to provide a taste of his vision. Some of the images appear mundane at first glance, but when viewed over a longer time period one cannot but be astounded by the depth of perception Cooper brings to his compositions. Other images, are plainly abstractions of the world he sees, perhaps extrapolations of his feline visual cortex, the complexities of which we mere humans can only wonder.Truly this is a work of genius that should be kept as a well thumbed reference book in every street photog's bag.

This is an interesting idea that should work, but doesn't deliver. This is a length of bathtub chain with some flexible plastic "wings" added and a plastic "flower" at the end to stop the chain falling down the drain. It's easy enough to insert into a grille-type drain, although I would suggest running the tap at the same time to get the water to help.What is a bit misleading are the pictures of it being used with a pop-up drain cover. This is not easy to achieve and can really only be done by unscrewing and removing the plug entirely since the chain and "flower" interfere with the plug's functioning.Overall verdict: overpriced and too fiddly to use.

This is an interesting idea that should work, but doesn't deliver. This is a length of bathtub chain with some flexible plastic "wings" added and a plastic "flower" at the end to stop the chain falling down the drain. It's easy enough to insert into a grille-type drain, although I would suggest running the tap at the same time to get the water to help.What is a bit misleading are the pictures of it being used with a pop-up drain cover. This is not easy to achieve and can really only be done by unscrewing and removing the plug entirely since the chain and "flower" interfere with the plug's functioning.Overall verdict: overpriced and too fiddly to use.
Informative book for use at Temple University.

A great university care packet. My daughter was really pleased: "It was packaged really well, it was a box in another box and there was bubble wrap around it all. The basket itself was really well packaged and nicely presented: it had the fancy plastic wrap stuff around it and a golden bow which was really cute. There's a ton of candy in it and popcorn. There's also individual popcorn bags as well as the bucket. There's a free bag too :)"

This is a great story about a "dysfunctional family" getting to grips with their terminally ill father. Sounds miserable, but in fact it is hilarious, yet poignant. Super writing that you would expect from Andy Hamilton and Guy Jenkin. Great acting all round, but especially form the three young actors playing the children who steal the show with their matter-of-fact line delivery.British comedy at its best: wonderfully funny yet thought provoking.

Waste of time. This poorly manufactured, overpriced piece of garbage cannot cut in a straight line!Instructions:1. Print out item to be trimmed2. attempt to trim it despite all the pointless "safety" features: lift up the paper holder, press down on blade3. end up with odd, curved line4. reprint5. cut straight line with scissors.

Finally, a piece of furniture arrives in a box and I don't have to put it together!This is a nice modern style and no effort to unpack and stand up. I take off a star as there was a little damage: a scratch on the front frame at the bottom, and a glue mark of the mirror itself that was a bit of a pain to scrape off with a blade. Otherwise, it's a nice item.

This is a nice looking, cherry wood colored swing mirror. It comes as 8 pieces and takes about 10 minutes at the most to put together. You will need a screwdriver (Philips or flat blade) to tighten the 4 screw bolts for the crossbar.The back of the mirror is a little bit basic (stapled hardboard/fiberboard) but as this will face away from us I don't have any issue with this whatsoever.
Fantastic candle holder that can be used for years afterwards to make galloping horse sounds and amuse the children and grandchildren.

Every executive and politician should use this when addressing the crowds - it holds an iPad to display your vacuous platitudes and the toilet roll holder emphasizes what a load of bulls__t is being fed to the masses.

We've had this measure for several years now and it's held up well. At first we were bewildered by the fact that kitchen scales are not the norm in the US and that measurements for recipes seem to generally be dry volume quantities rather then weight. For those recipes that do use weights this handy measure bridges the gap by converting to volume for commonly used ingredients.
This is quite a small item that goes together easily and will hold one person's clothing. An ideal item for a dorm room. It has 2 carry handles to allow it to be carried to the washing machine.
This is a nice looking cushion cover. We stuffed ours with a couple of old pillows and it looks very pretty.

Solid made roof bars that are easy to fit and look stylish when in place. Initially I thought that the L-wrench to affix them was missing but then found that each bar stores one L-wrench in the right foot so you never lose it. Also comes with 4 keys to lock the covers. A nice touch was to include 4 small stickers to attach inside the top of the door frames This means you only have to measure where to put the bars once as it's quick to identify where to place the bars when subsequently refitting them.

Wow, when I was a kid "Welsh Rarebit" was basically cheese on toast with some mustard added to it. These days we need to have specific dishes to deliver this Cymric delicacy to our more refined palates. These small dishes are "perfect" if you like that sort of thing. They could also be used for serving avocados ....

If you like your science fiction full of fight scenes, lasers, noisy explosions in space, gratuitous sex, tentacled aliens and bugger all thinking then this ain't for you.If, on the other hand, you are capable of sitting still for nearly three hours without requiring a bathroom break or the need to check your phone and you have the ability to think, then this 169 minute epic passes in the blink of an eye.This movie is absolutely spectacular, both from the effects it uses as well as the breadth of story and ideas that it covers. As an aside, I especially liked the surprising design of the robots. Totally wacky, yet it works.Highly recommended[One slight, pedantic niggle I have, which is shared with every sci-fi film, is the odd inconsistency that is perpetuated when leaving the surface of a planet with a gravity similar to earth's. I'm not a physicist but I find it odd that huge 3 stage boosters packed full of fuel are needed to leave the earth's gravitational pull, yet when our protagonists need to come and go on another planet with similar gravitational pull then can do so with impunity using a simple lander craft. Perhaps someone can explain that?]
Great drives. Used one to create a Windows 10 restore USB and it worked very quickly.

This is an attractive device that sits in the middle of our stone bird bath and works as expected. The battery life is very long. My only gripe is that it occasionally stops due to small leaves/flowers getting caught it it and if it gets moved slightly from the center so that it isn't completely level. Otherwise a neat idea that keeps the water agitated and does the job.

A small group of WWII code breakers from Bletchley Park living in post-war London see patterns in a serial murder that other miss and uncover a twisted plot.This is an excellent mini-series that is full of suspense, excellent acting.
Really nice-looking, well made rug that brightens up the hardwood floor and is loved by the dog too!

This is a nicely painted and fairly heavy item, fashioned in the style of the coconut toys seen throughout the Caribbean and beyond.To operate you place the animal on the ground and then pull up the string, so winding the elastic powered roller underneath. As you lower the string the animal rushes forward, with head and tail swaying to the movement.At least that's the theory. Unfortunately, the one we received has the hole drilled too far back and so doesn't work properly. It can be made to work, but only by holding down the shell with your other hand, somewhat defeating the purpose.Nevertheless it remains a beautiful ornament.
This is a nice and sturdy trellis that is easy to put up, and looks good. Note it is quite heavy to manipulate.
Nice looking mat that fits inside a double set of French doors. Lose a star though as it keeps getting ruffled, although that's probably because  it's sitting on carpet rather than a hard floor.
It breathed life into my Samsung N120 notebook running lubuntu distro for under 20 bucks! Can't do better than that!

These fit snugly on a 4" wooden balcony rail. We have 6 on the front rail with ferns and nasturtiums in them and they look great. I drilled some holes in the base to let the water drain and obviously have no problems with water-logging plants.
Great value twin pack. 32GB in the camera means I never worry about running out of space, even when shooting RAW! Cards are fast and sturdy and I would recommend the Transcend brand.
Now you can stick Old Glory into anything soft, although I would generally suggest it's a cake.Great, easy to use product. When you have finished waving them that can even be used as toothpicks!

This is a truly amazing product to hold a variety of liquids, although I would suggest they are not hot as the glass may crack! I love that you can see the contents through the clear sides. The addition of a reusable screw cap makes it really useful too as the contents don't spill out when travelling. A simple counterclockwise twist to remove the elegant lid allows the liquid to be dispensed. Resealing it is easily achieved by reversing the process. This is a true marvel of engineering and I am amazed it hasn't been patented, as I am sure it could have many other applications.

An excellent set of letters and replies from Mr Henry Root, fishmonger to and from various political and other figures in the UK in the late 70s.The reader would probably benefit from some understanding the political climate and society in the UK in those times. It is difficult to know if the recipients thought he was real, mad, and/or serious.
Very nice luggage. It holds enough for a week if you pack properly and fits into an overhead bin on an Airbus 319 with no problems. No issues with airline policy regarding carry-on luggage.

Great kit for the summer. Easy to put together and use. Yes, the stakes are a bit flimsy but you should treat them accordingly. This set has been up on our lawn for several weeks now with no problems and is used regularly for a knockabout game. What on earth do some of the reviewers expect for this price?
A nice looking brush and pan set. Brush is soft and wide.

Great product that arrived rolled up and vacuum packed in an amazingly small box. Open up, put on the bed and allow to decompress and there you have it. My daughter was pleased with a decent night's sleep on this.
Very nice: came quickly!

Works well and seems sturdy enough so far. Easily rolls. It is NOT a spinner, that's why it only has two wheels... It fits in an overhead bin on an Airbus 319 with no problems as long as it is unexpanded. No questions asked form US Airways / American Airlines.It makes me laugh when people buy a case that is the right dimensions for carry on and then expand it to the full, including having bulges in the center of the case and wonder why it wont fit the bins. To be honest I think it was better when the airlines used to use frames that you had to be able to pass your hand luggage through. Pack correctly, rolling your clothing instead of folding and you can easily pack for a week in the sun with this.

This is a super lens for low light situations as well as for great landscape and street photography. It is ideal for indoor shots when you do not want to use flash. I attach this to my GX1 and carry my 45-200mm zoom as my standard kit no and I am very pleased with it.
Good tarp, made from woven plastic, that has stood up successfully through 3 heavy storms so far protecting our chicken coop.
I received this as a gift and was pleased with the gorgeous 1950's style artwork and delicious dark chocolate, which has a very slightly sweet taste.

It comes to something when a 13 year old says, "these aren't well made". Plastic is thinner than a Solo cup. If you are lucky you may get two uses out of them.Cynical marketing: "30 piece kit" means 10 cups, 10 inserts and 10 straws.Functional but very disappointing,

Returning from vacation to a front yard filled with at least a dozen different types of mushrooms rekindled my interest in these wonderful fungi. Bill Russell's book is an excellent read, with a casual style that imparts a lot of information.The book has a great introduction, basics of mycology and then is split into the characteristics of 100 commonly found mushrooms in this area of the country, separated by the time of year that they are found.I am looking forward to making spore prints and attempting to identify the variety of 'shrooms in our vicinity. I may even pluck up enough courage to eat some if I am sure I can identify them.

Pros: Quick to make - you need only a can opener, bowl and microwave. Cheap (a buck at the dollar store).Cons: Bland, thin sauce, weird texture, fiddly getting paper off tamales.Overall: OK for a quick hit, but I won't buy again and will stick to a can of chili.

Easy to use Wi-Fi extender.1. Plug into wall socket in same room as your router, wait for yellow power light to go green.2. Press the WPS button on extender.3. Next press WPS button on router and wait for WiFi light to go greenHey presto you have connected this to your wifi.4. Next unplug from socket and plug into power outlet where you want to extend WiFi (e.g., next floor)5. Wait for unit to boot up (power goes from oramge to green) and then watch as WiFi light goes green.6. Connect your devices to [YourOriginalWiFiNetworkName]_EXT using your usual password for [YourOriginalWiFiNetworkName]7. You are done... :-)

Brilliant little device. Ideal for the office!Pairing was tricky at first, so this is how to do it:1. Press and hold the button till the voice says "power on"2. IMPORTANT: keep holding the button until the voice states "pairing."3. Locate S530 on your bluetooth phone and pair it up.Works really well for listening to streaming music discreetly! I have used this for a while now and when co-workers come to my desk just a single push of the button stops the music. The way my desk is set up no-one even knows I am wearing this! :-)Edit:I had a problem today by somehow accidentally turning it to Chinese mode as i was having difficulty pairing to my phone. After some fiddling about I discovered that to switch back to English:1. Power it off2. Power it on and let go of the button before it tries to pair.3. Now the blue light is on (but not in pairing mode)4. Hold the button again for a second. The mode will then change back to English.On another note: Although the "Apple" type packaging is excellent it is a bit bulky to carry in your pocket! I have found an old 35mm film canister is a superb little container for the charging cable and the earpiece.

We purchased this from Sam's Club for a fraction of the cost, but even at the price here it's a good item. The product is easy to put together (just fix the metal spigot with the washer and nut provided). It holds a lot of drink and looks neat when sitting atop the galvanized bucket. It is sturdy (heavy)  and well made.This was a hit at a recent party.

I was so skeptical about this but in reality this is an astounding piece of equipment for the money. Easy to set up and compact. We attach this to a laptop with a DVD drive using HDMI cable and run a pair of USB powered speakers. Projected onto a white sheet over the garage doors or over the patio doors and this has been a success at two teenagers parties so far.

I gritted my teeth and opened this up to see what the angle would be. It is an interesting read and makes a lot of sense to freethinkers and similar-minded readers. I don't think it will sway any staunch GOP follower or Christian Conservatives (fundamentalists) though as they simply would never read the book in the first place. The text concerning why the South went from Democrat supporting to staunch Republican country after Truman was fascinating, and saddening. I cannot help but think that this great country could be so much greater if only the GOP wasn't so self-serving and manipulative of the South. If only the Southern states could focus on what is truly important, rather than being hoodwinked by the GOP all the time. For example, defending the confederate flag, and focusing on issues of religious intolerance means nothing if you have no health service, poor education and no welfare. The irony is how Jesus' words of compassion have been twisted so much and that the most "devoted" Christians have strayed so far from the path he espoused. I have to admit I have a whole new respect for the phrase "what would Jesus do" after having read this book. Undoubtedly, the answer is simply, LTN.

Well made, comfortable Crocs, that fit well. My family hate them as they think they are ugly and "European looking." I say they're comfortable and that's good enough for me. I'm wearing them at the beach, not with a business suit!
Super little ball head. Well made, versatile and fits easily on the 3 piece Targus monopod I carry to add more flexibility for shooting with my m43 set up. I definitely recommend this small mount.
Left light brown hair with high lights  nice and shiny but no sign of pink.

This is a funny film, and the acting by Vaughn, Franco and Wilkinson is excellent. To say the story was quirky would be an understatement. Unfortunately the trailer in the movie theater shows almost every funny scene. Be prepared for lots of nudity and swearing. There were some good opportunities for building out the characters of Franco and Wilkinson, but it didn't happen in the 90 minutes. Good entertainment, but not brilliant.
Great shoes that fit as expected, are light and comfortable. Almost like wearing slippers at the office :-)

I love this machine! I have a damaged knee and separated AC joint from an accident years ago so I am always careful about the impact of exercise and I don't run. This rowing machine is fantastic! The resistance is easily changed, it runs smoothly, is uncomplicated and provides a great aerobic workout.Highly recommended!

This is a fantastic spoof High School Yearbook. Considering this was done years before photoshop was available, the detail within the photographs is astounding. With the addition of the humorous text, Terry deRoy Gruber has created a true masterpiece that can be enjoyed over and over.Forget "grumpy cat," the looks on the feline faces that adorn the pages of this publication are just purrfect!
Super little wooden toy that will take a long time to master. It even looks good as an artistic desk ornament. The carry sling is a useful extra to keep it tidy when transporting.
The 5V transformer works ok but the cable does not. I assume there's a break in the wire somewhere but it's irreparable. Very disappointing

A great representation of Clifford Last's beautiful sculpture, spanning from 1948 through to the late 80's.Clifford Last was the son of Nella Last, whose diary, Nella Last's War: The Second World War Diaries of Housewife, 49, was published as part of the British Mass Observation Project during and after World War II. This is a fascinating "extension" to that story to see the work of her son, Clifford, once he returned from the Front.Clifford's sculpture is beautiful, both as classic sculpture and also in his extensive abstract work.
We have used a smaller on of these for over 6 years with no problems. This one fills a 4 ft gap on our deck to keep the dog in. It is too high to step over though, so bear that in mind.
Easy to use device. Small wheel and gear-driven counter with reset button. Telescopes down for transporting. Ideal for internal measurements, although we have also used it outdoors on pavement.

This is a bit fiddly to set up but it is a fairly sturdy trellis due to the double prongs of a decent length. There are no instructions so what I did was set up one pole hook the trellis onto it loosely to get an idea of whee to put the second pole, set the second pole and then attach the trellis. It took only a few minutes, and that's on rough, stony ground so I had to use a wooden block and a hammer/It looks good although, to be honest, using a couple of black zip ties will probably help with ensuring the trellis doesn't slip off the pegs on the pole.

Nice looking small obelisk. Comes in 3 parts. You will need scissors to cut the plastic ties and a small srewdriver to tighten up the screws that attach the pieces together. Takes about 5 minutes to build.For those who say it's too small - it is 40" tall - what do you expect?
Didn't last a day. Easily ripped. Total waste of time.

You gotta be kidding me! A few pieces of softwood with rounded edges and some roughly daubed dowels stuck in.You will also need a Phillips (cross head) screwdriver to attach the uprights to the "feet". Holes are not pre-drilled, but the manufactured did, at least, add a pencil line to indicate where to screw.This should really have cost about fifteen bucks at most.Extremely disappointing for the cost...Update: don't leave it outside overnight as the bases will warp. This item is a joke! I can only assume it was a 9th Grade wood shop project

Easy to use and fairly sturdy with decent length of steel pin to attach to the ground. I take off a star though as it's a bit pricey for what, in effect, is a wire fence.Tip: use a rubber mallet or a block of wood and a decent hammer so as not to damage the finish of the pins when knocking them into the ground.

It's a decent size inflatable but it simply didn't hold the air. I inflated this behemoth and hid it by the side of the garage so my daughter wouldn't see it. When i came to more it into view an hour later it was a flaccid cetacean :-(I pumped it up again and the same happened. Thankfully we were only using this as a background party decoration; there is no way this would have held up to small kids jumping on it.

Nicely made pinata which was broken open after a couple of whacks by the birthday girl using a length of 2" x 2" (!)I would give it 5 stars but the zip tie to hang it was broken so I had to make another hole in the fin and use another zip tie.Overall a good, fun item
Cheap flag for under five bucks. Does the job - it "flutters" appropriately and celebrates the current Union.

I can only comment on the table as the chairs still have not arrived!The table comes as 8 pieces: 1 top, 4 legs, 2 mid braces and a horizontal brace. i use the term brace 'loosely'.The 4 legs are metal and fit into flimsy plastic square holders which are loosely attached to the table frame. They are 'held in place' using a screw.  The attempt to add strength to this table is achieved by using a horizontal brace which is bolted in place across the 4 legs and the 2 mid braces. Initially, I thought there was a manufacturing defect but then I realized that the plastic holding the mid braces can simple be pushed along the underside of the table as you see fit. Interesting, as it's meant to add stability.The 25mm bolts used to fix the legs to the brace are tightened with the supplied hex key and so you cannot get too much pressure on them. They would have been better designed as proper hex bolt so you could fit a wrench/socket. Anyhow, it appears that only 3 of the 4 threaded holes that the bolt fit into have been drilled out sufficiently, so you will need a few extra washers to pack these out!Overall, an annoying and frail piece of  furniture. It will probably stand up as long I don't have to move it, but it surely isn't anything I would even lean against.Disappointing. I wonder what the chairs will be like?

This is a nice stylish kettle that boils pretty fast on 110V (but we still miss the UK 220V that boils in half the time!).The cut off works well enough and is quite quiet, not the usual "clunk" that you get with some models once the water boils. There's a light also to tell you when the power is on. It fits easily to the base and is convenient to use.Only downsides: this is quite a heavy kettle, even when empty. Also, for those who are used to more of a straight design, because of the bulbous shape you really do have to tip this a long way over to empty it when boiling a small quantity of water.Overall though, very pleased.

This is easy to fit to a Panasonic LX5. I had trouble removing my previous one, which did its job and took the crack instead of the screen, and used a tiny dab of WD-40 to remove the last traces of adhesive.A good investment.

There is no doubt that glyphosate (RoundUp) works as a total systemic herbicide I have used it for yeas, even in field trials in the 1980s. HOWEVER, the people that designed and marketing this worthless battery-driven sprayer were idiots. I have used many sprayers over the years and this is, without exception, the most unreliable piece of garbage I have come across. It just doesn't work properly or consistently to deliver a spray. It also causes foaming at the nozzle making using this product in this way an absolute trial by ordeal.Get a simple pump spray - so much better and nothing much to go wrong.

Great shoes for use about the house and yard. I have has a pair of vented Crocs for years but thought I'd try these unvented ones. They are comfortable, lights and also splash proof too. I love the flip-over croc band that makes these into clogs too.Great buy.

"Jeff's Wife"-- This plate is AWESOME! One, if not the best plate I own and I own a lot of plates. Every image stamps perfectly and beautifully. Each image is about 2cm tall and 1.5cm wide. I can't wait to do some ugly sweater manis! If you are looking for a Christmas plate, this is it!

"Jeff's Wife"- These brushes are great for making decals or lead-lighting. They are very comfortable in the hand. The metal part of one wasn't glued properly but nothing that couldn't be fixed with a little glue. They should hold up well since I'm not using them every day.

The price was right for was it is, but it's not the greatest thing since sliced bread.The point does not hold itself in the thread and constantly loosens. So much so that I lost the point for a few days in my bug out bag. A little thread locker worked.The flat end of the point protrudes through the inside of the ring when tightened completely. This causes abrasions and cuts to your finger when used. I took the flat end to the grinder to solve this issue, but that also took off any coating.The ring and point are stainless steel, but the chain is not.The ring is too small on my large size 8-1/2 man hands. I can only get the ring on my pinky finger. I wear a 11-1/2 wedding ring for comparison.For 7 bucks I'm not sending it back and it will work for most people.

My new LCR is an excellent CC firearm, but with my size 9 hands it's challenging to hold correctly and confidently.Fortunately Hogue makes a LCR No Finger Groove Rubber Tamer Cushion Grip (Model# 78030) that is slightly larger and provides a better grip area for large man hands.Installation was all of 5 minutes. 1) Take off old grip 2) Install new grip. I used a T10 (torx) driver to remove the screw. A slotted driver can be used but looks like it would be prone to slipping and stripping out.The end result was like night and day. My fingers were in proper alignment and I didn't feel like I would lose my grip if I squeezed too tightly. My pinky didn't slide back and was able to complete the hold.The images show before and after shots, plus my LCR riding in a DeSantis mini-scabbard holster.

As an advanced DIY'er, old car dude, and tool geek I was looking forward to reviewing this set. This set is very similar to what Bosch, Black & Decker, and Dewalt offer but at a much higher price point.The metal is basic, non-stainless, with no torque capabilities. But that is common with most inexpensive sets. The case is plastic, but some of the bits don't snap in tight enough causing them to bounce around and dislodge other bits.The bit selection is decent, but the average DIY'er will probably only use half of these infrequently, and the more popular slotted and phillips more frequently.The "bit grip collar" continually slips and doesn't properly hold the screw before torque. You'll be sure to punch holes in your drywall or scratch your wood projects. Best not to use it and buy one more purposefully designed like Dewalt or Bosch.For basic use, this is an adequate set, but the price is horrendous. $27? You've got to be mad. A similar, name branded set is easily half this price and will last you longer due to better materials and craftsmanship.Most of the less expensive bit sets are made in China, with some Taiwanese contenders. There are some USA varieties, and well worth the investment.

We use many eco-friendly bags for our shopping trips. This Snap Basket is a bit different than the normal soft sided bags.The weight capacity is 25 pounds. In perspective, that's equal to 3 gallons of milk.The 'rip-stop' fabric should hold up, but it's not as durable as canvas. Once this tears it will never stop contrary to what it says.It does collapse flat and opens with a 'snap' to keep the sides upright.Not sure about the 'stash' pocket for valuables. If I put anything in there I'm sure to forget about it.Only 3 stars because it's just an okay product. Way too expensive for what it's used for, but it does work as intended.I'll stick with the $1 bags canvas bags offered by my grocer.

"Jeff's Wife" I love it! The best wall rack for any person that has too much nail polish! It was extremely easy to install. Wall mounts were included. Currently it is holding 147 bottles, there is room for 1 more OPI and 2 more China Glaze. So I can get it to hold up to 150 bottles. Each shelf will hold 18 bottles of OPI. The shelves are wide and tall enough to hold a 2oz bottle of OPI Nail Lacquer Thinner.

I like this plate. I don't know if I love it though. But I do love the variety Halloween images. I did need to use a very flexible scraper, they aren't my favorite type of scraper, as some of the images have large etched sections. When I did get a clean scrape the images came out crisp. I did not use stamping polish for the swatches.

I think this will be an excellent stamper in my rotation. The only XL stamper I have to compare with is the one from Born Pretty Store, which is in the pics and always on the left. It comes with a little tiny scraper. lol I didn't even use it and more than likely won't. Scrapers like this, for me, are too difficult to pick up once I lay it down. It feels slightly softer than the BP one but not by much. As you will see it picks up regular polish excellently without priming. However it, just like the BP one, doesn't like MdU or Konad. Then I primed it with a paper towel soaked with acetone for 10 second intervals until it picked up. I think it could use one more go but I'm happy with it.

I work 12 hour shifts of which 75% is in constant motion. I'm always on the lookout for anything that will help the pains and stress.These insoles are unique, nothing looks like them. The construction seems tough and can handle some weight from a big guy like me.I wear big shoes and didn't have to trim these insoles. They just slipped right in.I could tell immediately that these felt differently than other inserts. My entire sole felt the cushioning effect, not just the heel.My first 12-hour shift in these insoles was better than without the inserts. My feet felt better and didn't feel 'jammed up' like before. The soles did not slip around or break apart.Another reviewer mentioned a bad smell. Well, it is plastic/rubber and those products do have a odor. But I would rather smell plastic than the feet of a high school locker room!I'm hoping they last at least 6 months.

It's a decent 12" ruler, but misleading about where it's made.I assumed that it was Made in the USA based on the ruler inscription, but the little tag on the back told the tale..Made in China.It's still a decent ruler, but I would have prefered a Made in USA product.

Store bought granola is like eating cardboard with a side of yoghurt or milk. Pamela's granola is a breath of fresh air.It's organic, not too sweet, and downright tasty. Granted I haven't tried many granolas but I know when I like something.It's crunchy so I let it set in milk for a couple of minutes. My wife likes it with yoghurt, while the rugrats like it plain out of the bag.

Store bought granola is like eating cardboard with a side of yoghurt or milk. Pamela's granola is a breath of fresh air.It's organic, not too sweet, and downright tasty. Granted I haven't tried many granolas but I know when I like something.It's crunchy so I let it set in milk for a couple of minutes. My wife likes it with yoghurt, while the rugrats like it plain out of the bag.

After 9 years we finally wore out our original set. It went through hell and back...kids, campings, backyard BBQ's, the oven and Barbie melting (don't ask).The new set is just as robust with a slightly thicker handle.They work on flat-top and glass-top stoves as well. Can be popped in the oven to awesome steak finishing techniques.

What's to say about a hot plate?It works as advertised. Heats my pot fast whether its beans, water, or dead swamp rat.I keep it stored in the box. I've used it approximately 20+ times now with no issues.

I took a chance on this EDT due to price and reviews. I never smelled it before.I'm glad I took that chance. It's an excellent scent. Very light and manly, not girly at all.The scent is a bit strong at first, but then mellows out nicely. My wife could notice it if she was close. Intimate close if you know what I mean ;)

The reviews of this wash were good as was the product video. But it was disappointing at best.The suds were disappointing. I normally use Mothers California Gold, which gives me tons of suds in the bucket or from the foam wand.The citrus wash did not make any more suds than Mothers, in fact it was much less. The difference was in the bucket. After a couple of minutes the big mound of suds that should have remained on top were gone. Big let down.Foaming this wash in the pressure wand made my car white, but no thick foam. If I had to measure I would say the foam was only a 1/8" thick. Very disappointing especially considering the hype and high cost.The scent was okay, but not enough to make me purchase it again. I gave the rest of the bottle to a co-worker that I don't like real well.

I really wanted to like this red dot. The price was right, the brand was right. So what happened? I couldn't see the red dot!My first range outing and the red dot was washed out in the sunlight. Unacceptable!I even tried reversing the sight on the mount. No luck.If you live somewhere with little or no sunshine this red dot might work for you. But it's a no-go in Florida.

Since my kidney surgery in July, I haven't been able to wear pants with a belt. These training pants have been a god-send for me. They fit well and look good at the same time. They're a little loose, but I like the free feeling.According to the wife, laundry care is super easy.My only quibble is the ties. They're flimsy, kind of like a cheap sneaker lace. But they do work. I would have preferred the wider ties like other brands.

Excellent pan. Our last one lasted 8 years and it went through hell and back. No complaints.The new version is just as robust, but a bit beefier handle.Works on flat-top and glass top stoves. Oven safe as well for those excellent steak finishing techniques.

I like the scent and luckily, so does the wife. The scent is a bit overpowering at first, but dies down within 20 minutes. The scent lingers very subtly for about 4-5 hours, but only if someone is close, very close.My only quibble is the spray nozzle thingy. It needs to be perfectly straight when applying. Kind of hard to do with man-hands.

I use this oiler for precise oil application in my firearms. The flow is perfect and the oiler does not leak when placed in the pocket.The pre-filled oiler was cheaper than the empty oiler. Go figure.I use a 5w synthetic oil in this oiler.

My wife uses this paste for her mini red bean cakes. Being pre-sweetened takes a lot of the work out of the process. Her little cakes taste as good as always.This is a huge bag, will make tons of cakes. Send me some!

Everything on my pack has held up well.No issues with the bladder, but I can see where if not installed properly it can split or crack, then leak all over your backside.The fit, finish, and sewing are decent. No split seams or missed areas.I got it on a deal and am happy.

Even though these are for plates, my wife was thinking outside the box when she ordered two of these.She uses them for small, soft covered notebooks. They stand nicely, don't sag, and look good in her craft room.
It's plastic but for my wife's "Fin Room" it's awesome.We bought several and placed on the top of each wall as a border.
DO NOT PASS THIS BY!This is a real Magpul sling. It's only 1" but built to last with excellent connectors and swivels.For under 10 bucks you CANNOT go wrong. Get some for your buddies as well.
I fill this oiler with synthetic oil for use on my firearms.There can be some leaking. Soak the inner fiber with oil and wrap the thread with white plumber tape.Works as needed and US made.

Decent sound and quality, but you're paying for the looks not the innards.I picked two of these up on a deal for $16 each. A rip-roaring deal at that price. But the are much better choices in the $50+ range.

I use T25  security screws on my auto license plate. I keep it in my glove box. You'd be surprised how many mechanics don't have security bits.I got this on a deal for $2. It's not worth any more than that. It's cheap and will not hold up to continued use.

We've used this brand of gloves for about a year. They work as intended, with no manufacturing issues.Non-latex if you have an allergy issue.However, they do run a bit small. I would order the next size up.

These Hefty bags work and work well with the zipper, but they are more expensive.We have a large family and have 2 extra freezers to store bulk foods. We use the gallon size mostly for veggies from the garden and bulk meats when they are broken down, like roasts.By using the regular zipper gallon bags you can save half the cost over these bags. That may not seem like a lot, but over a year it adds up.

I ordered 2 medium cases for my Tokarev and Sig 220. Even the medium cases are way too big. But I can also add 3 magazines. The cases seem better suited for revolvers with 6 inch barrels.The fit and finish is excellent and the zipper pull is adequately sized.Excellent case for the money.

Let's not confuse this electric chainsaw with it's gas operated big brothers. This B&D saw won't take down a monster oak or redwood, but for most homeowners it should be okay. Just because it has a 18" blade doesn't mean that you can cut down a 18" diameter trunk. You probably could, but you'd be there for 2 days and have to resharpen your blade 4-5 times.The instructions are easy to follow. Make sure you read EVERYTHING in the manual. Chainsaws are dangerous tools. You can lose a finger, eyeball, or testicle in the blink of an eye. Be careful!The build quality is on par for B&D, not great, not terrible, just middle-of-the-road.  With lightweight use and proper lubrication this saw should last many seasons.After installing the bar and chain, I trimmed my queen palm, red oak, and bald cypress trees. The biggest branch I tackled was 4-5 inches. The saw did it's job, but I noticed it does bog down when pushed too fast. Never an issue with a gas model.One thing I don't like is the cord. Imagine climbing a ladder with a chainsaw. That alone is dangerous, but now you've got cord dangling down from your waist and down the ladder. Yes I know it's electric and there is a cord, but this saw was sent for me to review. And honestly, the cord makes it very dangerous when above ground level. You'll need a second person below you so you can lower the chainsaw down out of your way.My recommendation for a lightweight saw would be a battery operated model. No cord! But if you need a saw with more oomph I would consider a gasoline version.The B&D is a cheapened version of the Oregon PowerNow chainsaw. Which is a better saw, but more expensive.

Another big name company trying to reinvent the disposable plastic cup.The package says 'crack resistant', but I got them to crack with some continued squeezing. The grip design does help, but when you're inebriated I don't think anyone really cares. :)There are less expensive choices from the off-brand companies. After all it's just a disposable cup.

I like the idea of stevia products and was looking forward to trying a different tonic water. Most diet tonic waters have no bite from the quinine and leave a bad after taste.Zevia's tonic water has little tonic water flavor and no bite from the quinine. Very disappointing.I guess if you're looking for a really mellow tonic water this would be okay, but it's not for true tonic water fans.

I was looking for a small, cheap extra range bag when I saw this NCStar bag. It's new with no specs and no reviews, but I took my chances ands was surprised.Size: 13"L x 9"D x 9"H - Decent size but closes into a triangle shape reducing some of the volume.There are pockets outside, inside, and mesh on the outside. The pockets will hold pens, pencils, small tools, 9mm magazines and other small items.The bottom is rigid and will accommodate most items, but I wouldn't test it with a  1,000 rounds of ammo. The top opens completely and has a sewn-in metal rod for rigidity.If you already have a pouch or rug for your pistol this bag would be ideal. It will hold a pistol, magazines, ammo, hearing protection and other items needed for a successful range day. It will also work as an extra bag for ammo, brass, or shooting accessories when at the range.I don't expect the bag to last more than a few years, but at a $6 price point I'm okay with that. It will do what I need, at a cost that's amazing.

OMFG!These cremes are amazing. Very creamy, light, and not too chewy to pull a cavity.Why did it take Hershey years and years to release this recipe?Note this is a 2.5 pound tin, which means that 11.89 pounds will be added to your 'bottom' line.Enjoy!

Going in, I was expecting the flavor of Clamato to fall somewhere in between a clam explosion and an old timey sea captains beard.  But it didnt.  Theyre not lying when they say a touch of clam.  Its surprisingly subtle.  Its there, but the spaghetti sauce flavor is the most in your face.  That and the salt.  Its salty.  Eight-hundred milligrams of sodium per eight ounces.  Blimey.I didnt have the clams to mix this stuff with beer, but I did whip up a Caesar, which is a Bloody Mary made with Clamato.  Not bad.  Still salty.  Probably not going to be my go-to cocktail.And what makes this a cocktail and not a cold soup anyway?  Its made with dried clam broth.  Its got spices.  Ive had less flavorful soups than this.  Is it just because its in a bottle?  Served in a glass and not a bowl?  Again, your input is appreciated.I was really hoping for something disastrous with Clamato, but altogether, its not bad.  I dont know if I would drink it even semi-regularly, but someone is enjoying it.  To each his own, I say!

Good concept, expensive to use. I was looking forward to reviewing this ceramic cutter as I've never used one before. Wow, was I disappointed.I compared the Slice cutter to my Olfa SVR-2 which has a similar blade cutting area (see my image).The Slice's body is plastic with a slight taper towards the blade. The three-position slide lock would loosen and slide back when any pressure was applied. The slide lock is positioned perpendicular to the blade, right where you would normally rest your thumb or index finger. This causes the lock to fail. The Olfa slide lock, on the other hand, does not move when engaged due to its side positioning.The blade on the slice protrudes correctly, but is rounded. There are instances when a sharp point is needed to puncture to start your cut, like thick packing tape or duct tape. The Slice's blades, being ceramic, are uber spendy. $13.68 for 4 blades. Ouch! No extra blades are included with the cutter.I tested the Slice cutter on manila bubble envelopes, paper/fiber packing tape, thick 3M packing tape, duct tape, standard shipping boxes, cardboard soda case bottoms, plastic blister packaging, and shrink wrap used on pallet wrapping.The Slice cutter work adequately on thin material, but fell short on thick cardboard or tape. Due to the thickness of the ceramic blade the Slice bogged down on the duct tape, where the Olfa just whizzed on by. Due to the rounded blade tip I couldn't get the Slice started on blister packaging.Bottom line, the Slice is extremely expensive, especially with it's shortcomings. The Slice cutter, with a pack of 4 blades will set you back over $26! The Olfa, however, costs only $13 for the cutter and 130 blades!I cannot justify paying double for a simple cutter that performs poorly on various materials.
Just the right size for adding 1/2" numbers to my magazines.Thick board stock that should last.Be careful when pulling out the cut outs, they're small.
These are small as others have stated. But even my big 8-1/2 sized hands can use them effectively.Super sharp right out of the package.

I always took TP for granted. Buy TP, usually on sale, use TP, then repeat. Never gave much consideration for weights, widths, strengths or scents. Although I know that 1-ply TP is a disaster waiting to happen.When I got this Charmin TP I noticed it was thicker than anything else I tried and very soft. So far so good.Then I did some internet exploring and learned that the TP manufacturers manipulate the lengths of the rolls, width of the sheets, and thicknesses to ply extra month from us. Why is TP advertised so heavily on TV? It's not like it's something we don't need.Then I came across test results of Charmin's Ultra Strong.The pros were strong, absorbs well, and rated softest.But the cons were dissolves slowly (bad), and low weight per roll (mean less TP for your money).It's your choice, but for the money I'll stick with my Kirkland brand TP. I get 36 rolls of Kirkland for $19, but only 24 smaller rolls of Charmin Ultra for $25.

Amope's Pedi Perfect is a decent and effortless way to keep your toe and finger nails natural looking and shiny.It's easy when you follow the 3 steps:Step 1: File nails--allows filing and shaping to help prevent nail damage.Step 2: Buff nails--to even out ridges and smooth the nail surface.Step 3: Shine nails--instant natural looking shine.I like it, but don't like having to replace batteries or pads.

The tape dispenser works as it should, but the tape included should be thrown in the river ASAP.I found the dispenser works best with 3M or Scotch brand tape.Otherwise, the dispenser is nice change from your basic black.Looks like a whale. Cute.
