Love, love, love these headphones. here were the ups and minor downs for me.- Great sound quality on my iphone and ipad- completely comfy- Comes with attachments you put on between the ear plug and cord that will keep them in and on your ear even when you're running or walking- Also, Comes with a nifty carrying case and extra different sized ear plugs to fit any ear- Totally tangle free cords!My wish and minor down on this one is that it doesn't have a "take or ignore the call" button/mic on the wires --- so, can't automatically join calls without digging out the phone to do so.Bottom Line: Highly recommended for all it's great features - but not if you are looking for one that has a mic/answer call option

This heavy-duty stapler could fool you - because it's so light and easy to use, you wonder if it really will have the necessary power. It does!  I'm not a fan of most tools - have neither the skill nor the muscle to make most of them work the way I want them to work. But, this makes attaching things to wood or walls a breeze!Bottom Line: Powerful, user-friendly device I think everyone should have.

I haven't gone totally paperless yet --- and I'm always having to sign things, so I like the clever quality design of this that lets me cart around both a stylus and a pen at the same time.  Pen is high quality and cartridge can be replaced.  Nice, elegant size - not too thick, but not as thin as it looks in the picture.  It's a favorite thing of mine for Christmas gifts, as well.

Like others I was using Norton McAfee before.  Here's what I liked about this - and the one thing that keeps it from getting five stars.1. Doesn't take as much RAM2. Not a lot of annoying pop-ups and things telling I need to do something3. All-in-one perfection ease - covers everything so that I don't have to have another protect me from various web issues (phishing, putting data in unsecure sites, etc.)4. Covers up to three computers --- my laptops and my desktop.5. Ease of set-up - simple, accomplished in no time and it simultaneously (w/ my permission) removed my McCaffeeOne downside on mine and one that I've heard from a friend (am not counting that one towards my review - but, might want to be something you check out if it relevant to you...)Mine: Lately, it has random crashes of the web site protection feature.  Doesn't hurt my computer - but just stops working and tells me so.  So far, haven't had any security breaches I know of.A friends: He used a VPN connection on his computer and something in the Norton settings messed it up entirely (those VPN connections can always be a little tricky to me - and I don't have one on any of the ones I've installed it into)BOTTOM LINE: I like it far better and feel better protected with this easy to use all-in-one security system over McCaffee and it's priced much lower than I paid for that one for a single license.

This both a wonderful coffee table book - as well, as a fascinating photographic tour and exploration of more than 100 of the world's greatest designs. It includes an eclectic mix of well-designed items --- not just furniture, and some of them are bound to send you down memory lane --- from artichoke lamps and egg chairs to vespas and the moulton bicycle.  Highly recommended for anyone who loves design.

Here's the ups and downs of this one with me:- The sunshine scent is just a pure, fresh light clean smell that I'm looking for in a detergent.  Love that.- Not terribly a fan of powder based detergents - when I follow the quantities indicated on the package (or even when I reduced them somewhat) with this one - I still ended up having to put through a rinse cycle again to clear out the detergent signs lefts on jeans. Maybe this formula just doesn't work as well in Houston water.- I don't think that it was as effective at removing stains as Tide with Bleach - but then again, maybe the stains were just worse.Still, think I'd go for Tide over this one - even if P&G does make them both.

If tumblr makes publishing on the web easy - why do I need a book about it? That was my first thought.  But, then I realized my real question was should I publish on Tumblr or somewhere else.  This book starts out by telling you what Tumblr does and it's advantages and disadvantages - then walks you through the steps in detail.  It's  written in a simple, direct and lightly humorous way that makes it a friendly guide.  It's also filled with colorful screenshots and pictures to make sure you understand what you are supposed to be doing.  From signing up to your account to more advance techniques - this book covers the gamut, without bogging you down in a bunch of technical mumbo jumbo.Bottom Line: Thinking about publishing something on-line from a blog to a portfolio? Then maybe you want to grab this book and check out Tumblr.

There is no doubt, this is one smart "Cookie" of a toy.  My six-year old princess fell in love with her immediately - and it hasn't been a short-term affair.  She constantly comments on how soft her coat is and with the help of 4-C batteries acts like a perfect little happy puppy lady, including chewing her bone.I agree with another reviewer that about the 5-8 range is where this gift lies, and for the most part it will make a wonderful gift. There's only one caveat, if you or the person you are giving the gift to already has a real dog - this may not be your best choice of gift.  The bone Cookie chews is easily confusing to a real dog as their squeaky toy. In fact, the young mixed mutt real puppy exposed to Cookie was completely bewildered by her, she thought it was supposed to be her toy and playmate.BOTTOM LINE: A great, highly-entertaining and engaging gift for a six-year old princess (this really is designed all the way as a girls toy - right down to the pink and purple accessories) that is probably best for those that do not already have a dog in the house.

A purple airplane, a pretty little girl, and a puppy with lots of accessories made this a hit with my six-year old princess.  It's a good size and she has spent a lot of time imagining Blythe and her pet friend are taking exotic journeys.  Sometimes she has Blythe be the pilot and sometimes she's the passenger, either way this is a toy that has delivered a lot of good, simple imaginative play.The plane opens up in much the same way as a doll house and provides that type of experience, but with a more exciting travel theme.  Since the princess's father is a pilot this may have had a bit more appeal than to some.  But, overall I think if you have a 4-7 year old that has ever been on a plane or dreamed of traveling to far off places - this is a great, good quality gift.  It'd also make a great birthday gift if you're looking for one for a girl this age.

As other reviewers point out this is not your typical thriller.  It's more of a blend of a mystery-who-dunnit thriller with the tale of a woman coming to terms with the loss of her sister and discovering her inner strength.  Here was why I liked it - and where I think it might not appeal to some based on their tastes.Short Summary: Older sister is unconvinced that her sister's death was a suicide and goes on a hunt to find the killer. She writes an open letter to her sister to tell her of the pursuit.1. For me, this was a page turner - but, not in that normal thriller way.I read this in one day.  I was captured by Beatrice's pursuit of tracking down clues to discover who and why her sister died equally as much as by her blossoming understanding of her sister and the dynamics of her family. Most thrillers are more short chapters of action and suspense.  This one not so much.  So, if that's what you truly enjoy - you're going to like this one less.2. It's well-written with an equal focus on character development and family dynamics.This book shines beyond a thriller by bringing to life the complex dynamics of relationships with her mother, siblings, father and fiancee as she grows to better understand herself through her sister's death. If you're not into well-written more introspective looks at familial relationships - or stories of women finding themselves bore you - this probably won't be your cup of tea - even if it's, in my opinion very well written.3. You don't have to have a sister to enjoy it - but there's no doubt you'll enjoy it more if you are a woman.I don't have a sister, and yet could relate to the dynamics of the sister relationship. And, even more so within all of Beatrices relationships there is something I think most women, but not men, might relate to within themselves. To me, this is the type of book that will appeal to people who also liked Before I Go to Sleep: A Novel, Still Missing or other more psychologically relation-based thrillers versus your typcial action or who-dunnit thrillers.4.Don't read it because everyone says it has a twist.Yes, it does twist in a surprising way that I found unique and relevant.  But, more importantly for me is that it really did seem a great way to bring the entire big theme of the book together. That was realy it's true beauty to me.BOTTOM LINE: A well-written, intriguing book that kept me turning the pages through its combined tale of a who-dunnit mystery with the story of a woman finding her inner self and coming to terms with the relationships in her life. But, you're not going to like it as much if you're expecting twisting suspenseful and action-filled turns on every page - it's just not that type of thriller.

I'm a sucker for any ab machine infomercial. So, I have the full gamut of products. Here's my rating and comparison on this one vs. what they promise and vs. the other available products to help you decide if it's for you.1. Quality - 5.0 starsThis is a very-well constructed, sturdy piece of exercise equipment - particularly for the price. Really capable of dealing with even taller or wider people.2. Ease of Assembly/Space Needed/Storage 3.0 StarsAssembly is not too hard (I was able to do it and I'm technically challenged), but it's not as easy as many of the infomercial machines which come totally together.  I find the space needed for this one and the storage more challenging.  While out - it takes up about 6-1/2 feet by 2-1/2 feet of clear space to use - or almost as much as a couch.  At the same time, it's not really attractive enough to be putting out as a general lounger. Storing it, isn't as easy as the infomercial makes it appear.  It's big and bulky even folded up. And, all of those quality materials mean it's heavy and more challenging both to fold and find a place to hide away.3. Ease of exercises - 5.0 StarsThis is as easy to use as promise.  It provides great back support - if you are one of those whom typical crunches and other machines sometimes hurt your back.4. Effectiveness of exercises - 4.0 StarsThis really does allow you to get in those long crunches that stretch your muscles and allows you to hit those hard to hit lower abs.  There's exercise routines included on the CD - or you can just sit in it watching your favorite TV show and do your favorite exercises from it.  The area that it's not as effective on are those side ab muscles.  For that, I still stand by my all time most favorite infomercial product AB Dolly Plus.  But, this one is more comfy than that one and you'll definitely feel and see it working if you use repeatedly.5. Desire to use repeatedly - 4.0 StarsFor me, these machines always come down to "Do I want to use it often and does it work?"  The answer on the first part of that question for me is "it depends".  When I have it out and sacrifice the space and look of the room - I use it regularly.  But, it's such a pain to get out and then put away - when I don't want it hogging up space - it can stay tucked away for a long time.  But, it does work.BOTTOM LINE: Good quality, fine ab machine that works.  But, make sure you really have the space needed to allow you to leave it out somewhere to really encourage you to use it regularly.

Wow! Don't those late night infomercials make this one look great?  There's a lot of problems in this one both versus what they say and versus other Ab machines out there (and I swear - I pretty much have them all, I'm a sucker for a good infomercial).So, here's the rankings vs. what they promise:- A back massage and neck support: 0 starsThose rollers sure look like they'd give a massage - but, in fact, they are not comfortable and there is definitely no massaging going on. I'd say this is easier on the back than crunches - but not by much. Since the back is one size fits all - whether you get neck support is going to vary by your neck and torso length.  Tall people be particularly wary. That said, you are not on it that long. It's really a five minute work out.- Quality: 1-starReally flimsiy made for an exercise machine.  Particularly cheap handles and attachments.  Doesn't click the way they say it will in the ads. If you are a larger/wider person this thing may not stand up to your weight, and the small seat is definitely going to bother you.  It's made cheaply all the way around - or there is poor quality control going on.- Ability for anyone to use it - 4.0 StarsComes with a DVD that has routines for every level from beginner to advanced, and three different level tension cords that attach the seat to the back that make the exercises harder or easier. There's also they typical meal planner and recipe book that comes w/ all of these because any promises of losing inches ARE ALWAYS based upon you BOTH following the plan and using the machine.- Value of exercies for abs - 3.0-4.0 starsIf you just sit on this thing and rock up and down like a rocking chair, as the ads imply, it won't hurt - but isn't going to do that much good (and there's far better machines out there for that like the Ab Lounge Sport that give you better range more comfortably. However, those are harder to work the obliques - and the twister motion on this works.  But, the way this does the most is by following the routine that's appropriate for you on the DVD.-Versus other ab products 1-starI liked the idea of this because I thought it combined the benefits and ease of the Ab Lounge (without being so big and bulky) and my favorite all time informercial ab machine, the AB Dolly Plus (without requiring the hard floor space to use) into one.  But, the poor design and flimsy construction, plus the lack of comfort using it just don't stand up.BOTTOM LINE:  There are better all around and better made ab products out there that will do the job as effectively, if not more so.  This one just doesn't deliver on the promises of the ads and for the cost it's quality is below par. It's just not one I'd want to use everyday. Recommend looking at other options.

This was a solid, engaging thriller that had some ups and downs to me.  Here they are to help you decide if its for you:SHORT SUMMARY: Unemployed woman gets dream job in art gallery - only to find herself in the midst of a set up for murder.  Separately, another girl goes missing.  Who is trying to set her up? Can she extract herself from this mess? How did the girl go missing? Where has she disappeared to?1) A well-plotted who-dunnit with an intriguing conceptFrom the first page, the writer had me intrigued with Alice and set up a complex whodunnit plot. If you like following clues and and trying to figure out who and why is behind it all - this is well plotted for that, with lots of twists and turns as clues are revealed.  Having said that, while it all ties together well in the end with some surprising revelations - I'm not sure enough clues were laid down really for having anyone piece it together before the end.2) There's a side story about a missing girl that seemed out of place.Though the author weaves the two tales tangentially together - it has a totally disconnected feel to it.  If it's supposed to be a red herring, for me, it didn't really work. Partly because that line of the story gets short thrift at the end, and feels forced.3) I found myself invested in the answer to the plot, but not the charactersI just didn't find I cared about these characters.  Admittedly, there are a lot of them - and that side-story doesn't help - so much of the character development gets short thrift. Initially I was invested in Alice plight, but as the story progresses even she seems to have only surface emotions and reactions. I just wish I had cared and understood the key players characters and releationships more - it would have made the book and the resolution that much more enjoyable to me.BOTTOM LINE: 3.5 Stars for a solid, engaging whodunnit.  While it's not a book "I couldn't put down" it is one I wanted to continue reading to see where it lead.  So, it makes it good as a summer pool-side or plane ride read.

For me, this was a solid, but not-as-suspenseful-as-I'd-hoped of a psychological thriller. Here were the ups and downs I found to help you decide if it's for you.Short Summary: Adopted woman decides to find her biological parents only to discover her father is a serial rapist-murderer who is still on the loose.  Through her search the serial killer discovers he has a child - and now he's determined to connect to her.  She turns to the police and works with them to help catch him.  Will they be able to catch him before he kills again? What does it mean to her and her child that they share a crazy pyschopath's genes? Will he hurt her or those she loves before he can be caught?-  Stevens resurrects her original unique approach from Still Missing, of telling the story through a series of sessions by the protagonist with a psychiatrist (who never speaks). While still original, it doesn't work as well in this book as it did in the former. For me, in this one, the sessions weren't believable and acted as a a distraction.- Stevens is a good writer and the concept is unique, but as executed it didn't provide the page-turning suspense needed to make this book as great as her first.I love a unique concept and do this one as well.  Unfortunately,  While there's a psychological mystery built into it - it's really not apparent until the end. And so, most of the book has the main character annoyingly continually vacillating on whether she should or should not help her bring her serial murder father down - based upon some rather unbelievable pressures and opinions by her fiance, adopted father, police and her family. Every chapter in the middle was just another bout of her doing the "should I talk to him or see him, shouldn't I talk to or see him" game. It became tedious and made putting the book down pretty easy.- At the same time, there was enough that was engaging about it to make me want to finish it - and it's really a couple of surprising twists at the end that actually turned this into a real psychological thriler for me.Bottom Line: While a decent, solid psychological thriller in large parts due to a couple of twists at the end -it didn't live up to my expectations based upon the authors first book, "Still Missing", which I loved.  If you are a first time Stevens reader - go for that one instead, and for more page-turning psychological suspense I'd have to say I recommend Before I Go to Sleep: A Novel or Room: A Novel before and over this one.

Whenever I see the word "Bleach" I think of my colored clothes getting bleached out. But, that wasn't the case here. Here's what I liked and the minor downsides I found w/ this detergent to help you decide if it's for you.1. It did exactly what it promised - the white were whiter and the colors were brighter (and I have a bad habit of throwing them all in together - and this still worked wonders).2. It did a great job of lifting out tough stains. Though I didn't pretreat any of them - they were all gone.3. "Can that little of detergent really clean a whole wash?" That was my thought when I followed the directions and put in the amount. "Wow! that's pretty efficient" was my thought after the clothes were cleaned.4. Nice, clean fresh smell.Still, it hasn't changed my preference towards liquid detergents. They've just never come up with a good way to package these powder ones. The box (on all of them, including this one) is hard to open and doesn't reseal, which isn't good if you store on a higher shelf.I also am a fan of the alternative Tide versions that have the proprietary Actilift in them. While this took out some tough stains - Actilift I've seen lift some amazing levels of stains easily.Tide runs more than other brands typically. But, having tested them - I firmly believe they have better quality than the others. They also, unlike many of the others, don't make private label version of their soap that grocers can sell - so the only way to get the quality is to pay for it.Bottom Line: Though my preference runs towards liquid and the Tide Actilift versions this is an efficient, high-powered powdered detergent that delivers whiter, brighter, cleaner clothes and gets stains out.

These quart-size Hefty Slider Storage Bags are ideal for everyday use. For things like packing sandwiches or snacks for lunches, storing some leftovers in the fridge for a few days, or organizing odds and ends, they're great. Unlike some reviewers, I've had no problems whatsoever with the sliders creating and keeping a tight seal. In fact, I find the sliders much easier to use than the standard seals used on Ziploc bags. (Boy, I sure have trouble getting *those* to close sometimes!) My only complaint? I wish the bags were just a little bit thicker. I realize these are standard bags and not freezer bags (which are 35% thicker), but they still seem a little too thin to me. That said, they still work well and are a good value.

This is a brutally honest memoir about love and mental illness. Like some other reviewers, I find it very hard to believe that it took so long for Sheila Hamilton to recognize her husband's illness; but who am I to judge? Without being in the same exact situation, we can't say for sure if we would have realized what was going on any sooner. The important thing about this book is that it brings mental illness into the open, and shows the world the devastating effects it can have on individuals, spouses, and families. It also includes resources that can educate people about mental illness, which may lead some people to getting the help they so desperately need. That's a wonderful thing.Toward the end of the book, Sheila Hamilton writes:"Grief is like an unwelcome stranger, an abductor who comes just at the moment you least expect and puts a black sack over your head, whisking you away to a dark, unknown place. Just when I thought I could cope with the idea of David's absence, I would wake up confused and traumatized all over again."Sheila Hamilton's soul-baring honesty makes this book a winner. As Bren Brown says, "When we push down hurt or pretend that struggle doesnt exist, the hurt and struggle own us." That's why transparency is always a good idea. I commend Hamilton for telling her story and hope that she can eventually break free from her grief.

This is a terrific space heater that will keep any standard size room toasty warm. Unlike a lot of heaters, this Vornado VH10 has a sleek and appealing design. And although it's made of plastic, the build quality is very good. Controls are on top of the unit and very simple: on/off, hi/low, and a rotating dial to adjust temperature. The one thing that really surprised me about this heater is how crazy quiet it is. I've used a lot of different space heaters over the years, and this is by far the quietest of them all. It would be perfect for a bedroom or baby's room. I also like the cord wrap that's integrated into the bottom of the unit. A little thing, for sure. But it's really convenient. The handle that's built in to the top also makes it easy to carry from room to room if you need to. Add in a nice 5-year warranty, and this heater is truly top-notch. The only thing I don't like about the VH10? The price. At around $80.00, it seems a little overpriced, which is why I only gave it a 4-star rating. (If I could've rated it 4.5 stars, I would have.) But maybe this is an instance of "you get what you pay for." Trust me: There are a lot of bad heaters out there at budget prices. This Vornado is pretty darn nice.

I've used plenty of space heaters over the years and I have to say: This Dr. Heater DR-838 Family Ceramic Heater is the worst. Yes, the heater does provide decent heat. So there is that. But the build quality of this heater is absolutely awful. As at least one other reviewer pointed out, the metal used for this heater is pretty flimsy. When you put the heater down on a hard surface, it sounds like you're setting down an empty tin can. The front grill can be bent simply by pushing on it with your fingers. I can only imagine what would happen to it if it was accidentally kicked by someone wearing a shoe. And the biggest joke of all? The foam electrostatic filter on the back of the unit. It's so thin, I thought it was a piece of scrap foam that was used as packing material. (How thin is it? Look at the photo I've included and you'll get an idea.) It's supposed to slide into two grooves, but it's so thin and flimsy that they had to stick two pieces of tape on the back to help hold it in place. The instructions for the heater say that you should clean the filter once a month by "vacuuming filter clean." Are you kidding me?!? If you tried vacuuming the filter, it would end up getting sucked into the vacuum cleaner in an instant. I have no doubt that this filter will start to rip and tear in no time at all. My favorite thing about this heater is the handle on the top. It makes it easy to carry. Other than that, this heater seems like something you'd find on the clearance table at a discount store. Believe me, there are way better options out there. (For example, the Lasko 754200 Ceramic Heater with Adjustable Thermostat is fabulous. I bought two of them seven years ago and they are still going strong. I've never had a problem with them.)

I've used Macs for the last 15 years or so, but I have to admit that Microsoft's suite of productivity software has always been better than anything Apple has offered. I got Microsoft Office Home & Student 2016 for Mac to replace the Microsoft Office 2008 that I've been running on my MacBook Pros for quite some time. (What can I say? It did what I needed it to do!)Of the four programs included with this version of Office, I will only use two of them--Word and Excel--with any regularity. PowerPoint is nice to have, I suppose, but I rarely use it. And I've been using Evernote for a few years now, so I won't be using OneNote at all. That said, Word and Excel are worth the investment all by themselves.Downloading the software was simple, although it did take quite a while--a little over an hour using my 70 Mbps Internet connection--and installation was a breeze. I am not a Microsoft Office power user, so I can't speak to the differences between this version of Office and the older version I was using, other than the 2016 version has a much cleaner look. It also seems to be faster, which is definitely a good thing.Microsoft's Office has been the standard office software for several years now, and I don't know of anything out there that's a threat to stealing that title away from Microsoft anytime soon. So if you own a Mac and do word processing, spreadsheets, or slide shows, you should probably own this software. Whether or not you get the Home & Student edition--which is only good for use on a single Mac--depends on your particular situation. Your other options are Microsoft Office Home and Business 2016 for Mac | Mac Key Card (which adds Outlook to the mix); or Microsoft Office 365 Home 1 Year | 5 PC or 5 Mac Key Card (which adds Outlook, online storage, and allows use on 5 Macs and 5 tablets, but is an annual subscription instead of a one-time payment).One thing to be aware of: You have to have OSX 10.10 or above on your machine to use this version of office. So that means Yosemite or El Capitan. If you are still running Mavericks--or anything earlier--you will have to upgrade before you can use this software.Lastly, I don't quite understand why the key card for this software has to be mailed to you. Other than the actual key card with the Product Key number on it, all you're getting is a little cardboard box and a small piece of cardboard with five short steps on how to set up the software (a grand total of about 50 words). Isn't this something that could be emailed to purchasers? Why waste the materials and resources to mail it? If anyone knows the answer to that question, please let me know.

I already own an Olympus VN-702PC Voice Recorder, but decided to upgrade and give this Olympus WS-853 a shot. Boy, am I glad I did! I have to say, the WS-853 is better than my older model in a lot of ways--better sound, more storage, more features--but the one feature I like the best is the direct USB connection. After I record interviews, I frequently upload them to my Mac. With my older Olympus recorder, I was constantly fumbling with the (very short) USB cable needed to upload files to my computer. What a pain! Now all I have to do is pop out the built-in USB connector and I'm ready to roll. A simple thing, yes, but what a relief! (By the way, the recorder is compatible with both Macs and Windows computers.)The WS-853 does a great job of recording voices in pretty much all settings. The stereo microphone system is terrific, as is the automatic recording level adjustment option. Playback sound of the unit is excellent, especially for a device this small. The storage capacity--8 GB of memory that will record 2,080 hours--is surely more than enough for most people's needs. And if it's not, you can even add a MicroSD card for even more capacity. In addition, the two AAA rechargeable batteries (included) are very convenient--especially since they can be charged via USB.There are several functions on the WS-853 that a lot of people might not need to use, but don't fret. Olympus has outdone themselves by providing a "Simple Mode" for this recorder. Selecting this mode offers a "no-frills" option that displays only basic information and limits the available functions to the most commonly used. The display font is also larger in "Simple Mode," which is great for old people like me. ;)All in all this is an incredible little device. Yes, there are more expensive digital voice recorders out there that have more features. But I have to believe that the Olympus WS-853 is the perfect choice for the vast majority of people shopping for a compact, full-featured, quality voice recorder. I highly recommend it.

These are very nice, very large (about 30" x 37") kitchen towels. They are all cotton and made in Pakistan. My wife and I tried drying dishes with them the other night, and they work great. But they're even better for covering and wrapping bread dough. (We bake a lot of bread from scratch.) A simple product, but very handy in the kitchen!

In the interest of full disclosure, let me state up front that I'm a Mac guy. I've been using strictly Apple computers and devices for the last several years, with the exception of a couple of Windows laptops I was issued by my employer. Even so, I have found this ASUS Transformer Book Flip TP200SA-DH04T 11.6" laptop to be a very handy machine.The size of this device is very handy. It's just about the same thickness as my 13" MacBook Pro and is very light. This makes it very portable. It was also very easy to set up. From the moment the unit was first turned on, I was guided through the setup process on-screen and everything went very smoothly. To my surprise, I even found Windows 10 to be very manageable. In the past, that hasn't always been the case with me and Windows.The speed of this Transformer isn't the greatest, but it's still decent. I noticed the biggest slow-downs when browsing the Web and watching videos. I'm not sure if this is a hardware issue or if it might have something to do with the Microsoft Edge browser. (I've also tried Google's Chrome browser, but can't really say that it made things any faster.) The storage space on this machine is pretty limited, so I'm thinking it would only suffice as a secondary device for most people. Even though the advertised storage capacity on the SSHD is 64 GB, I checked this morning and Windows tells me that there is only 29.9 GB of free space left. That's not very much, and the only thing I've downloaded or saved to the device is Google Chrome. That said, ASUS does provide 500 GB of Web storage space, which appears to be entirely free. So if you don't mind storing stuff in the Cloud, maybe you'll be alright.My biggest complaint about this "laplet" is the display. The size is perfectly fine, but the actual display seems like it could be a little sharper. I'm used to the Retina display on my Apple laptop, so maybe I'm just a little spoiled. But after a few hours of using this ASUS, I find that my eyes are a bit more fatigued than usual. Maybe it's something I'll get used to, though.The versatility of this laptop/tablet is really nice. I really like being able to use it as a normal laptop, and the keyboard has a nice layout and feel to it. The touchpad works well, too. It's also terrific to be able to rotate the display around and turn this computer into a tablet. The touchscreen works very well, and using the tablet is very reminiscent of using an iPad. The ability to use the Transformer as a notebook OR tablet, or in "stand mode" or "tent mode" is certainly a plus. (That said, I have yet to figure out how to make the display have the proper orientation while in tent mode. Every time I try tent mode, the display is upside down. I tried searching ASUS's support site for a solution, but apparently it's too early for there to be any support online for this unit. So I'm not sure if this problem with the display is a hardware or software problem. But hopefully it will be remedied sooner rather than later.)The ports and slots on this machine are also nice. On the right side you have a USB 2.0 port and a headphone/headset/microphone jack. On the left side you'll find the power input port, volume button, power button, a MicroSD card slot, a micro HDMI port, a USB 3.0 port, and a USB Type-C port. There is no optical drive, but that's certainly not unusual these days. (Even my MacBook Pro doesn't have one.) I've had no problems at all with any of the ports or slots, although I will say that I'm not a fan of how the power cord connects to the unit. The end of the power cord is small, almost like a mini USB cord. Getting it into the power input port can be a little tricky, and once it's in there, it's in there tight. I've already had a couple of incidents where I almost pulled the Transformer off of my desk because I got a little caught up in the power cord while the device was charging. (A connection along the lines of Apple's MagSafe connector would be so much nicer.)All in all, this ASUS laptop/tablet is a pretty nice device. Is it good enough to be your primary computer? Probably not. But it's certainly more than good enough to be a very formidable secondary machine. I think it will be especially good for traveling, or for other times when I don't need to have my primary laptop with me. For the price, I don't think you can go wrong.

I've had this Brita pitcher for a week now and I have no complaints whatsoever. It's the perfect size, is easy to lift and pour from, and looks much nicer than my old Brita pitcher. I know a lot of people here have complained about the top being loose, but I haven't experienced that. The top to my pitcher fits nice and snug, and I've never even seen it move when I've poured water, let alone come off. Likewise, I've had no problems with the filter not staying seated, either. Perhaps those issues were present in earlier runs of this pitcher, and maybe Brita addressed them. For me, this pitcher is top-notch. Really like the LED filter status indicator, too.

I'm a big fan of all kinds of jerky, and even love quite a few Jack Link's products. But I have to say that these Flamin' Buffalo Chicken Tender Bites are terrible. Visually, they are just plain gross. Chunks of meat that look like they've been sprayed with orange paint. The texture? Kind of mushy. And the taste? Well, let's just say it's not very good. These bites didn't taste like chicken to me, and the "Flamin' Buffalo" flavoring was very bland, with pretty much no spice whatsoever. Flamin'? Hardly. If I were you, I'd steer clear of these little nuggets. They may be high in protein and low in calories and fat, but other than that they're rather disgusting.

The Bose Wave Music System IV is the latest version of a product that has been incredibly successful for Bose. And there's no doubt as to why it's been so successful: the Bose Wave packs a lot of punch for something with a relatively small footprint, which makes it perfect for use in a bedroom, standard size living room, or anywhere you want to listen to great sounding music without sacrificing a large amount of space.The familiar design of the Wave has been tweaked nicely, and the concept--terrific sound made simple--remains the same. The super-slim remote is your control center for the Wave, so be careful not to lose or misplace it. If you do, you won't be able to operate the system very well (although you can turn the Wave on/off by touching the top front edge of the unit). All of the functions work very well, and operation is pretty intuitive. I was especially surprised at how nicely the radio--both FM and AM--performed. Getting stations to come in loud and clear was no trouble whatsoever.CDs may be on their way out, but if you're like me you still have a large collection of them. So it's nice to have a quality sound producer to listen to them on. (The slot-loading player works flawlessly.) Of course, it would've been great if this unit had wifi or Bluetooth capability, but those features are indeed available on a pricier version (Bose Wave SoundTouch music system IV- Espresso Black).My one minor complaint with this unit is something that has annoyed me with other Bose products in the past: There is no way to adjust the bass, treble, or even the overall tone of the sound the Wave produces. I understand that Bose prides themselves on knowing a lot about sound, but I think the absence of any kind of tone adjustment is just plain wrong. I appreciate quality sound as much as the next guy, but I don't think that Bose's idea of the best sound is necessarily what *I* want to hear. If I want to listen to my Tom Petty with a little more treble, or my Beatles with a little more bass, I think I should be able to do so. But I can't do that with this system. And that bothers me.Overall, the Wave IV is a very nice little system that will more than satisfy the ears of most people. I'm using it in my bedroom and it does a yeoman's job. The design is sleek, the footprint is small, and the sound is beautiful. It may be a bit pricy, but I think it's worth it.

I eat a lot of beef jerky, and Jack Link's is definitely one of the better quality mass market brands in the space. The original flavor is very tasty, with a nice, smoky taste and just a touch of soy sauce. The texture is great, too. It's not too soft or too tough, but just right. Beef jerky should take a little bit of effort to chew, and Jack Link's gets that right. All in all, this is a terrific product. It's low in calories and fat, high in protein, and makes a wonderful snack anytime.

I went many years without drinking as much water as I should, but I corrected that behavior about five years ago after a bout of diverticulitis. Unfortunately, my new practice of drinking at least 100 ounces of water each and every day means that sometimes I get sick of drinking plain old water. So last year I started looking for a way to enhance the flavor of my water a bit.Enter Mio, which I decided to try when I saw it on my grocery store shelf one day. There were several flavors to choose from, and the idea of making my water taste better made Mio an easy sell. I started using it once or twice a day and continued to do so for about six months. One thing I didn't do, though, was read the label to see what the ingredients were.Fast forward to a few weeks ago. For at least a month or two prior to then, I had been having regular severe episodes of dry mouth and very badly chapped lips. I had no idea what was causing it and started to analyze what I was eating and drinking very closely. So one day I decided to look at the list of ingredients on the multiple bottles of Mio in my cabinet. To my surprise, there was one ingredient that just sounded like trouble: Propylene glycol.After water, the next most prevalent ingredient in Mio is "propylene glycol." According to Mio's website, propylene glycol "is a common additive found in many products" and "is considered by the FDA to be 'generally recognized as safe' for use in foods." While that may be true, after doing some more research online I discovered that propylene glycol is a solvent used in many pharmaceuticals, including oral, injectable, and topical formulations. It is also used in automatic brake and hydraulic fluid and industrial antifreeze. It's also found in the stuff they use to de-ice aircraft with. The Material Safety Data Sheet for propylene glycol warns users to avoid skin contact with propylene glycol as this strong skin irritant can cause liver abnormalities and kidney damage.And they want me to put this stuff in my water???But here's the kicker: One website told me "since propylene glycol is considered a humectant (it collects moisture), your throat can become dry after use and potentially sore." Dry throat means dry mouth, and dry mouth means chapped lips. At this point, I was pretty sure I had found the cause of my chapped lips mystery, so I tossed out all the Mio I had on hand. And guess what? In a matter of days, my lips felt normal again. The chronic dryness and pain that I had endured for far too long was gone. (Interesting fact: Mio products sold in Canada do not contain propylene glycol.)If you want an flavor enhancer for your water, steer clear of Mio and give Stur a try. It doesn't cost any more, and it comes with a 100% satisfaction guarantee. You really have nothing to lose, except for a somewhat suspicious chemical that is considered "generally safe" by the Food and Drug Administration. I made the switch to Stur and couldn't be happier...or healthier. Stur is sugar- and calorie-free, contains all-natural ingredients, is gluten-free and non-GMO, and...contains no propylene glycol!!!!! Try the Stur - Variety Pack (5pck) - ALL-NATURAL Stevia Water Enhancer ..........................makes 100 8oz. servings - drink mix. Non-GMO, natural fruit flavor, natural stevia leaf extract, sugar-free, calorie-free, preservative-free, 100% Vitamin C, liquid stevia drops. **Family Business, Happiness Guaranteed, You will Love Stur**. You'll be so glad you did!
