One thing I didn't do, though, was read the label to see what the ingredients were.Fast forward to a few weeks ago. For at least a month or two prior to then, I had been having regular severe episodes of dry mouth and very badly chapped lips. I had no idea what was causing it and started to analyze what I was eating and drinking very closely. So one day I decided to look at the list of ingredients on the multiple bottles of Mio in my cabinet. To my surprise, there was one ingredient that just sounded like trouble: Propylene glycol.After water, the next most prevalent ingredient in Mio is "propylene glycol." According to Mio's website, propylene glycol "is a common additive found in many products" and "is considered by the FDA to be 'generally recognized as safe' for use in foods." While that may be true, after doing some more research online I discovered that propylene glycol is a solvent used in many pharmaceuticals, including oral, injectable, and topical formulations. It is also used in automatic brake and hydraulic fluid and industrial antifreeze. It's also found in the stuff they use to de-ice aircraft with. The Material Safety Data Sheet for propylene glycol warns users to avoid skin contact with propylene glycol as this strong skin irritant can cause liver abnormalities and kidney damage.And they want me to put this stuff in my water???But here's the kicker: One website told me "since propylene glycol is considered a humectant (it collects moisture), your throat can become dry after use and potentially sore." Dry throat means dry mouth, and dry mouth means chapped lips. At this point, I was pretty sure I had found the cause of my chapped lips mystery, so I tossed out all the Mio I had on hand. And guess what? In a matter of days, my lips felt normal again. The chronic dryness and pain that I had endured for far too long was gone. (Interesting fact: Mio products sold in Canada do not contain propylene glycol.)A few days later, I came across Stur on the Amazon website. I was intrigued by the minimal ingredients in the product, and completely thrilled that it was all natural. So I decided to give it a shot. And boy, am I glad I did.After a couple of days with the Stur variety pack, I pretty much fell in love with all of the flavors. It's so nice to have something *natural* to add to my water when I want to mix things up a bit. And the best part? No sugar, no calories, all-natural ingredients, non-GMO, and gluten-free...and no propylene glycol!!!!!If you want an flavor enhancer for your water, steer clear of Mio and give Stur a try. It doesn't cost any more, and it comes with a 100% satisfaction guarantee. You really have nothing to lose, except for a somewhat suspicious chemical that is considered "generally safe" by the Food and Drug Administration.
Excellent book with tasty recipes. Stop buying expensive jerky and start making your own! This book tells you how.
This is an excellent mattress pad at a very reasonable price. It fits nicely, is the perfect thickness, and is machine washable. My wife and I are very happy with our purchase!

This is the best single-disc Talking Heads compilation available. As with any "Best Of" collection, chances are pretty good that there will be people wishing one song or another were on the album...and others wondering why some other song *is* on the album. But such is life. If you love Talking Heads and want one CD that gives a great overall representation of their work, this is it.

This OtterBox Symmetry case is a terrific option for the Samsung GalaxyNote 5. It's one piece, very easy to install, and offers just the right amount of protection for my phone. Is it as protective as the OtterBox DEFENDER Cell Phone Case for Samsung Galaxy Note5 - Retail Packaging - INDIGO HARBOR (ROYAL BLUE/ADMIRAL BLUE)? Absolutely not. But if you want a relatively sleek case that offers a very good level of protection, the Symmetry is a great choice. I particularly like the raised bevel edge around the screen. Putting my phone screen-side down on a table no longer freaks me out, because I know OtterBox has me covered.

Hats off to T.J. English for doing some research, but if you're already familiar with the Whitey Bulger case there are no new revelations here. There have already been multiple books published on this subject--Whitey Bulger: America's Most Wanted Gangster and the Manhunt That Brought Him to Justice; Black Mass: Whitey Bulger, the FBI, and a Devil's Deal; and Whitey: The Life of America's Most Notorious Mob Boss, to name a few--along with a documentary film and the new motion picture "Black Mass," which stars Johnny Depp. I was hoping to find something new and interesting in this book, but I was disappointed. I suppose if you're a newcomer to the Bulger case, this would be a decent read. But I got nothing out of it. To be totally honest, it seems like this book is an attempt by T.J. English to cash in on the release of the "Black Mass" movie.

I think these AmazonBasics dry erase markers are just as good as the Expo brand, and they are priced lower than what a 12-pack of Expo brand chisel point markers would cost. That said, I was surprised to see--at the time I'm writing this review--that a 12-pack of Expo chisel point black markers (Expo Original Dry Erase Markers, Chisel Tip, 12-Pack, Black) can be purchased from a seller on Amazon for about four bucks less than these. And that includes Prime shipping. So, depending on what the price of the competitor's product is when you decide to purchase, these may or may not be a good deal. But as far as quality goes, these are top-notch. They write smoothly, erase easily, and, as advertised, have virtually no odor.

This is a decent basic power strip/surge protector. But there is something I'd like to point out.I suggest people read the warranty that comes with *any* surge protector very carefully. I know many people who buy items like this one to protect sensitive electronics from lightning damage. Just be aware that the warranty for this product clearly states:"This Limited Warranty will not cover claims for damages resulting from a lightning strike."Let the buyer beware.If you're looking for a very basic power strip/surge protector, this one's more than adequate. The sliding outlet covers are nice, as is the price. Just don't count on Woods to reimburse you if stuff you have plugged into this gets fried by a lightning strike.

You can never have enough USB ports in a car these days, especially when going on a road trip. My wife, son, and I recently took a car trip from Michigan to a music festival in Canada and we all had devices that needed charging. This Oenbopo Universal Mini Bullet 3-Port USB charger worked like a charm and helped us keep our iPhones and iPod fully charged. The best part? No one had to wait until another device was charged! Hallelujah!! I'd highly recommend this charger to anyone who finds themselves in need of multiple charging ports in their car. It's truly a lifesaver!(Note: I received this item either for free or at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.)

This shampoo and conditioner is terrific! I love the scent, the texture, and how it leaves my hair. Really great stuff! I will be ordering more of it when my current supply runs out, for sure.(Note: I received this item either for free or at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.)

These are excellent heat resistant silicone gloves that are equally at home around the outdoor grill or the indoor stovetop/oven. They are easy to get on and off, fit nicely, and do a terrific job of protecting your hands from heat. They are also very easy to clean. What more could you ask for? I will get a tremendous amount of use out of these gloves!(Note: I received this item either for free or at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.)

This grill brush is pretty darn good. The brush is nice and wide, and the configuration allows you to clean all the surfaces of the grates--on top, in between, and in the corners. I also appreciate the 18" handle, which allows you to cover the entire surface of your grill without too much exposure to heat. Too many grill brushes these days are way too short. The brush is also sturdy. There's a little bit of give in the handle when you're pushing down during cleaning, but I think it should hold up fine. Plus, it has a lifetime guarantee against breakage. Still, my personal preference would be for the handle to be just a wee bit stiffer. But maybe I'm just nit picky. All in all, a very nice grill brush!(Note: I received this item at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.)

This is a beautiful serving platter! Its size is very generous, and I plan to use it to serve up all types of cuisines. Despite the Rick Bayless "Mexican Kitchen" tie-in, this piece is definitely suitable to serving up any kind of food. I've already used it to present a beautiful caprese salad (tomatoes, mozzarella, and basil). The color worked perfectly! (The green color with the terra cotta-ish edges really is nice.) It's also perfect for serving steaks hot off the grill. This is quality stoneware, and I love that it's microwave and dishwasher safe. I'm very happy with this tray!

This is an aesthetically pleasing personal space heater that is very handy for use on top of or under a desk. I really like the design, which is a bit more contemporary than other space heaters I've had. It's also very simple to operate, with two round rocker switches on the back: one to turn it on and off, the other to choose between high heat (750 watts), low heat (375 watts), or fan only. It's also very lightweight and pretty quiet, and the automatic tip-over feature works well. I have to say, I really do like the fan only setting. Maybe that setting will allow this unit to be out all year long instead of getting shoved back into the box and put away for the warmer months. Lastly, this heater has a 3-year warranty, which is pretty darn good. I only have a couple of minor complaints. First of all, the fan speed for the high heat and low heat settings is the same. Not really a big deal, but because of that the only way to know which setting the heater is on is to look on the back and see which position the switch is in (I for low or II for high). I guess maybe I'm just used to heaters that have different fan speeds for low and high. Also, the heater doesn't come apart for cleaning. Again, not a deal-breaker, but I know that heaters like this accumulate dust and dirt on their blades over time. It would be nice to be able to take it apart to clean it on occasion. But again, not a deal-breaker. All in all, this is a terrific little heater that's great for a personal space!P.S. It's interesting to see how Apple continues to influence other company's packaging. On the inside flap of the box for this heater, it says, "Designed, engineered and supported in Andover, Kansas." (For what it's worth, the heater is made in China, though.)

I'm not exactly sure what "Youth Boost" is, or how one can measure it, but this Tresemme shampoo is nice. I've used the shampoo several times now. I don't feel any younger, but my hair is clean and that's the main reason we use shampoo, right?Seriously, though, this shampoo works really well. It has a very subtle scent to it, which is nice. I don't like overpowering scents in my shampoo. Also, a little bit goes a long way, and that's a great thing, especially when you consider that this shampoo is low-priced to begin with. Very economical!

We go through ear buds/headphones like they're candy in my house. Wait. Let me rephrase that. My *son* goes through ear buds/headphones like they're candy. I'm constantly having to replace them because they break. Let's face it: The wires are not the most durable things in the world. That said, it's always nice when I find a pair of headphones that are comfortable, have excellent sound, and are reasonably priced. These Panasonics are just that. Are they the world's most comfortable headphones? Probably not. Are they the world's best sounding headphones? No. But they are definitely reasonably priced, and that makes them an overall winner in my book. The fact that they have a microphone and inline switch is just icing on the cake. Plus, my son loves purple! You really can't go wrong with these!

I've tried a large number of grilling brushes in my four decades of grilling. Call me old fashioned, but the ones I keep coming back to are very basic.  But they just plain work. Every once in a while, though, I'll try something new, just to see if maybe someone's improved upon the simple designs I'm used to. This Grill Daddy Dirty Grill Killer is one of those brushes I thought I'd try.My first impression of this brush? It looks like something you'd see in a late night TV infomercial. But wait...there's more!I'm not sure who decided this brush was durable enough for cleaning a grill, but the first time I tried it on my Weber Genesis gas grill with stainless steel grates, the brush head bent at the point where the circular brush is connected to the square brush. But wait...there's more!To call this a "steam-operated grill brush" is very misleading. No, it's not steam-powered. And it can't even generate its own steam. The steam is created by water dripping out of the little water reservoir and coming into contact with the hot grill surface. Using this criteria, your kid's squirt gun is just as "steam-operated" as this Grill Daddy brush is. But wait...there's more!Speaking of squirt guns, do you remember how frustrating it was to fill up a squirt gun when you were a kid? Trying to get water from the faucet to go into that tiny little filler hole on the squirt gun? Well, if you've forgotten that experience, this grill brush will remind you of it the first time you try to put water in it. But wait...there's more!This thing is made in China and you can see and feel it right away. The plastic is cheap and the brush assembly is pretty flimsy. Add to this the fact that replacement brushes will cost you almost half of what you paid for this thing in the first place, and I think you get the picture.If you want a good grill brush at a reasonable price, try the Weber 6464 18-Inch Bamboo Grill Brush or the Weber 6494 12-Inch 3-Sided Grill Brush. Yes, they are very basic. But they work. And if you absolutely must have steam to help you clean your grill grates, then invest a couple of bucks in a spray bottle, fill it with water, and keep it by your grill. Not only can you use it to extinguish flare-ups, but when you're cleaning your grill you can spray it on the hot grates and generate your own steam to use with your Weber grill brush.

This book didn't hit me the way I thought it would based on the description. There are some good stories here, and the glimpse inside this father and son's reconciliation is interesting. But I found some of the stories kind of boring and mundane, and the back-and-forth nature of the book was a little hard for me to follow. Worth reading? Sure. But it didn't live up to the glowing reviews I read. Maybe you'll feel differently, though.

This is a really nice guitar tuner with a very cool and functional design. My son's been using an iPhone app to tune his guitar recently, but this TC PolyTune electronic tuner has become his new favorite. It easily clips to his guitar and doesn't take up much space. The display is bright and easy to read, too. Battery included, which is nice. My son's only "complaint"? He wishes it came with a little case of some kind. But the tuner is so small, it should be easy to find something to store it in.

This is a great idea. This Belkin Lightning to USB cable has a connector that's angled 90 degrees on the Lightning end, which is supposed to mean little or no strain on the wire. As we all probably know much too well, Lightning to USB charging cables inevitably stop working when the wires break due to excessive bending, stress, and strain. I can't tell you how many charging cables my family has gone through in the last few years. Hopefully, this new design will put an end to the disposable charging cable! By the way, in addition to the angled tip on this cable, the cord itself seems to be thicker and more durable than most competitors. Belkin even offers a 2-year limited warranty on this item. An enthusiastic 5-star rating for the design. But only time will tell how durable this charging cable proves to be. I will be sure to update my review if I encounter problems as time goes by.

I bought these wood chips for use in my propane smoker. They work alright, but the chips are, in my opinion, a little too small. I prefer larger chips or chunks. I think these chips are better for other applications, like a little smoker box or homemade foil smoker packets. Good maple flavor, though.

This is my sixth Apple computer, and it's the best computer I've ever owned. Period. Fabulous design, fabulous performance, fabulous operating system. I've used both Windows computers and Macs, and I'm constantly amazed at how much easier and intuitive Macs are to use; and how much better they work. I've been using this laptop for a year, and it's never crashed. Not once. Once you go Mac, you never go back.

1:05 Mins **I was given this product at no charge in exchange for an honest review**This is a terrific, very reasonably priced, easy to install shower head. I absolutely love the rainfall/waterfall option. Watch my video to see it in action!

Not much to say about this product. It's a bag full of chunks of wood. I use these in my Masterbuilt propane smoker with terrific results. I much prefer wood chunks to wood chips. Easier to soak and easier to handle. Weber consistently gives me chunks that are the perfect size, and all of the "flavors"--apple, cherry, hickory, mesquite, and pecan--are great. Also, the price is very reasonable. Highly recommended.

Another sterling effort from one of the more underrated singer-songwriters out there. The inclusion of acoustic versions of all of the songs is such a great bonus. I wish more artists would do the same. It's amazing to hear how different two renditions of the same song can sound so similar, yet so different at the same time. "Glorious You" is such a great song (electric or acoustic) and "Get Better" is loud and a whole lot of fun. Those are my two favorite tracks so far.

I've been without a full-time job for a little less than two years now, after leaving a company I worked at for 24 years. The reason I left? I was tired of working a job I wasn't passionate about just to get a paycheck. When I was offered a buyout, I jumped at the chance, albeit with a bit of trepidation. As the months have gone on, I've done a lot of freelance writing, which is work that I love. And even though I don't make as much money as I used to, my life is more fulfilling. Elizabeth Gilbert's Big Magic: Creative Living Beyond Fear speaks so loudly to me. Broken up into sections called "Courage," "Enchantment," "Permission," Persistence," "Trust," and "Divinity," Big Magic teaches us how to deal with fear, how to say "No" to things you don't want to do and "Yes" to those you do, and so many other things that make living a creative life easier. "You do not need anybody's permission to live a creative life," Gilbert writes. Stay focused on what you want, keep working at it, and it can be yours.For the record, when Gilbert talks about a "creative life," she's not necessarily talking about a life in the arts. "When I refer to 'creative living,'" she states, "I am speaking more broadly. I'm talking about living a life that is driven more strongly by curiosity than by fear." Isn't that a life that all of us would like to be living?Big Magic is not just full of sugarcoated positivity, though. For example, Gilbert is brutally honest when she says, "You will fail. It sucks, and I hate to say it, but it's true. You will take creative risks, and often they will not pan out." But that is part of the process and can be overcome, if you forgive yourself and don't let your ego get in the way. The important thing is to do something you love, because "When it's for love, you will always do it anyhow," even if success never comes. That's what passion is all about.Gilbert tells us that "the universe buries strange jewels deep within us all, and then stands back to see if we can find them." This is an uplifting, informative book for anyone who aspires to hunt to uncover those jewels. Gilbert definitely has a way with words, and her words are so wise and impactful in Big Magic. I love the fact that each section of the book is comprised of relatively short essays and stories. It makes it very easy to pick this book up and read a bit when you only have a few minutes of time."Creative living can be an amazing *vocation*, if you have the love and courage and persistence to see it that way. I suggest that this may be the only sanity-preserving way to approach creativity. Because nobody ever told us it would be easy, and uncertainty is what we sign up for when we say that we want to live creative lives."Amen, Elizabeth Gilbert. Amen. Thank you for helping to guide me on my latest journey.

My wife really loves this hair dryer, and she fell in love as soon as she took it out of the box. That's not surprising, since this blow dryer is pretty sleek looking. It's also got a cool finish, which the box calls a "Soft Touch Finish." Translation? It has kind of a matte, rubbery feel to it. The dryer's 1875 watts also produce some serious drying power, with two speeds and three heat settings. The bottom line? It dries hair super fast. One of the best features of this dryer is the removable air filter. It's simple to unscrew the filter on the back of the unit and clean out the accumulated hair and dust. It helps prevent that familiar burning hair smell from filling up the bathroom. My wife doesn't use the two included attachments--a diffuser and a concentrator--but it's nice to have them available. Add to that a rubber hang loop for easy storage and a FOUR-YEAR warranty, and you have yourself an impressive blow dryer!

I got this toy for my 25-year-old son, who has been a Star Wars fan for pretty much his entire life. You're never too old to have cool toys, and this is a cool toy. I was pleasantly surprised when it arrived, because it's bigger than it seems in the photograph. It's built well and would, I'm guessing, hold up to countless hours of play. I realized this toy is designed for younger kids, but I wish the Han Solo and Chewbacca figures were less "cartoonish." Also, having to put peel stickers off a sheet and stick them on the toy is no fun. But overall, this is sweet!

This is the first manual coffee grinder I've ever owned. In the past, I've always used noisy, obnoxious electric models. The kind that wake up the whole house when you grind coffee early on a Sunday morning. Well, I think my family will be able to sleep in now. This Tanors Ceramic Burr manual grinder is the cat's pajamas! It's compact, easy to use and clean, and does a great job of grinding my coffee beans. I love being able to adjust the grind size for different coffee making applications. I'm not sure if I'd ever travel with this, but it's so compact that it would not take up much room if I decided to pack it in my suitcase. The travel bag it comes with is pretty cheap, but it serves its purpose. Nice that a cleaning brush is included, too. If you've never tried a manual grinder for your coffee beans, I'd suggest you give this one a try. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

I had read the bad reviews of this thing on Amazon, but I needed a cart this size in the worst way. When I saw it at my local Ace Hardware today, I thought about it for about 30 seconds...then figured I'd take a chance on it. After all, it couldn't be as bad as the reviews on Amazon made it out to be, could it? Turns out it wasn't. It was a hundred times worse! OMG. Who in their right mind could even design a product this bad? And even if that was allowed to happen, what genius at the manufacturer decided it would be a good idea to sell this thing? Did anyone associated with the company even try to put it together or use it??? I doubt it, because if they had this cart would never have come to market. Never. Ever. It's virtually impossible to assemble. The package touts "no tool assembly." Little did I know that that meant there was literally nothing holding this thing together. No screws, no clips, not even holes for ends to stick or snap into. It's all pretty much based on gravity. I felt like a circus juggler while assembling this cart. I was holding lightweight pieces of painted steel, but they may as well have been chainsaws. That's how hard it was to get this thing together. And after it was together, and the casters were popped on? This is the painted steel version of a house of cards. Yes, it's that flimsy. Shame on you, Whitmor for even making a product like this. What were you thinking?? If someone offered to PAY me $100.00 to use this, I would emphatically say "NO!" Needless to say, I returned this travesty to the hardware store. Do yourself a favor and DO NOT order this. If you do, I guarantee you will regret it with every bone in your body. If I could have rated this zero stars, I would have.

This is a nice tablecloth. The gray color goes with everything, the size is perfect for our large dining room table, and the quality is excellent. I inspected the tablecloth closely upon arrival and didn't find any flaws or problems. Hopefully it will hold up well after being washed several times. If it doesn't, you can bet I'll come back and update my review accordingly. But as of now, I'm satisfied.

At the age of 14, Jason Smith got his first taste of addiction. Literally. While his parents were away for the weekend, his uncle--a heroin addict who was living with Jason and his family--overdosed, and Jason had to perform CPR on him. Without going into too much detail, let's just say that the taste was unforgettable.The bitter taste of dying indeed.Three years later, Smith inadvertently stumbled upon the warm, comforting effects of drugs when he ended up in the hospital following a car accident that injured his back. One shot of Demerol and Smith was hooked.The Bitter Taste of Dying is a gripping, no-holds-barred memoir of Smiths experiences while in the throes of the beast known as addiction. He takes the reader along on his journeys to Europe, Mexico, and China, documenting his innermost feelings and the crazy, mixed-up thinking that goes hand-in-hand with drug dependency. Smiths days and nights are filled with desperation and recklessness as he constantly chases a high while simultaneously running away from life.Smith cant live without drugs, but he cant live with them, either. At least not in a manner that most human beings would want to live. His addiction is his constant companion through college, allowing him to shed the shyness and anxiety he felt while growing up. Drugs make his life easier, but at the same time they make his life a living hell.Some of the situations Smith finds himself in are nothing short of terrifying. His time spent in a Tijuana prison--where he was beaten by guards and given drinking water from a janitors mop bucket--and his encounter with the Russian mob had me overflowing with empathy. The lengths Smith goes to in order to stay high are beyond what most people can even comprehend.Jason Smith is a guy who manipulated every person in his life and every system he encountered, all for the sake of getting high. A guy who chewed on Fentanyl patches that were meant to be stuck on his arm, because his method gave him a quicker, better high. A guy who at one point wanted to die but didnt, because he couldnt even commit suicide right. His life and addiction got so bad that he was devoid of any feelings.But 16 years after that fateful shot of Demerol, Smith finally got clean and sober. As he states so eloquently: It took me losing everything to appreciate anything.Smith is an excellent storyteller and The Bitter Taste of Dying is an enthralling read. The end-of-chapter conversations with his sponsor, Bryon, are almost as compelling as the words that precede them. They add an insight that I havent found in most addiction-related memoirs, and show the evolution of Smiths thought process as he moves from addiction to recovery.Like so many people, Jason Smith turned to drugs when life and the feelings that go along with it got too hard to manage. Self-medication numbed him and allowed him to navigate what he previously thought was unnavigable. But hell be the first one to tell you that the magic didnt last.The Bitter Taste of Dying isnt just a riveting story of addiction and recovery. Its a story of self-discovery and hope, too. Make no mistake: Your life can be in complete ruins, but if you try hard enough you can rebuild it. The transformation of Jason Smith is proof of that. It may have taken him 16 years to find the light at the end of the tunnel, but the important thing is that he found it.

These Panasonic RPHJE190K in-the-ear headphones are a good value. My teenage son goes through earbuds like they're candy, and buying more expensive models does not make economical sense. (I bought him a pair of $50 ear buds once...they lasted about two weeks before the wires broke.) Are these the best sounding headphones you'll come across? No. But they're far from terrible and actually seem to be built pretty well. The multiple silicone tips make getting a comfy fit easy, and the bass response is surprisingly good for something this inexpensive. I think they sound terrific, and my teenage son likes them. And he might be one of the toughest critics of all. Don't throw your money away on pricier headphones. Go with these Panasonics and save your money.

I have a 19-year-old son who has been using Axe products--body wash and deodorant--for the last few years. Maybe I'm just old, but every Axe product we've ever had in our house smells awful to me. The scent is just too strong and lingers for too long. To me, this Pre de Provence shower gel smells like an Axe product. To be completely honest, I was really looking forward to getting this product and trying it out. When it arrived today, I opened the bottle and took a whiff. I immediately put the top back on and won't be opening it again. Maybe I'll give it to my son. Because it smells like Axe. And, in my opinion, that's not a good thing. UPDATE: I offered the shower gel to my son and told him I thought it smelled like Axe. His reply? "It does." He took possession of it, so at least it won't go to waste.

This Case Logic Intrata 15.6-Inch Laptop Bag is very functional and is perfect for my wife's 15-inch work laptop. The case offers some nice features. Among the ones we like the best are the slightly wider opening at the top and the shoulder strap that attaches at the back of the case. Both of these are great because it makes it a lot easier to remove the laptop from the case. The carrying handle that doubles as a luggage loop is nice, too. The padding in this case is not over-the-top, but it seems adequate for an everyday laptop bag. (A little more would've been nice, though.) The front zippered pocket fits the AC charger nicely. There's a phone pocket in there, too, but I'm not sure if my wife will ever use it. Nice to have the option, though. As far as appearance goes, this case is not going to win any fashion awards. But the black nylon material and the overall design falls pretty much in line with other Case Logic products we've purchased over the years. And, based on our experience, Case Logic stuff holds up nicely over the years. This is a nice, durable, functional laptop bag. Perfect? No. But way more than adequate.

Confession: When I first ordered my Echo, I was very skeptical. I didn't think it was something I would use very much. In fact, when it arrived I thought seriously about returning it. I wondered if it was going to be one of those frivolous purchases I'm famous for. But after a couple days of looking at the sealed box, I decided to open it and try it. And I've been hooked ever since. I love to listen to music and I love to cook. The ability to stream music in the kitchen and control it all without touching the device makes it worth the money alone. No more having to wash dough or chicken residue off my hands before skipping to the next song! Between my iTunes library--which I uploaded to Prime Music for the $24.99/year fee--Prime Music, iHeart Radio, and Pandora, I have pretty much all the music I need available to me via voice command. Also... I am pretty picky when it comes to how my music sounds, and I must say I have been pleasantly surprised by how good the Echo's speaker is. I didn't expect it to sound half as good as it does.I primarily use the Echo for playing music, so all of its other features are like icing on a black, cylindrical cake. Weather reports, traffic reports, reading Audible books, making shopping and to-do lists, etc. All very cool and handy at times. Just like the Echo's remote!I love my Echo, and to be perfectly honest? I can't imagine my kitchen without it now! I'm sooooo glad I didn't return it! And I can't wait to get another one!!

This is a pretty little bracelet, and I think the infinity symbol is nicely done. But be forewarned that this is a very small and delicate piece. Granted, it's always tough to tell what something like this will look like in person when you're looking at it online; but I was kind of surprised at how small it is. Maybe the best word to describe it is...dainty. Which isn't a bad thing.

As the parent of a son who struggled through more than seven years of addiction, I have read countless books on the subject. There's no doubt that this is one of the best. In S.O.B.E.R.*, Anita Devlin and her son, Michael Jr., take turns telling the story of Michael's addiction from two different perspectives: The mother's and the addict's. This back-and-forth storytelling gives the reader great insight into what was going on in both of their minds during particularly difficult times. As a bonus, we also get occasional passages from Alex, who is the daughter, sister, and "collateral damage" in this addiction tale. What makes S.O.B.E.R.* so impactful is the brutal honesty with which all involved tell their story. Anita says the things that all parents of addicted children *think*, but often times keep to themselves. There is no filter between her thoughts and the words she writes on these pages.This is an intimate story. We learn so much about the Devlins and how Michael Jr.'s addiction slowly eats away at the foundation of their family. We also read the "cost letters" that a mother, father, and sister write to their addicted loved one. Again, nothing is held back. For example, Alex writes to her brother:"I listened to you talk about how you wanted to help your friends that were going through the same things you are...and the whole time I thought to myself, 'What are you talking about? You are more messed up than all of them, and you don't even see it.' The difference is, you are the luckiest sh*t in the world, because you have three people who are willing to take all the crap that you've thrown on us, and still stand up for you and want to help you at the end of the day."Those are the kinds of feelings that engulf a family struggling with addiction. It's so common for family members to wonder why their loved one continues to do what they're doing, even though it's toxic to all the relationships they have. But Michael Jr. helps shed some light on why that might be when he writes, "My mind is my problem, and drugs and alcohol were the solution that helped me to feel OK." That's it in a nutshell. People don't use drugs because they *want* to become addicts or inflict hurt on their families. They self-medicate because they want to feel "normal." There is no intent to cause pain for others, and sometimes that's so very hard for a drug user's family to grasp.Anita also visits the importance of self-care, a concept that is too often overlooked by family members dealing with addiction. "I've learned that the most important thing family members can do while we are waiting for the addict to want the help is to help ourselves," she says. "We cannot handle what is happening without getting help. If we do not understand what addiction is, we cannot help our children. The anger and hatred and war we wage is not against our children but against the real enemy--addiction itself. A family must join forces for the battle, helping each other, not just the addict."Addiction is indeed a family disease, and S.O.B.E.R.* does an incredible job of telling this family's story. If you are the loved one of someone struggling with addiction, read this book. If you know someone who is struggling with addiction--either their own or a loved one's--read this book. If you think addiction is a disease that only affects the addict, read this book. S.O.B.E.R.* is a monumental comeback story, full of love, fear, courage, honesty, and hope.

This is a beautiful ring that looks much more expensive than it is. My wife has long fingers, so the length of this ring works great for her. It was packaged nicely, too. My wife loves this ring and has nothing negative to say about it. You can't beat that!

Excellent rug, although there were some loose threads that I noticed as soon as I pulled it out of the bag. But they were nothing too terrible. I actually put this rug through the wash before I even put it in my bathroom. I just wanted to see how it went through a washer/dryer cycle. I must say, it came through with flying colors! No change in texture or shape, and the non-skid rubber backing is just like new, too. All in all, this is a really nice bath rug. I would recommend it.

This Hoover FloorMate Cordless Hard Floor Cleaner is a terrific product. Easy assembly, easy-to-follow instructions, and fabulous results. We have tried it on our hardwood floors, tile floors, and even our painted concrete basement floor. It performed flawlessly on all surfaces, and I honestly believe that the tile floors in my bathrooms are cleaner than they have EVER been. Like others have suggested, sweep or vacuum first, because it makes emptying and cleaning the FloorMate a lot easier. (We have three cats and are used to doing a thorough vacuuming before mopping.) One of the greatest features of this unit, though, is the fact that it's cordless. This makes cleaning so much easier, especially when using a cleaner that uses water. No more dragging that cord across a wet floor! But as much as I love the cordlessness (is that a word?) of this machine, that feature also leads me to my one small complaint: The battery just doesn't last long enough. When doing a thorough cleaning, I think I need about an hour. But so far the battery has lasted only slightly more than 30 minutes. Then it's time to take a break from cleaning and charge the battery, which takes a little less than an hour or so. It's just a little inconvenient. If this thing could run for 60 minutes on a battery charge, I'd have given it 5 stars. But 30 minutes or so of battery life forces me to knock 1 star off. Overall, though, it's a really nice machine.

This is a very simple product, and I was really looking forward to putting it to good use in my upstairs bathroom. Unfortunately, it doesn't work on all doors. I'm guessing it will *fit* over all (or most) doors, but when I tried to use it on my upstairs bathroom door...the door would not shut. This was disappointing, but I suppose nothing is perfect. The hook did fit on my downstairs bathroom door, and the door shuts with only a little friction from the hook's plastic. So I'm using it...just not in the place I wanted to use it. Overall quality is good, the silicone covers on the hooks keep things from slipping off.

This SanDisk Ultra 64GB Micro SDXC card works like a charm. I'm using it in a BLU Studio 6.0 HD Smartphone - Unlocked - Black and have no complaints whatsoever. I am truly amazed that something so small holds 64GB of data. My first home PC, not all that long ago, had a 1GB hard drive. Technology is wonderful, isn't it?

My main phone is an iPhone, and I must admit: I'm in love with it. And with iOS. But I thought I'd give this Android phone a try. As indicated by my three-star review, it's okay. But there are a number of things that miss the mark, at least for me.First of all, I have no issues with the display, and--surprisingly--very few complaints about the Android operating system. It was pretty intuitive, though not as intuitive as iOS. Granted, that may be because I'm used to iOS.Here are some things that I don't like about this phone:*Personally, I think it's too big. I know that "phablets" are all the rage now, but I don't think I could ever get used to carrying and using a phone this big. I find it very awkward to hold it in my hand and talk on it. I do have small hands, so maybe that's a factor. I also find the phone quite heavy.*Quality of the calls on this phone are not as good as on my iPhone. The audio is just not as clear/sharp.*The screen itself--the actual glass--is not as resistant to fingerprints and smudges as my iPhone screen. I find myself having to clean the glass on this phone constantly.*The case provided with this phone is pretty cheap. Fortunately there are some third-party cases available.*The few times I've tried to take video with this phone, the quality has been poor. Simple video of my cat playing in the living room was choppy. I'm using a quality micro SD card, so I'm confused as to what the problem is. (On the other hand, the still camera works very well.)*Playing videos from YouTube and other websites seems to be a challenge for this phone. The actual video seems to play alright, but the audio is, in many instances, terrible. Full of distortion and static. It's frustrating, to say the least.That's a quick summary of some of the negatives I've experienced with the Blu Studio 6.0 HD. As with all electronics these days, your mileage may vary. That said, I'm a firm believer in "you get what you pay for." I just don't believe that a top-notch, 6-inch, unlocked smartphone can be had for $129.99 to $149.99. But maybe that's just me being skeptical.I've decided to keep using an iPhone for my wireless service. I am now using the Blu phone as a mini-tablet. Took out the sim card and it works great as something between an iPod Touch and an iPad Mini. So all is not lost!
I don't use this soap personally, but my wife absolutely adores it. Nice scent, keeps the wife happy. You have to love that.
These Braun Professional Deep Sweep replacement brush heads work great, and I love the way they clean my teeth. I just wish they weren't so darn expensive.

My son loves Gatorade Frost. I'm not crazy about it, because it has a bunch of sugar in it. That said, I'd rather have him drinking this stuff than soda. And buying through Amazon Prime with free shipping is pretty economical.

In general i spend most of my waking day with a set of headphones on. I love listing to music while at work and at the gym etc So when I was given the opportunity to review these Wireless Headset from Senty at a promotional rate in exchange for my opinion on them I jumped on it. That said Im not compensated in any way and this is a real review containing my own honest to goodness thoughts. Ok so onto what I like/dislike about these.Pro'sGreat sound, durable construction.Nice feel to the headset itself and the cord has mic etc to switch back and forth between calls and your music.I liked that the option to use wired when battery low is possible with these.The Mic is quite a bit better then the last several pairs I've had.The Headphones sounded better after letting them play for a while.Neg'sThis is minor and may be just me but I couldn't get the stop-start to work on the app I was using on phone to listen to a recorded lecture.UPDATE: I was able get it working later I don't know what I was doing wrong at first.My Final thoughts...If you are looking for good bang for the buck or just and extra pair for gym etc give these a try im liking them so far.
