This is absolutely the best safety mat I've ever used.  In the first place, it is LONG ENOUGH!  Most items of this type are only about half the length of a tub, and that leaves an awfully large amount of slippery surface. This may be TMI, but my spouse and I shower together, and we find the length a major asset.  Although other products I've used have a similar surface, this one seems to be especially comfortable for the feet.  Finally, of course, there's the color.  I love the lavender, as opposed to the clear plastic of my previous safety mat.  Since the time requirement on the review does not permit long-term use, I can't at this point testify to durability or long-lasting effectiveness, but I see no reason to suspect that this mat will be equal to or better than other similar products over time.Actually, in reading negative reviews after posting my own very positive one, I discovered that they mostly complained about the odor.  To be honest, when I first put mine down, though I didn't notice anything worse than the usual "new plastic" smell, my adult son, who happened to be visiting at the time, made a remark about the "strange odor" and was looking around the house trying to figure out what it was.  In our very large bathroom, however, I suspect it will not be a problem for us.

This book, edited by Sandra Taylor and Hazel Barnes, with an introduction by Sister Jeannine Gramick, contains 34 brief narratives organized around 6 themes: Family; Is Catholicism home?; A religious life?; A long journey; Significant events; and Working for understanding and acceptance.  The people who share their stories represent a large diversity of age, life circumstances, relationship status, and national origins; the shared theme, obviously, is their identification  past and present  with the Roman Catholic Church, as well as their self-identification with the LGBT community.This book is, I believe, especially timely, coming as it does during the era of Pope Francis, who is doing so much to bring a renewed understanding of Catholic teachings into the public awareness.  Although belief in the importance of the guidance of ones own conscience has long been a part of the doctrine of the Church, it is only since Catholicism began earnestly wrestling with the issue of sexuality in general and homosexuality in particular that this fact has become part of public discussion.  As anyone who has been following this discussion should be aware, the questions of contraception, abortion and divorce are all interrelated with the status of women and the morality of various forms of sexual expression not directly purposed for reproduction.  To the extent testimonies of LGBT people speak directly to the idea that spirituality and sexuality ARE in fact intended by the Creator for the purpose of increasing loving relationships among individuals even when reproduction is not involved, they indeed offer a major contribution to this discussion.In my own personal memoir, completed years ago before there were nearly as many resources on the theology of sexuality as there are now, I struggled with this same concern for the development of a perspective that allowed my conscience to deal with these questions.  I find that my own evolution parallels many of the stories shared in this book, which gives me a warm fellow-feeling; we are indeed a cloud of witnesses calling Christianity in general and Catholicism in particular out of the dark ages of unquestioning acceptance of a very flawed and limited view of Gods purposes for human sexuality.

Cynthia Ruchti is another author whose work I consider myself blessed to have encountered via the Vine for All category of Christian Books.  Her deeply insightful and beautifully written novel As Waters Gone By, published by Abingdon Press, is another winner from that amazing publishing house.  Although it is my policy NOT to check on reviews by others before writing my own, I will not be surprised to discover that this one has received so many accolades mine will be merely icing on the cake.Of the numerous things that made this an extremely meaningful read for me, perhaps the most significant is the description of the conflict resulting from Maxs incarceration and Emmalyns ambivalent response to it.  As it happens, over the past 30 years or so, my husband Ray has had a ministry of ongoing correspondence with a large number of inmates.  He has visited several of them during their time of imprisonment; had telephone communication with some of them; and in several circumstances maintained contact after their release to various parole or probation situations.  Therefore I am absolutely able to verify the authenticity of Ruchtis description of the difficulty in communicating under those conditions, which forms such an important plot element in this novel.Although this book is deeply imbued with a genuine spirit of love, faith and hope, it is at no point saccharine or clich.  All of the characters are vibrant and realistic, in a decisively off-beat sort of way.  The discussion of Emmalyns own resentment of her mother's and sisters attitudes as they impact her own feelings and actions offers a powerful counterbalance and additional infusion of realism.  In all, Im very glad that the paucity of meaningful offerings on my Vine Queue led me to seek out this book.

Through the Eyes of a Lion by Levi Lusko is intense spiritual witness based on his familys experience of losing their five-year-old daughter Lenya to a fatal asthma attack a few days before Christmas in 2012.  Although I dont agree with all of Luskos theological perspectives, I deeply respect the power of his faith, and I certainly share many of the insights he offers in this heart-rending, powerful memoir.A major focus of this narrative is that unbelievable grief CAN be endured, and that to do so is to allow Gods love to transform it into powerful witness.  As long as life goes along smoothly, we may find that our assertions of reliance upon Gods love ring a bit false.  As is pointed out so effectively by the Devil in the Book of Job, why WOULDNT Job honor and serve God as long as everything was hunky-dory? Only if all the blessings were removed would the real truth be manifest.  Or, as a more modern clich says, what happens when the rubber meets the road?  Although all of us can relate to SOME challenges and difficulties in life, the testimony of those who have had such an extremely traumatic experience as the loss of a young child and yet have emerged with strengthened faith and deeper compassion is especially valuable.Luskos writing is both authentic and contemporary.  His use of current day references, including his references to movies, TV shows, and so on, should make it easy for those who are not overly fond of churchy language to relate.  No matter where a reader is on the spiritual journey, Lusko is a worthwhile co-pilgrim to encounter.

Fans of the Impossible Life by Kate Scelsa is another of those books that I wish I liked as much as I hoped I would.  It is, according to the classification, one of the rare offerings in the Gay and Lesbian literature category.  It is also, as it happens, another iteration of teenage angst; all of the main characters exhibit various degrees of dysfunctionality.  Sebby, the most extreme of the three, is an unabashedly gay casualty of the foster-care system, a drug-addicted school drop-out whose worst problems began with a nearly-fatal bashing incident in a high-school locker room.  Mira, the daughter of a mixed-race professional couple with an over-achieving elder sister, is probably mainly suffering from self-image problems and chemical imbalance being improperly treated.  Jeremy, whose family constellation includes two gay dads, is really hypersensitive; it seems to me he could benefit immensely from some common-sense counseling, which his teacher Peter tries to provide, but with limited effectiveness.As Ive observed in several recent reviews, my biggest dissatisfaction with this narrative is the apparent complete idiocy of the supposedly rational adults involved in the story.  As a previous high school teacher myself, and a parent and grandparent, I found myself becoming more and more outraged by this factor.  Although the characterizations of the three young people are well-drawn and their motivations fairly explicit, one cant help but want to slap their parents and/or caregivers upside the head and shout, Wake up!  While this may be an honest depiction of the world in which many of us live today, it is certainly not one to celebrate.  In all, I found the tone of this story grim and, while perhaps dealing with important realities, not one I would return to for enlightenment or inspiration.

This is a book that Im more than delighted to have discovered in the Vine for All section during one of those times when my personal queue contained absolutely nothing of interest.  Of course, I will always go for things in the Gay and Lesbian category, but the special extra gift of Chinelo Okparantas Under the Udala Trees is that it deals with the pressing issue of being in the LGBTQ community in Nigeria, one of the African nations which have currently introduced extremely repressive legislation.The story itself is beautifully crafted, and offers wonderfully sensitive insights into the human drama involved.  As the narrative begins, in 1968, Nigeria is in the midst of the conflict with Biafra.  Her narrator character, Ijeoma, is eleven years old, an only child.  Her educated and loving father becomes depressed by the course of the war, and refuses to go to a bunker during a bombing raid.  He is killed, and Ijeomas mother becomes unhinged, and believes that the only way to keep her daughter safe is to board her with a couple in a nearby town while she herself tries to rebuild her life.  Regretfully, this arrangement isnt particularly nurturing; Ijeoma and another war-orphan child, Amina, are treated as servants  house girls  and are relegated to an out building, a one-room shack  as their sleeping quarters.  Having only each other, and no parenting of any sort, as the girls enter puberty they automatically establish a deep emotional bond that of course involves sexual exploration.  It should come as no surprise that when their relationship is exposed, all sorts of repercussions occur.Okparanta perfectly captures a number of significant nuances, including the confusion and destructiveness of the interaction of the native African cultural mores with the overlay of fundamentalist Christian homophobia.  Although Ijeomas mother has obviously, in her own self-absorption following the death of her husband, opted out of any role of nurturing of her daughter, she suddenly decides it is her duty to rescue the girl from the abomination of homosexuality as described in the Bible (KJV, no doubt).  Gay youth who  whatever their culture  have been subjected to such a barrage will recognize the oppressiveness of it, and will be able to empathize completely with Ijeomas ensuing trauma.Descriptions, characterizations, and the psychological and sociological aspects of this novel are pitch-perfect.  It is a brilliantly done work, deserving of full recognition.

Finally, a real triumph for e-books.  Having recently read and reviewed Tess Gerritsen's stand-alone novel "Playing with Fire" on Amazon (September 14, 2015), and discovering that her Rizzoli and Isles series was available as a "bundle" for a relatively affordable price, I decided to "take the plunge".  The real motivation for this decision was the awareness that at the beginning of November, we will be on a "river cruise" in Europe.  I wanted plenty of reading material, and didn't want to deal with packing books.  Although I plan to reserve most of this series for that trip, and have no intention of reviewing the books individually, I decided to go ahead and start reading now.  These books seem to avoid a common complaint I've recently had about other e-books, namely extremely casual and inadequate editing - no doubt because these have been available in bound format for a number of years now.  In any event, I am heartily in favor of the whole notion of re-publishing entire series such as this one in compact format, chronological order, and reasonable price.

This is the first time in several months of being eligible for a free Kindle download as an Amazon Prime member that Ive taken advantage of this perk.  In general, I have found the offerings less than appealing.  However, Here and There by Joshua Scher was listed as Experimental Fiction, and had the intriguing come-on Some quantum entanglements shouldnt be untied.  Since I am a one-time science teacher, and have been extremely interested in quantum factors both in terms of philosophy and physics, I decided to give Schers book a try.Although Ive read none of the other reviews posted on Amazon (when I commit to a book, I like to form my own opinion from scratch) I note that they are pretty evenly distributed across the entire spectrum.  I must admit that some of the authors ploys (such as pages of numbers) really put me off.  Also, in the Kindle format, the hand written notes and other reproductions that were supposedly part of Hilarys report were unreadable, and therefore annoying.  It appears they were used merely as fillers.  The basic premise, of course, is that Dr. Kerek Reidier has apparently developed a mode of teleportation that involves using the quantized properties of matter/energy and the patterns of consciousness.  Of course, both government and private enterprise are determined to exploit his discovery for their own agendas.  The two narrator characters who carry the story are Daniel Brand, and his mother Hilary, who is a theoretical psychologist presumably commissioned by the government to prepare an in-depth report on the accident that occurred when The Reidier Test was performed (and a catastrophic explosion resulted).  Daniels mother has disappeared, leaving her son with the rough draft of this report.  It is Daniels attempts to utilize this document to perhaps discover Hilarys whereabouts or eventual fate that develop the intricacies of the narrative.Stylistically, there are some brilliant passages, and the story-line is presented effectively despite much of the extraneous material.  Characterization and the interactions between the key characters are vivid.  The narrative style, especially as it involves interjections by both Hilary and Daniel, is confusing at times, but it is possible to sort these out with a bit of focus.  The reader should not, of course, expect a neat happy ending, but if one is willing to go with the flow, the story is a fair read.

In my personal religious and intellectual experience, there has been no greater joy than to investigate and perceive the overlap of science and spirituality.  I have never doubted the existence of an overarching creative presence in the universe, and at one time I began to define this as an Omnipresent Intelligent Being (OIB).  I do not in any way accept the fundamentalist interpretations that consider the Creation Myth of the Judeo-Christian Scriptures to be a factual description of the origin of our universe or life upon this planet, but I likewise totally reject the notion pseudo-science sometimes proposes that everything is purely accidental.  When during my young adulthood I discovered the writings of Pierre Teilhard de Chardin (several of whose books Ive previously reviewed for Amazon), I knew I had encountered truth at a level much deeper than the superficial ideas involved in the current arguments between Creationists and Evolutionists.Therefore, with all my subsequent scientific and theological reading since, I have been searching for those writers who do in fact integrate scientific and spiritual insights in the same way Teilhard did, actually carrying his ideas forward as ever-new insights evolve in both areas.  Ilia Delio is one such writer that I am ecstatic to have encountered.  As both a scientist and a Franciscan Sister, Delio has all the necessary qualifications to continue to expand this dialogue.  Her writing is brilliant, thorough and completely readable.  In the past, the dissemination and development of Teilhards thought was hindered by the fact that his ideas were so revolutionary, the authorities of the Catholic Church (he was a Jesuit priest as well as a scientist) prohibited publication during his lifetime.  Thus he was unable to personally engage in the exchange of ideas among other scientists that is the lifeblood of the development and testing of theories.  Fortunately, the Second Vatican Council occurred shortly after his death when his work began to be published and translated, and thereafter his writings became more and more acknowledged among the new breed of theological thinkers which resulted from that Council.  In addition, the principles of quantum science became ever more prevalent in the scientific community, and have verified and reinforced Teilhards theory of complexity consciousness.I was fortunate indeed to hear Sr. Ilia speak at a recent conference sponsored by the Center for Action and Contemplation (CAC) here in Albuquerque, NM, where I live, and was completely enthralled by her presentations.  Needless to say, I purchased this book and have been reading it with complete fascination and great enjoyment.  It will be a cherished addition to my collection of books relating to the theology of Cosmic Consciousness along with Teilhards original works.

Without doubt, this is a theological study that will be completely rejected by many of those who most need to hear what Jeff Hood is saying.  On the other hand, it is definitely going to bring the Wind of the Spirit into other hearts that have been waiting and yearning for just such a refreshing.  At the beginning of the book, the reader will find glowing endorsements from nearly three dozen extremely diverse individuals, including Kittredge Cherry, whose comments initially led me to purchase this book.Hoods basic premise, the understanding that in the person and teaching of Jesus, God fully intends to confront and forever discredit the normative of human belief and practice, is not new.  What IS new is his use of the term queer as a noun, a verb, and even  capitalized  as a Name of God and the Divine Principle in Jesus and those who follow.  Although even those who, like me, agree with Hoods thesis may find that endless repetition of a term so often used as a pejorative is disturbing, I urge them to hang in there.  What Hood has to say is important enough to allow the concepts to come through regardless of the (intentionally employed) shock value of his vocabulary.I frankly acknowledge that I have never adhered to  perhaps a better descriptor might be been enslaved by  the normative concepts of law and conformity that bind so many people who believe they are following the Christ.  My parents before me were free thinkers, and when my dad Ted eventually became an active participant in a church congregation, it was only after informing the pastor that this action in no way implied acceptance of all the doctrines and premises of that particular group.  In his own mystical encounters with Cephas (St. Peter), Ted was told, Dont belong to church, belong to God.  Other aspects of my own life and belief have indeed led me to define myself as queer, which is a marvelously NON-DEFINING term indeed.  As a result, I can wholeheartedly applaud Jeff Hoods book as affirming my perception of what the Cosmic Consciousness  or in his term, the Queer  has in mind for the ultimate evolution of the human species.

Although The Telling by Jo Baker is described as A ghost story of the most unusual kind on the jacket blurb, I would really characterize it much more as two parallel stories.  There really is no connection in time or circumstance between the two protagonists, 19th century Elizabeth and 21st century Rachel.  The only connection is, of course, the Reading Room cottage in which Elizabeth lived and to which Rachel came in a time of extreme emotional stress following the death of her mother to try to dispose of the property.Both portraits of the women are vital and extremely involving, and the tone of the writing is authentic for each time period and set of circumstances, although there is no genuine overlap.  One gets the impression that Baker is really reaching a bit to try to convince the reader that something numinous is occurring, bringing in the typical signs of ghostly manifestation as experienced by Rachel during her stay in the cottage.  It is psychologically interesting, but not really convincing, and there is actually no reason given for Elizabeths haunting.  Obviously, she experienced a life-changing event during her early years in the cottage, but Baker makes it plain that she did not die young or, apparently, traumatically, so one wonders why the haunting.The most interesting part of the story for me was the description of the Chartist movement in mid-19th century England, and the discussion of the conflict between the church and the intellectuals of that era, because it echoes so completely much of what is happening in our own time.  Religious fundamentalists, far from supporting and uplifting the poor as the Gospel enjoins them, continue to pander to the wealthy few while simultaneously fighting the truths of science by mindless adherence to Biblical literalism.  Well, after all, only 160 or so years has passed; so perhaps this repetition of history is not really unexpected.

On more than one occasion Ive averred my growing interest in the memoir genre.  It is my firm conviction that everyone has a story, and that all stories are worth sharing and  as long as they are sincere and honest  should be accepted as non-judgmentally as possible.  Of course, that puts certain things off limits for reviewing.  I will not critique the beliefs, motivations or actions of the author, even though they may be very different from my own.Still, I believe that honesty on my part as a reviewer DOES require admission of the specific areas of my own inexperience and therefore to some degree lack of rapport.  Specifically, I have never experienced rape myself, nor has it happened to anyone near and dear to me.  In addition, my own philosophy and practice of parenting has been so diametrically opposite to that practiced by Mrs. Parker as described by her daughter that I really found it almost impossible to credit this behavior.  And, finally, Ive never felt the urge to attempt long-distance, endurance hiking; hence to even begin to accept that doing so is anything other than insane requires a significant stretch for me.Given these fiats, I have to evaluate Aspen Matis memoir as an astonishingly powerful piece of writing for a person as young as she is.  Her descriptions of her hiking experiences and the terrain she traversed are breathtakingly vivid.  The characterizations of her family members and the others she encountered during the journey are sensitive and engaging; even the not-so-charming characters are depicted with a certain sympathy and definite reality, including those who are presented only in brief vignettes.  Most important, the development of her psychological insight as the story progresses is incredibly authentic and valuable.  There really is wisdom here far beyond Aspens age.One thing only really bothers me at the end, and that is the ambiguity of what has actually happened with Dash.  There is only one comment in the epilog, and another very cryptic note in the acknowledgements, but this is a loose end that distresses me immensely.  Since this is an Advance Readers Edition that Im commenting upon, perhaps this concern will be addressed in the published edition.

1.  Has a no frills look -- the outer case is utilitarian and functional, but it looks like it should be an internal hard drive -- definitely NOT pretty.  It's thin, which is good, but not particularly light for its size.  It does not come with a case, so carrying it around might be problematic as it could be easily scratched on the outside.2.  Easy to install, just plug it in -- no instructions needed3.  Even though it says it is a 750GB hard drive, the software installed on it (auto-run etc) takes up 52GB, so you really only get 698GB of free space.4.  I have 81GB of pictures on my laptop, so I decided to back them up by copying them to the Seagate.  I connected the Seagate to a USB3.0 port.  The copy took over 40 minutes, which I consider to be very slow performance for USB3.0.Overall it is easy to use and when you have a lot of data to store, better than a thumb drive.  I would not consider this the kind of drive I would carry around with me.  The slowness of the interface, even though it says it is USB3.0, makes it impractical for use as a supplemental hard drive, but it would be fine for backup.  You would want to initiate the backup at night when you don't need to wait around for it to finish.Given the specified cost of >$50, I would rate it 3/5 because there are much faster (and sleeker) external drives out there in that price range.

Although Ive read a number of books recently relating to the circumstances surrounding the incarceration of Jews and others in Nazi concentration camps during WWII, I found The Prisoners of Breendonk to offer intriguing and unusual insights.  The book is lavishly illustrated, many of the illustrations being sketches by Jacques Ochs, a prisoner himself.  Ochs had been the director of the Academy of Fine Arts in Lige, Belgium, and had published an uncomplimentary cartoon of Hitler, which led to his imprisonment.  Frankly, I think this book would be worth it for these illustrations alone, but of course the histories are fascinating, as are the numerous photographic illustrations of the prison camp itself.This book is both extremely readable and extraordinarily informative about many of the sidelines of a prison camp.  Breendonk, utilizing as it did a previously-built structure that had been one of a series of forts surrounding the city of Antwerp, was not a death camp as such, and had an intriguing arrangement of prisoner quarters in what had at one time been barracks for the garrison.  The individual insights and character studies  especially as enhanced by Ochs caricature portraits  are incredibly poignant.

The real brilliance of Vanessa Diffenbaughs We Never Asked for Wings lies in her exquisite character development.  The plot is fairly basic and very contemporary; Letty Espinosa is the American-born daughter of Enrique, an artist who creates breathtakingly beautiful feather mosaic paintings and Maria Elena, a super mom.  The elder Espinosas are undocumented, but have lived in the San Francisco area for over thirty years.  However, as the narrative begins, Enrique has returned to Mexico due to his mothers illness; when he does not come back to the US, Maria Elena decides to also join him in Mexico.  The trouble is that during the past 15 years she has completely taken over the rearing of Lettys two children while her daughter has become the family breadwinner, working as a bar tender at a watering hole in the San Francisco airport.Feeling deserted and unable to take up the parenting role, Letty goes into complete panic mode and chases her mother down to the border, eventually actually accompanying Maria Elena to the family estate, which has fallen into complete disrepair.  She tries to persuade the parents to return with her and resume care of the kids, despite the extreme danger posed by tightened immigration restrictions.  They refuse, and from this point on the story of Lettys struggles to become a functioning parent to 15-year-old Alex, a brilliant kid in an extremely unacceptable high school situation, and 6-year-old Luna, precocious but completely disequilibrated by the loss of her care-giving grandma, balloons into a major family trauma.  The story is gravely complicated by the introduction of a love-interest for young Alex, Yesenia, who also turns out to be undocumented and has a physical impairment that renders her the prey of bullies at school.A fascinating sub-plot involves Enriques feather collection, which he has left as a heritage (both the collection itself, and a rich depth of knowledge about bird migration) to Alex.Although the story deals with the plight of undocumented individuals and the circumstances of young women  both Letty and Yesenias mother Carmen  who have become unwed mothers and are struggling to rear children in extremely dire circumstances, this is only part of the problem.  A much greater issue for me is the lack of communication occurring between parents and children, and the way in which one persons over-protectiveness of another ends up backfiring seriously.  Hopefully other readers of this charmingly-drawn story will find, as I did, both entertainment and significant food for thought.

When you have bought a book four or more times because you've given away numerous previously purchased copies, it says you think that book is vitally important.  My first encounter with David Ray Griffin's "Christian Faith and the Truth Behind 9/11" was on the "Sale" table of St. Phillips Cathedral bookstore in Atlanta, GA.  This was before I'd started reading and reviewing books for Amazon, but not before I'd begun to have my own serious personal doubts about the validity of the "official" findings of the government-appointed 9/11 Commission.That purchase was in fact a conscious-raising event of the highest order.  Griffin not only did an incredible amount of exquisite work in pulling together all the available information countering the "official conspiracy theory"; because he is a theologian of great repute, he also managed to put the unthinkable into the context of all the other false flag operations by which those who aspire to empire have opened the way to the diabolical throughout the ages.I read and re-read this book many times, shared it, reflected upon it, and then read all the subsequent writings by Griffin I could acquire, many of which I've also reviewed for Amazon, including "9/11 Ten Years Later"; "Debunking 9/11 Debunking" and "Cognitive Infiltration".  However, as it happens, I'd never shared my review of this book directly but only via references in reviews of my later purchases.  Having just purchased it yet again to replace the most recent "lost" volume which appears to have gone wandering amongst those whom I wished to introduce to Griffin's incredibly important insights, I will now remedy that deficit.If you sincerely CARE about the truth - especially as related to the 9/11 event - this is the ONE BOOK you need to read!

Well, it was my own fault that I ended up enmeshed in this book.  I didnt HAVE to choose to read it, although it was one of the few viable options on my Vine queue at that point.  Once I started, of course, it held the same morbid fascination as a multi-car wreck on the highway.Its too bad there isnt a dual rating system available, like they use for various sports competitions  one set of points for technical quality and one for enjoyment of the presentation.  Saul Blacks The Killing Lessons is pure horror from start to finish, and there is way too much collateral damage  but simultaneously, there is exquisite description and deeply appealing characterization.  Of course I know that the gruesome happens, and that normally sensitive human beings in law enforcement fields have to deal with the unthinkable and indescribable, and in the process become victims of PTSD.  Its just that in general Ive chosen to avoid the grimmest of the thriller type of narrative where all this is played out in gory detail.Anyway, this book is not for the faint of heart; but it IS masterfully articulated and vividly plotted.  I have been told that at times a critical review, if honest, can help other readers to evaluate a story realistically; this is my best effort at such a review.

Stonewall: Breaking Out in the Fight for Gay Rights by Ann Bausum is a delightfully written, nicely illustrated and  of course  very timely bit of contemporary history.  It is designed for the young adult reader  what I guess we are now calling the Millennials.  I lived through all the events she discusses, and, although I was not actively involved in the LGBTQ community until a decade after the Stonewall Riots (my first Gay Pride March was the 1979 Lavender Anniversary celebration in Atlanta, GA commemorating Stonewall) from that point on I was very much aware of and involved with the ongoing push for Gay Rights.  Bausum is accurate and clear in her discussion and explanation of the many events which occurred.  I can only wish, however, that because she gave some attention to the oppressiveness of many Christian denominations which initially contributed to refusing to acknowledge the human dignity of LGBT individuals, Bausum had also mentioned those pioneering individuals and denominations who went against the tide and  just as in the Civil Rights Movement  changed the consciences of so many.Bausums book was, of course, published before the Supreme Court decision supporting Marriage Equality, but she accurately predicted that such a decision was inevitable based on the changing attitude of the populace at large.The one thing that I really DIDNT know about the Stonewall event which Bausum clearly articulated was that the police raids that sparked the riot were NOT specifically motivated by police cruelty but rather by corruption.  She explains that the order to Close down the Gay Bars in NYC was prompted by the fact that those bars were Mafia controlled, and an elaborate extortion scheme with international ramifications had evolved by means of which closeted homosexuals in the financial sector of the city were blackmailed into stealing negotiable bonds.  The Mafia not only paid off local police to keep the bars open, but also used threats of exposure of these well-to-do closeted patrons to fuel the stolen-bond market.In all, as mentioned, this book is both timely and well-presented, and is a worthy addition to Ann Bausums already impressive array of titles relating to the major social justice issues in our nation.

Fatal Trauma by Richard L. Mabry,M.D. is a fast-moving medical thriller in the Christian Fiction category.  As such, it avoids the usual thriller pitfalls of foul language and explicit sex and violence.  Because the author is himself a doctor, the terminology and descriptions of the hospital setting are accurate.The initial incident in the story sets the scene as a man bursts into the ER of the hospital in which Mark Baker, the protagonist, works.  The man is holding a gun to the head of Kelly Atkinson, one of the nurses at the hospital, with whom Mark is falling in love.  Kelly is pushing a wheelchair containing the bleeding body of the gunmans brother.  By the time the ensuing chaos is over, the gunman and a security guard are also dead, and Mark and Kelly (along with other hospital personnel) have become revenge targets for the Zeta drug cartel, to which the two dead gangsters belonged.The story has a satisfactory number suspicious situations that turn out to be innocent circumstances, while in other cases evil lurks in unexpected locations.  In addition, the theme of losing and rediscovering a relationship with God carries through the plot of the narrative in an interestingly coherent way.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book without finding it overly challenging.

Having fed my pets Wellness products before, I tend to trust the brand.  Recently, I've found that my elderly feline has been having more and more difficulty digesting dry food, and I have been tending to feed more canned product.  However, she still likes "crunchies".  When I offered her the Kittles for the first time, she was delighted - but I fear ate them too enthusiastically, and almost immediately "yakked".  I have since been being more careful with amount, and hope that they will stay down.  I do caution other owners of cats with sensitive digestion to go slow with offering this product, which apparently tends to be on the rich side.

As stated in several recent reviews, I have become thoroughly delighted with Abingdon Press.  I have read a number of novels put out by this publishing house, but now Ive encountered a memoir that I believe to be absolutely superlative, Hidden Inheritance by Heidi Neumark.  This book combines deeply touching personal sharing with incredibly relevant theological, psychological and sociological insights.The author is a Lutheran pastor with a specific ministry in New York City at a shelter for LGBT and other abused and neglected youth.  Very recently, her daughter Ana found information on the Internet indicating that their family had Jewish roots and that in fact, Heidis grandfather Moritz Neumark had actually been Moses Isaac Neumark, and he and his wife Ida had been sent to the Theresienstadt (Terezn) concentration camp, where he had died.  Heidis grandmother Ida survived and emigrated to Switzerland, but during the entirety of her subsequent life (she died in the mid-1960s), there was no discussion of the circumstances of their war-time experience, and indeed, as Heidi Neumark did subsequent research, she became convinced that in fact her father had perhaps not even shared the fact of his Jewish heritage with his wife.Obviously, coming as a bolt out of the blue this revelation of family history proved to be a life-changing experience for Neumark.  As she went more deeply into available archival information, and indeed traveled to Germany to retrace the circumstances of her familys losses during the Shoah, the author also meditated upon the role of her own Lutheran faith in dealing with these horrific events.  She weaves together her own experience of dealing with this hidden inheritance and the traumas experienced by many of the young people in the shelter where she ministers in NYC.  The result is a deeply moving and extremely cogent call to awareness.  As those people who experienced the depredations of the Nazis and the incredible tragedies of WWII are passing from the scene, it becomes ever more relevant that endeavors like this narrative be undertaken by caring and sensitive descendants.  The fact is that many people, like Neumarks father and grandmother, apparently preferred to put the tragedies as far behind them as possible, avoiding bitterness but also avoiding sharing the truth.  We need to take seriously the adage that those who fail to learn from history are doomed to repeat it; but how can we learn if history is hidden from us?  This is why I believe that efforts such as the one Heidi Neumark so lovingly details in this memoir are of vital importance to all of us.

One of the major perks of being an Amazon Vine reviewer for me has been the opportunity to become acquainted with Abingdon Press.  I have found that virtually every book I have chosen from the Christian Books and Bibles section of Vine for All has been interesting, uplifting, and thoroughly enjoyable.  Conversations with Saint Bernard by Jim Kraus, however, exceeds in excellence.The basic plot is of course simple and straightforward.  George Gibson, still grieving the death of his wife, plans a cross-country trip as a valedictory.  Alex Burden, after a precarious childhood with repeated heart surgeries, seems on the mend until it turns out hes allergic to his beloved dog Lewis.  Through the intervention of Providence working through Georges daughter Tess and Alexs mother Trudy, it eventuates that Lewis becomes Georges traveling companion, but much more as well, during the time it takes for Alex to take desensitizing shots.  The dog is psychic, or perhaps an angel in disguise, and serves not only to bring George in contact with several people along the way that he needs to meet, but also insists that he confront and deal with the truth.The story is lively, amusing while of significance relevant to the issues it resolves, and develops the special character of Lewis without overplaying the anthropomorphism.  Other characters, as well as the under-girding theme of how prayer does (and doesnt) work make this a story well worth reading and sharing with loved ones.

This little lantern is attractive and simple, but not terribly sturdy.  Also, since it only comes with one of the repellent pads, long-term testing without re-ordering would be difficult.  I do not look up the "suggested price" of items before making an evaluation, so I can't say if the item would be "worth the price".  A plus value is that it included the requisite batteries, hence I could test it without having to supply those myself.  The light is dim, and this would not make it useful for actual visibility in the dark.  Frankly, except in situations where an open flame is inadvisable, I think the old-fashioned citronella candle or torch would probably be equally useful.

My husband is the coffee drinker of our family; there was a time when I actually refused to brew the stuff, because I thought the one who drank it ought to fix it.  Also, since we do not entertain a great deal, it is easy to "make do" with a much smaller coffee maker.  However, there are times when a larger capacity is desired, and one of our biggest concerns was the speed of brewing.  So the first thing we tested was the time required to process the full 12-cup capacity.  This was quite acceptable, taking only about 15 minutes.  Obviously, a smaller amount of coffee, under 4 cups (the lowest calibration on the carafe), brewed even more rapidly.  However, it was a bit difficult to evaluate the amount of water input needed for this smaller amount.  To be honest, I have not put the full capability of the computer control functions to the test; I'm much more of the "punch a button and wait til the little red light goes on" type.  However, the instruction manual (in 3 languages) is easy to read and thorough.  I would not hesitate to recommend this coffee maker to anyone who wants to prepare coffee quickly for a medium-sized group of people or a large family.  It is also compact, well-designed, and takes up minimal counter space.

This is a snack bar that contains everything I like, and nothing I don't enjoy.  The flavor is excellent, and the touch of salt greatly enhances without being overpowering.  I have long trusted the "Nature Valley" brand name, and I definitely think these bars do it justice.

Now this is an item which really "works" for me!  It is light weight and very easily assembled, which matters a lot to this 76-year-old.  I have used Swiffer products before, and one of my main concerns has in fact been that unlike vacuum cleaners, they didn't "pick up anything but dust".  The trap on this device really does work, though.  Most important for me is the low profile and ability to go under my king-size bed.  That space is now cleaner than it has been since I moved in to this house last fall.

Melvin Urofsky's "Dissent and the Supreme Court" is a fascinating and extremely timely history.  For a person like me who has no law degree and only a passing awareness of the history and development of the intricacies of Constitutional Law, it offers a great deal of enlightenment in a very accessible form.  Since as a Vine reviewer I'm reading the "uncorrected proof" version which lacks page references to the notes and other technical information, I can't make an immediate evaluation of its effectiveness for the serious student.  However, from the quality of the writing I can say emphatically that this book is extremely detailed and supported by voluminous research.  I especially appreciated the numerous illustrations (which, fortunately, WERE included in this proof version).  These greatly enhance the charm of what might otherwise be too academic.Admitted, in this "Google" era, it would be possible to look up many of the background details that Urofsky presents; however, I believe that the author's skilled compilation of this information following the important theme of his discussion greatly enhances understanding and enjoyment.  This is not a book to be read casually, but rather one to be studied and savored, which is what I am doing.

The memoir Here Comes the Sun: A Journey to Adoption in 8 Chakras by Leza Lowitz appealed to me on many levels.  First and foremost, as a story of adoption, it resonates thoroughly, because I have an adopted son.  Unlike Lowitz, we adopted not because I was infertile (wed already had four children) but to balance our family (we had three girls and a boy who desperately wanted a bro).  Also, in those pre Roe v. Wade days there were many available children in various difficult to place categories needing homes.  However, though the situation in Alabama, USA was not as tight in the late 1960s as it apparently is in Japan today, we did run into some serious road-blocks that made it easy to empathize with the challenges Leza Lowitz faced.Once I started reading, I found the thread of yoga practice and philosophy running through the story quite valuable.  I also meditate (though not in the yoga style) and am keenly aware of the importance of this type of centering practice, especially as it applies to weathering frustrations of life like those the author encountered in dealing with the difficulties of achieving motherhood, especially in the Japanese cultural milieu.A final fascinating aspect of this story is Lowitzs merging of her own Jewish background with the spiritual path of yoga and the description of her encounter with the hugging guru, Amma, of whom Id heard before and whose ministry intrigues me.In all, this book is honest, charming, beautifully written, informative, and extremely well-balanced.  I have no hesitation in giving it the highest rating possible.

Occasionally I think a bit of a fiat is needed in assisting the reader to place my reviews in the proper context.  That is certainly true in the case of Speaking in Bones by Kathy Reichs.  When I first accepted the invitation to participate in the Amazon Vine program, it was after Id reviewed several books at the authors request.  These were books that Id selected to read out of personal interest, and in general the writer making the request had not achieved best seller status.  Although having reached retirement age with a large accumulated library of old favorites I intend to re-read for pleasure, there are still certain favorite genres and authors whose new works I have felt motivated to select.  The Vine program has opened up my horizons, encouraging me to read books I might not otherwise have encountered.  However, when asked to review a best-selling author, I am frequently a bit stymied; if the writer already has a coterie of loyal fans, what is the point of gilding the lily?As it happens, Reichs Temperance Brennan novels had not previously become part of my library, although for the past several years the TV series Bones has been one of the few shows that Ive watched with anything like excitement.  In addition, a number of years ago (before my reviewing interest began), I read almost all of the Kay Scarpetta novels by Patricia Cornwell.  It is nearly impossible, therefore, to evaluate this book without mentally referencing these other series.  I have honestly tried, but I find that I would have far preferred to have NO mental image of Tempe Brennan working at the Jeffersonian along with her merry band; the woman in this novel may bear the same name, but there the resemblance comes to a screeching halt.The most thoroughly enjoyable part of this story for me was the turn of phrase that was part of Brennans narrated thought-processes.  The author has tremendous skill with clever analogy zingers that keep the mental peregrinations of her protagonist, as well as much of the dialog, lively and amusing.  The plot is acceptably convoluted, and the eventual resolution relatively plausible.  Certainly, given the fact that the author is herself a forensic anthropologist, one cant challenge the accuracy of the technical information she provides, so the book also has a great deal of educational value in that field.

After a long spell of other types of narrative, this is my second Sci Fi book in a row.  However, it could scarcely be more different than The Empress Game (reviewed 6/14/15).  This book is high tech with all the action focused on the problems with the computer in a revolutionary-design secret starship, the Ananke.  The action takes place not in some imaginary space empire, but in our own Solar System, where, apparently, human habitation has extended to the various other planets and/or their moons as a result of terraforming.  However, it seems that these various colonies established in the extremely inhospitable environments thereby provided, are exploited and oppressed.  The System  meaning the central administrative government ruling these domed environments, is totalitarian in the extreme.A good part of the story revolves around the efforts of Althea, the computer tech who was largely responsible for the design of Ananke, to resolve the computer malfunctions resulting from the introduction of a virus by the two intruders, Gale and Ivanov, who break into the starship at the beginning of the story.  In addition, the three-person crew of the ship, after capturing Ivanov, is subsequently taken over by Ida Stays, the System investigator who comes aboard to interrogate Ivanov and to try to establish his connection with the terrorist group which is fomenting revolution.  Whatever part of the narrative does not involve fruitless efforts to fix the computer is made up of exhaustive (and exhausting) descriptions of this interrogation.None of the characters, with the possible exception of Althea and the Ananke hersef, even border on the appealing or sympathetic.  Of course, shades of HAL in 2001: A Space Odyssey, it should surprise no one to know that Ananke becomes human, and indeed begins to consider herself a god.  Again, this story is the first of a series; the announced sequel, Supernova, will doubtless hinge on further adventures of Althea and Ananke, since most of the other characters (with the exception of Ivanov and Gale) have been eliminated. This is not a spoiler, by the way, since it is referenced early in the narrative.Im a bit doubtful about the scientific accuracy of much of this narrative, especially the plausibility of colonies on the outer planets and their moons, and did find the inclusion of all the interrogation aspects more than a bit tedious.  However, there are some intriguing aspects of the story, particularly the inclusion of the Laws of Thermodynamics as section headings.  All in all, it was compelling and interesting.

This is a neat little FM transmitter that has a lot of cool options.  I like that this is quite small and doesn't stick way out from my cigarette lighter like some others do.  The design is nice and I like the blue and black colors of it.  The front piece with all the controls pivots on the cigarette adapter part so that you can adjust this to face various angles.  There is a knob and buttons on the front that work the controls and allow you to answer calls.  This also comes with a remote which is a nice added feature so that even someone in the back seat can change songs and such when you are using this device.  This has many input options which is great.  It accepts wireless, but also can be used with micro SD cards, TF, and USB and aux cord which is included.  You can also use the USB to charge up to two devices at a time even while talking or listening to music.  I found this easy to pair with my phone and the sound quality on my end was great for both music and talking.  The downfall that forced me to give it four stars instead of five was the sound quality on the end of the person I am talking to.  The microphone could be better on this because the sound for the other person tends to be a bit muffled and not always easy to hear.  Otherwise this is a great device that is easy to use and works well.  I received this transmitter at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a great little transmitter and I would definitely recommend it:)!!

These little inhalers are perfect for use on the go because they are smaller than the average tube of lipstick and fit easily in your pocket or purse.  There are six inhalers in this set that include stress ease, insomnia relief, breathe easy, mood lift, zen, and inner peace.  Each is made up of various essential oils to achieve the particular effect desired.  I have been very congested lately because I struggle with seasonal allergies and sinus problems and I have found the breathe easy inhaler to be my new best friend.  It is mild, but helps to clear my nose when I am feeling stuffy.  I love that it is all natural and I don't have to worry about breathing in any drugs or chemical.  These are super easy to use.  You simply remove the cover and place this by your nose and breathe in.  All of the great benefits of the included essential oils go to work right away.  This set has a nice variety and also comes in a really nice gift box making it great to give as a gift.  I would defiantly caution you to buy two though if you plan to gift these because you won't want to let them go once you get them:)  I received this set of essential oil inhalers at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of them at all.  This is a great set of inhalers and I would absolutely recommend them:)!!

I think that essential oil diffuser necklaces were a brilliant invention.  What better way to enjoy the benefits of your essential oils for a person constantly on the go.  I use my regular humidifier diffusers when I am at home and working at my computer but for many people, sitting in one place for a period of time during the day is not possible.  Many people have active, on the go lifestyles and I think this necklace is the perfect solution for those people.  Not only does it make a great fashion statement with the Aum design and classic black cord, but it smells amazing and allows you to benefit from whatever oil you choose all day long.  This comes with five little cotton disks that you can put your oil on and it opens like a regular photo locket.  You simply put the cotton disk inside and close it back up and you are breathing the oils benefits in no time.  This is also a great alternative to perfume.  I can be very sensitive when things are applied directly to my skin.  With my essential oils, I can still smell great without applying perfume each day.  This comes with a small bottle of inner peace oil which is a blend of orange, clove, germanium, lavender, and patchouli.  It has a light, relaxing scent that I really like.  This necklace comes in a metal canister case with a clear top and I feel it just adds to the great quality of this product and makes it great for gifting, but I would suggest buying two because you will want to keep one for yourself:)  I received this essential oil diffuser necklace set at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a great set and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

These are super cute little storage containers but they definitely are small so keep that in mind when purchasing them depending on your needs for them.  The listing mentions earphones and SD cards but neither will actually fit in these and that is why I gave them four stars instead of five.  I felt that the listing was a bit deceiving due to the wording.  That being said these are very cute and well made and do work great for other things.  They snap together snugly and are a nice heavy plastic material.  They would be great to keep a few tylenol or other pills in to take in your purse or tote bag.  I plan to use them for my daughter's earrings.  She does several sports that don't allow her to wear earrings for competition and she never seems to remember to take them out ahead of time.  We usually arrive at the event and she asks me to take her earrings for her.  I never have any good place to put them and they are kind of small to just stick in my pocket so these little cases will be perfect.  This is a package of six and I plan to stick one in every one of her sports bags.  They will keep her earrings safe and together and easy for her to find afterwards.  I received these little macaron shaped cases at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of them at all.  These are cute little cases that would work great for a number of things and I would definitely recommend them:)!!

These sticky notes are hilarious and great for a lot of laughs or to put someone in their place who has a parking problem.  I bought these with my best friend's husband in mind.  I am always yelling at him because he has a big truck and intentionally takes up four parking spaces when he goes somewhere so that nobody parks too close to him.  These come in different versions and the one I got has a donkey on it and says, "See this Jackass?  Even he can park better than you can!"  These come in a sticky pad just like post it notes and you just peel them off and stick them to your subject's window or door.  I put a couple on his driver's window and one on his windshield to be sure he saw them.  He wasn't expecting them at all and when he went back to his car after football practice, the look on his face was priceless.  He vows to get even with me and I can't stop laughing.  I received these sticky parking tickets at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of them at all.  These notes are perfect to get your point across to someone in need of parking lessons and I would absolutely recommend them:)!!

This is a great little bluetooth, wireless hands free device.  I love how small it is.  I have a few of these and this one is the smallest so far and I love that about it.  It fits nicely in my ear but I don't feel like I am carrying a full sized phone on my head.  I am very impressed with this headset for the price.  I find the sound quality to be quite good both when listening to music and when using it for hands free calling.  This has a built in microphone to use it for hands free calling and my husband says that I am sometimes hard to hear on his end so the quality of the microphone could definitely better but I am not docking it a star because we are able to have a conversation and for $10 I don't think you will find a better quality.  This headset comes with a standard USB charging cable and a plastic hook to go over your ear to help hold it in place.  I received this bluetooth headset at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a nice little headset for such a low price and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

Nothing that you buy at the store in a jug compares to fresh squeezed juice straight from the fruit.  It not only tastes great, but it's great for you.  This juicer is awesome and perfect for achieving just that.  First off, I love the look of this juicer.  It is stainless and black in color and looks really impressive when setup on my counter.  And although, looks can sometimes be deceiving, this juicer works as great as it looks.  It has a powerful motor and sharp blade that juices harder items such as carrots with ease.  I like that this has an overheat protection built in so this will shutoff to protect the motor if it starts to get too warm while working.  This is very easy to use and works wonderfully.  Cleanup is definitely not the fun part.  This like most juicers I have seen does take a little more work to cleanup that it does to make the juice.  That being said I love that this juicer includes a nice cleaning brush making it much easier to get the excess pulp cleaned from the juicer.  I was also impressed that I received an email with detailed instructions to get the most from the juicer.  I told the best way to juice various items and gave helpful tips.  I received this premium high yield juicer at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a very nice juicer that not only looks great in my kitchen, but also performs as good as it looks and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

I really love this little backpack and especially the color.  This is a very lightweight material that is also very durable and great for hiking or cycling or other outdoor activities.  The zipper pulls are heavy duty and almost remind me of wire ties with a little more rubbery texture to them.  All of the zippers are durable and zip and unzip very well.  This backpack is a single strap sling style bag with an adjustable strap.  One feature I really love is that there is the small zippered pocket on the shoulder strap.  This is great for your keys or money or other small item that you want to have easy access to while wearing the pack.  There is a large zippered compartment which also has an inner separating pocket.  There is a smaller zippered pocket on the front perfect for a cell phone or wallet and there is an elastic water bottle pocket on the side.  I gave this backpack to my best friend who enjoys riding motorcycle with her husband.  She wanted a small bag that she could carry some essentials in when they go on short rides.  She loves this bag and says it is perfect for what she wanted it for.  I got the purple with yellow accents, but there are plenty of colors to choose from to meet your personal tastes.  I received this shoulder sling style backpack at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a really nice and durable backpack that is great for a day out to keep your essentials close by and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

I love these titanium necklaces and I ordered this one for our foreign exchange student.  Both of my kids have one of these necklaces and love them.  I wanted to get our exchange student one also so that she had it in her new school colors.  These comes in so many different colors so you can get the right colors to show your school or organization pride.  I ordered the red, black, and white and really love it.  It represents our school colors perfectly and my exchange student loves it also.  This has a quick connect so that it is safe to wear for sports or pretty much any activity because if pulled on with force it will come apart and not choke the wearer.  This necklace is very durable and well made also so it is great for kids and for everyday wear.  I received this sports necklace at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a great necklace and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

This is the nicest set of styluses that I have ever gotten.  This is a set of four and they come in pink, purple, blue, and black.  The body of the stylus is made from stainless steel and aluminum so they are very solid feeling.  They have a clip on the side just like most pens that allows you to attach them to your pocket or a notebook.  The tips are interchangeable when they start to wear out and the set comes with four spare tips.  I have to be honest that when I received these I was a bit nervous about them.  The tip feels like a metal mesh and I was concerned it would scratch my screen.  I took the plunge and tried it and it ran across my screen as smooth as butter.  It is very high-sensitive and works great on both my phone and tablet screens.  Another thing I love about these styluses is that they have a small loop on the bottom end and included with the set are two short connector cables and two longer ones.  What I mean by connector cables is that they have the plugs that hook into your phone's headphone jack and on the other end the long ones have a small keyring type loop that can hook to the stylus loop.  The shorter ones have a lobster claw closure to attach to the stylus.  This is a great way to keep your stylus with your tablet or phone at all times.  I received this high sensitivity stylus set at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of them at all.  This is a great set with lots of cool extras and I would absolutely recommend them:)!!

This monokini tassel bikini is not for the faint of heart.  If you have any body image issues then this is not for you because it is definitely revealing and meant to be a sexy item.  I think the design definitely succeeded in the sexy department and it is very well made and put together.  The material is silky feeling and stretchy and very comfortable the wear.  My problem is that it is not made for anyone with large breasts.  It has foam inserts in the cup areas which can be removed but there is not near enough material to cover and support large breast either with or without the foam cups.  I have a DDD breast and while the rest of the suit fit me like a glove, there was no way that my breasts were staying in this suit.  I don't see this as much of a design flaw because I am aware that most women who order this size will have smaller breasts that will most likely fit the suit just fine and so I didn't dock it a star for this, but I would definitely caution you to be aware of this when ordering.  Overall, I love the swimsuit and was sad that it will not work for my body type.  The design is very nice and definitely an eye catcher in the sexy department.  I received this swimsuit at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a nice suit and I would definitely recommend it:)!!

This is recommended for use in scaring away other small animals but I like it just a cool looking decoration as well.  It comes with mounting hardware so you can mount it to a pole or elsewhere deepening on your desired use.  I set it on the top step of my porch and love how its eyes glow at night.  It charges with the sun daily so you have to make sure you put it where it will get enough sun each day for charging so that it continues to glow at night.  As a prank, I put it just inside our bushes a couple of nights ago and totally freaked my kids out when they saw the glowing eyes in the bush.  It was pretty funny and my husband and I couldn't stop laughing.  I really like this owl and he is a great new addition to my porch.  I received this owl at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This owl is really cool and works really well and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

This is a great towel for yoga or any other exercise that causes you to break a sweat.  It is super soft and absorbent and I like to use it for toweling off my face and neck during and after my yoga class.  This towel is machine washable and dryer friendly as well which makes it super easy to clean and have ready for your next workout.  I really love that there is a zippered pouch on it also.  I put my keys and phone in it to keep them safe and out of sight at the yoga studio during my workout.  This is definitely one of my favorite yoga towels.  It is a nice thickness and the microfiber is very smooth and softer than some of my others. This is just what I wanted for her room because especially in the winter her floors sometimes get chilly and this fits perfectly beside her bed to catch her little toes when she first gets up in the morning. What I love most about this leather conditioner is that it isn't oily like so many others I have tried.  It leaves the leather feeling soft without that oily residue that so many others have.  I do wish it had a nice after smell but that being said it doesn't have a bad smell either so I can live with that part.  I love that it comes with a nice sponge applicator to easily apply it to any sized surface.  I used this on my leather boots and my leather handbag and was pleased with the results on both.  I like that this helps to protect my leather when I go outside in the rain or snow as well because it helps to make the items water repellent.  My handbag is old and has been starting to show some wear and age and I really felt like this leather conditioner restored some of its old life back to it.  My boots are newer but it still gave them an added shine that they didn't have before.  I have been impressed with the long term affect of this product also.  The shine on both my boots and handbag is still looking freshly conditioned after more than a week.  This product has my respect and works like it says it will.  I received this leather conditioner at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a great leather conditioner that leaves your leather products looking great and I would absolutely recommend it:)

I am really impressed with this leather cleaner from leather nova.  It comes in a spray bottle making it super easy to apply and use and is a generous size bottle as well with a full eighteen ounces.  Included with your purchase is a microfiber towel that is the perfect companion to this cleaner.  You simply spray the cleaner on your towel and massage it into the leather to loosen dirty and grime.  This helps lift the dirt to the surface and then you can use a clean, dry cloth to wipe it away.  The bottle suggests waiting a couple of minutes for tougher stains before wiping them away.  We just purchased a new SUV.  It is new to us but is a used vehicle and the previous owners clearly had children and very messy children at that.  They didn't take very good care of the leather seats and although the dealership cleaned it before we bought it, they didn't do a great job.  I took this leather cleaner and went to work on the spots that were still noticeable to me and was very impressed with the difference.  I was able to get the seats looking almost new again and I really love that there are no harsh chemicals and smells in this.  I am quite sensitive to harsh smells and didn't find this to be bothersome when using it.  I received this leather cleaner at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a great leather cleaner that does an excellent job and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

I absolutely love everything about these solar LED string lights.  The first thing that I noticed that I think is an awesome feature is that the flower blossoms are a rubbery material.  This is genius.  Every other set of lights like these that I have owned, the flower part is a rigid plastic and a few flowers always end up breaking with normal use.  These are so much better and I feel will hold up a great deal longer due to this fact.  The lights themselves are beautiful.  They have a light blue tint to them and there are several lighting options.  They have a solar panel that also has the control buttons on it which are super easy to use.  There is an on/off button and a mode button.  You simply press them to use them.  With the lights on, you can switch modes and there are several to choose from.  You can have them on constant, twinkling, or several different flashing/blinking options.  These lights are really pretty and in my opinion an exceptional quality.  I received these solar LED lights at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of them at all.  I love these lights and I would absolutely recommend them!!:)

This is a nice large package of privacy fence screen and the quality is excellent in my opinion.  It is a thin, tarp like material that even includes grommets for easy attachment to your fence.  This is black but the woven material is great for allowing air to still pass through.  We actually decided to use some of this on our outdoor dog kennel to help provide a bit of shade to our dog on the east side of his pen.  It still allows for air to pass in so he can benefit from the breeze in the summer but keeps some of the bright sun out.  This is thick enough that it definitely does provide a privacy barrier as well.  When our dog is next to it in his kennel, you can barely see him on the other side. I love that this bluetooth hands free speaker hooks to your visor.  I have had several of these and I like the visor location the best.  That being said, the one problem I have with this is the volume and that is why I gave it four stars instead of five.  The volume option needs to be louder.  I sometimes find it hard to hear when I am driving.  When I am able to hear it well though, this is a great little device.  It paired easily with my phone and the buttons are nice and large and easy to use for the functions.  I like the size of this overall and it fits my visor nicely.  I really wish that the volume could go louder because this would be my new favorite hands free unit.  Overall though, this is a great little bluetooth hands free speaker.  I received this speaker at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all. If you are looking for lightweight and compact then look no further because this is definitely the backpack for you.  This backpack comes zipped up as a small pouch.  You unzip the pouch and turn it inside out and you have a backpack.  The pouch it comes in is part of it and then becomes an internal zippered pouch within the backpack.  This is awesome because when you are not using this backpack it is a great way to store it and it takes of barely any room at all.  The backpack itself is waterproof and made of a material that is tear resistant as well making it great for hiking or outdoor activities.  The backpack while being able to be folded up so compact is actually quite roomy when opened up and can hold a change of clothes or small towel as well as small necessities like keys or a wallet.  There are pouches on the sides for holding water bottles also.  The straps are comfortable and adjustable for an easy fit.  This also comes in several colors to meet your personal tastes which is nice.  I got purple and I love it.  I received this backpack at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a great lightweight waterproof backpack for hiking or other activities and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

This is a great bluetooth wireless mouse that is super easy to setup and use.  This mouse takes one "AA" battery that is not included.  You simply install the battery in the bottom of the mouse and turn on the small on/off switch located near the battery compartment.  Make sure that your bluetooth settings on your computer are on to detect devices.  Press the connect button on the bottom of the mouse for a couple of second to let your computer detect your mouse.  Once paired this mouse works completely wirelessly with your computer.  This is a pretty basic mouse that has all of the typical features for navigation.  There is a page up and down button on the side and a typical scrolling wheel on the top with right and left click buttons.  This is a curved design which I find to be very comfortable in my hand to use.  I received this mouse at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a very nice little mouse and at a great price and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

I have a bunch really nice flashlights that take this size rechargeable batteries.  This is a great extra battery to have charged and on hand for my flashlights.  This battery is 3500mAh and has overcharge discharge protection.  This battery is rated to have over five hundred charge-discharge cycles so it will last a for many many uses.  One thing that I love is that this came with a nice little plastic snap shut storage box.  I plan to charge this battery and store it in the battery case for when I need a spare for my flashlight.  I received this battery at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  This is a great battery to have as an extra for your high end devices and I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

This is a nice yoga mat for the price if you just want something lightweight to put between you and the floor when exercising.  I only gave it four stars because it is quite thin and not a mat I would get for everyday workouts.  If you are going to be using it randomly from time to time and just want something to add a barrier between you and the floor then this is a decent mat for the price.  If you are a hard core yoga fanatic, I would spend more money and go with something more durable and thicker to give a more comfortable surface that will also last longer.  A nice bonus of this mat is that it comes with antibacterial wipes to help keep it clean.  Overall this is a good mat for the low price.  I received this mat at a discounted rate for my honest and unbiased review but that does not affect my opinion of it at all.  If you are a looking for a cheap yoga mat for casual use then I would absolutely recommend it:)!!

This is a really nice accessory set for a go pro style camera.  It includes a lot of different options for mounting the camera for various uses.  This set includes a head strap, a chest strap, a selfie stick, a hand float, a windshield mount, and several attachments as well as a wrench to tighten and loosen the screws that hold them together.  I have gotten other sets before and never had a wrench included so I thought that was pretty cool because sometimes it is hard to get ahold of the screws to tighten and loosen them well.  This set also comes with a very nice drawstring, velvet bag to store all of the pieces in.  Each piece is made very well and is nice and durable.  The elastic of the head and chest straps is thick and wide and fits well and feels comfortable to wear.  The quality of each piece of this set is excellent in my opinion and this set gives you many options for shooting with your camera. This is a great set of silicone wedding rings.  They are solid black and each come in a small hinged plastic box which is great for storage or gifting.  The top of the box is clear so you can see the ring through the lid.  This set includes sizes eight through twelve so they are great for gifting or if you have any issues with your hands swelling, it gives you options to change the size as you need.  The rings are a nice thick silicone that is durable and safe to wear.
