And she plastered the attic room with horrific images of women being tortured and killed for their evil natures.  But it appears She may have come to believe these images to be true.  She berates herself constantly for her guilt and evilness.  It could be that women are inherently evil, or that a SEXUAL woman is evil.  After all, their son died while she was enjoying sex.  And throughout the film, she occasionally practically rapes her husband, and these moments of brief physical release seem to be her only moments of relative control (not sanity, though.  Just harnessing her wildness.)  Have her studies and the events of her life rendered her convinced of the crazy notion that she is evil...or is she ACTUALLY evil, as VonTrier seems to hint.  We get ideas that she...may have been a little unhinged (especially about her son) prior to his death.  She seems to not only FEEL responsible but perhaps actually IS responsible for what happened.3)  Visually, the film has some stunning moments.  There are some scenes of beautiful slow-motion, in particular the opening.  (I liked the slow-motion better in MELANCHOLIA, but it's nonetheless quite something here too.)  There are many alarmingly disturbing moments (consider yourself warned that there are moments where you must turn away from the images on screen).  The actors give strong, committed performances, especially Gainsbourgh, who is really quite something in this film.  VonTrier, the director, is pretty effective in working his audience over.  VonTrier the writer is perhaps just a little too proud of himself and sometimes wallows in imagery or metaphors that are a bit too heavy-handed.I can only give the film, despite some strong elements, 3 stars because it is so deeply unpleasant to watch (overall) and because it is too clever by half.  I'm great with "art films" or "indie films"...but VonTrier just tries too hard at times.  He's never yet done better than BREAKING THE WAVES...a movie with some humanity.  In the end, ANTICHRIST seems to hate both its main characters and we sort of do too...thus we are left with a film with no compassion towards the suffering parents.  Simply put, I didn't like that.By the way, I watched the Criterion Blu-Ray.  The movie itself looks and sounds great.  The essay provided is thoughtful.  The bonus materials are a bit skimpy, given that this is a fairly recent film.  There are a few moderately interesting interviews with the two stars...but the little "making of" videos are brief and very surface-level.  We don't quite get the "academic" dive into the film that Criterion gives us in their best releases.

The movie JAWS is one of my all-time favorites.  I saw it as a young teenager and it just totally changed the way I saw films.  Everything about it was great, but one element I learned to appreciate more and more over the years was the performance of Roy Scheider.  He was the "everyman" in the film, and when I saw him in other movies over the years, that's kind of how he always struck me.  A bit unusual looking, but friendly and stolid.  So that makes his performance in ALL THAT JAZZ all the more of a revelation.  To say his Joe Gideon is larger-than-life is an understatement.  He's a brilliant director and choreographer who is failing miserably at being a father, husband, lover and "good person."  But he doesn't even care.  To him, life is a performance (for him, seduction is just an extension of the idea of performing), and he even choreographs his own inner musings as though they were stage productions.  He choreographs shows and he tries to choreograph life.  When this doesn't work out for him, he just starts over, heedless of the damage his failed attempts leave behind.  He works hard and lives hard.  He can tell he's very sick (too much smoking, mostly) but he also feels invincible.  As long as he can create, he will live.Scheider gets this all with remarkable detail.  He's playing a jerk/genius, hardly a new idea in films...but he gives him a down-to-earth believability that elevates the film.  And when Joe Gideon begins to realize he is in a creative rut, where his own ideas fail to excite him anymore (even as those around him applaud his efforts), he begins to see his life slipping away too.  If he can't be a brilliant creator and not just a rehasher of his own work...he can't stave off the damage he's done to himself.The best parts of the film are really the dance numbers.  The opening scene...a cattle call audition...is more chaotic and more memorable than the opening of A CHORUS LINE.  The use of "On Broadway" is classic.  Near the mid-point of the movie, Joe shows his producers his new choreography that features lots of sensuality and nudity.  It's a great scene and still feels a bit daring even today.  Ann Reinking gets to strut her stuff in several memorable numbers, and actress Leland Palmer also makes quite an impression.So why only 4 stars?  Well, this is a film about indulgence (or self-indulgence if you will) to some degree, and occasionally director/writer/choreographer Bob Fosse over-indulges a bit.  And unfortunately, it's mostly towards the end.  Joe is in the hospital, and as his situation grows more dire, his fantasies become a bit more elaborate.  The numbers where he's laying in his post-surgical bed, watching as an imaginary, healthier version of himself directs various numbers geared to tell Joe how he has wasted his life OR the grand-finale set on a TV variety show soundstage simply go on too long.  We get the idea in about half the time Fosse takes to show it, and the choreography is among the LEAST imaginative of the film.  The climax is just drawn out.  (Although the final few seconds of the film are nicely and concisely done.)Also, I found Jessica Lange (who is a great actress), as the "angel of death" character Gideon imagines is waiting for him to be far too willowy and diaphanous and soft-focus.  She makes for, in my opinion, a silly metaphor.  Not Lange's fault, so much as the director.  Maybe it felt fresh in 1979, but not so much now.Speaking of fresh, if you can possibly see the film (as I did) on the Criterion Blu-Ray...DO!!  It is fantastic.  The colors pop...all those awful, wonderful Danskins and male dancers wearing tube socks.  The '70s show-biz look if a blast to look at.  And the sound is fantastic.  It's just at 3.0 surround track...but it still fills up the room.  And the bonus features are very plentiful, including a great interview from Tom Snyder of both Fosse and Agnes DeMille.  These two greats of the stage, both innovators in their time, are just amazing to watch together.

Michael Shannon is simply terrific at playing the "creepy" guy...the one with perhaps a normal exterior, but whose inner life is deeply troubled.  Usually, he delivers these shadings in the service of relatively nice guys (REVOLUTION ROAD, TAKING SHELTER [maybe his best role] and BUG, for example).  These are all nice guys with issues.  Shannon lets us see the surface and also the anguish just below.  Whether it's a gaze that doesn't quite meet your eyes, or a furrowed brow or just a turn of phrase...he's never less than riveting and just a little scary.In THE ICEMAN, he has found the perfect character...one that no one but him could have played as well.  While his lead role in the remarkable TAKING SHELTER is perhaps his most layered performance; his role in this true story is perhaps the most tailor-made for him.  Which IS ironic, since it's a true story.  Shannon plays a cold-blooded killer for the Jersey mob.  Over the decades, it is estimated he killed over 100 people.  In all manners of death and without remorse or pity.  And without any seeming enjoyment.  His face is a blank stare.  When he is threatened with death, he has virtually no reaction beyond mild curiosity...and when he kills, there is even less going on.  But when he is temporarily sidelined, he becomes like a caged animal, literally pacing and on edge and ready to explode.  Killing clearly is his way of exorcising some kind of personal demon.At the same time, Shannon is married and has a lovely family he cherishes above all else.  His feelings, though a bit tightly contained, seem genuine.  He loves his wife (Wynona Ryder) and never strays from her.  His daughters are the light of his life.  He keeps them sheltered from what he really does, and provides for them well.  He is a bit of an odd-bird, even to his wife...but certainly no one would suspect what he really does.This is a dark and low-budget film.  There is little sunshine to be found, and given that much of it takes place in the '70s, it has an extra sheen of grime that comes with all the polyester.  And the plot itself is pretty straightforward.  We know (because the first scene shows us) that Shannon will be caught, but because he is surrounded by other low-life thugs who seem even more petty than him, we actually sort of root for the guy.  The story is told through his eyes almost entirely, and we cannot help but side with him just a bit.  There is, I reluctantly admit, something a bit gripping about seeing someone who is a master at what he does at work.Shannon is the main reason, by far, to see this film.  He is mesmerizing throughout.  Ray Liotta  has a significant role as the mob boss...doing the exact same character he's been doing for about 20 years.  Ryder is fine...the role is hardly one that would revive her career, but it's good to see her in something where she isn't making fun of herself too.  Best of all is Chris Evans as another hit man, who embarks on a years long collaboration of sorts with Shannon.  His personality is all flash and sparkle...and Evans, normally such a straight-laced good guy (CAPTAIN AMERICA, anyone?) looks great in the '70s garb and hair.  He's busting out with energy, creating a stark contrast with Shannon's contained rage.We find out very little about this true to life character.  We get a tiny glimpse at what may have broken in him, but no sense of what makes him so casual about killing.  His love for his family seems genuine and shows real emotion.  Yet he appears to be a sociopath of the first order.  The two sides of him make for an uneasy reconciliation for the viewer, which I feel only adds to the power of the film.The climax of the film comes fast and surprising.  And Shannon finally gets a chance to let loose...and it's a thing of power and rawness.  And unlike with his silly character in MAN OF STEEL, when this guy sees his life instantly collapsing, his outcry of rage and horror is chilling.I highly recommend this film, although it does have a bleak outlook on life and humanity.  I didn't feel depressed at its conclusion (not at all, it is so well done), but I wasn't exactly uplifted!  [By the way, James Franco receives pretty high billing in the film and is on the cover of the disk.  He is in exactly one brief scene.  Just to warn ya.]

CHLOE is a very implausible movie, but it has a classy sheen and some high-class actors.  It comes from director Atom Egoyan, so it has artsy overtones.  But at its heart, it is trashy fun, almost in the FATAL ATTRACTION vein.Julianne Moore is a tightly wound OB/GYN, married to handsome music professor Liam Neeson.  The two have built a good life on the surface, but they have a troubled teenage son (Max Theriot, later from TV's BATES MOTEL) and are no longer physically close.  Moore is convinced her husband is having an affair, and she hires a prostitute (Amanda Seyfried) to make the moves on her husband, to see if he responds.  It's a dangerous game and Moore finds that this relationship between her husband and the hooker seems to bring her closer, erotically, to her husband.  While all the characters have roughly the same screentime, this is really Moore's movie, and she does a solid job (as always) balancing between her dismay at her arousal and being drawn further into these unfamiliar feelings.  I've deliberately kept this a bit vague, because I don't want to spoil the various entanglements that ensue.  But as I said, she's playing a dangerous game with her own emotions and the emotions of others.  It all culminates in a bit of an over-the-top climax, but it does come somewhat full-circle.Not only is Moore good, but Seyfriend is beguiling.  I wouldn't say she gives a great performance, and her character is far too "wise" in knowing the secret hearts of others...but if we look at this film as more of a psycho-sexual thriller and less of a drama, her performance makes more sense.  Neeson is solid.  And Atom Egoyan, whose SWEET HEREAFTER and EXOTICA are great movies, does do a good job of giving the film a sense of being more important and having more to say than it really does...but it's really entertainment first and thoughtful a distant second.If I could, I'd give the film 3.5 stars.  It's worth seeing, I think, but not something you should drop everything for.  It's a very adult movie, obviously, and does have a few graphic scenes and some graphic language.  But it is good, clean, "dirty" fun.

I've said it before and sadly, I must say it again...some perfectly okay horror films have been much diminished by having silly or incomprehensible endings.  Sure, every movie wants to do something like leave room for a sequel...but too many horror films (in particular) seem to fumble their conclusions/climaxes.  Finding a satisfactory resolution for something that's already requiring more suspension of disbelief than usual is just tough.AS ABOVE, SO BELOW certainly falls into that trap. It has an excellent set up...a group of young adults sets out to explore the catacombs below the city of Paris.  This is actually a premise that could be rooted in reality (like the setting of THE CHERNOBYL DIARIES).  And there are some early thrills in these explorations, although they also felt a little bit like poorly done rip-offs of better scenes in THE DESCENT.  We get plenty of creepy images, featuring hooded figures or weird groups of women.  And when things start going poorly, we can actually sort of believe these guys would keep moving forward because their "leader" is a driven archeaologist wanna-be (Perdita Weeks) who has already been shown to have a propensity for driving ahead regardless of the danger, like a reporter in war zone.  So her companions follow her just a bit blindly, until things are suddenly so bad, it's time to go back.  Only, of course, the trip back is not nearly as simple as the trip down the unexplored caves and hallways.The film has atmosphere aplenty.  If you've got a surround-sound system, you should be quite impressed by the sound design.  Certainly a few jarring moments.But there are real head-scratching moments and things left unresolved.  For example, for a good chunk of the film the main characters are joined by a mysterious man who was apparently a catacomb-explorer himself, but had disappeared quite some time ago.  Suddenly he appears, and it's clear (at least to the viewer) that this guy is not right in the head.  Then suddenly, he commits a horrible act and is abruptly gone, never to be mentioned or referenced again...despite what he did.  It's a creepy character with no-payoff or explanation.  Good setup...bad execution.There is also some code-deciphering in the film (remember, the lead is a third-rate Indiana Jones) that makes no sense.  And in the end, many of the threads of the film are left unexplained in a particularly obvious way.  I think the film THINKS it has told us something, but in the blurry, hand-held filming and screams and frantic editing...something is lost.  Something like logic.The director of the film made one of my guilty-pleasure favorites, QUARANTINE and showed much more skill and even gave us a real ending.  Nothing brilliant, but solid throughout, with some actual intelligent performances.  AS ABOVE, SO BELOW is a step backward.  Moderately entertaining overall, but I certainly cannot actually recommend it.

These headphones operate exceptionally and simply.  The instructions for use are very brief.  Essentially:  charge your headphones, easily sync to your chosen device, and start playing.  Easy to skip tracks.  Easy to adjust volume.  They are comfortable to wear and pretty lightweight.  I have no complaints in this regard.  4.5 stars.Unfortunately, they don't sound very good.  I am not an audiophile, and don't have the vocabulary needed...but "tinny" is the word that comes to mind.  Listening to some of my favorite rock music, be it RUSH or VAMPIRE WEEKEND or THE BEATLES or SLEIGH BELLS...they all sounded like they were being played through a layer of fabric or from a great distance.  Even cranked up the highest volume, the sound felt thin.  And if you can't get a big sound from RUSH or SLEIGH BELLS, something is not right.  I was very disappointed, and am likely to not use these headphones very often.  1.5 stars.

You know, for $2 a napkin, these are not bad.  They do not "fake" being linen, so if you need your guests to think they are eating with fine napkinry (is that a word?), these polyester substitutes will not work.  So bear that in mind.What I do like about them is that they will dress up a modest table, and because of their price, you could order a couple of different colors, depending on the china/dishes you were using.  We have the brown, and they would go with pretty much anything.  They look crisp and are easy to clean afterwards.  They are NOT absorbent, so if you get a spill, don't expect these guys to do any heavy lifting.  They give a table a nice appearance and are a good way to dress things up.  But they'd also do well in a more upscale picnic basket too, in my opinion.  This is another product that is great with the right expectations.Not sure one can say much else about them!  If what I've described as their level of usefulness fulfills your needs, then I can heartily recommend them.  Just don't expect a $2 napkin to act like a $20 napkin.

As a 52 year old adult, I'm probably not the target market for this toy.  So I let a 9 year old boy give it a whirl on my behalf.  He did need adult supervision putting it together.  There are a lot of parts, and it's more complicated than a lego, that's for sure.  I was also worried that this long gun made of K'nex wouldn't be very sturdy.While you can't exactly throw it around against walls or trees, it IS actually quite substantial when complete, and it looks COOL.  The picture on the box actually doesn't do it justice.  It feels great in your hands.  And the darts that come with it willy fly a mile!  We were shooting across the length of a medium size house...down a long hallway and into this kid's bedroom.  The darts flew straight and true and hit the back wall still going at good speed.  I do worry just a bit that kids thinking they've got something more like a Nerf toy MIGHT be able to actually hurt someone a little...but overall, this is an excellent toy that lives up to its promise entirely.  As a note, the darts it comes with LOOK like Nerf darts, but when we tried the Nerf darts from another toy, they did NOT fly much further than they usually did with the Nerf toy.Oh, and the other cool thing?  You can fire TWO darts at once.  THAT is a blast.  And when they hit their target, they are only slightly further apart than they started on the gun.  It's actually pretty amazing the force and accuracy of this toy.  We (all us adults) were quite impressed.  And the 9 year-old was THRILLED.  Yes, the toy is pricey.  But if it sounds up your alley and you have the funds...I don't think you'll be disappointed!

A LONELY PLACE TO DIE is a low-budget thriller that almost completely overcomes the limitations of its budget because it uses the magnificent scenery of the Scottish Highlands as almost a special effect of its own.  Some of the most gorgeous scenery I've seen in a film outside of a LORD OF THE RINGS film in quite awhile.  The land is gorgeous looking, but also sparse and forbidding.  It's the kind of place that reminds you that the wild really still is WILD.At the beginning of the film, we meet three rock climbers scaling one of these tricky mountains.  There is a mishap and a near disaster ensues.  It gets the heart pumping, but also helps establish the pecking order of the characters.  They soon meet two more friends and we discover these 5 companions have met up in this secluded area to hike and to climb.  The next day, they head out on their journey, and adventures ensue.  I don't want to spoil anything, which is tough...but let's  say that while nature continues to be demanding, they run into more danger via happenstance encounters with some REALLY bad folks.  They also have the misfortune to find someone in danger and take it upon themselves (as good citizens of the world) to help that person...much to their personal cost.  The film is man vs. nature, man vs. man, and man vs. himself (or at least, his closest friends).Once events begin to unfold, they move quickly and almost unrelentingly.  We've never gotten more than sketches of these characters, but it's enough for us to pick up on the dynamics and to begin to appreciate that people show bravery and competence in different ways.  Towards the end, the film becomes particularly violent, and by no means is this a movie for children.  I enjoyed the thrills in the earlier parts of the movie a bit better, but overall the action was satisfying.Unfortunately, the characters also sometimes do things that aren't always logical.  Yes, they are under duress, so some silliness can be excused, but honestly, a couple of the folks act as though they've never seen a movie with crazy killers before!  And I have to say the very ending of the film is a significant let-down.  A real "huh" moment for me.  Maybe I missed something, because there are a lot of competing accents in this film...but one of the characters introduced very late in film just does something that appears to fly in the face of the motivations established earlier.  I apologize again for sounding vague...but part of the fun of the film are some of the unexpected places it takes you.  They aren't "twists" necessarily, but just some interesting, amusing or exciting alley-ways.The film IS gorgeously shot.  Yes, the scenery helps, but the filmmakers also knew they had something special and they made the most of it.  The physical competence of the characters is very visceral and convincing.  The actors at least seem like they might know how to rock climb.  No one gives an Oscar worthy performance, but everyone is very solid.  Melissa George stands out as the "good guy" and Sean Harris makes an excellent villain.  He's competent at being "bad" to be quite dangerous, but Harris gives him a bit of the psycho edge too...so we know he's smart but liable to do something a bit stupid because it suits his looney streak.Not a perfect film by any means.  But if you want something a little grittier and more rooted in the "real" world than many Hollywood action blockbusters, but still nice and exciting, I hope you'll give the sadly overlooked A LONELY PLACE TO DIE a look.

I am not a very adept assembler.  Even when following directions, I can struggle.  Sad to admit, but true.  But this chair came together for me in about 10-15 minutes.  Everything fit together as it needed to and I was overall very pleasantly pleased.The chair itself is fairly utilitarian.  It is not the handsomest task chair I've ever seen, but the black at least makes it all look crisp, clean and functional.  This is an OFFICE chair.  It says, "I'm here for you to accomplish business with.  I'll support you and let your roll around your desk area.  I will not bring a sense of design fashion to your space."  And that's okay, because it DOES feel good.  I'm not terribly picky about my office chairs...when I walk into a new office, I generally make peace with whatever is there.  But I do like this chair and the lower back support it provides.  It doesn't have a lot of sophisticated adjustments that you can make, but I found it quite nice right from the get go.  I haven't used it long enough to testify to its durability, but it sure has a good, sturdy feel.  You can really feel the difference between this chair and a more standard $80-90 task chair from Staples.  While this piece of furniture will never make me do backflips BUT is delivers in the important ways.  I recommend it.

The picture on the packaging is a little bit deceiving.  This bar is pretty darn SMALL!!  But if you're ready for a snack that's about 3" x 1.5"...it's very, very tasty.  It's rich and chocolaty.  It does not taste like low cal dessert, nor does it taste like a high protein snack.  It's rich, and chewy and quite yummy.  Just small!!  Be prepared.

This is NOT a tablecloth for fine dining situations.  It is a polyester fabric that for all the world feels almost like a shower curtain.  It looks like a woven cloth, but it also looks like a picnic tablecloth.These are not bad things, per se.  Just set expectations correctly.  For a more informal dinner or perhaps if you're also entertaining a bunch of kids, this is a great choice.  It's EASY to clean up, yet dresses up a table nicely. I see it working very well for party situations, when you're trying to match your party dishes to the cake to the decorations (and now, the tablecloth).  These tablecloths, in general, are fairly inexpensive, so I can see a situation in which you might have a small handful, so you can select the best color for a specific occasion.  And YES, they would make excellent clothes for an outdoor dining situation as well.  Again, cleanup, either via spot cleaning or in the washing machine, is pretty painless and pretty effective.

This products works.  It is not a MIRACLE worker, but after just two days of use, my teeth are whiter.  I'm very happy to be seeing results so quickly, and this is easier to use than the whitening strips (and theoretically, you can even whiten teeth no one can see).  So for efficacy, I give this 5 stars.I dock one star because of the price.  You'll see that I received a free sample of this product, and based on my limited time use, I can heartily recommend it.  But I'm not wealthy, so I doubt I would keep this stockpiled in my bathroom.  It's just "too rich for my blood" and even if I had more money, I just can't imagine actually spending it on this.  The profit margin must be pretty significant (and I don't even mind a reasonable profit).But if you can get past the price hurdle, I think you'll be pleased with the product.

This is a big kitchen towel.  Considerably larger than what I'm used to (and probably what you're used to).  So look at the measurements before ordering and decide if that's right for you.  If size-wise you're good, then I highly recommend the towel.  It's a bit "expensive" I suppose, but the quality is there.  It is a very attractive towel (I had the pewter, and it was very nice and subtle).  And it absorbs very well, which for me and kitchen clean-ups is non-negotiable.  I like to be able to wipe down our ample counters, and have the towel actually soak up the water, not just shove it around (like you get with some cheap towels).  This thing does the trick!  And because it's cotton, it also seems to air dry very quickly.I don't even mind the size.  When not in use, we fold it and hang it from our dishwasher handle, and it looks great there, because the stainless steel goes well with the towel.I see no downsides to this item!

This is very tasty tea!  I wasn't quite sure what to expect when I saw the title "CREAM Early Grey."  Would this be like the Chai Latte's I've had, where something resembling milk or cream is part of the k-cup experience, resulting in a literally creamy beverage that is also cream colored?  And also, I have to admit that while I occasionally like Earl Grey as a change of pace, I'm not the biggest fan.But I was very pleasantly surprised. First, this tea does NOT come out cream colored.  It's a black tea.  But it has a creamy feeling in the mouth, almost silky.  It is also a very mild tasting Early Grey, not nearly as strongly tasting and scented as I associate with Earl Grey.  I was very pleased by the texture and taste.  The smell was mild as well, I should mention...not quite as engaging as a "normal" Early Grey.My only significant issue is price (hence docking it one star).  I'll admit right here, I was sent this item for free as part of the Vine Program.  But, as much as I enjoyed the tea, I will not be purchasing any morenot at its current price.  Pay a buck or more for ONE k-cup is just too much for me.  My budget is such that a daily 60 cent k-cup is a bit of an indulgencebut I cant see my way clear to these higher prices.  Others will obviously have no issues, and thats great too.  But to me, its tough to give 5 stars to something I wouldnt buy again (whatever the reason).  Tasty tea, though!

First of all, this braiser LOOKS amazing.  As soon as we pulled it out of the box, there were lots of "oohs" and "aahs."  The white enamel is so crisp and clean and inviting, and the overall design is very pleasing.It is advertised as "light cast iron" and in my opinion, it doesn't really look or feel like cast iron.  If you're thinking this will fool someone into thinking you're cooking witih cast iron, that isn't going to happen.  This is not to say it doesn't look and feel and perform great...it just doesn't look and feel like cast iron.  In part, this is due to the non-stick finish on the inside.Functionally, it's great as well.  We've had a very short time, but I like that it's deep enough for cooking bigger pieces of meat.  Big hunks of roast, or lots of chicken...with plenty of potato and veggie room.  It works like a deep skillet, but also like a casserole.  It cleans up very well.  Its a sturdy, attractive piece of cookware that I believe will see a lot of use in our household!One tiny little complaint.  The product description says this comes with a cookbook.  The cookbook is a tiny, flimsy little thing with about a dozen recipes, MOST of which dont involve the use of this brazier at all.  The recipes seem quite lovely, but we had hoped for more that would actually pertain to our new brazier.

I did NOT enjoy these.  The strawberry flavor was pretty mild (more like strawberry yoghurt) and the biscuit had virtually no flavor at all.  Full disclosure:  I'm a 51 year-old man, so not exactly the target market.  But on the other hand, I enjoy snack foods of ALL kinds (just ask my scale!), and I did not enjoy these.Also, the nutritional information is not very good on these, so they really have nothing to offer.  I see from the other reviews that I'm in the minority, so obviously I must not "get" these Pocky Sticks.  Okay, I admit it...they are not good and I will never "get" them again.

WHAT WE DO IN THE SHADOWS is a blast.  It's a low-budget spoof of low-budget reality shows (including shaky, hand-held camerwork, spotty lighting and questionable zooming) and it focuses on a group of room-mates who happen to be vampires.  The concept is amusing, and for the most part, the execution is excellent.  The film is a bit of a one-joke wonder...but these guys have found every variation of the joke/conceit, and made them work.We're introduced to four vampires, sharing a ramshackle house in Wellington, New Zealand.  Part of what was amusing is that the vampires come from various parts of the world, and are given outrageous accents...none of which are New Zealand.  You've got the old-school Dracula-like vampire from Romania (or thereabouts), a decadent play-boyish type (or at least playboy wannabe) who reminds me of a sleazy, greasy, less suave & attractive version of Eric from TRUE BLOOD.  Then there's the European dandy, who is relatively new to being a vampire and still pines for his long-lost human love. Finally, and to me, funniest of alltheres Peter, the VERY ancient vampire who looks just like Nosferatu from the silent film days.  This vampire only hisses, he cannot speak, but hes one of the best sightgags Ive seen in awhile.Much of the movie just shows these roommates squabbling, grappling with petty vampire problems and looking for a party.  Their immortality has rendered them indifferent to housework and easily bored.  As any full-length one-joke movie must do, eventually some plot is introduced as a brand-new vampire is introduced to the mix and the group must grapple with the training and responsibility for this insolent newbie.  Complications ensue.The movie is just under 90 minutes long, but Ill admit that it occasionally feels stretched.  Inevitably, the joke must grow a little thin, and once in awhile, I felt that thinness.  What keeps the movie fun 97% of the time is the characters.  We actually grow to take an interest in these guys, and there are a few genuinely touching moments by the end.The film does show some blood, but it is only graphic enough to remind us that were dealing with vampires.  It doesnt dwell on the violence, but you never feel its shying away.  The language can be rough, and overall, this is not a movie for kids.This little film, which few will see, turns out to be a delightful, engaging and frequently hilarious surprise.

WILD is a simple story, told with economy against a beautiful, but sometimes sparse and stark scenic background.  Reese Witherspoon plays Cheryl Strayed, a young woman torn apart by grief over the loss of her mother and the consequent behavior she embarks on including infidelity and drug-use.  She is a smart woman with a nice husband, but apparently without the emotional resources to weather the storm of her loss.  Her path could easily have taken her to an early and ugly death.But by good fortune, Cheryl has at least enough on the ball to recognize shes near the bottom, and her plan for redemption is to walk the 1,000+ mile Pacific Crest Traila tough trek for experienced hikers, and a brutal one for Strayed, who doesnt have the know-how.Despite this being a true story, the basic premise has the ring of clich.  A personal journey of redemption, as this troubled woman is both worn down and built back up by the impersonal harshness of nature.  And thats true.  But it is told amazingly well, has far more humor than you would think, and features the best performance of Reese Witherspoons career.  She is never anything less than magnetic, and her face shows you all you need to know about what shes thinking and experiencing.  Witherspoon clearly connected with her character, and shes a marvel to watch.  Its easy to take her for granted as a performer sometimes, but WILD will remind you that behind the frivolous faade of characters like Elle in LEGALLY BLONDE, Witherspoon has a unique presence that she can bring to bear for the right material.I didnt know much about the Pacific Crest Trail, and I assumed Id just see one vista of startling beauty after another.  But a lot of it is desert, and it isnt always glorious.  Sometimes it seems dry, dusty, windy and unforgiving.  Watching Cheryl cope with the early days of life on the trail, trying to set up her tent, trying to make decent food, forcing herself NOT to give up, is much of the drama of the story.  But its done so well, and with such a strong dose of welcome humor that were with her all the way.There are lots of flashbacks in the film, so that we understand to some degree what Strayed is going through.  Many feature scenes of her with her mother (Laura Dern, playing what seemed to me to be a variation of her nutty character on ENLIGHTENED).  Clearly, Strayed relied so heavily on her mother for love, courage and stabilityand when she loses that we see her unmooring.Its heavy stuff, but I cant emphasize enough that Witherspoon and director Jean-Marc Vallee (the excellent DALLAS BUYERS CLUB) bring big doses of humor to this film.  Life on the trail also brings plenty of chance encounters with amusing characters and amusing circumstances.  The film never drags and while the journey of personal redemption theme is an old chestnutthe landscape, the approach and the lead performance make this a must-see, in my book.

Maybe this concept has existed for years, but I've never seen it.  But to me, this "over-the-corner" colander is one of the most obvious improvements to a standard kitchen product that I've seen.  WE LOVE IT!The typical collander sits in the middle of your sink and it's tough to find good room to work around it.  Essentially, the sink becomes useless for other purposes as long as you're draining something in the collander.  This OXO product hangs on the corner of the sink and thus the rest of the sink is free to work on.  If you're rinsing various vegetables, as you finish, just toss them in the collander to drain and you can just keep working.  It's such a simple concept, but we've just been thrilled with it.This particular product is very sturdy and it grips the sink REALLY well.  No chance of it getting top-heavy and tipping over and spilling into the sink.  Not really much chance of accidentally bumping it and disloding it either.  It's study.

I love my Brita.  (actually plural, I have a couple).  We live out of town a little bit and have our own well.  The water is fairly hard, and the Brita does a GREAT job of giving me nice, fresh, clear water to drink.  Naturally, the filters are the crux of this.  They are GREAT.  I use them hard.  I know that, for example, if I boil water in our tea kettle, and don't dump out the unused water quickly...white streaks will be left on the inside of the kettle.  I never get any deposits in my Brita pitchers.  So I'm pretty impressed.These 3 packs are the best value in their filters, so I certainly commend this, because once you use the Brita, I'm convinced you'll KEEP using it!

I'm a guy.  A 51-year-old guy.  So I am not a shampoo snob by any stretch.  I like my hair, which I was every day, to be clean.  And I don't want to smell perfumy.  I don't worry or notice things like "full body" or "damaged", etc.This Herbal Essences shampoo fit my modest standards very ably. In particular, I liked the smell.  It's actually fairly subtle and just little fruity.  It's a nice pleasant smell that is absolutely NOT perfumy or "artificial".  (Although I'm sure the scent is to a large degree artificial, it doesn't immediately come across that way.)  It lathers up very nicely, and overall simply gives me what I am looking for.  I'm sorry this isn't much help to many out there...but if you, like me, dislike overbearing scents, then you should be well pleased by this product.  I'll certainly buy more.

Heres MOVING DAY (at least the set up) in a nutshell.  An elderly couple in their 70s has decided to downsize their east coast home and move to something smaller in California.  Theyve had successful lives and hes had a successful career.  Kids are grown and doing well.  Family business handed over to the capable eldest son.  Time to pack up the expensive antiques and valuable paintings and slip into a pleasant, well-deserved retirement.  And when the movers show up a day early, it must be that the couple has simply mis-remembered the day.  And the movers are so polite and competent anyway.  And sure enough, the next day, the REAL movers show up.  And Mr. & Mrs. Stanley Peke are suddenly bereft of all their earthly possessions, a lifetime of memories gone.But the thief has underestimated Stanley Peke and unknowingly tangled with one tough and determined old bird.  And therein lies most of the drama of MOVING DAY.Author Jonathan Stone gives us an excellent set-up for his interesting but uneven thriller.  I really dont want to spoil much more, but lets just say that Stanley Peke is much more than just a successful, upper, upper-middle class businessman.  He has an interesting back story.  And interesting motivations for what he does.  Stone, unfortunately, spends HUGE (and I mean HUGE) amounts of time justifying Pekes actions to the reader.  Yes, a 72 year old man should probably not be taking the law and detective work into his own hands (and leaving everyone out of the picture).  But we get a clear picture of the type of man Peke is early on, and MUCH of this internal monologue is just the same thing over and over, simply presented in slightly different ways.  Stone tries too hard to make us believe this old codger would do the things he does.  As a reader, I was super frustrated, because this caused the plot to grind to a CRAWL.Stone also spends a lot of time trying to inform us about the back story and motivations of the criminal mastermind Nick.  A bit of this is admirable and interesting, but for awhile, I worried wed spend the entire book just bouncing back and forth between the two characters as they think about their pasts and how their present is motivated by it.  NOTHING HAPPENED for huge chunks of the book.Towards the end, some of the psychological buildup has a bit of payoff (although really for PekeNick becomes more generic as the novel progress).  And events to finally begin to move swiftly and mostly satisfyingly.  There are numerous tense moments, and I have to say the final 25% of the book was well-done: tense and exciting.  But honest-to-goodness, the explanations of the motivations and thought processes CONSTANTLY throughout the book were just too much.  Im glad Stone was so excited by his characterbut too often he spends way more time TELLING than SHOWING.  Often Pekes actions and words are all we need to understand himbut no, we have to have it painstakingly told to us.MOVING DAY, I believe, could easily have been 20% shorter and have much swifter and more gripping, and no less psychologically complex.  I do not regret taking on this book, but Id hesitate to try another book by this author.(By the way, I mostly experienced this as an audiobook.  The narrator was good, but spoke very distinctly and slowly.  This was very aggravating, but I set the speed on my Kindle Fire to 1.25x and it was perfect.  Still caught all the nuance.  No one sounded like Alvin Chipmunk.  So theres my tip to audiobook listeners.)

This is a very serviceable chai tea.  I'm not a tea fanatic and frankly I enjoy the scent as much as anything when making hot tea.  And I'm a bit lazy, so usually, my hot teas (whether black, green, chai, earl grey, etc. etc.) are via a k-cup.  Fast and easy.  Hot.  Nice smell.The Tattle Tea Chai is, to my untrained palate, a step above k-cup chai tea or an inexpensive grocery store chai.  It certainly has a strong and pleasant scent, both in the bag or after brewing.  Loose leaves, of course, do smell better than a tea bag that's been sitting on a shelf for weeks.  I won't say, though, that this is the best tasting chai of my life.  To me, the taste was not as strong as the scent.  I had hoped for more of a spicy kick.  It isn't bad...and again, it's better than cheap stuff (which is what I generally have), but I've sampled better at Teavana or even from a "fancy" coffee shop.  For me, it would not be worth the extra money for the slight improvement in taste and the inconvenience of making loose-leaf tea (I told you I was lazy about my tea.)  It's perfectly fine, and I'm sure the less lazy won't mind the extra effort.I've spent so much time describing my own tea habits so that, hopefully, you can put my thoughts into proper context.  If you are a tea fanatic, don't listen to me!!

Overall, this is a very nice scale.  It has excellent features like measuring BMI that are, for me, a first.  I've had more "old school" scales all my life, so this was a fun toy to play with.  Frankly, though, for me, just weighing me is still what I'm most interested in!But it delivers what it says it will, and it's very nice and sturdy looking.  My only issue or warning relates to the set-up.  BE CAREFUL.  Don't even touch the thing until you've read the first few steps of the set up.  The scale is very sensitive and if you put weight on it too soon or in the wrong way, you will have to start all over!

Badminton is one of those games that people of all ages and athletic abilities like to play.  Not necessarily play well, but it's fun.  You don't have to have incredible ability to participate and theoretically it can be played just about anywhere outside where you can find a flat surface (and hopefully minimal wind!).  But you really need to have a net to make it fun.  And this is where Zume Games has stepped in.This set weighs only a few pounds and is easy to carry.  When it arrived, I challenged my daughter and myself to see how fast we could go from complete ignorance of its contents to actually playing the game.  Try 5 minutes.  EVERYTHING you need is in this zippered case which is the size of a large briefcase / small suitcase.  There are 4 rackets, 2 birdies, a net and the expandable poles you need to hand the net between.  The poles also snap into the case itself, which serves as the base.  (By the way, it takes about 2 minutes to take down and put away.  3 if only one person is doing it.)Let's be clear.  This is not a regulation sized net.  It is meant to allow a group of a casual players to just quickly start playing with a minimal of hassle.  It's lower than most nets (great for kids) and not as wide (great for smaller places).  This is the kind of thing you take on a picnic or outing...or quickly throw up in your yard when you've got some company over.  We love it and have already had lots of fun.The rackets, I will admit, are pretty cheap.  And don't encourage kids to hit the actual net...it doesn't look like it would do well under abuse.  But it truly lives up to the description of "portable" and I'm just completely thrilled with this product.

Over the years, I've used various versions of Pinnacle to try to wrangle my home movies into something resembling entertainment!  Until I received 18 Plus, I had been using 16 for a couple of years.  My overall feelings about this program have never really changed.  It is important to note:  I am not a filmmaker.  I have no commercial applications I'm trying to fill.  I have no aspirations to be the next Scorcese.  But I like to film a lot on vacations and such, and because I'm such an amateur, I usually end up with lots of pretty boring footage.  My goal is to simply trim that down into something entertaining, with some sub-titles where needed, a bit of humor injected via effects, etc. and the ability to add music where appropriate and to turn that music up or down.  I will use other features AS THEY BECOME AVAILABLE.  I don't sit around wondering where features are.  I don't think about what is MISSING from the program...I think about how easy (or not) it is to use what I do have available to me.To an amateur like me, Pinnacle provides LOTS of options and choices and for the most part, they are easy to use.  I find the program to always have been fairly intuitive.  (It won't make you a great filmmaker or editor, that's still up to the limits of YOUR artistic ability.)  But if I want to drop an .mp3 into a specific section of the video, it's a piece of cake.  Want a fun title menu?  Take your pick of scads of pre-made one?  Need subtitles?  Well, you've got thousands of choices.I know there are simpler programs out there, but for various reasons over the years (came free with a new camcorder, was on sale, etc.), I keep ending up with Pinnacle.  And of course, it's usually the latest or next to latest version.  So here comes my difficulty.  I generally don't own the most up-to-date computer.  Currently, I have a 4 year old Dell laptop.  It works great for almost everything.  But boy, oh, boy...when it comes time to actually render the video onto disc...watch out!  Usually I'll start rendering a 30 minute video when I know I'm leaving the house for a couple of hours.  The process is VERY slow, and often (33% of the time), I end up with either an error mid-stream that scraps the whole process OR there's an error on the disc, and mid-way through, it stops working.  But I'm pretty confident it's because I'm asking my computer to stretch to the edge of its limits.  If I went back to version 11 of Pinnacle, I'd probably be in great shape.  But I wouldn't have all the fun extras!Pinnacle is pretty good, in my view, of providing lots of templates (whether for titles, sub-titles, scene changes, etc.)  It's these bells and whistles that I enjoy, but getting them no doubt drops my rendering experience down several pegs.  But blank discs are cheap, so I'm willing to endure some failed renderings.

We love this product.  In our home, traditionally, the storage area under our kitchen sink has been a bit of a disaster.  We are far from sloppy people or poor housekeepers, but nonetheless, wet things frequently have gone under there.  Sponges.  Dish soap with the lid not quite closed all the way...so when it tips over it leaves a slippery puddle, etc.  In fact, when we moved not too long ago, we found warped wood under out sink and had to repair the area.  Just a pain in the rear, and it looked bad too.This non adhesive, rubbery stuff is a bit like shelf liner, but it is more substantial too.  It exists because apparently we aren't the only people with spills and messes under our sinks.  It goes on like a breeze (the most complicated thing is cutting the piece to the size ou want with a pair of scissors!)  It just goes down and it's done!  If we do make a mess, it doesn't soak through to the wood below, and because of the rubbery material, it's easy to clean up.  It reduces noise a bit too.Our color is taupe and it really blends with just about anything.  While our cabinet doors are wood, the floor of the cabinets are white and this is a good compromise color.While under-sink liner is not exactly a product I think a lot about and is hard to get enthusiastic over...this is a solid product that delivers exactly what it says it does.  So that is 5-stars in my book!

While this cannot possibly take the place of a "full size" welder...it is perfect for the job it's meant to do.  Quick work and small projects.  It's pretty light and doesn't take up much space.  Any time you have access to a plug, you can weld!  For repairs, fast jobs and frankly, as an educational tool...you can't beat it.Have only had a short time and can't speak to reliability and durability over time, but we are very proud owners at the moment.  Only drawback so far is having to hold the facemask by hand.  Pretty minor issue.

This is an okay toy, but it's a battery hog (required a bunch of batteries up front) and we found the RC controls to be a bit problematic.  But in the end, the replay value of this toy just wasn't that great...and that's really why I'm only giving it 3 stars.  One can deal with less than wonderful RC (heck, a little kid can just move this thing around by hand if it comes to that)...but all the destroyer really does is fire these green balls and you're essentially using this blast to try to knock down some of the little figures.  Oh, and the little figures are done failry poorly.  Granted, they are small, but the level of detail seems pretty low (and for a Star Wars toy, this is pretty surprising).  But to me, the single biggest issue is that the toy just isn't being played with very much.  Having said that, the Star Destoyer itself is pretty cool looking, and certaingly makes a good decoration for the right room.

It works just as advertised.  You plug one end into the cigarette lighter of your car.  And just like that, you have TWO care outlets.  We'll use it for longer car trips so we can each charge our iphones using our pre-existing car chargers (My wife has one that lives in her car and I have one that lives in mine).  But we won't get much more use than that.  And frankly, both our cars have multiple cigarette lighters, so this is a bit of a "luxury" item for our lifestyle.  So my only advice would be to think about how often you would really use it.  If it really fills a need, then by all means...it does work just as it should.  But if it's a VERY occasional use, perhaps you can find other workarounds that don't cost as much?

Does exactly what it says it does.  It is a no-frills, no-perfumy smell ointment that is a step above being a moisturizer.  A moisturizer, in my mind, is something you can apply liberally over large parts of your body, such as arms and legs.  It's good for modestly dry skin, might smell nice, and is almost more of a psychological comfort than anything.  HOWEVER, Aquaphor is meant, in my opinion, for the targeting of truly dry, cracked places.  It gets in deep and if your cracks are too bad, you can even feel the sting of it working.  It is NOT glamorous...it's more medicine than a toiletry item.  Cracked ankles, feet, elbows are great spots for using it.  It does leave a little bit of a greasy residue on your hands when applying, but other than that...it's a nearly perfect product.  While it won't heal things overnight,  you will usually see at least some improvement in less than a day.  Good stuff!

I've enjoyed Dove soap bars over the years.  The white bars are about as perfume free as you can get.  It's like cleaning yourself with a silky cream.  We've generally used Dove just for our faces though and stuck with "regular" soap for everything else.The body wash gives you pretty much the exact same experience and feeling as the bar.  It all depends on how much you like Dove soap.  It's certainly gentle and has a very mild smell.  It does feel moisturizing.  My only hesitancy is that I've always questioned how good Dove was for just simply cleaning off dirt.  (Not that I'm particularly dirty.)  It's a psychological thing for me, I think, but sometimes with Dove I feel like I'm cleaning myself with a body lotion, not a soap.Note that the 34oz bottle is pretty darn big.  If you would normally prop this on a small shelf in your shower, for example, it's NOT going to hold this big bottle.

This review is geared primarily to folks whove read the book, but nonetheless, Im going to try really hard to avoid spoilers, but just the fact that everyone knows GONE GIRL has a spoiler to be avoided at all costs sets anyone up to expect something major.  If youve read the book, you know what Im talking about.Lets say this:  the middle-of-the-book twist in GONE GIRL was more effective in the book.  It isnt poorly done in the movie, but this is an instance where WRITING (done correctly, which author Gillian Flynn did) is simply more effective at obfuscating than a movie can ever be (even though Gillian Flynn wrote the screenplay).  But its still fun.The book is also noted for an ending that many found dissatisfying (myself included).  While I understood what was happening, and even the social commentary being madeI was dissatisfied that Flynn couldnt pull of something more impactful.  The book is SO very well written that theres no denying Flynn has significant talentbut she wasnt quite up to her own ideas of the story should wrap up.  The movie, in this case, handles it a bit better.  I wont say if the ending is DIFFERENT, per sebut in this case, I felt the visual medium actually served the story better.Now that we have that pussy-footing out of the way, what about the movie overall?  Well, Im happy to report that the film is extremely solid and utterly gripping throughout.  Director David Fincher is undeniably a director of great strength.  He handles tone well, and he handles MOOD well.  His films are always impeccably crafted, and he handles the color grey (in all its shades) very well.  (Think about how much grey is in PANIC ROOM or GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO.)  I cannot fault his work here.  But where he has REALLY succeeded is with his cast.  I loved everyone, really.Ben Affleck has never been one of my favorite actors.  Hes certainly improved later in life, (and no doubt he has proven himself a really fine director), hes a bit bland.  A charming guy with a gloss of insincerity over almost everything he does.  I think of one of his better performances (in ARGO)that character spends most of the moving PRETENDING to be something else, and he also hides his feelings & tension from the hostages hes trying to free.  He seldom shows his real persona.  Its that trait that works so well for him in GONE GIRL.  Hes seemingly our heroyet were also not surprised when some darker things come out.  Hes charming.  Hes superficial.  Theres a famous scene in the book when Afflecks character is first being interviewed by the press (after his wifes kidnappingno spoilers).  He smiles, because hes uncomfortable knowing what to do in front of the cameraand this smile causes suspicion and dislike to fall upon him.  Affleck handles this perfectly.Rosemund Pike will be revelation to some.  Ive enjoyed her in a wide variety of roles, and shes certainly had a varied career that never quite made her a breakout.  She did action in DOOM (yes, DOOM!), she has done period pieces in PRIDE AND PREJUDICE, comedy in THE WORLDS END and more.  But she is a striking presence and a marvelous cipher in GONE GIRL.  Her porcelain skin (and Ive NEVER, EVER used the adjective porecelain before) makes her seem delicate and lovely.  But her eyes allow her to go across all spectrums of emotion (again, cant be more specific without spoiling).  I would not have picked her for this critical role, but Fincher did, and he was right.My favorites, though, are two supporting characters.  Kim Dickens (recently in a minor role on SONS OF ANARCHY) is simply terrific as one of the cops investigating the case.  Shes exactly the sort of cop wed all want if WE were accused of a crime we didnt commit.  Fair, forthright, not willing to jump to conclusions but also very quick to put two-and-two together.  Her role was not flashy, but she steals almost every scene shes in be the power of her competence.  And Carrie Coon (who I didnt really know before) plays Afflecks sister.  Its a pretty pivotal role, and she gets everything out of it and more.  She takes an already excellent character in the book, and makes this multi-faceted woman unforgettable.  Id like to say she should be nominated for Best Supporting Actress, but well see if shes remembered come awards season.Also fun:  Neil Patrick Harrishes a bit of comic relief, but hes such a delight.  Tyler Perry as Afflecks attorney is completely credible and engaging.  I could almost see a TV series coming out of this character.  Patrick Fugit, as Kim Dickens partner, is fun as well.  Hes the more jump-to-conclusions cop and his snarky asides serve the film well.  Only Emily Ratajowski (of Blurred Lines video fame) is poorly cast.  Her character in the book (no spoiler from me) is more fleshed out, and thus she has little to work with.  An actress of her limited skill is unable to make these meager pieces into a likeable characterand the story is more effective when her character is a bigger part.I highly recommend the movie.  It isnt a message film.  It wont stir lively social debate.  It wont make anyones Greatest 100 Films of All Time list.  But it delivers exciting, thoughtful, funny, fast paced and tension filled drama and is a wallop of pure movie entertainment.  And boy, after this drab summer at the movies, that makes this film all the more welcome!

I still remember the days when "contact paper" was a huge pain in the rear.  Not only did you have to cut the piece to size, but getting it in place without wrinkles, or being crooked, etc. was a challenge.  The new trend in shelf liner is these squishy, sticky sheets that are much more simple to peel up and restick if you mess up.  Overall, they are easier to put in place and I like the extra feature that the items you then put in the drawer or on the shelf are less likely to slide around themselves, because the liner creates its own tackiness.This particular product has less plastic and more "air" than most of this type that I have seen.  I have to admit, I'm not sure I like that.  It still works, but it looks, to my eye, a bit cheaper.  Air is free...plastic or rubber is the added ingredient.  One might argue that this product is better for the environment, but it just doesn't look as nice in a drawer.I've used it in our new home in some shelving in the garage and such, but have elected NOT to use it in our kitchen.  I just prefer the similar products from other companies that look more substantial.

One of my main gripes about plastic trash bags, particularly those for tall kitchen containers, is their tendency to not stay in place.  Slowly, the bag begins to creep up around the lip of the trash can and a corner or two starts to sag into the container.  It's a petty thing, but I want to be able to open the lid of my can and easily throw trash in without missing the bag!  If I hit the inside of the container, I ought to be hitting the darn bag.Some of these new Hefty bags have this "gripper" feature, and it seems to work pretty darn well.  It hugs the edge of our kitchen trash can much better.  I've not yet had one slip as described above.  Yea!!  Victory!!I'm not a big fan of scenteded trash bags...sometimes the scent can be pretty bad and it gets on my hands when putting in a new bag or throwing out the trash.  I like the idea in THEORY, because who wants to smell their trash?  But in reality, some of the scents out there (such as lavender) are too perfumy.  This "Clean Burst" scent is less offensive for me, so I give that feature a tentative thumbs-up too.Finally, these bags are "ultimate" because they can carry much more without breaking.  I can't really speak to that...it's pretty rare for me to overstuff even the cheap bags to the point where they rip.  This Hefty bag SEEMS like it is sturdier...but I have no experience in testing its limits.These bags are pretty pricey.  You have to decide if some of the features I describe above are worth a premium to you.  I'm not entirely sure I'm willing to keep paying a premium price for a plastic trash bag.

These are really lovely.  I'm afraid there isn't a lot I can say about a teatowel...but my wife and I really like these.  They're very plain, simple and attractive.  Not fussy at all.  Basically, all I can say is...if you like the pattern, then you'll be well pleased, because the towel is strudy, the cloth feels nice and natural and use get just what you expect, basically.Sorry, I already know this isn't much help...but I hope you can tell by the 5 stars that I have nothing bad to say about these towels.  What more would you want?

These clothes feel like something from a bygone age.  Many products describe themselves as basic or simple...but these clothes live up to that.  They feel like an all natural cross between muslin and cotton (I know, weird).  They aren't the softest in the world, but they aren't abrasive.  They ARE oversized and can practically be used as a little table cloth for a small table.  I can see using them as clothes for picnic tables or other casual dining (I imagine them being issued to individual guests at a crawfish broil in a backyard).  They are meant to be like dishtowels, but they are much bigger.I haven't had them long enough to know if they eventually stain.  They SEEM like after cleaning up some messy spills, it might be difficult to get them back to their natural white color.  Perhaps that's why you get so many in the pack.  I don't think these will last for the long haul, the edges are not finished off totally, so I can already see a little bit of fraying.  But again, they have a 19th century kinda feel to them, so the fraying only adds to the charm.My major issue is that these don't suit the decor of most modern kitchens, in my opinion.  I like these, but we don't display them...we still have our usual dish towels that were purchase to compliment our kitchen.  BUT, that doesn't mean we don't use them...they are kept in a handy cabinet and have many purposes.

We had a newly purchased HP 15.6 inch laptop, so when I had the opportunity to acquire this item, it felt like the stars had aligned!  And when it arrived, it looked great. Sleek and shiny.So with much anticipation, the application of the sleeve began.  It did not work.  Simple as that.  The 15.6" laptop would no longer close quite all the way, and frankly, we had to stretch the material SO tight to just get it on, we were worried about damaging the computer.  To give the benefit of the doubt, I should mention that our laptop has a somewhat large bezel (the edge around the screen).  Not all 15.6" are quite the same.  Perhaps with a slightly smaller bezel, it would have worked.  But it says 15.6" and we have a 15.6", so I'm not willing to cut much slack.And on top of everything else, it smelled bad!  I think  that was actually the final straw that had us take the darn thing off.  It didn't fit right and it stunk.  Why keep it??!!I'm not going all the way down to 1 star, because I can still see someone with a slightly smaller computer getting this to work, and if they had a not-so-keen sense of smell, they wouldn't mind.  So it was a complete bomb for us...but maybe not for everyone.

I read most of the reviews on this shirt and for me the shirt fits nicely. I'm 6' tall and weigh 165 athletic build. This is not a snug fitting shirt and its not overly loose. The photo of the model on this shirt pretty much is how the shirt looks on me. Its long enough to tuck in if I wanted too.The material is on the thinner side so that's why I gave it 4 stars. If the material was a bit thicker it would have been perfect. Its soft, very comfortable and the tag on the neck does not scratch or irritate you. I like the sleeve cuffs as they keep the sleeve from ridding up on you. The collar has 3 buttons and doesn't choke you or feel too tight around your neck.I'd get another one in a different color. its a nice shirt

I got the blue ones...great color. I've been wanting to try silicone versions because the regular plastic trays seem to chip and crack the actual ice. The silicone trays hold more water making it take double the time to freeze. I also had a difficult time getting them to pop out of the tray. While its flexible, one corner gets stuck when you try to work the opposite corner.I'll be honest and say that these are just ok. They are real big cubes and take up a lot of space in your glass so you'll get less of your beverage. These are probably great for one of those short wide glasses with your favorite liquor. but for everyday, they are a little bit of a hassle in my opinion. Too long to freeze and hard to pop out.

These are really great cutting boards. They are solid and have a good weight to them so they aren't moving all over the counter when cutting stuff. The large one can tackle just about anything and there's plenty of room for cutting multiple items. The smaller one is more narrow and i've used it as a cheese platter. I cut some slices and put it on the table so people can cut themselves their own slices.They are definitely worth the price and are of great quality. The thickness of these boards is also great and they don't feel cheaply made. Bamboo will outlast regular wood and doesn't nick as easily from your knife. After a while the boards might fade but just get a real high quality bamboo oil and they will refresh to brand new again.If there are any stains i use a little baking soda and cut a lemon or lime and use that to scrub the boards to sanitize them and get out stains.+ i received this item at a discount for my honest review

When i got the box i immediately said to myself how heavy it was. The packaging was really nice although large, its definitely a sign of quality. The box did have a glue chemical smell which i thought was strange. The watch itself is also very heavy, thick but striking to look at. Its a very masculine watch at the same time being elegant.Nice gold accents on the face with big hands that are easy to read. Day, date and 24hr mini faces are on the face of this particular watch. One thing i found was that you can accidentally hit the quick buttons and make the date, day and 24hr bump ahead by mistake. Kind of unnecessary buttons in my opinion. It doesn't make any kind of tick tick sound which is nice because i usually put my watch on the dresser at night and theres nothing worse then hearing that faint tick tick when you are trying to sleep.This is definitely a watch for a bigger guy because of the size of it. If you have a smaller wrist it will feel like you strapped a brick to your wrist because its so big and heavy. For me its a little larger than I like but once on it is nice and comfortable. It definitely can be a casual and dress watch because of its looks.The watch is water resistance to 100 feet but because its so nice i wouldn't want to get it wet like that. You will need to bring it to a jeweler or watch repair place to get the battery professionally replaced to keep the water resistance intact.I'm a watch collector and this one is a very nice and different addition to my collection.

What an excellent laptop briefcase bag. Its made tough for daily use and also for travel. I use it for travel because its sturdy, comfortable to hold and most of all its compact. I can fit my 15" laptop and my iPad plus all the cords and accessories needed for both and it still has room for much more.There are many of compartments both outside and inside. There are even compartments inside of compartments. One compartment has a small strap with a clip at the end to keep your keys from getting lost in the bag. Pens, papers, misc items, there's room for all of it or a compartment too.Upon first glance, you can tell that the bag is made very very well. The zippers are thick and the metal parts are heavy materials too. I highly doubt these will ever break. It has faux leather accents on the handles, bottom and shoulder strap. It comes in nice colors too.  The sewing is perfect, no loose threads or uneven seams. You also register the bag with Tumi which can return your bag if it gets lost. (probably empty but its  a nice thing they offer).The only issue is its so expensive most cannot afford or would want to put that much money into a briefcase.  However, it looks expensive, the materials are high grade so you do get high quality for the price.

I had expected the printer to be larger but epson has done a great job in keeping the profile of this one small. Because its able to handle 11x17 its going to be wider than the usual printers that handle only 8.5x11. It doesn't have a sheet feeder on the top so this saves some size on it. Most people who get this printer aren't concerned that it doesn't have the paper feeder on the top. You bought this to make 11x17 prints as well as scan legal sized documents.One of my favs on this printer is that you can print right on dvd/cd's. I make a lot of discs so its a great way to label them rather than writing on them and have them look junky. You can print on just about every paper size up to 11x17. Its a fast printer as well although when you use it on photo paper and high/fine settings it will run slower than just plain paper but thats acceptable because the prints look amazing.Copy scan, print wireless, AirPrint from iPad, iPhone android smartphone. There is no faxing but really who does that anymore. Its got a nice 4.3 touch screen which really makes life easy, no million buttons like older models had.This printer takes 6 inks...yes 6...the usual CMYB and the addition of light cyan and light magenta. So refilling standard inks will run around $65. if you go for the XL capacity inks be prepared to spend about $16 per cartridge or about $90 in the multi pack. Luckily for me black and magenta always seem to be the ones that run out so i can just buy the inks as needed.This printer is a great machine that does a great job on 11x17 size as well as the standard 8.5x11. So if you are looking for a great all around machine that can handle larger format, definitely give this one a try. Epson really makes great printers.

I have the larger Cameo which is awesome. The new smaller Curio is best for card making, embossing, etching. It can only go up to 8.5x12 by purchasing a separate cutting mat. It comes with an 8.5x6 which should be fine for most. It comes with one cutter and a fine and wide embossing tool. The etching tool is another separate accessory. You also get an embossing mat (as well as the cutting mat) in the kit and of course the software, plug, usb cord, free trial to the design store and 50 free design downloads.If you have or are familiar with other Silhouette cutters, then this one will be easy to figure out. It also uses the Studio software. It comes with the disc but i would download right from the website to have the latest version.The hardest thing is to configure the cutting, embossing, etching settings. What i mean is that you need to have the paper type, thickness, depth etc. I was cutting stickers that I printed and it took me 3 tries to get it right. First i had the cut depth too deep and when i peeled the sticker sheet off the mat, the cut outs were stuck to the mat. I also had problems with the stickers peeling while the machine was cutting and getting stuck to the cutter tool. If you buy other paper not made by Silhouette you will have a lot of trial and error to get things just right.other reviewers recommended watching videos on it...although this is a brand new machine (at time of this review) and there aren't any curio youtube vids yet...you can get the same info from the cameo vids.Both the camera and curio has a little learning curve but once you get that all down its a breeze to use. If i had to choose which is better i'd go with the cameo, its got a larger platform and you can do vinyl, and pixscan.

This is a very elegant and inexpensive nice watch. the face is nice and easy to read. the hands have that glow stuff on them so you can read it in the dark. The band may need to be sized if you have a small wrist. this will have to be done at a watch repair/jewelry shop.the watch comes wrapped in plastic to keep it from getting scratched up. Its a little difficult to unwrap it all so have patience. The watch is water resistant to 165 feet but I don't know anyone who will wear this type of watch and go diving. Being its that waterproof, i doubt you can replace the battery yourself. Again it will have to be brought to a professional jeweler. There is a 15 year limited warranty and the inclosed instructions mention $15.00 fee when you send it back to the manufacturer for repair.Its a nice watch for a gift or for that someone special but know that you will most likely need to have it sized.

This speaker is a bit larger than expected. Its not as portable as others on the market. I think this would be more the home speaker. What I really like about this is that the clarity of the sound is definitely superior than most. I have a Braven 805 speaker and its smaller but the volume really over powers the NYNE. This was a bit of a surprise to me. Comparing them, the sound of the Braven was a bit more muffled as it didn't have the clarity in the treble as the NYNE. The NYNE is definitely a winner in sound quality as it was crisp, clear and booming bass.This has a few cool features like the NFC pairing which was a simple tap and it worked great. I do like the larger buttons on top. Each button is for its own function no multiple function buttons to confuse or mess you up. It has a nice carrying handle in the back built in. You can also charge your USB devices with the power bank in the back. It also has an external aux 3.5 plug for non bluetooth devices. Hands free calling, 10 hour battery life. There's also an additional on off switch on the back that keeps the top buttons from being pressed when not in use.Overall its a super sounding speaker. The deep bass actually blows air out of the back port. Its a decent price point for the size speaker and sound quality.its got rubber coating on the sides and top. The grating is metal.  Its not as portable as others because of its size.

B+W makes some of the best filters for your camera lenses. This one in particular is fantastic. Its pretty thin which is great as it doesn't add further length or weight to your lenses. The quality of the metal and glass is top of the line. You need to have a top of the line polarizer on your expensive lens or your wasting your time. Inexpensive flyers are inferior quality and will only make your photos less sharp.You also can't get just any polarizer for digital cameras as they won't work correctly. There are linear and circular versions. Its a little involved to fully explain but basically digital cameras need the circular type for proper metering and exposure. Its easy to use and you see the results thru your eye viewer or screen (eye viewer is better). Just slowly spin the filter(its able to freely move even though the filter is screwed to the lens) until your glare disappears  or lessens. You can fiddle with it to your desire.Because the filter is slightly tinted, you will lose about 1-stop which isn't a big deal as other filters can block 2-3 stops. You will be very happy with this purchase its worth the extra money. Your photos will be stunning.

I read all the reviews before ordering this. I have tried so many other products over the years to extend my summer tan. Some had great color but smelled like rotten fruit. Some smelled ok but were orange. The scent on this one is a bit strong when you first apply it. Its not quite a masculine smell so some guys may want to pass on this. The Xen-Tan works a little differently than other products as you apply it and then after an hour or more you shower it off. This does help get rid of most of the scent.After a few hours your color will develop. I used the special Xen-Tan mitt to help apply the product. The Xen-Tan is a gel not a lotion so it goes on clear which makes it difficult to see where you've applied it. There was no rotten fruit smell afterwards which is a huge plus. I do however feel that it is a bit orange for me. Most people would be ok with the final color but i found in certain lighting it was a bit orange. I've used other products that were either more brown or slightly a red tone which I prefer. That's just me being picky.I recommend that you apply it lightly making sure you cover everything you are putting it on evenly so there are no streaks. Watch out when applying to fingers and toes. Make sure you get into all the creases etc or you'll have streaks. Then after 1 hour shower it all off off. Everyones skin is different so you don't want it to be too dark at first. You want to build up your color or it will look fake. And if you get the mitt, dampen it a little first and you will get better results.Don't get me wrong, this is overall a great self tanner that smells nice when applying and then doesn't have that rotten fruit smell afterwards. Its a little pricey but the overall experience using it was good.

I mainly use it for the scraping slicer. The pit remover didn't work that well because when i slice the avocado, the pit is horizontal but the pit remover is vertical so it needs the pointy end in but you can't do that with the way its designed. It's hit or miss with that feature. The knife end worked to slice the avocado in half but I still felt more comfortable using a regular knife to cut it in half and then remove the pit.The scraping slicer is the real star for me. It worked real well and it gets down to the outer skin pretty well. Its so much easier than trying to scrape it out with a spoon. I make lots of stuff with avocados so this tool will be a big help in preparing them.*got this at a discount for my honest review
