This laptop here at Amazon is ASIN B00X9KPSKK.  The other two above are B00UVXJEUS (the other maybe identical 13.3 inch with Core i3-5010U), and B016D03S18 (the 11.6 inch model).You should always go to cpubenchmark.net and enter the CPU of the laptop you are thinking about getting.  The trade offs all start based on how fast the CPU is and how much memory it has.  So the Pentium N3540 in this model with a TDP of 7.5w is consuming half the max power of the other processor at 15w.  And the N3540 has a slightly faster clock speed and four cores instead of two.  But this does not tell the complete story.  The CPU MARK for the N3560 shows it performs at 66% of the faster one.  And there is a tradeoff between overall CPU processing speed and battery life.  But it does not necessarily mean that you get 2x or even 1.3x the battery life of the Core i3-5010U in the other laptop.  And because HP does not list battery life comparisons for various x360 models on their own website or on Amazon, you are left to continue sleuthing which is crazy in the era of big data, analytics, and the world at your fingertips via the Internet.Laptopmag says this of another x360 sibling (with a 2.17-GHz Intel Pentium N3520 Processor)  "You won't get much use out of the HP Pavilion x360 without a charger handy. The notebook lasted 3 hours and 43 minutes on our battery test (Web surfing over Wi-Fi at 100 nits). This endurance falls short of the K200MA (5:23), Yoga 2 11 (5:19) and NB15t (4:07), which all failed to live up to the 7:45 category average."Laptopmag says of an x360 i3-5010U (2nd model in comparison above?)  "The Pavilion x360 13t has pretty good staying power for its price. This convertible lasted 6 hours and 56 minutes on the Laptop Mag Battery Test (continuous Web surfing over Wi-Fi at 100 nits), which is better than the TP300 (6:12) and the Inspiron 15 (4:46). The HP also beat the budget 2-in-1 average (6:17)"  (Note that the model number of "x360 13t" does not appear anywhere in the HP Amazon listing.  We are guessing we have a match based on the screen size and CPU.)Techradar, speaking of a [?newer] x360 model says "Users will also be able to configure the 11.6-inch HP Pavilion x360 with a fanless Intel Core M chip for $499 (about 334, AU$646), which HP promises will deliver eight hours of battery life. "  I could not tell which x360 this is because none of the Amazon HP x360 product listings say 'Core M' and the review did not refer to any x360 model number.HP needs to be consistent in clearly distinguishing the features of the zoo of x360 offerings.  This is something that manufacturers like HP can no longer ignore.  A model number should include the main specs of the laptop.  Otherwise you risk picking a laptop that does not meet YOUR specific needs.  And the HP website is no better.  Although you can see some model numbers there.  If you click on 'See all offers' on the x360 page using either Chrome or IE, nothing happens.But besides clearer product numbering and model naming, HP and the entire industry need to come to a kind of *** truth in labeling *** when it comes to price and performance.  Most product pages for laptops do not clearly talk about battery life.  If you can get talk time and standby time for every mobile phone you should be able to get some kind of standard battery and performance specs for computers and tablets.In the photography world there is a CIPA standard for battery life in cameras.  There needs to be a similar standard here for battery life for laptops, tablets, and phones and all manufacturers need to use it.  Maybe something like PerfLife = batteryLifeAtBenchmarkSettings * standardPerformanceBenchmark

OK, you want to track your fitness/workouts/movement and want something a little more sophisticated than a pedometer.  And maybe you don't want to have your phone with you all the time.  Ok, so get a activity tracker like the fitbit.  Or maybe you want an UP2 instead.  Comparing the two there are many reasons why the fitbit flex shows that the UP2 is the better product.Wrist band - First, you have to press into your wrist to get the prongs to attach the band to your write.  This feels very uncomforable to do.  But still this kind of mechanism is waiting to fall off your wrist.  Many people don't press hard enough when putting it on so it's not really on and then falls off during exercise.  The problem is so bad that people are loosing them all the time.  There is even a product called BANDCUFFS which is a $6 piece of rubber you slide over the clasp on the fitbit band to keep it from coming apart.  You will want a better band than what it ships with.  In this regard the adjustable metal clasp on the UP2 is much more secure.  Point to UP2.Charging - The fitbit module comes with a charging cradle that is notorious for being slightly too big.  The cradle often does not hold the contacts in all the way and people are using paperclips and bent pieces of paper to keep the module in snug enough to charge.  The UP2 charger is also USB and is magnetic.  If you put the charger contacts on backwards the UP2 will not charge.  The fitbit charger is another design foible. Point to UP2Phone User Interface / App - The fitbit application one the bare bones application.  It's hardly graphical.  It does help you control settings on the fitbit but you get a distinctly meh feeling using it.  Fitbit is showing little effort to make a nice application here which is disappointing.  The UP2 UI is fairly well done.  It's pretty and very graphical.  It even helps you get exciting about meeting and exceeding your fitness goals.  The UP2 UI has some bad/nonsensical choices about how to save and exit menus.  But it's much more interesting to use than the fitbit UI.  Point to UP2.Other features are similar for sleep mode, alarms, activity tracking, food tracking, etc.  There are other minor differences here.  But the above items of band, charging, and Phone App, all scored 3 points for UP2 and 0 for fitbit.If you want to feel like you are interacting with a fun, interesting, and motivational device, that will charge without playing with it, and that is not waiting to fall off your wrist, get the UP2Update: 2015-OCT-02 - Yesterday the fitbit gave me a badge for making my 10K steps goal, although actually I had achieved the goal the previous day and was only around 7.5K steps when this award came up.  But then each time I double-tapped the fitbit it would only flash two dots and another two dots in a slightly different position [that's it's notification 'message'].  I could look on my phone and see what my current steps were as the day went on.  But the fitbit never got itself out of this notification mode when double-tapped (to see how many of 5 lights (each 20%) you were to your goal).  And it even did NOT reset itself the next day.  I had to remove the module and start charging it again (even though it was nearly full), in order to get the fitbit to respond to the double-tap as it should.  So be warned, both the phone apps and the onboard firmware are buggy.  My partner has an UP2 and it is SOOOO much nicer than a fitbit.  The fitbit has too many fits compared to the UP2.

This is a very good budget tripod, great for travel.  Much more sturdy than a U6000 I already have.  Only downside for me is that most other retailers are now including a free tripod bag at the same price.  Not so for sellers on Amazon including Roberts LP.  Luckily I already have a tripod bag to travel with.

It's cuddable, and it reacts to your child based on touch at the paws, chest, etc.  This is an interesting idea.  I think this would be enjoyed by most children.  Beware that it has a handful of Spanish words.  But the music and sounds are worth it.  Kids can absorb way more than most people think.  Exposing them to the ABCs, songs, and counting at a young age, is sure to help stimulate your toddlers development.

This model is very well built.  It goes together and is easy to use.  It heats up pretty quick and does a good job.  We've used other steamers before that just seemed klunky, were hard to get consistent results, or you had to refill too frequently.  This this one is a great balance of price and performance.  Highly recommended.

This is a really good exercise and sleep tracking band.  It concedes nothing to fitbit and holds it's own very well.  However there are a few issues to be aware of.  The pedometer/tracker tends to under-measure compared to other pedometers.  We even had one morning were nearly all of an entire hike was not recorded (240 steps on the up2, but 5000 on a smart phone).  It's unclear whether this device uses NFC to upload to your phone as it seems to be uploading even when bluetooth on the phone is turned off.But the largest letdown here is the UI (phone software, food database, and band indicator lights).  First, the phone app software UI design itself is bad.  It tries to look nice but uses some strange UI symbols such as a pressing a check-mark to dismiss/save the current settings instead of a button clearly marked SAVE  or go back.  There are enough non-standard UI queues in here that you will get confused from time to time.  This needs to be fixed with standard user-friendly metaphors.  But the worse part of the app is the food tracking database.  Just try to find something like fresh strawberries or fresh blackberries, you can't, at least on the version we are using.  And there are many other common foods that the S Health application on Samsung Android devices can find that you won't find here.  Clearly the food part of the application is just plain bad.There are some issues with the band itself.  You really need to watch the video on how to adjust the clasp so you don't lose it.  And there is nearly NO other device that lights up RED when it's done charging.  What!!!  I don't care if on some other Jawbone models there is an outline of a runner in red when it's done charging.  That's NOT this model.  When it's charging you get alternating white, blue, and red lights.  And when it's fully charged you get a RED light??????  facepalmOverall, jawbone is coming close to the perfect solution.  But it has enough blemishes to make you pause and continue looking around.  If they can fix the software, make the UI more rational, upgrade the entries in the database, change the 'charged' led from red to green, and clearly explain how the UP2 is communicating with your phone (bluetooth and/or NFC, and which for what data), then they would have a more serious product here, and a winner.Update 2015-NOV-15 - After a month of using the UP2, it has stopped correctly recording all steps.  We changed nothing, and yet when compared to a fitbit flex, both of these units used to record within 3% of each other the correct steps.  But in the past few days the UP2 only records from 3000-5000 steps whereas the fitbit flex is recording more accurately the 12,000 to 15,000 steps we have been doing.  It looks like the UP2 has some issues.

The two year old this was given to was wide-eyed for sure!  It's, it's, zoe? no, it's Abby  And this doll is just about as large as the two year old girl is.  It's like having your own character from Sesame Street jump into your arms.  It's squeezable and just well done.  I now think that Abby here is #2 to her most favorite #1, Elmo !!!  This is a great doll, highly recommended.

Most 1.5-2 year old girls, making the transition to potty training, are excited about shifting into 'big girl pants'.  These are a great step along the way as they are easier to get out of and into than traditional diapers.  The design is great and mostly they are a replacement for diapers.  Though they are great for all around use, including sleeping in, I have heard of some parents giving negative reviews for night use.  But in those few cases it sounded like baby had a problem that required medical attention.  Highly recommended.

We got a big box today from Amazon.  It's a Q3, measuring at 37" long x 10.5" wide x 3" tall.  First one of these I've ever seen.  I had no idea what could be in that large box.  I opened that box, and inside saw an Amazon basics box 13.5" x 10.5" x 1.5".  Inside of that box (feeling like nested Russian dolls at this point) was... VIOLA!  this 11.6 inch case.  I'm sure this case had a very comfy ride inside the plastic wrap, inside the box, inside the Q3 monster box.Now, at first when you touch this case from the outside you think.  ooooo, mega protection.  But open the zipper and find that there is a cushy white bubble/air something inside giving it the cush.  Ok.  So, take that out, and you have a nice neoprene sleeve.Putting this on a 11.6" Thinkpad x140e, it did not quite, really fit.  The first zipper was a little hard to get around the top corner, and coming across the laptop into the home stretch, I really had to pinch the fabric together to get it zipped shut.  I'm sure it will be fine as it will stretch out over time.  But Amazon should make this just a couple mm longer in each direction to ensure that beefer notebooks like the thinkpad (a little thicker than most) will fit comfortably.I also wish Amazon would go to a percentage rating system like most things are on the Internet rather than trying to shoehorn your perceptions into 5 start.  Amazon products are not movies, there is much more nuance in products.Minus .25 star (5%) for the wasted large box used in shipping, and Minus .75 star (15%) for a bit too snug of a fit of the case on the Thinkpad x140e.

lf you are health conscious you are interested in the healing power of nature and the use of herbs such as tumeric.  Who hasnt seen or heard Hippocrates famous quote about letting food be your medicine and your medicine your food?  And this particular pill isn't just tumeric-based, but real tumeric powder.  And it's also got bioperine (black powder) which assists in the tumeric absorption.  This combination is particularly effect for a majority of people for inflammation and is even being examined in it's role to fight certain cancers.Yes, the price is a little high, but the blend is very good and it's based on organic ingredients.  So if you can afford it, then there isn't a better choice out there right now than this one.

The box clearly says this is a TRAVEL razor.  It's small, it will take you longer to shave.  It eats batteries so have some extra NiHM rechargables with  you.  It works wet or dry so that's good.  This is for someone who much prefers electric over blades and who is going on a trip for a couple of days.

This is a very handy tool.  Yes, it's versatile.  But there are a number of issues with this tool when used for grout removal.  I used the best/correct blade for the job Dremel MM501 1/16-Inch Multi-Max Carbide Grout Blade.  Took care to wear safety googles and a breathing mask.  I've used it a couple of times for removing 1/16" grout and though the tool works very well in long straight stretches, there are a number of issues.First, it can get really old to keep having to loosen/remove the holding screen, re-position the blade, and screw it back down.  When you are working corners or edges next to tubs this really slows you down.  There should be another kind of quick release here where you can change blade position in a few seconds, not a minute or two.  Another issue is that the holding screw tool itself, which is supposed to clip on the top of the tool, won't stay on after you take it off a few times.  That entire design of the plastic retainer is flawed.  You'll end up leaving the removal tool just off to the side.  Lastly, with any kind of dust build-up on the outside of the tool, the power switch itself becomes very hard to turn off.  This should be an on/off push button under a rubber cup or other dust-protecting cover.  Even after a few minutes of using the tool for grout removal, if you keep turning off the tool to change the blade and you have any kind of dust around, you will be slowed both by blade changes and by the power switch getting harder to turn on and off.Yes, it's a great tool.  But it's not great if you have to adjust the blade frequently or if you are generating a lot of dust.
These work great, absolutely no issues.  Very fast.  Recommended.
These work great, absolutely no issues.  Very fast.  Recommended.

This info is from the woman in the house using it.Ok, does this work?  Yes.  But you really need to be careful with this.  A) Use plenty of shower gel  B) Keep away from sensitive areas.  Basically this is for the fronts and sides of legs, stay away from the backs of the knees.  Does it keep the hair away longer?  Yes.  But the epilator action is somewhat ouchy.  That's what you get in exchange for going longer between shaves.  The charge time is like crazy 20-24 hours.  Needs a larger battery to last longer.  This is an alternative to waxing, BUT it's a decidedly hard way to go with limited use are and a certain amount of pain.

We used this at first as a vacation laptop, something to take on trips.  But after a taking it with him on a trip to Asia, the teen in our house fell in love with it.  A month ago he took it with him to college in California.  And here, in late 2015, this laptop is still going strong.  We upgraded it's memory and put in an SSD and it's one sweet ride.  It's a great laptop.BUT, I have to say with my other experiences of Acer that I don't think I would purchase them again.  We have the i5 powered 5755G 15.6 laptop.  That laptop never worked adequately, it's fan seemed to always run and it seemed a little hobbled regardless of more RAM and disk defragmentation.  When we carefully disassembled it (being well versed in laptop upgrades), we found it was one of the most difficult laptops to upgrade.  You tend to find this a lot in Acers and in general among most cheaper laptops.  The Acers seem to be just a little too cheap and don't make upgrades easy.Today we like ASUS much better.  This ASUS laptop was very upgrade-unfriendly returned it ASUS F555 15-Inch Laptop [OLD VERSION].  Eventually we bought up the food chain closer to the $1000 level with this excellent and more easily upgradable i7 ASUS machine ASUS N550J 15.6-Inch Laptop [OLD VERSION]IF you are looking for something that has been sold in the past year or so that is similar to this Aspire One here,  then your two best choices are the Lenovo x140e Lenovo Thinkpad X140e 11.6 inch Laptop, AMD APU E1-2500, 4GB RAM, 500GB HDD, Windows 8 Professional (Certified Refurbished) and the ASUS K200MA-DS01T(S) 11.6-Inch HD Touchscreen Laptop (Black).  The x140e is no longer sold but you can find great condition ones on eBay.  The advantage with the Thinkpads are two-fold, they are usually among the most upgrade friendly laptops you can find, a single screw unlocks most of the bottom cover for memory and disk upgrade.  The ASUS K200MA is spec-d similarly, but the over-glare screen that won't tilt back quite far enough for good viewing is a consideration.  As is the fact that they have buried access to the hard drive under the keyboard, a typical cheesy and cheapskate move that even the Asus F555 used.The other main thing about the Thinkpads, is that they have an innovative fan design that keeps most of the dust out of the fan.  The number one issue with any laptop, any computer, over time, that will usually doom it a slow death (as the fan runs more and more) is usually dust buildup on the cooling fans.  As dust gathers on the fan the efficiency goes down, the fan keps running, the CPU and other components heat goes up, and this wears them out (the hotter they are the shorter they will function before failure.)  THIS single issue is THE primary one that eventually kills laptops and the Thinkpad design is one of the few that attempt to address this issue.  It's really abhorrent that there is no required standards about laptop fans and dust build up.  This design choice in the x140e, 'dustless fan' is a bit of magic you should be aware of.  "Dustless Fan - Filters dust from entering the fan assembly to extend the life of the fan"So when we were looking to replace the Aspire One that went to college, it came down to the ASUS KM200A and Thinkpad x140e.  I was leaning towards the ASUS (BHphoto 311.00), but switched to the Thinkpad x140e finding one in great condition on eBay at 150.00.

Interesting the ingredients are not currently on the Amazon website.  If you are a vegetarian you probably want to avoid.  MGM would be the supplement you want if you are a vegetarian.  With this product you are supporting the deplenishment of life in the oceans.Supplement FactsServing Size 1 softgelServings Per Container 30Amount Per ServingCalories 5Calories From Fat 5Total Fat 0 gTrans Fat 0 gCholesterol 0 mgProvinal Omega-7 Fatty Acid Blend 420 mgOmega-7 Fatty Acids (Palmitoleic Acid) 210 mgHyaluronic Acid 40 mgIngredients: Fish oil (Anchovy and/or Menhaden), softgel (gelatin, glycerine, water, sorbitol sorbitan solution, and caramel color), hyaluronic acid, beeswax, and sunflower lecithin.

This is very fine seed.  When you open the bad you think "yep, that's really blue".  It goes on with no issues with a scotts hand spreader set on medium.  Though I have some concerns about inhaling the powder that comes off is as you spread it out.  I would either stay upwind or wear some kind of mask.  We are going to get more main in the next few days, so we'll see how the sprouting comes along.  Will update this review with more info either way.

Ok, I thought I had tasted various kinds of 'goji' berries before.  I'm sure most of us have.  You've heard the hype, consumed for thousands of years by levitating yogis in the himalayas or wherever.  Well, it's time to forget the hype.  Because, at least for me, none of those poser berries were the real thing.  I'm not exaggerating, these taste unlike any goji berries I've ever had, and I've had all kinds in the past few years.  They are organic, dried to perfection, and the taste, it like layers of enjoyment compared to anything else you've had named 'goji'.  In fact, the only things the other berries have in comparison to these is the spelling of the name.  Do yourself a big favor and try these.  You won't go back to any others.  Absolutely Yummy.

I've been using Maca for a few years now.  It's one of the many wonderplants from South America.  I mix mine into protein shakes.  You can feel the energy throughout the day.  This is a very good brand, much cheaper than Viva Labs #1 Organic Maca Powder, Gelatinized for Enhanced Bioavailability, Non-GMO, 1lb Bag.  Highly recommended !!!!!

I've never been disappointed by any Dell monitor I've owned.  So long as you are not a coder and won't missing the extra vertical pixels as in the Dell Ultrasharp U2415 24-Inch Screen LED-Lit Monitor, this monitor will suit you fine.This monitor is extremely well designed, aethestics are top notch.  I'm knocking off a single star due to lack of vertical/height adjustment and pivoting, these are missing features that should not have been left out.

Where to begin, there are just so many things wrong with this.  First, the headset itself, plastic and aluminum that wraps around your head.  This is so thin it just feels like it's waiting to break.  Second, the ear pads themselves, think really nice pads that would go around your ears, but then shrink them so they press on your ears directly.  My ears start getting hot within 30 seconds.  Next the wires, they are soo thin that I can see them breaking in short order.  The next misfire is the control switch.  With a fully charged AAA battery in there, turn it to ON and you hear nothing.  Turn it to OFF and you hear the sound.  ?????  The one thing that works is the volume button on the control.  Do these actually noise cancel, well, not so much.  I'm sitting here with a window open and can hear the neighbors a few doors down doing yard work and my front loading washing machine gently turning away in another part of the house.  Not sure if these are defective but all of this together means these are not worth it.These are not something I would purchase for an adult or a teen.  They are soo fragile, think tween.  And yet for the price, you are stuck in a strange pricing level.  At $50 you are much better off going for Sentey Warp LS-4420 High Definition Stereo Foldable Headphones with Noise Isolation Ear Cups for Apple, Samsung Headphones, 3.5mm Connector, 40mm Drivers, 20Hz-20KHz Frequency, Black/Red.  And if you want more name brand recognition get to the $99 level here Sennheiser HD 280 PRO HeadphonesAs it is, given the durability issues with this design, I don't think they are worth more than $29-$35.

Ok, most young girls (I'd say age 6+) who love the Frozen movie are going to really groove on this book.  It would be a VG book if it just had some hair styles in it and showed you how to do them.  BUT, it also has other sections like creating hair accessories.  It's that kind of creative engagement and MAKING something, instead of just BUYING something, that can help give girls a good sense of empowerment.  Highly recommended.

Ok, from the look it's seaweed on one side and some kind of batter on the other.  From the touch, they remind me of Honey Grahams cereal (because they are a little powdery).  They are crunchy.  But the flavor is too complex.  It's seaweed, with a touch of fish, wait, no it's some kind of batter, wait, it's pepper or cayenne or something.  Added sugar and added salt.  Why?  These are really trying too hard to be liked.And what's up with no reseal zip on the bag?  Nearly every other bag of this style (inner aluminum foil) has a reseal.  These are simply not so outstanding that I'd want to eat an entire bag.

There is something about Chamomile.  I knew it relaxed you.  But also in dealing with pain?  This is very interesting and it works with adults...Science poo-poos anything they cannot verify, including homeopathy.  However, there are too many evidences of this and other homeopathic products that do work.  We need to preserve nature, help it to grow, and it will show us it has the answers we are looking for.

Ok, this it toilet paper.  As others have said, the cardboard tube is a bit larger than standard, so you may have trouble fitting into your holder.  Maybe this is made for bears ?  Yes, it is a bit stronger than most.  What is also weird is the packaging.  These are 3 across by 4 tall which makes unopened packages a bit long for storage.  Better is the standard configuration of 3 across by 2 tall which stores much better.  The jury is out.  But it is really hard to beat the brand of the cost company.  This one is VG, but price a whee bit high.Now that I think about it, I'm considering taking a bunch of this and making either a canoe or party favors in the shape of swans.  Think hygenic toilet paper mache on steroids, with a coat or two of varnish, this could just work.  Putting that heavy duty to good use.

Ok, I get it.  No alcohol.  It's trying to be minty-ish, sort of.  But overall this taste is very tentative.  Nothing like the very sparky TheraBreath Dentist Recommended Fresh Breath Oral Rinse - Mild Mint Flavor, 16 Ounce (Pack of 2).  Not even as much as the muted Nature's Answer PerioBrite Alcohol-Free Mouthwash, Cool Mint, 16-Fluid Ounce.  Check for an article on the Internet named Fundamentals of Dentifrice: Oral Health Benefits in a Tube  to get an idea of what fluoride is supposed to do.  Just ensure to spit it all out.

This is a good roller,  The black ones are supposed to be the hardest.  It does work well.  However, as it's only 18 inches wide, would not recommend this to someone who has not used one before as it may turn out from under you if you are not careful.  If you are a beginner then go with something that is more like 36 inches wide.
We have a few puppets already including a kitten.  This little seal, with it's big eyes, is a hit with toddlers and young children.  Great quality, highly recommended.

This is a pretty small scanner for what it does.  Powered by USB as compared to some large dongles and bricks you get on many other units.  It's forte are documents but it can handle photos also.  Got something large?  Use the ArcSoft Scan-n-Stitch Deluxe software which does a pretty good job at lining things up.  Downsides?  For most users, I can't think of any.  At < $80?  It's a great value.

My millennial daughter likes using typewriters and keeping organized in spiral planners.  This one is very good.  The July-to-July works great for her.  The size is very handy yet portable.  This is definitely an up-scale calendar not like the < $5 things you can get at cheapmart.  If you want a much better planner for people on the go, this is it (short of a smart-phone).

This mouse will go down in history as one of THE best input devices ever made along side the Microsoft Keyboard Elite.  I've been using these for over 10 years.  I have one at home and one in the office.  They have never fail me even once.  I just bought another one to keep around as insurance in case there is a failure I won't be without for that long.I've used all kinds of devices like this from Logitech, Kensington, Microsoft, etc.  But there is something about this overall well thought out package that really makes this a classic.  If you want to save your wrists and want something that intuitive to use, you won't find a better option in this price range, or any price range that I know of.  Highly recommended. !!!!!

This has got to be the smallest typeset on a bottle in nearly the entire planet.  I can't be sure exactly what it says because after putting on 3 pairs of glasses at the same time I can almost make it out.  Here's what I see:Aqua, Sodium Laureth Sulfate, glycerin, sodium chloride, cocamidoproyl betaine, PEG-4, raspesedamind, parfum, glycol, disterate, cocamida mea, styrene/Actylates copolymer, propylene glycol, citric acide, magnifera indica juice, trideth-9, bisbolci, methychlroishaizarflone, methylischaloline, limonene, hexyl cinnami.Here is what google hits find with a few minutes of searching.- PEG compounds are routinely contaminated with the carcinogen 1,4-dioxane.- The jury is out on  Sodium Laureth Sulfate but it is generally frowned upon in the health food and healthy living circles.- Cocamidopropyl Betaine (CAPB) is a common trigger for skin irritation including  eczema, psoriasis, rosacea, and contact dermatitis.- Cocamide Diethanolamine (cocamide DEA) was listed by California last year as a carcinogen.- Acrylates copolymer causes skin irritation in some people- Methylchloroisothiazolinone - the webpage I saw on this said this chemical is anti-fungal and is similar in some respects to Agent Orange and is a nerve agent ?- Hexyl Cinnamal is rated by DIMDI (German Institute of Medical Documentation and Information) rates it as a Class B allergen when given in high doses (but considered 'safe' in cosmetics).This brew is not something you are likely to find mom and pop making in the jungle from the natural plants.  This is industrial chemistry.Choices such as Puracy, Method, and Mrs Meyers are similar products but with varying degrees of more natural than this one.And I don't get why folks want to say this review is not helpful.  Just because you disagree?  Really?  Care to please comment and make a solid and factual refutation?  Otherwise methinks that Duru fans or employees lurk on Amazon.com.

This is certainly not your normal mouthwash.  It's not a Scope or Listerine or anything like that.  Think Tom's of Maine but make it more intense.  I've used Nature's Answer PerioBrite Alcohol-Free Mouthwash, Cinnamint, 16-Fluid Ounce products before which are in a similar vein.  This product here is like that but a bit more intense.  You can tell it's working longer than most other products.  But it's kinda hard to justify using only this due to the price.

Like many/most folks who have tried various things over the years from chitosan, goji berries, cambogia garcinia, etc to try and reduce overweightness or turn a little flab into muscle, just dropping a few seasonal pounds in the Springtime and so on.  Most of these really don't do much for me.  After a week of Forskolin, I can say that I do feel a slight change in decreased hunger which I've only experienced with one or two products in the past like Hoodia.I'll update again after a couple more weeks.

Got this for a friend who will be having their baby soon.  It's high quality material with a lot of design points that make it worth consideration.  The material is very nice, the bottom access for diaper changing is good.  The design keeps in mind the best position for hips on newborns when laying down.  I'm sure baby will feel snuggled well back to sleep.  Halo consistently gets high ratings on Amazon and it's easy to see why.Oh, and if you baby is standing up in this like the photo on the Amazon page, please post your photo.  :-)

If you have never read any account of any medicine people at work such as Lame Deer or a Castenada tale, then you might find something interesting in here.  But this was written in the mid-80's.  It's a fairly dry read, slow at parts, with lots that makes it a bit of a slog.  Certainly not one on the must read list for the topic of 'shamanism' or even if you are a Villoldo-ite.  It's a pass.  Much more interesting stuff out there.Good first books on Native American medicine people include:Rolling ThunderMother Earth Spirituality: Native American Paths to Healing Ourselves and Our World (Religion and Spirituality)If you are interested in Andean mysticism/'shamanism' here are some of the best titles:Gate of Paradise: Secrets of Andean ShamanismAndean Awakening: An Inca Guide to Mystical PeruThe Fourth Level: Nature Wisdom Teachings of the InkaMasters of the Living Energy: The Mystical World of the Q'ero of PeruIf you want a very good overview of the medicine path ('shamanism') this is a great book:Walking in Light: The Everyday Empowerment of a Shamanic Life
This is a good night guard.  Got a good fit on the first try.  But be sure to shop around because often sellers like wmart have comparable products for nearly half the price.

It's a nice lens for M4/3.  Good range and good complement to standard kit lens.  You can pick these up on eBay for alot less.Personally I became discouraged M4/3 as many of the lenses are getting a bit pricey for what was primarily supposed to be a shrinkage of the form factor.  I sold off my Panasonic and Olympus gear and went onto to Sony DSLT and the results are amazing.  If I were tempted to go back into M4/3, it would be for Olympus OM only.  No other sensors in this form factor come close.

Amazon sent this in a neat box...with a kind of cut out for the two bars.  The problem is, I live in Florida, and the chocolate melted.  So I popped it in the fridge, and it resolidified.  Problem solved.  I didn't have a bar that had 12 distinct pieces, mine looked more like a block...but I didn't care, because it was delicious.  It reminded me of the homemade candy bark you can sometimes be lucky enough to receive during the holidays from a talented friend.  Cailler is excellent quality chocolate...and the milk chocolate is particularly good.  (Yes, I know I"m supposed to like dark better....but I really prefer milk.) I actually spent some time living in Swtizerland, so it brought back happy memories.  You can actually visit their chocolate factory in Broc in Western Swtizerland.  The nuts and fruit are very chunky and delicious.  This is excellent chocolate to treat yourself with, or to give to a friend.
Great help!

My kindergartner, who thinks he's a cat, loved this book.  It's a cute little story that asks the readers to prove they are cats by meowing, purring, stretching, etc. before the cats in the book reveal the "Cat Secrets."

I didn't realize this was just a card game when I bought it, but it doesn't matter...we love it.  Basically, you try and make stacks of money that add up to $100.  (Cards are $15, $20, $30, $40, $45, $50, $55, $70, $80, $85).  You can steal another player's stack by adding a card on top that makes it $100...so if the top card is $70 and you add a $30 card you can steal it.  You can also steal using a thief card.  The final way to steal is via a jail card and that can only go on a thief card.  Once you have a jail card, nobody can steal your stack.  It's a fast paced game and doesn't take a long time to play.  The game is over when one person runs out of cards.  We've played with three and four players and it went well.  IMHO, the more players, the more fun.

My five year old got this for his fifth birthday.  He loves his wallet.  It's a trip fold....and has velcro.  It has a zip pocket for coins.  He loves it.  The colors are nice and it seems very well made. (He opens and closes it a gazillion times per day).  Very happy we bought this.

My kids (11 and 9) all loved the first series of Spirit Animals, so were excited to see this new book.  My 9 year old says this is his favorite spirit animals book so far.  My 11 year old says,  "the idea of the ever tree rotting and releasing the dreadful creature called 'worm' is a very nice concept. I can't wait for the next novel that they write."  He gave it five stars.  Although it's a separate series, he thinks that kids should read the first series first.  My nine year old thinks that kids can enjoy it regardless.  Scholastic used to have a fun video game kids could play online.

I've been using Coromega since they first came out.  So I was curious as to how these would compare.  I still buy the original orange Coromega.  I prefer the squeeze packs to any sort of pill because no fishy burps, and it's absorbed better.The Coromega packs I take say:20 calories2000 mg fish oil650 mg long chain fatty acids350 mg EPA230 mg DHAThe Sundown Packs say:20 calories2000 mg fish oil588 total omega 3s comprised of:314 EPA196 DHABoth have 10 mg of stevia.So Coromega provides slightly more Omega 3s, but not by a lot.  Taste-wise, I preferred the Coromega that I've been using for 15 years.My son (11) said they both taste the same.  Depending on the price, that's who you should go with IMHO.  I can get a big 90 pack of Coromega for about $10 more than the Sundown is selling right now.  So as it's triple the packs, that's what I'd buy.  (Everybody in our family takes it, so we go through it quickly.)  But if you just want to try out the fish oil squeeze packs to see if you like them, or perhaps you're more regular taking them than with pills, then I'd take whichever gets you 30 cheaper.Oh, when Coromega first came out, "Prevention" ran an article on all of the different ways you could eat it.  If you don't like it plain, I believe they suggested adding it to a smoothie or even pudding.

First, a disclaimer. I was given this book for free.  I haven't read any of Salman Rushdie's works before, and I wanted to see what all the fuss was about. Within a page or two, you realize why Salman Rushdie is such a venerated author.  His choice of language and the breadth of the cultural and religious references he uses is inspiring. The premise for the story was fascinating. It harkens back to his Muslim upbringing with the story of Jinn.  Believing in jinn and angels are one of the articles of faith for Muslims.  I don't think any fatwas will come down over this topic, though.In "Two Years Eight Months and Twenty Eight Nights" (aka 1001 nights...a critical time period throughout the centuries that the book transverses), we have basically a battle in our time between the Jinn and the descendants of a female Jinn Dunia and her relationship with the 12th century  great Muslim philosopher, mathematician, and physician/scientist Ibn Rushd (Averroes).  Her children are known as the Duniazat (the tribe of Dunia), and they all share the unique characteristic of having no earlobes.  They also are prone to lightening strikes.  Without adding any spoilers, I'll say 1) Probably better to read in your Kindle so you can look up references you don't know.  2) I think Rushdie cheapened himself with some of the crude language and focus on sex.  He's a master wordsmith, he didn't need to do that.I think if you like fantasy or end-of-times type books, you will enjoy this.  As far as I know, this may be the first end-of-times book with a Muslim slant that I've read.  I enjoyed it, but it's not an easy rush through read.

A little more than a year ago, I started using a pumpkin peel from Skin Obsession every two weeks. (I'm in my mid-40s, with fair skin and light eyes.)  I've been looking for a moisturizing mask to add to my routine, and am now using the pumpkin peel every month.  When I saw the opportunity to try this out, I was quite happy to do so.  I know the Phyto 5  brand and was excited to try this product.  In general, I liked it.  My skin felt lightly moisturized after and the next morning.  It's not a deep hydrating masque in my opinion.  At the price it's listed for now, it's a good value.  There were two issues regarding the product IMHO:1) The mask did not come out of the container very easily and smoothly.2) It's not really a mousse as stated on its label.  Its more of a normal mud masque for lack of a better description.I do think it moisturized my skin well, but the product did not have the luxurious feel/texture I was expecting.

ETA...October 2015:  Our new favorite (simple) is the raspberries with white chocolate chips.  So simple that my five year old can make them, but really delicious. I buy the raspberries at a warehouse club, and then a package of white chocolate chips at Trader Joe's or Target (best prices).  You can also use the white chocolate chips for the grapes dipped in white chocolate.First off, my kids really love this book.  It's an engaging format, with lots of pictures, good layout, that made them want to look through it for recipes.  We all also really like the rating system for recipes in the back, it helps us remember what we've tried and liked.  Many of the recipes are simple and easy.  I have an 11, 9, 7, and 4 year old, and many of these are perfect for kids to help with, or even do by themselves.  She talks about GF alternatives which is key for me with one of my kids.The negatives (for me) would be two.  One, she uses a lot of honey in the recipes.  I hate honey.  Yes, I've substituted agave and just good ol' plain sugar in some--but to me, it just seems honey happy. :)  Secondly, some of the recipes are just too involved for the average Mom.  The s'more toaster pastries are a wonderful idea....but are most Moms really going to make homemade pie dough, homemade Nutella, and homemade marshmallow fluff?  I don't think so.  (We made the recipe using store bought Nutella, marshmallow fluff, and homemade pie dough. :))  Some people may complain that many of these are not real recipes (too easy to need one), but since they reminded me of that idea or gave me that idea, it works for me.  (Plus, there are plenty of real recipes to make up for those.)So far, the winners have been:The afore mentioned toaster pastriesThe various cream cheese spreadsThe chia puddingThe banana popsThe dipped pretzelsApple sandwiches (apples and peanut butter)Watermelon Pops (yes, not really a recipe, but my kids loved having watermelon on a stick.)Now that it's summer, the kids are picking out ideas for snacks every week.
This worked great for my son who looks better with longer hair.  Very happy to find this comb.  I used it on my Wahl clippers with the rainbow colored combs.

I was so excited to see these on Amazon.  I used them to make chocolate s'mores cupcakes.  They worked wonderfully.  Only problem is there are only 12 marshmallows in each package! I think it's a better deal to just buy the regular Paskesz marshmallows.  A few years ago, I found a multipack on Amazon that had the minis and regulars.  Wish that would be offered again.These marshmallows are the same as American Halal Marshmallows.  Paskesz and American Halal are both basically rebranded Campfire marshmallows from their markets that use fish gelatin.  These are the best for real roasting over a campfire or any recipe that calls for marshmallows.

For those having trouble finding the downloadable guide, you need to add a / at the end of pinpoint massager. They didn't write it on the directions. So http://downloads.gaiam.com/pinpointmassager/  Unfortunately, that just got me a picture of basically six ways to use it on different body parts, but no real directions.  So try Google or Youtube for videos/guides on how to use the Backnobber or Body Back Buddy.I used to have something called a Backnobber, which I loved, as well as one other variation.  There's also something called a Body Back Buddy, which is even more versatile, as well as the TheraCane.  I was a massage therapist for 10 years, and it was wonderful.  This is similar in design, but it doesn't have as many knobs/variations as the Body Back Buddy...or even the Backnobber.  The premise is the same, and it if you press/pull it in a certain way, you can put pressure on your trigger points/sore points.  To me, it's especially great for the rhomboids (area in between the shoulder blades).  If you'd like to get an idea what it would feel like, have a friend use the eraser side of a pencil to press around the outline and underneath your shoulder blade.  You can pop your shoulder out more by putting your hand behind your back (For your left side, think of it making like a 4 shape with your elbow being the western point of the four and your open hand resting in the middle of your back.)I love the idea of this, but I think other companies have done better jobs.  For a few more dollars, you can get a TheraCane or Body Back Buddy.

We were given this one and the 6-7 grade one to review.  It's really well done.  My 4th grader is the type who only does the minimum required work. (Write a paragraph with five sentences? You will get exactly five sentences.)  Still, even he was fine with the amount of work each day.  They include character development as well as each month focusing on a different fitness goals.  There are flash cards in the back--some are good (IMHO...like the vocab), but the math to me are hit or miss.  Still, my guess is if you can get your kids to do this one page per day, they won't have as much brain drain as their peers over the summer.  My son took less than 10 minutes to do one page.  I think this was right on the money in terms of level...not too hard, not too easy.

This was intended for my 9 and 11 year old sons to try, but my 40+ year old husband got it first.  It is fun for boys of all ages.  You don't need to use the stickers at first, you can just shoot it like normal Nerf darts.  It's a slide-action type gun...and the air propels the darts forward.  They really do go far.  Eventually, my 9 and 11 year old got a chance and enjoyed it too.  Next stop, is to look for a multipack so all the boys can play.

I have both the 6-7 and 4-5 books.  I like them.  They are divided into three different months.  Each day has about a one page day of activities.  It also talks about fitness, which each month having a theme.  Month one is flexibility; month two is strength; month three is endurance.  My son is in 5th grade going into 6th grade, and this is definitely his level, so I'm not sure if one should buy a grade ahead or not.  In the back are vocabulary cards, some analogy cards (not sure why these are flash cards), and some math problems.  It won't be too hard to get your kids to do one page, but it will help them avoid the summer brain drain hopefully. :)Our summer break is not quite three full-months, so I'm not sure if we'll double up some days or just end when we do.

We moved into a two story 2500 square foot home.  Our router is located upstairs, and we noticed that there wasn't good reception downstairs.  So, we plugged in the Linksys Range Extender downstairs.  It really does make a difference.  One other thing that helped was changing our modem to the 5GHz setting, which is not used as much (at least in our neighborhood area).

This was a really wonderful "real" book.  I read it in one day.  The book is about five women who meet because they are married to sex addicts.  I think anybody who has been married or had an unfaithful partner can relate a lot to what is said in therapy and the struggles these women (and their partners face.) The book had a few totally unexpected turns--both regarding a mentor as well as at the end.  Without revealing any spoilers,  the two characters I related most to were Gail and Hannah.  Gail is a well-respected judge whose husband Jonah is a professor at Harvard.  Hannah is married to an architect and has two children.  Her husband is gay.  Other group members include Bridget who is a nurse and married to Michael, Lizzie the teacher whose husband likes to watch porn, and Flavia whose husband Demetrius was caught on the Tube (subway) groping women.Only negatives would be that the ending kind of left you hanging (perhaps designed for a potential sequel?), and it was weird how some group members conveniently disappeared.  It was almost like the author wasn't sure what to do with their stories.

I've been receiving Mike Dooley's emails from The Universe for a few years now.  They always brighten my day and make me think, so I was really looking forward to this book.  One of my favorite bits was the letters at the end of each chapter.  Basically, to reiterate the point of that chapter, there's a letter from a loved one who has died back to people on Earth.  There were many good reminders, things I've heard from other people in talking about NDEs or other teachings--but some things were new.  Not sure I buy all the new thought/if you dream it, you can have it type stuff, although I know that's popular right now.  In general, though, I've enjoyed books from people who've had NDEs more....although I think Mike's letters at the end were good.  Points on love being important and forgiveness being important--definitely spot on.

This translation was the recommended one to use for a course I'm taking on the Juz Amma (last part of the Qur'an).  I like the size/binding of this Qur'an.  It kind of reminds me of a Bible, in that it has a leatherish cover and is of similar size.  I love the translation...and all of the notes/discussions.  My one complaint is the size of the Arabic.  It is very very small.  I understand that they wanted to make the English larger and easier to read, but given how small the Arabic is, I'm not sure why they included it all.  Having the Arabic there means one must treat it differently than an English-only copy, and yet the Arabic itself is almost useless.  I hope they will come out with future editions that have larger Arabic (while keeping a similar size English).

A sample lady at Target got me hooked on this stuff, and then they had the nerve to be out! :)  So, I came to Amazon to fulfill my need for Larabar chocolate coconut granola.  It is so freakin' good.  I've been GF seriously for the past year, and one of my kids has issues.  This has become Mom's secret treat.  It's too expensive and good to share.  Yum.  Just wish it was a little cheaper, or I could figure out my own recipe.

At first, I didn't like this book mainly because of the switching authors bit.  But, I got used to that.  I'm not sure why I ordered it, actually, as I didn't think I had a problem with saying "no".  But I did.  It was the exercises that helped me realize it.  IMHO, they are the value in the bookmore than the stories/authors' experiences.  While those are valuable too, it's doing the work on yourself that will really lead to change.  It can be really tempting for me with self-help books to rush throughto finishto try and get the secret, so to speak.  I really tried with "The Power of No" to slow downand I think it made a big difference.
This was a great replacement for my OEM Apple iPad cord.  It works greatand I can finally sit on my bed and charge my iPad at the same time.  Great, fast shipping too.

We got this for my four year old's birthday.  It's been a big hit with everybody in the family, as well as my daughter's Brownie troop.  The game comes with a wide variety of objects to find in Ned's headplus nine (I think) blank cards so you can add your own objects.

These are awesome.  Got them for the goodie bags for my 4 year old's birthday.  They are smaller than the rockets you see at Chuck E Cheesesbut because of that, the rockets really zoom.  Each rocket came with two darts.  They were individually packaged. Great deal!

We got this to use for a Brownie (Girl Scout) passport project.  The girls had great fun stamping their passportsand everything else.  It took me awhile to figure out the date, thoughit's backwardsso you can't really see what date you are setting.  Still, lots of fun once you figure that out.  (For me, it was via trial and error.)

I enjoyed Jane Isay's book, "Secrets and Lies."  I wasn't familiar with her story, or her husband's story.but without giving a lot away, just say that it rang true to me.  She gives examples throughout the book of different secrets and lies that families keepand how that impacts people.  She also shares from her own life.  I think what I was expecting, though, is more information on how to deal with things if you're one of the people from whom the truth has been kept.  I didn't really glean a lot of advice in that regard.  She's not a psychiatrist or psychologist, so perhaps that's why she limited herself to telling her own and others' stories.  Still, I enjoyed her book and it reinforced to me how damaging secrets, lies, and omissions can be.

This came up on an Amazon list for me because I've been reading a lot about death midwifery.  I need to warn you that it is a little disturbing to read.  There are things in there I never knew about...and like most Americans, probably never wanted to know.  Still, I'm glad I did read it.  It's not a hard read.  Caitlin is a wonderful, engaging writer. I love how she shared death rituals from other time periods and cultures throughout the book.  She does paint some disturbing word pictures, though--and yet, I came away from the book believing that she and her coworkers truly cared about the people they took care of.  Yes, it was a job, but they tried to maintain the dead person's dignity.  One thing this does do, quite effectively, is think how you want yourself and your loved ones' bodies to be handled in death.  As a plump woman, I'm not so sure I want to go through cremation now... at least not at a crematorium with a brand new "floor" in the ovens.  I definitely have no desire for embalmment.  And I think I'll hold off on that one last viewing.  This book is recommended, but with a warning of some gory details.Thanks Caitlin, for an entertaining/disturbing read, that caused me to think about things I never knew existed.

As somebody who lives only a few hours from Sarasota, I really enjoyed this Amish fiction book set in Pinecraft.  I've read a few Amish novels that feature a family that go on vacation in Pinecraft, but this is the first I remember that has 95% of the story take place thereas well as so many real Pinecraft places like Yoder's, Big Olaf's, and even Emma's Pizza.  Even the character of Imogene is a lot like Katie Troyer and her Pinecraft Sarasota blog. While there are other story lines which feature an Amish widow or widower with young children, this was the first I've read that featured a non-Amish circus performer as the female lead.  While you might think there's no way that can work, it really does.  (I don't want to give away too much.)  It also featured some faith struggles regarding salvation and the Amish belief of being sure of one's salvation would be a sign of pride as interesting.  Highly recommended.

With two/four kids having gluten issues plus one adult, it's usually easier to just make everything gluten-free at home.  Problem is, the gluten free kids are new enough that they'll complain if it doesn't taste "normal" as well the non-gluten free kids.  Pamela's baking and pancake mix makes awesome pancakes that everybody likes.  We usually add in a mashed banana and chocolate chips, and make it with milk instead of water (no dairy issues).  It's a winner.  I usually make a triple batch so I'll have some to freeze for busy mornings.  Happily you can try a small bag at Target and a lot of major grocery chains, and then come on Amazon to buy in bulk.

I was really pleasantly surprised by Serena Dyer's "Don't Die with Your Music Still in You."  I've seen her Dad on PBS many times, and actually own a few of his children's books for my kids.  Still, I didn't know what to expect from her book, as honestly, I've never heard of her.  Well, I picked the book up and couldn't put it down.  Not only that, I actually got out the Post-It notes.  For me, it's a rare book that requires me to either use Post-It notes to mark favorite pagesor even more rare, copy passages on the Post-It note to put on a mirror or 'fridge.  I found myself doing both with Serena's book.  It was wonderful hearing stories about how she was raised (seems like her Dad and Mom are quite authentic), as well as her interpretations/life lessons learned.  Highly recommended.  I hope she writes more.

I've never tried a stevia blend, and was pleasantly surprised by this.  I usually think the best way to try out a product is by using the recipe on the back of the box/bag, so I decided to make chocolate chip cookies. I did not have any molasses (as required by the recipe to make brown sugar/stevia), so I used my regular recipe, only subbing in 1/4 cup of the Sweet and Lite for my normal white sugar.  Not only did the raw dough taste great and pass the kid test, so did the baked cookies.  Granted, they only were about 1/4 steviabut still, it was a good way to subtly reduce the sugar without anybody knowing.  I'm going to experiment some more in other recipes as well.  Really happily surprised by this.

I haven't used a dedicated label maker in 20+ years, so I'm way behind the curve.  Now, I'm wondering why not?? This worked great with my MacBook Pro.  We recently moved, and this was great in trying to organize the pantry, office, and my kids rooms.  If I hadn't had it, I probably would have either not labeled stuff or gone for the sticky note option. Things look much better.  Too hard to organize labels on the Avery sheets, when every one will be different.  Brother saves the day.Only issue is the cost of the label tapebut as this isn't something I'll be doing daily, I figure it's worth the cost.  I need to check out Costco and see if they carry the labels any cheaper.

We moved to a temporary apartment which is all tile.  All tile!  Sweeping is just too cumbersome. This little vacuum works great.  It's lightweight, and has good suction. I love that it's bag less.  Really worth it if you have a lot of hardwood floors or tile to clean.I'd try it out on some carpet, but for the next 2 months, we're carpet freeso hopefully I'll come back and update my review. (Even though it's made for hard floors.)Updating a year later, and adding a star:  Now, we're in a two story house that has tons of wood floors.  I love this vacuum 100x more. :)  It has continued to perform awesomely.  It's so light that I can easily use it on our wooden (well, laminated wood...type you use Bona for) stairs.  Works well on our area rugs too.  Quite happy with this Bissell.

I'm on my fourth child, and we've had many Melissa and Doug puzzles that have held up through four kids.  What we do is to store the pieces in a ziplock gallon baggie next to the boardand then put all the puzzles together in a bin with a lid.  That keeps them from getting lost.  The puzzles are thick woodgood qualityand last.  My son loved this vehicle one.  It's good for about an 18 month to 2-1/2 year old.

I've been thinking about getting a bike rack as we have four kids and lots of bikes, but hadn't made the plunge yet as I thought it involved getting one professionally installed.  When I saw this come up on Amazon Prime (yes, I get to try this out for a review), I decided to give it a try.  I'm a 45 year old woman, who is not that mechanical (although I can follow Ikea directions to put together furniture), so I was wondering if this was something I could figure out, or if it would require my husband.  I was able to install it on our Honda Odyssey minivan without trouble.  We put the little kids' bikes in the trunk, and put my adult bike on the rack (this holds one bike, but there are other models that hold more).  It held it quite well for going to the park and back.  It also worked quite well for a longer drive of about two hours.  It fits nicely in the trunk for emergencies, like picking up my son and his bike at a friends house because of rain or whatever.  I'm assuming it's not as secure as a permanent bike rack, but then again, we need a rack only about once per month.  I predict as the kids and their bikes grow, we'll move to a larger capacity rack.  It was a good starter rack for people who aren't sure how often they'd really need a bike rack.  I do wish we'd gotten a larger capacity one, just in caseso I would recommend getting one for at least 2-bikes.  I think it's a great introduction.  I noticed no damage to the car/paint because of the rack (or the bikes on it).

In general, I'm really disappointed by pre-made First Aid kids.  They usually have substandard suppliesnot enoughand are overpriced.  This falls in line with those.  It's much easier to put together your own by going to a big box store or buying stuff on Amazon.  But the thing ismost people won't.  This is a good kid for our minivanand I'm glad to have it.  I'm also glad I didn't pay anything for it, although the box is fine. :)The addition of eyewash is nice, but honestly, as somebody married to an ophthalmologist, there probably isn't enough to really do the job and a small bottle of water (distilled if you can get it) or contact lens saline solution would offer more volume and do the job just as well.One nice thing about Amazon is that you can find really good quality medical supplies for not very much money. If you're looking for what to put in it, check out the Red Cross or another disaster or survival website. But here's my suggestions:Rather than buying individual packets of antibiotic ointment or cortisone, just pick up a store-brand tube of each.Buy a box of Band-Aids, assorted sizes.Pick up a good pair of tweezers (Amazon sells great ones designed to remove splinters.) Include an ACE Bandgage, some rolls of gauze and non-stick gauze pads, a pack of steristrips, a roll of paper tape.Throw in a bottle of chewable aspirin, a bottle of ibuprofen or acetaminophen, and an anti-diarrheal like Lotramin.Can include a space blanket if it's going in your car or for camping.If you're on meds, include some.If you can get an Rx, include an Epi-pen.Need a snazzy case? Pick up a nice toolbox or even a plastic box with a lid at the dollar store.

I didn't know Umm Zakiyyah had come out with some new books since the "If I Should Speak" trilogy, so I was happy to stumble across this in the Kindle store.  It's the story of a young American girl who moved to Saudi Arabia with her mother when she was nine, and has now moved back to the states.  She must face the trials of do I want to be "visibly" Muslim or do I want to be "normal."  Even older Muslims can relate to that as a struggle, and it's something that our kids will definitely go through as well, so it's a good read.  I enjoyed it tremendously, but wished it had been flushed out more.  It's a quick readand like all of her books, ends too soon! Would have loved to hear more from the character Anisa (Inaya's Mom's friend), as well as hear more about Nasra.  I'm hoping that there's a sequel in the works. :)I've been Muslim for 15+ years.  Like many, some days/years are easier than other.  One thing I've found is that Umm Zakiyyah's fiction is always inspirational.  I always take away something that helps me.  Jazakh'Allah Sister for that.  I've also recently discovered her Facebook page, which I enjoy following.

I work part-time for an organization that deals with family violence.  Reading about other people's experiences on blogs, etc. can be so healing. You are not alone.  You did nothing wrong.  You need to hear that over and over again.  Having the luxury of an entire book is just wonderful.  While you can find many survivor stories online, it's really nice to have an entire book to pass on to somebody.especially somebody who might not always have easy internet access (or whose access may be monitored).  The book is a normal sized paperback which can be kept in a purse.  Really grateful for this collection.  National DV Hotline is 1-800-799-SAFE. Please take a moment to memorize this so you can share it should somebody ever need it.

My sons and their Dad have had so much fun playing with this at the park.  We've had it over a month now, and it's still the go-to "Mom, is the bow and arrow in the car" toy.  I really have nothing negative to say.  It's great fun and my younger son can use it with no problems.  The arrows have got stuck in the trees a few times, but are easy to get down with a broom or by throwing something.Highly recommended!

I'm not even sure how we found out about this (Amazon led me to it), but I'm so glad we did.  I bought it hoping it would be good for Eid/Ramadan type crafts.  What I didn't expect was that my kids (10, 8, 6, and 3) would open up the book and start finding crafts they wanted to do on their own.  We've had this book about two weeks now, and they still keep going to it.  Really well done.  Clear instructions.  Highly highly recommended.  Would be a great resource for weekend Islamic school too.

I bought this for my 10 and 8 year old who are major Lego Chima fans. I had seen it come home in the Scholastic magazine for my third grader, so I thought it would be at his level.  It was very hard for him to do such complicated drawings. I think they could have simplified them or made them easier for this age group.  We got a similar book on drawing Pokemon at the same time, which was far easier for them to follow.

Wow. I'm so so glad that I picked this up.  It's one of those books that will stay with you a very long time.  I've grown more and more interested in the history of the feminine divine (if you haven't seen the BBC documentary "When God was a Girl", check out Youtube.)  This book brings you a few familiar and not so familiar stories from the Bible told in a different way.  I instantly recognized the story of Abraham/Ibraham, Sarah, and Hagarbut the others were not as clear to me.  Still, I enjoyed them tremendously.  I was, however, left with a sort of sadness at how crappy, in general, women's lives have been and are still in many parts of the world.  There is such a longing for us to see ourselves in the divine, because that is a form of validation.  Highly recommended.  And if you have daughters, pick up Trista Hendren's "The Girl God" and "Mother Earth."

I'm not familiar with Ms. Greiner, nor do I watch "Shark Tank", so this book was a nice surprise to me. Oh, how I wished I had this 10 years ago when I was trying to bring a product to market.  She really does cover so much.  In reading this, it hit me that this would be a great book for parents trying to encourage entrepreneurship in their high school kids.  I think the key point is that "anyone can have the next big idea, but not anyone can bring it to market." (paraphrasing)  It takes a certain skill.  And with this guidebook, I think you increase your likelihood of doing so by 500%.  I have an MBA from a top program. I worked for a Fortune 50 company.  Neither of those gave me the hands-on skills/knowledge necessary to bring a product to market on my own.  This book does.  Highly recommended.  Love that she addresses crowd funding, shopping channels, and social media too.  Everything is well presented, with key questions to ask/answer.  I also highly recommend checking out your local SCORE group for business mentoring.  Good luck!

3-1/2 stars. I've been doing Pilates for the past 25+ years.  I recently bought a new reformer, so was happy to see how comprehensive this book is in covering the various apparatuses and mat work.  Of course nothing replaces in person classes, but I think having a book like this as a reference if you use DVDs mainly is a great idea.  I love the imagery bit for each exercise.  I think she provides very clear instruction.  My one complaint is that Rael doesn't offer any modification information on the mat work to meet the needs of a wide variety of exercisers.  Very few can start right off and do all of the exercises the way they are meant to be.  While a few variations to make the exercises more difficult are given, none are given to make them easier.  That is a serious miss in my book.  It's great in its range of exercises covered, but lacking in providing really good instruction for every exerciser for each exercise. But, I do think she should have covered more modifications.  Pilates really is for everybody--not just professional dancers or those who are already fit.  If you don't think you'll need the modifications or are perhaps a Pilates teacher or what not, then you'll probably love this book and would rate it 5 stars.  For me, I've seen too many people who do need modifications of some sort...especially at first.

This is a wonderful gentle class, far more gentle than other plus-size yoga DVDs I have.  Still, don't discount it.  There is a wonderful, long sequence of hip openers and stretches which I adore.  She does what appears to be a modified moon salutation which is a nice change from the usual sun salutations.  Abby uses both American and sanskrit names for poses.  I love how Abby offers positive affirmations/encouragements throughout.  I wish the relaxation bit at the end had been more along the lines of a guided relaxation.  Still, I enjoyed the class and will add this into my rotation.

I discovered headlamps about a year ago when my sons were going on a Cub Scout camping trip.  Not sure how we've lived without them.  They are great for camping, for kids who like to read in bed, and for emergency kits.  We keep one in the car in case there's a tire to change late and night.  We have a few set aside in our hurricane kit.  My eldest used this on a Webelos camping trip and loved it.  He said the band was much more comfortable than the other headlamp we have.  Light is super bright.  Batteries are still going strong.

This works amazing. It's like the best pedicure I've ever had in terms of taking care of dry, excess skin.  I didn't even have to charge it first to use it I just plugged it in and went to town.  My came with only two rollers, but I've seen other packages which have more, so you might want to look for those.  I got this for myself and one for my Mom for Mother's Day.  Best gift ever. :)  Puts other foot files, pedi eggs, and the like to shame.

Like many, I've read a lot about Anastasia. I remember the film with Ingrid Bergman.  I remember all the talk about Anna Anderson.  Well, as the author points out, hypotheses about whether or not one or more Romanov daughter survived have been put to rest by DNA evidence found a few years back.  Still, I find their story fascinating.  I was given a chance to review an early copy of this book as part of Amazon vine.  This book is extremely well researched and well done.  The author is a historian, writer, and Russianist who has written about the deaths in her book, "Ekaterinaberg", as well as about Queen Victoria in "Magnificent Obsession" and "Queen Victoria".  Because of her extensive knowledge, she really makes the girls and their life come alive. What surprised me most was how much I felt for the Tsarina. A few chapters are spent on her upbringing in Germany, and early marriage to Nicholas.  She really had a dream marriage compared to Queen Victoria's other grandchildren and most royals.  A marriage where she was truly loved.  Thing is, none of them seemed meant for the life of a ruling Tsar/Tsarina.  They seem like they would have much happier had Nicholas been a younger brother--and they had lived their life out of the spotlight.  While I thought I'd become intrigued with one of the daughters, I actually found Alexandra the most interesting "character."  Rasputin (cue Boney M song) is of course mentioned, but still the focus of the book really is the girls. In reading the book, I found I could never divorce myself of knowing their fate.  I also could not forget all the things that happened during Nicholas's reign, such as the pogroms and such.  It was a weird phenomenon, kind of like reading about somebody getting on the Titanic.Still, the book focuses mainly on the girls (Olga, Tatiana, Anastasia, and Maria).  You feel for Alexandra as she gives birth to daughter after daughter.  Yet they were well-loved and cherished by both of their parents.  You rejoice at the birth of the tsarivich, even though you know about his hemophilia.  The girls to me, come across, as just really nice, slightly sheltered girls.  Normal girls, really. You learn about the girls' upbringing, governesses, even their toys.  Sounds like they had a wonderful happy childhood.  Their parents (or perhaps it was the time as well) kept them secluded as well.  Still, these were teen girls, growing up, having crushes--being teens.  I did not know about OTA training as nurses during WWI.  Still, it did nothing to save the family from their fate.  You want to hope that each will find a nice Duke or something to marry, but you know the truth.  You want George V to sweep in, grant the family refuge, and save the day.  It never happens.  History is not rewritten.Not a lot of attention was paid to politics going on outside that lead to the abdication and death of the family.  While I appreciated that (as that might have dragged the story away from the girls and family), the book seems insulated from reality a bit just like they were.  I don't think we get an idea just how bad things were, which was perhaps for the best, and really fitting for the book.  The entire royal family was extremely isolated from St. Petersburg society.  Alexandra and Nicholas kept their daughters isolated too (although there's almost a disconnect with how they cavort with some soldiers.)  The book was meticulously researched and the author weaves in quotes from their diaries into the book with ease.  I finished the book feeling enormously sad that four lovely and harmless girls met such a fate.  Actually sad for their whole family.

Back when I had braces and a retainer, the advice of my orthodontist was to clean it every week or so using a denture cleaning tablet.  Seeing that these are made by Efferdent, I'm assuming that they are capitalizing on that.  I wear a bite guard for teeth grinding.  (I actually bought my latest one from Amazon by SportingSmiles instead of buying a $400 replacement from my dentist.)  Everyday, I brush it with toothpaste--but that's about it.  I clean the case, but I haven't used a denture cleaner tablet or anything similar.  So, I was curious as to how much of a difference this would make.It comes in little thin packets, kind of like the kind you open to add flavor to a water bottle.  You put your guard/retainer in a clean cup with warm water to cover, and then add the packet. The water automatically turns blue, and after 5 or so minutes, the water will be clear and you can remove and rinse your appliance.  It really did a  good job in that my bite guard felt so clean when I put it on, but the water mixture smelled horrific.  So take that as a warning.  It did not, however, make my appliance taste bad.I will use this about once/week.  I will buy more.  I can't comment as to whether it does a different/better job though to regular denture cleaning tablets.

To be honest, I first picked up this book because I had done well with my investment in Southern Company.  The second reason is that I used to be in corporate America, but had left--and am now in the process of starting my own business. Oh how I wish I had this book 15 years ago when I graduated for B-school.  Thing is, it still applies. So much here applies not only to women who want to succeed in the C-suite, but also women who want to succeed in politics or in their own businesses.  I also found her experience of actually being a better leader in a field that wasn't your expertise to be true in my case as well.  I remember having a discussion with a good friend about accepting a big step up to Senior VP at a Fortune 500 company.  She didn't know if she was ready for the spot, and I said, "of course you are."  We talked about all of her experience, her skills, and thennear the endI mentioned a few men we had worked with, and I said, "they wouldn't even hesitate one second"that's the difference.  She did take the job, and has excelledbut the truth remains.  It's not a "Leaning In' that many women face, it's that we doubt ourselves.  We dare to try.  Think of all the bozos in Congress.  There are easily women who could do a better job, but they never try.  That's why this book is so important.  It inspires you to Dare to try.  Dare to reach.  Dare to fail.  It was a great boost to me as I work on my business plan.  Why shouldn't I succeed?  Highly highly recommended.

I was so excited when I saw Barilla had released a GF pasta. I've used Barilla products since when I was a student in France, and have been a fan.  I have gluten sensitivity as do some of my kids, and we've gradually transitioned many products.  For pasta, I've been using Ancient Harvest Quinoa Organic Pasta Gluten Free, Elbows, 8-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 12) this, which we buy at Costco. It's expensive though.  The Barilla worked great...and nobody had any ill effects after.  I used it to make macarona bchamel, which is an Egyptian version of pastito.I'm adding this to my list of favorite GF products, along with Blanched Almond Meal Flour, 5 lb. (1 Pack), Betty Crocker Gluten Free Brownie Mix, 16-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 6), and Bob's Red Mill Gluten Free Whole Grain, Rolled Oats, 32-Ounce Bags (Pack of 4).

Years ago, Biore had a different self-heating masque that I loved.  I remember using it, and I swear that it stayed hotter longer. (I think you could add in more water, which would make the reaction last longer). They discontinued it, and I was so upset.  A few years ago, they had a self-heating cleanser which I loved too.  Can't find it.  Then, a few years ago, I bought an Olay facial brush and it came with a sample of a heating cleanser/exfoliater, which I loved.  Unfortunately, I can't find it anymore, so I was so excited to try this.  It looks like a normal mud masque (dark grey in color), but a little thinner.  Unfortunately, the heat effect really last barely a minute.  I think if they could change it to last 5 minutes, it would be a total win.  The one minute is just too short.  I like itbut it has a ways to go yet.

I have four kids, ages 10, 8, 6, and 3 who love my iPad.  They've played with it and dropped it so much that the wi-fi only works if I'm super close to the router.  The eldest is home schooled and goes through a book a day.  He's a fast reader.  Purchasing this for them was the best thing I've bought in a long time.  The FreeTime app with the subscription makes it an incredible buy.  The content is spot-onincluding an interactive potty chart for my 3 year old.  It's held up to a lot of abuse, and still works great.  Well worth the $139.
