Your previous knowledge of the sports events he is describing will go a long way in gauging your enjoyment of each little jaunt.However, despite that interesting/inventive format, I couldn't ever bring myself to really enjoy this book because it was so bleak on the prospect of parenting (especially a first child).  I will fully admit that, having no children of my own, I can't directly identify with Wilker's experiences, but he almost seems depressed at times and really struggling to cope.  Instead of "laughing along with him", which is what the book tries to get the reader to do, I more just felt sorry for him.  At first, I thought that Wilker was just using a lot of self-deprecating humor, but as the book continued on the same tone I realized that this was not the case.  He seemed to literally be struggling that much, and that made me more sad than anything.Thus, although I did appreciate some of the humor in this book, there were too many times when I almost didn't want to pick it up because it got so depressing for me.  I just didn't want to read anymore about a man struggling with heavy, heavy issues...and then trying to comically relate that to sports scenarios.  Maybe I'm just taking the text too seriously or mis-reading the tone, but I wanted a "message of hope" at least somewhere in the text.  I never got it, and thus I didn't enjoy the overall experience.

Most of the books in the "Chronicles of Narnia" series have an epic sense to them.  In "Voyage of the Dawn Treader", however, that epic feel is set aside for plain, simple adventuring.For a basic plot summary, "Dawn Treader" sees Edumund, Lucy, and cousin Eustace pulled into a painting that turns into Narnia.  They arrive smack dab in the middle of a seafaring quest to the ends of the Narnian world, led by Caspian (as well as the plucky Reepicheep).  As the Treader sails on and on, the crew encounter a number of strange phenomena in their quest to reach "Aslan's country" at the end of the world.As a child, I remembered this book being easily my favorite.  I can see why, as it is light on allegory and heavy on plain child-enticing adventuring.  There are dragons, wizards, spooky places, sea creatures, and more!  Rarely are there even pauses for reflection.  Instead, the action is always driving forward in this one.From an adult perspective, this one might not quite hold up.  It doesn't have quite that same "newness" as "Lion, Witch, Wardrobe", nor does it have the gravitas of even, say, a "Prince Caspian", despite being a better overall book.  Simply put, "Dawn Treader" is much more structured for the mind and energy of a child.Overall, I enjoyed the rollicking fun of this novel.  It isn't my favorite in the series anymore, but I can see why "childhood me" was swept away by it.

Sometimes, a movie only needs a great idea and a great actor to be really, really good.  "The Terminal" is an example of that kind of film making.  There are a number of things that prevent "The Terminal" from being an all-time classic, but the performance from Tom Hanks and the "guy trapped in an airport" premise is enough to make for a very entertaining movie.For a basic plot summary, this film focuses on Viktor Novorski (Hanks), who is trying to get from his home country of Krakosau into the United States (New York City, to be exact).  On the international trip, however, Krakosau is over-run by rebels and no longer recognized by the U.S. government.  As a result, Novorski cannot return home, nor can he legally enter America.  He is "trapped" in the airport terminal, waiting for something to happen.  Not helping matters is that airport director Frank Dixon (Stanley Tucci) has it out for Viktor.  While patiently waiting for a resolution to his situation, Viktor meets a number of friends, including a potential romantic interest (Catherine Zeta-Jones), a woman he greets every day trying to get his status validated (Zoe Saldana), and a number of other airport workers who help him be as comfortable as possible in such a strange situation."The Terminal" is a charming movie mainly because you'll probably never watch a film quite like it.  Under the able direction of Steven Spielberg, the movie succeeds in taking a ludicrous situation and making you care about a majority of the proceedings.  Of course, it helps to have Hanks in the drivers seat of the leading role, as he turns in yet another performance that will make you think "this can can play anything!".  Without his presence, this would be a forgettable experience.Unfortunately, "The Terminal" is completely and utterly unable to capture any romantic chemistry between the Hanks & Zeta-Jones characters.  For whatever reason (likely because Zeta-Jones just simply isn't around enough), the emotional backbone of the movie fizzles.  For me, this was enough to drop the experience an entire star rating.  Had the romance angle been done better, it would have easily been five stars.  As it was, there were just too many moments towards the end of the film where I was thinking "I know I SHOULD be wrapped up in these emotions more, but..." instead of just enjoying the experience.Overall, though, "The Terminal" is a quirky, entertaining little flick that really emphasizes the "less is more" philosophy of making a solid cinematic experience.  In this case, all it took was a great idea and a great actor.  With those components given to Mr. Spielberg, he was able to work his magic (sans a believable romance) with the rest.

On the surface, "Nightcrawler" is a very well-made film.  The production value is high, the visuals are great, acting is solid, and it delves into a number of very relevant themes regarding journalism and TV news.  The problem, however, is that director Dan Gilroy doesn't pause nearly enough to examine the really interesting parts of the film.  Instead, everything in the movie is kind of viewed in the abstract...with very little (and thus I would argue not nearly enough) context given in order to make it a truly great piece of film-making.For a basic plot summary, "Nightcrawler" sees Louis Bloom (Jake Gyllenhaal) trying desperately to find a job in a rough economy.  One night, he stumbles upon a crime scene and meets Joe Loder (Bill Paxton), an independent TV news cameraman who impresses Louis with his ability to "do the dirty work" and get paid handsomely for it.  So, Louis decides to get into the TV journalism business himself, even doing well enough to hire a partner in Rick (Riz Ahmed).  Along the way, Louis also develops a relationship (that some might considere inappropriate) with head news director Nina Romina (Rene Russo).  Things seem to be going great for Louis and his thriving business...until the night he arrives at a burglary scene before the police, making a number of choices leading him down a shady ethical path that he may or may not recover from.Easily the two most interesting parts of this film are Gyllenhaal's Louis and the movie's examination of the TV news business.  Both of those subjects carry very weighty, relevant themes in today's society and are worthy of examination.  Unfortunately, both are also just kind of glossed over in favor of "the spectacle" in this case.Louis is one of the strangest characters I've ever seen on the big screen (done to perfection, as usual, by the underrated Gyllenhaal).  On one hand, you can kind of feel sorry for him, as he never seems to catch a break early on.  On the other hand, he is such a smarmy individual that he is far from like-able.  Usually I like this kind of ambiguity in my film characters, but in this case it comes off more as confusing than interesting.  At the end of flick, I didn't feel like I cared any more about Louis than I did, oh, 20 or so minutes in.As for the many themes regarding televised news, I really wish the pace of the film would have allowed even more examination of them.  There is a character in the newsroom (played by Kevin Rahm) who always bring up the ethical issues of what is transpiring, but he is quickly pushed aside each and every time.  Perhaps that is a statement being made in and of itself, but I still feel like the movie wanted us (as viewers) to take a few too many things at face value.  I wanted to see the principals struggle a bit regarding their decisions.  There just didn't seem to be any conflict in what was happening.Overall, though, "Nightcrawler" isn't a bad movie by any stretch of the imagination.  In my mind, it is the complete and utter personification of a "three star effort", as it easily did enough to hold my interest, yet didn't do anything more to really make me care in the end.  To me, this was very much a "take it or leave it" experience.  Had some closer examination of themes/characters taken place, I think it could have been much, much more interesting.

While I had enjoyed the previous (first) season of "Hannibal", there were a few things that prevented me from giving it five-star billing (mainly, a number of "procedural" episodes that seemed a bit like time-fillers).  With the basic premise of the show now set, however, this second season becomes a tour de force, with not a moment of "wasted space" or downtime whatsoever.(Minor spoilers ahead)For Will Graham (Hugh Dancy), this season is all about redemption.  As the season opens, Will is in the Baltimore psychiatric facility, being suspected as the Chesapeake Ripper after his mind has been completely manipulated by therapist Hannibal Lector (Mads Mikkelsen).  Of course, we (the viewers) know that Hannibal is to blame all along, so that knowledge only further intensifies Will's quest to prove his innocence.  Jack Crawford (Laurence Fishburne) and Dr. Alana Bloom (Caroline Dhavernas) are stupefied by this strange turn of events, while Dr. Frederick Chilton (Raul Esparza) tries to play both sides in his quest for glory.  Even Hannibal's old shrink, Dr. De Maurier (Gillian Anderson) cannot helped but be roped back into the action.To give you an example of the type of energy this season provides, consider this: the first scene of the season gives glimpses of a furious brawl between Hannibal and Jack Crawford.  Obviously, something has come to a head.  Yet, without any resolution or reasons why the confrontation happened, the action abruptly jumps back in time to slowly, over the course of the season, "fill in the details".  Essentially, it's a flash in the pan, followed by a slow burn to reach that point again.By this point in the show, all the characters have really found themselves and turn in consistently great performances.  There are even some extraordinary "OMG" moments that rival anything I've ever seen in a televised drama (and a network one at that).  Gone are the days, most certainly, when the show couldn't (or wouldn't) decide exactly what it wanted to be (waffling between charge-ahead drama and pace-conscious procedural).  Now, each episode is back to the gills with action, drama, and character development.Sadly, this season of "Hannibal" still proved to be a ratings disappointment.  Perhaps the graphic content (on a network) has something to do with that, or maybe people just don't want to take the time to understand the often thought-provoking actions behind the show's drama.  Either way, it's still a little tough to believe that the show may very quickly have an ax over its head, as it is so clear that series creator Bryan Fuller is producing a show of the utmost quality here.Thus, with this incredible second season, "Hannibal" easily made the jump onto my "favorite shows not to be missed" list.  A third season is scheduled to begin in the summer of 2015, and I hope the new change of scenery (the previous two installments were spring airings) provides a bit of a ratings boost to keep this deserving little gem afloat.

When I first heard that Vince Gilligan was working on Breaking Bad spinoff "Better Call Saul", I dismissed it as an oddly-conceived cash grab for AMC.  I mean, seriously...a show all about Saul Goodman?  Nah, that'll never work...right?  But then, something a bit strange happened: All the pre-show reviews/buzz gave it incredibly high marks.  It got picked up for a second season before the pilot even aired!  All of that being said, I settled in to watch that opening episode with very low expectations.  10 episodes later, I was amazed by the quality of the show and the continued genius of its creators.  If only I could figure out what the heck kind of a show it is (or wants to be)!The basic premise of "Better Call Saul" sees Jimmy McGill (Bob Odenkirk), essentially a con-man, trying to make it in public law defense while running schemes on the side.  He's got a cramped office (in the back of a salon owned by a number of Asian women), crashes with brother Chuck (Michael McKean), a once-great lawyer who Jimmy reveres, but now has some sort of strange sensitivity to electronics (or is it all just in his head?), and seems to have very little future.  He is connected to the law firm managed by Howard Hamlin (Patrick Fabian), primarily through a female friend Kim Wexler (Rhea Seehorn), but doesn't seem to be too well-received around the place.  Oh yes, and let's not forget...the "ticket-taker" parking lot attendant just happens to be a stone-faced figure named Mike Ehrmantraut (Jonathan Banks).It's very tough for me to describe a show like "Better Call Saul", because to be honest, I've never quite seen a show like it.  Whereas some TV shows produce serial episodes (like Breaking Bad did) and others take a more "plot of the week approach" (think Person Of Interest in its most basic form), this show manages to do both at the exact same time.  Each episode is about something almost completely different than the next...yet there is still tremendous amounts of character growth from beginning to end.I won't throw in any absurd spoilers here (maybe some minor ones), but when the show begins, it looks to really be skirting off the coattails of Breaking Bad's success.  Nacho Varga (Michael Mando) makes a very quick appearance, and just the whole look/feel/vibe of the show screams "BB nostalgia!".  By the third episode, however, the show turns into Jimmy's quest to change from "Slippin' Jimmy" to a respectable lawyer.  Just as soon as that has happened, the show takes an abrupt aside to focus on Mike for an entire episode before its back to Jimmy & Co.  Towards the end, more time is given to Jimmy's strange relationship with brother Chuck, female friend Kim, and a potentially new career path that could offer him some legitimacy...if he chooses to fully embrace it.Suffice it to say, this show shifts gears quicker than Slippin' Jimmy himself can concoct another rip-off scheme!  I can honestly say I've never seen a show cover so much ground (and diverse ground at that) in the span of just 10 episodes.  The plots/scenarios of the show play on a very interesting dynamic: even though the viewers know exactly who/what "Jimmy" will become, we tend to forget that while we are watching because the stories/characters are so engrossing.  Just when we (as viewers) think we have everything "figured out", however, we are always reminded that we know exactly how this Jimmy character is going to turn out.  So, the show really taps into two distinct emotional areas: The one where we WANT Jimmy to do something, and the one where we KNOW he is going to do something...the question just being "when?"Yet, despite all the praise I have heaped on the show so far, I can't give it the full five stars for this opening campaign for one main reason: I really just don't know what I am watching yet.  It's like each episode is a non sequitur.  A very entertaining non sequitur, to be sure, but just all over the map in terms of plot from episode to episode.  Like I said previously, I've never watched a show like this before...one in which I enjoy it each week but can't quite put my finger on how/why.Putting things into perspective, though, I actually thought that "Better Call Saul" had a more intriguing initial season than its cousin "Breaking Bad" (which I felt took a whole season and a half to really find the base of the characters).  This show does it in the opening scene of the opening episode...tight from the word "go".  I enjoyed each and every episode, and will be waiting patiently until the next installment of Jimmy McGill's inevitable journey towards Saul Goodman.

In COOTIES, Elijah Wood plays a wannabe-writer from New York named Clint. Forced by failure to move back in with his mom (THE OFFICE's Kate Flannery in a criminally-underused cameo) in his hometown of Fort Chicken, Clint turns to substitute teaching to pick up the slack until he can finish (and hopefully sell) his horror novel about a demonic boat. On his first day on the job, he meets a bevy of kooky coworkers as well as a school full of obnoxious kids who get even more unmanageable once they eat some tainted chicken nuggets and start turning into blood-thirsty zombies.Penned by horror-vet Leigh Wannell (SAW, INSIDIOUS), this film relies pretty heavily on its central image -- fed-up teachers clobbering pre-teens with savage abandon -- for both its horror and its comedy. It works well at the start, but when the second and third acts fail to build on the premise in any interesting way, the movie starts to drag. There are a few plot points that suggest the movie wants to be more than just a slaughterfest, including a love triangle, a microscopic subplot about how kids are over-medicated, and lots of talk about how the nugget virus works and can be stopped, but nothing comes of this. There are a few hurdles for the teachers to overcome here and there, including finding cell phones and food for a character with diabetes, but these obstacles feel like half-hearted attempts to disguise the fact that the movie doesn't know where it wants to go with itself. In fact, a conclusion never really gels, and the movie seems to end before the story does.This is most evident in our characters, none of whom really change or grow, existing mostly as uninspired stereotypes. This is a shame, since the cast list is pretty impressive, including Rainn Wilson as a Dwight Schrute-ish gym teacher, Jack McBrayer as Jack McBrayer, Jorge Garcia as a shroom-loving security guard, and Matt Jones as an unfortunate police officer. Because none of them are asked to move the plot forward, the characters are basically one-note jokes that get repeated over and over, including Clint's pretentious obsession with his writing (in lieu of teaching his kids, he has them read his book aloud and give him notes), Jack's possible homosexuality (his lines exist primarily as double entendres), and Jorge's movie-long shroom trip. Even the love triangle that builds through the second act is quickly abandoned in favor of moving the film to a new location, not so that the story can build, but simply so we can watch the characters battle zombie kids in a new, creepier location.It's a shame that so little work went into the writing, because so much more work clearly went into everything else. Our set pieces are pretty great, as is the music. And the cinematography is A+ quality, starting from the opening credits sequence which films chicken nuggets being made with a gorgeous sumptuousness that is at odds with its glistening nastiness. The gore, also, is plentiful and effective, even more so when you consider that much of it is sold by child actors. Unfortunately, like the bulk of its cast, the tale itself feels underfed and like it wasn't given the chance to mature into a story that's worth telling. Any opportunity to give the flick more backbone -- whether by making a point about kids and Ritalin and teachers' poor wages, or by amping the stakes with the death of a central character -- is squandered in favor of showing more bloody battles with the kids. These turn out to be decently entertaining, but -- without clear stakes or the driving tension of a good story -- they fail to be terribly interesting or memorable.

PROM RIDE tells the story of eight teens who are on their way to prom when their stretch limo is hijacked by a mysterious assailant who is intent on torturing the young couples for some unknown reason. It is the kind of movie that looks like it was filmed over a weekend and then edited overnight. There is a critical problem with the pacing, but that might be due to the writing, which is juvenile and uneven.Claiming to have been "inspired by TRUE events," the film skitters back and forth between footage from smartphone video and more traditionally cinematic shots. Neither one works that well, but combined they way they are, so haphazardly and thoughtlessly, they bring out the worst in each other. They also make the padding in the film (of which there is a lot), a lot more obvious and mind-numbing. This includes a stupid beach prank, a really dumb five-minute musical dance number in a clothing store, and lots and lots of shots of people dressing or admiring the stretch limo or just generally being high schoolers on their way to prom.Normally, this is where the character development and exposition would be located, but there's not a lot of depth to our story or its players, and the only stuff of substance that we get is a tidbit about a couple that's saving their virginity for prom night and a (obligatory?) make-out scene with two girls. There's more mindless prattle and some drunken montage-ry before the limo ride finally goes south.It doesn't go that south, though. Ludicrous implausibilities abound, and even if your disbelief is light enough to be that easily suspended, the "horrors" that take place in the limo are so poorly choreographed and filmed that they are laughable. One "fight" that occurs consists of one character punching another character over and over for about three minutes, and it is so poorly acted, directed, lit, and edited that it comes across as an overlong joke.Only three real things of any note happen in this movie, and like everything else, they happen with a sort of half-hearted, lackadaisical care, like everyone on set was on ambien or maybe thought they were just doing a rehearsal run-through without realizing the cameras were actually rolling. I don't know that more energy would've saved things, although it might have made the film a bit more vibrant and maybe would've detracted from the abysmal performance that nearly every actor turns in (although, interestingly, the kids do a better job than the adults; the parents at the beginning and the cops at the end tied for first place as the worst performers of the film).Dull story. Dull execution. Dull everything. If you and your buddies like to watch bad films and make fun of them, you might have something here to work with, but overall, this is just another bland and lifeless product of our over-saturated media landscape. Technology has made filming movies easier than ever before, and as a result, the internet is now bloated with thousands and thousands of flicks just like this one: movies that people make just because they can, without ever really stopping to ask themselves if they should.

STUNG follows the swarm-horror formula so closely that its predictability almost becomes a reminder of why that formula exists to begin with. This means it's not necessarily a bad film, but it's also not a terribly memorable one. Since it expends enough energy (and not a drop more) to toe that line, if you're a genre fan, you'll enjoy it about as much as you make up your mind to.The film is populated by convincing caricatures. We have Paul, the clownish lead male, a man-child with a hero's heart, and  his boss/love interest, Jessica, a woman with daddy/control issues. Jessica runs a catering business that is working a wedding on a large estate owned by a spoiled/bitter rich kid toiling under mommy's ancient thumb. Include a token cougar, a ne'er-do-well mayor, and a Latino maid (among other similarly shallow archetypes), and you have a nice crowd of people ready to be mowed down by our resident evil: in this case, a swarm of wasps that have developed mutations as the result of some hastily-explained chemicals.Although there are some disappointingly-shaky CGI sequences, the film also relies on some satisfying PFX for more than a few scenes. The acting is decent, even considering the rather sparse character development found in the script, and the gore is plentiful. The film excels mostly at its pacing, spacing the action so perfectly that audiences aren't allowed too much time to dwell on how derivative it all is. At least until the ending.As with most formulaic films, STUNG is (ultimately) about a man who wins a woman. Even though it tries to give Julia a personality and her own, personal arc, really she exists mainly to be the reward for when Paul manages to subvert his own goof-off persona and find the moxie in him to save the day (or does he?). Although the movie shows shades and tones of something that wants to be nastier, sloppier, and wilder than the formula it follows (this includes the flick's final shot), it ultimately boils down to the same, basic wish-fulfillment that a lot of horror (and all other genre) films are based on: a guy doing what it takes to finally win the girl, right down to a head-shakingly ludicrous sex scene that owes a lot to early Bond films.This might have worked more had the previous 80 minutes been more clearly satirical. Clearly fun was had and almost no one involved (from the writer to the director and his cast) took any of it too seriously, but they also didn't try as hard to subvert the formula as they did to follow it. Expertly tongue-in-cheek (almost to a fault), the film would have benefited more if it had stuck that tongue between its lips and had blown a big fat raspberry right at the audience, instead of giving it exactly what it expected.

The story behind CREEP is simple. Aaron (Patrick Brice) is a filmmaker who needs some extra cash, so he agrees to go to a cabin in the woods (natch) to meet Josef (Duplass). Dying of a brain tumor, Josef hires Aaron to film him during the day so as to leave a video will of sorts to his unborn child. During the course of the filming, Aaron begins to realize that there is something off about Josef. Maybe it's the brain tumor. Maybe it's something else.Although the movie is not long (at 77 minutes, it's more a short than a feature), only about three or four events occur in the whole thing. This makes the movie seem longer than it really is, and not so much in a good way. The audience is kept on its toes by what are clearly two unreliable narrators, but the "what's true and what's not?" aspect of things only holds water as long as we care or are interested in the characters. However, whatever sympathy is elicited by Aaron and whatever curiosity is elicited by Josef quickly starts to wane as the movie progresses without many actual events or contextualizing reality. Just like our lead character, the movie seems to be 99% talk, which is rarely creepy in and of itself.Fortunately, Duplass (notable for approaching filmmaking the way water approaches its lowest point: via the path of least resistance), low-key to a fault, has enough weird charm in his eyes to keep the movie from being a total exercise in self-indulgence (part of me wondered if the idea for the movie wasn't kickstarted by people telling Duplass that he sometimes makes them feel uneasy). Plus, the setting of the woods gives us enough uncertainty that the mere possibility of something happening is tantalizing enough for a bit. However, when the film moves to other locales, it starts to feel forced and aimless and hastily improvised. By the time we get to our legitimately creepy ending, it feels like the climax of very little actual rising action.While it does want to be scary (or at least unsettling), the movie is also trying to skewer found footage horror in a number of ways. Take, for instance, the jump scare, when something non-scary happens in a loud and sudden way so as to make you jump in your seat. This is a common (and very annoying) trope for horror movies in general. As Aaron films, Josef constantly jumps out and yells "boo!" to try to scare him. In fact, he does it so much that it is clearly their way of mocking the trope. However, it's also -- cleverly, I'd say -- a way of retooling the trope so that it IS scary (creepy, I mean) that this guy keeps doing it. In other words, it takes something not scary and makes it scary in a different way.This is what makes it hard not to like CREEP. It's trying to do the same old thing in new, inventive ways. It is, unfortunately, doing it without also having much in the way of a story to build on. As a result, the talent behind and in front of the lens feels formless and flat, and it is used to tell a tale that doesn't even seem to know where it's going until it finally appears to stumble across its own conclusion.

A year and a half ago, I reviewed a film called SORORITY PARTY MASSACRE. I expected it to be a bad movie, but in a cheesy, fun kind of way. The movie WAS bad, but in a bad way. It had very little of anything you'd expect from a film with that title.GIRL HOUSE delivers pretty much everything I expected from that first movie, and does so in a strong, competent way. The film follows a secluded house that is wired to the gills with cameras as a sort of Big Brother-ish version of a porno webcam show that runs 24/7. The girls who live in the building are visible at almost all times to the horn dogs who subscribe to the site to switch around between cams in bedrooms, bathrooms, and showers. You can even watch the ladies watch TV with curlers in their hair and skin cream slathered on their faces, if you're into that sort of thing. One of the subscribers, however, has a less than healthy interest in the ladies and this leads to a full on assault on the house, where we see just how hot-blooded these ladies really are.There is a nearly non-stop stream of T&A, and when the bad guy gets going, the movie goes full-tilt into gory slasher territory with no hesitation or apology. The makers of this film know exactly what its audience wants and it gives it to them. Unfortunately, it also never once attempts to be creative, nuanced, or unique in the least. The dialogue is rote and predictable. The characters are all one note. Even the title is about as uncreative as it is possible to be. My wife and I kept trying to figure out what the movie's twist would be only to discover that there is no twist. For once, what you see is exactly what you get. I'm not saying that's necessarily bad, but I am saying it's lazy and results in a film that's fairly forgettable.Or kind of. Unfortunately, the film does two things that lowered my rating for it. The first is it overtly compares itself to Hitchcock's REAR WINDOW. Although there are some obvious parallels -- people around the world watching the massacre on the webcams are unable to stop the killer -- the comparison is not very flattering, at least to anyone who has seen Hitchcock's far superior film and gets the winking joke in the script. Also, the movie is more than a little preachy about online webcam porn, the women who provide it and the men who consume it. The message is very clear: the writer does not approve. The girls who are killed are some of the vainest, most vapid characters put on screen, and the girl who survives is described over and over as "the wholesome" type, "not the kind to normally do this sort of thing," and is the only one you never really see naked.This is hypocritical in a film that draws much of its audience with the explicit promise of plenty of nudity, capitalizing on the very thing it's not-so-subtly pooh-poohing. "Here are some super sexy ladies without their clothes," it seems to say. "Now lets kill them all for being so slutty." It's kind of dizzying.Competent in nearly every other way (even if it never aspires above mediocrity), the film should satisfy the basic urge of any classic slasher lover, even if it does so with an edge that could use a little sharpening.

For a movie that gives away its twist on its poster, I-LIVED takes a long time to get to its point. The film follows Josh, an over-educated and under-employed 20-something who wants to make a living reviewing cell phone apps. (I said he was over-educated, not smart.) He reviews an app called called I-Lived that promises to help you achieve any goal that you input into it as long as you successfully do the missions that it provides for you. I'm not giving anything away (unfortunately) by revealing that the app was actually created by the devil, and that when you agree to the terms and conditions (without reading them, natch), you are essentially selling your soul.Since the poster and trailer both give away the "secret" of the film, the burden of the entertainment lies on the story, acting, and directing, all of which fall short in one way or another.Big problem here: our lead is extremely unlikeable. It's hard to pinpoint what's more to blame, the way he's written, acted, or directed. Perhaps it's a combination of all three. When he's reviewing apps, he behaves with a choppy, frenetic, cartoonish goofiness that rapidly grates. When he's disappointed by his life, he's flat, dull and featureless. When he's scared, he mostly looks confused. When it becomes clear that his life and his (ill-gotten) achievements are at risk by supernatural forces, it's hard to care since he doesn't really demonstrate any traits worth rooting for. Halfway through the film, seemingly out of nowhere, he starts to worry about his cancerous mother's health, but this feels like a half-hearted ploy to rig sympathy that was shoved into the script at the last minute. He also has an ex-girlfriend that is meant to provide him with sympathy, but in her only scene, she is so poorly acted and written that she feels like some kind of absurd joke character.The directing is off, since the film can't decide if it wants to be goofy, dark, otherworldly, or truly terrifying. There's the sense that maybe they wanted to blend all of those elements together, but they aren't blended even a little bit. As a result, the movie shifts tones often, making it hard to get into any kind of groove with the plot. This includes an abrupt ending and a brief, on-the-nose speech by the apps designer himself in a scene with a visual gag that's shoved in your face -- for laughs or chills, I have no clue.The overall story has the potential for some serious juice, even if it is very clearly a rip-off of Stephen King's NEEDFUL THINGS, just updated for the modern techno-age. It's just too bad that the people involved didn't try harder to find unique places in the tale to go to instead of taking the easy route with nearly every scare or plot point. This is evident even in the title, which has the "e" spelled backwards in case you are the dumbest of the dumb and can't figure out that "lived," spelled backwards, is "devil" (because Satan's marketing department stinks).

In THE JOKESTERS, a group of guys called the Prankmasters (famous on YouTube for their prank videos) decide to throw one last big prank on a member of their crew who is getting married. The synopsis (written by the screenwriter/lead actor, Nathan Reid) calls it a "Cabin in the Woods" prank that goes "so well that it actually becomes The Cabin in the Woods horror in real life."If you're a first-time filmmaker, it's generally wise to avoid mentioning in your script or promotional materials other, far superior films. It invites comparisons that are rarely flattering.This very short film (it's barely 80 minutes long) spends the bulk of its time following the Prankmasters (why is the film called THE JOKESTERS and not THE PRANKMASTERS?) as they do pranks, ruin Ethan's wedding, and generally treat each other like crap. You have Ethan (the hot one who's getting married), Chris (the one who sometimes speaks in Spanish), and Andrew (the one who is not the other two). The fourth member of their crew, Nick, is by far the most obnoxious. Scriptwriter Nathan Reid plays him with an unrelenting juvenile abandon that quickly annoys everyone around him. That includes me.For a movie that classifies itself as found footage horror, there is very little of that promised terror. It takes 55 minutes for anything remotely interesting to happen, during which we are treated to a series of pranks that include things like ripping off a girl's top and then running away, locking the car when someone gets out to pee by the side of the road, and putting a two-day-old jockstrap on a friend's face. (I'm surprised no one gets a phallus drawn on their forehead.) This hour is clearly meant to provide us with character development, but the script obviously doesn't know what constitutes "development." There are a few plot points dropped here and there, but mostly the story just spins its wheels. There's a hint at a gay subplot that could've made the movie a little more unique if not interesting, but this is quickly abandoned.The final twenty minutes of the movie are a hasty, scattershot mess with two very heavily foreshadowed twists. Perhaps hoping to make up for the glacial pace of the previous hour, the last act of the film is unnecessarily rushed (especially considering that the movie doesn't even have the run time of what most would consider a feature film). Although we are treated to some decent effects and shots (for an indie), they are cobbled together with so little awareness of pacing that they play like a highlight reel, like the editor got tired of trying to tell a story and just slapped together all the creepiest scenes that they filmed without adding any of the connective tissue that would make it interesting or coherent.There's a clear stab at a possible sequel, including a segment where a news reporter (a friend of the bride from the aforementioned wedding) learns on-air about the Cabin in the Woods horror that (possibly?) claimed the lives of her friends. (I'm pretty sure television reporters preview the stories they're going to read and don't just wing it live.) The same reporter also -- in one of the laziest tropes a screenwriter can employ -- delivers a big chunk of parting exposition (the kind of stuff that should've been salted into the first hour of the movie) to justify the choppy mess you just watched.If the last quarter of the film had been stretched out to form the bulk of the film, and if the twists and turns had been more skillfully employed, and if the character development had been actual development, even if the pranks had been more creative or the jokes less childish, this might have been worth the viewing. As it is, the only thing genre fans might get a kick out of is the fairly liberal T&A (and that includes of the male variety, in case you're into that sort of thing).

Say hello to the flirty apron! What makes it "flirty"? Well, wouldn't YOU like to know! *wink, wink*Um.Okay, so not much. In fact, this thing is only "flirty" as long as the wearer is naked underneath. However, that applies to all aprons, when you think about it. Ditto with neckties, bowler hats, and bibs.Wait. Not bibs. I take that back. Flirty bib? Yuck.Anyway, the flirty apron. It's a nice modern design for an old timey garment and the long ties make it truly a one-size-fits all, but that's really all that helps this thing stand-out from any other "non-flirty" apron. Maybe if it said something flirty on it, like "Guess what's cooking?" or "Is that a spatula in your apron or are you just happy to see me?"Wait. That last one doesn't work on the apron. It only works for someone interacting with an apron-wearing guy. Forget I wrote that one.Man. I really screwed this review up.

This is an interesting little doodad. Interesting, but not terribly useful.Let's start with the logistics of using the thing. You are meant to use the device anywhere that you experience acne. This is to be done for 3-4 minutes per application, twice a day. After a 6-8 week treatment period, you move into maintenance. Maintenance is 3-4 minutes per application, twice a week total. The booklet says to expect possible redness and irritation upon initially using the device, but my redness never lasted very long.The device works by emitting blue light and exposing your skin to heat. According to the literature that came with it, Blue's light and heat combo work by breaking down the bacteria in the pores that are the culprits behind acne and other blemishes. Realistically, the device seems meant primarily for those people who have chronic acne but only in spots. If you have chronic acne all over, using this device as directed would require hours. Even someone with just average acne problems is probably going to need half an hour (if not more) for a full session.It's also not a good device for use on or next to the nose. When I get blemishes, they're usually in that crease between the cheek and the nostril.  Applying Blue there means smooshing your nose to the side and hoping that the blemish is getting enough of the light and heat. Blue is also not designed for spot treatment.  When I have a blemish pop up here or there, it's usually gone within the week, especially if I apply some benzoyl peroxide. With a 6-8 week treatment period, Blue doesn't seem like the proper tool for eradicating spontaneous, short-lived zits. That means that when all is said and done, this tool is a reasonable purchase only if you have chronic acne that affects just a few small, easily reached areas.There are also a few technical issues with the device. When you turn it on, you must wait for the green light to indicate that it's ready, and then you press it against an affected area. Upon contact with your skin, the blue lights illuminate and the head gradually heats up. After the 3-4 minutes, you move the wand to another spot. Once it loses contact with your skin, the lights and heat are meant to turn off. However, frequently the lights remained on after lifting the device off my skin. At least once every couple of days, I had to turn it off and back on. Less frequently, the lights would not come on at all.  A quick power-cycle fixed that for a time.Although it seemed to work as directed (more or less), it's hard for me to recommend the device. First of all, I can't guarantee that my blemishes went away because of the device or just due to natural causes. For me, zits don't stick around long unless I pick at them, so the ones that faded away on my face may have done so because it was just time. Secondly, the amount of time one is required to spend holding a heated light to your skin is pretty problematic unless you were already planning to spend the next half hour or more sitting around doing nothing. Therefore, I recommend you try out Blue only if you have one or more of the following:1. Chronic acne that occurs in very small patches;2. Overly-sensitive skin that reacts badly to chemicals like benzoyl peroxide and salicylic acid; or3. A ton of free time to use Blue on larger acne-prone areas

This product is made primarily for hikers and outdoorsy types. I live in Seoul, and outdoorsy situations don't come around quite so often or last quite that long when they do. So caveat: most of my experience with this bag is for general use than for those who are interested in taking this thing for a day out in Mother nature.Pros:Like most Kelly backpacks, this thing is very lightweight. I've seen IKEA catalogs that have weighed more.You can't have a backpack like this without having numerous pockets of all sizes. The external hydration pocket is huge. The largest camelpak pouch should fit easily.Strap storage. All the straps come with attached elastic bands to keep the excess neatly out of the way.Action pocket. Cool little holder for your phone with a hole for camera. Also detaches and can be used as an easel. As others have noted, this doesn't work with some newer models of phones, though.Cons:Definitely designed for backpacking and camping. This is not the pack for carrying textbooks or documents.Rigid internal spine. Probably effective when needing to maintain good posture with a full pack on a long hike. Not so good (uncomfortable) to toss in a few essentials for a day at the park with the kiddos or even just errands in town.

I didn't know who Jude was when I purchased this book, and you don't really need to in order to enjoy the stories. His tone and voice is much stronger and more mature than you'd expect from the person portrayed in the pages. Autobiographical almost to a fault, this collection of true tales pretty much deals exclusively with drugs, sex, and (maybe you'd call it) love. The lens for each story is unflinching and unclouded, and our narrator is guilelessly straightforward about his thoughts, experiences, and general level of depravity and dismay.The biggest flaw with the book is that the stories get repetitive after awhile. If they aren't about him doing drugs and/or having sex, they're about his family or his longing for the One That Got (Thrown?) Away. Each piece is beautifully written and achingly sincere, but the themes blur into one long, monotone landscape after awhile. The force of his honesty starts to lose its edge when you read about the same basic confessions over and over. He has a knack for analyzing his mistakes and self without coming across as preachy or self-pitying, which is amazing actually and keeps the tales moving without ever growing too stale, but in retrospect it feels like some of the pieces could've been eliminated or joined together to avoid blunting their energy with repetition.Minor quibbles for what is one of the best story collections I've read in a long time. Beware: these tales are about as X-rated as they get without crossing over into full-out smut.

BIG TIME is a crass, off-kilter comedy drama about two oblivious wanna-be filmmakers who are better at creating trouble than actual movies. When their parents threaten to kick them out of the house, they go to extreme lengths to figure out a solution. Needless to say, they tend only to make things worse.Saying much more would ruin the enjoyably twisted and convoluted story line. Like a lot of shows these days (It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia comes immediately to mind), this one features obnoxious idiots as our protagonists, but they are portrayed by a couple of charming guys with great timing. They're also surrounded by a lot of great talent, including some new faces (John Bass as Del is perfect and seamless) and some old (Cuba Gooding, Jr. as you've never seen him before).The story gets very dark very fast, but it moves with such snappy precision (and is so elegantly contrived) that it's hard not to be impressed. It keeps itself and viewers on their toes, so the grim tone never gets too heavy to handle, unless you get a little squeamish at the sight of blood. If you don't mind a little gore and enjoy a good dark comedy, BIG TIME is among the best out there right now. A parody of a self-obsessed generation that lacks self-awareness (among other things), the show is even brilliant at times, but enjoyable regardless if you have the brainwave for that kind of stuff or not.

Considering its Olive Garden budget, TIME LAPSE manages to execute its intriguing premise with some impressive skill. Unfortunately, significant elements of the script come across as juvenile or half-formed, resulting in a viewing experience that is half-awe and half-scoffs. Or maybe a little more of one than the other.The story is about apartment manager Finn, a budding artist who shares an apartment with his girlfriend, Callie, and his pill-popping buddy, Jasper. One day, they discover that a tenant has died, leaving behind a camera that can take pictures of the future. Once the friends find the photos and start trying to figure them out, things quickly spiral out of control. Are they causing the pictures to happen, or is it the other way around? Are we in charge of our fate? Which came first: the future or our picture of it?The bare bones of the story are pretty interesting and worth a good post-film conversation with anyone who's got the patience for time-paradox discussions. The problem is that the film's idea of conflict is pretty adolescent. Although the movie focuses mostly on our three leads (almost aggressively so, including a weirdly-framed shot at a party where every single person is dancing with their backs to the camera except Finn, Callie, and Jasper), it tosses in a violent bookie to amp up the stakes. The problem is that the bookie is not a very threatening guy (I'd lay money that his beard is glued on), and the paranoia and chaos that results from his introduction to the film makes very little sense. A lot of explanations for this might lie in the fact that Jasper is constantly doing drugs, but even this is portrayed in a half-baked way: Jasper carries around a metal case that is filled with a random assortment of pills of all shapes, colors, and sizes, and he ingests them and shares them with others without seeming to distinguish between which pill is which, like they all do the same thing even though they're clearly different. This is like what a prepubescent kid might imagine when they think of a guy who's addicted to pills. It just smacks of laziness and/or ignorance, which is a shame, since the actual plotting of the film clearly took some time and brains.While the whole film may not add up to the sum of its parts (there's much that's lukewarm, including the acting, set design, and even the title), and while there is a level of immaturity to the film's general idea of reality, the philosophical thrust of the story and the nuts and bolts of its timeline (as well as its small handful of secrets and twists) are pretty satisfying overall. You take what you can get: I enjoyed the film when all was said and done, but I have a hard time recommending it to anyone who doesn't already have a lot of free time on their hands.

I'll admit: I have a soft spot for Vince Vaughn. He's done a lot of stinkers at this point, but I've never disliked him or his performances. His problem these days seems to be that he's got no quality control on what scripts he chooses to do. Consider UNFINISHED BUSINESS, a film that feels very much like it, too, is unfinished. The script concerns a salesman named Trunkman (Vaughn) who is sick of getting jerked around by his boss, so he leaves to start his own company with two other workers. A year later, and he's still searching for that one elusive deal that will legitimize his business. His last chance, it seems, is in Germany, where he and his coworkers go to get the handshake that will ensure their success.There are a lot of weird gaps here. The actual mechanics of the business deal are vague to the point of irritation, and when it is mentioned, it's a clutter of businessy-sounding words that don't mean anything. All viewers are guaranteed is that Vaughn's business has "better numbers," so it deserves the deal more. This is a surprise, because Trunkman's company isn't really a crack team. Wilkinson plays a downtrodden man who is afraid of his hideous wife and Franco is Mike Pancake, a guy who may or may not be mentally handicapped. The character comes close to being seriously annoying (some might even say offensive) except that Franco does such a poor and uninteresting job of portraying him.Everything a comedic script is supposed to have locked down -- conflict, pacing, jokes -- feels vacant and tired. Every gag is more like a set-up of a gag than anything else, so that when Trunkman unwittingly finds himself having a conversation with a glory hole, you wait for the punchline or the pay-off but to no avail. That's the whole joke: he's talking to a guy in a glory hole. Character development happens the same way. Trunkman has issues with his kids that are crammed into the script so awkwardly, it feels very much like they were a second thought that was hastily scribbled in by a last-minute script doctor.As charming and Vince-Vaughn-ish as ever, Vaughn does his best to sell the material, but it's just too weak to work on any level.

First of all, if you enjoyed the first MAD MAX, then you'll almost certainly enjoy this one. It's got the same heart, drive, and attitude as the original without being a carbon copy of it. Mad props to George Miller, the man who wrote and directed all of the films. His dry, tribal vision of the apocalypse remains as solid and gripping as ever. (It's hard to believe nearly every non-Max film he's done has involved cute, CGI animals prancing around.)Second of all, if you've never seen any of the Max films, know that they are exercises in Showing, Not Telling. One of the most common rules of scriptwriting is that the less dialogue, the better, since that means more is being communicated by the drama and visual aspect, which are the two most important components of a film. I've never seen the script for FURY ROAD, but it wouldn't surprise me if dialogue composed no more than 10-15% of it. The tale here -- of rebellion, redemption, and revenge -- is what amounts to three long action sequences strung together with a cobweb of exposition.The majority of non-stop action films are dull because they confuse activity with action, filling the screen with energy, fire, and violence as a substitute for story. These grow tedious to watch, since the movies spend so much time on the speeding cars, fight scenes, and explosions that they leave no time to convince viewers that we should care about who's in those cars, fights, or flames. FURY ROAD carefully crafts its sequences so that they are as much about the character and story as they are about giving viewers something cool to look at. Not that there's nothing cool to look at; you've probably already heard about the flame-throwing guitar.That makes it sound over-the-top, and it is, but in a way that makes you want to redefine where the "top" is. This future is heavily stylized (FURY ROAD LESSON #38: After the apocalypse, everyone's eyes will look AMAZING) but the sureness of its story-telling and the quiet (for the most part) confidence of our characters keeps it from seeming cartoonish. This is quite a feat, as anyone knows who's ever tried to explain the plot in depth to anyone.Some fans have complained that this film's cast is saturated with female protagonists. As a result, our title character is forced to share a big chunk of his spotlight with others, notably Theron's Furiosa. If this is the sort of thing you think you might take issue with, you might not enjoy this film. Also, I feel sorry for you. No characters are extraneous, and whatever politics you think you can ascribe to the cast's heavy supply of estrogen, it's still never turned up nearly half as loud as the frenetic artistry that surrounds it and propels it forward. Although this is a serious movie, it is clearly designed not to be taken that seriously, so if you find yourself bristling at implied politics (the film contains hints at class warfare and wealth distribution), maybe you should take a step back and focus on that flame-throwing guitar for a second.A film that sets a specific goal for itself and accomplishes it perfectly, MAD MAX sets the bar for the rest of this summer's inevitable deluge of action blockbusters.

It's been over a decade since this was released, but I recently had to go back through some old music, and when I rediscovered this gem, I figured I'd add my voice of praise to the mix.I won't go into the mixed expectations that haunted Sneaker Pimps after the success of BECOMING X and the (according to some) mixed love of SPLINTER. I will say that, even as a shift in gears from their previous stellar offerings, BLOODSPORT is an excellent album. It's a record that is mixed and mastered with authority and a certain level of maturity, but that's written and composed with a lot of dark, playful energy. I'd argue there isn't a bad track in the whole thing. Even the songs that are stand-outs vary depending on who you're talking to. Some reviewers praise "Loretta Young Silks" as their favorite, but I like it the least (without actually disliking it). I prefer the grim propulsion of "The Fuel" and the chaotic beauty of "Think Harder." Still, I don't think there's a misstep in the whole line-up.A strong, sometimes-raucous, often-beautiful, and intriguingly complex album, BLOODSPORT mingles songs of melancholy and praise into a set of imminently listenable electro pop.

THE LAZARUS EFFECT is a horror/thriller that squanders an intriguing premise on cheap scares and shoddy plotting. It seems sometimes to be missing some connective tissue in the dialogue or editing that would give the story more flow, which makes it feel a lot longer than its lean 82-minute run time would suggest. My guess is this thing was chopped to shreds in post-production. Whatever the cuts were supposed to improve, I'd say it didn't work.The story is nothing new. A group of scientists have developed a serum that can revive a dead brain. Any seasoned horror movie fan knows that when a film is about bringing creatures back from the dead, inevitably something supernatural is brought back with them. This movie is notable, at least, for blurring the lines between science and spirituality. When our leading lady is brought back from the dead, she's not the same, but it's unclear whether the change is chemical or demonic. In fact, for an intriguing moment, the movie seems poised to argue that there's a way it can be both, but then it devolves into dumb, predictable slasher-y territory.This might have worked better had the rest of the film been a bit more interesting, but this nifty twist on an old trope is surrounded by a lot of cliched window dressing, including a canned "You're playing God" speech as well as a shadowy corporation that suddenly threatens to take the research for no good reason. There's also a lot of stuff that is stupid or nonsensical, such as scientists taking home a test animal that they just revived from the dead and living with it like it's their normal pet dog. At one point, the elevators stop working and the characters announce that they are trapped in the building, even though there is clearly a sign next to the elevators that tells people to use the stairs in an emergency.At least we have a decent cast that tries hard (for the most part). Olivia Wilde does her best as our revived leading lady (a plot point that is revealed in every trailer but which still takes nearly half of the movie to happen), and Ray Wise is a nice treat in a brief cameo. Unfortunately, our leading man, Mark Duplass is a cold fish for the bulk of the film. Duplass has never met a scene he couldn't underact, and although that serves him well in his mumblecore romantic dramas and quirky indie flicks, it's a huge detriment in a film where he's supposed to act terrified for his life or devastated by the death of a loved one. He could've been wearing a plastic mask of his face over his real face and his performance would be 99% the same.It sets out with a cool idea, but this movie quickly dies, and no amount of demonic black eyes and spilled blood is able to bring it back to life.

It's nearly impossible to watch or talk about this film without being reminded of PULP FICTION, a movie that's inspired so many cheap knock-offs that it's kinda baffling that it's still going on over two decades later. How is it like PULP FICTION? Well, we have a fractured timeline that proposes to tell three intertwining tales of murder, revenge, and ill-fated romance. The flick attempts to punctuate its straight-faced humor with cavalier violence, and even has a character who wears a black suit, is an "expert" at dealing with assassinations and murderous situations, and is (shamelessly, I'd say) named Wolfe. As our characters' fates intertwine in complicated ways, the movie even tries to throw in some light-hearted kookiness, like a woman who accidentally hits her husband with a car or a killer who stops in mid-murder to answer his cellphone. These things are played as jokes, but they come across as half-formed and derivative, as does the rest of the film.The biggest difference between this movie and PULP FICTION (and the biggest reason why this film fails), is that the characters are uninteresting, one-note caricatures who never once do anything to earn our sympathy or attention. Even the abused wife who is the subject of our central assassination fails to strike a note of empathy since we never learn anything about her as an individual with a personality. Everyone is like this, a watered-down version of a real human being who dutifully fulfills their stereotype without ever adding a dash of flair or panache. Likewise, the script rests on its loopy knot of a plot without ever attempting any moments rich with suspense, drama, mystery, or any of the other things that make a film, you know, fun to watch. Instead, scenes are stitched together with overlong musical interludes (the same surf-noir song seemed to play non-stop throughout the film whenever no one was speaking), and gaps in logic are never even partially addressed (biggest example: a character with a massive and life-threatening gambling debt never considers selling his palatial, shore-side home, which could clearly pay his arrears ten times over).It's dull. It's derivative. It barely knows what it's doing. Killing it once would be too good for it.

Spare, smart, and sharp, EX MACHINA is a strongly-directed thought experiment on A.I. and humanity's ever-growing reliance on (and susceptibility to) technology. Nathan, a brilliant-and-reclusive tech billionaire, invites Caleb, one of his lowly programmers, to his personal estate to test the humanity of his latest invention, a robot named Ava. Nathan says Caleb's job is to give Ava a Turing test (a test designed to tell if a computer has true intelligence or just simulated intelligence), but as secrets and trust-issues and lies start to build, the real story turns out to be more complicated than that.With just three characters (okay, let's call it 3.5), the movie feels a bit like a stage play, right down to its pacing, action, and set design/staging. People without much love for sci-fi (especially for its more cerebral varieties) might find themselves running out of patience with the film. Maybe wanting to give audiences time to really process the implications of the story, the flick moves at a leisurely pace. It's not slow -- not a single shot of the film is wasted -- but it is a little indulgent at times, especially when the soundtrack takes over for the dialogue.It's also impressive just how fantastic everything looks considering the relatively small size of the budget. Add in the understated acting and weighty/economical scripting, and you've got an excellent sci-fi parable. Some might hanker for a bit more action or excitement (a la Blade Runner, perhaps). When you look back on it, there's not a whole lot of actual meat on the bones of the plot. But the ideas presented by the story are plenty enough to chew on for viewers with the interest in sifting through them.

PROJECT ALMANAC is a found-footage, time travel film that wastes everything cool about its premise on predictably cheesy high school drama. Here's all I'll say about the found-footage aspect of the movie: it was completely unnecessary and -- given the way certain scenes are shot -- the movie is well aware of that fact.David is a brilliant inventor (and the son of one, too), who can't afford to go to MIT. By chance (I'm skipping a lot here), he discovers a time machine in his basement. It's not humming and ready to go, though, and he and his brainy friends spend the first hour of the movie trying to get the thing into working condition. Meanwhile, David's sister films literally everything that happens, and David occasionally pines from afar for the beautiful Jessie, his longtime crush.One flaw with the film right away is that the producers cast a guy who looks like a professional model, making his geeky awkwardness around Jessie really hard to believe. Even his friends mention his fantastic "bone structure." I'm sure that was supposed to be a wink at the very thing I'm complaining about, but it seems lazier and less effective than casting a guy who, you know, looks like he would have trouble with girls. Still, I can ignore this for the most part. After all, looks don't automatically make you charming.However, it's really hard to ignore the massive plot holes that form when the movie tries to be philosophical or even just funny. After an overly long build-up, when the kids finally figure out how to use the machine, they use it -- of course -- to change the past. There are some cool segments where we see some of the effects of the time travel, including the danger of deleting yourself from existence, but none of these rules are adhered to very well by the script. It passes over its own logic in an attempt to be heartfelt. Scenes aren't designed to make sense so much as they are to fill you with laughter, longing, or a vicarious thrill as the teens go back in time to pass failed tests, attend Lollapalooza, or even to woo one another.Maybe if I cared more about teens passing tests, attending Lollapalooza, or successfully flirting with one another, I'd have enjoyed this part of the film more. Unfortunately, our two leads are so attractive and so clearly designed to end up together, that their romantic subplot never did it for me. Neither did our two buddy characters, who were pretty much interchangeable. Although the film takes a cool and clever approach to setting up its time traveling reality, it gets stale and kind of childish with its second act. The options for a movie like this are pretty vast, but this one chose to oversimplify in favor of a few low-hanging ideas.The final lesson of the film is a good one, in spite of the pedestrian way it was told. More odd logical loops show up to tantalize us with the close of the film, but they don't entice so much as confuse. It's normal for a time travel film to have a few loose ends or contradictions, but it's also normal for those things to be at least brushed past or disguised. This movie turns one of its largest plot holes into its last parting shot for the audience, which takes all of the oomph out of the story's real ending.Even all of this would be forgivable if the film wasn't nearly 110 minutes long and didn't spend the first half of that trying to prove it has an above-average brainwave. It takes so long for it to establish its own rules that when it inevitably breaks some of them, the effect is annoying, made even more so by how frustratingly close the whole movie comes to being truly entertaining.

There's a lot of extremely flattering praise on the back of this book. Ken Wilbur, for instance, glowingly says that author "DeHaven is either a thinking man's Tucker Max, or an idiot's Hunter S. Thompson." Who is Wilbur? No clue. The blurb says he's got a PhD and works for California's Marketing Magazine Journal, but that's not a lot of help. If he's the Kenneth C. Wilbur of the website of the same name, then I'd argue his opinion doesn't carry a lot of weight.The blurb that really caught my eye and convinced me to read the book, though, was by a man named Michael Scripps, who declares that "DeHaven makes Bukowski look like a Disney writer!" This is a pretty bold statement to make, especially since the only Michael Scripps I could unearth anywhere online is a convicted felon serving time for stealing over three million dollars from his own mother.That might be the joke. After all, this book is all about blurring the line between fiction and reality. The book's forward claims that "this is a true story." The idea is that DeHaven was bamboozled by a free-lance self-help writer named Michael Enzo. To get back at Enzo, DeHaven published this collection of some of Enzo's journal entries. There is even a brief and tepid Twitter war between the two writers, although it's not very convincing.The book is not so much a novel as it is a collection of short stories, most of them about Enzo's life "on the razor's edge." Because they don't really connect in any meaningful way, it's hard to maintain interest in anything that happens. It also makes it harder to get a bead on Enzo himself, and what the whole point is other than to very, very, very lamely mimic Bukowski's darkest protagonists, right down to the gambling, alcoholism, sex, and self-loathing.The tepid mimicry (maybe you'd call it an homage) isn't the book's biggest problem. Because it pretends to be about someone who writes self-help books, there's a great chance to see the blurry borders between how we live our lives versus the lessons we learn from it. But DeHaven isn't really interested in exploring that. Instead, the book is a series of uninteresting tales about being in the Boy Scouts, dating a porn star, and stealing cars to pay back gambling debts, the whole lackluster mess peppered with inspirational quotes that you might find in self-help books scrawled in the margins. It's hard, even here, to tell how serious the book is trying to be, because most of the marginalia is the worst kind of meaningless profundity. "Life is a series of lies that wind up on the cutting room floor," is one of the worst of the lot.The stories also have these constant narrative digressions that are meant to be chummy in a kind of absurdist way, making a sliver of a joke's worth of sense in an attempt to come across as familiar and friendly. But really, it just reads like forced posturing, not the least because none of it is nearly as funny or clever as it thinks it is. Mostly it just makes you furrow your brow and think, "Wha?" For example, here he describes the car he drives: "This particular model was from the only year Plymouth made the Neon before the marketing giant Dodge bought them in a close-out deal worthy of the main character in PRETTY WOMAN (not the hooker), if only there were some gerbils involved. Oh Dick, you silly bastard."The final nail in the coffin is that the prose is so inconsistent. It can't decide if it wants to have the dismissive jokiness of a frat boy, the hard boiled grittiness of a Bukowski-type loser, or the faux-insightful intelligence of a philosopher. At best, this kind of fluctuation is just annoying or disorienting, but at its worst, it creates moments of cringe-inducing awfulness. Much like the self-help quotes and the jokes, oftentimes they make absolutely no sense even if they sound like they should. Here's an example: "The sun induces a reflective state of mind and has a sobering effect. Especially when it looks in your bloodshot eyes and pounds jealousy in your heart, its misdirected envy toward the moon pouring in briefly to smash your soul."Actually, that line there is pretty much indicative of the whole book. It sounds like it wants to be pretty, meaningful, unique and even kind of vicious, but it's none of those things. It's just a tortured, meaningless mess that is a chore to slog through. I'd rather read an actual self-help book.

Is your bathroom a debris field of loose toothbrushes, crumpled tubes of toothpaste, and massive webs of unorganized floss? Do you constantly catch yourself muttering, "Now where on Earth did I put that stupid water pick?" When you go to do your oral ablutions, is your sink so cluttered that you grasp comically at your hair and say stuff like, "If only there was a better way!"I thought so.Well, bemoan no more, because here comes the InterDesign Med Plus Dental Center! It's plastic! It's clear! It has four slottish-type areas for toothbrushes or other long items, like pencils, if you're the type to write a lot of bathroom memos. It has a larger section for larger things, like tubes of toothbrush, or tubes of other things, like anti-fungal cream or rolled up memo pads. Plus, since it's plastic, it's easy to clean and will never, ever biodegrade, so that you can pass it down to your children, and your children's children, and your children's children's children. As long as humans exist that long and don't evolve away their teeth in favor of, I don't know, acidic cheek pouches.And guess what? This baby is yours for just eleven bucks. That's right! For the price of a pack of cigarettes or a ticket to see the matinee showing of Teen Sex Comedy #5,409, you can finally clear all of the mostly unavoidable chaos that your bathroom is bound to be in.Or you can, I don't know, use like a drinking cup or something instead. For free. And call it a "dental center."The choice is yours.

Names are tricky. Long ones are good if you're a royal dignitary or an essay by David Foster Wallace. Short ones are good if you're a recreational drug or a child's doll. This item is called the "Turtle Beach Ear Force Stealth 400 Premium Fully Wireless Gaming Headset For Playstation Blah-blah-blabbity-blah." I get that this is a use-specific set of headphones, but still. Having a name that won't fit on a typical Twitter message is a sign that maybe you're pigeon-holing yourself. Or trying too hard. Or not enough?Not that these are bad headphones. They come pre-charged, so you can use them immediately (who likes waiting?). Also, they've got a pretty impressive range. They worked up to 50 feet away in a signal-heavy environment (these particular items were tested in a TV studio). They've got nice sound, packing a great bass level, and it's a snap to cycle through it's various EQ settings with just one button. (This, granted, might be a flaw for people who prefer to fine-tune their own levels rather than put up with pre-set standards.)The headphones' wireless audio lasted for over fifteen hours, which is what I would call a marathon gaming session, although some players might just call that "Monday." The headsets also had distinct controls to set game and chat volumes, as well as a removable headset mic. And they appear to be compatible with almost any device with a headphone jack. That's nice.But problems? Yeah, there are a few.-- The documentation says that the headphones and the transmitter are already linked up, but they were not in my case. It took me ten tries using the instructions to sync the devices. You'd think this part would be automatic.-- There aren't readily noticeable indicators for which side is Left or Right. I mean, one side is saddle-bagged with all of the controls, but that's not a dead giveaway. After much searching, I found discreet L and R letters on the inside of the headphone arch, which is kind of a counter-intuitive place to put them.-- Be prepared to feel like an airstrip with the nonstop blinking lights. I thought the blinking signaled that the headphones were syncing, but they never stopped blinking. At first, it wasn't such a big deal, but if you're the type of person to wear them for a long period of time (i.e. any serious gamer), you might start to get annoyed by the constant flashing. I can only imagine the chaos that might be caused by a whole room of epileptic gamers wearing these things. The hilarious, hilarious chaos.-- The headphones have some seriously annoying Siri-voice feedback that is constantly telling me what I already know. "Powering on" the voice says as I turn them on. "Bass Boost" the voice announces when I turn on the bass boost. What possible reason could there be for this function? Are there really gamers out there who need this kind of validation? "I know I turned it on, but it would be nice to hear a disembodied voice remind me that I did. You know, for the heck of it." It wouldn't be so bad if you could turn it down or off, but -- worst. idea. ever. -- this stupid voice is not only unavoidable, but it completely mutes all other audio while it talks to you. What this means is that every time you perform even the most mundane of functions, you risk missing important audio from the game you're playing.-- CLICK! If you turn off the headphones, get ready for an eardrum shattering CLICK! Because who doesn't want to be aurally thumped in the ear when you're done playing?

Everyone knows that babies are usually up to no good and cannot be trusted. This is why they must constantly be monitored. But there are so many options out there for worried parents who need to spy on their babies. How does this particular device stack up? I sent this to my brother who has a particularly mischievous baby girl and asked him to tell me how well it enabled him to keep tabs on his child. Here's what he had to say:PROS:-- The device is light and compact, making it easy to cram into tight places or conceal in nooks and crannies. The baby will not know it is being watched.-- It is remarkably easy to set up and use. Even the most idiotic of parents could figure it out, provided they haven't swallowed it first. It is very small, as I said.-- You can link up to four cameras to one monitor, all of which can be cycled through with ease.-- You can take your baby's temperature with it. Hot babies, as we all know, are the most dangerous of babies. The only catch is it must be used as directed: by placing it a 1/2 inch from the baby's head. This may be difficult if your baby is recalcitrant or anti-authoritarian. It is still easier than jamming a thermometer into one of the baby's orifices, though. It is also handy for gauging the temperatures of any other liquids you wish to subject your baby to. You know what I'm talking about.-- It's got pretty good color resolution for its size, and when the lights get low, the camera switches to an infrared night mode! Ha ha! Take that, baby! No sneaking around at night and getting into monkey shines and other subversive activities. My brother said this was handy for all types of night surveillance, not just those related to suspicious babies.-- The device claims to work from up to 500 feet away, but that is only true if there are no walls or obstructions between the camera and monitor. So, you'd have to live in a bowling alley or something. However, my brother said it worked fine up to 100 feet away with six intervening walls, so in an average house, it should be just fine. Unless you live in a mansion and/or wish to sleep very, very far from your baby, in which case, your problems are greater than what kind of monitor to buy.-- You can not only hear what's going on near the camera, but you can also respond with a microphone on your end. This is in case you wish to speak to your baby, but cannot be bothered to pause whatever Saw movie you are in the middle of watching. The sound quality makes you sound like a principal announcing the lunch menu at a grade school, but this will prepare the baby for the drudgery of school that is soon to come.-- There are many helpful accessories, including a stand, belt clip, and even a light bar that indicates the volume of the sound near the camera. This is in case you are sick of your baby's constant pleading and wish to turn down the volume during polite dinner functions or meetings, but still need to know if the baby's screaming continues unabated. Or if the baby has gotten hold of a power saw or something.-- The batteries last for a long time as long as you are not constantly checking the monitor, which goes into standby mode after a long period of having no buttons pressed. The listed power life is 3 hours, but my brother timed it at a little over 7 hours.
